column1: Data Supplied By: National Livestock Reporting Service
Data source: National Livestock Reporting Service
Please see terms of use here: https://www.mla.com.au/general/Terms-and-conditions/data-and-information/

Yardings increased to 1,888 head at Charters Towers this week, with a large gallery of buyers present and active. An excellent draft of big lines of northern prime cows and bullocks were supported by a good draft of store cattle, resulting in an increase in values across all categories on last sale. All regular buyers were in attendance, accompanied by two live export buyers, a southern meatworks buyer and central store buyer. Cattle were drawn from Burketown, Normanton, Richmond, Pentland, Cape River, Woodstock, local and coastal areas.  

Greater supply of vealer steers were keenly contested within the buying gallery, with many lines pushing values above last sale, topping at 320c/kg.  A large line of northern yearling steers attracted strong interest among western restockers, selling consistently above 265c, to top at 300c/kg. Vealer heifers were of mixed quality, however, sold strongly to several restockers, to top at 274c, with many pens selling above 245c/kg.  Yearling heifers were dominated by one larger line of northern bred cattle which sold to 254c/kg, mainly to a central feeder buyer.

An excellent selection of 3 score bullocks attracted strong buyer interest, selling strongly throughout to both live export and processor buyers, to top at 264c, while 2 score bullocks sold to 258c/kg to live export. A larger yarding of 3 score cows to slaughter increased by 9 to 13c on last sale, topping at 213c, with 2 score cows similar, selling to 202c, and averaging 188c/kg. Cows to restockers sold to 179c, with many lines selling from 165 to 172c/kg. Prime heifers were well supplied and sold to higher rates to top at 240c for slaughter types, while heifers to restockers sold to 205c and averaged 196c/kg. Heavy slaughter bulls sold to a top of 219c, while live export buying increased values for medium weight bulls, topping at 246c/kg. A small number of cows and calves sold to $950/unit.

With the local district still suffering from the dry seasonal conditions, numbers remained relatively similar to the last sale. Contained in the market were 338 store and 105 prime cattle. Generally there was a slight improvement in quality; however there was very few large lines presented for sale. With only one major processor and several local butchers and restockers operating, prices suffered the same fate as other markets averaging on a cheaper trend.

The majority of the grown steers were under 400kg, and they sold to a top of 131.2c to average at 123.4c, which was 5c/kg cheaper. Medium and heavy weights sold to 135c, while bullocks reached 135.2c/kg.

Grown heifers were of 2 and 3 score and averaged in the early 110c/kg mark. Cows were generally of lightweight with 2 scores topping at 116.2c and 3 scores at 121.2c/kg. There were only a couple of bulls and they reached 105.2c/kg.

With the last sale two weeks ago numbers lifted greatly for a plainer yarding of cattle. The largest percentages by far were the cow categories with most weights and grades represented. Steers were only represented with fair numbers with the heifer portion very scarce in the pens. All the regular buyers competed.

Steers were mainly medium weights with the better quality drafts trading from 147.2c to 163.2c/kg. Heavy pens sold from 149.2c to 158.2c with most sales around the 155.7c/kg.

Cows were mainly light and medium weights with only a few pens of heavies yarded. The better quality lightweights sold from 89.2c to 126.2c/kg. Medium and heavy pens traded from 100.2c to 135.2c/kg. Bulls mainly held their firm prices with the best topping at 132.2c/kg.

With the absence of further rain events and public holidays, Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents yarded 1,731 cattle this week, the largest yarding in over 6 weeks as the mustering season begins. The offering of cows was quite good with some very good heavy and extra heavy cows on offer along with some very good quality bullocks, while store cattle were of mixed quality with some good lines on offer. Two regular processors and feeder buyers were absent, however the processors in attendance were selective in their participation, as was the sparing gallery of restockers and backgrounders. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Forasyth, Greenvale, Tully, Ingham, Mingela, Balfes Creek, Belyando, local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers were generally good quality however met limited buyer interest, topping at 298c for lighter types to average 280c, while young steer calves sold to 304c/kg. With the absence of live export feeder orders, the demand for yearling steers was absent. Yearling steers comprised of several small lines and considerable variation in quality, with better bred 280-330kg lines selling to 284c for those returning to grass, while those above 330kg sold to 262c/kg. Vealer heifers were generally good quality and also met limited buyer demand. Light vealer heifers affected by dry conditions sold to 196c, while better grown vealers to grass sold to 254c to average 217c/kg. Yearling heifers sold firm on the recent intermittent sales topping at 224c for those of joinable weight, while lighter types returning to grass sold to 222c, averaging 219c/kg. Grown heifers to slaughter sold to 246c, averaging 239c, up by nearly 20c/kg on the last notable sale.

A very mixed consignment of bullocks sold according to quality with best 3 score heavy bullocks to slaughter topping at 266c, to average 261c, with lighter 2 score bullocks reaching 259c/kg. Several small lines of 2 score bullocks returned to grass for 241c, while one live exporter secured suitable bullocks to 251c/kg. Heavy grown steers to slaughter sold to 261c, with some very good crossbred types returning to grass for 251c/kg. The increased supply of good heavy cows met subdued demand from processors, with the best extra heavy 3 and 4 score cows topping at 217c/kg. Heavy C muscled 3 score cows to processors made to 215c, easing by up to 14c to average 207c, and D muscled heavy 3 score cows sold to 210c to average 198c/kg. Heavy C muscled 2 score cows also to slaughter topped at 205c to average 196c/kg and D muscled cows of similar weight average 181c, with medium weight averaging 165c/kg. Several small lines to restockers sold to 151c to average 135c/kg. A good supply of bulls met keen competition, with heavy bulls to live export selling to 269c, with most sales above 260c, while a small number to slaughter sold to 256c/kg. A southern backgrounder paid to 263c for lighter 2 score bulls, while light weight males to restockers sold to 248c/kg. One very good line of young cows and calves sold to $1,225/unit.

With temperatures falling, numbers fell by more than 900 for a total yarding of 1592 head for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, with quality across all lines showing more variability. Reduced numbers of heavy prime cattle saw prices ease by 2 to 4c for cows, while bullocks lifted 1 to 2c/kg. One major processor was absent this week, with all other regular processors, feeder buyers and restockers active throughout the sale along with one live exporter.

A similar number of vealer steers to last sale attracted mixed buyer interest selling to 380c/kg for lighter weights. One large line of northern yearling steers attracted strong interest, with most sold to feed, to 318c/kg, for an average of 298c, while lighter weight steers returning to grass sold to 354c/kg. A good line of heavier yearling steers returning to grass sold to 325c/kg. Steers destined for live export sold to 296c, to average 286c/kg. A small number of vealer heifers was on offer with values easing 10 to 14c, topping at 290c/kg, with quality and weight variable. Yearling heifers were of mixed quality and condition with one large northern line attracting strong interest from both feeders and restockers. Heifers to feed sold to 276c to average 265c/kg, while those above 280 kg returning to grass sold to 274c, to average 263c/kg.

A small number of bullocks of variable quality and weight sold to mixed demand with bullocks to live export sold from 285c to 281c/kg, and bullocks of lesser quality and weight to feed destined for live export made to 272c/kg. Some grown steers to live export sold to 295c/kg. A very mixed quality yarding of cows saw values ease, particularly lower yielding heavy cows, 3 score cows sold to 240c, to average 218c, while heavy 2 score cows sold to 217c, to average 204c/kg. Lighter 1 and 2 score cows to slaughter lifted 3 to 7c, topping at 205c, to average 186c/kg. Bulls maintained the trend of recent strong sales, with heavy bulls to slaughter topping at 266c to average 261c, while heavy bulls destined for live export sold to 286c, with sales mainly falling between 274 and 279c/kg. Medium weight bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 318c, to average 292c/kg. One very good line of cows and calves sold for $1720/unit.

With some useful rain across many areas and the forecast of further rain, numbers increased by more than 900 for a yarding of 2495 cattle.  Quality was mixed, comprising of some large northern lines, an increased supply of heavy bullocks and cows, supported by several mixed lines of store steers and heifers. All regular processors were in attendance and operating at stronger rates, along with one feeder and opportunity feeders, backgrounders and restockers. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Normanton, Georgetown, Prairie, local and coastal areas.

Increased demand saw solid gains for heavy, better quality processor types with grown steers and heifers to processors lifting 20-40c, cows averaged 11-26c better, heavy bulls improved 15c to 20c/kg.

Limited numbers of young steers to restockers sold to 266c to average 246c, similar heifers to processors made to 240c to average 234c/kg. Yearling steers were of mixed quality and sold accordingly. Steers above 280kg to feed reached 262c to average 225c, while steers above 330kg sold to 292c to average 250c to 279c/kg. Yearling heifers above 200kg to processors sold to 252c, averaging 233c, while a good sample above 280kg to processors averaged 232c/kg. Heifers of good quality above 330kg to feed made to 284c to average 263c/kg.  Grown steers above 400kg to the trade averaged 268c to 277c selling to 310c, heavy steers reached 314c/kg. A good sample of heavy prime grown heifers made to 292c averaging 263c to 286c/kg.

An increased supply of heavy bullocks to export slaughter topped at 330c, most sales from 304c to 324c /kg. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors averaged 221c to 234c, selling to 256c, 3 score cows reached 276c multiple times to average 247c to 271c/kg. A good sample of prime heavyweight cows topped at 282c to average 277c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors sold from 230c to 262c/kg.

A good supply of cows and calves sold to $1,250/unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

With some light rain around, numbers fell by 145 head to 1223 cattle. Quality was mixed, comprising of some good lines of prime cows and feeder steers, supported by many small mixed quality lines. All regular processors operated at stronger rates, supported by one live exporter and several opportunity feeder operators. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa to Normanton, Coen, and south to the local area.

Most categories improved in price with firm demand for most lines, however light heifers and secondary cattle were difficult to sell. Prime cattle improved by 10c to 40c/kg.

Yearling steers above 280kg to feed sold to 228c to average 182c and a good sample above 330kg to feed averaged 244c  reaching a top of 252c/kg. Yearling heifers above 330kg reached 218c, best quality heifers to the trade made to 232c. Grown steers to live export reached 240c to average 231c, steers to the trade sold to 236c to average 227c/kg. Steers to feed sold to 220c to average 158c/kg. A good sample of grown heifers to the trade made to 198c, most averaging 186c to 192c/kg. 

A very small number of bullocks sold to 256c to average 240c/kg. Lightweight 2 score cows to processors sold to 172c to average 145c, medium weight 3 score cows sold to 220c to average 180c, a small number of prime heavyweight cows made to 218c/kg.  Medium weight feeder bulls to live export sold to 258c, heavy bulls to processors reached 238c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

With rain and storms forecast across much of the north in coming days, 2,806 cattle were penned in a combined Prime and Store Sale. Quality was very good with some large lines of local grown steers and bullocks along with some good small lines of heavy prime cows. Several younger store lines showed the effect of the dry season. The regular buyer panel was in attendance and operated at stronger rates on many lines. Grown steers were firm to 10c dearer, bullocks eased up to 10c, heavy cows to processors were firm to 7c dearer and bulls improved by up to 20c/kg. Cattle were drawn from Julia Ck, Georgetown, Greenvale, Pentland, Hervey’s Range, Ingham, local and coastal areas. 

Light steer calves to restockers sold to 728c and heifer calves reached 642c/kg. Isolated single vealer steers above 200kg returning to grass reached 750c with most averaging 650c/kg. A good sample of vealer heifers less than 200kg returning to grass topped at 638c to average 572c/kg. Yearling steers above 280kg to backgrounders sold to 524c and steers to feed sold from 480c to 522c/kg. A good sample of yearling heifers above 280kg returning to grass topped at 558c to average 505c and similar heifers to feed above 280kg averaged 480c/kg. Heifers above 330kg to feed also sold to 468c to average 450c/kg. Heavy heifers to feed above 400kg sold to 476c/kg to average the same.

Grown steers were of very good quality with some large lines attracting strong demand and selling to a dearer trend. A large sample of steers above 400kg to feed sold to 494c to average 463c and similar types to the trade sold to 442c to average 418c/kg. Heavy steers to the trade topped at 442c to average from 412c to 436c/kg. A good line of grain-fed steers topped at 448c to average 440c/kg. A reduced supply of good quality heavy grown heifers to the trade sold to 370c, while a small sample of grown heifers to feed averaged 395c/kg.

A good number of 3 score heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 438c multiple times to average from 421c to 436c, while 4 scores sold for 442c/kg. Processor demand for cows continues to be very strong. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 392c to average 377c and 3 scores reached 386c to average 374c/kg. A small sample of prime heavy weight cows topped at 396c multiple times to average from 390c to 393c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors sold to 364c to average 358c, with increased numbers to feed selling to 422c to average between 351c and 377c/kg. Young males returning to the paddock sold to 720c to average from 610c to 708c/kg.

Good quality cows and calves sold from $1,700 to $2,850/unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

With no sale last week due to insufficient numbers, agents this week penned 1046 cattle.  Quality was good for most lines with some very secondary types in the bulls.  Only three regular processors were operating, supported by most regular feeders, one live exporter and some enthusiastic restockers.  Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa to Georgetown and south to the Belyando.

Light steers and heifers improved 17c to 23c on the back of active restockers, yearling heifers to feed improved 20c to 35c, heavy bullocks lifted 3c and prime cows averaged 3c lower.

Light vealer steers returning to the paddock averaged 264, sales to 274c, similar heifers reached 160c/kg. Yearling steers above 200kg made to 224c as did steers above 330kg, while steers to feed averaged 177c/kg. Yearling heifers above 330kg to feed sold 148 to average 136c/kg.

A good sample of grown steers above 400kg to live export topped at 190c, steers to feed averaged 165c and heavy grown steers to processors made to 160c to average 154c/kg. A small offering of grown heifers to the trade sold to 174c to average 157c/kg.  

Soft demand for heavy full mouthed bullocks saw those export slaughter topping at 162c averaging from 148c to 157c/kg. A smaller offering of medium weight 3 score cows reached 156c multiple times to average 135c, those to restockers averaged 130c/kg.  
Heavy bulls to live export topped at 208c to average 203c, processor types averaged 150c to 160c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

With no sale for over a month there was only a small yarding offered. 

Medium weight steers reached a top of 129.2c/kg, with D2 lighter weights selling to 110.2c/kg.

Grown heifers sold to 130c/kg, while cows under 400kg reached a top of 130.2c/kg. Medium weight bulls sold to 138.2c/kg.

With much of the industry focussed on Beef Week, the supply of cattle reduced significantly on last week, with 1122 cattle penned in a combined prime and store sale. Quality was variable with a smaller offering of heavy prime cattle, however there were some good lines of store steers and heifers.  Buyer representation was limited to two processors, one live exporter and opportunity feeders, backgrounders and restockers.  Cattle were drawn from as far west as Boulia to Mt Isa, Normanton Georgetown and the local area.

The limited demand saw values ease across most categories, with quality a factor, however prime lightweight cows, and best quality store steers improved by 10c to 16c on last sale. 

Best quality yearling steers above 280kg returning to the paddock averaged 221c, selling to 284c, steers above 330kg averaged 276c/kg. Steers above 330kg to feed averaged 234c/kg. A limited supply of yearling heifers sold relative to quality - a small sample above 330kg to the trade made 208c/kg. 
Many small lines of grown steers met limited demand, single sales of trade types made to 238c, ranging from 228c to 234c/kg.  A limited sample of grown heifers to the trade reached 232c to average 198c/kg. 

There was only a small offering of heavy bullocks for export slaughter, making to 234c to average 230c/kg. Lights weight score cows to processors sold to 180c to average 168, medium weight 3 score cows sold to 210c to average 189c, a small number of prime heavyweight cows topped at 218c/kg.
Bulls above 280kg to live export reached 244c to average 222c, heavy bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 222c to average from 183c to 209c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

With isolated storms in the region and many producers hanging onto the forecast for rain, numbers fell dramatically to 393 cattle for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week. Prime cattle contributed to the majority of the yarding, with store cattle too few to quote. Three of the four major processors were in attendance and operating, while the remainder of the buying gallery were restockers and onlookers. Cattle were drawn from Greenvale, Ingham, Belyando, local and coastal areas.

Vealers were absent from this week's sale and there were insufficient heifers to quote. Some yearling steers sold to 298c/kg to restockers. Some good lines of mostly well finished 3 score bullocks to slaughter sold to 255c/kg.

Grown steers 2 and 3 score attracted strong restocker interest, selling to 267c, to average 260c/kg. Well finished 3 score cows sold to slaughter and topped at 216c/kg, averaging 211c, while 2 score cows to slaughter sold to 197c, to average 191c/kg. The small number of bulls to slaughter sold to 230c/kg. A small number of cows and calves sold to $1,400/unit.

With isolated storms across the north and local area and the potential of further rain in the coming week, numbers declined by more than 1,300 head for a yarding of 520 cattle for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, comprising of mostly store steers and heifers. The absence of significant lines of cattle were a factor in the reduced offering, along with a recent contraction of values across many classes of cattle. The lack of prime cattle only saw one processor operating, however the return of one feeder buyer accompanied by local restockers and backgrounders ensured most store values were firm to dearer on last sale. Cattle comprised of one line of northern steers, with several smaller lines on offer. Cattle were drawn from Normanton, Einasleigh, Townsville, Mt Coolon and local areas. Light weight vealer steers to restockers improved 5c on last week, while similar light weight yearling steers to restockers eased  by 11c/kg. Yearling steers over 280kg to restockers eased 8c, however similar steers to feed increased up to 27c/kg, with most destined for live export. Yearling steers over 330kg returning to paddock sold firm, to average 258c/kg. Light weight heifers increased up to 8c, while a selection of better quality yearling heifers to feed improved by more than 35c/kg on last sale. A limited offering of heavy 2 score cows to processing sold firm on the previous fortnight, while 2 score cows to restockers sold firm on last sale. 

Light vealer steers sold to 280c, to average 271c, while the heavier types averaged 263c/kg. Light yearling steers to restockers topped at 266c, to average 250c, while steers over 280kg averaged 246c, with similar steers to feed averaging 237c/kg. Steers over 330kg returning to grass sold to 266c, to average 258c/kg. Young light weight heifers returning to the paddock sold to 224c, to average 197c, while better bred lines of yearling heifers to feed made to 216c, to average 175c/kg. 

A single pen of heavy 2 score bullocks made 232c/kg. Grown heifers to processors sold to 151c, and heifers to feed sold to 138c/kg. Heavy 2 score cows to processors made to 162c, averaging 157c, while lighter 2 score cows to restockers averaged 154c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export sold to 238c/kg, while good conditioned cows with weanable calves sold to $1,020/unit.

With cool temperatures and rain in the local area, 340 excellent quality prime cattle were offered at the annual Northern Beef Expo Cattle Show and Sale in Charters Towers. Two regular processors and three live exporters operated at increase rates on many lines of high yielding prime bullocks, cows and domestic steers and heifers. Cattle were drawn from Torrens Ck, Mt Surprise, Bowen, Belyando and local areas. Several lines of young cattle were not offered for auction.

A small number of steers calves for sale improved 5c and heavy milk tooth steers and heavy yearling steers to live export improved by up to 25c/kg on regular weekly rates. Yearling heifers to domestic processors displayed improved quality and weight, increasing by up to 40c/kg. Heavy export bullocks to processors sold 20c better, with heavy bullocks and steers increasing by up to 15c/kg. Extra heavy export cows improved by up to 16c/kg.

Steer calves sold to 269c and young steers above 400kg to live export made to 258c to average 252c and heavy yearling steers made to 290c to average 287c/kg. Yearling heifers to slaughter reached 255c to average 243c/kg. Heavy bullocks to processors made to 289c multiple times, while grown steers to live export made to 294c to average 290c/kg. Extra heavy 3 score cows sold to 193c to average 187c, and 4 score cows sold to 190c to average 188c/kg.

With around 25mm of rain in most of the supply area, a smaller yarding was offered. All the regular buyers were present and active Quality was similar to previous sales with a handful of good steers and bullocks included in the line up. 

Most of the light steers averaged around 112.3c after selling to 120.2c as the plainer lines averaged from 89.8c to 97.5c/kg. The better medium weights reached 143.2c as a large number of heavy steers averaged 147.1c/kg. The top of the heavy bullocks made to 154.2c/kg. 

Light export heifers made to 118c as the E2s averaged 86.3c/kg. A fair number of light and medium weight cows were offered. Light D2s sold to 102.2c as leaner lines averaged 85.1c/kg. Good medium weights reached 112.2c/kg.

With an uncertain wet season and delayed start to the year, a yarding of 1,332 cattle were drawn by Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, with some good lines of bullocks, cows and store cattle on offer.  One of the major processors was notably absent, along with a seasonal processor and regular feeder buyers, while restockers were intermittent and a buyer for live export was present. Reduced values were seen across most classes, compared to the final sale of 2016, particularly in the prime cows.

Some very good vealer steers sold to strong demand, particularly lighter types, topping at 388c/kg, with most sales around 370c, and heavier types averaged 352c/kg. Yearling steers sold to 364c to restockers, averaging 345c, while steers to a live export backgrounder sold to 324c, averaging 316c/kg. Vealer heifers were of mixed quality and sold strongly to restockers to top at 352c, averaging 343c, while yearling heifers sold to 302c to average 298c/kg.

Some well finished 3 score bullocks sold to 289c to processors and 274c to restockers while plainer bullocks to feed sold to 245c/kg. Some well finished cows sold to mixed processor demand, with heavy 3 score cows topping at 253c, averaging 221c, while heavy 2 score cows sold to 227c to average 215c/kg. Medium weight 1 and 2 score cows to processors sold to 216c to average 204c/kg. A very good number of well finished heifers to slaughter sold to 263c to average 251c, while restockers paid to 258c to average 250c/kg. A small number of heavy bulls sold to 245c to processors, while medium weight bulls to feed, destined for live export sold to 322c/kg. Young males to restockers sold to 388c/kg. Mixed numbers of cows and calves sold to $1,440/unit.

With agents undecided if a sale will be held next week, a much smaller yarding was offered. Quality was generally plain with only a handful of finished steers offered. Scattered storms across the supply area have been well received with further falls forecast for the coming days provide hope for many producers. Cattle were drawn from the local areas as well as a mixed draft from the Northern Territory. 

Medium weight C3 steers in small numbers averaged 173.2c after selling to 174.2c/kg. The plainer D2s averaged 142.4c/kg. Most cows offered were leaner 2 scores with lightweights averaging 128.7c and medium weights averaging 133.7c/kg. Young light cows topped at 150.2c/kg. For the size of the yarding, a fair number of bulls were offered with lean medium weights averaging 121c/kg.

With a poor seasonal outlook, numbers increased on previous sale to 2,825 cattle for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, with good numbers of well finished bullocks and cows being presented. With one major processor absent, competition for processor cattle was strong throughout, with prices easing in line with processor grids. Buyers in the store section were represented by a couple of feeder buyers and backgrounders for live export, supported by several restockers, albeit at lower values than previous sale. Cattle were drawn from Prairie, Mt Garnet, Innisfail, Ingham, Ayr, Ravenswood, Belyando, Balfes Creek, local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers showed signs of the light season averaging 8c lower to a top of 364c/kg. Yearling steers returning to paddocks sold to 341c, to average 324c/kg. Vealer heifers were in good supply, selling to lower rates than previous sale, with some good lines presented in very good condition. Light heifers to restockers sold to 296c, while yearling heifers to feed sold to 274c/kg. Yearling heifers to restockers sold to 303c to average 271c, while some good PTIC heifers sold to 278c/kg. Some well finished 3 and 4 score bullocks to slaughter sold to 270c multiple times to average 261c, while 2 score bullocks to restockers sold to 271c, averaging 259c/kg. Heavy steers to slaughter sold to 260c/kg. 

Some large lines of well finished 3 and 4 score cows sold up to 15c lower than the previous sale, topping at 238c, to average 210c/kg. 2 score cows to slaughter sold to solid demand to 205c, to average 195c/kg. Some good lines of heavy heifers sold to 241c, averaging 234c/kg. Heavy bulls sold to 228c, while medium weight bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 220c/kg. Some good lines of cows and calves sold to $1,350/unit.

Widespread storm rain across much of the north and west resulted in a large decrease in the supply of cattle to 654 head, 1973 fewer than last sale.  Quality was very mixed, with only a few pens of genuine heavy prime cattle, while store steers and heifers consisted of several small lines. Only one processor was in attendance with all regular processors and feeder buyers absent due to the small yarding. Opportunity local feeders and restockers were the most active at reduced rates.  Cattle consisted of far western cattle held prior to the rain event, supported by several small local lines.

Good quality lightweight steers sold to 564.2c to averaging 423c to 456c and similar heifers to opportunity restockers made to 402.2c to average 360c/kg.  A small sample of good quality yearling steers to feed averaged 348c reaching to 356c, while a small selection of yearling heifers returning to the paddock sold to 326c to average 273c/kg.

Limited numbers of grown steers to feed destined for live export sold to 346.2c to average 336c to 346c/kg.  There were insufficient grown heifers to reliably quote.  Single bullock sales made to 322c/kg.  A small selection of prime cows to processors made to 290.2c to average  273c/kg.

Heavy bulls to processors sold to 282.2c to average 249c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Widespread rain over the past fortnight resulted in a smaller yarding of 565 cattle. The mixed quality consisted of some good pens of heavy cows, supported by several small lines of store steers and heifers.  Demand was solid throughout with three regular processors operating, supported by two live exporters, one central backgrounder along with opportunity traders and local restockers. Cattle were drawn from Richmond and east to the local area.

A small sample of suitably weaned steers returning to grass averaged 310c selling to 318c, similar heifers to backgrounders made to 288c/kg. Yearling steers above 330kg to live export reached 301c, most selling from 266c to 288c/kg. Yearling heifers above 280kg to restockers reached 268c to average 265c, processor types sold to 258c to average 233c/kg.

A small offering of grown steers to live export sold to 292c to average 288c,  well finished steers to processors averaged 286c/kg. Heavy grown heifers to processors reached 256c to average 254c/ kg.

A very small sample of heavy bullocks to processors topped at 300c to average 293c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows  made to 238c to average 221c to 229c and prime heavyweight cows also reached 238c to average 237c/kg.  Heavy bulls to processors averaged 272c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Widespread rain across the region over the past week impacted supply with 2204 cattle yarded, 1926 fewer than last sale.  Quality was mixed with two large lines of northern pastoral cattle, supported by small lines of prime cows and some good quality young steers and heifers.  A reduced number of processors were present and operating, however feeder, backgrounder and restocker buyers were active throughout the sale.  Cattle were drawn from vast northern and western regions, local and coastal areas.  Grown steers and heifers improved 9-17c, prime cows lifted 10-12c and heavy bulls increased by 9c/kg.

Light steer calves to restockers sold to 552.2c with mixed sexes averaging 487c, while heifer calves to the trade sold for 422c/kg.  Good quality vealer steer returning to the paddock reached 487c to average 432-464c and heifers to the trade reached 404c to average 361-391c/kg.  A small sample of yearling steers to live export reached 400c, steers below 280kg to backgrounders topped at 420.2c to average 411c and steers above 330kg to feed reached 416.2c to average above 408c/kg.  Yearling heifers to feed reached 376.2c to average same and trade types made to 372.2c/kg and average 357-369c/kg.

Grown steers to live export sold to 388c, steers to feed reached 372.2c, averaging 358-362c and a small sample returning to grass averaged 363c/kg.  An increased supply of good quality grown heifers to the trade sold to 360.2c to average 326-349c and similar heifers to feed averaged 341-350c/kg.  A limited supply of full mouthed bullocks to export slaughter mostly sold from 342-350.2c/kg.  Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 274.2c to average 270c and 3 score cows reached 286.2c to average 276c/kg.  Prime heavyweight cows topped at 288.2c to average 283-286c/kg.  Heavy bulls to background feed destined for live export sold to 350.2c to average 326-344c and medium weight bulls to live export made from 358-408c/kg.  A good sample of bulls  from 280-350kg to feed averaged 377c/kg and a large sample of young males returning to grass topped at 550.2c to average 406-477c/kg.

Mixed quality small lines of cows and calves sold to $1,700/unit.

Widespread rain across the north and west reduced numbers by more than 750 in a combined prime and store sale with 686 cattle penned. Quality was very mixed, featuring three lines of northern cattle and one from the southern part of the supply area. There were less than 200 cows penned with most cattle lacking weight and offered in plainer condition. The smaller buyer panel consisted of three regular processors and opportunity feeder operators with selective demand. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Normanton, Belyando, local and coastal areas. The smaller offering improved prices on most categories by 8c to 18c/kg.

A small offering of yearling steers above 200kg returning to the paddock sold to and averaged 238c, while yearling heifers above 280kg, sold to 202c multiple times with those to feed  averaging 197c and 194c/kg to the trade.  Grown heifers to the trade reached 244c  to average near 226c and a good sample of plain conditioned heifers to feed averaged 187c/kg. A small sample of bullocks to export slaughter sold to 246c to average 221c to 238c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows sold to 194c to average 183c and 3 score cows topped at 214c to average 202c/kg.

Heavy bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 246c multiple times to average 242c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Widespread rain across much of the north and west resulted in a large decrease in supply with 1869 cattle penned, 1251 fewer than last sale.  Quality was mixed with fewer prime cattle -mostly consisting of one large line of northern cows, along with some good quality store steers and heifers. A major road closure prevented one processor and opportunity restockers from attending, however there was strong competition for lighter cattle. Value changes were reflective of quality, with light steers improving by 30c to 40c, heifers increased by up to 30c while heavy cows to processors averaged 4c/kg higher.  Cattle were predominantly drawn from Normanton, Croydon, Cloncurry, Greenvale. 
 
Light steer calves to restockers sold to 738.2c while a good sample of vealer steers topped at 624.2c to average 602c/kg. Good quality vealer heifers to restockers sold to 580.2c to average 520c/kg. Yearling steers above 280kg to restockers reached 492.2c to average 423c to 492c and heavy yearling steers above 400kg to feed sold to and averaged 414c/kg. Mixed quality yearling heifers above 280kg to feed reached 402.2c to average 384c/kg.

There were insufficient grown steers and heifers to reliably quote.  Medium weight 2 score cows to processors reached 304.2c to average the same, while 3 scores topped at 354.2c to average 325c/kg.  A small sample of heavy bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 370.2c to average 323 to 362c/kg. A large sample of young males returning to grass sold to 680.2c to average 608c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Widespread rain across much of the north and west resulted in a dramatic decrease in numbers to 690 cattle in a Combined Prime & Store sale. Quality was impacted by a large offering of northern pastoral cattle with only a limited number of prime cattle offered. Two regular processors were absent due to the smaller yarding while those in attendance, including opportunity restockers, operated at reduced rates in line with other sales across the state and the quality penned.

Cattle were mostly drawn from northern areas including, Burketown, Doomadgee, Georgetown and Ravenshoe. Yearling steers and heifers sold in line with quality, grown steers were mostly firm, cows to processors fell 8c and bulls averaged 14c easier.

Light weight steers returning to the paddock sold to 528.2c, to average 504c/kg. Better quality yearling steers above 200kg returning to the paddock sold to 465.2c to average 420c to 440c/kg. A limited number of grown steers above 400kg to feed sold to 406.2c to average 398c and suitable trade types also sold to 406.2c to average 365c/kg. A reduced number of heifers to feed sold to 316.2c with trade types making 326.2 c/kg.

A small sample of heavy well finished full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 355.2c to average 350c/kg. A much-reduced offering of cows met subdued demand. Medium weight 3 score cows to processors topped at 315.2c to average 308c/kg.  A small number of heavy bulls to feed sold to 316.2c to average 299c/kg.

The only pen of cows and calves sold for $1,500/unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Vendor numbers were up, but overall cattle numbers were slightly lower. Quality was not up to previous weeks standard, with only the odd pen of better types. All the regular buyers were in attendance and operating however values for most suffered losses. 

All of the steers were plainer types with the only ones able to realise increased rates were the lightweights, which sold to 141.2c/kg. Both the medium and heavy steers reached 160.2c, as a limited number of heavy bullocks reached 162.2c/kg to return over $1,000/head. 

Going against the falling trend was the light heifers, which improved up to 5c/kg. The D3s reached 146.2c to average 141c/kg. The cows in large numbers also suffered falls. The lightweights reached 100.2c, as the mediumweight D3s averaged 124.9c/kg. 

The medium bulls were able to realise increased rates, as the heavy types topped at 149.2c/kg to remain firm.

Values were mixed as a larger yarding was offered to a full panel of buyers, also operating was a new southern buyer. Even though increased numbers were presented the quality of the yarding was improved on previous weeks. The continuing dry and the current good rates were the main factors in producers offloading stock. 

A large number of steers suited to the Korean market reached 210.2c as an even greater number of heavy steers topped at 219.2c/kg to return over $1,200/head. The heavy bullocks were a relatively small percentage of the yarding with the strong competition pushing sales to 225.2c/kg. 

The heifers regained last weeks losses and improved further with most 10c/kg dearer. Over 150 light D3s reached 198.2c/kg. Most of the cows offered were medium weights, however the light D2s remained firm after selling to 170.2c/kg. Medium weight D3s topped at 199.2c/kg and returned over $1,000/head. 

Nearly all of the bulls offered were light weights selling to 168.2c, as a single heavy weight sold to 200c/kg.

Useful rain in the local area saw numbers fall by around 200 for a yarding of 1745 cattle. Quality was mixed -with the supply of prime cattle halving on last week- however some good pens of well finished, heavy bullocks and cows were penned, supported by some very good quality store steers and heifers.  All regular processors were in attendance and operating, supported by one feeder, local opportunity restockers and backgrounders along with central backgrounders. Cattle were drawn from Normanton, Georgetown, Hughenden, The Belyando and the local area.

Values lifted across most categories, particularly better quality lines. Yearling steers and heifers improved by 10c to 40c, prime grown steers, bullocks and cows averaged 6c to 35c better.

Very good quality weaned steers above 200kg to restockers sold to 320c to average 294c to 315c, lighter weights averaged 291c/kg. A good sample of lightweight heifers to backgrounders reached 236c to average 231c/kg. Yearling steers above 280kg to feed sold to 280c to average 273c, feeder types averaged 276c/kg. Steers above 330kg to feed reached 312c to average from 268c to 295c/kg. Yearling heifers above 280kg returning to the paddock sold to 236c to average 197c, heavy heifers above 400kg to processors made to 272c to average 271c/kg.

Grown steers above 400kg to feed sold to 312c to average 299c, heavy trade types made to 288c, most around 275c/kg. Good quality heavy grown heifers to the trade sold to 270c to average 248c, plainer types averaged 189c/kg.

Small lines of heavy 3 and 4 score bullocks to export slaughter topped at 292c, averaging from 276c to 286c/kg. Lightweight cows to processors sold to 190c to average 169c, medium weight 3 score cows sold to 272c to average 240c and prime heavyweight cows topped at 270c to average 268c/kg.  Heavy bulls to processors sold to 266c to average 263, bulls to feed destined for live export averaged 249c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

There was slight decrease in supply and similar to others weeks quality dropped way quickly once of the top end of the market. All the regular buyers were in attendance and keen to purchase stock. Light steers sold from firm to 14c/kg dearer with the poorer quality stock realising the best gains. Medium steers gained from 4c to 7c/kg and there were too few heavy weights to provide an accurate quote. Heifers improved 14c to 16c while the cows were 2c to 10c/kg with the lesser finished grades the improving by the greatest margin. 

Light poor quality steers averaged 100c while the best grades made to 135c and averaged firm at 115.8c/kg. Good quality medium weight steers peaked at 160.2c and the C muscled cattle averaged from 146c to 158c/kg depending on finish. Poorer grades were in the largest supply and averaged 130c/kg. 

A small number of heifers topped at 135.2c/kg.  Over 180 light D1 cows averaged 82.2c while the better grades made to 113.2c/kg. Medium weight cows peaked at 123.2c and the D3s averaged 121.8c while the D2s saw most sales around 110c/kg. Poor quality medium weight bulls averaged 100c/kg.

There was only a small supply available and an accurate trend is difficult to quote. There were some good heavy steers offered and these were 2c/kg dearer while the cows were mainly of lighter weight and received mixed results. Most of the regular buyers were in attendance and active.  

The light steers made to 117.2c and averaged 108.5c while the small number of medium weights topped at 138.2c and averaged around 125c/kg. The heavy steers came from the one vendor and they were of similar quality to the top steers of recent weeks. They topped at 144.2c and averaged 141.5c/kg.

The heifers reached 100c and averaged 86.5c/kg. The light cows topped at 105.2c and the better grades averaged 85.6c/kg. The medium weight cows were in limited supply and the D3s averaged 104.9c/kg. Heavy bulls sold to 119.2c/kg.

There was an increased yarding of 2,026 head consigned by Charters Towers Combined Agents. The yarding was drawn from northern gulf regions, Richmond, Woodstock, and Green Vale, local and coastal areas. It was a mixed quality yarding of plainer condition cattle, selling to a limited panel of buyers, with two processors not operating. The yarding was dominated by plainer steers, cleanskin bulls and mickeys. Limited numbers of cows and calves sold to $890/head. 

Calves to restockers were 11c dearer to average 261c/kg. Light weight vealer steers to the restockers eased 7c to average 248c, while vealer heifers were in good supply to top at 250c/kg, for a line of C4 heifers to slaughter.  Medium weight yearling steers to live export lifted 35c to average 256c, while heavier weight D4 lines settled on 251c/kg. Light weight D4 yearling heifers to slaughter were 6c higher on 197c/kg. 

Medium weight D4 manufacturing steers to slaughter were 20c cheaper on 243c/kg. Medium weight D4 cows to slaughter were 13c lower on 215c, while light weight bulls to feed were 12c cheaper on 185c/kg.

There was an increased yarding of 1,823 head of cattle, 290 more than last sale despite only 191 prime cattle on offer. The sharp decline in prime values contributed to the decline, with no processors operating during the sale. Some large lines of store steers and heifers attracted a large gallery of buyers, with several western restockers and regular local backgrounders active throughout the sale, along with one live exporter. Quality throughout the sale was generally good, with many lines presenting in forward condition. Cattle were drawn from Normanton, Greenvale, Ingham, Mt Coolon, local and coastal areas. Increased restocker activity improved values for better quality vealer steers by more than 8c, while a large sample of very good quality yearling steers increased by up to 70c/kg on last sale. Yearling steers over 280kg improved by up to 9c, while the presence of a live exporter saw suitable steers sell to 252c/kg. An increased supply of good quality heifers increased demand throughout. Light vealer heifers sold to 226c, an increase of 12c on last sale, while yearling heifers sold to 228c/kg. Heifers over 280kg improved by 16c/kg, with western restockers consistently active.

Light vealer steers to restockers sold to 270c, to average 261c, with lesser quality types averaging 243c/kg. Light yearling steers to restockers sold to 270c, to average 261c, with steers over 280kg averaging 254c/kg. Similar steers to live export made to 252c/kg. Light vealer heifers to restockers topped at 226c, averaging 203c, while light yearling heifers returning to grass made to 228c, to average 174c/kg. Lesser quality heifer lines averaged 132c, while heifers over 280kg returning to grass sold to 228c, to average 211c/kg. 

Grown steers to feed destined for live export sold to 211c, with plainer types to restockers also selling to 211c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows to restockers sold to 110c, to average 96c/kg. Bulls of feeder weight to live export sold to 242c, while young males returning to grass sold to 266c, to average 252c/kg. Very good quality cows and calves sold up to $1,100, while plainer conditioned cow/calf units made to $680/head.

There was an increase of almost 900 head, to 2,450 cattle at Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week. Featured were some large lines of heavy prime cows and bullocks, mostly from the northern gulf, supported by some good quality store steers. All regular processors were operating at increased prices, with superior weight and yield on many lines. Two regular feeder buyers operated on many lines, particularly plainer types, supported by several restockers with an eye for better quality types. Cattle were drawn from Mount Isa, Burketown, Richmond, Corfield, Mount Garnet, Greenvale, Townsville, Home Hill, as well as local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers were generally plainer than last sale and the lighter weights met limited demand. Better quality steers returning to grass sold to 276c, averaging 246c, while light steers calves made to 217c/kg, with variable quality on offer. Yearling steers to restockers eased 7c, topping at 248c to average 233c, while better quality medium weight steers to feed were 2c dearer making 230c/kg. A small offering of vealer heifers and calves sold according to quality, with one good line of vealer heifers making 206c, while the influence of the season saw very light heifer calves make 176c/kg. Most yearling heifers were also showing the effects of the season, with the majority destined for feed. Better quality medium weight heifers to feed eased 23c, topping at 231c to average 207c, while lighter types averaged 196c/kg.

There were 743 head of prime heavy weight bullocks seen, making this the largest offering in more than 3 years. This offering saw all export processors active throughout, lifting values by 2c to 4c/kg, with consistent improvements in weight and yield for many pens. Extra heavy bullocks to export slaughter reached 269c to average 262c, while heavy bullocks sold to 266c, improving 4c to average 257c/kg. Lower yielding heavy bullocks sold to 242c, while plainer medium weights to feed destined for live export sold to 234c to average 206c/kg. An improved offering of high yielding heavy cows improved by up to 14c/kg, with many lines attracting strong processor demand. Prime 3 score cows to processors lifted 1c, averaging 206c, with a top of 214c, while extra heavy 3 score cows sold to 217c/kg. 4 score cows sold to 228c to average 217c/kg. Heavy D muscled cows sold to 208c to average 197c and medium weight cows sold to 193c to average 191c/kg. A lift in the quality of light cows saw restockers secure cows up to 162c, increasing 15c and averaging 140c/kg. Heavy grown heifers with improved yield and weight sold to 258c to average 256c, with one very good line to restockers making 246c/kg. A continuation of large numbers of heavy bulls sold mostly firm for better quality types, with those above 600kg to feed destined for live export making to 247c, with most receiving above 220c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors made to 247c to average 224c/kg. An increased supply of plainer medium weight feeder bulls mostly sold to feed destined for live export, easing 8c to average 203c, while good quality suitable weaned males to feed made up to 226c to average 216c/kg. Light conditioned cows and calves sold up to $840/unit.

There was an increase of 760 head to 2,057 cattle were presented by Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents, featuring several good lines of prime cows and store steers. One returning processor competed for lighter cows and in conjunction with regular processors, two live exporters and several opportunity restockers, most categories lifted on previous prices. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Richmond, Forsayth, Einasleigh, Pentland, Ingham, Belyando local and coastal areas.

An increase in the number of vealer steers attracted strong competition lifting values for better quality types. Light vealer steers reached 299c to average 257c and medium weight vealers made to 274c to average 254c/kg. Yearling steers of 280-330 range to live export sold to 267c and heavier feeder steers above 330kg sold to 264c to average 254c/kg. Restockers competed for steers presented in larger lines, with the better quality lines above 280kg returning to grass selling to 269c to average above 235c/kg. Lesser quality types sold to 244c to average 213c/kg. Vealer heifers comprised of a few quality lines and several smaller mixed quality types selling according to quality. Light vealer heifers sold to 198c, with better quality heifers above 200kg returning to grass selling to 212c to average 194c/kg. Heavy vealers to feed sold to 212c to average 198c/kg. Fewer mixed quality yearling heifers met variable demand, with better grown, heavy yearling heifers to feed making to 226c/kg.

Very few numbers of prime heavy bullocks were on offer, with heavier types selling to 247c, with older northern bullocks less than 540kg selling to 239c to average 211c/kg. Grown steers also showed considerable variation in quality, with one line of heavy steers to feed selling for 229c/kg. The cow offering improved in number and quality with some very good extra heavy cows selling to 196c, and heavy 3 score cows sold to 195c to average 190c/kg. Heavy 3 score D muscled cows made to 196c for some high yielding cows, with most averaging 181c/kg. Large numbers of heavy 2 score cows sold to 180c to average 158c, while medium weight 2 score cows, with greater processor demand sold to 161c to average 132c/kg. Opportunity restockers were active on light cows to 140c to average 125c/kg. Mixed quality grown heifers to the trade sold to 211c/kg. Heavy bulls continued recent strong trends to live export selling to 270c, with similar bulls to slaughter sold from 160c to 257c/kg. Medium weight bulls to feed destined for live export sold from 222c to 250c/kg. Light young males returning to grass sold from 200c to 244c to average 231c/kg. Mixed quality cows and calves sold from $560 to $860/unit.

There was an increase of 696 head to 2,502 good quality cattle yarded by Charters Towers Combined Agents this week, which included some very good lines of well finished bullocks and cows in the prime section and several very good lines of store steers and heifers. Two regular processors were absent from the buying panel, reflecting on lower values across some prime categories, however regular feeder buyers and restocker jostled for dominance on store lines. Cattle were drawn from Chillagoe, Georgetown, Greenvale, Ingham, Woodstock, local and coastal areas.  

Vealer steers increased in numbers and set another saleyard record of 418.2c for light weights and regularly sold above 390c to average 392.6c/kg. Yearling steers varied in quality, however feeder buyers were dominant on suitable types, with steer to feeders topping at 328.2c, to average 301.6c, while yearling steers to restockers sold to 392.2c, for an increased average of 349.6c/kg. Vealer heifers again sold strongly, although were easier on last sale, topping at 330.2c to restockers to average 320.9c/kg. Vealer heifers to feed sold to 320.2c for a 305.7c/kg average. Yearling heifers were in good supply and sold strongly, particularly feeder types, topping at 314.2c and averaging 288.6c while restockers paid to 328.2c/kg.

Some very good heavy 3 score bullocks to slaughter sold to 302.2c and averaged 293.6c while 2 score bullocks to slaughter sold to 289.2c/kg. A good supply of 2 score grown steers to restockers sold to 290.2c/kg. The continued offering of good lines of cows sold to easier rates on last sale. Heavy 3 score cows to slaughter topped at 257.2c and averaged 249.4c, while heavy 2 score cow sold to 246c, to average 234.7c/kg. Medium and heavy 2 score cows to feed sold to 235.2 and averaged 226.9c/kg. Restockers paid to 232.2c/kg for medium weight 2 score cows. A small number of heavy bulls to slaughter sold strongly, topping at 262.2c while medium weight bulls to feed sold to 265.2c/kg. Young males to restockers sold to 330.2c/kg. Several small lines of cows and calves were offered, selling from $1,140 to a top of $1,600/unit.

There was an increase of 203 head to 1,618 cattle for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week. There were some good lines of well finished cows, store steers and young males were featured and sold to higher prices, with buyers active in the market. All processors were in attendance for the first time in several months, increasing prime cow prices by up to 20c/head, while one regular feeder buyer, two live exporters and several restockers were very active throughout the store section. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Cloncurry, Hughenden, Croydon, Ingham, Woodstock, local and coastal areas.

Some very good quality small lines of vealer steers with more weight compared to recent weeks lifted in price by 11c, to top at 356c/kg. Steers greater than 200kg eased 12c to 19c to top at 358c and averaged 327c/kg. Yearling steers were of mixed quality and weight as feeder steers suitable for live export sold to 322c and heavy steers to 279c/kg. Good quality light steers returning to grass sold to 332c, to average 304c/kg. A small number of vealer heifers returning to grass sold to 300c/kg. Light heifers returning to grass sold to 282c, to average 265c/kg. Feeder heifers to live export sold to 278c, to average 274c/kg. Grown heifers returning to grass sold to 260c, to average 244c/kg and some PTIC heifers sold as open auction for $910/head.

Bullocks lifted in quality and prices increased accordingly. Heavy 3 score bullocks to slaughter sold to 276c/kg. Live exporters were very active to fill orders and secured heavy bullocks to a top of 270c, with sales between 259c and 268c/kg. Lighter bullocks to feed sold to 258c/kg. Grown steers less than 400kg to live export sold to 280c, to average 277c/kg. Keen competition from all processors lifted prices for heavy well finished C muscle cows by more than 20c to top at 240c, with most sales between 225c and 238c/kg. Heavy 3 score D muscled cows sold to 230c and averaged 223c, while 2 score cows sold to 220c, to average 204c/kg. Lighter 2 score cows to restockers sold to 212c, lifting 8c to average 195c/kg. Bull numbers lifted and quality was superior to recent weeks, with live exporters securing most heavy bulls to 265c, as the majority sold above 250c/kg. Bulls of feeder weight to live export sold to 302c, to average 267c/kg. The very good quality light males to restockers sold to 366c and averaged 329c/kg. A mixed offering of cows and calves sold to $1,280/unit.

There was an increase in supply but quality was of a lesser standard than previous weeks, particularly the steers. The good lines of stock that attracted the best rates last weeks were not present.  All the usual buyers were in attendance but competition was subdued. Steers were 10c to 11c/kg cheaper and heifers sold slightly easier. Lightweight cows gained ground while the medium weights were 4c to 7c/kg cheaper. 

Light steers reached 119.2c and averaged just under 116c/kg. The bulk of the steers offered were medium weights the better grades mostly sold around 131c while the lesser stock averaged close to 115c/kg. One pen of heavy steers sold to an isolated 144.2c/kg. A limited number of good quality heifers made to 134.2c and the majority were D2s that averaged 106.4c/kg. 

Light cows varied from poorer E muscled stock through to fair quality D2s. The bulk was of a better standard and peaked at 109.2c to average 98.3c/kg.  The largest number of medium weights were also D2s that averaged 103.3c while the D3s topped at 116.2c/kg. One pen of heavy D3s sold for 129.2c/kg. Bulls showed gains with most being heavy weights that averaged 98.2c/kg.

There was a yarding of 1,764 cattle presented in Charters Towers, with quality generally good throughout. Some well presented lines of store steers and heifers met strong competition, while less than 600 prime cattle were on offer. Only three processors were in attendance along with regular feeder and backgrounder buyers, along with opportunity restockers and plenty of onlookers. Cattle were mostly drawn from local and coastal areas with some western lines. Prime cows and bullocks sold firm to 4c easier, while most store lines lifted by up to 20c/kg.

Steer calves returning to grass sold to 550.2c to average 477c/kg. Vealer steers returning to the paddock sold to 582.2c to average 493c and vealer heifers suitable for processors sold to 422.2c to average near 420c, while light heifers to feed averaged 368c/kg. Light yearling steers to restockers reached 450.2c to average 427c while yearling steers above 330kg to feed topped at 400.2c to average 395c/kg. A good supply of yearling heifers above 280kg to feed sold to 368.2c to average from 359c to 364c/kg.

Grown steers above 400kg to live export sold to 350.2c to average 336c and heavy bullocks to export slaughter sold for 356.2c/kg. Heavy grown heifers to the trade made to 348.2c to average 319c and heifers to feed sold to 355.2c to average 344c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows sold to 255.2c to average 246c and heavy 3 score cows topped at 270.2c to average 266c/kg. A small number of heavy bulls to live export sold to 352.2c, with young males returning to the paddocks selling to 482.2c/kg. A good selection of cows and calves sold from $1,300 to 1,625/unit.

There was a very small penning that consisted mostly of heavy steers and medium weight cows. Most buyers were in attendance although not all were as active. Processors purchased the top cattle and competed with some butchers on the better lines. Steers were 4c and 5c dearer while the cows gained between 10c to 25c/kg.

The medium weight steers peaked at 150c/kg. The heavy steers sold to 155c and averaged 146.8c while most came from the one vendor. Heifers sold to 116.2c/kg.

Light cows sold to 110.2c and the D2s averaged 95.4c/kg. The medium weight cows peaked at 135.2c and the D3s averaged 129.5c/kg. Heavy bulls sold to 133.2c/kg.

There was a substantial decline in numbers and quality was fair to slightly plainer across most grades.  The yarding consisted of grown steers, bullock and cows with only a limited supply of heifers penned.  The regular panel of buyers was present and competition was firm to stronger across most categories.

The majority of the grown steers were light and medium weights and most were firm to slightly dearer while heavy pens were up to 6¢/kg dearer.  The well-finished C3 pens made from 157.2¢ to 159.2¢/kg.

Light weight cows were 1¢ to 4¢ dearer while the better medium weight lines rose by 4¢/kg.  The D3 medium weight pens averaged 131.1¢ and heavy 4 score cows sold up to 143.2¢/kg.

There was a small prime penning for the first sale of the year although as store sale of 550 head was also held. The season has deteriorated over the break with feed and water becoming real issues for most producers. It has been reported that there is some good live export trade at present. The small yarding makes an accurate trend difficult to quote. 

Steers sold to 147.2c and heifers reached 129.2c/kg. Light cows were in the greatest numbers and topped at 110c with most around 90c/kg. Medium weight cows peaked at 110.2c and poor quality bulls made to 90c/kg.

There was a slightly larger yarding consisting of approximately 600 prime and 2200 store cattle. The prime sale consisted of some excellent quality bullocks and cows, which sold to a dearer trend. A full compliment of buyers was present including one extra meatworks operator. 

Grown steers were of mostly good quality consisting of medium weight C muscled types. These ranged from 145.2c to 154.2c to average 149.8c/kg. Heifers sold to a slightly dearer market averaging 138.2c after reaching a top of 140.2c/kg. 

It was a good quality cow yarding containing some large runs of well-finished stock. Light and medium weight D muscled types averaged 132.4c and 136.1c respectively with the occasional pen making a top of 155.2c/kg. The best of the bulls sold for 124.2c/kg.

There was a slightly larger yarding at Charters Towers today, made up mostly of export types. Steers were in good numbers and sold on a firm to dearer trend. 

Heifers also sold well with a large number of D3 types selling to a top of 147.2c, lifting 27c from last sale to average 140.1c/kg. The cows were the highlight of the sale with all grades selling from firm to dearer. The light and medium weight cows showed some good lifts with all D muscled types in particular improving strongly. Heavy cows were mostly firm on last sale.

A good yarding of bulls sold at irregular levels, with light bulls losing value but heavier types improving slightly.

There was a slight increase in numbers and quality was plainer compared to the previous market.  The penning mainly consisted of grown steers and heifers along with a mixed selection of cows.  All the regular buyers were in attendance and competition was weaker across all grades.

The plainer offering of grown steers and bullocks eased by 2¢ to 6¢ and the C muscled heavy weight pens sold from 143.2¢ to 152.2¢/kg.  Grown heifers were 4¢ to 7¢ cheaper and the D2 lightweight lines averaged 112.2¢/kg.

Cows fell by 5¢ to 7¢/kg with odd isolated pens having greater price corrections.  The D2 lightweight cows averaged 112.7¢ while the D3 medium weight pens averaged 122¢/kg.

There was a larger yarding of better quality that sold to the regular field of buyers. Local butchers bought a fair percentage of the yarding. Much of the local area is looking for rain with water availability becoming problem in some instances. 

There was a greater number of Jap ox weight steers available that improved in price as well as quality. The D3s topped at 186.2c to average 177.4c/kg. 

Export heifers sold at cheaper rates with a good run averaging 161.6c/kg. Cows were in the majority and lights weights eased. No accurate trend was available on the remaining grade following last weeks limited numbers, however medium and heavy weight D3s average around 132c/kg. 

Bulls lost ground and the best heavy weights sold to a top of 128.2c/kg to return close to $900/head.

There was a large increase in supply following the stronger markets of recent weeks. The improved numbers saw a mixed quality yarding penned. All the regular buyers were in attendance and active, although competition was subdued on some of the poorer quality stock. A small number of light steers gained ground, while the medium and heavy weights eased by 2c to 7c/kg. Heifers were 3c to 6c cheaper and the cows varied 3c to 4c/kg either side of last weeks rates. 

Light steers topped at 134.2c and while the medium weights made to 143.2c the better grades averaged close to 140c/kg. The best heavy steers sold for 157.2c but most were of a lesser standard and averaged 144.6c/kg. Good quality heavy bullocks peaked at 159.2c/kg. There was some good heifers that reached 135c, with most making around 110c/kg. 

Light cows sold to 117.2c and close to 200 head averaged 110c/kg. There were some good lines of medium weight cows and these sold from firm to 3c dearer with the best grades making to 129.2c/kg. A large number of D2s averaged 115.5c/kg. All the bulls were of poor quality and sold from 50c to 96c/kg.

There was a decrease in supply and quality was also of a lesser standard. Competition varied, processors were keen to purchase cows while the steers and heifers generally sold to weaker demand. The bulk of the steers eased 3c/kg. Heifers were cheaper and the light cows varied either side of last week. Medium weight cows improved 7c/kg. 

Light steers made to 132.2c/kg. Most of the steers were medium weights and they topped at 147.2c, although 120 head averaged just under 130c/kg. Heavy steers topped at 149.2c and averaged 148.8c/kg. The best heifers sold to 144.2c and a fair number averaged 116.6c/kg.

Light cows reached 113.2c and the D2s averaged 3c dearer at 106.5c/kg. Medium weight cows were well supplied and the sold to a top of 128.2c and close to 100 D3s averaged 124.7c/kg. One heavy cows topped at 129.2c/kg. Heavy bulls sold from 95c to 100c/kg.

The yarding was reduced and this combined with strong demand from export processors led to a very dear market. The four major processors operated throughout the sale with strong support for all grades of cattle with little dependence on quality. Additional support from butchers was evident but they had only limited opportunities to purchase better-finished cattle as processors secured most.

 A large line of 200 heavy steers from Cargoon north of Charter Towers was a feature of the sale selling to strong support, resulting in averages of 189.2c/kg. This accounted for a large percentage of the grown steers yarding but a smaller number of medium weights sold from 171.2c to 182.2c/kg. 

The strongest gains were reserved for the cow market with light and medium weights improving between 7c and 9c/kg. Surprisingly given the seasonal conditions many of the cows had good fat coverage which was welcomed by processors and led to the best lines selling to 175.2c/kg.

The yarding of 422 prime cattle at Charters Towers on Thursday which was down by 334 head on last weeks sale.
  
In the export classes, light steers, D1 sold to 120.2c/kg for one pen.  A good sample of D3 medium weight steers topped at 125.6c to average 120.2c/kg.  Other heavier steers and ox reached 123.2c/kg.  D3 heifers reached 117.2c/kg.  

There was good numbers of cows penned, the better end of the heavy cows sold to 105.6c to average upwards of 100c/kg.  Bulls topped at 106.6c/kg.

The yarding of 1,503 prime cattle at Charters Towers on Thursday represented a considerable rise of 907 head on last week.  

In the steers, light weight steers sold to 121.2c/kg, medium steers sold to 119.2c to average 107.4c/kg.  

Best of the heavy export steers reached 123.8c for a large sample of D3s with other heavier bullocks selling to 127.2c/kg.  A fair sample of D2s  heifers made to 125.2c/kg.  

The heavy cows that were offered sold up to 103.2c/kg to average 91.9c and bulls sold to 109.2c to be 3c/kg dearer.

The yarding increased with just under 800 prime cattle offered. Quality was similar to the previous sale and appears to be declining in line with the season being experienced, with feedstocks in the local area deteriorating rapidly. Three regular buyers operated and purchases were generally shared.

Medium steers ranged from 140c to 150.2c while the heavy steers sold from 144c to 156c/kg, both weight grades experienced lifts in value. A large offering of grown heifers sold to varied competition with the best c muscled lines averaging 122.7c/kg.

The largest percentages of the cows were d3 medium weights; making up the bulk of these was a consistent line of six decks, purchased solely by one major processor. The best of the cows reached 136.2c while the overall average was 132.4c/kg. A smaller number of lighter conditioned cows averaged 119.2c/kg.

The yarding improved, with the increase attributed to the beginning of the new financial year and continued decline in seasonal conditions. Not all buyers attended with one major exporter absent, this did not result in a weaker price trend with local butcher able to compensate for any weaker competition. 

Grown steer quality was quite good with plenty of competition for the better-finished lines, with medium weights averaging 147c, while heavier steers ranged from 165.2c to 169.2c/kg. Bullocks were in high demand and spirited bidding saw prices reach 173.2c, with the average at 169c/kg.

The quality of the cow yarding was quite varied with over 50% of the offering very good while the tail end was very light in condition and finish. Overall prices improved between 3c and 8c/kg for all weights and grades. Lightweights lifted 3c to average 122c while medium weight D3s dominated the yarding and ranged from 132.2c to 144.2c and the heavy conditioned lines averaged 149.2c/kg. A small number of heavyweights averaged 144c/kg.

The yarding improved, with all the usual buyers in attendance and operating fully. Prices throughout the sale were erratic at times with the price trend towards the end of the sale significantly stronger as buyers battled to secure adequate supplies. The season in the surrounding region is heading backwards with much of the area in desperate need of rainfall leading into winter. 

Medium steers ranged from 142.2c to 160.2c while the heavy steers sold from 148.2c to 164.2c/kg, both weight grades eased slightly. Grown heifers sold to varied competition with the best C muscled lines averaging 122.9c/kg.

The largest percentages of the cows were D3 medium weights and the best of these reached 143.2c while the overall average was 131.2c/kg. A smaller number of lighter conditioned cows averaged 116.2c/kg.

The yarding improved with a full panel of buyers in attendance. Overall quality was mixed with lightweight cows and heavy steers in greatest number.
 
Medium weight lines lifted 3c on top of 3c rises last week to average 172.9c/kg. Heavy steers were in greatest number with just over 250 head offered ranging from 178.2c to 186.2c/kg. 

Cows were dominated by light and medium weights with prices generally mixed. The lightweight 3 score lines averaged 143.1c and a large number of medium weights sold from 139.2c to 152.2c/kg.

The yarding improved and all buyers competed strongly to secure their share. Overall quality was mixed with steers lines plain in condition and the cows better presented. Cattle were drawn from the local region plus additional supplies from Townsville and Richmond. 

Grown steers and bullocks were not to the standard of those offered in the past month, but this did not prevent prices from improving. Medium weight lines lifted 3c to average 169.8c and a large line of steers averaged 176.6c to be 2c/kg stronger. Bullocks were in similar numbers but quality was limited and few reached the levels of previous weeks. 

Cows were dominated by medium weights and the majority were in very good condition. Strong competition from a large contingent of processors coupled with the improved quality led to a stronger trend for medium weights the 3 score lines gaining 5c to average 149.9c/kg.

The yarding fell significantly with just under 1000 cattle offered. Quality was similar to the previous sale, with only a small percentage of older cows offered. Drizzly rain over the past few days has boosted producers spirits, with some areas of the surrounding district receiving up to 2 inches. All the major export buyers operated plus a couple of local butchers.
 
Medium steers ranged from 134c to 153.2c while the heavy steers sold from 144c to 154c/kg, both weight grades struggled to improve from the rates of the last week. Grown heifers sold to varied competition with the best C muscled lines averaging 132.4c/kg.

The largest percentages of the cows were D3 medium weights and the best of these reached 136.2c while the overall average was 127.9c/kg. A smaller number of lighter conditioned cows averaged 118.2c/kg.

The very small yarding sold to most of the usual buyers. Accurate quotes are difficult although the medium weight cows were 6c/kg dearer. There was a few heifers penned along with some steers. 

Light steers reached 119.2c and averaged 108.6c/kg. Heavy steers topped at 127.2c/kg. The better quality heifers averaged 105.5c and the poorer grades sold around 94c/kg. Light cows averaged 79.7c and the medium weights reached 105.2c to average 99.2c/kg.

The usual processors competed for a mixed yarding of cattle with numbers lifting marginally compared to the last market. There were some pens of quality drafts offered with values remaining strong for these lines, however the buyers present discounted any unfinished plainer pens in price. Steers and cows were represented with high percentages with the heifer portion very limited in number.

 The better C muscled medium steers traded from146c to 160c while the heavier drafts sold from 148c to 159c/kg. D3 heifers returned values from 125c to 135c/kg.

Light D muscled cows recorded prices from 91c to 113c with the medium drafts selling from 93c to 129c/kg. The few heavy pens offered sold from 129c to 136c/kg. The top price for the bull categories was 136c/kg.

The trend of a large supply of cattle continued following two sales last week with 3221 cattle penned. Despite the continuing dry conditions across much of the north and west, quality and condition of cattle was mostly good with an increased number of female cattle at hand. All regular processors were in attendance but operating selectively supported by regular feeders, backgrounders and restockers. Buyer demand was subdued on some lines with quality a factor. Prices eased for yearling steers and heifers by 20c, grown steers by 40c to 45c, heifers averaged 15c lower, while cows to processors fell by 20c/kg. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Richmond, Hughenden, Pentland, Georgetown, Ingham, Woodstock, Belyando, local and coastal areas. 

Young steer calves to restockers sold to 698.2c to average 644c and vealer steers above 200kg returning to grass made to 598.2c to average 548c to 574c/kg. Good quality large lines of vealer heifers to feed sold to 514.2c to average 501c to 504c/kg, while a good sample to the trade sold to 526.2c averaging 478c to 500c/kg. An increased supply of yearling steers above 280kg to feed reached 526.2c to average 481c/kg. Steers above 330kg to feed topped at 496.2c multiple times to average 470c/kg and restockers averaged 481c/kg. Yearling heifers above 280kg to feed sold to 460.2c to average 447c and heifers above 300kg also to feed topped at 460.2c to average 434c/kg.  

Good quality grown steers above 400kg to feed sold to 446.2c to average 404c to 419c/kg and suitable trade steers above 500kg to the trade reached 400.2c to average 397c/kg. A large sample of grown heifers to feed sold to 394.2c to average 382c to 392c/kg. A small sample to backgrounders averaged 386c/kg. A small number of mixed quality heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 402.2c to average 400c/kg. 

Selective processor demand for cows resulted in an easing trend on recent weeks. Medium weight 2 score cows made to 324.2c to average 320c, 3 score cows to processors reached 364.2c to average 333c and prime heavyweights topped at 360.2c to average 344c/kg. A large sample of cows to opportunity restockers sold to 338.2c to average 323c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors sold to 330.2c to average 329c/kg.  

A small number of good quality cows and calves sold from $1,900 to $2,450/unit.

Market Reporter; Mick Kingham.

The total prime cattle yarded at Charters Towers this week was 307 head.  The market held up quite well despite the absence of one Northern processor.  

The best of the steers topped at 143.6c/kg.  Heavy cows, C4 sold particularly well to a top of 127.2c/kg.  Heifers made to 112.6c and bulls to 117.6c/kg.

The supply of stock increased by 446 head to 3,099 cattle this week, featuring several large lines of heavy prime cows and store steers and heifers. The buyer gallery expanded with two additional processors, one live exporter and several opportunity restockers. The increased buyer attendance pushed values higher particularly prime cows which lifted 7c to 10c and grown steers and heifers improved by 10c/kg. Cattle were drawn from north of Mt Isa, Burketown, Normanton, Richmond, Pentland, Greenvale, local and coastal areas.

Steer calves to restockers sold to 506.2c to average 481c and heifer calves to the trade made 400c/kg. Vealer steers to southern backgrounders topped at 500.2c, with a large sample averaging 493c and those above 200kg averaged 444c to 451c/kg. Vealer heifers to the trade reached 422.2c to average 412c, while restocker lines topped at 432.2c to average 358c to 398c/kg. A very good quality line above 280kg sold for 392.2c/kg. Light yearling steers to backgrounders reached 450.2c and steers above 330kg to restockers made to 412.2c to average 405c/kg, with feeder types averaging 365c to 384c/kg.  Increased numbers of yearling heifers above 330kg to feed reached 384.2c to average 360c to 384c, with a line to restockers averaging 381c/kg.  

Heavy grown steers met improved demand with suitable trade types selling to 354.2c multiple times and feeder types reached 368.2c to average 348c to 365c/kg.  A good sample of heavy grown heifers to the trade topped at 334.2c to average 329c/kg. Heavy full mouthed bullocks to export slaughter sold to 348.2c to average 347c/kg.  

Strong demand for prime cows pushed values higher with medium weight 2 score cows selling to 286.2c to average above 270c and 3 score cows topping at 292.2c multiple times to average 282c/kg.  Heavy bulls to live export reached 368.2c to average near 356c/kg. A large sample of very good quality young males to backgrounders sold to 456.2c to average 424c/kg. Good quality cows and calves sold from $1,700 to $2,025/unit.

Market Reporter: Mick Kingham

The supply of stock continues an upward trend, with 3,679 cattle this week, an increase of 403 on last sale.
