Quality was good throughout with increased numbers of heavy grown steers and prime cows supported by some excellent quality store steers and heifers. One major processor was absent from the buyer panel, however all regular operators and one live exporter were very active throughout the sale. Cattle were drawn from Richmond, Croydon, Georgetown, Mt Surprise, Ingham, Townsville, Ravenswood, Belyando local and coastal areas. 

Vealer steers and heifers improved 6c to 12c, yearling steers and heifers sold firm, grown steers and heifers lifted by 17c to 20c, heavy cows were 9c higher and bulls were up to 10c/kg higher.

Market Reporter: Mick Kingham

The supply of cattle was similar to last week with 1,721 head offered in Charters Towers, featuring some good lines of heavy prime cows, bullocks and bulls supported by some very good quality lines of northern store steers. The usual buying panel was operating at increased rates, particularly for better quality heavy prime cattle. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Burketown, Chillagoe, Georgetown, Tully, Balfes Ck, Ravenswood, Belyando, local and coastal areas.

Light vealer steers to restockers improved by 7c and a small sample of quality young heifers increase by 16c/kg. Yearling steers returning to grass improved by 4c and a good draft of yearling heifers increased by 19c/kg. Heavy grown steers to processors lifted by 10c and heavy bullocks to export slaughter improved by more than 20c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows improved by up to 18c, with heavy 3 score cows increasing by more than 7c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors increased by more than 15c/kg.

Young steer calves made to 288c to average more than 280c, while young vealer steers to restockers sold higher, reaching 286c to average more than 280c/kg. Vealer heifers were in limited supply, with good quality lines selling to 190c to average 179c/kg. Yearling steers to restockers made to 268c with most sales above 260c/kg. Some very good quality yearling heifers returning to the paddock made to 221c, averaging 217c/kg. Limited numbers of quality grown heifers to slaughter sold to 256c averaging 246c/kg. Heavy grown steers to slaughter reached 283c and heavy export bullocks sold to 299c to average 291c/kg.  

Heavy 3 score cows topped at 227c, averaging 224c, while extra heavy 4 score cows made 238c/kg. Heavy 3 score D muscled cows sold to 220c to average 185c and medium weight 2 score cows to slaughter sold to 171c to average 138c/kg. Lighter cows to restockers reached 154c to average 141c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors sold to 307c to average 301c, while heavy bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 298c to average 275c/kg. A large sample of young males to restockers and backgrounders sold to 280c, to average 268c/kg.

The supply of cattle was reduced by more than 1,200 for a yarding of 1,651 cattle in Charters Towers, comprising of some good quality prime cows from the local area and some larger plain lines of northern cattle. The regular processors and one live exporter operated in a limited buying panel supported by local opportunity restockers. Cattle were drawn from north of Mt Isa, Normanton, Georgetown, Einasleigh, Mt Garnet, Julia Creek, Hughenden, Paluma, Ayr, Pentland, local and coastal areas.

Young steer calves eased by more than 18c and reduced numbers of young vealer steers eased by 12c/kg. A small offering of good quality heifer calves improved by 9c and vealer heifers were very mixed with better quality types improving by more than 25c/kg. Yearling steers suitable for live export were in limited supply, selling firm on last sale, while yearling heifers to feed improved by 3c/kg. Grown steers were of mixed quality with limited buyer support, while some small lines of heavy bullocks eased by more than 19c/kg on the previous week. Mixed quality grown heifers sold firm for the few suitable pens on offer. Medium weight 2 score cows eased by 13c, while heavy 3 score cows eased by 1c and some extra heavy 4 score cows lifted 8c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors eased 11c and suitable types to live export eased by 8c/kg.

Steer calves sold to 290c to average 268c for better quality types while well grown vealer steers sold to 277c to average more than 276c, with lighter types reaching 294c to average 287c/kg. Heifer calves sold to 238c to average above 214c for the better bred lines, while vealer heifers were in limited supply and sold to 216c, to average 209c/kg. Yearling steers to live export sold from 260c to 274c, while similar types returning to grass made to 280c to average 267c/kg. Yearling heifers to feed sold to 198c, heifers to restockers sold to 197c and heavier types to the trade made to 235c to average near 215c/kg. Grown steers to live export sold to 256c to average 253c/kg. Grown heifers to processors made to 230c, with most sales from 182c to 209c/kg. A small number of heavy bullocks to export slaughter sold to 269c to average near 269c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 174c to average 127c and heavy 3 score cows reached 211c to average 196c/kg. Some good pens of extra heavy 4 score cows sold to 223c to average 214c/kg. Heavy D muscled 3 score cows sold to 197c to average 182c and light cows returning to grass averaged 141c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors sold to 284c, and those suitable for live export topped at 278c to average 271c/kg. Young males returning to the paddock sold to 286c to average 268c/kg.

The supply of cattle more than halved for a yarding of 1542 head. Quality was mixed, comprising of a reduced number of heavy prime cattle, however some very good quality store steers and heifers were penned. One major processor was absent from the buyer panel, while those in attendance including opportunity feeders and backgrounders mostly operated at reduced rates. Cattle were drawn from Burketown, Mt Isa, Julia Ck, Einasleigh, local and coastal areas.

Most categories eased on last sale, however odd pens sold at improved values. Yearling steers improved 16c to 23c, yearling heifers to feed were firm to 11c easier, Grown steers and heifers averaged 10c to 22c lower, medium weight cows to processors were mostly firm.

Young steers returning to the paddock averaged 263c selling to 282c, with similar heifers averaging 256c/kg. Yearling steers to backgrounders reached 270c to average 262c, with steers above 280kg to feed selling to 278c to average 254c to 278c/kg. A large line of very good quality yearling heifers above 330kg to feed sold for 254c/kg.
A small offering of grown steers to feed made from 266c to 268c/kg. Heavy steers to the trade sold for 272c/kg. Grown heifers to the trade reached 262c, a good sample averaging 244c to 250c/kg.

A limited supply of heavy bullocks sold to 284c, most from 264c to 272c/kg. Medium weight 3 score cows to processors sold to 246c, averaging 236c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors made to 248c, most from 220c to 240c/kg.

A small number of cows and calves sold from $725 to $1,025 per unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

The supply of cattle more than doubled on last sale, with 3,553 head penned in Charters Towers. Quality was mostly very good with several lines of prime conditioned cows and heifers.  Well presented lines of store steers and greater numbers of cows and calves were also available. The buyer panel was increased with three additional processors, two live exporters, central backgrounders and southern restockers operating strongly throughout. Cattle were drawn from the far west and northern areas, with many local vendors. Values improved across most categories, with young steers and heifers improving by up to 30c, grown steers and bullocks were firm to 4c higher, prime cows were firm, cows and calves sold to a new saleyard record.

Light steer calves returning to grass sold to 566c with mixed sex averages of 481c to 512c/kg. Light heifers to the trade sold to 440c to average 437c/kg. An increased supply of light vealer steers above 200kg to southern restockers sold to 512c to average 472c to 498c and vealer heifers above 200kg to the trade sold to 446c to average 421c/kg. Yearling steers above 330kg to feed sold to 438c to average 404c, while restocker lines sold to 468c to average 404c to 414c/kg.  A good sample of yearling heifers above 330kg to feed sold to 374c to average from 365c to 372c/kg. 

Grown steers to the trade made to 352c, with averages from 338c to 349c/kg. Suitable steers to live export sold to 342c multiple times, to average near 340c/kg. Grown heifers to the trade sold to 324c to average 310c/kg. Heavy full mouthed bullocks to export slaughter reached 342c to average 326c to 338c/kg. Increased processor demand saw medium weight, 2 score cows reach 262c to average 257c, while a large sample of 3 score cows sold to 280c to average 266 to 275c/kg. Prime heavy weight cows sold to 286c to average 279c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export also increased with the best quality topping at 334c with averages from 318c to 325c/kg. Increased numbers of cows and calves of very good quality sold to a new saleyard record of $2,090/unit, with most selling from $1,880 to $2,020/unit.

The supply of cattle increased to 3246 head this week, 1042 more than last sale.  Quality was generally good with several large lines of heavy prime cows on offer, along with good lines of grown steers and heifers supported by increased numbers of heavy bulls.  The regular buyer panel operated strongly throughout at similar values to recent sales.  Large lines of cattle were drawn from far western and northern areas, with smaller lines from local and coastal areas.  Grown steers and heifers were firm to 5c easier, prime cows 2-5c lower, while heavy bulls improved by up to 6c/kg.

Very good quality steer calves to central restockers sold to 554.2c and similar heifers reached 454.2c , with a large sample of mixed sexes averaging 481c/kg.  Heifer calves to the trade reached 428.2c to average 408c/kg.  Increased numbers of vealer steers above 200kg to restockers and backgrounders sold to 548.2c to average 473-483c, while steers above 280kg to backgrounders reached 448.2c to average 409-421c/kg.  Vealer heifers returning to grass sold to 410.2c/kg to average 372c/kg.  Reduced numbers of yearling steers less than 330kg to feed reached 388.2c, while a good line above 400kg reached 384kg to southern restockers.  Yearling heifers were in short supply with insufficient numbers to reliably quote.

Good lines of grown steers met strong demand, with improved quality lines to feed reaching 348.2c and heavy grown steers to the trade topped at 350.2c to average 348c/kg.  Steers below 400kg to backgrounders made to 392.2c to average from 326-358c/kg and those above 400kg averaged 369c/kg while a small sample to live export sold from 346-354.2c/kg.  Good quality grown heifers to feed sold to 340.2c to average 331c, and heifers to the trade reached 340.2c to average 328-337c/kg.

A small number of full mouthed bullocks to export slaughter reached 354.2c to average 347c/kg.  Light weight 2 score cows met very strong demand from the gallery with those to processors reaching 282.2c to average 261c and restocker lines averaging near 244c/kg.  A large sample of medium weight 3 score cows sold to 288.2c multiple times to average 274c, while prime heavyweight cows reached 282.2c to average 278c/kg.  Heavy bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 356.2c, with most sales from 336-350c/kg.  Young males returning to grass topped at 486.2c with a good sample averaging 418-463c/kg.  A good line of young cows with calves at foot sold for $2,000/unit.

Market Reporter - Mick Kingham

The supply of cattle increased by more than 1,000 for a yarding of 3,062 head.  Quality was very good for majority penned, comprising of many lines of well finished prime cattle, supported by some very good quality store steers and heifers.  All regular processors including one southern operator were actively operating at revised rates in line with recent grid adjustments, supported by one live exporter, regular feeders and restockers. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa to Georgetown and south to the local area.

Most categories sold lower than last sale, particularly secondary lines attracting minimal buyer interest, however a line of yearling heifers sold above market expectations. Yearling steers eased 12c to 25c, yearling heifers to feed ended 12c to 29c lower, restocker heifers increased more than 20c, grown steers to the trade fell 13c, grown heifers were down 18c, bullocks eased 7c to 11c, prime  cows were 19-35c lower and bulls averaged 8-12c less.

Suitable weaned young steers returning to the paddock averaged 283c/kg, with a good quality line selling to 320c, similar heifers to restockers made 184c/kg.  Yearling steers above 280kg reached 260c and steers above 330kg to feed topped at 248c to average 239c/kg.  A very good quality line of yearling heifers above 280kg returning to the paddock sold to 268c to average 264c and heifers to feed made to 244c to average 202c to  223c/kg. HeIfers above  330kg to feed sold to 232c to average 224c/kg.

Better quality grown steers above 400kg to feed sold to 234c to average 231c, with trade types topping at 268c to average 249c/kg.  Better quality grown heifers to the trade sold to 239c to average 230c/kg. A good supply of well finished, heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 281c to average 236c to 268c/kg.

An increased supply of cows attracted good demand, with 2 score cows to processors reaching 206c to average 177c to 184c, 3 scores also made to 206c to average 193c and prime heavyweight cows topped at 211c to average 205c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export sold to 274c to average 264c/kg. 

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

The supply of cattle increased by almost 1,000 for a yarding of 3714. Quality was mostly good, consisting of some large lines of well finished heavy cows and small lines of heavy bullocks, supported by an increased number of good quality store steers and heifers. Cattle were drawn from Burketown to Mt Isa, Richmond, Hughenden, Georgetown, Mt Coolon, local and coastal areas. The buyer panel increased with additional southern processor activity, supported by opportunity feeders, central backgrounders and restockers.

Increased demand from the buyer gallery resulted in price improvements for most categories. Yearling steers rose by up to 30c, yearling heifers to feed lifted 3c to 5c/kg. Bullocks were mostly firm, grown steers to the trade lifted 17c to 24c, grown heifers improved 23c, lightweight cows lifted 13c to 24c, heavy cows improved by 8c and bulls averaged up to 30c higher.

Young suitably weaned steers returning to the paddock averaged 277c to 294c selling to 310c, similar heifers to grass reached 256c, averaging from 244c to 250c and heifers to processors averaged 241c/kg.  Yearling steers above 280kg to feed averaged 253c to 269c, with backgrounder steers averaging 270c/kg. Steers above 330kg to feed eased, selling to 328c to average 280c, while a sample of steers above 400kg averaged 305c/kg. Best bred lines of yearling heifers above 200kg to feed sold to 258c to average 256c and heifers above 280kg reached 274c to average 256c/kg. A small quantity of prime yearling heifers to the trade made to 298c to average above 290c/kg.

A good sample of grown steers above 400kg to the trade averaged 315c selling to 328c, prime grown heifers sold to 296c to average 290c/kg.  An increased supply of heavy full mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 328c to average from 312 to 325c/ kg.
Lightweight 2 score cows to processors sold to an improved 262c to average 243c, medium weight 2 scores averaged 257c, 3 score cows averaged from 265c to 275c and a good supply of prime heavyweight 3 and 4 score cows topped at 294c to  average 287c/kg.  Heavy bulls to processors reached 268c, most around 240c/kg.

A small number of cows and calves sold from $650 per unit to $1,450 for cows with large weaners at foot.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

The supply of cattle increased by 757 head to 1,887 cattle for the final combined prime and store sale of 2020. Young cattle made up the majority of the yarding with quality very mixed and several lines showing the effects of the lengthening dry season.  Several processors were absent, while regular feeder and backgrounders were supported by opportunity restockers. Cattle were drawn from Normanton to Ingham and south to Ayr and Belyando, local and coastal areas.

Steer calves returning to the paddock sold to 450c to average 422c, while processor calves averaged 382c/kg. Vealer steers to restockers topped at 410c, to average from 393c to 395c, while vealer heifers to southern backgrounders reached 380c to average 341c and heifers to processors average 368c/kg.  Yearling steers to western restockers sold to 402c with most sales above 380c, with yearling heifers above 280kg topping at 352c to average from 345c to 351c/kg. Grown steers to feed sold to 360c to average from 326c to 341c and grown heifers to feed made to 344c to average from 318c to 337c/kg.

A small number of bullocks to processors sold to 348c/kg. Reduced numbers of cows presented in lighter condition than recent sales, with medium weight cows 2 score cows to processors topped at 278c to average above 260c/kg and 3 score cows reached 272c to average 263c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export sold to 334c with most sales from 300c to 326c/kg. Good quality cows and calf units sold from $1,335 to $1,875.

The supply of cattle increased by 577 head to 4130 this week, with several large single vendor lines dominating the offering.  Quality was very good for the majority of lines that continued to show improved weight and condition.  The buyer panel was bolstered by two live exporters and several southern backgrounders and restocker orders who operated strongly throughout the sale.  Prices improved across most categories, particularly grown steers, medium weight bulls and medium weight cows driven by live export demand. Cattle were drawn from a wide supply area of far northern and western areas and south to the Belyando.  

Light  steer calves to southern restockers topped at 538.2c with mixed sex averages of 502c, while heifer calves to the trade sold to 424.2c to average 421c/kg.  Vealer steers above 200kg to restockers reached 500.2c to average from 442-480c, while a good sample of very good quality steers above 280kg returning to grass sold to 478.2c to average near 466c/kg. A large sample of lightweight vealer heifers topped at 460.2c to average 447c and heifers above 200kg to backgrounders made to 446.2c to average 439c, while trade types reached 410.2c to average 399c/kg.  Well bred yearling steers 280-400kg sold to 428.2c multiple times to average 404c and steers above 330kg to live export sold to 408.2c to average 376c/kg.  Yearling heifers to feed mostly sold from 360-388.2c, with some PTIC yearling heifers under 300kg to feed selling in open auction making $1,260/head.

Increased numbers of grown steers to live export sold to 370.2c with most making 360.2c, with lighter types averaging 367c/kg.  A small number of grown heifers to the trade sold to 332.2c, while a good sample of heifers to feed sold to 360.2c to average 324-330c/kg.  A small supply of full mouthed bullocks to export slaughter reached 356.2c to average above 332c/kg.  More than 1,100 cows were penned attracting very strong demand from the gallery throughout, resulting in many unfilled orders.  Light cows under 400kg to processors averaged 255c and restocker lines sold to 276.2c to average 247c/kg.  Medium weight 2 score cows to live export sold to 280.2c to average 276c, while 3 score cows topped at 300.2c to average 287c/kg.  Medium weight 2 score cows to processors reached 265.2c to average 261c and 3 scores made to 286.2c to average 274c/kg.  PTIC cows to restockers sold to 288.2c to average from 276-282c/kg.  Heavy bulls to live export reached 338.2c to average near 330c and heavy bulls to feed destined for live export made to 334.2c with most averaging 310-330c/kg.  Light males to restockers sold to 486.2c to average 455c/kg.  Small lines of cows and calves sold from $1860-$2,100/unit.

The supply of cattle increase by 200 for a yarding of 2980 head in a Combined Prime and Store sale. Quality was very mixed comprising of some good lines of prime bullocks heifers and cows, one large line of northern cows an increased number of northern bulls and mixed quality lines of steers and heifers. All regular buyers were in attendance along with one central feeder, one live exporter and opportunity backgrounders and restockers. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Normanton, Croydon, Georgetown, Richmond, Belyando,
local and coastal areas.

Demand was firm for most classes, however poor quality types struggled to attract buyer interest, with values reflective of quality and weight. Grown steers were firm to 15c better, cows lifted 2c to 6c, bullocks increased 4c and heavy bulls averaged 15c better.

Light suitably weaned steers returning to the paddock sold to 284c, similar heifers reached 266c to average 250c and processor heifers sold to 220c, most at 210c/kg. Yearling steers above 200kg to backgrounders reached 274c to average 230c/kg.  Steers above 280kg to feed made to 290c and those above 330kg sold to 286c to average 274c/kg. Steers suitable for live export averaged 285c/kg. Yearling heifers above 280kg to feed averaged 257c and heifers above 330kg sold to 276c to average 271c/kg..

Grown steers above 400kg to live export sold to 299c to average 296c, steers to the trade sold to 298c to average 284c/kg. Grown steers above 500kg to live export reached 310c, processor types averaged 315c selling to 322c/kg. A good supply of grown heifers to the trade sold to 272c, averaging 267c/kg.

A mixed offering of heavy full mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 324c, better quality types averaging 294c to 318c/kg. More than 1,100 cows were penned, with strong demand throughout. Lightweight 2 score cows to feed reached 232c to average 226c, cows to processors sold to 244c to average 211c/kg. Medium weight 3 score cows sold to 266c to average 250c, a small number of prime heavyweight cows topped at 268c to average 265c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export sold to 298c most sales from 268c to 282c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors reached 296c, averaging 241c to 282c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

The supply of cattle has once again increased with 2700 penned in a prime only sale. Quality was mixed comprising of plainer conditioned lines and northern males, however one very good quality line of young bullocks and small lines of heavy prime cows were present. Buyer attendance was good comprising of all processors,  regular feeders, one live exporter and opportunity restockers.  Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Richmond, Prairie, Ayr, local and coastal areas.

Despite the large offering, most classes attracted strong demand with values mostly firm throughout. Medium grown steers to processors lifted 15c to 29c, while heavier steers slipped up to 18c, medium weight 3 score cows eased 4c and heavy aged bullocks trended up to 14c lower.

Yearling steers to feed above 330kg averaged 285c selling to 288c, steers above 400kg to the trade sold to 304c to average 303c/kg. Yearling heifers to the trade made from 246c to 270c/kg.  A good sample of grown steers to processors above 400kg reached 296c to average 271c and steers above 500kg sold to 315c to average 305c to 312c/kg. Heavy grown steers above 600kg sold to 306c to average 305c/kg. Grown heifers to processors made to 254c to average 229c to 248c/kg.

A large sample of 3 and 4 score heavy full mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 310c to average 299c/kg. Plain conditioned cows returning to the paddock sold to 200c to average 188c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors made to 250c to average 244c, 3 scores sold to 272c to average 252c to 266c/kg.  A good sample of prime heavyweight cows topped at 285c to average 276c/kg. Heavy bulls suitable for live export made from 254c to 278c, bulls to processors sold from 240c to 272c/kg.

A store sale scheduled for Friday has 4,600 head booked.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

The supply of cattle fell by more than 850 for a yarding of 2112 cattle.  Quality was very mixed, consisting of fewer numbers of heavy prime bullocks and cows and increased numbers of bulls and small mixed lines of store steers and heifers. All regular processors were in attendance and operating, supported by one live exporter and one feeder operator. Cattle were drawn from Croydon, Richmond, Ingham, local and coastal areas.

Quality lines continued to attract solid demand, with lesser quality types difficult to sell. Bullocks improved 5c to 9c, lightweight cows lifted 17c, medium weights firm to 4c better and bulls averaged 6c to 15c lower.

Suitably weaned heifers returning to grass sold to 240c to average 240c, limited numbers of processor types averaged 190c/kg. Better quality yearling steers above 200kg to restockers made from 264c to 292c, steers above 280kg also made 292c/kg. Steers above 280kg to feed reached 308c averaging 306c and steers suitable for live export topped at 308c to average 306c/kg. Yearling heifers above 280kg to feed sold to 256c to average 225c to 245c/kg. Heifers above 330kg to processors made to 272c to average 252c/kg.
Grown steers above 400kg suitable for live export sold to 304c, most around 294c, trade types reached 300c to average 295c/kg. Heavy steers above 500kg sold to 314c to average 299c/kg. Good quality grown heifers to the trade made to 288c averaging from 255c to 269c/kg. 

Heavy full mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 328c, averaging 306c to 327c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows made to 250c to average 230c, 3 scores reached 268c, averaging from 252c to 264c and a small number of prime heavyweight cows made 268c multiple times to average 266c/kg.

Heavy bulls to live export reached 304c averaging 274c to 280c and processor bulls made from  208c to 298c/kg.

Pens of cows and calves sold to $925 per unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

The supply of cattle fell by more than 700 for a yarding of 2450 cattle. Quality was very mixed, with fewer numbers of good prime cows and several small lines of store cattle.  Buyer attendance was good with one additional southern processor and several opportunity restockers. Cattle were drawn from Burketown and Normanton, south to The Belyando, local and coastal areas.

Firm demand for many classes saw quality related price changes, with better quality lines improving 5c to 15c/kg. Light steers and heifers met limited demand, while yearling steers returning to the paddock improved 30c to 50c/kg.

Young steers to restockers averaged 246c, selling to 264c, similar heifers to processors averaged 160c/kg.  Light yearling steers to restockers made to 266c, averaging 220c to 258c and steers above 280kg averaged 200c/kg. A good sample of steers above 400kg to feed sold to and averaged 238c/kg. A large sample of heifers above 200kg returning to the paddock reached 228c to average 201c and heifers above 280kg averaged 195c/kg. Yearling heifers above 400kg to the trade sold to 238c to average 228c/kg.

Grown steers above 400kg to feed made to 232c to average 213c, steers to processors reached 235c to average from 224c to 230c/kg. Grown heifers to the trade made to 218c to average 213c/kg.

An increased supply of heavy bullocks to export slaughter topped at an isolated 250c, the majority averaging 225c to 231c/kg. A larger offering of lightweight 2 score cows to processors sold to 172c to average 162c, medium weight 2 score cows made to 180c to average 171c and 3 score cows reached 210c to average from 184c to 194c/kg. A good sample of prime heavyweight cows topped at 224c to average 206c/kg. Medium weight bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 226c, most sales from 184c to 218c, a small number heavy bulls sold to 210c/kg.

Small mixed quality lines of cows and calves sold from $850 to $1,025/unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

The supply of cattle fell by 748 head to 3,537 this week, largely due to a controversial council decision to cap numbers to accommodate two live exporter bookings for yard space. Quality was variable throughout, however some very good lines of heavy prime cows and bullocks were on offer, along with some very good vealer steers and heifers. Two major processors were again absent from the buyer panel, however southern processor and feeder orders continued along with one additional central processor and two live exporters. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Burketown, Croydon, Georgetown, Mt Garnet, Julia Ck, Ingham, Ayr, local and coastal areas.

Demand for mixed sex calves was strong throughout, with some very good steers returning to grass topping at 436.2c, with a large sample averaging above 400c, while light heifer calves returning to the paddock sold to 432.2c, most averaging 369c/kg. Vealer steers to restockers sold to 396.2c averaging from 380 to 388c/kg. Vealer heifers to processors reached 374.2c, to average 366c, while those to feed sold to 300c/kg. Yearling steers to back grounders reached 364.2c, to average 340c to 356c, while restockers paid to 370.2c, with most sales above 360c/kg. Yearling heifers were of mixed quality, with better bred pens to feed selling to 319.2c, to average from 302c to 314c/kg.

Increased numbers of grown steers to feed sold to 344.2c, and grown heifers to the trade reached 296.2c, to average 272c to 282c/kg. Heavy bullocks to export processors topped at 330c multiple times, to average 313c, while suitable pens to live export also reached 330c, to average above 325c/kg. Continued strong demand for cows saw medium weight 2 scores to processors sell to 255.2c, to average 230c, and 3 score cows averaged 253c to 267c, topping at 274c/kg. Strong demand for heavy bulls to live export resulted in a top of 328.2c, averaging 313c to 319c, while young males returning to grass reached 414.2c, to average 340c to 398c/kg. A small number of good quality cows and calves sold from $1,380 to 1,400/unit.

The supply of cattle fell by 580 for a yarding 1870 head. Quality was mostly good throughout, with a similar number of prime cattle to last sale, however store pens consisted of many smaller lines. Only three regular processors were in attendance and operating, supported by one live exporter, regular feeders and opportunity retsockers.  Cattle were drawn from Burketown, Richmond, Greenvale, Harvey’s Range, local and coastal areas.

Reduced demand for prime cattle saw values ease with bullocks down 10-18c, cows 3 to 12c lower and heavy bulls averaged 10-20c less.

Young suitably weaned steers to backgrounders averaged 253c, selling to 282c. Similar heifers to processors made to 174c to average 170c/kg. Light yearling steers returning to the paddock made to 268c, averaging from 232c to 252c, steers above 280kg sold to 262c to average 246c/kg. Yearling heifers were insufficient to reliable quote and sold according to quality.

Grown steers above 400kg to the trade sold to 225c to average 214c, heavy grown steers reached 228c to average 221c/kg.  A good supply of grown heifers to the trade sold to 228c to average from 203c to 221c/kg.

A mixed quality sample of heavy full mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 233c to average from 213c to 227c/ kg.  A large sample of medium weight 3 score cows to processors sold to 202c to average from 172c to 188c and a small number of prime heavyweight cows averaged 195c/kg.

Medium weight bulls to live export sold from 236c to 244c, heavy bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 246c multiple times to average 241c and processor bulls averaged 196c/kg.

Several good quality small lines of cows and calves sold from $1,000 to $1,240 per unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

The supply of cattle eased by 595 head on a fortnight ago to 618 mixed quality cattle. Isolated storms across much of the supply area reduced numbers of many store lines, affecting buyer participation. Only three regular processors were in operation along with opportunity restockers, backgrounder and feeder buyers. The limited supply of prime cattle saw values increase 14c to 20c/kg, with only a small number of pens of suitable weight fro processors. Most store lines were up to 40c/kg easier on last sale. Cattle were mostly drawn from the local area.

Mixed sex calves to restockers sold to 466.2c to average 441c and processor types averaged 414c/kg. Vealer steers returning to the paddock topped at 458.2c to average 443c/kg. Prime vealer heifers to processors sold to 416.2c to average 408c/kg. A small number of yearling steers to feed sold to 407.2c to average 404c and yearling heifers to feed reached 354.2c, while backgrounder heifers made to 366.2c/kg. Grown heifers to the trade sold to 250.2c to average 246c/kg.  

A small number of bullocks to live export made 356.2c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows topped at 266.2c to average 251c, with heavy 3 score cows topping at 308.2c for a single cow, to average 265c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export made to 318.2c with most selling from 280c to 295c/kg. Light males to restockers sold to 436.2c to average 406c/kg.

The supply of cattle continues to increase with 3,276 cattle penned, 177 more than last week. Quality was generally good throughout the yarding which featured increased numbers of heavy prime cows, bulls and bullocks, supported by some excellent store steers. The regular buyer panel operated strongly throughout all categories with increased feeder orders actively supported by central and northern backgrounders. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Croydon, Georgetown, Richmond, Hugenden, Ingham, local and coastal areas. Heavy grown steers and bullocks were up 7c to 9c from last sale and heavy bulls held firm to 10c/kg higher. 

Steer calves to restockers sold to a top of 486c and crossbred heifer calves reached 466c with mixed sexes averaging 454c/kg. Light vealer steers to central backgrounders sold to 500c to average 444c, with a large sample of excellent quality heavy vealer steers making 466c to average 456c/kg. Vealer heifers in forward condition to restockers sold to a top of 408c, averaging from 393c to 404c and trade types averaged near 382c/kg. Yearling steers mostly sold to feed, with those above 280kg reaching 390c to average 381c and steers above 330kg to feed made to a top of 414c to average 366c to 383c/kg. Increased numbers of suitable yearling heifers to feed above 330kg sold to 400c to average 365c/kg. 

Good quality grown steers to feed topped at 388c to average 355c and trade types averaging 358c/kg. Greater numbers of grown heifers attracted strong feeder demand selling to 332c to average 325c and heavy trade types reached 326c to average above 313c/kg. Heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 358c, with most averaging 355c to 356c/kg. Cows met very strong demand on all categories with many processors jostling to fill orders. Medium weight cows to processors sold to 280 and averaged 269c, while score 3 cows reached 288c averaging 282c/kg. Greater numbers of prime heavy weight cows topped at 292c to average 288c/kg. Good lines of cows to active restocker orders sold to 290c, averaging 277c to 283c/kg. Heavy bulls to feed destined for live export sold to a top of 348c with most selling from 308c to 340c/kg. Feeder weight bulls were keenly sought after, topping at 426c to average 371c to 396c/kg. Very good quality cows and calves sold to $2,050, with most selling from $1,725 to $1,950/unit. 

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

The supply of cattle continues to increase with 2,017 cattle penned in a prime only sale. Quality was mixed with some large single vendor lines of heavy prime bullocks and cows, with increased numbers of plain conditioned northern cows and bulls. All regular processors were in attendance and operating, supported by two southern feeder orders. Cattle were predominantly drawn from Mt Isa, Burketown, Normanton and Georgetown, with smaller lines from the local area.

Good quality grown steers lifted 23c and heifers averaged mostly firm, prime cows eased 6c and heavy bulls to processors finished 10c easier. An increased supply of grown steers above 400kg to feed averaged 410c reaching 432.2c multiple times, while heavy steers to the trade sold to and averaged 384c/kg. Grown heifers to feed reached 396.2c to average 357c to 380c/kg.

There were more than 700 heavy bullocks on offer. Heavy bullocks to processors topped at 398.2c to average 386c to 398c/kg. Increased numbers of plain conditioned cows to feed sold to 330.2c to average 316c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors reached 358.2c to average 336c and 3 score cows topped at 378.2c to average 351c to 339c/kg. Bulls to processors sold to 360.2c to average 339c/kg.  

A store sale scheduled for Friday has 4,500 cattle booked.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

The smaller yarding was mainly the result of the short trading week, although all the regular buyers were in attendance. There were some good quality stock available and light 1 and 2 score steers and cows were of a better standard than previous weeks. The better quality medium weight steers were 4c dearer and some poorer grades eased 5c/kg. Heavy steers were well above last weeks rates. Poorer heifers were slightly dearer with insufficient good grades to quote. Light poor gains gained 4c while the medium weights eased 1c to 2c/kg. Bulls were mostly 2c/kg cheaper. 

Light steers sold to an isolated 140c with most around 117c/kg. The medium weight C3s topped at 174.2c to average 162.2c while the large number of D3s averaged 137c/kg. A small number of heavy steers peaked at 176.2c and averaged 173.2c/kg.  The best heifers made to 121.2c/kg. 

Light D1 cows made to 89.2c and averaged 86.5c with the best stock to 111.2c/kg. Medium weight cows sold to 129.2c and the D3s averaged 120.1c with most D2s around 107c/kg. Light bulls averaged 81c and heavy weights sold to 108.2c/kg.

The small penning sold to most of the regular buyers. The limited number made an accurate quote difficult and quality was reported to be poor. Light steers, and heifers along with medium weight cows were in the greatest numbers. 

Medium weight steers reached 110c while the heavy steers and bullocks ranged from 80c to 97c/kg.  The heifers were all of poor quality and most averaged below 70c/kg. Medium weight cows sold to 81.2c and a fair sample averaged 79.7c/kg.

The slightly smaller yarding was offered to a full panel of buyers. The quality was improved on the last sale and when this is combined with the very active buyers values improved for most categories. Most of the cattle offered were from local areas, but a small number were also penned from the Northern Territory. 

The steers and bullocks received the largest gains for the day. The better quality medium weights managed to top at 220.2c, but it was the heavy steers that were the highlight of the sale after reaching 225.2c/kg. All of the heavy steers and bullocks returned above $1,100/head.

A large number of light heifers were offered with the better quality descriptions selling to 185c/kg. Most of the cows offered were light weights. The D2s made to 169.2c as some very good medium weights topped at 191.2c/kg. 

Nearly all of the bulls offered were light weights reaching 179.2c with the heavy weights making to 193.2c/kg.

The slightly increased yarding was offered to the usual field of buyers. Cattle were drawn mainly from the local supply areas and producers who did offer stock were well rewarded. The quality of the yarding is slipping, but there was a small number of good pens scattered throughout. These good pens sold to fierce competition with record prices resulting. 

The light steers sold to 197.2c as the medium weights reached 208.5/kg. The highlight of the sale was the heavy steers selling to a record 229.2c/kg and over 100 head averaging over 222c/kg. 

The large numbers of heifers were unable to sustain last weeks gains, however the better types did sell to 193.2c/kg. The cow market was also cheaper in places with the falling quality being the major factor. A large number of light cows averaged 150.8c as the medium weight D3s topped at 198.2c/kg. 

The bulls were offered in large numbers with the light and heavy weights receiving further gains. The top of the heavy weights sold to 203.2c/kg and returned over $1,600/head.

The slightly increased yarding was made up completely of export descriptions and it was reported as improved on last weeks quality. Most of the usual buyers were present and active, however values were mixed with the bulls receiving the largest gains. 

The limited numbers of light steers improved 4c to average 133c, as the medium weights topped at 141.2c/kg. Both the heavy steers and bullocks sold to 156.2c, as the large numbers of heavy steers averaged 145.6c/kg. 

The light heifers had a mixed day, with the D2s receiving a gain, yet large numbers of D3s suffered a fall to average 132.2c/kg. The cows also had a mixed day, with the light D2s slipping 5c to average 109.6c, while spirited competition on the large number of medium weight D3s saw prices top at 149.2c/kg. The heavy cows reached 145.2c to average 142.9c/kg. 

The medium bulls sold to 148.2c, as the heavy weights topped at 152.2c to return over $1,100/head.

The selling agents sold 758 prime cattle over the live weight scales at Charters Towers on Thursday.  The majority of the yarding sold at dearer rates.  

In the export cattle, medium weight steers sold to 124.8c/kg for a good sample of D2s and these averaged 117.7c/kg to be 2c dearer than last week.  Heavy steers sold to 126.2c and were up to 6c/kg dearer.  

A big numbers of heifers sold to a top of 111.2c/kg.  Cows were plentiful in the yarding and were recorded to 107.2c for a large sample of D2 cows, and these averaged 90.8c/kg to be around 4c easier.  Bulls sold up to 105.2c/kg.

The selling agents in Charters Towers sold 850 prime cattle on Thursday, a rise of 562 head compared with last week.  

The D1 light weight steers sold to 120.6c, medium weight steers D2 made to 128.2c to average 123.6c/kg. A fair sample of heifers, D2 sold to 120c and these averaged 116.2c/kg.  While best of the heavier steers and ox peaked at 128.2c/kg. 

Cows were well supplied and the best of the heavy cows, D2 sold up to 109.8c/kg for a good sample.  The heavy bulls sold in a range from one dollar to 114.2c to average 110.3c/kg.

The selling agents in Charters Towers sold 850 prime cattle at their weekly market on Thursday. Prices were generally easier this week, in line with other southern Queensland auctions.

Lighter steers in the export classes sold to 108.2c/kg in several instances.  Medium stees weighing to 500kg, B3, sold up to 125.2c to average 110.7c/kg.  Heavy steers reached 126.2c for a large sample of B4, while a few other bullocks in the heavy weight range made to 125.2c/kg.

The best of the export weight heifers sold up to 119.6c/kg.  Cows were well supplied, and sold to 113.6c for a large sample of B3 cows, and these averaged 95.4c/kg.  Bulls met an excellent market and reached 121.2c/kg.

The selling agents in Charters Towers sold 410 prime cattle on Wednesday where all descriptions sold to an excellent market.  

The small yarding resulted in medium weight steers making to 147.2c/kg for a large sample of B3s.  Heavy steers reached 148.2c and a few other heavier ox peaked at 147.2c/kg.  The best of the heifers sold to 114.2c/kg.  

Cows made up a fair proportion of the offering and sold to 118.2c and bulls sold to 120.2c/kg.

The second special sale in a fortnight saw 1,385 cattle penned 2,768 fewer than the previous sale. Despite some late withdrawals, the offering consisted of very good quality steers and heifers, with some PTIC heifers, cows and young males. The buyer gallery was limited to one live exporter, one feeder buyer and a small number of restockers and backgrounders. Cattle were drawn from Normanton, Palmerston, Dimbulah, Greenvale, Tully, Ravenswood, local and coastal areas.

Light steer calves sold firm to restockers, while a large sample of vealer steers sold eased by more than 20c/kg. Yearling steers mostly sold to feed, easing by 15c/kg, while grown steers sold firm. Vealer heifers met limited demand, easing by up to 55c/kg, for majority penned. Yearling heifers to live export sold firm and similar heifers returning to grass improved by 4c/kg. PTIC heifers and cows attracted limited buyer interest. Steers calves sold to 268c to average 255c, while vealer steers made to 270c to average 259c/kg for the better quality types. The main run of vealer heifers sold to 172c to average lower at 165c/kg. Light yearling steers to feed destined for live export made to 250c to average 244c, while steers above 280kg averaged 242c/kg. Steers above 330kg sold to 261c to average 258c/kg. Grown steers to feed sold to 259c/kg. Yearling heifers to live export sold to 181c multiple times to average more than 178c and heifers returning to grass made to 174c to average 170c/kg.

PTIC heifers sold from $470 to $550/head. PTIC cows sold for $600/head, with PTE cows returning to the paddock for 142c/kg. Very good quality young males returning to the paddock made to 268c to average 261c and similar types to feed destined for live export averaged 264c/kg.

The rise of cattle prices over recent weeks saw the yarding increase by 462 head to 3,454 cattle this week. Some very good lines of cows and grown heifers were accompanied by some large lines of northern steers and heifers. The prime market saw values for bullocks ease 4c to 7c/kg and cows were back 10c to 16c/kg, in line with southern markets and easier grid values being offered by processors. One regular processor was again absent this week, notably reducing competition on better finished heavy cattle. Store cattle again sold very strongly to western and central restockers and feeder buyers, despite prices easing in the prime market. Cattle were drawn from Normanton, Croydon, Georgetown, Tully, Home Hill, Woodstock, local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers were of very good quality and condition with the best types selling to 386.2c/kg to western restockers. Yearling steers eased slightly on last sale, with lighter types selling to 370c to restockers and prices reaching 348c for heavier types to feeder buyers, to average 334.1c/kg. Vealer heifers sold stronger on last sale, with restockers and feeder buyers active on better conditioned types which sold to 344.2c/kg. Some large heavier lines of northern heifers were dearer to feeder buyers which sold to 322.2c, to average 304.7c, while restockers paid to 348.2c/kg for lighter types.

Grown steers sold to feeder buyers for a top of 329c/kg. Heavy 3 score bullocks to slaughter were fewer in number, following easing prices and buyer competition last sale, and sold to 299.2c/kg. Live exporters were active on most lines which sold to 292.2c, to average 284.5c/kg. Lighter, less finished types reached 268.2c/kg. Another good quality yarding 3 and 4 score cows saw values ease 10c to 13c and prices for medium weight 2 score cows eased by 14c to 16c/kg. Prices for heavier types eased on last sale as a result of less processor competition, topping at 238.2c and averaging 227.8c/kg. Some very good 4 score cows sold to 246c/kg. Processors were selective on 2 score cows which sold to 235.2c and averaged 217.6c/kg. Good heavy 3 score bulls to slaughter sold to 272.2c, while a live exporter paid to 271.2c/kg for medium and heavy weight bulls. Restockers paid too 396.2c for lighter young males, 27c/kg less than last sale. Another good offering of cows and calves sold to $1,420, with most selling from $1,220 to $1,380/unit.

The recent uplift in prices has seen a significant increase in the supply of cattle, resulting in a prime only sale with 2328 cattle penned. Quality was mixed, however there were several large lines of good quality heavy bullocks and cows. All processors were in attendance and operating, supported by one live exporter and regular feeders. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Burketown, Mt Garnet, Hughenden local and coastal areas. 

There was only a limited number of yearling cattle due to a store sale being held on Friday. Processor demand  was strong throughout, although most categories eased on last week’s gains primarily due to the increased supply and some pens lacking weight. Grown steers eased 15c, heifers averaged 6c to 22c lower, heavy bullocks fell 17c, medium weight cows averaged 3c to 16c lower, however heavy bulls to processors improved by up to 20c/kg. 

A small sample of yearling heifers above 280kg to processors sold to 260c to average 258c, heifers above 330kg to feed averaged 257c, while heifers above 400kg to the trade sold to 278c to average 276c/kg. 

Grown steers above 400kg to feed sold to 282c, trade types made to 318c to average 294c/kg. Increased numbers of heavy grown steers above 500kg to processors reached 320c to average 308c and a good sample of steers above 600kg also topped at 320c to average 312c/kg. Mixed quality small lines of grown heifers to the trade sold to 268c to average 248c to 266c/kg.

Heavy full mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 328c to average 307c, lighter bullocks averaged 295c/kg. Lightweight 2 score cows to processors made to 252c to average 247c, 3 scores averaged 252c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows sold to an isolated 275c, most 240c to 250c, 3 scores reached 288c to average 263c to 273c/kg. A good number of prime heavyweight 3 and 4 score cows sold to 288c to average 273c to 280c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export 286c, averaging 253c to 263c, processor bulls reached 298c to average 238c to 268c/kg.

A small number of cows and calves sold for $775per unit.

Approximately 2,200 cattle have been booked for a store sale on Friday.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

The recent trend of declining numbers saw 793 cattle drawn by Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents, representing a reduction of 631 head on last sale. Some odd lines of well finished prime cows and bullocks improved 6c to 8c/kg, while mixed lines of store steers and heifers had limited demand, seeing values ease across most lines. One processor returned along with a feeder buyer, which improved competition throughout the sale. Cattle came from Mount Isa, Richmond, Georgetown, Mount Garnet, Woodstock, as well as local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers comprised many small mixed lines. A line of northern steer calves sold to 210c to restockers, who also secured better bred medium and heavy vealers up to 244c/kg. Very few yearling steers were on offer, receiving limited demand from the gallery. Medium weight steers to live export sold for 220c, while 330kg plus steers going to backgrounders also made 220c/kg. A small number of vealer heifers in mixed lines sold to irregular values, with better quality heifers to slaughter making 193/kg. One northern line of light heifer calves to restockers sold for 202c/kg. Yearling heifers comprised of many small lines, with processors and feeder buyers active throughout. Heifers above 280kg to slaughter made to 211c and heifers above 330kg sold at 199c/kg. Heifers above 330kg to feed made 212c and heavy heifers above 400kg sold at 214c/kg.

Fewer numbers of heavy export bullocks improved 6c, topping at 256c to average 252c, while medium weight bullocks to slaughter reached 239c/kg. A selection of heavy grown steers for slaughter also sold to 239c/kg. Plain bullocks to slaughter sold at 233c, to average 206c/kg.

Heavy cows were in fewer numbers, however some small lines of good heavy yielding cows were on offer. Better quality, heavy 3 score cows to slaughter sold to 197c to average 193c, improving 9c/kg on last sale. Extra heavy 3 score cows sold to 198c/kg. Heavy D muscled cows topped at 195c to average 179c and 2 score cows to slaughter averaged 161c/kg. The return of one processor saw values improve for medium weight 2 score cows by up to 30c to average 136c/kg, with cows showing improved weight and yield on previous week. The absence of live exporters saw values decrease by up to 20c for heavy bulls, with those to slaughter topping at 221c to average 204c/kg. Heavy bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 240c, with most sales making from 207c to 224c, while medium weight bulls to feed sold to 200c, to average 148c/kg. A selection of bulls weighing 280-330kg going to live export sold to 224c/kg. Young males to restockers sold to 244c/kg. Small lines of good quality cows and calves sold to $890/unit.

The prime cattle component at Charters Towers this week totalled 1,109 head.  

In the steers, best of the medium weights sold to 118c to average 107c/kg.  While a good sample of D3s in the bullocks reached 125c/kg.  A large sample in the heifers sold to 107.2c/kg with other D3s to 111.2c to average 104.6c/kg. 

Cows were in good supply, best of the heavy cows selling to 110.2c/kg and bulls sold to 114.2c to average 109.4c/kg.

The opening sale of the year saw 1,213 mixed quality cattle penned, comprising of less than one third prime cattle. Most slaughter lines generally lacked weight and prices eased accordingly throughout. Prices across most prime categories were 20c to 30c lower than the close of 2020, however prices for light steer and heifer categories improved by up to 150c/kg. Despite a large gallery attendance only three regular processors were in attendance and operated selectively, along with two feeder buyers and opportunity southern restockers and backgrounders. Limited local buyer activity was noted. Cattle were mostly drawn from the local supply area, with some from western areas.  

Light steer calves to southern restockers sold to a new record 616.2c averaging 605c, with a heifer line also selling to a record 620.2c to southern restockers to average 613c/kg. A large sample of vealer steers above 200kg to southern backgrounders sold to 534.2c, to average 514c/kg. Vealer heifers to processors sold to 400.2c with most sales from 386c to 396c/kg. A limited number of yearling steers to feed reached 392.2c, with most selling at 380.2c, while mixed quality small lines of yearling heifers made to 340.2c to average from 326c to 328c/kg. Grown steers to feed sold to 386.2c, averaging from 358c to 381c/kg. A very small sample of grown heifers to the trade sold to 282.2c and heifers to feed averaged near 280c/kg.

A small number of bullocks to export slaughter sold to 340.2c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows eased throughout, with suitable processor pens selling to 234.2c and cows to feed sold to 252.2c to average 245c/kg. Heavy 3 score cows to processors topped at 286.2c to average from 249c to 262c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export sold to 366.2c, with most sales 350c to 358c, while medium weight bulls to live export feeder orders sold to 373.2c/kg.

The opening sale of 2022 saw 1596 cattle penned in very hot conditions. Quality was generally good with many lines offered due to the extending and deteriorating dry season across many areas. All regular processors and feeder buyers were present and operating at reduced rates on all lines relative to the close of 2021. Restocker presence was limited and participated only on better quality lines. Yearling steers averaged 20c to 40c lower, yearling heifers sold firm to 10c easier, grown steers averaged 20c lower, cows eased by up to 30c and bulls eased 30c to 40c/kg on last sale. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Julia Ck, Richmond, The Lynd, Pentland, Mt Garnet, local and coastal areas.

Good quality vealer steers to restockers sold to 758.2c to average 647c, while good vealer heifers to the trade mostly sold from 600c to 614c/kg. A line of light yearling steers above 200kg to backgrounders sold for 722.2c and steers above 280kg to feed reached 672.2c to average 611c to 672c/kg. Steer above 330kg to feed topped at 672.2 to average 591c/kg. Good quality yearling heifers above 330kg to restockers sold to 528.2c to average above 512c and similar heifers to feed sold to 522.2c to average 468c to 490c/kg. 

A limited supply of grown steers above 400kg to feed sold to 430.2c to average 414c to 424c/kg. A small number of grown steers to the trade topped at 408.2c to average 384c to 400c/kg. A good supply of good quality grown heifers to feed sold to 472.2c to average 390c to 440c/kg. A small number of bullocks sold relative to quality.

Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 346.2c to average 340c and 3 scores reached 400.2c to average from 346c to 359c/kg. Processor activity on bulls was limited with suitable types reaching 355.2c/kg. Bulls above 400kg to feed sold to 402.2c to average 350c to 400c/kg. Young males returning to the paddock sold to 710.2c to average 597c to 685c/kg.

Good quality cows and calves sold from $2,300 to $2,700/unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

The opening sale of 2019 for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents comprised of 1,138 mixed quality cattle, with several lines showing the effects of a continuing dry season, particularly lines from western areas. Two regular processors were absent, along with one feeder buyer. Additionally, there were several restockers and backgrounders present, but they were inactive, and there is still an absence of any reliable wet season rain. Cattle were drawn from McKinlay, Pentland, Ingham, local and coastal areas.

Some very good lines of vealer steers met strong demand, selling to 277c, to average 252c, while lighter types sold to 244c/kg. Heavier vealer steers to feed destined for live export sold to 258c/kg. Yearling steers comprised of some good quality western lines, topping at 253c, averaging 246c/kg for those returning to grass. The yearling steers to feed destined for live export sold to 244c, to average 243c/kg. A small sample of very good yearling steers to processors made to 277c/kg. Vealer heifers met limited demand, with very good quality suitably weaned heifers to restockers selling to 180c, to average 169c, with many lighter lines selling from 132c to 160c/kg. Yearling heifers returning to grass made to 200c, to average 181c, while larger framed plainer heifers to feed sold to 194c, to average 179c/kg.

An insufficient number of bullocks were penned to reliably quote, with single sales to 283c, while sales to processors made from 265c to 274c/kg. Grown steers were also in limited numbers, selling to 271c/kg. Limited numbers of C3 and C4 score cows sold to 231c, to average 223c, and D scores sold to 208c, to average 197c/kg. Increased numbers of heavy 2 score cows sold to 219c, to average 182c, with lighter cows to restockers selling to 160c/kg. A small number of grown heifers to processors made to 231c/kg. A small number of heavy bulls sold to 259c to feed destined for lived export, and young light males returning to grass sold to 212c/kg. Light conditioned cows and calves sold for $530/unit.

The opening sale in Charters Towers for 2020 saw 1,243 cattle penned in very humid conditions following scattered storms in the area overnight. All rates were stronger than the close of 2019, with cows showing the greatest increase in price. Minimal numbers of prime bullocks were on offer, with quality of most cattle generally good with one large consignment of northern cattle, supported by several small local lines. Not all regular processors were in attendance in a large gallery of onlookers, supported by two feeder buyers, a central backgrounder and opportunity restockers.

Very good quality medium weight vealer steers to restockers sold to 346c to average 335c/kg. Yearling steers above 330kg returning to the paddock made to 370c to average 362c, while steers to feed sold to 379c to average 370c/kg. Vealer heifers to trade sold for 330c and yearling heifers sold to 347c to average 334c/kg. Yearling heifers to feed sold to 304c to average 279c/kg. 

Grown steers to restockers sold to 356c and grown heifers returning to paddock reached 254c to average 203c/kg. Heavy grown heifers to processors topped at 359c to average 356c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors topped at 272c to average 263c and heavy 3 score cows sold to 279c/kg for similar average. Extra heavy 4 score cows sold to 289c to average 276c/kg. Heavy bulls to feed destined for live export sold from 275 to 300c/kg.

The opening sale for the year attracted  878 cattle. Quality was mixed, comprising of limited numbers of well finished prime cattle and several small lines of store steers and heifers, with many in plain condition.  Three regular processors operated at stronger rates than last year, supported by two regular feeder operators and opportunity restockers. Cattle were drawn Hughenden to Einsaleigh and the local area.
 
A small sample of vealer steers to restockers sold to 320c to average 309c, with light heifers making to 198c to average 190c/kg. A small sample of yearling steers above 330kg to feed reached 264c to average 258c/kg.
Yearling heifers above 280kg to feed sold to 246c to average 220c, restocker lines reached 272c to average 229c/kg. 

Limited numbers of grown steers to feed sold to 276c to average 266c/kg. A good sample of grown heifers returning to the paddock sold to 270c to average near 236c/kg, a small number of heifers to the trade made to 272c to average 270c/kg.

A limited number of full mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 274c to average 265c/ kg.
Medium weight 3 score cows sold to 266 to average 251-256c, isolated single cows to 270c/kg. A pen of prime heavyweight cows made 252c/kg.  Heavy bulls to processors reached 270c to average 257c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

The opening sale for 2023 attracted 1141 cattle.  Quality was very mixed, with a few good pens of heavy prime cows, a good number of heavy bulls, supported by one very good local line of yearling steers.  The gallery consisted of all regular processors, opportunity feeders  and restockers, along with a large number of interested onlookers. Cattle were drawn from Richmond, Pentland, Tully and mostly the local area.
 
Values for most categories ease on  the close of 2022, however demand for quality
lines of young was strong from restockers and feeders.

Good quality yearling steers returning to the paddock topped at 460.2c to average 451c and suitable feeder types averaged 358c/kg. Grown steers to feed above 400kg sold to 370c to average from 338c to 350c/kg. Heavy grown steers to the trade sold to 340.2c to average 328c/kg.  Yearling heifers above 280kg returning to the paddock for breeding topped at 370.2c to average 360c and heifers to feed reached 394 to average 357c/kg. Young bullocks to export slaughter sold to 330.2c to average 326c/kg.

A small supply of medium weight 3 score cows topped at 300.2c to average 280c/kg.  Heavy bulls to processors sold to 338.2c to average 306c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

The much larger yarding compared to last weeks ANZAC Day market saw a large number of very poor quality stock penned. There was only limited competition from a field of buyers that was missing a number of regulars. The overall availability of a large number of stock and lack of genuine quality at the sale were the main factors in a cheaper market. 

The medium weight steers sold to a top of 126.2c and a fair sample averaged 5c cheaper at 123.9c/kg. There was some fair quality heavy steers available and the C2s reached 137.2c and averaged 135.4c/kg. The poorer heavy steers lost considerable ground and D3s averaged 124.6c/kg. A limited number of heavy bullocks sold to a top of 143.2c/kg.

The heifers were around 4c cheaper and the D2s averaged 102.1c/kg. The cow yarding saw values drop and there were no cows sold that made over 100c/kg. The best cows sold to a top of 95.2c and a large number of medium weight E2s averaged 77.2c/kg.

The move to a Wednesday sale saw an increase in numbers with nearly all stock sold over the scales. Quality was similar to recent weeks and a normal standard for this period of the year. All the regular buyers were in attendance and keen to purchase stock. Values were generally dearer with steers up to 18c higher while the cows mainly gained 18c to 23c/kg. 

Light steers sold to 125.2c and a small number averaged 118.7c/kg. The medium weights topped at 142.2c with the best stock averaging 141.9c, though poorer grades saw most sales around 125.7c/kg. Heavy steers reached 147.2c/kg. Heifers sold to 118.2c and a good number saw most sales around 108c/kg. 

A large number of light cows were penned and they topped at 95c, though most averaged around 85c/kg.  A number of very poor cows went against the dearer trend and averaged below 60c/kg. Medium weight cows peaked at 125.2c and the D3s averaged 120.3c while the D2s recorded some of the largest gains and averaged 107.6c/kg. Heavy bulls made to 117.2c/kg.

The larger yarding sold to the regular field of buyers plus some added competition and values were generally dearer. Steers were generally of better quality while there was still a fair supply of light and poor quality cows and heifers available. Steers improved 2c to 3c and heifers were generally slightly cheaper while the cows gained 4c to 11c/kg. 

Light steers topped at 117.2c and averaged 111.9c/kg. The medium weights were in the largest supply and topped at 136.2c with the better quality grades averaging 129.1c. The D2s saw most sales around 113c/kg. A small number of heavy steers and bullocks topped at 133.2c/kg. 

Heifers reached 122c and averaged 114.5c/kg. The light cows sold to 99.2c and most sold around 84c/kg. Medium weight cows topped at 112.2c and averaged 105.6c/kg.

The larger yarding followed the cheaper trend set at other centres, although not the extent experienced at some. There was a good number of fair quality cattle considering the size of the yarding although there was also a fair supply of poorer quality stock. Most of the regular buyers were in attendance and operated on a yarding dominated by medium and heavy weight steers along with medium weight cows.

The medium weight steers were slightly cheaper and the better quality stock averaged just under 130c while the majority averaged around 119c/kg. The heavy steers were of fair quality and averaged slightly cheaper at 132.6c after they reached 137.2c/kg. 

There were an insufficient number of heifers to provide a reliable quote. The light cows were all of poor quality and topped at 66.2c/kg. The best medium weights topped at 120.2c and over 20 percent of the total yarding were D3s that averaged 2c cheaper 108.3c/kg. 

The best heavy bulls sold to a top of 100.2c/kg.

The larger yarding compares to the sale of two weeks ago, and due to the small numbers at both sales an accurate trend is not possible. Steers dominated the yarding while heifers and cows were fairly represented. 

Light steers averaged 105.3c/kg while the medium weights were in the largest numbers. The better quality medium weights averaged 124.5c and reached 130.2c while a large number of D3s averaged 116.4c/kg. A pen of heavy steers sold for 126.2c/kg. 

The better quality heifers reached 132.2c although most of the lighter quality heifers averaged 106.7c/kg. Medium weight cows reached 100.2c and averaged 93.2c/kg.

The larger number was offered to the regular field of buyers and although quality was lacking, values improved for a large percentage of the yarding. The light steers lost ground while the medium weights eased slightly and heavy steers improved 4c/kg. Heifers traded 2c either side of firm while the cows gained 1c to 4c/kg. 

Light steers sold to 114.2c and averaged just under 100c/kg. The medium weight steers topped at 125.2c and averaged from 112c to 121.5c/kg. The heavy steers made to 135.2c, which saw most sales around 130c/kg. The heavy bullocks sold around 134c/kg. 

Heifers topped at 121.2c and most averaged around 113c/kg. The light cows in better condition averaged 88c while the poorer grades saw most sales around 58c/kg. Medium weight cows topped at 118.2c and the D3s averaged 106.5c while the heavy cows also sold to 118.2c/kg.

The large yardings continued, with numbers increasing by more than 500 to 3,831 cattle in Charters Towers under gloomy skies with light misty rain across much of the local area and a positive outlook for rain ahead. The supply of cows continued the recent upward trend with almost 1,800 penned in a yarding of mixed quality, given the large numbers being presented. The regular buyer panel was joined by one NSW processor and a southern backgrounder, supported by central and western backgrounders and feeder orders. Cattle were drawn from Northern Territory, Dimbulah, Burketown, Croydon, Georgetown, Julia Ck,  Richmond, Ingham, Belyando, local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers continued recent strong demand, however eased 14c, while similar heifers returning to paddock eased up to 40c/kg, most quality related, mostly to southern orders, while trade types sold firm. Light weight yearling steers to feed eased 15c with reduced numbers on offer, while better quality medium weights to feed eased by 2c/kg. Medium weight yearling heifers to feed increased by 10c to 30c/kg depending on quality. Grown heifers to feed improved by nearly 40c, with heavy heifers to the trade increasing by 10c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors lifted by 14c, heavy cows increased by 15c to 30c/kg. Heavy bulls to background feed and processors improved by 30c/kg.

Vealer steers returning to grass sold to 350.2c to average 329c for better quality types, while those above 280kg made to 362.2c to average 243c/kg. Some very good lines of vealer heifers to the trade sold to 305.2c to average above 283c, with restockers lines averaging 271c/kg. Yearling steers above 330kg to feed averaged from 283c to 305c, with heavy weight averaging 323c/kg. Yearling heifers to feed mostly sold from 280c to 310.2c, with lesser quality types below 250c/kg. 

Grown heifers to feed averaged 263.2c and heavier types to the trade averaged from 252c to 260c/kg. A consignment of averaged quality grown steers to feed averaged 241.2c/kg. Heavy 3 score bullocks to export processor reached 336.2c to average 330c, with suitable types to background feed for live export selling to 328.2c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows sold higher, topping at 246.2c to average 213c, while heavy 3 score cows sold to 272.2c to average near 256c/kg. Prime heavy weight cows made to 270.2c to average 266c/kg. Heavy bulls to background feed for live export sold to 334,2c, averaging 310c to 332c and bulls to processors sold to 336,2c to average above 290c/kg. A large line of very good quality cows and calves above 3mths sold for $1,440, with smaller lines making from $920 to $1,320/unit.

The large yarding of last week was maintained, with cattle being sourced from up to four hours away while large numbers were also being brought forward locally. Despite the increase in numbers, quality was similar with both steers and cows having a small proportion of plain lines offered. All major processors operated with cattle being sent to processing works around the state.

The quality of grown steers was aided by a large consignment from Mount Gravett as well as increased supplies from local regions. Medium weights ranged from 133.2c to 145c and a large supply of heavy 4 score steers sold from 150.2c to 163.2c/kg. The large number led to prices easing slightly as processors competed only to justify purchase levels. Bullock quality was as good as has been seen at this selling centre and prices ranged from 156.2c to 165.2c/kg to average over $1,000/head.

The cow quality was similar to the previous market and prices also maintained a firm trend. The greatest percentage of medium weights sold from 129.2c to 136.2c, while in comparison, lighter conditioned lightweights were discounted to average 118c/kg. A smaller number of heavyweights topped at 144.2c to average 142c/kg.

The large supply of stock continued with a return to a combined prime and store sale with 3,577 cattle penned. Quality was mixed featuring some very good lines of heavy cows and large lines of yearling steers, along with lesser quality northern pastoral lines. All regular processors were present and operating at increased rates along with one live exporter, feeders, backgrounders and opportunity restockers. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Northern cape, Georgetown, Julia Ck, Hughenden, Bowen, Ingham, local and coastal areas.

Light steer calves returning to the paddock sold to 592c with mixed sexes averaging 507c/kg. Light vealer steers to restockers reached 576c to average 544c, and a large sample of steers above 200kg reached 544c to average 477c/kg. Mixed quality vealer heifers to the trade sold to a top of 420c, while heifers above 280kg returning to the paddock averaged 444c/kg. Increased numbers of yearling steers sold to improved rates, with steers above 280kg returning to grass reaching 486c to average 444c, and those above 330kg to backgrounders topped at 490c to average 471c/kg. Heavy yearling steers to feed sold to 466c to average 420c/kg. Light yearling heifers to feed sold to 430c, while heifers above 330kg to feed reached 412c to average 390c/kg.

Large lines of grown steers to feed reached 435c to average from 386c to 396c/kg. Heavy steers to the trade reached 366c, averaging between 355c and 359c/kg. Grown heifers to the trade sold to 354c to average 349c/kg. Limited numbers of heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter reached a top of 366c to average from 337c to 364c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors continued the recent trend of price increases, reaching a top of 312c to average 297c and 3 scores sold to 326c multiple times to average between 311c and 320c/kg. Prime heavy weight cows topped at 328c to average 325c and a good line of heavy PTIC cows sold to 340c to average 330c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export topped at 380c to average 373c/kg. Light males returning to the paddock sold to 560c to average 461c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

The large supply of cattle continues with a return to a prime only sale that saw 1,876/head penned. A store sale on Friday has 2,900 cattle booked and the selling centre is currently at capacity with two live export consignments ready for shipping. Quality this week was very mixed, featuring a couple of good lines of heavy prime cows and grown steers along with some lesser quality northern types. All regular processors were in attendance and operating, albeit at reduced rates, along with central and southern feeder and backgrounder buyers and two live exporters. Grown steers improved by up to 8c while heavy cows eased by 8c and heavy bulls were 6c/kg cheaper. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Georgetown, Richmond, Pentland, local and coastal areas. 

Yearling steers above 400kg to feed sold to a top of 390c to average 387c, and yearling heifers above 330kg to feed, sold to 372c averaging 352c/kg. A good supply of grown steers met strong demand, with a central backgrounder adding to the gallery. Steers returning to the paddocks made to a top of 390c, averaging 373c, and suitable steers to live export topped at 370c to average from 360c to 368c/kg. Heavy steers to the trade sold to a top of 371c to average 370c, while a good selection of steers to feed topped at 406c, avergaing 389c/kg. Grown heifers sold according to quality with those to the trade reaching 322c/kg.    

A mixed offering of heavy full mouthed bullocks to export slaughter sold to a top of 370c/kg, however quality variations were reflected in the range in prices. Medium weight score cows to processors topped at 284c to average 261c, with score 3 cows selling to 290c to average 274c/kg. Prime heavy weight cows averaged 286c, while light conditioned cows to restockers sold to a top of 270c to average from 221c to 252c/kg. Increased numbers of heavy bulls to live export sold to 358c, averaging 350c, while feeder weight bulls reached 380c to average 358c/kg. 

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

The large supply of cattle continues with 2,414 cattle in a prime only sale. Quality improved for the heavier cattle with a good supply of heavy full mouthed bullocks and prime cows, however there was a large single vendor consignment of plain conditioned northern pastoral cows and bulls. Small lines of yearling steers and heifers were penned. The regular buyer panel was active throughout, particularly better quality lines with the support of regular feeders and local opportunity restockers. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Normanton, Croydon, Mt Garnet, Greenvale, local and coastal areas.

Grown steers to feed above 400kg sold to 420.2c to average 379c to 402c and heavyweight steers to the trade sold to 398.2c to average 392c/kg. A small sample of grown heifers to the trade made to 376.2c to average 352c to 365c/kg. Increased numbers of numbers very good quality heavy full mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 402.2c to average 379c to 394c/kg.  

Medium weight 2 score cows sold to 340.2 to average 318c to 320c and 3 score cows reached 370.2c to average from 340c to 348c/kg. Prime heavyweight cows topped at 368.2c to average 362c to 365c/kg. Good quality heavy bulls to processors made to 362.2c with most sales from 330c to 352c/kg.

A store sale scheduled for Friday has 4,500 cattle booked.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

The large supply of cattle continues in a return to a prime only sale with 1,720 cattle penned. A store sale on Friday has 3,800 cattle booked. Quality today was very mixed with some very good lines of heavy prime cows along with isolated pens of bullocks and heifers. Two large consignments of northern pastoral cattle were also presented. One regular processor was absent, however, the buyer panel was assisted by one northern feeder order and the gallery operated at similar rates on most lines. Grown steers eased 5c, heifers to the trade lifted 11c, bullocks sold firm, medium weight cows eased 11c, while heavy cows to processors were firm to 4c higher and heavy bulls averaged 30c/kg lower. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Burketown, Normanton, Richmond, Greenvale, local and coastal areas.  

A good supply of heavy grown steers met strong demand with those to the trade topping at 406c to average 394c, and steers to feed reached 455c, averaging 371c to 424c/kg. Improved quality of grown heifers to the trade sold to 382c to average 357c and a small sample of grown heifers to feed made to 376c to average 336c/kg.

Increased numbers of heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 410c, to average 383c/kg. Processor demand for cows continues to be very strong. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 336c to average 314c and 3 scores reached 340c to average 329c/kg. A good sample of prime heavy weight cows topped at 350c to average 343c/kg. A sample of cows to feed reached 334c to average above 320c/kg. Demand for bulls was notably reduced! Heavy bulls suitable for live export sold to 340c to average 326c and heavy bulls to process averaged 321c/kg.  

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

The large supply of cattle continued with an increase of 105 head for 2433 penned in a prime only sale. The buyer panel consisted of all processors, one live exporter, regular feeders and opportunity backgrounders. Quality was good for the majority, comprising of nearly 500 bullocks and 1,500 cows and an increased number of northern bulls. Cattle were drawn from Burketown to Georgetown and south to the local area.
