Solid competition from the buyer gallery saw improved demand for the major of classes. Grown steers increased 5c, bullocks improved 5c to 17c, grown heifers to processors were firm, cows averaged 2c to 9c less and bulls lifted  by up to 15c/kg.

Prime yearling heifers to the trade sold to 281c multiple times.  Grown steers above 400kg to live export averaged 307c, selling to 308, trade types reached 302c to average 286c, while steers above 500kg sold to and averaged 312c/kg. Good quality heavy grown heifers to processors made to 285c to average 270c/kg.

Another large offering of full mouth heavyweight bullocks to export slaughter topped at 327c, averaging from 312c to 319c/kg. Lightweight prime cows to processors reached 244c to average 240c, medium weight 2 scores sold to 256c to average 238c/kg. A very good quality line of 2 score cows returning to the paddock for breeding made 248c/kg. Medium weight 3 score cows sold to 278c to average 258c to 266c, a sample of prime heavyweight cows topped at 276c to average near 270c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export sold to 287c/kg, most around 270c, processor bulls averaged 238c/kg.

A store sale scheduled for Friday has 2400 head booked.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

The large supply of cattle continued with 2485 cattle penned in a Combined Prime & Store Sale.  Cattle were drawn from Richmond, Prairie, Georgetown, Greenvale, south to Belyando and the local area.  Quality of prime cattle improved on recent weeks, supported by some very good quality single vendor lines of store steers and heifers. All regular processors were in attendance, albeit operating selectively which resulted in an easing of price in most categories, supported by regular feeders, backgrounders and restockers.  Good quality yearling heifers to feed lifted 15c, Grown steers to feed sold firm to 10c easier, heifers to feed finished firm, cows to processors averaged 15c to 30c lower and bulls were 9c easier.  

Good quality vealer steers above 200kg to backgrounders made to 568.2c to average 528c/kg.  A large sample of good quality vealer heifers to the trade sold to 460.2c to average 422c to 441c/kg, while a good sample above 280kg to feed topped at 430.2c to average 425c/kg.  Fewer numbers of yearling steers above 280kg to feed reached 450.2c to average 422c/kg.  A limited number of steers above 330kg to feed topped at 480.2c to average 460c/kg. An increased supply of very good quality yearling heifers above 330kg to feed sold to improved rates topping at 442.2c to average 430c/kg.  
A good sample of grown steers above 400kg to feed sold to 416.2c to average 402c/kg and suitable steers above 500kg to the trade reached 400.2c to average 398c/kg. Limited numbers of grown heifers to feed sold to 372.2c to average 366c/kg. There were insufficient numbers of bullocks to reliably quote. 

Selective processor demand for cows resulted in an easing trend on recent weeks.  Medium weight 2 score cows made to 308.2c to average 294c, 3 score cows to processors reached 326.2c to average 300c and prime heavyweights topped at 324.2c to average 320c/kg. A good sample of cows to feed reached 304.2c to average sold to 274c to 292c/kg. Heavy bulls to feed destined for live export topped at 350.2c to average 316c/kg, while bulls to processors averaged 300c/kg.  

A small number of good quality cows and calves sold from $1,700 to $2,000/unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

The large numbers continued on Charters Towers with 3412 cattle penned for another predominantly prime sale, 849 more than week.  Several large lines of northern cattle resulted in more variable quality on offer, particularly for heavy cows and bullocks.  The regular buyer gallery was again supported by southern processor and feeder orders, with all in attendance active on most categories.  A store sale on Friday with more than 4,600 cattle booked resulted in a very small number of restockers and onlookers in attendance.  Cattle were drawn from west of Mt Isa, Normanton, Chillagoe, Greenvale, Tully, Ayr, local and coastal areas.

There were insufficient vealers and yearling steers to reliably quote, all selling relative to quality.  Good quality yearling heifers above 330kg to feed sold to 331.2c to average near 320c, while heavier types to the trade reached 314.2c/kg.  Grown heifers were again well supplied, albeit generally lighter weights, easing by 10-15c/kg. Heavy heifers to the trade sold to 304.2c to average from 271-287c , with heifers to feed topping at 328.2c averaging near 280c/kg.  Increase numbers of grown steers were penned with variable quality easing by up to 20c/kg.  Suitable types to live export reached 348c to average 325c/kg, while a good line of steers to backgrounders sold for 354c/kg.  Heavy 3 scores to processors sold to 348c to average, with medium weights averaging 329c/kg.  Heavy bullocks were again well supplied, with most easing by up to 25c/kg.  Heavy 3 score sold to 350c to average 338-348c, while medium weights sold to 347c to average 300-329c/kg.

Increased numbers of cows were offered, with some large lines of northern cows penned, easing values throughout by 9-14c/kg.  Medium weight 2 score cows sold to 285.2c to average 249c, while light cows to processors averaged 228c/kg.  Heavy 3 score cows sold to 289.2c to average 264-277c, while prime heavyweight cows topped at 295c to average near 294c/kg and 4 scores averaged near 280c/kg.  Heavy bulls to live export reached 340.2c to average 325c, while heavy bulls to processors sold to 336.2c to average 313c/kg.  Good quality light cows and calves sold from $910 - $1,100/unit.

The large fluctuation in supply continued with an 18% increase in numbers yarded. Medium weight cows dominated the yarding and most of the steers lacked condition and fell into the lighter weight category. Grown heifers were also in good supply, but there were almost no bullocks offered. 

Medium steers ranged from 131.2c to 145.2c while the heavy steers sold from 147c to 154.2c/kg, both weight grades experienced a mixed trend with the medium weights easing and the heavier types lifting 2c/kg. Grown heifers sold to varied competition with the best C muscled lines averaging 119.1c/kg.

The largest percentages of the cows were D3 medium weights and the best of these reached 138.2c while the overall average was 131.5c a gain of 4c/kg. A smaller number of lighter conditioned cows averaged 119.5c/kg.

The increased number sold to a full field of processors, although not all were active as some have sufficient stock on hand. The top end of the market was of good quality, but once of these it dropped away with some very poor stock penned. Prices were mostly cheaper and the steers eased by 4c to 7c/kg. Heifers were 8c lower and the cows lost up to 13c, although the good stock were firm to 2c/kg cheaper. 

Light steers sold to 135.2c and most averaged 115.5c/kg. The good quality medium weights peaked at 151.2c/kg. There was some good quality heavy steers penned and they reached 159.3c to average just under 154c/kg. One heavy bullock topped the sale at 165c/kg. 

Heifers made to 141.5c and the better grades averaged 117.5c/kg. Light poor quality cows felt the brunt of the cheaper market and close to 150 D1s averaged 72.7c/kg. The best D3s sold to 117.2c/kg. The best quality medium weights were only 2c cheaper and over 200 D3s averaged 120c after the made to 128.2c/kg. Only poor quality bulls were penned and they sold to 116.2c/kg.

The inaugural Northern Beef Producers Commercial Cattle competition attracted 233 head for the prime sale section at Charters Towers, featuring some outstanding heavy prime bullocks and cows, along with very good quality trade steers and heifers. The feeder heifers and vealer steers and heifers offered for sale did not sell at auction. Three larger processors who regularly operate at the weekly Charters Towers sale operated at enthusiastic prices for the good quality offering of heavy, high yielding bullocks and steers lifting by up to 9c/kg. Heavy cows consistently improved by up to 20c/kg, while feeder cattle sold similar to recent prices. Cattle were drawn from Pentland, Belyando, Collinsville, Bowen and local areas.

Heavy export bullocks sold to 255c, to average 250c, while the winning pen of 5 grown steers to slaughter sold to 256c/kg. The heavy grown steers category averaging 253c/kg. Heavy yearling steers to slaughter sold to 259c to average 252c/kg. A small number of yearling steers returning to grass sold to 249c with similar types to feed selling to 243c/kg.

The cow section of the sale produced some extra heavy 4 score cows topping at 215c for those above 700kg, averaging 207c/kg. Heavy 3 score cows above 520kg sold to 209c to average 199c/kg. A small number of 3 score cows 400-520kg sold for 199c. Heavy grown heifers sold to 223c, with extra heavy 3 score heifers above 520kg selling for 230c/kg. Heavy trade heifers sold to 230c and yearling heifers to the trade selling for 223c to average 223c/kg.

The flow of large numbers of prime cattle continued on Charters Towers with 2,563 cattle presented in a predominantly prime sale. With over 4,500 cattle booked for a Store Sale on Friday, many restocker buyers were absent from the gallery. All regular processors operated at increase rates along with southern processor and feeder operators, however there were no live exporters in attendance. Large consignments of good quality northern cows and bullocks sold to improved rates with solid competition on all lines.  Cattle were drawn from north of Mt Isa, Croydon, Georgetown, Einsaleigh, Greenvale, local and coastal areas.

Limited numbers of vealer steers and heifers sold according to quality with light heifers to feed averaging 275c/kg. Yearling heifers above 330kg to feed sold to 326.2c to average 318c, while heavier heifers above 400kg to the trade reached 340.2c to average near 332c/kg. Yearling steers above 330kg to feed sold to 370.2c to average 345c, with steers above 400kg selling from 322c to 357c/kg. Grown steers to processors sold to 368c, averaging from 356c to 366c, with steers above 400kg to southern feeders averaging 331c/kg. Grown heifers to the trade topped at 348.2c to average 345c, with lesser lines averaging from 249c to 299c/kg.

Heavy export bullocks to processors topped at 368.2c with most lines selling above 320c/kg. Increased numbers of medium weight cows improved by 5c to 9c, selling to 260.2c to average more than 240c/kg. Heavy 3 score cows lifted 12c to 16c, topping at 307.2c to average 291c, with a large sample of lesser yielding 3 score cows averaging 278c/kg. Several pens of prime heavy weight cows sold above 300c, reaching a high of 310.2c to average near 302c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors sold to 350.2c to average 349c, while bulls to feed destined for live export averaged 343c to 346c/kg.

The first store sale in close to five years saw 3,831 cattle penned, consisting of 2,236 steers and 1,595 heifers. There was an enthusiastic buyer gallery consisting of one live exporter, one feeder buyer and several restockers and backgrounders from western, central and local areas. Cattle were drawn from Normanton, Croydon, Mount Garnet, Innisfail, Tully, Giru, coastal and local areas.

Light steer calves eased 12c, with several lines of yearling steers improving from 13c to 25c/kg. Heifer calves improved by more than 25c, particularly better bred lines, while lighter types improved by 15c/kg. Yearling steers returning to grass and backgrounders improved throughout by more than 20c, with heavier types improving by up to 30c/kg. Steer calves sold to 292c to average 254c, as light vealer steers sold to 300c to average 281c, with heavier types averaging 275c/kg. A good sample of heifer calves sold to 232c average 220, while vealer heifers made to 226c to average 220c/kg. Yearling steers to live export made to 262c, averaging 255c, and steers to feed averaged 252c/kg. Yearling steers weighing 280-330kg to restockers sold to 256c to average 248c and those above 330kg averaged 261c/kg. Yearling heifers above 280kg returning to the paddock made to 194c, and heavier types made to 180c, while heifers to feed sold to 182c to average 175c/kg for the majority penned.

Grown steers to live export made to 264c multiple times and grown heifers to live export made 192c/kg. PTIC heifers sold to $820/head multiple times. Bulls above 280kg to live export made to 274c to average near 273c and younger males returning to grass topped at 284c to average 265c/kg. Several pens of good quality mixed age cows and calves sold from $1,020 to $1,230/unit.

The first sale for three weeks resulted in 944 cattle penned in a very mixed quality yarding. The supply of prime cattle was minimal, however there were several small lines of good quality store cattle. Three regular processors were operating selectively, supported by one live exporter and opportunity feeders, backgrounders and restockers.  Demand from the buyer panel was very selective, with poorer quality lines difficult to sell. Cattle were drawn from Richmond, Pentland, local and coastal areas.

Good quality weaned steers  returning to the paddock reached 325c,  most sales from 210c to 270c similar heifers made to 246c to average 220c/kg. Light yearling steers averaged 216c reaching a top of 292c, a small sample of steers above 280kg to live export made 270c, while steers above 330kg to feed averaged 273c/kg. Yearling heifers above 280kg to processors sold to 238c to average 220c/kg.  

A small sample of grown steers to live export made to  276c to average 275c/kg. A small number of grown heifers to the trade sold to 246c to average 243c/kg. There were insufficient numbers of bullocks to reliably quote.

Medium weight three score cows averaged 226c, isolated single sales between 260 and 280c/kg. A small number of prime heavyweight cows averaged 228c/kg.  A small quantity of  bulls to processors sold to 270c, most around 240c/kg.

A small number of cows and calves sold to $800/unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

The first sale for the year saw very few cattle penned. Only local butchers were present and active in the market with no major meat works operating. Quality was very mixed with some poor cows and bulls selling at low rates. Better quality stock opened the year cheaper, however values were still healthy.

Due to the very limited number of cattle offered, it is difficult to accurately provide any quotes.

The first sale for the winter months showed a dramatic decrease in numbers, with the greatest percentage of the market consisting of the cow categories. Steers and heifers were short supplied and all the usual competition competed for the reduced yarding.

Medium steers traded from 120c to 139c/kg with the majority offered D muscled drafts. The better C muscled pens traded from 147c to 155c/kg. The greatest percentages of the heifers were D3 lines and these sold from 122c to 130c, with the few lighter drafts trading from 108c to 120c/kg.

Light D muscled cows returned values from 85c to 123c with the heavier medium weights trading from 105c to 129c/kg. Heavy cows were not penned at this week s market.

The first sale for nearly a month resulted in 3317 cattle penned. Quality was mostly good,consisting of some well finished heavy bullocks and cows, supported by several good quality lines of steers and heifers in fresh condition from areas receiving good rain at the end of 2023. All regular processors operated throughout with solid demand for heavier pens. Regular feeders, live exporters and opportunity restockers were active on suitable lines. Cattle were drawn from Hughenden to Georgetown, south to Belyando, local and coastal areas.

Values were generally in line with other selling centres relative to quality. A good sample  of vealer steers returning to the paddock averaged 261c, selling to 296c/kg.  A good sample of heifers under 200kg returning to grass averaged 240c, making to 248c, with heifers above 200kg to processors selling to 240c to average 218c/kg.

Yearling steers above 200kg to restockers averaged 254c to 272c reaching 290c. Suitable steers above 280kg to live export averaged 273c, those to feed averaged 271c, restocker lines averaged 292c/kg. A large sample of steers above 330kg to feed averaged 288c, steers to live export averaged 283c/kg. Yearling heifers were well supplied with heifers above 280kg to feed reached 254c to average 228c, and heifers above 330kg to feed topping at 268c to average 243c to 252c/kg.

Good quality, heavy grown steers to processors made to 294c, most sold from 276c to 290c/kg. A small number of grown heifers to the trade reached 250c to average 230c/kg. 

Heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 290c multiple times to average 285c, younger bullocks reached 310c to average 303c/kg.
Medium weight cows sold to 242c to average 239,c, a good sample of prime heavyweight cows topped at 250c to average 245c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export sold to 290c to average 279c, bulls to processors averaged 265c/kg.

A large offering of cows and calves mostly sold from $800 to $1,240/unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

The first sale for a month after a prolonged wet period saw Charters Towers Combined Agents yard 752 mixed quality cattle.  Prime cattle were in limited supply, however there were some very good quality grown steers and heifers, supported by small lines of store steers and heifers. Most regular processors were in attendance and operating, accompanied by regular feeders and opportunity restockers. Some cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Mt Surprise and Tablelands, most from the local area.

Good quality young steers to restockers sold to 306c, similar heifers to processors reached 240c/kg. Yearling steers above 200kg returning to the paddock sold to 274c and those above 280kg made from 276c to 290c/kg. Good quality steers above 280kg to feed sold to 312c averaging same, with steers above 330kg making 286c/kg. A small sample of yearling heifers above 280kg returning to the paddock made 270c/kg. Grown steers above 400kg to feed sold to 326c averaging 277c to 321c, while processors secured steers from 288c to 326c/kg. Grown heifers to the trade sold from 248c to 292c/kg.

A limited number of bullocks to export slaughter sold to 322c to average 320c/kg. Lightweight 2 score cows sold to 220c to average 180c, medium weight 3 and 4 score cows reached 288c averaging 268c to 286c and a small sample number of prime heavyweight cows sold to and averaged 278c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors made to 282c/kg.

A small number of cows and calves sold from $700 to $840 per unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

The first sale for a fortnight attracted 2051 cattle in a combined prime and store sale. Quality was mixed throughout, comprising of many smaller mixed lines, however 850 cows were penned with many presented in prime condition. All regular processors were in attendance and operating along with one southern processor at stronger rates in line with other selling centres, supported by  one live exporter, regular feeders and opportunity restockers. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa to Georgetown and south to the local area.

Steers and heifers lifted by 10 to 30c, grown steers to processors increased by 30c to 60c and cows improved by 27c to 48c/kg.

Vealer steers returning to the paddock sold to 280c, while similar heifers to processors reached 220c to average 211c/kg. Light yearling steers returning to the paddock averaged 241c selling to 257c and steers above 280kg sold to 264c to average 262c/kg. Yearling heifers to feed above 280kg made to 216c to average 211c/kg. Small lines of grown steers to processors sold to 282c, better quality types averaging 244c to 272c/kg. Grown heifers to the trade made to  270c to average near 260c/kg.  

A small number of heavy bullocks to export slaughter topped at 290c to average 272c to 289c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 230c to average 206c, a large sample of 3 scores reached 246c to average 222c and a good number of prime heavyweight cows topped at 248c to average 240c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export averaged 260c, bulls to feed destined for live export averaged 250c/kg.

An offering of 2 large lines of cows and calves sold from $920 to $1,160 per unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

The first sale for 6 weeks, due to the flooding and restricted access across the north, attracted a yarding of 1,533 mixed quality cattle. Only two processors attended, along with one feeder buyer and a limited number of opportunity restockers, however the gallery was filled with interested onlookers. Heavy prime bullocks and cows eased significantly in line with other selling centres, while selected store lines were firm to 40c/kg dearer, with spirited demand from restockers. Cattle were drawn from Prairie, Pentland, Einasleigh, Tully, Ingham, Bowen, Gracemere, Belyando, local and coastal areas. Most lines eased in comparison to last sale 6 weeks ago, with prime bullocks easing up to 40c and grown steers decreasing 35c/kg. Heavy 3 score cows met limited competition, easing by more than 80c, while 2 scores decreased by 40c, however 2 score cows to restockers were firm to 10c/kg lower. Vealer steers sold firm to 30c/kg stronger. Light yearling steers to restockers were met with selective demand, most selling firm to 40c easier, while light and medium yearling steers to feed eased up to 30c/kg. Light vealer heifers improved by more than 30c, while yearling heifers had limited demand, averaging more than 60c/kg cheaper, with quality a major factor. Limited numbers of bulls suitable for live export eased by 40c/kg.

Vealer steers generally sold firm, with selected lines of light steers in high demand, reaching 300c to average 252c, with heavier types averaging 239c/kg. Light yearling steers to restockers sold to 200c, to average 191c for a large sample, with an isolated sale to 270c/kg. Steers weighing 280-330kg sold to 257c to average 245c and yearling steers above 330kg topped at 240c to average 234c/kg.

Grown steers to restockers sold to 232c, averaging 204c/kg. Limited numbers of 4 score bullocks to process sold to 250c and 3 scores sold to 231c/kg. Medium weight 3 score grown heifers to process sold to 130c, while medium weight grown heifers to feed sold to 166c to average 133c/kg. Extra heavy 5 score cows sold to 161c to average 147c and heavy 3 score cows topped at 165c to average 136c, with 2 score cows averaging 111c/kg. Lighter 2 score cows to restockers made to 168c to average 106c/kg for better quality types. Heavy bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 237c/kg. Young males returning to grass sold to 240c/kg. Very good quality cows and calves sold from $950 to $1,150/unit.

The first Combined prime and store sale for a fortnight saw 2043 cattle penned. Despite most cattle presenting in fresh condition, quality was very mixed throughout the offering. Only three regular processors were in attendance and operating, supported by one live exporter, regular feeders and opportunity restockers.  Buyer demand was selective throughout with preference for better quality types.  Prices received were in line with other selling centres relative to quality. Cattle were were drawn from Richmond to Chillagoe, and south to local and coastal areas.  

Lightweight young steers averaged 310c selling to 316c, similar heifers reached 205c to average 175c/kg. Steers above 200kg returning to the paddock reached 298c to average 258c to 278c/kg. Heifers to restockers sold to 230c to average 224c/kg. Yearling steers above 280kg to live export sold to 290c, restocker steers averaged 251c/kg. Yearling steers above 400kg to feed made to 270c to average 255c, those suitable for live export averaged 276c/ kg. A good sample of yearling heifers above 330kg to feed averaged 224c/kg. 

Grown steers above 400kg to live export averaged 275c, steers to processors averaged 255c/kg. Heavy grown steers to processors topped at 260c to average 259c/kg.  A good supply of grown heifers to the trade sold to 230c to average 216c/kg.

Heavy bullocks to export slaughter topped at 270c, most averaged 250-267c/kg. Medium weight 3 score cow to processors sold to 222c to average 209c to 215c, while prime heavyweight cows sold to and averaged 218c/kg.  Heavy bulls to processors reached 256c to average 235, bulls to feed destined for live export averaged 254c/kg.

A large sample of cows and calves sold from $575 to $1,0000 per unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

The first Charters Towers sale for the year saw a slightly increased yarding with values firm to easier for all grades bar heifers.

Light weight steers topped at 138.2c, to average at 114.6c/kg for D2s. Medium and heavy weights steers, mainly D muscled sold to a high of 147.2c, with most averages in the mid to high 130s. Grown heifers the only are not to loose ground with 55 D3s averaging 15c/kg higher at 136.5c.

In the cow section lightweights failed to reach the 100c mark, medium weight D3s to 104.2c, and averaged at 101.2c/kg. A small sample of bulls saw 12 lightweight sell to a top of 100c/kg and average at 86c/kg.

The final sale of the year resulted in 2623 cattle penned, an increase of 123 on last sale. Quality was very good with some local large lines of grown steers, along with some good small lines of yearling steers in fresh condition. One regular processor was absent from the buyer panel which operated at stronger rates to last sale. Yearling steers averaged 25 to 80c higher, yearling heifers met quality related price changes, grown steers were 10c to 25c dearer, bullocks sold firm, heavy cows to processors were 2c dearer and bulls averaged 16c to 57c higher on last sale.  Cattle were drawn from Hughenden, Pentland, Mt Garnet, Collinsville, local and coastal areas. 

Light vealer steers to restockers sold to 835.2c, while a good sample of steers above 200kg reached 824.2c to average 755c/kg. Light vealer heifers to southern restockers topped at 798.2c to average 739c to 769c/kg. Good quality yearling steers above 280kg to restockers sold to 696.2c to average 659c to 661c and heavy steers above 400kg to feed reached 562.2c with most averaging 555c/kg. Light yearling heifers above to feed reached 666.2c to average 590c/kg. Heifers above 330kg to feed sold to 578.2c to average 478c to 486c/kg. 

Grown steers consisted predominantly of two very good quality large lines from the local area attracting very strong demand, selling to a dearer trend.  A large sample of steers above 400kg to feed sold to 560.2c to average 534c/kg.  A line of heavy steers above 500kg to feed sold 500.2c to average the same while a small sample of prime steers to the trade made 436.2c/kg. A reduced supply of good quality grown heifers to feed sold to 465.2c to average 411c/kg.

A limited supply of 3 score heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 442.2c average 432c to 436c/kg. Despite one processor absent, the demand for cows continues to be very strong.  Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 394.2c to average 392c and 3 scores reached 404.2c to average from 388c to 393c/kg.  A small sample of prime heavyweight cows topped 402.2c to average near 392c to 400c/kg. There was no processor activity on bulls with increased numbers to feed selling up to 508.2c to average 360-435c/kg. Young males returning to the paddock sold to 750.2c to average 679c/kg.

Good quality cows and calves sold from $1,900 to $2,800 per unit.

The opening sale for 2022 is booked for Wednesday 19th January.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

The final sale of the year attracted 3612 cattle. The prime yarding was limited to 438, with several small mixed lines, a small number were well finished.  Three regular processors were in attendance, along with regular feeders, two live exporters and opportunity restockers. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Richmond, to Chillagoe, east to Ingham and south to the local area.

Demand for prime cattle was limited, however store steers and heifers received good demand from feeders and restockers. Most categories eased eased 10c to 30c on a fortnight ago, however young heifers average 20c to 60c lower, with poorer quality types remaining difficult to sell.

A large sample of light vealer steers to restockers sold to 288c to average 261c and restocker heifers topped at 226c for a reduced average of 178c to 203c/kg. Yearling steers above 200kg returning to the paddock averaged 243c, selling to to 268c. Steers above 280kg to feed reached 254c to average 241c/kg. Good quality steers above 330 kg to feed made to 288c to average 257c/kg. A good sample to live export reached 288 to average 281c/kg.  A large sample of yearling heifers above 280kg to feed sold to 222c to average 209c and heifers above 330kg to feed averaged 222c/kg.

Grown steers above 400kg to feed topped at 266c to  to average 262c/kg. Grown heifers to the trade made to 224c to average 209c/kg. A mixed quality offering of bullocks to export slaughter topped at 250c to average 243c/kg.  

A small sample of 3 score cows reached 214c to average 207c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export made to 238c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

The final sale of the calendar year for Charters Towers Combined Agents drew a yarding of 1,062 mixed quality cattle, dominated by 833 store cattle and a plainer consignment of cattle in the prime section. There were no processors present, however the buyer gallery was active, with restockers, backgrounders and feeder buyers active throughout the sale, with strong competition for better types. The limited number of heavy weight cattle attracted interest from feeder buyers destined for live export, whilst restockers showed strong interest for better grown steers and heifers.  

Vealer heifers topped at 268.2c, with many small lines selling consistently to 250c/kg. Vealer steers attracted strong restocker interest and topped at 301.2c/kg. An increased number of yearling heifers were strongly contested and topped at 280.2c, with many lines selling to 262.2c/kg.

Grown steers sold strongly, particularly to feeder interest, selling to 283.2c, with the top selling line to restockers making 295.2c/kg. Cows were limited in supply and sold to 215.2c/kg for the very few 3 score cows. A mixed selection of bulls sold to limited buyer interest with the lack of processor competition and sold to 219.2c/kg for heavy bulls.  Younger age, lighter bulls sold to feeder buyers, destined for live export and sold to 245.2c, with vealer bulls selling to 275.2c/kg to restockers. A very small offering of cows and calves were sold from $480 to $680/unit. 

The first sale for 2016 is scheduled for January 20th.

The final sale for 2024 resulted in 1745 cattle penned, 767 fewer than last week in a very mixed quality offering. The supply of well finished prime bullocks and cows was minimal, store lines consisted of several plain conditioned lines and there was a large consignment of northern bulls. Only three major processors were in attendance and operating, supported by regular feeders, one live exporter and opportunity restockers. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa to Normanton, east to Innisfail and south to the local area.

Demand for most classes was good, particularly better quality types. Lightweight steers and heifers  improved 6c to 15c, feeder heifers improved 20c to 50c, grown steers and heifers improved 2c to 7c and prime cows lifted 6c to 9c/kg.

Lightweight steers to restockers averaged 272c, reaching 300c, steers above 200kg averaged 254c to 278c/kg. Yearling steers above 280kg to feed sold to 306c, averaging 277c to 280c, while steers above 330kg to feed averaged 268c/kg. Yearling heifers above 200kg to feed destined for slaughter made to 242c to average 230c/kg. Heifers above 280kg to feed topped at 314c, averaging 248c to 274c/kg, while good quality heifers above 330kg sold from 288c to 314c/kg. A good sample of plain conditioned grown steers under 400kg to feed averaged 261c, while steers above 400kg to live export made from 292c to 308c/kg. A limited supply of grown heifers to the trade reached 240c to average 227c/kg. 


Heavy bullocks to live export made 290c, plain conditioned types to feed averaged 265c/kg. Medium weight 3 score cows reached 274c to average 261c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export sold from 250c to 310c/kg.

Finally I would like to wish all listeners a safe and happy Xmas and look forward to 2025.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

The entire gallery of trade buyers competed for a generally better quality line of cattle especially in the better-finished drafts. Numbers fell marginally compared to the last market with the greatest percentage falling into the cow categories. There were also fair numbers of grown steers offered with the heifer portion limited in number.

Medium C muscled steers traded from 140.2c to 159.2c with the heavier drafts reaching 154.2c with most sales around the 150c/kg mark. Heifers were mainly unfinished and these sold from 113.2c to 125c while the better-finished lines traded from 127c to 140c/kg.

Light cows sold from 104c to 124.2c as the medium pens traded from 116c to 134c/kg.

The Easter break has once again caused a reduced yarding with the quality of the export weight offered reported as on a par with last week. All of the usual buyers were in attendance and operating in a market that yielded mixed results.  

There were insufficient light steers to get an accurate quote, however medium weight D3s lost 5c to average 149.5c after selling to 157.2c/kg. The least effected by the falling trend was the heavy D3s which only lost 2c to average 157.7c/kg. Heavy D3 bullocks sold to 164.6c and returned over $1,100/head. 

The females were able to realise increased rates, unlike the males. Similar to other centres, the heifers were all lightweights and they improved 3c/kg. In the largest number, the D3s sold to 145.6c and averaged 142c/kg. The light cows received the largest gain of the day, after topping at 130.2c/kg. Large numbers of medium weight D3s reached 148.2c, as the limited numbers of heavy weights offered sold to 138.2c/kg.

All of the bulls offered were D1s with the medium and heavy weights suffering losses. The heavy weights topped at 144.2c/kg.

The drier conditions have allowed for extra cattle to be penned this week at all centres, and Charters Towers was no different with an extra 150 head offered. In a yarding of mainly D types with a few E types, values for most saw a fall after the good sales last week. 

Large numbers of medium weight D2 steers reached 142.2c to average 136.4c/kg as bullocks weighing from 500 to 600kg topped the sale after reaching 151.2c and averaging 143.6c/kg. 

The light D1 heifers suffered a 9c fall to average 126.6c after topping at 141.2c/kg. Light D2 cows reached 130.2c as medium weight D2s sold to 121.2c/kg. 

Light D2 bulls topped the bull section with 126.2c with medium weight D2s in the largest numbers selling to 110c/kg.

The current good prices and the dry conditions combined and resulting in a much larger yarding being offered. Helping to increase numbers was large lines of cattle from the Richmond area. The offering contained good even lines of cattle that improved the overall quality of the yarding. Even though numbers improved, it had no negative effect on values, as an extra buyer was present. 

The light steers were in relatively small numbers as were the heavy bullocks. Medium weight D3s were in large numbers and sold to 179.2c while the heavy steers reached 186.6c/kg. The heavy bullocks were again in demand topping the sale after selling to 190.2c/kg and returning over $1,200/head. 

Similar to other centres, the light heifers came under increased demand with the better types selling to 181.2c/kg. The large numbers of light cows sold well with the D2s topping at 165.2c/kg. There were good even lines of cows that met very good competition from all buyers with the best of the medium weights selling to 174.2c/kg. The heavy cows were in limited numbers and a small pen sold for 167.2c/kg. 

Increased numbers of light bulls were offered selling to 139.2c as the heavy weights sold to 169.2ckg and returned over $1,300/head.

The continuing dry conditions and failed rain forecasts further increased numbers by 659 head to 3,035 cattle. The supply of prime cows and grown steers doubled on last sale with some very good lines penned while quality in the store section was mixed. Most categories were firm to 10c higher on last sale, particularly better quality lines. A larger buyer panel operated on selected lines with one new feeder buyer, one processor and two live exporters actively increasing demand, along with four regular processors and regular feeders, backgrounders and restockers. Cattle were drawn from Cloncurry, Hughenden, Georgetown, Einasleigh, Greenvale, Tully, Ingham, Ayr, Bowen, Belyando, local and coastal areas.

Steer calves met strong southern competition, selling to 556.2c, mostly selling from 506c to 524c, while heifer calves to processors made to 412.2c to average 404c/kg. An increased supply of good quality vealer steers to backgrounders made to 530c for lighter types while a large sample above 280kg reached 526.2c to average from 459c to 471c/kg. Steers above 280kg to feed reached 464.2c to average from 432c to 453c/kg. Well bred vealer heifers to processors topped at 428.2c to average near 407c, while a large sample of heifers above 200kg to feed destined for slaughter reached 432.2c to average 399c and suitable southern backgrounder types sold to 448.2c to average near 422c/kg.

Yearling steers above 330kg to feed sold to an improved 458.2c to average 442c and those above 400kg to feed averaged 439c/kg. Suitable steers for live export averaged from 380c to 410c/kg. Yearling heifers were of mixed quality, with those to restockers above 280kg topping at 324.2c to average 314c and better bred types above 330kg to feed selling to 364.2c to average 351c/kg. Grown steers were supplied in increased numbers with improved quality and demand pushing values for trade types to 346.2c and a large sample to backgrounders selling to 396.2c with most sales from 376c to 390c/kg. Grown heifers of similar quality to feed sold to an isolated 360.2c for most to average 338.2c, while best quality trade types reaching 340.2c to average 320c to 338c/kg.

The supply of heavy bullocks was of mixed quality and mostly full mouthed selling to export slaughter for a top of 352.2c to average from 317c to 347c/kg.  Medium weight cow numbers more than doubled on last sale, with 2 score cows to slaughter reaching 254.2c to average 252c, while restocker lines sold to 266c to average 242c/kg. Medium weight 3 score cows to processors sold to 276.2c to average from 258c to 270c, while prime heavy weight cows topped at 272.2c multiple times to average above 270c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export topped at 330.2c to average from 310c to 323c, while medium weight bulls to live export made to 398.2c with most averaging from 354c to 378c and young males returning to grass reached 500.2c to average 422c/kg.  
A small number of single cow calf units sold to $1,520/unit.

The continued large supply saw a return to a prime only sale with 1,820 cattle penned. Quality was very mixed featuring some very good lines of heavy cows and grown steers along with lesser quality northern pastoral cows and bulls. The regular buyer panel were present and operating at similar rates to recent weeks. Grown steers increased up to 15c, heifers were 20c higher, heavy bullocks lifted 6c/kg. Heavy cows were firm to 6c/kg higher and heavy bulls held firm. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Burketown, Georgetown, Hughenden, Pentland, Ayr, local and coastal areas.  

A limited supply of yearling steers above 330kg to feed sold to 420c, to average between 409c and 417c/kg. Light yearling heifers returning to grass averaged 402c and yearling heifers above 330kg to feed sold to 390c to average 384c/kg. An increased supply of grown steers met strong demand with those to feed reaching 422c, to average 407c/kg. Heavy steers to the trade topped at 370c multiple times to average near 366c, and a good sample to restockers averaged 378c/kg. Grown heifers to the trade sold to 370c to average 353c and heifers to feed averaged 337c/kg. A good supply of heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter reached 376c to average 366c/kg. 

A good supply of cows continued to meet strong processor demand. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors made to 318c to average 300c, and 3 scores sold to 326c multiple times to average between 316c and 321c/kg. Some good pens of prime heavy weight cows topped at 330c to average 325c/kg. A good line of heavy weight grain fed cows averaged 324c/kg. Strong demand for light cows saw those returning to grass sell to 304c to average 274c to 302c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export topped at 370c to average between 358c and 370c/kg. Medium weight bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 374c to average 324c to 351c/kg. A small quantity of young cows with calves at foot made $1,940/unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

The continued large supply of cattle resulted in 1423 cattle penned in a prime only sale.  Quality improved on last sale with increased numbers of prime yearlings, heavy prime bullocks and cows. The regular buyer panel was bolstered by two southern processors and feeders along with opportunity restockers and one live exporter. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa to Normanton, east to Mt Garnet and south to The Belyando and local area.

The additional buyer demand saw values improve for most categories, with quality a factor. Prime yearlings lifted 49c to 60c, bullocks increased 35c, medium weight cows lifted up to 23c and heavy bulls averaged 25c to 50c higher.

Good quality prime yearling steers to processors sold to 254c, those to feed averaged 272c/kg. Prime yearling heifers to slaughter made from 220c to 248c/kg. Grown steers above 400kg to feed reached 262c to average 238c, processor types sold to 270c to average 249c/kg. Grown heifers to the trade made to 246c, averaging 210c to 231c/kg.

Heavy young bullocks to export slaughter topped at 266c to average 257c, full mouthed bullocks averaged 247c/kg. Lightweight restocker cows averaged 156c to 179c, 2 score cows to processors averaged 186c, selling to 198c. Medium weight 3 score cows sold to 228c to average 212c to 218c, a good sample of prime heavyweight 3 and 4 score cows topped at 228c to average 224c/kg.
Medium weight bulls to live export sold to 264c to average 249c and heavy bulls to processors made to 248c to average 236c/kg.

A special store sale on Friday has 3200 cattle booked.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

The continuation of large numbers in Charters Towers, saw 3,490 cattle penned, 385 more than last week. Quality was mixed throughout and despite some lines showing the effects of the season, several lines of good heavy prime cows and bullocks were on offer, supported by increased numbers of light young store steer and heifers. The regular buying panel was accompanied by some additional central feeder and backgrounder orders, with resellers also active on lighter vealers and calves. Cattle were drawn from Katherine in Northern Territory, Croydon, Georgetown, Mt Garnet, Collinsville, Clermont, local and coastal areas.

Young vealer steers met increased demand, increasing by up to 12c for better drafts and similar quality light vealer heifers increased by 7c to 11c/kg. Mixed quality yearling steers also sold to a dearer trend, increasing by up to 20c/kg for better quality types, particularly those to backgrounders destined for feed.  Yearling heifer quality was mixed with increased feeder demand, while grown heifers to the trade improved by 10c/kg.

Increased numbers of heavy export bullocks sold up to 8c/kg higher, with many secondary types meeting increased buyer demand. Medium weight cows to processors increased by up to 22c, due to supply pressures in southern markets, while heavy cows also sold to up to 7c/kg higher. Heavy bulls eased by up to 10c/kg in line with quality on offer.

Light vealer steers to restocker sold to 342c to average 325c, with heavier types reaching 370c, to with the better quality majority selling from 330c to 348c/kg. Light vealer heifer demand was spurred by resellers, reaching 276c to average above 255c, with suitable types to trade averaging from 258c to 267c/kg. Feeder and backgrounder orders dominated the yearling steer offering, with a large sample of better quality types selling to 350c to average from 336c to 340c/kg. Yearling heifers to feed sold to 270c to average an improved 254c/kg. A small sample of grown steers to feed sold to 321c, while grown heifer quality was mixed with heavy heifers reaching 258c to average 211c/kg.

Heavy bullocks to export processor sold to 298c to average 290c, while increased numbers of secondary types averaged 260c/kg. Medium weight cows sold to 214c to average 198c/kg, with southern processors jostling to fill orders. Heavy cows topped at 243c to average 219c and some very good lines of prime heavy weight cows sold to and averaged 240c/kg. Large framed light conditioned cows to restockers sold to 202c to average near 183c/kg. Heavy bulls to background feed destined for live export sold to 300c to average above 280c, while those to processors sold to 284c/kg. Small lines of cows and calves mostly sold from $800 to $1,060/unit.

The continuation of a large supply resulted in today being a prime only sale with 2,327 cattle penned, 930 more than the last equivalent sale. A scheduled store sale on Friday has more than 2,900 cattle booked. Today, quality was mostly good, however fewer lines of heavy weight cattle were on offer. Despite one major processor being absent, all other regular processors, feeders, and one live exporter operated at similar rates to recent weeks along with opportunities for restockers and backgrounders. Demand was strong throughout particularly for feeder steers and heifers that sold firm to 10c easier, cows eased 6c to 10c/kg and heavy bulls were firm. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Julia Ck, Pentland, Greenvale, local and coastal areas.   

Yearling steers returning to grass sold to a top of 396c to average 386c while the steer portion reached 388c to average 380c/kg. A good supply of yearling heifers to feed reached 350c multiple times to average from 340c to 347c, while restocker lines averaged 366c/kg. Grown steers to feed reached 390c to average from 361c to 366c, while those returning to grass made to a top of 384c/kg. Suitable steers to live export sold to 368c while steers to the trade topped at 390c to average 354c to 361c/kg. Grown heifers to the trade sold to 330c multiple times to average from 306c to 319c, with heifers to feed also reaching 330c to average from 319c to 324c/kg. A limited number of heavy full mouthed bullocks to export slaughter sold to a top of 362c/kg. 

Medium weight score 2 cows to restockers met strong demand reaching 286c to average 275c to 281c/kg. Cows to processors sold to a top of 274c to average 260c, with score 3 types reaching a top of 296c, to average from 277c to 286c/kg.  Prime heavy weight cows topped at 302c to average from 283c to 291c/kg. Heavy bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 362c, to average 336c to 345c, while medium weights to feed sold to a top of 384c to average 365c/kg. 

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

The Charters Towers stock agents penned 821 prime cattle this week.  Some of the export steers and ox were easier in places to follow trends set in southern Queensland major auction centres.  The yarding included a good mix of cattle.  Steers in big numbers saw medium steers to 125.2c, heavy steers C4 to 129.2c to average 127.6c with other heavier steers and ox selling consistently around 127.2c.  D3 heifers in the lighter range sold to 116.2c for a good sample.  Best heavy cows reached 108.4c to average around the dollar mark, this market mainly unchanged on last week.  Once again this week, bulls were the highlight of the sale the best recorded to 154.2c.

The Charters Towers selling agents yarded a small offering of 247 cattle for their prime sale on Thursday.  The steers and bullocks sold at rates basically unchanged on last week, heifers were easier, while cows and bulls were dearer across the board.

The medium weight steers sold to 130.6c to average 120.2c/kg, bullocks in the 500 to 600kg weight range made to 130.2c/kg for a small number, while other heavier bullocks sold to 133.2c/kg.  

A small number of heifers reached 116.2c for an average of 110c/kg while the best of the D3 cows sold up to 115c for an average of 110.5c/kg.  Bulls were up to 3c/kg dearer than last week, and sold to 109.4c to average 107.5c/kg.

The Charters Towers selling agents weighed around 539 prime cattle on Thursday where values for most descriptions showed an easing trend in line with other Southern Queensland markets.  

In the steers, light steers D3 made to 127.2c with other medium weights selling to 128.2c to average 117c/kg for a fair sample of D2s.  Best of the bullocks, C3 made to 131.2c and they averaged 127.7c/kg.  A large sample of heifers in the lighter weight range topped at 115.2c/kg.  

Heavy cows, D2 sold to 113.2c with a good sample making to 109.2c/kg to average a shade over the dollar.  Heavy bulls at Charters Towers sold to a top of 110c/kg to average upwards of one dollar per kg liveweight.

The Charters Towers Selling agents penned 605 prime cattle on Thursday which was down just 25 head on last week.  Values for steers were dearer, heifers eased by 2 to 5c/kg, cow prices varied and bulls sold at rates mainly firm.

Light steers D2 made to 106.2c, medium steers D2 sold up to 124.2c/kg to average 112.7c to be 4c/kg dearer.  The best of the other heavier steers and ox made to 135.2c/kg.

In the female section, export heifers reached 111.2c for a fair sample.  Heavy cows sold up to 114.2c/kg to average 103.6c.  Bulls topped at 117.2c to average 113c/kg.

The Charters Towers combined agents sold close to 400 cattle at their prime sale on Thursday.  Export cattle made up the yarding with steers, bullocks and cows dominating.  Values varied but were generally in vendors' favour considering the type, quality and condition available.

The better lighter steers sold to 129.2c to average 115.1c/kg with medium weight steers selling up to 128.2c/kg.  The best of the other D4 bullocks peaked at 132.2c/kg for a small sample.

In the female section, a line of D3 heifers sold in a range from 111.2c to 118.2c/kg to average 116.8c/kg.  Heavy weight D4 cows reached 119.2c for an average of 113.8c/kg.  A fair sample of bulls sold to 129.2c/kg.

The Charters Towers agents sold 727 prime cattle on Thursday and all descriptions were generally dearer than last week.  

Light steers D2 sold to 129.2c/kg.  A good sample of D2 steers in the medium range sold to 130c to average 124.5c, a rise of 2c/kg.  A few other heavier steers and ox made to 137.2c.  Heifers were well represented and sold to 125c/kg to average in a range from 115.9c to 120.4c, this market dearer by up to 9c/kg. 

There were plenty of cows available in the line-up and these made to an isolated 118.2c with other good samples to 117.6c to average 112.9c/kg.  Best of the bulls reached 118.2c/kg.

The Charters Towers agents penned a substantially larger offering on Wednesday. The extra numbers did not help prices at all, as values for most descriptions suffered losses. 

Most steers weighed over 400kg, as the medium weight D4s sold to 139.2c and averaged 131.9c/kg. Over one hundred D4 bullocks averaged 136c as the heavier bullocks averaged 139.9c after reaching 143.2c/kg. 

The yarding was dominated by cows and in particular the medium weight D3s of which over two hundred and fifty were penned and sold to a top of 116.2c but lost 2c overall to average 108.7c/kg. Heavy D4 cows were once again the top price in the cow section reaching 117.2c/kg.  The top of the bulls was a heavy D1 reaching 130.2c/kg.

The agents in Charters Towers sold a shade under 600 prime cattle over the liveweight scales on Thursday.  

In the steers, medium weight D2s sold up to 122.2c/kg to average 120.7c to be around 3c/kg dearer than last week.  A good sample of C3 heavy steers made to 127.4c/kg with other heavier bullocks to 128.2c/kg.  The better end of the heifers sold around the 112c to 116c/kg mark.  

Cows were in fair numbers sold to a top of 105c/kg for a good number and these averaged 94.2c to be up to 4c/kg better. The best of the bulls sold to 107.2c/kg.

The agents in Charters Towers reported a much larger offering of prime cattle this week, in fact a rise of 1,021 on last weeks offering.  

A large offering in the medium steers, D2 sold up to 124.2c/kg, to average 116.3c with other heavier ox to 127.2c/kg.  Best of the heifers reached 117c/kg.  

Cows were also well represented in the yarding, and these sold up to 110.8c/kg for a good sample of D2s with large numbers of D1s to 108.2c, to average 100.6c/kg.  Bulls reached an isolated 106.2c/kg.

The agents at Charters Towers yarded 40 less cattle in an offering dominated entirely by D muscled export type cattle. Values for the cows increased while all other grades varied either way of the last sale. 

The medium weight D3s lost on average of 2c but still sold to a top price of 125.2c/kg. While the heavy weight D3s sold to the top price for the sale of 134.2c/kg and the heavy weight D3 bullocks sold well to reach 130.2c, up 8c/kg on last week. 

In the female section there was only light weight heifers and these were in small numbers with the D4s increasing 4c to average 119c/kg. Cows were the highlight of the sale and rose 7c and even more in places. The D3 medium weights sold to a top of 117.2c to average 112c, which was up 10c/kg. The medium weight D4s also sold well selling to 124.6c to average 120c/kg. 

There was only D1 bulls yarded with the top price for these weighed over 600kg and sold to 125.2c/kg.

The agents at Charters Towers reported a small offering of 122 prime cattle on Wednesday.  Values varied by just a cent or two either way of last weeks rates.  

In the export steers, best of the medium steers sold to 123.6c for D2 s to average 122.4c while a few heavier steers and ox made to 126.2c/kg.  D2 heifers in the lighter range sold up to 115c to average 111.5c/kg.  Heavy cows D2 sold up to 118.2c for a fair sample, the cow market showing a rise of 1c to 3c/kg.  A couple of heavy bulls made to 117.6c/kg.

The agents at Charters Towers offered an increased yarding, as nearly 800 head were penned. The yarding was dominated by steers and heifers, in a completely export type offering. The buyers were keen to secure stock and as a result, values for most types realised rises.

In the largest number, D3 medium weight steers sold to a top of 161.2c, while heavier D3s reached 162.2c and averaged almost 160c/kg. The D3 heavy bullocks also reached 162.2c to return in excess of $1,000/head. 

The heifers were all light weights, with the D3s reaching 143.2c and improving 10c to average 138c/kg. The light D2 cows sold to 116.2c, as the medium weight D3s topped the cows section after selling to 130.2c/kg. 

All of the bulls offered were D1s, with the medium weights selling to 150.2c and the heavy types reached 159.2c to return over $1,100/head.

The 451 prime cattle that were presented at Charters Towers this week had values pretty well dearer across the board compared to last weeks sale.  

A big sample of D2 steers to 500kg made to 119.2c/kg with best of the other bullocks to 125.2c to average 121c/kg.  Export type heifers made to 114.6c/kg.  Quite a number of the cows sold into the 80c and 90c/kg range, the  best sold to 104.2c to average 94.4c/kg.  Heavy bulls sold to 102.2c/kg.

Supply was again reduced and prices were dearer. Not all buyers were in attendance however processor competition again was quite strong, especially on the best cattle. Steers improved by 8c to 11c/kg while the heifers were slightly cheaper. The light cows improved 4c/kg and the medium weights lost some ground on last weeks very high rates. 

The light steers sold to 139.2c and averaged 132.5c/kg. The medium weights peaked at 165.2c and the best stock averaged 157.7c while the 2 score grades saw most sales around 147c/kg. Heavy steers reached 165.2c and averaged 163.1c while a small number of heavy bullocks topped at 169.2c/kg and returned up to $1,170/head.

Heifers sold to 136.2c while the light cows peaked at 135.2c although the D2s averaged 116.6c/kg. Medium weight cows sold to 147.2c and averaged 134.8c/kg. Heavy bulls topped at 145.2c/kg and returned up to $1,075/head.

Supply of cattle lifted by 325 for a yarding of 1473 cattle. Quality was mixed with reduced numbers of well finished bullocks and cows, however some good lines of store cattle were penned. The buyer panel consisted of most regular processors and feeders, two live exporters and opportunity restockers.  Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa to the east coast and local area.

Demand was selective throughout, with better quality lines attracting good support, however secondary lines attracted limited competition. Bullocks eased 20c, cows to processors were mostly firm and heavy bulls averaged firm to 10c higher.

Vealer steers above 200kg returning to the paddock sold to 222c to average 194, similar heifers averaged 132c/kg. A good sample of yearling steers above 330kg to feed sold to 212c to average 209, heifers above 330kg to feed made to 176c to average 162c/kg.

A good supply of grown steers above 400kg to feed averaged  177c to 206c selling to 212c. Grown heifers to processors sold to 186c to average 169c to 183c/kg.  Heavy full mouthed bullocks to export slaughter sold to 210c, the occasional single sale to 220c to average 201c/kg.  A reduced number of medium weight 3 and 4 score cows to processors topped at 180c to average from 154c to 173c/kg.
Heavy bulls to live export reached 270c to average 260c, bulls to processors averaged 183c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Supply increased following last week’s rain affected sale for a yarding of 2,833 cattle. Overall quality improved on recent weeks’, with some excellent lines of heavy grown steers and cows penned along with increased numbers of spayed heifers and some very good quality lines of store steers and heifers. All processors were very active along with the regular feeders, backgrounders and opportunity restockers. Grown steers increased 12c to 28c, heifers to the trade lifted 20c, bullocks improved 10c, cows to processors averaged 14c to 16c higher and heavy bulls increased by 3c/kg. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Burketown, Doomadgee, Einasleigh, Hughenden, Ingham, Mt Coolon, Belyando, local and coastal areas.  

Light heifer calves to the trade sold to 490c and a small sample of steer calves returning to grass reached 538c to average 506c/kg. Reduced numbers of vealer steers to restockers sold to 538c to average between 475c and 505c/kg. A good supply of vealer heifers to feed topped at 454c to average 408c/kg. A smaller supply of light yearling steers above 330kg to backgrounders reached 414c and averaged 411c, while heavy steers above 400kg to backgrounders averaged 410c/kg. Heavy steers to feed averaged 410c/kg. Grain assisted steers to the trade sold to 386c to average from 345c to 360c/kg. 

An increased supply of grown steers met strong demand with heavy steers to the trade reaching a top of 410c to average 405c, and steers to restockers made to 410c and averaged 387c/kg. Heavy steers to feed averaged between 378c and 392c/kg. Good quality, spayed grown heifers to the trade sold to 366c and averaged between 346c and 365c while a small sample of heifers to feed made to 372c to average 361c/kg.

A good supply of heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter reached 396c multiple times to average 393c/kg. An improved offering of cows resulted in very strong demand, with medium weight 2 score cows to processors making to 358c to average 326c and 3 scores reaching 360c to average 346c/kg. A good sample of prime heavy weight cows topped at a saleyard record of 366c to average 358c/kg. Heavy bulls suitable for live export sold to 370c to average 362c and heavy bulls to processors topped at 402c for an improved average of 344c to 354c/kg. A large supply of young males returning to grass topped at 532c and averaged 452c/kg. A small number of cows and calves sold from $1,640 to $2,120/unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

Supply increased by 721 for a yarding of 2909 cattle. Quality was good for the majority, comprising of increased numbers of prime cattle including 900 cows, supported by some good quality lines of store cattle.  All regular processors were active along with one southern operator, one live exporter, feeder and opportunity restockers and backgrounders.  Cattle were drawn from Burketown to Georgetown, south to The Belyando and the local area.

Values improved by 2-10c on most categories with strong demand for heavier better yielding prime cattle, however young lightweight cattle met limited demand and were difficult to sell.

Very good quality suitably weaned steers returning to the paddock sold to 300c, a good sample averaging 257c, plainer types averaged 240c/kg.  Good quality weaned heifers sold to 230c/kg. Yearling steers above 200kg returning to grass made to 252c, those to live export made to 262c to average 236c/kg, while steers above 330kg to live export made to 250c to average 248c/kg. Good quality steers above 330kg to feed topped at 280c to average 260c/kg.  Yearling heifers above 200kg to backgrounders sold to 200c to average 167c, heifers to feed averaged 211c/kg, with those above 280kg averaging 233c/kg.

Grown steers above 400kg to feed sold to 280c to average 260, steers suitable for live export also reached 280c to average 268c/kg.  Heavy grown steers to the trade made to 278c to average 267c/kg.  Yearling heifers to the trade topped at 286c,  a good supply of grown heifers to processors sold to 252c to average 233c/kg.

An increased supply of heavy bullocks to export slaughter topped at  286c to average near 280c/kg.  Lightweight  2 score cows to processors made to 222 to average 189c, medium weight 2 scores cows sold to 230c and 3 scores sold to 268c to average from 241c to 253c/kg.  A good sample of prime heavyweight cows topped at 274c to average 261c/kg.  Heavy bulls to live export sold to 270c and those to feed destined for live export made to 264c/kg.

Good quality cows and calves sold from $750 to $1,200 per unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Some useful storm rain across much of the supply area over the past week saw numbers increase by 400 head for a yarding of 2512 cattle. Quality was very mixed with some good lines of heavy, well finished bullocks, cows of mixed condition and quality, a large consignment of northern bulls and some good quality lines of store cattle. A reduced buyer panel consisted of four major processors, one live exporter and opportunity feeders and restockers. Cattle were drawn from McArthur River in the north, Richmond to Ingham and south to The Belyando and local area.

Values for prime categories were firm to 8c higher, depending on quality, restocker and feeder types lifted 9c to 50c/kg. Secondary and lesser quality lightweight cattle attracted minimal buyer support.

A minimal number of young steers sold according to quality similar heifers returning to the paddock averaged 267c, light heifers to feed destined for slaughter averaged 223c/kg. Yearling steers above 330kg to feed made to 284c to average 280c/kg. Good quality yearling heifers above 280kg to feed made 252c and heifers above 330kg sold to 266c/kg. A line of grown steers under 400kg to feed reached 290c to average 241c/kg. Grown steers above 400kg to the trade sold to 324c to average 287c, a small sample above 500kg averaged 298c/kg. Grown heifers to processors reached 272c to average 245c/kg.

An increased supply of heavy full mouthed bullocks to export slaughter met strong demand, topping at 338c multiple times to average 317c to 328c/kg. Lightweight prime cows to processors made to 244c to average 202c/kg. Medium weight 3 score cows sold to 264c to average 254c, prime heavyweight 3 and 4 score cows sold from 274c to 292c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export made form 246c to 270c, processor bulls sold from 210c to 270c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Some recent isolated rain and shortage of cattle saw numbers fall by more than 1,000, for a yarding of just on 900 head for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, with quality of all classes of cattle variable throughout. All major processors were in attendance and operating, supported by one feeder buyer and some central and western restockers. Cattle were drawn from Cloncurry, Winton, Richmond, Greenvale, Ingham, Woodstock, Belyando, local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers were fewer in number than recent weeks, however restockers were particularly active on lighter types, selling to 443c, with many lines selling from 384c to 405c/kg. Yearling steers were of variable quality and weight, with best steers to feed selling to 314c/kg. Vealer heifer numbers were notably less than recent weeks, however restockers were particularly active on lighter types, with heifers returning to the paddock topping at 374c/kg. Yearling heifers were limited in supply and quality was variable, with few suitable heifers to feed selling to 282c, while heifers to restockers sold to 282c/kg.

Bullocks continued the trend of recent sales with variable quality and age.  The small number of 3 score bullocks to slaughter averaged 268c, selling to 274c, while heavy grown steers to slaughter sold to 268c/kg. Lighter 2 score bullocks returning to the paddocks sold to 247c, while similar bullocks to feed sold to 242c/kg. The significantly less numbers of heavy cows saw values lift by 4c to 7c on last sale, however lighter cows lifted up to 15c/kg to both restockers and one processor. Heavy 3 score cows to slaughter averaged 224c, selling to 229c, while heavy 2 score cows sold to 231c for an increased average of 218c/kg. Light 1 and 2 score cows to processors sold to 228c, while similar cows to restockers averaged 216c, selling to 218c/kg on multiple occasions. Good numbers of bulls were again on offer, with quality much improved on last sale, however many were of similar light condition. Heavy 3 score bulls to slaughter sold to 206c to average 197c, while medium weight bulls to feed sold to 228c/kg. Some individual sales of bulls for breeding sold to 298c/kg. Light bulls to restockers sold to 402c/kg. There were no cows and calves this week.

Smaller numbers and some better quality cattle saw values increase across the board. All the regular buyers were in attendance although not all purchased stock with some processors inactive. Steers mostly gained 3c to 4c and some lighter weights improved up to 15c/kg. The cows were 7c and 8c/kg dearer. 

Light steers sold to 121.2c and averaged 114.1c/kg. The good quality medium weight steers reached 135c and they averaged just under 130c while the poorer grades saw most sales around 117c/kg. Heavy steers reached 135.2c to average 133.7c and the heavy bullocks topped at 136.2c/kg. 

The cow market sold to strong competition and the lightweights made to 105.2c and the D2s averaged 96.4c/kg. The medium weight cows sold to 118.2c and most averaged 113.4c/kg. Heavy bulls reached 124.6c/kg.

Similar to other yards, a smaller yarding of export types was penned at Charters Towers. Also similar to other centres, mixed results were received by most categories. All the usual buyers were present, although not all were in operation. The quality of the yarding was reported as plainer with most of the offering not properly finished. 

The light steers were in small numbers, as D3 medium weights topped at 148.6c to average 139.9c/kg. The top price for the steers was for the heavy D3s reaching 149.2c/kg. 

All of the heifers weighed under 540kg, as the D3s fell over 10c to average 119c after reaching a top of 135.2c/kg. Cows on the other hand, met increased demand, as the light D2s improved 5c and the medium weight D3s improved 4c/kg. The heavy D3 types also realised a gain after topping at 126.2c/kg.

The medium weight bulls sold to 124.2c, as heavy weights sold to 138.2c to return over $1,100/head.

Similar to other centres around the state, a smaller yarding was offered with the cheaper prices of recent weeks and limited numbers in the supply area the major reason for this. The quality of the yarding was affected by the current dry season with increased numbers of cattle being offered. Not all the regular buyers made purchases, but there was some good competition from local butchers. 

The better medium weight steers reached 182.2c with others selling to 176.2c/kg. The top of the heavy steers sold to 192.2c/kg and returned over $1,000/head. The few light heifers that were offered sold to solid demand as the C3s made to 190.2c/kg. 

The light cows dominated the yarding and despite this still managed to improve up to 9c after selling to 158.2c/kg. The medium and heavy cows suffered further falls, but the heavy weights still topped at 172.2c/kg. 

As has been the case at a few other centres the light bulls were in large numbers. Both the light and medium weights sold to 162.2c/kg.

Sale numbers lifted by 278 head to 2,336 head this week for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents, with increased numbers of yearling steers and heifers accompanied by a good selection of well finished cows. The absence of one regular processor saw values ease for heavy cows and bullocks while live exporters were intermittently present on suitable types. Feeder buyers were active and competed strongly on while restockers competed on lighter yearlings and vealers. Cattle were drawn from Normanton, Croydon, Einasleigh, Richmond, Hughenden, Greenvale, Tully, Ingham, Woodstock, Ravenswood, local and coastal areas.

Vealer heifers were of mixed quality and sold slightly easier, topping at 334.2c and averaging 321.3c/kg, predominantly to restockers. Several large lines of yearling heifers attracted strong feeder interest, with restockers active on lighter types. Heifers to feed sold to 332.2c, averaging 304.6c, while heifers to restockers sold to 326.2c for an average of 313.6c/kg. Vealer steers were fewer in number and sold easier on recent sales to a reduced restocker panel of buyers, topping at 368.2c, to average 358.7c/kg.  Yearling steers were in strong demand from feeder buyers, underpinned by demand from restockers for lighter weights. Yearling steers to feed sold to 350.2c, to average 348.6c, while lighter lesser conditioned types to restockers sold to 362.2c, to average 354.8c/kg. 

Grown steers sold to 350c, averaging 316.5c for feeder weight lines, while restockers pushed values for better quality backgrounders to 351c/kg.  Bullocks sold 3c to 9c easier on last sale, with best 3 score bullocks to slaughter selling to 293.2c to average 271.3c/kg. A continued large yarding of prime cows saw values ease, most notably for heavier types by 3c to 16c, with heavy C3 cows selling to 247.2c, to average 233.3c/kg. 2 score cows for slaughter sold to 261.2c, for an average of 235.4c/kg. Lighter 2 score cows restockers sold to 227.2c, averaging 212.6c/kg. Heavy heifers sold easier on recent sales, with slaughter types topping at 290.2c, while an increased number of heifers to feed topped at 330.2c/kg. A very good selection of heavy bulls attracted interest from a live export buyer and sold to 268.2c/kg. Processors pushed values to 264.2c/kg for heavy slaughter bulls. Lighter bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 330.2c/kg. A good number of cows and calves were on offer, regularly selling above $1,300 to a top of $1,500/unit.

Recent wet weather across the north resulted in a reduced yarding of 1,154 head drawn by Charters Towers Selling Agents this week, with a mixed quality yarding dominated by some well finished northern cows and some very good small lines of quality vealer steers and heifers. All major northern processors were in attendance, along with a live exporter and recent regular western restockers. Two southern processors were notably absent, with medium and light weight cows 10c to 20c/kg easier, while heavy cows and bullocks were 5c to 8c/kg easier. Cattle were drawn from Burketown, Croydon, Georgetown, Einasleigh, Hughenden and Woodstock, with recent local rain preventing supply of many local cattle.

Vealer steers were in very strong demand by western restockers, selling to a new saleyard record of 387.2c, with most 180-220kg steers selling above 370c/kg. Yearling steers were in strong demand, with values lifting by up to 30c, topping at 308.2c, while medium weight steers to feed sold to 302.2c/kg. Vealer heifers again sold very strongly for the small number on offer, selling to 314.2c for lighter types and 306.2c/kg for heifers above 220kg. Yearling heifers sold to 308.2/kg for the few good quality types presented.

Bullocks were of very mixed quality and weight with a live exporter dominant for suitable medium and heavy cattle. 3 score bullocks sold to 290.2c, while medium weight bullocks sold to 278.2c/kg. Some very good heavy 3 score cows to slaughter sold to 252.2c, to average 239.8c, while heavy 2 score cows to slaughter sold to 238.2c, to average 221.1c/kg. Light and medium weight cows to restockers sold to 198.2c/kg. A small number of bulls sold predominantly to live export, topping at 273.2c, with lighter males to restockers sold to 362.2c/kg. A small number of cows and calves sold to $1,300/unit.

Recent wet weather across much of the north and west restricted numbers to 868 cattle this week. Quality was mostly good with some good small lines of prime cows and bullocks, supported by some good quality store steers and heifers and one large line of cows and calves. The buyer panel consisted of all regular northern processors and opportunity local and western restockers.  Values eased in line with other selling centres, notably cows easing 10c and yearling heifers averaging 40c lower.  Cattle were drawn from Hughenden, Mt Surprise and local areas.

Light steers returning to the paddock sold to 470.2c to average 336c and yearling steers above 330kg to live export sold to 348.2c to average 344c/kg.  Vealer heifers returning to the paddock averaged 329c and reached 350.2c, while yearling heifers above 200kg also to grass sold to 384.2 to average 336c/kg.  A small sample of grown heifers to the trade made to 266c to average 250c/kg. Heavy prime bullocks to export processors topped at 298.2c with most selling for 290c/kg. Medium weight 3 and 4 score cows to processors topped at 254.2c to average 234c and prime heavyweight cows sold to 256c to average 248c/kg.

A large line of cows and calves sold for $1500 per unit.


Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Recent scattered showers across much of the local area, reduced numbers to 2,476 cattle in Charters Towers in a combined prime and store sale. The yarding consisted of some very good lines of prime cows and bullocks, and increased numbers of prime heifers. The regular buyer panel again consisted of southern processors and some additional southern restocker orders, supported by two live exporters and feeder buyers, along with local restockers and backgrounders. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Julia Ck, Croydon, Einasleigh, Mt Garnet, Greenvale, Innisfail, Ayr, Ravenswood, local and coastal areas.

Buyer demand was strong for all classes, with feeder buyers active on suitable weight cattle. Yearling heifers to feed increased by 40c to 60c and grown steers improved by more than 20c/kg. Medium weight cows increased by 6c and heavy weight cows increased by 10c/kg. Heavy bulls to feed destined for live export increased by more than 3c/kg.

A very good line of light steer calves to restockers sold for 416.2c, while vealer steers returning to the paddock, topped at 381.2c to average 352c/kg. Heavy vealer heifers to the trade reached 320.2c, while light restockers heifers sold to 300.2c to average above 286c/kg. Limited numbers of good quality yearling steers above 330kg to feed sold to 352.2c to average from 336c to 343c/kg. A large sample of yearling heifers above 330kg to feed topped at 346.2c, averaging from 320c to 333c, while heifers above 400kg to feed reached 346.2c to average 333c/kg. A small line of heifers above 330kg to the trade sold to 354.2c, while heifers above 400kg sold from 308c to 334.2c/kg. Heavy grown steers above 400kg to feed topped at 366.2c to average above 345c, and those to background feed destined for live export averaged 351c/kg. A large sample of grown heifers to the trade averaged 279c, reaching 310.2c, while those to feed sold from 269c to 322c/kg.

Heavy bullocks to export processor sold to 350.2c to average from 335c to 343c for better lines, with lesser types averaging from 302c to 315c/kg. Medium weight cows to processors sold to 246.2c to average 235c, while heavy 3 score cows topped at 290.2c to average near 280c/kg. A large sample of heavy, lesser yielding 3 score cows average 266c/kg. Several pens excellent of prime heavy weight cows sold to a high of 295.2c to average 286c/kg. Heavy bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 350.2c to average from 306c to 331c/kg. Pens of cows with small calves sold from $1,000 to $1,180/unit.

Recent rain across much of the supply area saw numbers reduced to 1057 mixed quality cattle.  Prime cattle consisted mostly of forward store cows, with several lines of northern store heifers also on offer.  Most regular processors operated at increased rates, particularly for heavier lines, while one live exporter and several backgrounders operated throughout the sale.  Cattle were drawn from Burketown, Einasleigh, Georgetown, Mt Surprise, Ingham, Collinsville, local and coastal areas.

Small lines of vealer steers eased by up to 4c, while young heifers improved by up to 7c/kg.  Minimal numbers of yearling steers sold firm, while better quality yearling heifers returning to the paddock improved by up to 11c/kg.  Grown heifers to processors increased by up to 20c, while heavy prime cows improved by 15c and lighter store cows improved by 9c/kg.

Steer calves sold to 271c and vealer steers to restockers sold to 258c to average 252c, with heavier types to live export reaching 263c/kg. A large sample of oung heifers to restockers sold to 196c to average 166c/kg.  Yearling steers to live export made to 259c averaging 257c with yearling heifers returning to grass and backgrounders making to 188c to average 175c/kg. A small number of grown steers to live export made 259c and there were insufficient numbers of bullocks to quote.  Heavy prime cows to processors sold to 206c to average more than 200c/kg, while heavy 2 score cows also reached 206c to average 183c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows to slaughter sold to 169c to average 153c and plainer types returning to grass made to 153c to average 144c/kg.  Heavy bulls to live export made to 274c/kg.

Recent dry conditions led to a plain quality yarding, resulting in significant numbers of cattle needing to be supplementary fed.  Unlike most southern markets, an increased yarding was offered.  Most stock came from the north and west and all the usual buyers were present and operating, including three major processors. Competition was steady and the market sold to a firm trend.
