Good quality lighter steers were in limited number and ranged from 130.2c to 144.2c/kg. The better end of the medium steers averaged 164.6c, some C3’s selling to a top of 167.2c/kg. Heavy steers topped the sale at 170.2c/kg. Export heifers were in limited numbers and most sales were around 126c/kg. 

Cows were present in large numbers with some better quality lines offered. D3 lightweights sold to 145.2c with most sales at 135c/kg. Medium weight cows were of mixed quality with some good C3s selling to 156.2c as D3s, which were in the majority, averaged 144.2c/kg.

Quality was noticeably poorer compared to last sale as the number of well finished cattle in the region dwindles. Despite this market trends were dearer for grown steers as all the regular buyers competed but a cheaper trend cold not be prevented on grown heifers, cows and bulls. 

Light grown steers ranged from 170c to 183.2c with occasional runs of heavy pens averaging 189c/kg. Grown heifer prices reflected the quality on offer and slipped to average 155c/kg. 

Light cows accounted for a large majority of numbers, these included a number of poor conditioned stock. Prices eased to average 148.3c while medium weights averaged 164c after reaching 175.2c/kg. There were very few heavy cows offered. Bull quality was poor and prices reflected this by easing for all weights.

Quality was noticeably better than the previous sale as last weeks dearer trend enticed more cattle onto the market. Storms are threatening on the district but no significant rain has yet eventuated. Despite the better quality and good competition from restockers, all grades sold to cheaper levels as the major processors operated at reduced rates. 

Medium weight grown steers comprised the majority of the steer yarding, they ranged from 167.2c to 195c with occasional heavy sales reaching 206.2c/kg. Light, unfinished types averaged 161.4c/kg while heifers also sold to cheaper rates. 

No heavy cows were yarded but medium weights averaged 170.6c after reaching 179.2c/kg. Light D3 cows ranged from 132.2c to 168.2c while plain, unfinished cows sold mostly at 119.8c/kg. Bulls sold to reduced rates.

Quality was mixed across the yarding with some excellent pens of bullocks offset by a much plainer cow yarding. All the usual export buyers were present and hotly contested the suitable lines to send the market on a dearer trend to last sale. Store descriptions continued to sell well with plainer cows and bullocks achieving good returns. 

Grown steers comprised a large percentage of the total yarding with medium weights ranging from 156.2c to 172c to average 166.7c/kg. Heavier lines topped at 177.2c to average 173c/kg. Bullocks were of reasonable quality and were rewarded accordingly, ranging from 165.2c to 178.2c to average 176c/kg. 

Cows attracted keen interest from all exporters with both good and plain quality types achieving good returns. Light D3s averaged 141.8c after reaching 151.2c while medium weights of similar condition averaged 149.8c/kg. Bulls improved for all weights with the better conditioned heavy weights topping at 158.2c/kg.

Quality improved and numbers increased by 1,121 head to 3,541 cattle in Charters Towers where records tumbled in a demand driven market. Some good lines of local bullocks and cows saw values increase on recent weeks, while some large lines of very good quality light steers and heifers saw records tumble. Values for prime cattle increase by 15c to 20c and restocker categories improved by up to 70c on recent weeks. All regular processors were in attendance and operating with strong demand supported by one live exporter regular feeder buyers and several western and southern restockers. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Doomadgee, Normanton, Greenvale, Ravenswood, local and coastal areas.

Light steer calves to back grounders reached 505.2c and heifer calves sold to 420.2c with a large sample of mixed sex calves averaging an astonishing 436c/kg. Light vealer steers to restockers sold to 490.2c to average from 454c to 485c, with steers above 280kg to restockers averaging 412c/kg. Vealer heifers to processors topped at 385.2c to average from 375c to 378c, while restocker lines averaged from 340c to 363c/kg. Yearling steers returning to grass made to 362.2c to average 332c, with feeder steers averaging from 335c to 364c/kg. Yearling heifers met continued strong demand increasing by 16c to 18c, selling to 366c to average from 321c to 352c/kg. Heavy grown steers to feed sold to 350.2c to average the same, while processors secured a small number to 347c/kg. Heavy grown heifers to the trade sold to 328.2c to average from 270c to 296c/kg. Heavy bullocks improved by 5c to 15c, with those to export slaughter selling to 377.2c with most sales from 364c to 374c/kg. 

An Increased number of cows met very strong demand from all processors, with heavy cows increasing by 16c to 18c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows sold to 280.2c to average 262c and 3 scores sold to 312.2c to average above 289c/kg. Prime heavy weight 4 score cows made to 318c/kg. Cows to western restockers sold to 260c averaging 235c to 246c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export reached 338.2c to average 317c to 327c while feeder weights reached 360.2c to average 309c to 335c/kg. Young males returning to grass sold to 492.2c to average 379c/kg. A small number of cows and calves sold from $1260 to $1700/unit.

Prime numbers remained limited although there were 785 store cattle also offered.  Grown steers, bullocks and grown heifers were limited with the majority of the penning consisting of light and medium weight cows.  Two major export processors were present along with several local butchers and competition was firm across most categories.

Grown steers and bullocks were slightly cheaper, however this was partly due to the plainer quality offered.  Most of the better C muscled pens made from 153.2¢ to 170.2¢/kg.  Grown heifers also eased slightly and most of the D muscled lines made from 124.2¢ to 130.2¢/kg.

Cow quotes fell under restricted competing and most of the D2s and D3s made from 119.2¢ to 138.2¢ with some heavy 4 score cows selling to 159.2¢/kg.

Prime cattle numbers increased slightly for a similar sized yarding. There were some good pens of bullocks and cows offered which helped lift the overall quality of the sale. All the regular export buyers were present plus one processor not seen for a number of weeks. Export grades sold to a slightly easier trend with the better lines of steers and well conditioned cows achieving firm to slightly higher rates.

Medium and heavy weight grown steers comprised the majority of the yarding. Medium weights ranged from 151.2c to 160.2c to average 157.3c/kg. The heavier lines reached 167.2c after averaging 165.1c/kg. 

Cow quality was fair to good. Lightweights ranged from 125.2c to 134.2c to average 128.9c/kg. Large lines of medium weight D3s averaged 139.1c after reaching a top of 148.2c/kg. The best bull price was 126.2c for a heavy weight description.
Only a handful of prime cattle were offered. Major exporters are still not in operation in the region. Numbers were too few to gain a reliable quote.

Once again, and as expected for this time of year, a smaller yarding was offered. The steers suffer losses while some cow classes were able to regain the losses of last week. Most of the usual local and export buyers were present.

The steers were reported to be of plainer quality and combine this with a missing buyer, the light weights were dealt the greatest falls for the sale. The medium weights sold to 148.2c, as large numbers of heavy steers and bullocks held firm after reaching 166.2c/kg. 

Large numbers of light heifers were offered, as the D3s sold to 148.2c/kg. The cows sold to strong competition, with lightweight D2s selling to 118.2c/kg. The top of the cows was the medium weight D3s reaching 138.2c/kg. 

Bulls were in reduced numbers and this allowed the medium and heavy weights to receive further gains.

On the back of two sales last week, the supply of cattle reduced for a yarding of 2970 in a Combined Prime and Store sale.  Despite some good lines of heavy prime  bullocks and cows, quality was not as good as recent weeks,, comprising of an increased number of plain conditioned cows and heifers along with an increased supply of northern males. All regular processors were in attendance and operating, supported by one live exporter, one feeder and opportunity restockers.  Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Richmond, Georgetown, Ayr, local and coastal areas.

Demand for heavy prime cattle and best quality feeders was good, however lesser quality and plain conditioned  light cattle struggled to attract buyer support. Heavy bullocks lifted 10c, grown steers and heifers fell 6c to 20c, medium weight cows averaged 7c lower, heavy cows 11c to 16c easier and bulls to live export were firm to 12c to 14c higher.

Good quality vealer steers returning to grass averaged 284c selling to 302c, similar heifers to restockers made 200c/kg. Yearling steers above 200kg to backgrounders sold to 256c to average 221c, steers above 280kg returning to the paddock averaged 247c and steers above 330kg sold to 282c to average 279c/kg. Best quality yearling heifers above 280kg to feed sold to 222c to average 210c, with a very good quality large line of heifers above 330kg to feed selling to 268c to average 260c/kg. A good sample of heifers above 400kg to feed averaged 263c and processor types averaged 282c/kg.

Grown steers above 400kg to processors averaged 256c to 266c, selling to 272c, steers suitable for live export made to 304c.  Grown heifers to the trade made to 262c to average 241c/kg.  A good sample of heavy full mouthed bulls to export slaughter topped at 315c to average 292c to 314c and bullocks to live export reached 310c to average 299c to 310c/kg. 

Lightweight cows to restockers sold to 192c to average 188c, while 2 scores to processors sold to 220c to average 180c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows reached 230c to average 200c, 3 scores sold to 262c to average 245c/kg. Prime heavyweight 3 and 4 score cows topped at 278c, averaging from 260c to 268c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export sold to 286c, most selling from 260c to 276c/kg. Bulls to processors averaged 227c to 254c/kg.

A small number of cows and calves sold to $650 per unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Numbers were up slightly in a similar quality yarding. Consistent runs of fair quality bullocks were offered and there were large runs of cows, which sold to a full gallery of the regular buyers. Processors purchased the majority of the offering with local butchers and traders securing the remainder. The quality and competition saw all grades sell to a dearer market with plainer types also securing good rates. 

Lightweight export steers sold to a top of 139.2c to average 115.8c/kg. Medium and heavy bullocks enjoyed stronger competition to improve for both grades. Medium bullocks ranged from 150.2c to 159.2c to average 152.1c while heavier weights averaged 159.2c/kg. Grown heifers achieved higher rates of 130.7c after reaching a top of 139.2c/kg.

Cow quality was consistent over the large lines of medium weight cows penned. Medium D3 s ranged from 127.2c to 142.2c to average 135c/kg. Bulls also enjoyed price gains to reach a top of 135.2c/kg for heavy weight descriptions.

Numbers were up slightly and quality was slightly plainer than the last sale. The continuing dry climate is making it difficult for producers to market cattle with sufficient condition. A feature of the sale were some excellent quality grown steers and bullocks that had been finished on grain and came from the coastal regions that sold to keen interest. However most sales experienced weaker demand from a full field of the regular buyers, although not all participated. 

Lightweights made up a fair percentage of the grown steer yarding, they sold to 149.2c to average 144.6c/kg. Medium weights averaged 170.1c with occasional supplementary fed descriptions reaching 196.2c/kg. Heavy steers reached up to 197.2c on individual occasions with most sales at 185.5c/kg. Grown heifers sold to a cheaper market, averaging between 147.1c and 154.5c/kg. 

Cow demand was weaker as lightweights lost value to average 144.8c/kg. Medium weight D3 also slipped to range from 140.2c to 174.2c, however some heavy cow sales reached 180.2c/kg. Competition on bulls was weaker for them to sell at cheaper levels.

Numbers were up in a much better quality yarding of well-finished cattle. Trade cattle were non-existent in a yarding of mostly export categories. The return of one processor buyer helped maintain strong competition as all other regular buyers were also present.

Grown steers were mostly present in the medium weights, these were contested by processors and local butcher operators. The majority D3s ranged from 129.2¢ to 149.2¢ to sell mostly at 141.5¢/kg. Heifers eased slightly to averaged 110.5¢/kg.

The cow yarding sold to a mostly firm market with medium weight D3s making the best money of 120¢/kg. Bulls sold to a top of 117.2¢/kg.

Numbers were similar to last sale with 2,585 mostly prime cattle presented this week with more than 2,600 booked for a store sale on Friday. Some very good lines of prime cows and bullocks were presented along with increased numbers of heavy bulls. All regular processors were in attendance and operating, supported by two live exporters and feeder buyers operating at increased rates on last sale. Bullocks improved by 7c, heavy cows lifted by 11c to 20c and heavy bulls improved by 5c to 8c/kg. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Normanton, Richmond, Pentland, Ingham, Townsville, Belyando, local and coastal areas.

A small number of heavy vealer steers to feed made 360.2c and vealer heifers to processors sold to 380.2c to average 366c/kg. Yearling heifers to feed sold firm to 20c dearer, topping at 338.2c to average 334c and grown heifers to feed also made 338.2c to average 294c/kg. Grown heifers to the trade sold to 324.2c to average 276c/kg. Limited numbers of yearling steers to feed sold to 365.2c/kg. Grown steers to live export sold to 339.2c to average 328c and heavy steers above 400kg to feed topped at 365.2c to average 355c/kg. Heavy bullocks to live export topped at 345.2c to average 340c and processor lines averaged 341c/kg.  

Medium weight 2 score cows lifted 3c, selling to 266c to average 248c and 3 scores sold to 290.2c to average 266c/kg. Prime heavy weight cows sold to 280.2c to average 278c/kg. Increased numbers of heavy bulls to live export topped at 342.2c, with most sales from 330c to 338c/kg. Feeder weight males to feed destined for live export averaged from 280c to 320c/kg.

Numbers were reduced following the larger yarding penned last week. Just under half of the yarding was store cattle as the supply area hays off very quickly. The lack of body of feed is impacting on quality and yield of the cattle. The regular exporters and trade buyers were in operation with values holding on rather well considering the cheaper markets of recent weeks. 

Light grown steers averaged from 129c to 139c/kg. Most of the steers offered were medium weights, which sold to 151.2c and averaged 146.2c/kg. Heavy steers remained firm after selling to 155.2c while good bullocks reached 157.2c/kg for the limited numbers available. 

A fair number of cows were also offered as prices held firm to slightly cheaper. Light D2s averaged 116c as plainer lines averaged closer to 94c/kg. The large number of D3s held firm at 127.5c after selling to 133.2c/kg.

Numbers were reduced again and values followed the trend of other markets to be mixed. Quality too was varied with a portion of each category in plain condition. Steers and bullocks dominated the market. 

Light grown steers made to 143.2c to average 141.5c/kg. The better medium weights suited to the Korean market topped at 158.2c as plainer muscled lines averaged from 135c to 146c/kg. Heavy weights reached 162.2c as a large number of heavy bullocks averaged 161c/kg. Only a handful of export heifers were yarded with most selling firm to slightly dearer. 

Most of cows offered were lightweights as heavy weights were almost non existent. Light D2s sold to 118.2c to average 116.1c as a small number of D3s averaged 120.4c/kg. A fair number of plain E muscled light cows averaged 73.1c/kg. Medium weights made to an isolated 136.2c as heavy weights reached 147.2c/kg.

Numbers were once again capped due to live exporter bookings of yard space, where 2,481 cattle were penned, 1,056 fewer than last sale. Two regular processors were absent, however one major processor returned to the buyer gallery, accompanied by two live exporters, feeder buyers with several local and western restockers. With the reduced yarding there were fewer numbers of heavy prime cows, however some very good pens of cows and bullocks were on offer imoproving by 3c to 12c, supported by some excellent young light weight cattle attracting strong demand. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Burketown, Normanton, Georgetown, Ingham, Home Hill, local and coastal areas.

Increased numbers of steer calves continued to attract strong restocker demand selling to 439.2c, to average 409c, with heifer calves to processors topping at 388.2c to average 370c/kg. Vealer steers returning to the paddock sold to 394.2c, to average 390c, while steers to feed averaged from 335c to 340c/kg.  Vealer heifers to processors topped at 386.2c, to average 355c/kg. Yearling steers above 280kg to restockers sold to 376.2c, to average 364c/kg and steers above 330kg to feed sold to 362.2c, to average from 336c to 339c/kg. Yearling steers to processors sold to 320.2c to average 319c/kg. Mixed quality yearling heifers to feed sold to 348.2c, to average 308c to 324c/kg. Grown steers consisted of considerable variation in quality, with better bred pens to feed selling to 340.2c, to average 313c, while heavy steers to the trade sold to 340.2c, to average 329c/kg. Some good lines of prime grown heifers to the trade topped at 299.2c, to average from 275c to 295c, while medium weights to feed reached 338.2c, to average from 266c to 302c/kg.

Some excellent pens of heavy export bullocks to export slaughter sold to 340.2c, to average from 322c to 336c, with suitable pens to live export selling to 333c to average 329c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 249.2c, to average 236c, with 3 score cows reaching 274.2c multiple times to average from 256c to 273c/kg. Prime heavy weight cows sold for 284c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export topped at 332c, to average above 318c, with heavy bulls to processors sold to 334c, and averaged 333c/kg. Feeder weight bulls destined for live export sold to 326.2c, to average from 260c to 315c/kg.

A small number of cows and calves sold from $920 to 1,320/unit.

Numbers were drawn from a wide area for a reduced quality offering. Light and unfinished descriptions dominated both steer and cow yardings. Despite this, competition was strong for the right article from a full field of the regular buyers plus one extra buyer. Most grown steers sold to good demand and achieved price gains, light cows eased while well-finished cows sold to dearer levels. 

Runs of lightweight D3s averaged 142.6c after reaching 150c/kg. Medium weights ranged from 182.2c to 195c with occasional heavy weight sales reaching 195.2c/kg. The limited number of grown heifers present sold to mostly dearer levels.

Cows sold to mixed demand with lighter grades easing and medium and heavy weights improving. Large runs of light D3 types averaged 145c to top at 167.2c/kg. Similar description medium and heavy types ranged from 135.2c to 178.2c with most sales around 170.5c/kg. Bull quality was mixed but most sold at dearer rates.

Numbers were back slightly in a similar quality yarding. Consistent runs of good quality bullocks were hard to come by but there were large runs of cows offered, which sold to a full gallery of the regular buyers. Processors purchased the majority of the offering with local butchers and traders securing the remainder. The extra quality and competition saw all grades sell to a dearer market. 

Lightweight export steers sold to a top of 125.2c to average 118.3c/kg. Medium and heavy steers and bullocks enjoyed stronger competition to improve for both grades. Medium bullocks ranged from 130c to 147.2c to average 142.7c while heavier weights averaged 144c after topping at 148.2c/kg. Grown heifers maintained firm rates of 120.2c after reaching a top of 134.2c/kg.

Cow quality was consistent over the large lines of medium weight cows penned. Medium D3 s ranged from 124.2c to 148.2c to average 137c/kg. Bulls also enjoyed price gains to reach a top of 128.2c/kg for heavy weight descriptions.

Numbers were back slightly in a better quality yarding. Large consistent runs of good quality bullocks and cows sold to a full gallery of the regular buyers plus one extra export operator. Processors purchased the majority of the offering with local butchers and traders securing the remainder. The extra quality and competition saw all grades sell to a dearer market. 

Lightweight export steers sold to a cheaper market to average 107.9c/kg. Medium and heavy bullocks enjoyed stronger competition to improve for both grades. Medium bullocks ranged from 130c to 151.2c to average 143c while heavier weights averaged 153.3c after topping at 156.2c/kg. Grown heifers maintained firm rates of 128.6c after reaching a top of 131.2c/kg.

Cow quality was consistent over the large lines of medium weight cows penned. Medium D3 s ranged from 117.2c to 129.2c to average 125.7c while the plainer 2 scores averaged 116.8c/kg. Bulls also enjoyed price gains to reach a top of 123.2c/kg for lightweight descriptions.

Numbers were back for a smaller fair quality yarding. A full panel of buyers were operating including one processor who has not been present for the last 18 months. Cattle were sourced from as far as the Gulf and a single processor purchased the majority of the offering.

Steers sold to strong competition and reached a top of 192.2c, the majority were medium weights and they sold mostly to 179c/kg. Heifers averaged 141c/kg.

Some good C2 drafts were offered along with very plain runs of E1 cows. The better lightweights made to 156.2c, medium weights averaged between 145c and 157c/kg. Heavy cows made to 163.2c/kg. A heavy C1 bull sold at 152.2c/kg.

Numbers returned to similar of the previous fortnight following insufficient numbers last week for a yarding of 2,351 mixed quality cattle in very hot temperatures in Charters Towers. Some good quality heavy lines of prime cows and bullocks were on offer, accompanied by several lines of prime and store cattle showing the effects of the ever increasing dry season. One major processor was absent and similar to southern markets, prices for all prime cattle eased considerably. One live exporter and several opportunity restockers and backgrounders operated selectively on many lines sourced from Mt Isa, Hughenden, Muttaburra, Mt Garnet, Belyando, local and coastal areas.

Mixed sex calves saw quality related price changes, while good quality vealer steers improved with spirited demand on selected pens. Vealer heifers softened across all categories, particularly lighter lesser quality lines by more than 30c and mixed quality yearling heifers to restockers sold 55c to 70c/kg lower. Yearling steers to feed and restockers eased by 20c to 40c and all grown steers to feed and backgrounders saw prices ease by 35c to 55c/kg. Select pens of good quality grown heifers to feeders improved by 50c, however heavy heifers to the trade eased by 40c to 50c/kg. Many lines of mixed quality plain bullocks met limited demand, with a small number of heavy export bullocks easing more than 50c/kg on previous sale. Medium weight cows to processor eased more than 30c and heavy 3 and 4 score cows sold more than 50c/kg lower. Bulls to feed destined for live export eased by 25c to 30c/kg.

Good quality vealer steers sold to 316c and heavier types made to 308c, with lesser quality lines averaging 268c/kg. Better lines of vealer heifers to restockers sold to 215c, while a good sample of heavy heifers to live export sold for 264c/kg. Yearling steers varied in quality and weight, resulting in selective buyer interest. Light weight steers to restockers topped at 190c, while steers above 280kg to feed sold to 269c to average 240c and plainer types returning to grass topped at 290c to average 265c/kg. Light grown steers to feed or background sold from 256c to 262c and those returning to the paddocks sold to 244c, for an average of 242c/kg. Light yearling heifers to feed sold to 185c with quality lines returning to grass topping at 198c, while heavy heifers above 400kg to feed made 225c/kg. Grown heifers to feed sold from 206c to 210c and heavy heifers to the trade sold to 229c/kg.

A small number of heavy 4 score bullocks to export slaughter sold to 260c to average 256, with many plainer types to feed selling from 250c to 254c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 148c to average 128c and heavy 3 score cows topped at 189c to average 181c/kg. Extra heavy 3 score cows topped at 197c and 4 scores sold to 189c to average 187c/kg. Cows returning to grass sold to 147c to average 126c/kg. Heavy bulls to feed destined for live export sold from 254c to 275c, with heavy bulls to processor selling from 210c to 212c/kg. Young males to restockers and backgrounders sold to 296c, to average 278c/kg.

Numbers remained similar to last week although there is less supply than the beginning of 2001. The late wet season has been cited as one reason behind the lower numbers, and true trends in the market will not become apparent until all northern processors are operating.  Rain is needed and there is a growing concern amongst producers regarding pasture and water availability. 

Only a handful of steers were penned and Korean weight D2s topped at 179.2c/kg. Cows made up the bulk of the yarding and prices were mixed. The lighter weights sold on a dearer trend and D2s topped at 117.2c to average 113.1c/kg. The majority of medium weights were in fair condition but lost 10c to average 122.9c/kg. There was an insufficient number of bulls to provide and accurate quote.

Numbers remained relatively small and not all buyers were in attendance. Quality overall was mixed. Processor competition was very strong and as a result prices were well above last week and the state average. Heavy steers were 6c dearer while the cows gained from 8c to 17c/kg as a result of the strong localised competition.

Light steers peaked at 140c and most averaged 124.2c/kg. Medium weights sold to 154.2c and averaged 133.7c/kg. Heavy steers peaked at 160.2c and averaged 152.5c/kg. 

Heifers sold to 148.2c and most averaged 137.7c/kg. Light cows reached 130.2c and averaged 112.5c/kg. Medium weight cows sold to 139.2c and most sales ranged between 132c and 137c/kg. Heavy bulls peaked at 143.2c/kg.

Numbers remained relatively close to the previous sale, although values suffered a similar fate to that of other markets across the state. The dry seasonal conditions in the local district and wintery conditions are definitely effecting the market, with competition subdued.

A small sample of steers and bullocks generally eased from 7c to 16c/kg. Most values fell into the early 100c mark, with the top price at 123.2c/kg. The sample of heifers consisted those under 540kg, also eased, but managed to reach a top price of 118.2c/kg.

The cow market overall received the smaller falls with a 5c to 8c/kg cheaper trend. Lightweights reached a top of 98.2c, with the best of the heavy weights to 109.2c/kg.

Numbers remained firm in a plain quality yarding. Recent poor seasonal conditions have meant that quality has been lower than usual for this time of year. All the usual buyers were present including three major processors and some local butchers.

Steers were well represented, particularly the medium and heavy weights and they sold to a top of 169.2c/kg. Heifers ranged from 91.2c to 120.2c averaging around 105c/kg. 

Cows made up a large percentage of the yarding, lighter cows accounting for 22% of the total. Quality was fair with D2 and D3 scores featuring heavily. Light weight prices sold to 132.2c/kg. Medium weight cows ranged from 115.2c to 155c, the heavier cows achieved some good prices selling to 155.2c/kg.

Numbers remained close to that of previous sales and with all buyers eager to fill orders values improved again.  The quality of the steers was improved, however the cows were not as good as previous weeks.

Both the light steers and heavy bullocks were in relatively small numbers with values across all weight ranges improving up to 8c/kg. The medium weight steers sold to 208.6c as almost 200 heavy steers averaged 203.3c/kg. The heavy steers and bullocks all returned over $1,000/head and both set a new saleyard record after selling to 212.2c/kg.  

The light heifers in the greatest number received the largest gain after reaching a top of 188.2c/kg. The lean light cows lost 7c as the D2s averaged 154.9c/kg. The medium cows sold to 188.2c with a single heavy D3 reaching 190.2c/kg. 

The bulls sold to mixed results as the light and heavy weights suffered slight falls yet medium weights received gains of over 10c/kg. The top of the heavy bulls sold to 190c/kg and returned over $1,400/head.

Numbers remained close to last week and values improved substantially as the regular field of buyers competed strongly. The best cattle were of quite a good standard while the balance of the yarding was reported to taper off in finish. The light steers gained 3c to 7c while the medium weights improved up to 14c/kg. The heavy steers gained 4c to 7c/kg. The heifers were 1c to 8c dearer while the cows improved 8c to 13c/kg. 

The light steers sold to 133.2c and they averaged 131.5c/kg. The medium weights topped at 155.2c and a large number averaged 150.8c/kg. Heavy steers were in large numbers and they reached 163.2c which saw close to 200 head average 154.2c/kg. Heavy bullocks topped at 162.2c and they averaged 159.6c/kg.

The light cows sold to 145.2c and the lightest grades averaged 100c while close to 100 D2s saw most sales around 125c/kg. The medium weight cows topped at 149.2c and over 100 D3s averaged 144.1c/kg. 

Light bulls topped at 130c and most sold around 106c/kg. Medium weights made to 147.2c and the heavy weights reached 165.2c/kg to return up to $1,578/head.

Numbers reduced slightly and quality was good for this time of year. Of all the buyers present only one meatworks operated with whatever leftover being bought by local butchers. As a result of the weaker competition values eased for all grades.

Grown steers were evenly spread across all weight ranges with lightweights averaging between 142.3c and 155.7c/kg. Medium weights averaged 160.1c after topping at 180c/kg. Grown heifers in limited numbers sold to weaker rates.

Cows slipped for medium D3s in the majority to average 139.2c and the small selection of bulls sold to a cheaper market.

Numbers reduced on a fortnight ago by 558 for a yarding of 986 cattle.  Quality was very mixed, comprising of some good quality pens of heavy cows and a good line of grown steers, while there were many smaller mixed quality light lines.  Buyer attendance was limited to three regular processors and opportunity restockers and traders. Price trends were similar to other selling centres across the state. 

Yearling steers and heifers eased 20c to 50c and cows to processors averaged 7c to 13 lower.  Good quality light steers averaged 357c, selling to 414.2c and yearling steers above 280kg returning to the paddock reached 398.2 to average 355c/kg. A good line of grown steers to processors made 298c/kg.  Light heifers to restockers sold to 322.2c to average 254c and heifers above 280kg for breeding topped at 312.2c to average 286c/kg.

A limited number of prime bullocks made to 304.2c, most selling from 284c to 298c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 254.2c to average 205c and a large sample of three scores reached 242c to average 219c/kg.  Heavy bulls to processors reached 268c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Numbers reduced by 634 for a yarding of 3151 cattle.  Quality was good overall, comprising of an increased supply of heavy prime cows and several good lines of store steers and heifers.  A reduced buyer gallery was in attendance - one central processor operated for the first time this year - most regular processors were supported by one live exporter, two feeder buyers and opportunity restockers. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa to Georgetown, Ingham, Ayr and the local area.

Values for better quality prime cattle were firm to 16c higher, with improved quality and factor, however many store lines met subdued demand, resulting in lower values than last sale, with some pens difficult to sell.

Suitably weaned steers below 200kg to restockers sold to 260c to average 246c, similar heifers returning to the paddock reached 206c to average 198c/kg. Steers above 200kg averaged 289c selling to 294c, similar heifers returning to the paddock averaged 185c/kg. Yearling steers above 200kg returning to the paddock averaged 248c to 265c selling to 290c, steers above 280kg averaged 236 and steers above 330kg averaged 231c/kg. Yearling steers above 400kg  to feed averaged 242c/kg. Yearling heifers above 200kg to restockers averaged 180c to 184c, a good sample of 280kg returning to the paddock topped at 255c to average 223c/kg, while heifers to feed averaged 190c/kg.

A small sample of grown steers to live export made from 250c to 268c, similar steers to feed destined for live export sold to 266c to average 251c/kg. Best quality grown heifers to the trade reached 238c to average 222c/kg.

A small sample of heavy bullocks to processors sold to 252c, most around 230. Medium weight 2 score cows made to 198c to average 194c, 3 score cows sold to 220c to average 197c to 199c/kg.
An increased supply of prime heavyweight cows topped at 240c to average 211c to 217c/kg.

A very small supply of heavy bulls to feed destined for live export averaged 238c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Numbers once again increased due to strong demand by 415 head to 3,150 cattle in Charters Towers. Overall quality was good, however many lines were showing effects of the deteriorating season. Some very good lines of prime cows and one grain fed line of cows were on offer along with some very good quality yearling heifers. All regular processors were in attendance and operating at firm rates, supported by central and southern feeder buyers, one live exporter and western restockers. Grown steers and heifers were up to 6c stronger, heavy cows lifted 3c and bullocks sold firm on last sale. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Julia Ck, Croydon, Mt Garnet, Einasleigh, Greenvale, Atherton, Woodstock, Belyando, local and coastal areas.

A large sample of light vealer steers returning to grass topped at 518.2c to average 499c, while steers above 200kg to restockers sold to a top of 440.2c multiple times to average from 406c to 426c/kg. Vealer heifers to processors reached 396.2c and restocker lines averaged 399c/kg. A large sample of light heifers to feed sold to 382.2c to average 345c/kg. Light yearling steers to backgrounders sold to 386.2c and steers above 330kg returning to grass reached 406.2c. Yearling heifers above 330kg to feed sold to 360.2c to average from 350c to 357c/kg. A very good line of heifers above 330kg returned to the paddock made up to 385.2c/kg. 

Grown steers to live export sold to 372.2c, with most sales above 364c while steers to the trade made from 364c to 386.2c/kg. Grown heifers to the trade sold up to 366.2c,while pen lots to feed sold from 334c to 364c and heifers returning to the paddock averaged from 299c to 340c/kg. Heavy full mouthed bullocks to export slaughter sold from 348.2c to a top of 388.2c/kg. 

Fewer numbers of medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 296.2c while 3 score cows reached 324.2c to average from 298c to 319c/kg. Prime heavy weight cows topped at 318.2c to average 316c/kg. A line of store conditioned northern PTIC cows averaged 280c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export sold to 378.2c with most sales above 360c while heavy bulls to processors sold to a top of 380.2c/kg. Younger restocker bulls averaged from 375c to 378c/kg. An increased number of cows and calves met strong demand selling from $1,020 up to $1,900/unit for large framed crossbred cows and calves.

Numbers once again increased beyond 3,000 head for a yarding of 3,105 cattle, 118 more than last sale. The offering comprised of some excellent lines of heavy prime cows and increased numbers of young crossbred steers all selling to increased rates on recent weeks. Most classes sold to increased prices with strong demand from the regular buying panel, assisted by central feeder and background orders. Cattle were drawn from Burketown, Croydon, Georgetown, Mt Garnet, Einasleigh, Richmond, Hughenden, Collinsville, local and coastal areas.

Young vealer steers sold to improved prices with crossbred steers attracting strong demand improving by more than 15c/kg on last sale. Vealer heifers met solid demand for better quality lines, however a mixed quality offering of yearling heifers sold in line with quality. Yearling steers to feed increased by 10c to 15c/kg in all weight ranges. However grown steers were of very mixed quality, medium weights to feed eased in line with quality and good heavy steers to processors improved by up to 3c/kg on last sale. Grown heifers to feed increasing more than 20c for better quality lines, with heifers to the trade improving by 6c/kg for heavy weights. Good quality heavy bullocks to export processor improved by 4c to 6c/kg. Medium weight cows to processors eased by 11c, mostly in plain condition, while suitable types to restockers lifted by 12c/kg. Heavy cows increased 9c/kg, with prime heavy weights firm on last sale. Heavy bulls to background feed destined for live export saw average increases above 20c/kg, with similar increases for good quality bulls to processors.

Light weight vealer steers to restockers sold to 334.2c to average near 300c, while steers above 200kg returning to grass sold to 352.2c to average 320c, with steers to feeder orders averaging 288c/kg. Very good quality vealer heifers returning to the paddock sold to 272c, with a good sample averaging near 228cc/kg. Suitable processor types made to 274.2c to average 249c, while a very good line of heavy young heifers to feed averaged 245c/kg. Yearling steers to feed mostly sold from 265c to 284c, with all weight categories averaging 273c to 278c/kg. Yearling heifer demand was mixed in line with quality with averages from 175c to 210c/kg.

Grown steers to processors sold to 292.2c to average above 285c/kg for heavy better bred lines. Mixed quality grown heifers eased slightly, with quality and weight a factor, however heavy weights reached 259c to average above 235c, with medium weights to feed averaging above 207c/kg. A good sample of heavy export bullocks to processors topped at 295c to average near 280c/kg. Medium weight cows to processors sold to 211c to average 179c/kg, with number of plain condition lines on offer. Increased numbers of good heavy cows sold to 245c to average near 220c, with some excellent prime heavy weights reaching 250.2c to average 233c/kg. Heavy bulls suitable for live export to background feed mostly sold from 275c to 299c to average above 280c/kg. Small lines of good quality cows and calves sold from $800 to 1,060/unit.

Numbers nearly doubled on last sale for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents to 1,415 head, following recent widespread showers and storms, with large lines of northern store steers generating considerable buyer interest.  One processor continued their year-long absence, while all others had the competition of two live exporters and several restockers throughout the sale.  The mixed yarding of cows and bullocks increased 5c to 8c/kg for the limited numbers with cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Croydon, Pentland, Ingham, local and coastal areas.

A small number of vealer steers sold stronger due to increased demand for opportunity restockers selling to 358c averaging 355c, while some smaller calves sold to a sale high 380c/kg. Yearling steers lifted in number due to two large northern lines with considerable demand from both live exporters and restockers lifting rates for all weight classes up to 30c/kg. Feeder weight steers to live export sold to 323c, with heavy feeder steers to 309c, with slaughter weights also reaching 309c to average 300c/kg. Light steers to restockers sold to 330c/kg. Vealer heifers were in short supply, attracting strong restocker demand, topping at 292c/kg. A large line of light northern female calves sold to 372c to average 320c/kg. A small mixed offering of yearling offers sold to 278c/kg to return to grass.

Bullocks attracted live export demand at supreme rates to processors, securing most of the mixed offering displaying variable age and weight.  Heavy bullocks to live export sold to 280c, averaging 263c, with better covered lighter types selling to 260c/kg. Processors secured a small number of bullocks for slaughter to 258c/kg. A larger offering of northern grown steers to live export sold to 298c, averaging 287c, with feeder types selling to 309c to average 305c/kg. Grown steers returning to grass sold to 281c, with most sales 264c to 271c/kg.

A similar number of mixed quality cows to last sale increased 8c to 20c with heavy 3 score cows to slaughter topping at 224c and 2 score cows to 219c to average 205c/kg. Heavy D muscled cows sold to 206c averaging 198c and 2 score cows lifted 9c to average 196c/kg. Restockers were very active on lighter cows, securing lines to 218c to average 174c/kg. Heavy bulls were dominated by live exporters topping at 270c, with a small number to slaughter selling to 238c/kg. Medium weight bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 249c, with lighter weights selling to 284c/kg. Feeder weight bulls to live export sold to 301c, averaging 275c, while light feeder bulls sold to 304c/kg. A single cow and calf sold for $1,050/unit.

Numbers nearly doubled and quality improved for the better grades. There was a large supply of light cows along with a large number of heavy steers. The steers were generally dearer by 1c to 4c and the bullocks were in small numbers and lost 4c/kg. The heifers traded either side of firm and the cows were cheaper by 4c to 9c/kg. 

The light steers sold to 137.2c and averaged from 127c to 133.9c/kg. The medium weight steers reached 153.2c and a large number averaged 135.6c/kg. The heavy steers were well supplied and reached 160c this saw 340 head average 155.9c/kg. The poorer grades averaged from 140c to 150c/kg. Bullocks reached 159.2c/kg and returned up to $1,024/head. 

The better heifers sold to 140.2c and averaged 135.9c while the stock showing less finish averaged 122.7c/kg. There was over 500 light cows penned and they topped at 138.2c/kg. Over 250 D2s averaged 118.7c while close to 350 D1s saw most sales around 97c/kg. Medium weight cows topped at 148.2c and the D3s averaged 129.3c/kg. 

Medium weight bulls averaged 138.9c and the heavy weights topped at 147.2c and averaged 143.1c/kg these returned up to $1,062/head.

Numbers more than halved to 995 cattle for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, with reduced numbers of heavy prime cows and bullocks on offer. There were several mixed quality smaller lines on offer, accompanied by one good line of young northern steers and coastal PTIC heifers.  Two regular processors were absent, however two live exporters and two feeder buyers were active, supported by some western restockers and regular opportunity backgrounders.  Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Georgetown, Mt Surprise, Tully, Mt Coolon, local and coastal areas.

Young steer calves in small pen lots sold firm and vealer steers improved by up to 14c/kg for one very good quality large draft. Limited numbers of yearling steers to live export improved by 1c on last sale.  Vealer and yearling heifers were too few to quote.  Bullocks were of very mixed quality and weight and eased accordingly, while fewer numbers of prime cows saw values increase by up to 6c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export improved 1c/kg and young males returning to grass sold firm.

Steer calves sold to 282c to average 261c/kg.  Well grown vealer steers to western restockers averaged 278c, reaching a top of 287c/kg. Yearling steers to live export sold to 268c to average 258c/kg.  A small number of yearling heifers returning to the paddock made 192c and PTIC yearling heifers sold to $660/head.  Mixed quality bullocks made to 257c to processors averaging 249c, while those suitable to live export averaged 254c/kg. Reduced numbers of heavy 3 score cows sold to 179c to average 173c and a pen of 4 score cows sold for 183c/kg. Lower yielding heavy D muscled cows sold to 176c to average 158c/kg. Better quality light cows returning to grass sold to 125c to average 120c/kg.  Heavy bulls to live export sold to 294c to average 291c and medium feeder weight bulls sold to 256c/kg.

Single cows and calves sold to $610/unit.

Numbers more than doubled for a yarding of 1,558 cattle for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, featuring some very good lines of heavy prime bullocks and cows. Limited numbers of store cattle were of average quality with quality related price movements. Most processors operated at improved prices, along with regular feeder buyers, two live exporters and a small gallery of restockers and backgrounders.  Cattle were drawn from Burketown, Normanton, Richmond, Greenvale, Collinsville, local and coastal areas. 

A few lines of good quality vealer steers sold to 251c to average 249c/kg.  Yearling steers were very mixed quality with no significant lines on offer.  A small number to live export sold to 230c/kg. Vealer heifers to restockers sold to 220c to average 214c, while heavier types made 188c/kg. Yearling heifers comprised of several good quality lines with sporadic demand from the gallery. Heifers 280-330kg to feed sold to 220c, averaging 198c, while heifers above 330kg to feed made to 230c to average 206c/kg. Heifers to slaughter sold to 194c to average 191c/kg. One very good quality line of northern bullocks dominated the offering and was keenly sought after by export processors. Heavy export bullocks to slaughter sold to 258c to average 249c, while extra heavy bullocks made to 253c, averaging 251c/kg. Heavy D muscled bullocks averaged 230c and 2 score bullocks averaged 178c/kg. Heavy grown steers to slaughter sold to 225c, while steers to feed sold to 218c to average 210c/kg.

A good supply of prime heavy cows improved by 2c to 6c, with solid demand throughout. Heavy 3 score cows sold from 180c to 199c to average 195c, while extra heavy 3 score cows sold to 203c and 4 scores to 210c/kg. Heavy 3 score D muscled cows averaged 180c, selling to 194c, while medium weight 2 score cows to slaughter made to 170c, averaging 147c/kg. A larger supply of grown heifers also attracted strong demand from processors, selling to 230c, with 2 score heifers averaging 156c/kg. Better quality 2 score heifers to feed sold to 209c to average 186c/kg. A larger offering of bulls was generally lighter and of more mixed quality.  Heavy bulls to slaughter sold to 228c multiple times, with most sales from 199c to 214c/kg. Heavy bulls compliant with live export specifications to feed sold to 228c with most above 220c/kg. Medium weight bulls to feed backgrounding for live export sold to 210c/kg. Young males to restockers sold to 226c, to average 212c/kg.

Numbers lifted only slightly with all the local and export buyers in attendance. Most of the yarding was plainer quality stock and values have generally eased. The supply area is generally dry and feed is starting to winter off and unfortunately this is not going to help quality in the coming weeks. Cattle were drawn from the local and usual supply areas. 

There was only a handful of better C muscled heavy weight steers offered with these selling to 162.2c/kg. Lean medium weights averaged 124.6c as a large number of heavy D3s made to 155.2c to average 145.4c/kg. Very few heavy bullocks were penned, selling to 158.2c/kg.

The better light D2 heifers averaged 104.6c as the plainer E2s averaged 91.1c/kg. Nearly all the light cows were plainer E muscled lines averaging from 58c to 70.8c/kg. The top of the medium weights reached 117.2c with the D3s averaging just under 110c/kg. Most of the bulls penned were heavy weights averaging 100c/kg.

Numbers lifted by more than 800 for a yarding of 2305 cattle.  Quality was once again mixed with some good lines of heavy bullocks and cows, an increased number of northern bulls, supported by good lines of store steers and heifers. Most regular processors were in attendance and operating at subdued rates along with one live exporter, regular feeders and opportunity restockers.  Demand for quality lines was fair, while secondary lines were difficult to sell. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, a east to local and coastal areas.

Yearling steers and heifers with quality were mostly firm, secondary lines sold lower according to quality. Values for all  processors categories eased in line with recent grid adjustments and other selling centres. Heavy cows eased 9c, bullocks averaged 30c lower and heavy bulls fell 10c to 15c/kg. 

Active restocker demand pushed light steers to 248c, to average 211c/kg.  A good sample of suitable weaned heifers  above 200kg returning to the paddock reached 188c to average 149c/kg.  Yearling steers above 280kg to restockers reached 230c to average 211c and steers above 330kg averaged 208c/kg.  Steers above 330kg to feed made t 212c to average 182c/kg. A very good quality line of yearling heifers above 330kg to feed topped at 182c to average 173c/kg.


Grown steers above 400kg to processors sold to 178c to average 176c those to feed averaged 190c/kg.  Grown heifers to the trade reached 172c multiple times to average 150c/kg. Heavy full mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 198c, most sales from 160c to 192c/kg. Medium weight 2 and 3 score cows sold to 178c to average from 132c to 159c/kg. A good sample of prime heavyweight cows made from 176c to 182c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export sold to 254c to average 230c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors averaged 196c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Numbers lifted by 962 on the last reported sale a fortnight ago to 2727 cattle. Quality was mixed throughout, comprising of several small lines of well finished heavy bullocks and cows, a very good line of feeder steers, supported by a large number of lightweight wearers. The buyer panel increased with additional processor attendance, along with regular feeders, opportunity backgrounders and restockers. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa to Croydon, McKinlay to Pentland, local and coastal areas.

Increased processor demand resulted in further improved averages for suitable feeder and processor categories with grown steers to processors lifting 20c to 25c, heavy cows improved by 5c to 13c, bullocks rose 40c and heavy bulls were mostly firm. Good quality young cattle sold to an enthusiastic panel of buyers, however lesser quality lightweight lines met limited demand. 

A good selection of suitably weaned.light steers returning to grass averaged 264c selling to 286c, best quality steers above 200kg averaged 278c/kg. Similar restocker heifers sold to 247c to average 244c, processor heifers averaged 230c/kg. Mixed quality yearling steers above 200kg made to 266c to average 251c, while a good supply of heavier steers above 330kg to feed sold stronger, reaching 320c to average 299c/kg. Several small lines of yearling heifers sold according to quality with trade types making to 278c to average 275c, best feeder heifers above 330kg selling to 267c to average 261c/kg. 

Grown steers above 400kg to feed made to 326c to average 321c/kg. Grown steers above 400kg to the trade reached 318c to average 293c, heavy steers above 500kg sold to 324c to average 321c/kg. Good quality heavy grown heifers to the trade sold to 302c to average 286c/kg.

A good sample of heavy bullocks to export slaughter topped at 338c, averaging 324c to 331c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows made to 258c to average 248c, 3 scores reached 284c to average from 258c to 268c and prime heavyweight 3 and 4 score cows topped at 286c to average 272c to 281c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors sold to 268c to average 260c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Numbers lifted by 640 for a yarding of 2910 cattle.  Quality was very mixed throughout, with many cattle showing the effects of the season. Some good lines of grown steers and odd pens of prime cows were on offer in a much plainer prime section.  A large consignment of northern weaners dominated the store section.  Most regular processors operated at reduced rates, with cautious support from feeders, backgrounders and restockers and one live exporter . Cattle were drawn from many northern areas and south to the Belyando.

Good quality steers and heifers eased 10c to 20c, with secondary lines up to 60c easier, grown steers fell 6c and prime cows averaged 6c to 14c lower.

Light steers returning to the paddock averaged 282c, reaching a top of 316c/kg. Young heifers above 200kg returning to the paddock sold to 236c to average 216c/kg.  A good line of light yearling steers topped at 322c to average 309c/kg. Yearling steers above 330kg to feed reached 256c to average 252c/kg. Yearling heifers above 280kg to feed sold to 230c to average 214c/kg.

Grown steers above 400kg to feed averaged 218c selling to 233c and steers suitable to the trade sold to 236c/kg. Steers to live export sold from 234c to 280c/kg. Grown heifers to the trade reached 233c to average 222c/kg.
An increased number of  lightweight 2 score cows to processors sold to 180c to average 162c and 3 scores made to 192c to average 179c, while prime heavyweight cows topped at 204c to average 196c/kg.
Heavy bulls to live export sold to 260c to average 248c and bulls to processors topped at 238c to average 226c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Numbers lifted by 612 head to 2376 cattle this week with quality generally good throughout.  The increased supply saw most categories ease in price particularly on lesser quality lines.  Some very good large lines of prime cows and young steers met strong competition.  Four regular processors operated selectively along with regular feeders, backgrounders and restockers. Cattle were drawn from Richmond, Pentland, Greenvale, Ayr, Belyando, local and coastal areas.

Light steer calves to restockers sold to 518.2c to average 484c and light vealer steers reached 482.2c to average 457c/kg.  A large sample of steers above 200kg to backgrounders made to 486.2c to average 430-445c/kg.  Vealer heifers to processors sold to 392.2c, with most sales near 380c, while plainer types to feed destined for slaughter averaging 351-370c/kg.  Yearling steers to feed above 280kg sold for 400.2c and steers above 330kg to feed sold to 396.2c to average 395c/kg.  A limited supply of yearling heifers to feed sold to 346.2c to average 327c/kg.  Grown steers were insufficient to reliably quote.  Grown heifers to the trade made to 332.2c to average 320-332c and heifers to feed averaged 309c/kg.

A small number of heavy bullocks sold from 294 to 336.2c/kg.  Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 246.2c to average 245c and 3 score cows reached 270.2c to average 257-267c/kg.  Heavy bulls to live export sold to 340.2c with most sales 320-335c/kg and young light males returning to grass sold to 506.2c to average 424-500c/kg.  Several small lines of cows and calves sold from $1,280-$1,550/unit.

Numbers lifted by 600 for a yarding of 2028 cattle.  Quality was very mixed with some well finished pens of cows and bullocks, along with an increased number of northern bulls and small mixed lines of store steers and heifers. A full panel of processors returned which helped demand along with two live exporters, regular feeders and opportunity restockers.. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa to Georgetown and south to the local area.

Values firmed for light steers and heifers by 14c to 24c yearling steers below 280kg eased 20c to 34c, yearling heifers to feed fell 27c, bullocks lifted 6c to 16c, cows improved 6c and bulls were firm.

Suitably weaned steers to restockers topped at 270c to average 256c, similar heifers returning to grass made to 192c to average 172c/kg.  Yearling steers above 330kg to background reached 214c to average 202c/kg. A large sample of heifers above 280kg to feed sold to 200c averaging 185c/kg and heifers above 330kg averaged 178c/kg.

A small sample of grown steers above 400kg to the trade topped at 230c to average 212c/kg.  A large sample of steers to feed sold to 212c to average 207c/kg. Grown heifers to processors topped at 228c to average 218c/kg, with a good sample of heifers to feed averaging 207c/kg.
An increased supply of heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter sold to 252c multiple times to average 229c to 246c/kg.

Medium weight 3 score cows sold to 198c to average 187c and prime heavyweight cows topped at 208c to average 207c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export reached 274c to average 258c, a small number of processor bulls averaged 220c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Numbers lifted by 430 head to 2,047 cattle for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, with fewer numbers of prime bullocks on offer, and prime cows of mixed quality, however two large lines of vealer and yearling steer attracted strong attention from a large buyer gallery. All processors were in attendance, with one previously absent very active in the market for slaughter cattle, while two live exporters, regular feeder buyers and central restockers ensured strong competition throughout the offering. Cattle were drawn from Burketown, Richmond, Mt Garnet, Einasleigh, Ingham, Woodstock, Ravenswood, Belyando, local and coastal areas.

Vealer steer numbers increased substantially and were of very good quality, which also featured one large line, displaying very good quality and condition, selling to 323c averaging 311c to restockers, while live exporters secured feeder weight types to 308c/kg. Yearling steers also met spirited bidding from the gallery, selling to 322c for those returning to grass, while those to feed sold to 316c to average 310c/kg. Live exporters were very active throughout, securing lines to 308c averaging 306c for lighter feeders and 288c/kg for heavier feeder steers. Vealer heifers met mixed demand for a generally good quality offering of smaller lines selling 7c to 10c higher on last sale, with live exporters securing heavier types to 268c, while larger framed types with condition to feed sold to 266c/kg. Younger, lighter heifers returning to grass sold to 256c/kg. Yearling heifers were in greater supply and sold 10c to 14c higher on last sale with feeder weight heifers to live export sold to 258c multiple times, with restockers securing similar weight lines to 254c to average 252c/kg. Bullock numbers were greatly reduced from recent weeks and the mixed offering met subdued demand easing 10c to 15c, primarily influenced by quality with the few heavy bullocks to slaughter selling to 240c/kg. Lighter conditioned types to feed sold to 250c, while a small number of grown steers to feed reached 240c/kg. 

Grown heifers to live export sold to 250c, with a small number to slaughter making 244c/kg. Heavy grown steers to live export sold to 260c, with feeder weight steers selling to 306c averaging 266c/kg. A mixed offering of cows eased 3c to 10c on last sale with best heavy 4 score cows to slaughter making 209c, while 3 score cows sold to 199c easing 10c on last sale, heavy 2 score types sold to 195c averaging firm on last sale of 185c/kg. Lighter 2 score cows sold to slaughter sold to 180c, averaging 164c, while cows to restockers of varying quality sold to 192c/kg. Some good lines of bulls sold sporadically, with heavy bulls to slaughter increasing by 7c to average 222c and topping at 229c, while bulls to live export sold to 237c, with most making 232c/kg. Feeder weight bulls destined for live exports made 300c multiple times, with feeder weight lines to feed, destined for live export selling to 310c, to average 260c/kg. Young males returning to paddocks sold to 296c/kg. A small number of cows and calves sold to $1,060/unit.

Numbers lifted by 1542 for a yarding of 3487 cattle in a combined prime and store sale.  Quality was mixed, with more than 1000 cows penned, there were fewer numbers of good heavy prime cows and bullocks, supported by some very good lines of steers and heifers.  One additional southern processor and a central processor joined the buyer panel, which operated selectively throughout.  One feeder was notably absent, while opportunity feeder orders and local restockers provided some valuable competition. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa to Mt Garnet and south to local area.

Values eased in line with other selling centres, grown steers easing 19c, bullocks fell 14-25c and cows to processors averaged 23c lower.

Suitably weaned young steers made to 376c and the heifer portion for breeding sold for 346c/kg.  Yearling steers above 280kg to feed sold to 302 to average 279c and heifers above 330kg to feed reached 278c/kg

Grown steers to feed averaged 256c, topping at 272c, suitable trade types sold to 284 to average 270c/kg. An increased number of grown heifers to the trade sold to 236c to average 220c and feeder lines made to 272c to average 229c/kg. Heavy bullocks to export slaughter topped at 280c, most selling from 259c to 274c.

Medium weight 3 score cows reached 227c to average 204c and prime heavyweight cows topped at 239c to average 222c to 237c/kg. Heavy bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 292c multiple times, selling from 268cto280c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Numbers lifted by 134 head to 1,868 cattle for Charter Towers Combined Selling Agents this week comprising of some well finished cows and large northern lines of mixed quality cattle. One regular processor continued their absence, with all other processors selective throughout the offering of prime cattle, while regular feeder buyers and local restockers showed subdued demand for some lesser quality types. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Croydon, Einasleigh, Hughenden, Prairie, Tully, Ingham, local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers were in greater supply with competition strong throughout, topping at 340c/kg returning to grass. Yearling steers were of mixed quality with feeder buyers securing most lines, topping at 294c to average 281c/kg. Vealer heifers varied in quality with better, well conditioned types making to 280c to average 262c/kg. Yearling heifers were also of variable quality, but in strong demand, with heifers to feed selling to 278c to average 273c, while those returning to grass sold to 282c to average 260c/kg. A large number of grown heifers to feed sold to 273c to average 259c, while a few heavy heifers to slaughter sold to 241c/kg.

Bullocks were of mixed quality and condition selling 5c to 8c lower on last sale, with heavy bullocks to slaughter selling to 274c to average 271c/kg. Grown steers to feed sold to 286c to average 258c, while lighter mature types to feed sold to 273c to average 271c/kg. Some very good quality well finished 3 and 4 score C muscled cows sold to 224c to average 215cg, down 3c on last sale, while heavy 2 score cows also sold lower to 212c to average 209c/kg. Heavy D muscled cows sold to 208c to average 201, while 2 score cows sold to 192c, to average 168c/kg.  Lighter 1 and 2 score cows to restockers sold to 175c to average 160c/kg. Bulls were of very mixed quality with a number of northern types meeting subdued demand, only a small number to slaughter sold to 235c/kg. Heavy bulls to feed sold to 252c to average 237c, with many poor quality bulls to feeder buyers making from 100c to 224c/kg. Lighter males to restockers sold to 324c/kg. One large line of good quality young cows with calves (1-4mth) sold for $1,230/unit.

Numbers increased slightly however it was weaker competition that caused most categories to loose ground. The poorest stock was most affected in a yarding that had fair numbers of most grades available. Fair quality steers eased slightly while the lesser grades were well below the levels of last week. Heifers and cows were up to 19c cheaper in places, although the better conditioned cows were around 2c/kg cheaper. 

Light steers topped at 120c although most averaged 105c/kg. There were a good number of medium weights offered and they topped at 140.2c, though the bulk were D2s that averaged 111c/kg. Heavy steers peaked at 140.2c ad over 80 head averaged 137.2c/kg. 

Most heifers sold around 94c and one isolated sale was recorded at 131.2c/kg. Light cows of poorest quality averaged 55c while the D2s topped at 105.2c and averaged 91.4c/kg. Medium weights reached 112.2c and the D3s averaged 110.2c/kg. Bulls peaked at 107c/kg.

Numbers increased slightly and quality was mixed with some lines reflecting the dry seasonal conditions.  The penning mainly consisted of store cattle that were sold in the open auction section with only a limited number of grown steers, heifers and bullocks penned.  Cows were once again well supplied and all the regular buyers were present and competition was firm to slightly stronger across most grades. 

Grown steers and bullocks were firm to slightly dearer as local trade operators competed strongly against each other to capture adequate numbers.  Most of the better C muscled pens made from 149.2¢ to 167.2¢/kg.  There were insufficient numbers of grown heifers to quote, however the D3 lightweight lines made up to 156.2¢/kg.  

Light weight cows were firm to slightly easier; however the better medium and heavy weight lines rose by 1¢ to 3¢/kg.  The D3 medium weight pens averaged 126.1¢ while heavy 4 score cows sold up to 140¢/kg.

Numbers increased quite substantially and there was a greater proportion of the penning suitable for processors.  There was a reasonable selection of medium and heavy grown steers along with several large pens of bullocks offered.  The majority of the cows were 2 and 3 scores and there were very few heavy weights penned.  There were several export processors operating along with a few local trade buyers.

Medium and heavy grown steers were 6¢ to 7¢/kg cheaper as processors were able to be more selective on the pens that they acquired.  Bullocks had similar price corrections and most of the C3s and C4s made from 152.2¢ to 168.2¢/kg.  Grown heifers fell by 9¢ and the D3s topped at 147.2¢/kg. 

The large numbers of light D2 and D3 cows were 6¢ to 8¢ cheaper while the better medium and heavy weight lines fell by 5¢ to 6¢/kg.  The D2 lines averaged 113.3¢ while the D3 medium weight grades averaged 127.4¢/kg.  Heavy cows topped at 143.2¢ and bulls were also cheaper and sold up to 119.2¢/kg.

Numbers increased quite substantially and quality varied across all grades.  The majority of the penning was sold in the open auction section with only a small selection offered in the live weight section.  The penning mainly consisted of grown steers and heifers along with a reasonable selection of bullocks and cows.  The regular field of export processors and local trade buyers were present and competition was a little weaker across most grades.

Grown steers and bullocks were mainly medium and heavy weights and most pens eased by 2¢ to 6¢ with odd sales falling by as much as 11¢/kg.  The majority of the C3s and C4s made from 147.2¢ to 160.2¢/kg.  Grown heifers fell by 10¢ to 14¢/kg and the D3 pens averaged 120.3¢/kg.  

Lightweight cows were 2¢ to 4¢ easier while the medium weight lines fell by 4¢ to 6¢/kg.  The D2 lightweight cows averaged 112.6¢ while the better medium and heavy weight pens sold from 123.2¢ to 135¢/kg.

Numbers increased quite substantially and quality improved compared to the previous week.  The penning mainly consisted of grown steers and heifers and there were also several pens of bullocks penned.  Cows were well supplied and all the regular buyers were present and operating.

Light and medium weight grown steers were 5¢ to 8¢ dearer while the heavy steers and bullocks were 4¢/kg dearer.  The majority of the well finished C3s made from 149.2¢ to 158.2¢/kg.  Grown heifers rose by 2¢ and the D3 lightweights averaged 126.1¢/kg.

All weights and grades of cows were 2¢ to 4¢/kg dearer.  There was a good selection in both the light and medium weight categories and the D2 pens averaged 117.1¢ while the D3 lines averaged 128.1¢/kg.  Bulls were also slightly dearer and the heavy weight pens topped at 128.2¢/kg.

Numbers increased however competition was strong from a full field of buyers. There were some top quality bullocks available that sold well while the heavy steers were well represented and improved slightly. The medium weight steers eased 3c/kg. Heifers were mostly 3c dearer while the cows varied 3c/kg either side of firm apart from the very poor quality lightweights that were well below last weeks rates.

The light steers sold to 143.2c and over 100 head averaged 135.8c/kg. There were some poorer quality grades that averaged around 121c/kg. The heavy steers sold to 150.2c and close to 150 head averaged 143.6c/kg. Heavy bullocks reached 150.2c also and they averaged 143.2c/kg and returned up to $1,032/head. 

The majority of the heifers averaged 113c although the better end made to 128c/kg. The poor quality light cows averaged 65.2c and a large number averaged 109.7c after they reached 118.2c/kg. The medium weights varied either side of firm and close to 100 D2s averaged 115c while an even larger number of D3s averaged 119.8c after they reached 128.2c/kg. 

Heavy bulls sold to 140.6c/kg and some returned up to $1,012/head.

Numbers increased for the second consecutive week and quality also improved.  A larger percentage of the penning was suitable for processors compared to the previous market and grown steers, bullocks and cows made up the majority of the yarding.  Three major export processors were present along with the regular field of trade buyers and restockers.

Grown steers and bullocks were difficult to quote due to the lack of numbers offered in the previous market, however most lines were firm.  The C muscled pens made from 151.2¢ to 160.2¢/kg.  Grown heifers were also firm and the D3s topped at 160.2¢/kg.

All weights and grades of cows were fully firm to slightly dearer except for a few heavy pens, which were firm to slightly easier.  The D3 medium weights averaged 133¢ while the heavy D4 cows sold up to 147.2¢/kg.

Numbers increased for the last sale of the year and values were mixed. Not all buyers were in attendance and competition was weak. Quality varied although most were generally not of the standard set in previous weeks. Steers were not comparable to the previous week while the heifers were 7c to 13c/kg cheaper. The light poor cows lost up to 31c while the majority were 11c to 16c/kg cheaper. Heavy bulls eased 4c/kg. 

Light steers mostly sold around 140c/kg. The medium weights were in fair numbers and they peaked at 135c and the better grades averaged 131.6c/kg. There were too few heavy steers and bullocks to provide an accurate quote. 

The heifers peaked at 130.2c and the better grades averaged 123c while the poor stock sold around 109c/kg. Light cows sold to 114.2c and the D2s averaged 100.3c/kg. The medium weight cows reached 128.2c and the D3s averaged 124c/kg. 

Heavy bulls made to 144.2c/kg and some returned up to $1,089/head.

Numbers increased for prime only sale by nearly 400 to 1,793 cattle with 4,400 cattle booked for a store sale this Friday. Quality improved on last week featuring some large lines of grown steers and heifers and many small local lines of well finished cows. All regular processors were in attendance but not operating with renewed feeder activity along with opportunity restockers. Grown steers to feed eased 8c to 12c and heifers sold firm to 5c easier, bullocks lifted 20c/kg and cows to processors averaged 2c/kg higher with bulls finishing15c/kg lower. Cattle were drawn from Winton in the west to Einasleigh in the north and south to Belyando including many from the local area. 

Insufficient numbers of light vealer and yearling cattle sold according to quality. Yearling steers above 400kg to feed sold to 446c to average 423c/kg.  Good quality grown steers above 400kg to feed sold to 446c to average 391c to 423c/kg. Heavy steers to the trade topped at 404 to average 385c to 399c/kg. A large sample of very good quality grown heifers attracted strong demand with most selling to the trade up to 376c to average 356c to 361c/kg. 

Heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter reached 396c to average 382c/kg. A greater supply of medium weight 3 score cows reached 342.2c multiple times to average 330c to 336c/kg. Prime heavyweight 3 score cows topped at 350.2c to average 344c, with 4 scores averaging 338c/kg.  Heavy bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 344c to average 336c/kg.

A store sale on Friday has 4,400 cattle booked.

Market Reporter; Mick Kingham.

Numbers increased considerably with a bigger percentage of cows including large lines of D2 and D3s offered. The expected price drop did not occur and prices held firm with the larger numbers, with the exception of some grades, which sold to an easier market. Quality was similar to previous weeks with smaller bullock numbers offered. All regular buyers plus one extra export operator were present and operating.

Medium weight grown steers ranged from 126.2¢ to 145.2¢ with most sales at 134.2¢/kg. Both medium and heavy weights maintained firm rates with the heavier lines averaging 145.8¢ after topping at 156.2¢/kg.

Cows were almost solely responsible for the increased yardings with large lines of medium and heavy D2 and D3 descriptions penned. Medium D2s ranged from 100¢ to 118¢ while similar weight D3s averaged 126.6¢ after topping at 134.2¢/kg.

Numbers increased by more than 900 head for a yarding of 2,195 cattle in Charters Towers, with the supply of heavy prime cattle increasing and values lifting for the better quality lines in these categories.  The usual panel of buyers were in attendance, supported by two live exporters and opportunity restockers and backgrounders.  Cattle were drawn from as far as the Northern Territory, Burketown, Normanton, Richmond, Georgetown, Tully, Belyando as well as local and coastal areas.

A limited supply of vealer steers eased in price, while young heifers varied in quality and met the minimal demand. Yearling steers varied in quality, with better lines firmer on last sale. Demand for yearling heifers was subdued, although heavy well grown single lines, to slaughter improved by 30c/kg.  Grown steers, to live export, sold firm and heavy grown heifers, to domestic slaughter, improved by up to 14c/kg.  Suitable heavy bullocks, to live export, increased by 8c and those to slaughter also improved in price. Medium weight 2 score cows eased, with many plainer lines on offer. Good yielding heavy 3 score cows increased by 8c/kg.  Heavy bulls to live export increased up to 9c/kg.

Vealer steers sold to 270c, to average 258c, and young steer calves made to 278c/kg.  A small sample of good quality vealer heifers, to restockers, sold for 163c and better finished types, to slaughter, made 170c/kg. A large sample of plain conditioned heifers above 200kg, returning to grass, averaged 157c/kg.  Yearling steers, to live export, sold to 274c to average 271c/kg, with a small number, to domestic slaughter, reaching 291c/kg.  Grown steers, to live export, sold to 302c, averaging 293c, with a large sample of lesser quality types, to feed, averaged 229c/kg.  Yearling heifers were of mixed quality with medium weight types, to feed, averaging 161c/kg.  Single sales of grown heifers, to slaughter, made to 280c to average 239c, with lesser lines averaging 187c/kg.

Heavy bullocks, to live export, reached 314c to average 311c and heavy bullocks to export slaughter also made to 314c to average 303c/kg.  A large sample, to feed, destined for live export sold to 286c to average 259c/kg.  Medium weight 2 score cows topped at 180c to average 145c, while heavy weights averaged 175c/kg.  Heavy 3 score cows topped at 221c to average 217c and extra heavy cows also made 221c/kg.  Heavy 3 score D muscled cows reached 211c to average 192c/kg. Heavy bulls, suitable for live export, topped at 301c, with most sales from 290-299c/kg, while heavy bulls to processors sold to 297c, to average 282c/kg.  Medium weight bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 290c to average 279c/kg.

Numbers increased by more than 900 for a yarding of 2,705 cattle for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, with increased demand across all classes. One regular processor continued their absence, however all others operated at similar rates to previous sale, supported by 3 live exporters, one feeder buyer and several motivated restockers and backgrounders. Several lines of bullocks and cows with improved yields and weights sold firm to 7c higher, while light steers improved by up to 20c/kg on some lines. Cattle were drawn from Normanton, Cloncurry, Richmond, Hughenden, Pentland, Mt Surprise, Greenvale, Ingham, Ravenswood, local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers attracted stronger competition from western and coastal restockers, lifting more than 20c for light weight steers to average 283c, topping at 296c, while young steers calves sold to 298c/kg multiple times. Increased demand for yearling steers to live export sold to 279c with most sales above 250c, while similar weight types returning to grass sold to 288c to average 7c lower at 253c/kg. Yearling steers above 330kg to backgrounders sold to 275c to average 235c/kg. Vealer heifers met much stronger demand, with heifers improving by 10c to 23c, with heavier types selling to 232c to average 210c, with lighter types to 222c to average 213c/kg. An increased supply of yearling heifers met strong demand, although quality was variable throughout, with better lines returning to grass selling to 212c to average 187c/kg. Heifers to live export sold to 216c, while similar weights to feed sold to 214c/kg.

Larger numbers of grown steers and bullocks from northern and local areas displayed much variation throughout. Better quality 3 and 4 score heavy bullocks to slaughter sold to 259c to average 254c, with lesser types averaging 230c/kg. Live exporters were active on suitable types securing bullocks to 264c and grown steers to 266c, with most above 257c/kg.  Lighter steers and bullocks to feed sold 245c with most from 214c to 225c/kg. Steers to grass for backgrounders sold to 232c/kg. Improved lines of heavy cows sold firm on last sale, with heavy 3 score cows to slaughter improving 2c to average 199c, topping at 207c and 4 score extra heavy cows selling to 208c/kg. Heavy D3 cows sold to 198c to average 182c and 2 score cows averaged 167c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows averaged 158c and cows to restockers sold to 167c to average 146c/kg. Light conditioned store cows sold to 154c to average 133c/kg.
