Heavy bulls varied in quality and weight with better quality types to live export selling to 276c with most above 267c, while similar types to feed destined for live export sold to 278c with most from 230c to 262c/kg. Feeder weight bulls to live export sold to 268c/kg. Young males returning to grass sold to 274c averaging 264c, improving more than 20c/kg on last sale. A small number of cows and calves sold from $440 to $960/unit.

Numbers increased by more than 850 for a yarding of 2980 cattle. Quality was very mixed comprising of an increased supply of grown steers and bullocks,northern males and bulls and several local lines showing the effects of the season . All regular processors were in attendance and operating, supported by one live exporter, feeder and opportunity restockers. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Normanton, Georgetown, local and coastal areas.

Demand was firms for good quality cattle, particularly those suitable for live export or slaughter, while lesser quality types attracted minimal demand..Grown steers and bullocks improved 3c to 20c, grown heifers were firm to 13c higher, medium weight cows  eased 6c and heavy bulls averaged 10c to 14c better. 

Young weaned steers returning to the paddock averaged 254c selling to 272c, similar heifers also to restockers reached 234c to average 217c to 230c/kg. Light yearling steers returning to grass made to 270c, averaging 249c and steers above 280kg averaged 259c/kg. Steers above 330kg suitable for live export averaged 292c to 305c/kg. Yearling steers above 400kg to live export sold  to 304c, a small sample to processors made 310c/kg.  A good sample of yearling heifers above 330kg to feed made to 254c to average 249c, with heifers above 400kg to the trade selling to 280c to average 274c/kg.

An increased supply of grown steers met strong demand throughout. Steers above 400kg to live export sold to 294c to average 288c, steers to processors reached 312c to average 289c/kg. Heavy grown steers above 500kg to processors topped at 336c to average 317c/kg. Grown heifers to the trade averaged 255c to 282c selling to 296c/kg.

Full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter sold to 328c to average 290c, heavy bullocks topped at 332c to average 309c to 327c/kg. Lightweight cows to feed sold to 210c to average 176c, 2 scores to processors averaged 201c/kg. A reduced supply of medium weight 3 score cows to processors sold to 274c to average 246c/kg. A small sample of prime heavyweight cows topped at 274c to average 270c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export reached 294c, most sales from 270c to 288c, while bulls to processors topped at  312c to average 220c to 274c/kg.

A small number of cows and calves sold from $600 to $945 per unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Numbers increased by more than 600 for a yarding of 4,126 cattle in a Combined Prime and Store sale. The supply of heavy bullocks and prime cows increased along with several large single vendor lines of yearling steers and heifers. The regular buyer gallery operated at stronger rates on better quality lines with two additional feeder orders. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa to Ingham and south to Belyando.

Grown steers and heifers sold firm to 4c higher, cows improved 4c to 9c and heavy bulls averaged 9c/kg better.

Vealer steers to backgrounders sold to 648.2c multiple times to average 587c/kg. Vealer heifers to the trade made to 428.2c to average 417c/kg. Yearling steers above 280kg returning to the paddock made to 468.2c to average 462c and yearling heifers reached 438.2c to average 436c/kg. Grown steers to feed averaged 396c to 420c selling to 426c with trade types selling to 392c/kg. A large sample of heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 400.2c to average 384c/kg.

Medium weight 3 score cows sold to 386.2c to average 357c to 370c and prime heavyweight cows topped at 384.2c to average 376c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors sold to 348.2c to average 342c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

Numbers increased by more than 500 head for a yarding of 1,725 cattle at Charters Towers, with several lines of northern steers and bullocks featuring throughout the sale. Most of the regular processors were in attendance and operating at increased prices, supported by one live exporter, two feeder buyers and local backgrounders and restockers. Cattle were drawn from Camoweal, Mount Isa, Burketown, Torrens Creek, Georgetown, Einasleigh, Tully, Ingham, Collinsville, local and coastal areas.

Steer calves sold to improved prices and better quality heifer calves also improved in price. Vealer steers were in limited supply, with better quality lines firm to 10c/kg higher, while vealer heifers improved by similar amounts. Yearling steers lifted by more than 25c for a large sample and yearling heifers to feed sold firm, with heifers to process improving by 9c/kg. Grown steers to feed destined for live export lifted 8c and suitable types to live export improved by 20c/kg. Better lines of grown heifers to process increased by 20c/kg. Heavy bullocks to feed, destined for live export, improved by up to 12c and heavy cows to processors improved by up to 17c/kg. An increased supply of bulls saw values increase throughout for majority on offer. Young steer calves made to 310c and the heifer portion sold to 246c, with several sales from 210c to 222c/kg. Light vealer steers sold to an isolated 306c, with sales more common to 296c to average 273c and steers above 280kg also reaching 296c, to average 287c/kg. Vealer heifers topped at 207c to average 190c, with a large sample selling above 180c/kg. Yearling steers to restockers made to 287c for similar average, with steers to live export selling to same values. Yearling heifers above 330kg to feed reached 205c to average 193c and heifers returning to grass made to 205c, averaging 202c/kg. Better finished heifers to domestic process sold to 236c to average 219c/kg.

Grown steers to live export made 275c and suitable types to feed, destined for live export, topped at 283c to average 276c/kg. Heavy steers to export process sold to 284c/kg. Grown heifers to process made to 233c to average 205c and heifers to feed averaged 180c/kg. Heavy bullocks to export process made to 287c and suitable types to feed, destined for live export, reached 293c/kg. Heavy 3 score cows to processors lifted to 221c to average 217c and 4 scores sold to 219c, while lower yielding D muscle cows reached 207c to average 192c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows to process eased, reaching 143c to average 121c, while light cows to restockers sold to 155c to average 129c/kg. Heavy bulls to feed destined for live export made to 302c and feeder weight bulls sold to 292c/kg. A large sample of young males returning to grass sold to 298c to average 275c/kg. Cows and calves sold to $820/unit.

Numbers increased by more than 300 to 1,985 cattle for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, with some good lines of well finished cows and bullocks and 1 large consignment of northern store steers and heifers. Bullocks lifted 4c to 5c mainly due to better quality, while cows were firm on last sale and store steers lifted up to 10c/kg with an improvement in quality. One major processor continued their absence, while all other major processors were present and active throughout the sale along with regular feeder buyers, one live exporter and local and western restockers.

Greater numbers of vealer steers met strong competition, reflecting in higher values on last sale, with light steers selling to 399c, while heavier types sold to 374c/kg. An irregular yarding of light weight calves 90-160kg sold from 270c to 320c/kg. A good line of northern yearling steers 260-310kg, met very strong competition, topping at 355c to average 339c, while steers above 330kg sold to 314c/kg. Vealer heifers were of very good quality with better conditioned types to slaughter sold to 298c, while well presented, lighter types returning to grass sold to 318c/kg. One large line of yearling heifers met strong feeder and restocker interest, with heifers to feed topping at 272c, averaging 266c, while those returning to grass sold to 270c to average 258c/kg.

One large line of well finished 3 score bullocks met good competition, with those to slaughter selling to 287c and averaging 281c, while the grown steers of the same consignment were secured by restockers selling to 292c, to average 288c/kg. Some good lines of well finished cows sold lower to 238c for best heavy C muscled 3 score slaughter cows averaging 229c, while heavy D3 cows sold to 229c to average 218c/kg. Heavy D muscled, 2 score cows sold to 204c to average 194c/kg. Lighter cows returning to grass sold to 204c, with the majority selling from 194c to 199c/kg. Heavy heifers to slaughter sold to 275c/kg. Heavy bulls were in shorter supply than recent weeks, with many showing less condition. Most were secured by a live exporter up to 265c, with medium weight bulls to feed destined for live export selling to 268c/kg. Some small lines of cows and calves sold to a top of $1,510 with most selling from $940 to $1,340/unit.

Numbers increased by more than 2100 for a yarding of 3785 head.  The larger numbers continued the trend of other selling centres with values easing for most categories despite a large buyer gallery. Quality was mostly good throughout, however the cow offering was not as good as the previous week. All regular processors operated at subdued rates, however demand improved throughout the sale, supported by one feeder, one live exporter and several opportunity restockers. Cattle were drawn from Julia Ck to Croydon in the north, east to Ingham and south to Bowen and the local area. 

Strong restocked demand for good quality heifers was the highlight of the sale, however most categories were easier on last week - notably cows and bullocks averaging 20c to 45c lower.

Best quality suitably weaned flat back steers topped at 334c, a large sample of Brahman steers averaged 307c/kg, with lesser quality lines averaging 285c/kg.  Similar heifers to processors made to 210c to average 185c/kg.  Yearling steers above 200kg returning to the paddock averaged 254c, topping at 276c, steers above 330kg to feed sold to 254c averaging 250c/kg. A very good sample of light yearling heifers returning  to the paddock topped at 290c to average 250c/kg. Heavy yearling heifers above 400kg to the trade reached 232c to average 204c/kg.

A very good quality sample of heavy grown steers to processors sold to 238c to average 236c, steers suitable for live export averaged 256c/kg. A small sample of grown heifers to the trade made to 242c to average 230c/kg.

Heavy bullocks to export slaughter topped at 240c to average from 231c to 234c/kg.  Medium weight 3 score cows sold to an isolated 216c, the majority averaging 186c/kg.  Medium weight bulls to live export made to 270c, while heavy bulls to feed destined for live export averaged 238c/kg.

A good number of cows and calves sold from $900 to $1,200 per unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Numbers increased by more than 1500 for a yarding of 2211 cattle.  Quality improved on last sale, comprising of some good quality grown steers and heifers, several good lines of young cattle to suit restockers and more than 700 cows penned.  All regular processors, feeders  and restockers operated at improved rates, supported by one live exporter and an additional CQ feeder operator.  Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa to Ingham and south to the Belyando.

Young cattle to the trade lifted 9c, yearling heifers to feed increased 18c, grown steers and heifers to feed improved up to 15c, 2 and 3 score cows were firm to 4c higher and bulls averaged 10c better.

Light suitably weaned steers returning to the paddock averaged 304 to 321c selling to 338c and similar heifers sold to 296c to average from 226c to 235c/kg. A good sample of yearling heifers above 200kg returning to the paddock topped at 266c to average 245c/kg. Heifers above 280 kg to feed reached 240c to average 224c to 235c/kg.

Grown steers above 400kg to feed sold to 268c multiple times to average 250-256 c and suitable trade types sold to 246c/kg. Grown heifers to the trade reached 224c and feeder types sold to 232 to average 228c/kg. 

A small increase in the supply of heavy bullocks to export slaughter topped at 242 to average 236c/kg.
The increased supply of cows met improved demand throughout. Lightweight 3 score cows to processors sold to 190c to average 170, medium weight 3 scores reached 200c to average 190c/kg.  A small sample of prime heavyweight cows sold from 197c to 208c/kg. A good supply of heavy bulls to live export sold to 274c to average 268 and similar bulls to feed destined for live export reached 264 to average 250c/kg.

Market Report, Mick Kingham

Numbers increased by more than 1,200 head for a yarding of 2,915 cattle in Charters Towers, with several lines of plain northern cows and males on offer.  Quality was variable throughout, with reduced numbers of good quality heavy prime cattle. The regular processor buying panel was in attendance and operating at rates in line with the lesser quality on offer, supported by one live exporter and opportunity backgrounders and restockers. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Burketown, George, Tully, Collinsville, Woodstock, local and coastal areas.

Steer calves sold to 308c, averaging 289c with strong demand, while better heifer calves sold to 228c, with most selling from 182c to 191c/kg. Vealer steers sold to 301c to average 288c, and yearling steers to restockers made to 264c to average 245c/kg. Most of the vealer heifers met limited demand selling to 228c to average 182c, and yearling heifers made to 196c/kg. Good quality vealer steers pushed above 300c/kg for better quality lines and solid buyer competition. Suitable weaned heifers eased 8c/kg for better types, however most drafts on offer met limited demand. Yearling steers were of variable quality and sold easier, particularly lesser quality lines. Yearling heifers were of limited supply and saw quality related price movements.

Numbers of good quality grown steers eased with most destined for live export. A small number of heavy bullocks eased by up to 10c with most lesser types decreasing by 22c/kg. A large offering of medium weight 2 score cows eased by up to 20c, and good heavy cows decreased by more than 15c/kg. A large supply of bulls was of mixed quality and mostly eased. Grown steers to live export made to 261c, averaging 256c, while heavy bullocks to export slaughter sold to 288c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows to slaughter sold to 173c to average 140c/kg. Heavy 3 score cows topped at 205c to average 197c, and heavy 4 score cows made to 206c/kg to average the same. Heavy bulls to feed destined for live export made to 276c, with most sales from 262c to 274c and heavy bulls to slaughter topped at 285c/kg. Increased numbers of young males returning to grass sold to 246c to average 234c/kg.

Numbers increased by almost 400 head to 1,640 cattle for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents, featuring a large line of local bullocks and several lines of light northern males and heifers. All regular processors operated at lower rates than previous sale, supported by two live exporters, regular feeder buyers and opportunity restockers. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Mt Garnet, Ingham, Belyando, local and coastal areas.

Several small lines of vealer steers sold from 276c to 282c, with better quality heavier vealers reaching 284c, averaging 280c/kg. Yearling steers consisted of several mixed lines of considerable variation in quality and weight. Steers above 270kg to live export sold to 272c, with heavier feeder weight steers reaching 292c. Steers to feed destined for live export sold to 264c/kg. Some very good quality yearling steers to slaughter made 289c/kg. There were insufficient vealer heifers to quote. A good supply of yearling heifers were in demand by feeder buyers, lifting by up to 4c on last sale, topping at 230c multiple times to feed, with most lighter types selling from 222c to 228c/kg. A small line of PTIC heifers made to 216c/kg. A good line of local bullocks improved the supply, with the heavier export bullocks selling to 298c to average 292c/kg. Heavy 4 score bullocks eased 9c, selling to 298c, with a notable improvement in quality of 2 scores selling to 297c, to average 292c/kg. Grown steers to slaughter reached 294c, averaging 293c/kg. Suitable grown steers to live export sold to 288c, while plainer types to restockers sold to 244c/kg.  

Cow numbers continued to lessen as the selling season draws to a close, with good heavy cows selling to a cheaper trend. Heavy 3 score cows sold to 241c, averaging 11c lower at 226c, with heavy 4 score cows making 227c/kg. Heavy 2 score cows eased 9c to average 212c, while medium weight 2 score cows sold to 197c to average near 175c/kg. A line of PTIC cows sold for 205c, with light cows returning to grass making from 155c to 184c/kg. Grown heifers generally lacked weight of previous weeks, easing 17c, selling to 253c to average 238c/kg. A continuation of good heavy bulls to live export sold to 291c, with most sales from 270c to 288c, with medium weights to live export reaching 291c/kg. Light males to restockers sold from 244c to 276c, with lesser quality lines from 110c to 190c/kg. A small number of cows and calves sold from $650 to $840/unit.

Numbers increased by almost 350 head to 1,243 cattle for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents, where most categories continued the trend of increased prices. All regular processors were in attendance and operating, with the increasing presence of one processor lifting values for medium weight cows, while two live exporters were active on suitable types. The addition of two central restockers stimulated prices for better quality lines of store steers and heifers. Cattle were drawn from Mount Isa, Richmond, Croydon, Ingham, as well as local and coastal areas.

Light weight vealer steers met very strong competition, reaching 332.2c, to average close to 328c/kg. A large sample of steers over 200kg sold to 298c to average 297c/kg. Yearling steers to live export improved by up to 16c, reaching 296c to average 288c/kg. Restockers were active on lighter steers to 300c, while heavier types sold to 289c, with most making 285c/kg. Steers to background feed destined for live export sold to 276c/kg. Vealer heifers lifted in value for most descriptions, with strong demand from central and local restockers. A large sample of very good quality heifers sold to 272c, with lesser types making from 218c to 226c/kg. Light yearling heifers to feed sold to 228c, while live exporters dominated the heifers weighing from 260-370kg, purchasing from 240c to 252c/kg. Good quality medium weight heifers returning to grass sold to 271c to average 258c/kg.

Some good quality lines of heavy bullocks sold firm on last sale, topping at 307c and averaging 304c, while heavy 4 score bullocks sold to 306c/kg. Lighter younger bullocks with the assistance of some supplementary feed sold to 312c to average 293.4c/kg. Medium weight 2 score bullocks eased according to quality, reaching 258c to average 248c/kg. Heavy grown steers to live export sold firm to make from 286c to 294c, while similar types to feed destined for live export sold to 288c to average approximately 285c/kg. A small number of heavy grown steers to processors sold from 264c to 291c/kg. Some good lines of heavy cows improved by up to 5c, with a large sample making from 233c to 240c, topping at 263c to average 236c/kg. Heavy 2 score D muscled cows sold from 188c to 218c to average 204c, while medium weight 2 score cows sold to 192c, easing 4c to average 172c/kg. Grown heifers generally lacked the weight of recent weeks, however, the increased numbers met strong demand throughout. Better quality 3 score heifers to processors made to 279c to average 249c, while 2 scores made to 262c/kg. A line of PTIC heifers made 228c/kg. Heavy bulls continued recent strong trends driven by live export, securing bulls to 286c/kg. Heavy bulls to process sold to 242c, with medium weights purchased to 278c/kg. A large sample of medium and heavy bulls to feed destined for live export sold from 281c to 291c/kg. Medium weight bulls to live export sold to 288c, with feeder weight bulls topping at 300c, averaging 294c/kg. Young males to restockers sold from 294c to 317c/kg.

Numbers increased by almost 1,000 head to 2,987 cattle in Charters Towers, with increased numbers of heavy grown steers and prime cows. The mixed quality yarding presented sold to an easier trend for most classes, however better quality lines of store steers sold to improved rates. The regular buying panel was bolstered by central and southern backgrounder orders generating increased demand for many store lines, with cattle drawn from Normanton, Georgetown, Richmond, Hughenden, Bowen, Collinsville, local and coastal areas. Light steers to restockers and backgrounders sold firm, while increased numbers of light vealer heifers met strong demand improving by more than 35c/kg. The supply of yearling steers increased attracting strong demand throughout, increasing averages from 23c to 55c, while medium weight yearling heifers to feed lifted by 16c/kg. The supply of grown steers also attracted strong demand with medium weight steers returning to the paddock saw quality related improvements, while steers to background feed for live export lifted by up to 32c/kg. Limited numbers of bullocks to export processor improved by up to 18c/kg. Medium weight cows to processors increased by 7c, heavy cows sold firm and prime heavy weight cows increased by 14c/kg. Light weight cows returning to grass lifted by 15c to 50c to western restockers, and cows to feed lifted by 3c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors increase by more than 30c, and suitable types for live export to background feed increased by up to 32c/kg.

Vealer steers to restockers and backgrounders sold to 336.2c to average 311c for a large sample and heavier types to feed averaged 298c/kg. Light weight vealer heifers returning to the paddock sold to 235.2c to average 225c, with a large sample of heifers, 200-280kg, selling to 282.2c to average 243c/kg.The supply of medium and heavy yearling steers increased with strong demand lifting averages for feeder types to 263c, and those returning to grass reaching 317.2c to average near 297c/kg. Medium weight yearling heifers to feed sold to 228c to average 205c, with heifers to the trade selling to 246.2c, to average from 215c to 231c/kg.

Grown heifers to the trade averaged 204c/kg. The supply of grown steers increased, with steers to processors averaging from 270c to 287c, topping at 289.2c/kg. Medium weight cows to processors sold to 214c to average above 187c, with heavy 3 score cows selling to 225c to average 211c/kg. The prime heavy weights topping at 240.2c to average 233c/kg. Light weight cows to restockers sold to 204.2c to average 178c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors sold to 304c, to average 286c, with suitable processor types for live export to background feed averaging from 239c to 279c/kg. A large sample of light males returning to grass sold to 306.2c to average 284c/kg. A small number of cows and calves sold to $1,060/unit.

Numbers increased by 742 head for a yarding of 3257 cattle. Quality was mostly very good throughout, featuring some large lines of heavy prime bullocks and cows, supported by several small lines of store steers and heifers.  All regular processors were in attendance and operating at easier rates, supported by one southern processor for the first time this year. Regular feeders, opportunity restockers and backgrounders from the local area and further south were also active.  Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Croydon, Georgetown, Mt Garnet, Greenvale, Belyando, local and coastal areas.  Most categories averaged 10c to 45c lower, except for some yearling heifers attracting stronger local buyer demand.

Light steer calves sold to 650.2c, and a good sample of weaned steers above 200kg to local restockers topped at 690.2c to average 570c to 591c/kg. An increased supply suitable trade heifers reached 542.2c to average 486c to 529c/kg.  Several smaller lines of yearling steers sold in line with quality. Light steers to local restockers reached 522.2c to average 502c/kg, with mixed quality steers above 280kg returning to grass averaged 406c to 455c/kg.  Good quality steers above 330kg to feed topped at 502.2c to average 459c/kg.  A good supply of yearling heifers mostly improved in price those above 280kg to feed reaching 456.2c to average 446c/kg.  Similar heifers returning to grass as breeders sold to 462.2 to average 439c/kg. Heifers above 330kg to feed topped at 456.2c to average 421c to 445c/kg.

Increased numbers of grown steers above 400kg to feed sold to 434.2c to average 418c to 422c/kg.  A good sample of heavy steers above 500kg to the trade made to 416.2 to average 403c/kg.  Mixed quality grown heifers to the trade reached 420.2c to average 370c to 390c/kg.  A greater supply of heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter sold from 384c to 404c/kg. 

A much larger offering of medium weight three score cows to processors sold to 368.2c to average 345c and a very good sample of prime heavyweights topped at 370.2c to average 347c to 354c/kg.  A line of PTIC cows sold from 340c to 398c/kg. Heavy bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 350.2c to average 341c to 344c/kg. Good quality cows and calves sold from $2,150 to $2,450/unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Numbers increased by 700 to 3180 cattle in a Combined Prime & Store Sale. Quality was variable throughout with seasonal effects on several lines, however some good single vendor lines of prime cows were penned.  Increased numbers of good quality yearling steers and heifers attracted limited demand. All regular processors were present and operating at reduced rates, along with regular central feeders and backgrounders.  Good quality young yearling heifers to feed lifted 50c, grown steers and heifers to feed eased 20c, cows to processors averaged 7c to 20c/kg lower and bulls were mostly firm. 
 
Good quality vealer steers above 200kg to backgrounders made to 534.2c to average 484c to 489c/kg.  A large sample of good quality vealer heifers to the trade sold to 460.2c to average 424c to 430c/kg.  Yearling steers above 280kg to feed reached 476.2c to average 427c to 423c/kg. A large sample of steers above 330kg to feed topped at 476.2c to average 446c/kg. Good quality yearling heifers above 280kg to feed topped at 408.2c to average 404c/kg.  

A good sample of grown steers above 400kg to feed sold to 400.2c to average 353c to 384c and suitable steers above 500kg to the trade reached 382.2c to average above 370c/kg. Increased numbers of grown heifers to feed sold to 376.2c to average 320c to 360c/kg. There were insufficient numbers of bullocks to reliably quote. 

Selective processor demand for cows resulted in a further easing trend.  Medium weight 2 score cows made to 306.2c to average 284c, 3 score cows to processors reached 318.2c to average 293c to 294c and prime heavyweights topped at 312.2c to average 303c/kg. A good sample of cows to feed reached 288.2c to average sold to 271c to 275c/kg. Heavy bulls to feed destined for live export topped at 320.2c to average 306c to 313c/kg. Young males returning to grass sold to 470.2c/kg to average 453c/kg.

A small number of good quality cows and calves sold from $1,940 to $2,650/unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Numbers increased by 70 head to 2,795 cattle in a Combined Prime and Store Sale. Quality was mixed, however there were some very good lines of heavy prime cows mostly from western areas. Many store lines consisted of smaller lines of steers and heifers. One major export processor was again absent, with other regular processors operating selectively on better quality lines. One major feeder buyer was absent while restocker and backgrounder demand was very subdued limited to one local and a few central operators. Cattle were drawn from many northern areas including Mt Isa, Normanton, Croydon, Georgetown and including Winton, Richmond, Ingham, local and coastal areas.

Vealer and yearling cattle eased by 30-70c for most categories, grown steers averaged 15-50c lower, while cows to processors eased by up to 30c/kg.  Bullocks and bulls ended 15c to 25c lower than the previous sale. Demand for light cattle was firm for the best quality lines and very subdued for poorer quality types. Light steer calves returning to grass made to 484.2c while trade types reached 368.2c to average 350c/kg. Vealer heifers to the trade topped at 364.2c to average 355c to 364c/kg. 

Mixed quality lines of yearling steers met limited demand with steers above 280kg to feed reaching 430.2c to average 346c to 380c/kg. Yearling heifers also consisted of mixed quality lines with heifers above 280kg to feed selling to 322.2 to average 309c/kg. Good quality local grown steers above 400kg to feed sold to 316.2c to average 302c/kg, with lesser types averaging 277c to 287c/kg. A small sample to the trade reached 320.2c to average 288c to 320c/kg. A good sample of heavy grown heifers to the trade topped at 328.2c to average close to 300c/kg.

A larger sample of heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter made to 324.2c to average from 286c to 318c/kg. A greater supply of cows met selective processor demand. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 248.2c to average 243c and a large sample of three score cows to processors topped at 298.2c to average 256c to 276c/kg. Prime heavy weight 3 score cows reached 288.2c to average 271c to 279c/kg. Heavy bulls also met more selective and reduced demand. Best quality heavy bulls to feed topped at 338.2c to average from 271-311c/kg. Light males returning to grass sold to 400.2c to average 355c to 366c/kg.

Good quality mixed age pens of cows and calves sold from $1,640 to $1,780/unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

Numbers increased by 669 for a yarding of 2116 cattle.  Quality was very mixed, consisting of some good quality heavy cows, increased numbers of young males and a large consignment northern weaners.  All regular processors and feeder buyers returned to the gallery along with one live exporter and opportunity western restockers.  Cattle were drawn from Normanton, Richmond, local and coastal areas.

Values were in line with other selling centre, young steers and heifers improved 20c to 25c, heavy cows eased 4c and heavy bulls improved by 15c/kg.

A large consignment of vealer steers above 200kg averaged 296c selling to a top of 320c with the female portion reaching 260c to average 240c/kg.  Light yearling steers sold to 310 to average 296c, steers above 330kg to feed made to 271c to average 251c and suitable steers to live export averaged 266c/kg.  Yearling heifers to feed averaged 233c with a top of 246c/kg.

A larger supply of grown heifers to feed sold to 246c to average 240c and heifers to the trade averaged 212c/kg.  A limited number of heavy bullocks sold to 242c to average 221c/kg.  Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 183c to average 181c and 3 score cows topped at 228c to average 186c/kg.  A small sample of prime heavyweight cows averaged 197c/kg.

Heavy bulls to feed destined for live export recached 250c to average 246c/kg. 
A small number of cows and calves sold from $1,000 to $1,150per unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Numbers increased by 660 head to 3759 cattle in a Combined Prime and Store sale.  Quality was very mixed, with fewer numbers of prime bullocks and cows and one large consignment of northern cows and bulls.  An increase in the supply of plainer store cattle consisted mostly of large single vendor lines of steers and heifers.  The regular buyer panel operated at firm rates on last sale, supported by one southern feeder buyer and opportunity backgrounders.  Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Normanton, Richmond, local and coastal areas.

Light steers returning to grass sold to 618c to average 581c to 591c, while the heifer portion to the trade reached 450c/kg. A large sample of yearling steers to backgrounders averaged 462c selling to 470c and steers above 330kg to feed topped at 456.2 c to average 442c/kg.  A large single vendor line of yearling heifers returning to the paddock for breeding sold to 464.2c to average 457c/kg.

Grown steers to feed reached 434.2c to average 427c and suitable trade types made 396.2c/kg.  Grown heifers to feed sold to 410.2c averaging 356c to 406c/kg.

A smaller, more variable offering of heavy full mouthed bullocks to export slaughter sold to 404.2c to average 387c/kg.  A greater supply of medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 356.2c to average 334c, 3 score cows sold to 378.2c to average 350c to 365c/kg.  Fewer prime heavyweight cows sold to 366c/kg.  Bulls to processors sold to 358.2c to average 344c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Numbers increased by 660 for a yarding of 1610 cattle.  Quality improved throughout, comprising of several good lines of heavy prime cows along with some good quality store steers and heifers. Buyer demand improved with two additional processors operating along with one live exporter, a regular feeder and several opportunity restockers and backgrounders.  Cattle were drawn from Richmond to Tully, with many from the local area.

Light steers returning to the paddock sold to 320c, while similar heifers reached 238c to average 232c/kg and processor types averaged 226c/kg. Yearling steers above 200kg to restockers made to 314c to average 273c, those above 280kg averaged 261c/kg.  Yearling steers above 330kg to feed averaged 258c, a small number of similar weight yearling heifers averaged 248c/kg.  Good quality heavy grown steers to the trade sold to 276c to average 270c/kg.  Heavy grown heifers to the trade reached 250c to average from 228c to 245c/kg.

A small sample of heavy bullocks to export slaughter sold to 258c. Medium weight 3 score cows sold to 232c to average 213c/kg. Prime heavyweight cows topped at 234c to average from 219c to 230c/kg.  Heavy bulls to live export sold to 278c, most from 260c to 266c/kg.

Cows and calves sold from $860 to $980 per unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Numbers increased by 64 percent, however values generally lost ground on the improved rates of the previous sale. In line with most other markets in northern areas, females remain in the largest portion, as cows and heifers represented over 60 percent of the total.

Medium weight steers reached 163.2c, with most averaging around 130c/kg. Heavy steers sold to 175.2c, to average at 172c/kg. There were only 77 bullocks, which averaged just under 176c/kg. 

Lightweight grown heifers reached 155.2c, while 2 scores sold to 119.2c/kg. Light cows were in the larger portion, and experienced the greater falls in price. D1s reached 89.2c, while D2s sold to 121.2c/kg. Medium weight D2s sold to 125.2c, to average at 110c/kg. Bulls were slightly cheaper to sell to 132.2c/kg.

Numbers increased by 600 for a yarding of 1,640 cattle, with increased numbers of prime cows and bullocks and several lines of store steers and heifers of variable quality. Overall, quality was generally good, with most cattle showing improved weight and condition from the recent wet season. One regular processor and feeder buyer were notably absent, however one regular processor was in attendance for the first time in 2019. Two live exporters were very active on suitable lines, although there was limited feeder buyer activity and restockers were very selective on all store lines. Cattle were drawn Burketown, Croydon, Richmond, Mount Garnet, Pentland, Guru, local and coastal areas.

Young vealer steers to restockers eased in all weight categories, with light weights easing by 17c and heavier types adjusting downwards by more than 35c/kg. Yearling steers showed much variation in quality, with better quality lines easing by up to 10c/kg and greater for lesser types. Better quality yearling steers to feed improved by up to 9c/kg, while those to restockers were firm on last sale. Heavy export bullocks to process eased by up to 12c, while suitable lines to live export improved by 6c/kg. Larger numbers of heavy prime cows were on offer with values generally easing, particularly for lighter and lower yielding medium weights. Extra heavy cows eased by 4c and medium weight 3 scores eased by 22c and 2 scores sold 27c/kg lower. Vealer steers to restockers sold to 274c to average 255c, with better quality heavier types averaging 253c/kg. Yearling steers returning to paddock sold to 270c to average 256c/kg. Light vealer heifers met limited demand, topping at 168c to average 151c for most lines and yearling heifers attracted little buyer interest to average 145c/kg.

Grown steers to export process sold to 285c, while suitable steers to live export reached 284c/kg. Bullocks to live export sold to 289c, with most making from 260c to 280c/kg. Heavy bullocks to processors sold to 280c to average 255c, while lighter 2 scores to feed sold to 241c/kg. Heavy 3 score cows sold to 211c, averaging 195c, while D muscled cows reached 192c to average 173c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows sold to 195c to average 152c, with light cows to restockers making to 157c for better quality lines, with most sales above 142c/kg. Grown heifers to process sold to 206c to average 197c/kg, with less quality and weight than last sale. Heavy bulls to live export sold to 286c, with most sales above 280c/kg. Several lines of cows and calves sold from $600 to $900/unit.

Numbers increased by 598 to 2,303 cattle this week, comprising several good quality lines of local steers and some good northern lines. All regular processors were present and operating throughout, except one who has been absent for a long period. There were also 3 live exporters, 2 feeder buyers and several opportunity restockers and backgrounders. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Burketown, Croydon, Einasleigh, Richmond, Prairie, Homestead, Ingham, local and coastal areas.

A very good quality offering of steer calves and vealer steers lifted by more than 25c with light steer calves selling to 288c, to average 281c, while vealer steers sold to 290c, to average 265c/kg. Yearling steers to feed improved by more than 10c, with 280-330kg steers selling to 246c, while those above 330kg sold to 245c, to average 242c/kg. Light and medium weight yearling steers returning to grass sold to 250c/kg. Vealer heifers improved in quality and met strong restocker demand, with opportunity buyers lifting prices to 208c, to average 204c/kg. Yearling heifers to feed from 280-330kg improved 15c, topping at 237c and averaging 213c/kg. Heifers weighing 330-400kg to feed sold to 216c, to average 211c/kg. Restockers secured medium weight heifers to 232c, to average 221c/kg.

Several mixed quality lines of bullocks met subdued demand, with best heavy 3 score bullocks to slaughter selling to 253c, and suitable types to live export sold to 248c, to average 242c/kg. Restockers secured lighter score bullocks to 216c to average 185c/kg. Heavy grown steers to live export sold to 246c to average 242c/kg. Steers to feed sold to 236c/kg. Increased numbers of heavy prime cows sold firm on recent sales across the state, with extra heavy 4 score cows selling to 215c/kg. Heavy 3 score cows sold to 207c to average 196c, while D3 cows sold to 199c to average 184c/kg. Medium weight D muscled cows sold to 179c to average 173c/kg. Restockers were active on lighter 1 and 2 score cows lifting prices to 162c to average 147c/kg. Heavy grown heifers to the trade sold to 225c, with the majority selling from 188c to 198c/kg. Heavy bulls eased slightly with heavy bulls to live export selling to 266c with the majority of sales between 254c and 262c, while feeder bulls to live export sold to 267c, to average 235c/kg. Heavy bulls to slaughter sold to 225c/kg. Young males returning to grass sold to 250c, with majority of sales between 198c and 236c/kg. Cow and calves sold from $920 to $980/unit.

Numbers increased by 544 for a yarding of 2527 cattle.  Quality was more variable than last sale, comprising of increased numbers of plainer conditioned cows, a large consignment of plain conditioned bulls and a large line of lightweight northern mixed sex weaners. Two major processors were notably absent from the buyer panel, however opportunity feeders and restockers operated with selective demand.

Values for prime cattle were mostly firm, while young cattle returning to the paddock averaged 15c lower.

A large sample of suitably weaned steers above 200kg to restockers sold to 362.2 to average 344c/kg. Similar weight weaned heifers returning to the paddock sold to 220.2c to average 210 with those to the trade reaching 204c to average 188c/kg. There were insufficient yearling steers to reliably quote. Yearling heifers above 330kg to feed reached 250 to average 240c/kg.

A small number of grown steers to feed sold to 246c and trade types reached 232c/kg. Grown heifers to the trade topped at 244c to average 226c and heifers to feed averaged 218c/kg. A small number of heavy full mouthed bullocks to export slaughter sold to 250c to average 240c/kg.

Medium weight 2 score cows to processors averaged 180c, with a top of 186c and 3 scores sold to 196c to average 182c/kg.  Fewer numbers of prime heavyweight cow topped at 195c to average 192c/kg.  Heavy bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 270c multiple time to average from 224c to 259c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Numbers increased by 490 head this week to 3,640 cattle. Quality was generally good with some large single vendor lines of steers and prime cows, along with an outstanding line of Brahman heifers. All regular processors operated at reduced rates throughout, supported by central and southern feeder and backgrounders along with western and southern restockers. Grown steers eased by up to 15c, prime cows eased from 11c to 14c and heavy bulls at an average were 30c/kg softer. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Richmond, Hughenden, Tablelands, Collinsville , Mt Coolon, Belyando, local and coastal areas.

Strong demand for restocker steer calves continued, selling to 526c while the heifer portion sold to 442c as the mixed sexes averaged 466c/kg. Light heifers to feed destined for slaughter sold to 364c/kg. Vealer steers returning to grass sold to 454c to average from 399c to 411c/kg.  An outstanding line of predominantly polled Brahman vealer heifers destined for breeding sold to an astonishing 1,190c with the line averaging 979c/kg. A large sample of vealer heifers to feed above 200kg sold to a top of 362c to average 353c/kg. Light weight yearling steers to backgrounders sold to 380c/kg. Steers above 330kg to feed sold to 402c to average from 381c to 398c/kg. Mixed quality smaller lines of yearling heifers to feed weighing 280kg or more sold to 370c to average 365c whilst heifers above 330kg to feed reached 372c/kg.

Increased numbers of grown steers met strong demand from the gallery with steers under 400kg to restockers selling to 380c to average from 354c to 375c, while steers above 400kg sold to a top of 372c/kg. Feeder steers reached 396c to average from 376c to 386c/kg. Grown steers to the trade sold to 370c. Grown heifers to the trade sold to 346c, while heifers to feed reached 368c with better quality lines averaging from 345c to 359c/kg. Heavy bullocks to export slaughter topped at 366c averaging from 333c to 354c/kg. 

Medium weight 2 score cows made to 310c to average 270c/kg whilst 3 score cows topped at 308c as the prime heavy weight cows sold to 310c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export sold to 350c with heavy bulls to processors selling to an isolated 346c with most sales making from 270c to 290c/kg. Medium weight bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 362c to average 321c/kg. Light bulls returning to the paddock sold to 436c to average 364c/kg. Small lines of good quality cows and calves sold from $1,400 to $1,525/unit.

Numbers increased by 475 head to 1,648 cattle for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents, featuring increased numbers of prime cows and bullocks. Prices eased for prime cows, while demand for heavy steers and bulls for live export saw solid gains throughout. All regular processor attended, with one operating very selectively, while two live exporters, one feeder buyer and opportunity restockers rounded out the gallery. Cattle were drawn from Burketown, Georgetown, Hughenden, Ingham, Guru, local and coastal areas.

Steer calves improved by up to 20c/kg for better quality types and light yearling steers were firm on last sale. Light vealer heifers improved by up to 20c, while yearling heifers met quality related price movements. Grown steers and bullocks were mainly consigned to live export, with prices stronger than previous weeks, however prime cows met largest decreases from 13c to 20c/kg across most categories. Heavy bulls to live export improved by more than 20c/kg. Steer calves to restockers topped at 288c and heavier types sold to 280c to average 252c/kg. Light yearling steers to restockers made an isolated 280c, with majority close to 270c to average 255c/kg. Yearling steers to live export sold to 262c to average 261c/kg. Light vealer heifers sold to 176c to average 166c, with most sales making from 144c to 160c/kg. Grown steers less than 400kg to live export topped at 271c, averaging 266c and steers above 400kg sold to 294c to average 266c/kg. Heavy steers above 500kg sold to 293c/kg multiple times.

Limited numbers of grown heifers to processors sold to 170c/kg. Heavy bullocks to live export sold to 292c to average 290c/kg. Heavy 3 score cows to processors sold to 177c to average 172c/kg. An increased supply of heavy 3 score D muscled cows reached 178c to average 155c/kg. Extra heavy cows sold for 179c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows sold to 133c to average 107c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export reached 290c, with most sales above 280c/kg. An offering of more than 100 good quality cows and calves sold to $860/unit.

Numbers increased by 419 head to 2,007 cattle for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents featuring larger lines of prime cattle on offer. All regular processors operated throughout the sale, particularly better quality lines, along with one live exporter, feeder buyer and opportunity restockers and backgrounders. Cattle were drawn from Mount Isa, Burketown, Normanton, Mount Surprise, Tully, Richmond, Balfes Creek, local and coastal areas. Steer calves were in short supply, selling firm on last sale, while fewer numbers of vealer steers improved by 5c/kg. Better quality young heifers improved by 4c/kg. Yearling steers returning to the paddock eased 8c, while steers to live export improved by 3c/kg. Yearling heifers were insufficient to quote and there were only a few grown heifers on offer. Grown steers experienced quality related price changes and heavy bullocks to live export sold to improved prices. Better lines of heavy cows improved by up to 1c, with lesser yielding heavy cows easing by 9c and medium cows easing by 4c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export eased slightly due to plainer types.

Good quality steer calves sold to 266c to average 261c and heavier vealer steers made to 270c to average 267c/kg. Light heifers returning to the paddock sold to 182c, with better quality heavier types making to 199c/kg. Yearling steers to backgrounders reached 256c, while steers to live export made 260c to average 257c/kg.

Grown heifers to process reached 183c to average 177c/kg. Grown steers to process sold to 256c and live export made to 258c/kg. Heavy bullocks to live export sold from 251c to 279c, averaging near 270c/kg. A large sample of heavy 3 score cows made to 183c to average more than 172c, with extra heavy cows reaching 187c and 4 scores making to 185c/kg. Heavy, lower yielding D muscled cows reached 174c to average 152c and medium weight 2 score cows averaged 118c/kg. Plainer cows returning to grass sold to 129c to average 123c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export sold to 296c, with most sales above 284c, while similar bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 294c to average near 278c/kg. Limited numbers of good quality cows and calves sold to $1,000/unit.

Numbers increased by 405 to 1,040 head of good quality cattle for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents. Increased numbers of well finished cows and two good lines of store heifers featured in a yarding of improved quality on recent weeks. Two processors operated at improved prices, however one feeder buyer was absent, impacting suitable feeder lines. Restocker and backgrounder interest was limited, however demand for better quality lines was notable throughout the sale. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Mt Garnet, Pentland, Ingham, Mt Coolon, local and coastal areas. Limited numbers of yearling steers sold predominately to feed, easing by 8c, while some very good quality vealer steers to restockers improved by 6c/kg on last sale. Increased numbers of grown steers to feed improved by up to 40c/kg for better bred lines, with lesser quality lines selling to similar rates of last sale. A good supply of yearling heifers to feed - backgrounded for live export - improved by 8c/kg. Light vealer heifers sold firm, however vealer heifers over 200kg to restockers met limited demand, easing by more than 30c/kg. Well finished heavy grown heifers to the trade improved by more than 40c/kg. Increased numbers of better quality, heavier 3 and 4 score cows saw prices improve by up to 30c/kg for the majority of cows penned. Heavy bulls to live export improved by 40c/kg.

Heavy vealer steers to restockers sold to 295c, averaging 291c, while yearling steers to feed made to 290c, to average 255c/kg. Light vealer heifers sold to 224c, averaging 211c, with heavier types averaging 198c, while an isolated pen made to 258c/kg. Yearling heifers to feed sold to 220c, averaging 209c, while better conditioned heifers to trade made to 238c/kg.

Heavy grown steers to feed sold to 270c, to average 260c/kg. Grown heifers to the trade met strong demand, selling to 267c, averaging 235c/kg. Extra heavy 4 score cows sold to 230c multiple times, to average 226c, and heavy 3 score cows reached 226c to average 217c/kg. Lower yielding heavy 3 score muscled cows sold to 211c, to average 189c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export made to 285c, averaging 280c, while bulls to feed backgrounded for live export made to 284c, to average 262c/kg. Good quality cows and calves made to $920/unit.

Numbers increased by 386 to 1,485 head of mixed quality cattle for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents, featuring increased numbers of plainer cows and store heifers. Heavy cows improved 5c to 8c/kg, while plainer lines of bullocks generally eased on last sale. All the regular processors were in attendance and operating, with two feeder buyers, three live exporters and a small number of local restockers operating throughout the sale. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Normanton, Forsayth, Einasleigh, Pentland, Mount Coolon, local and coastal areas.

A small number of good quality vealer steers met strong demand, improving by 13c to average 254c for lighter types, with young steer calves reaching 250c/kg. A very small offering of yearling steers generally went to live export from 250c to 260c/kg. Vealer heifers consisted of several small lines with considerable variation in quality. Better quality suitably weaned heifers sold to 208c to average 205c/kg. A very good line of yearling heifers to live export sold to 230c to average 228c, while heavy feeder heifers to live export made 228c/kg. Medium weight heifers to feed sold to 206c and lighter heifers reached 200c to average 198c/kg.

Bullocks were fewer in number and generally plainer, with variable quality throughout. Heavier types eased accordingly reaching 265c for D muscled bullocks going to processors, with a small number going to live export for 237c/kg. Medium 2 score bullocks to processors sold to 258c to average 246c and D muscled 2 scores eased 7c, topping at 265c to average 243c/kg. Some very good heavy 3 score yearling steers to processors sold for 249c/kg. Cow numbers increased by more than 200 head, with larger numbers of plainer 2 scores on offer, increasing by up to 14c/kg. Heavy 3 score cows sold to 224c to average 211c, while 4 scores made to 229c/kg. Heavy 2 score C muscled cows improved 5c to average 194c, topping at 210c/kg. Heavy 3 score D muscled cows topped at 206c to average 187c and 2 scores made to 186c to average 163c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 176c, averaging 142c, with restockers active on 2 score cows averaging 137c/kg. A plainer offering of bulls of mixed quality were in strong demand by live exporters and processors alike. Heavy 3 score bulls to processors sold to 247c and 2 scores reached 238c to average 220c/kg. Heavy 3 score bulls to feed destined for live export also made to 247c, with medium weight bulls to live export topping at 236c, while lighter types made to 262c/kg. Feeder weight bulls to backgrounders sold to 228c, while young males to backgrounders made to 260c to average 256c/kg. Good quality small lines of cows and calves sold to $800/unit.

Numbers increased by 331 head to 2,725 cattle in a Combined Prime and Store Sale. Quality was very mixed throughout with a reduced supply of prime cows, however there were some good quality lines of local steers. Only one major export processor was operating, supported by some smaller operators and feeders in a very lacklustre prime section.  Local and western opportunity restockers and backgrounders were more active on young steers and heifers. Cattle were drawn from many northern areas including Mt Isa, Georgetown, Einasleigh, and south-east to Ingham, Ayr, local and coastal areas.

Young, light cattle met increased demand from restockers with most categories improving by 5C to 50c, while heavier cattle more than 100c on many lines. Yearling steers and heifers to feed improved by 10c to 25ckg. Grown heifers to the trade improved 12c to 40c/kg. Bullocks were firm, and cows averaged 10c to 19c/kg less. Heavy bulls fell in price by 25c to 50c/kg.

Vealer steers above 200kg returning to the paddock sold to 531.2c, to average 484c/kg. The heifer equivalents made to 412.2c to average 402c/kg.  A good sample of heifers to the trade made to 400.2c to average 374c to 393c/kg. Light weight yearling steers returning to grass sold to 418.2c to average 411c/kg. A few good pens yearling steers above 280kg to feed sold to 404.2c to average 385c/kg. Steers above 330kg also reached 400.2c to average 386c/kg. Yearling heifers to the trade sold to 370.2c to average the same. Heavy heifers above 400kg to feed topped at 386.2c to average 362c/kg.

A very good quality line of local grown steers to feed sold to 396.2c to average 386c/kg. Steers above 400kg to the trade reached 350.2c multiple times to average 340c/kg. Heavy grown heifers the trade topped at 348.2c to average 336c/kg. A line of local heavy full mouth bullocks to export slaughter topped at 326.2c to average 314c/kg. A reduced supply of cows met lacklustre processor demand. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 260.2c, while a large sample of three score cows to processors topped at 320.2c to average 276c to 306c/kg. Prime heavy weight cows reached 314.2c to average 307c/kg. Heavy bulls also met reduced demand. Bulls to feed topped at 336.2c to average from 280c to 309c/kg. 

Good quality mixed age pens of cows and calves sold from $1,7000 to $1,900/unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Numbers increased by 317 head on last sale to 2515 cattle. Quality was very good, led by some large lines of prime cows, one line of PTIC heifers and some large lines of vealer steers and heifers. All regular processors were in attendance and operating at increased rates throughout, with demand from two feeders, along with restockers and backgrounders from central and western areas. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Burketown, Croydon, Mt Garnet, Ravenswood, local and coastal areas. Most categories improved in price, led by vealer heifers lifting 13c to 22c, grown steers improved 20c and heavy cows to processors increased by 9c/kg.

A sample of very good quality weaned steers above 200kg to western restockers topped at 706.2c to average 649c/kg, while the female portion sold to local restockers to 628.2c multiple times to average 606c/kg. Suitable trade heifers reached 536.2c to average 465c to 495c/kg. A small sample of yearling steers above 280kg to backgrounders reached 600.2c to average 507c/kg with mixed quality steers to feed averaging 392c to 451c/kg. Good quality steers above 330kg to feed topped at 488.2c to average 467c/kg. Limited numbers of yearling heifers sold in line with quality led by heifers above 280kg to restockers reaching to 450.2c to average 445c/kg. 

Limited numbers of grown steers above 400kg to feed sold to 465.2c to average 450c/kg. A small number to the trade made to 426.2 to average 420c/kg. A very good quality line of PTIC heifers sold open auction for $2,2325/head. Grown heifers to the trade reached 412.2c to average near 368c to 374c/kg.  A small number of heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter sold from 410c to 428c/kg. Medium weight 3 score cows to processors sold to 384.2c to average 369c and prime heavyweights topped at 392.2c to average 380c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors made to 384.2c to average 360c to 374c/kg. A large sample of young males returning to grass sold to 718.2c to average from 539c to 617c/kg.

A small number of cows and calves sold from $1,900 to $2,740/unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

Numbers increased by 310 head for a yarding of 958 cattle.  Quality was very mixed, consisting of a small number of prime bullocks and cows along with a large number of plain conditioned northern males and bulls. Most regular processors returned to the galley after last weeks absence, but not all were operating.  Regular feeders were absent, however opportunity restockers and one live exporter were active throughout. Cattle were drawn from Richmond, Croydon, Tully and local areas. Prices eased on most categories in line with other selling centres this week.

Light steers returning to the paddock sold to 502.2 to average 461c/kg.  Yearling steers above 200kg returning to the paddock sold to 408.2 to average 372c and suitable steers for live export reached 384,2c to average 351c/kg.  A good quality line of yearling heifers returning to the paddock for breeding sold for 406c/kg.
A small sample of grown steers to processors reached 300c and grown heifers to the trade made to 318c/kg.

A limited number of bullocks to export processors topped at 296.2c to average 290c/kg.  Medium weight 3 score cows to processors sold to 300.2 to average 282c and a small number of prime heavyweight cows topped at 306.2c to average 300c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors reached 312.2c with most from 240-276c, and feeder weights to live export sold to 348.2c to average 327c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Numbers increased by 2483 to 3906 cattle in a Combined Prime and Store. Quality was mixed, comprising of more than 400 bullocks and 1,500 cows, mostly in prime condition, supported by several good quality lines of store steers and heifers. Two processors were notably absent from the regular buyer panel that included one live exporter and opportunity restockers. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa to Croydon, Richmond to Greenvale, local and coastal areas.

Most categories eased by 20c to 40c with selective demand for better quality pens.

Vealer heifers to processors averaged 176c reaching 190c, similar bred steers returning to the paddock sold  to 232c to average 216c/kg. A good sample of yearling steers above 200kg returning to grass sold to 238c averaging 225c, steers above 280kg averaged 220c/kg. Steers above 330kg to live export averaged 256c and a good line of Brahman steers to feed sold to 254c to average 245c/kg. Similar bred steers above 400kg to feed averaged 243c/kg. A good line of flatback yearling heifers above 200kg returning to the paddock reached 244c, and heifers above 280kg to feed averaged 186c/kg.

Grown steers above 400kg to live export averaged 237c, selling to 240c, and good quality heavy grown steers to processors made to 244c to average 236c/kg. Grown heifers to the trade sold to 238c, averaging from 200c to 214c/kg.

Heavy full mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 248c, averaging 195c to 205c/kg.  The increased number of cows sold lower with selective processor demand. Medium weight 2 score cows sold to 182c to average 172, a large sample of 3 score cows reached an isolated 238c, most sales from 180c to 214c to average 182c to 195c/ kg. Prime heavyweight cows averaged 190c to 197c/kg.  Heavy bulls to processors made to 238c to average 215c, those suitable for live export averaged 226c/kg.

Cows and calves sold from $700 to $1,100 per unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Numbers increased by 24 head to 1,010 cattle. Quality improved on last sale with more than 200 very good quality, well finished prime cows and some very good quality northern weaner steers.  One southern processor returned to the buyer panel, supported by two regular processors and several opportunity restockers.  Cattle were drawn from Croydon, Richmond local and coastal areas.

Demand improved significantly on last sale with steers improving 30c to 75c, heifers to restockers lifting 20c to 60 and prime cows averaged 12c to 22 better. 

A single light steer sold to 518.2c, while a good sample averaged 451c/kg.  Freshly weaned steers above 200kg sold to 452.2c to average 421c/kg.  Yearling steers above 200kg returning to the paddock topped at 400.2 to average from 360c to 420c and steers above to 280kg to backgrounders sold to 342c/kg.  A limited supply of yearling heifers sold to 344.2c to average 296c to 314c/kg.

Heavy grown steers to processors topped at 296.2c, most selling from 290c to 294c/kg.  A small number of grown heifers to processors sold to 264c/kg.

A good pen of PTIC cows sold to 266.2c/kg. Very good quality 3 score cows to processors sold to 258.2c to average 250c and an increased supply of prime heavyweight 3 and 4 score cows also reached 258.2c to average 256c/kg. A small sample of heavy bulls to processors sold to 282c/kg.

Small lines of cows and calves sold from $1,255 to $1,425/unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Numbers increased by 22 head for a yarding of 1891 cattle, with quality mostly good throughout. Despite a reduced supply of prime cattle, more than 200 good quality prime bullocks were penned. Two regular processors were not in attendance and values fell for most prime categories. Regular feeders and restockers and one live exporter were very selective for better quality lines, with secondary types attracting very subdued demand. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa to Georgetown, south to the local area.

Good quality young lightweight steers to restockers increased 13c, yearling heifers to feed were mostly firm, grown steers eased 8c, bullocks were mostly firm,  heavy cows fell 18c and bulls averaged 16c lower.

Good quality young steers above 200kg returning to the paddock averaged 320c to 368c selling to 374c, and similar heifers returning to the paddock averaged 208c/kg.  Yearling steers above 330kg to feed sold to 266c to average 256c/kg.  Yearling heifers above 280kg to feed topped at 238c to average 234c/kg. A good line of heifers above 330kg to feed averaged 233c/kg.

A reduced supply of grown steers above 400kg to feed sold to 250c to average 245c and a small sample of trade types reached 260c to average 250c/kg.  Grown heifers to the trade made to 242c to average 232c and suitable heifers to feed averaged 223c/kg.  An increased supply of heavy full mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 282c, most sales from 256c to 266c and suitable steers to live export averaged 266c/kg.
A reduced supply of cows met subdued demand, losing most of last weeks gains. Medium weight 2 score cows sold to 196c to average 183c,  3 scores reached 220c to average 207c to 214c/kg. A good sample of prime heavyweight 4 score cows topped at 216c to average 212c/kg.
Heavy bulls to live export sold to 2702c to average 267c and bulls to processors averaged 233c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Numbers increased by 211 for a total of 2078 head for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week. There were some very good lines of prime cows, although quality in lighter cows was more variable than previous sales. All regular processors were operating for the first time this year, accompanied by regular feeder buyers and backgrounders and one live exporter. Cattle were drawn from both local and coastal areas including Richmond, Georgetown, Mt Surprise, Greenvale, Basalt, Ingham, Ayr and Ravenswood. 

Vealer heifers had similar numbers to last sale, with quality very good and many sold to slaughter, topping at 284c/kg. Light vealer heifers returning to paddock sold to 292c/kg. Yearling heifers were generally of very good quality with feeder buyers active on heifers above 320 kg, topping at 283c to average 271c/kg. Heifers returning to the paddock sold to 275c/kg. Vealer steer numbers lifted on last sale and were improved in quality, with lighter pens returning to paddock topping at 366c and vealer steers above 240 kg sold to 356c, averaging 317c/kg. While better finished types to slaughter sold to 291c/kg. Yearling steers above 370kg to feed topped at 300c, to average 281c, while steers 280-330kg returning to grass made up to 340c, averaging down 2c to 324c/kg. Steers above 330kg to grass sold for 317c, averaging 302c/kg. Bullocks were of variable quality and condition, with heavy 3 score bullocks to slaughter similar to last sale topping at 280c and lighter 2 score types to feed selling to 275c, to average 263c/kg.

Good lines of well finished 3 and 4 score cows sold similar to last sale owing to an additional processor, topping at 255c to slaughter, averaging 219c/kg.  Heavy 2 score cows sold to 220c to average 209c, while lighter 1 score cows to restockers sold to 179c to average 167c/kg. Heavy bulls similar to last sale, with the absence of one live exporter, a new backgrounder entered, pushing values to 298c, with most sales above 267c/kg.  Light, young males sold to 332c, with medium weight bulls selling to 298c/kg. Cows and calves sold lower on last sale, with several pens selling from $1080-1320/unit.

Numbers increased by 21 head to 1,579 cattle for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents featuring some continued lines of very good prime cows and bullocks and young northern males. Values for all prime cattle improved, with all regular processors in attendance and operating strongly throughout, supported by two regular feeder buyers and some opportunistic restockers. Cattle were drawn from Julia Creek, Richmond, Normanton, Tully, Ingham, Townsville, local and coastal areas.

An improved quality offering of vealer steers lifted by more than 30c, selling to 290c to average 286c, with heavier types selling to 273c/kg. Yearling steers generally consisted of variable quality small lines with limited buyer interest. Yearling steers to live export sold to 245c for heavy feeders, with some very good yearling steers to slaughter reaching 256c/kg. General quality of vealer heifers declined on recent sales with limited demand and quality related prices movements. Light heifer calves returning to grass sold to 194c, while better qaulity vealer heifers reached 168c/kg. Yearling heifers were in limited supply, with only quality related price movements. Heifers above 330kg to feed sold to 230c/kg. Good quality heavy export bullocks lifted 8c selling to 263c to average 260c, while similar bred lighter types sold to 256c to average 253c/kg. Medum weight 2 score bullocks sold to 253c averaging 248c/kg with improved quality on offer. 

Increased numbers of heavy grown steers sold to 259c to average 258c/kg. A small number of heavy steers to live export made 237c and medium weight steers to feed sold to 210c/kg. The cow offering continued recent trends of heavy, good yielding lines with heavy cows lifting by 8c to 10c/kg. Heavy 3 score cows to processors topped at 213c, to average 205c, and a small number of extra heavy cows sold to 219c, to average 209c/kg. Heavy D muscled cows sold to 204c, improving 13c to average 193c, while C muscled 2 score cows averaged 185c, with a top of 195c/kg. Opportunity restockers were active on plainer conditioned cows to 151c, averaging 133c/kg. Grown heifers improved in supply and increased demand topped at 257c, improving 7c to average 237c/kg. Heavy prime bulls to slaughter increased by up to 15c, selling to 245c, while similar bulls to feed destined for live export reached 246c, with most sales from 229c to 238c/kg. Feeder weight bulls to live export sold to 240c, while lighter types to feed destined for live export made to 252c to average 243c/kg. The highlight of the sale was a line of northern males selling to 283c, with most above 263c/kg. A small number of cows and calves sold to $850/unit.

Numbers increased by 204 for a yarding of 2026 cattle.  Quality Improved on last sale, comprising of some very good quality heavy bullocks cows and prime heifers, supported by several good lines of yearling steers and heifers.  Two major processors returned to the buyer panel providing solid support throughout, while two live exporters were active on suitable types.  Regular feeders and restockers were selective, with secondary lines difficult to sell. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa to Georgetown, east to Malinda and Ingham, south to Ayr and the local area.

Values improved for most prime categories, heifers lifted  18c, steers increased 5, bullocks were firm and cows increased by 6c to 18c/kg. 

Vealer steers returning to the paddock averaged 285c to 315c selling to 320 and similar heifers reached 248c to average 180c to 234c/kg.  Yearling steers above 280kg returning to the paddock sold to 280 to average from 262c to 272c/kg.  Steers above 330kg to feed topped at 280c to average 263c/kg. A good sample of yearling heifers above 330kg returning to the paddock sold to 246c to average 207c and heifers above 330kg to feed sold to 240c to average 238c/kg.

Grown steers above 400kg to feed reached 278 to average 259c, steers suitable to live export averaged 281c/kg. A good supply of heavy grown heifers to the trade topped at 260c to average 250c/kg.

Increased numbers of heavy bullocks sold to spirited demand.  Bullocks to live export reached 280c, averaging 265c to 278c, processor types averaged 267c/kg. Improved demand by processors saw medium weight 2 score cows sell to 210c to average 206c, 3 scores made to 240c to average 214c and prime heavyweight cows topped at 234c to average 227c/kg.

Heavy bulls to live export reached 286c to average 279c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Numbers increased by 198 head to 3177 mixed quality cattle in a stronger market.  Some very good lines of heavy cows and bullocks were on offer, supported by increased numbers of young steers and males.  The regular buyer panel including southern processor and restocker orders were in attendance and operating at stronger rates along with one live exporter.  Cattle were drawn from west of Mt Isa, Cloncurry, Normanton, Croydon, Northern Cape, Mount Garnet, Ingham, Belyando, local and coastal areas.  Demand was particularly strong for well finished heavy prime cattle and heavy feeder lines, with lightweight young cattle attracting spirited buyer activity.

Increased numbers of suitable weaned calves sold to strong demand with a large sample of heifers to processors selling to 334.2c, to average 317c, and young males to restockers/backgrounders sold to 388c, to average 355c/kg.   Vealer steers to restockers sold to 376c , averaging 324-348c/kg.  Vealer heifers to processors reached 338.2c, with best quality types averaging 334c/kg.  Mixed quality small lines of yearling steers to backgrounders sold to 354c across most weight classes, averaging 290-354c/kg.  Yearling heifers to feed sold to 314c with averages from 274-303c/kg, with heifers to the trade averaging near 283c/kg.

Increased numbers of grown steers to live export sold to 336.2c, with most sales from 318-334c/kg.  A large sample of steers to feed topped at 348.2c, with those above 400kg averaging 341c/kg.  Heavy grown heifers to the trade sold to 298.2c, to average 269-296c/kg.  Some very good pens of prime heavyweight bullocks to export processors sold to 333.2c, to average 302-323c/kg.  

Medium weight 2 score cows sold firm, topping at 248.2c, to average 239c, with heavy 3 score cows topping at 270.2c, to average 260c/kg.  Some excellent pens of prime heavyweight cows sold to 281.2c, to average 274c, with several pens of 4 score cows selling to and averaging 282c/kg.  Heavy bulls met strong live export demand selling to 334.2c, with a large sample averaging above 313-326c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors averaged near 290c/kg.  A small number of good quality cows and calves sold to $1120/unit.

Numbers increased by 1932 head on a fortnight ago due to the Big Country Bull Sale last week to 3846 cattle in a Combined Prime and Store sale.  Quality was generally good throughout with some well finished lines of grown steers and cows and some large single vendor lines of store steers and heifers.  The regular buyer panel of processors, feeders and southern backgrounders were in attendance and operating at increased rates on last sale, along with one live exporter and a large gallery of onlookers.  Cattle were drawn from Richmond, Pentland, Greenvale, Collinsville, Ayr, Belyando, local and coastal areas.

Light restocker steer calves sold to 826.2c top average 761c/kg.  Good quality light vealer steers to restockers topped at 900.2c to average 865c and a large sample of steers above 200kg returning to grass also reached 900.2c to average 788c to 821c/kg.  A good sample of light vealer heifers to restockers sold to 714.2c to average 692c/kg.  Good quality heifers above 200kg returning to grass topped at 732.2c to average 671c to 673c/kg.  A large sample of light yearling steers above 200kg to backgrounders sold to 802.2c to average 765c, steers above 280kg to backgrounders reached 746.2c to average 661c and steers above 330kg averaged 567c/kg.  A good sample of light yearling heifers above 200kg to feed reached 640.2c to average 517c/kg.  A small sample above 280kg to feed reached 586.2c to average 557c and restocker lines averaged 497c to 518c/kg.  Good quality yearling heifers above 330kg to feed sold to 590.2c to average 458c to 521c/kg. 

A good supply of grown steers above 400kg to feed sold to 514.2c to average 454c to 484c/kg.  Steers above 500kg to feed made to 465.2c to average 457c and suitable trade types topped at 460.2c to average 456c/kg.  Increased numbers of grown heifers to feed sold to 496.2c to average 421c to 446c/kg.  Limited numbers of heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter sold to 458.2c with most near 450c/kg.

Demand for cows continued upwards with processors, feeders, restockers and live exporters jostling to fill orders.  Medium weight 2 score cows to live export sold to 402.2c to average 390c and those to feed averaged near 400c/kg. Heavy 3 score cows to export processors reached 410.2c to average 355 to 404c and prime heavyweight cows topped at 406.2c to average above 396c/kg.  A good sample of lightweight cows returning to grass sold to 418.2c to average 373-382c/kg.  Processor activity on bulls was limited to suitable heavyweight types reaching 406.2c to average 394c to 402c/kg.  Young males returning to the paddock sold to 830.2c to average 695c to 711c/kg.

A large offering of cows and calves met strong demand with good quality cows and calf units selling from sold from $2,600 to $3,250 per unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Numbers increased by 179 head for a yarding of 2,479 cattle, featuring some good lines of heavy prime cows and some large lines of northern steers and heifers. Quality varied throughout with several lesser quality lines attracting limited buyer interest. Most of the usual buyer gallery was in attendance, supported by some western restockers, however the absence of some feeder buyers impacted on many store lines. Cattle were drawn from north of Mt Isa, Burketown, Cloncurry, Greenvale, local and coastal areas.

Mixed sex calves sold firm to 4c easier for better quality types, while vealer steers and heifers eased by up to 30c/kg, with many lines showing effects of the drying season. Yearling steers were of very mixed quality, with many small lines on offer, however better quality yearling heifers to domestic processors improved by up to 15c/kg. Limited numbers of grown steers sold firm to live export and to slaughter. Heavy bullocks suitable for live export increased by 10c, however heavy bullocks to export slaughter sold firm to 2c/kg easier. Medium weight cows eased more than 20c and heavy weight cows averaged 9c to 14c/kg lower. Heavy bulls to live export eased by up to 5c/kg with similar types to feed destined for live export easing by similar values. Steer calves sold to 258c, while heifer calves met limited demand, topping at 176c/kg. Light vealer steers to western restockers sold to 270c, to average 231c, while some small lines above 280kg sold to 250c, to average 249c/kg. Vealer heifers met limited buyer demand and interest. Those returning to grass sold to 166c, to average 153c and heifers to feed sold to 148c, averaging 132c/kg. Light yearling steers to restockers sold to 228c and feeder weight types to live export made up to 270c, to average 256c/kg. Light yearling heifers returning to grass made to 152c, to average 144c and heavier types averaged 155c/kg. Yearling heifers to processors made to 244c, to average 242c/kg.

Grown steers to feed destined for live export sold to 288c, with a small sample to live export making 268c/kg. Suitable bullocks to live export sold to 293c, while a large sample to feed destined for live export sold to 298c, to average 292c/kg. Heavy export bullocks to slaughter reached 289c, with most sales from 262 to 279c/kg. Medium weight cows sold to 160c, to average 135c, while heavy 3 score cows sold from 181c to 221c, to average 203c/kg.  Small lines of extra heavy 3 score cows averaged 205c and some 4 score cows averaged 217c/kg. A large sample of D muscled heavy 3 score cows sold to 201c, to average 187c/kg.  

Heavy bulls to live export topped at 280c, averaging 275c and similar types to feed destined for live export averaged 274c/kg. Feeder weight bulls backgrounded for live export made to 274c, to average 227c/kg. Young males returning to grass made to 232c to average 230c/kg.

Numbers increased by 161 head to 1,814 cattle in Charters Towers, featuring one large line of cows and northern store steers. All regular processors operated selectively and at improved prices on recent weeks, along with one live exporter, one feeder buyer and several enthusiastic opportunity restockers. One line of cows from the Northern Territory complimented cattle from Normanton, Chillagoe, Georgetown, Hughenden, Gumlu, local and coastal areas.

Light steer calves sold lightly easier on last sale and young steers were up to 14c/kg lower than last week. Yearling steers met quality related price changes, while yearling heifers improved by up to 20c/kg. Grown steers to feed and live export eased by 9c and the small numbers of grown heifers to domestic process improved by up 20c/kg.
