Bullocks to live export again met strong demand, as did suitable heavy bulls. Heavy 3 score cows recouped most of last week's decreases and medium weight 2 score cows improved by up to 14c/kg. Steer calves returning to the paddock made to 274c, with light vealer steers making to 271c to average 263c/kg. Yearling steers to restockers and backgrounders made to 230c to average 227c and similar types to feed made to 228c to average 220c/kg. Light heifers calves sold to 188c and a small number of vealer heifers made to 198c/kg. Yearling heifers to restockers sold to 181c to average 165c and heavier types to processors made to an isolated 216c/kg.

Grown steers to live export sold to 273c and steers to feed reached 261c to average 251c/kg. Limited numbers of grown heifers to process reached 208c to average 176c/kg. Reduced numbers of heavy bullocks to live export sold to 290c and lighter types to restockers made to 239c/kg. Heavy 3 score cows sold higher, reaching 199c to average near 192c and heavy 3 score D muscled cows sold to 195c to average 167c/kg. Extra heavy 4 score cows made to 195c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows sold to 150c to average 121c, with a good offering of PTIC cows making to 159c to average near 153c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export made to 293c to average near 273c/kg, with bulls to feed destined for live export receiving similar prices. Young males returning to the paddock made to 242c/kg. A small number of cows and calves sold to $1,000/unit.

Numbers increased by 148 head to 1,788 cattle for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents, comprising of some well finished lines of cows and a large consignment of young northern steers and heifers. All processors were operating at firm to stronger rates on last sale, along with two live exporters, while backgrounders and restockers were active on many store lines. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Richmond, Mt Surprise, Greenvale, Malanda, Ingham, Ravenswood, local and coastal areas.  

Several small lines of vealer steers sold up to 11c easier on last sale, topping at 272c to average 267c, with heavier types averaging near 272c/kg. There were insufficient yearling steers to reliably quote. Increased number of vealer heifers sold firm, with suitably weaned heifers returning to grass selling to 226c to average 223c, while heavier types to feed averaged 219c/kg. Yearling heifers to live export sold to 244c, with some PTIC heifers returning to grass to 226c/kg.

A mixed offering of bullocks sold firm on last sale topping at 300c for heavy export types and plainer 2 scores sold to 295c to average close to 282c/kg. Suitable bullocks to live export sold to 265c, easing 14c to average 226c/kg. Grown steers to slaughter increased 6c to 13c, selling to 299c for heaviest types and 295c for medium weights to average 293c/kg. Grown steers to live export sold to 290c to average 271c/kg.

A good supply of prime cows met strong demand throughout, however heavy 3 score cows eased 4c to average 221, with D muscled cows improving 12c to average 216c/kg. An improved supply of better quality medium 2 score cows lifted more than 15c, selling to 202c to average 191c/kg. Light conditioned cows to feed sold from 157c to 178c/kg. Grown heifers lifted 5c for better quality types, topping at 249c/kg. A good supply of heavy bulls lifted 5c, mostly selling from 278c to 292c, with a large sample averaging 280c, with medium weights to feed destined for live export selling from 250-280c/kg. Young males to restockers topped at 290c, to average 281c/kg.

Numbers increased by 141 head to 1,487 cattle for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, with fewer numbers of prime cows and bullocks and greater numbers of yearling store steers and heifers. One processor was again absent this week with all others operating selectively throughout the sale, along with one regular feeder buyer, several restockers and two live exporters. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Cloncurry, Richmond, Prairie, Mt Surprise, Einalseigh, Woodstock, Mt Coolon, Collinsville, Bowen, local and coastal areas.

A small number of vealer steers sold to 352c/kg. Some good lines of yearling steers met strong feeder and live export competition, with steers above 320kg to feed selling to 289c, while steers to live export sold from 276c to 293c/kg. A small number of lighter yearling steers returning to grass sold to 326c/kg. Vealer heifers were in greater numbers and met very strong restocker competition and sold to 274c/kg. Yearling heifers were mainly represented by one large line of western heifers, with those less than 280kg returning to grass up to 292c to average 280c, while heifers above 280kg averaged 266c/kg. Heavier yearling and grown heifers to feed sold to 245c to average down 7c to 242c/kg.

Some well finished small lines of bullocks increased by up to 14c to slaughter topping at 252c, while many 2 score types sold from 238c to 242c/kg. Heavy grown steers to feed sold to 280c, with heavy steers above 420kg returning to grass selling to 273c to average 255c/kg. Some very good well finished cows sold 8c to 10c lower with heavy 4 score cows to slaughter topping at 210c to average 207c/kg. Heavy 3 score cows to slaughter sold to 204c to also average 12c lower, while heavy D muscled 3 score cows sold 13c lower to average 173c, with better types to 190c/kg. Lighter cows returning to grass sold 16c lower influenced by quality, with several small lines below 160c/kg. Heavy bulls were in good supply and lifted 12c to 14c on last sale with many sold to feed destined for live export, selling from 210c to 242c/kg. The small number of bulls above 500kg to slaughter sold to 243c/kg. Medium weight bulls to feed sold to 265c, while younger males to restockers sold to 337c averaging 10c/kg lower, mainly influenced by quality. Some larger lines of cows and calves sold to $1,330/unit.

Numbers increased by 137 head for a yarding of 2188 cattle. Quality was mixed comprising of some well finished bullocks and cows and several smaller lines of steers and heifers. Processor attendance included one southern operator supported by one live exporter, one feeder and opportunity backgrounders and restockers. Cattle were drawn from Burketown to Tully and south to the local area.

Demand for better quality lines was firm, with lesser quality lines difficult to sell. Steers and bullocks lifted 16c to 30c, cows improved 9c to 14c and bulls lifted by 30c to 70c/kg.

Steer calves and vealer steers returning to the paddock sold to 272c, similar heifers to processors made to 220c/kg. Yearling steers above 200kg to grass reached 258c to average 239c, those above 280kg averaged 263c and steers to feed averaged 256c/kg. Steers above 330kg to live export sold to 244c, while steers to feed averaged 242c/kg. Good quality steers to backgrounders reached 282c to average 277c/kg. Yearling heifers above 280kg to processors made to 244c to average 227c, those above 330kg averaged 233c/kg. A small sample to feed averaged 223c/kg. 

An increased number of grown steers to feed sold to 266c, better quality trade types made to 292c, most averaging 257c to 282c/kg. Grown  heifers to the trade sold to 277c, a good sample averaging from 248c to 251c/kg.

Heavy full mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 290c, most averaging from 266c to 274c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows sold to 210c to average 194c, 3 score cows topped at 260c to average from 234c to 250c/kg.  Heavy bulls to processors sold to 260c to average 246c/kg and bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 274c to average 268c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Numbers increased by 135 head to 1,345 cattle for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week. Prime cows made up more than 30% of the yarding, supported by several small lines of prime bullocks, grown steers and young heifers. One regular processor was again absent, however this was offset by the return of one southern processor. One live exporter and feeder buyer operated on suitable lines, while restocker interest was very subdued. Cattle were drawn from Mount Isa, Hughenden, Pentland, The Lynd, Ingham, Townsville, local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers were of mixed quality, easing by 21c for lighter types, while heavier types were firm to 4c/kg easier on last sale. There were insufficient yearling steers to quote. Vealer heifers were more than 20c lower, while yearling heifers to restockers eased 8c/kg for better quality types, and those with more weight to process met subdued demand. An increased supply of heavy bullocks improved more than 10c and heavy 3 score cows sold to improved prices on two weeks ago.

Light vealer steers to restockers sold to 259c to average 243c, and heavier types averaged 263c/kg. Light vealer heifers returning to grass topped at 180c, decreasing by more than 20c/kg. Grown steers returning to the paddock made to 258c to average 249c and suitable types to feed destined for live export made to 265c, with most sales from 242c to 260c/kg. Grown heifers sold to 231c to average 200c and lighter types of variable quality returning to paddocks averaged 146c/kg. Heavy bullocks to export process sold to 276c, with most sales above 265c, as suitable types to live export made from 270c to 280c/kg. Heavy 3 score cows sold to 199c to average 191c and heavy 4 score cows topped at 198c to average 197c/kg. Heavy D muscled cows lifted 8c, topping at 198c to average 186c, and medium weight 2 score cows averaged 145c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export sold to 280c, with most sales from 262c to 276c/kg. Young males returning to the paddock made to 285c to average 243c/kg.

Numbers increased by 130 head to 1,617 cattle for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, featuring some good lines of prime bullocks and cows and mixed lines of store cattle. One processor continued their absence, while all others operated at increased rates on last sale, accompanied by two live exporters, one regular feeder buyer and several restockers. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Georgetown, Einasleigh, Ingham, Ayr, Collinsville, Belyando, local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers were in short supply and showing effects of season selling to mixed demand at values similar to last sale, with most sales from 296c to 321c to average 314c/kg. A reduced number of yearling steers sold lower, mainly influenced by quality, with heavy backgrounders returning to grass for 296c, while lighter steers sold to 318c to average 288c/kg. A small number to feed sold to 270c/kg. Vealer heifers were of mixed quality and weight with better conditioned types to slaughter selling to240c, while those returning to grass sold to 258c to average 251c/kg. Yearling heifers sold lower with quality the main influence, with heifers to feed selling to 246c multiple times, while similar weight heifers to grass sold to 259c to average 253c/kg.

Bullock numbers increased and quality improved on recent sales with some very good lines meeting strong demand from processor and live exporters.  Heavy bullocks to live export sold to 265c averaging 263c, while heavier weight lines to slaughter also sold to 265c, averaging 263c/kg. Medium weight types to feed sold to 244c, with some lesser quality types returning to grass making 213c/kg. Some very good heavy cows improved up to 10c on last sale with heavy C muscled 3 score cows selling to 238c to average 209c, while D muscled heavy cows sold to 210c to average 199c/kg. Heavy 2 score cows sold to similar values of last sale selling to 207c, averaging 185c, while medium weight 2 score cows sold to 185c to average 167c/kg. Cows of lighter weight to restockers were generally lower quality and sold to 160c, averaging 140c/kg. Heavy bulls met strong demand from processors and live exporters, with heavy bulls to live export selling to 260c multiple times, while bulls to slaughter sold to 264c, with most sales 213c to 223c/kg. Feeder weight bulls to live export sold to 294c while those to feed destined for live export sold to 270c to average 245c/kg. Young males were attractive to several restockers, selling to 300c to average 250c/kg. A small number of cows and calves sold to $1,080/unit.

Numbers increased by 125 head to 1182 cattle in Charters Towers, however there was reduced numbers of heavy prime cattle in a very mixed quality yarding.  Heavy prime cows and bullocks sold firm, while plainer lines eased and store cattle sold to to improved rates. One central processor added competition on suitable lines, supported by two live exporters, and regular backgrounders and restockers. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Coen, Mt Surprise, Ingham, local and coastal areas.

Mixed sex calves sold to improved rates with good quality heifer lines improving by up to 30c and steers improving by more than 3c, while some very good quality lines  of vealer steers improved by more than 30c/kg. Yearling steers to live export improved by 7c and by 4c to restockers, while yearling heifers improved by up to 20c/kg. Increased numbers of grown steers to feed improved by 7c and grown heifers to slaughter increased by up to 12c/kg. Mixed quality bullocks sold firm for better types and heavy cows to processors sold firm, while plain cows eased by 9c/kg. Heavy bulls sold similar to previous rates.

Steer calves sold to 290c to average 271c, while heifer calves made to 268c for selected pens, with most selling from 200kg to 220c/kg. Yearling steers to live export made to 266c, averaging 257c and steers to restockers made to 275c to average 259c/kg. Yearling heifers returning to grass made to 218c, and heifers to feed sold to 210c to average 198c/kg. Greater numbers of grown steers to slaughter made to 269c, averaging 257c and grown heifers to slaughter sold to 236c to average 232c/kg. Small lines of heavy bullocks to export slaughter sold to 289c, with most sales from 263c to 275c, with suitable lines to feed destined for live export reached 286c/kg.

Heavy 3 score cows sold to 204c to average near 200c and extra heavy cows reached 211c to average 202c/kg. Heavy 3 score D muscled cows eased 9c to average 188c, while medium weight 2 score cows sold to 165c, easing 9c to average 143c/kg. Plainer cows returning to grass made to 150c to average 134c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export made to 281c and young males returning to grass sold to 290c to average 262c/kg.

Numbers increased by 1198 head to 2705 cattle in Charters Towers, featuring some good lines of prime bullocks and cows in addition to northern stores steers and heifers. One regular processor was again absent with most prime cattle improving 4c to 6c, while 2 live exporters operated at similar rates along with two feeder buyers and several opportunity restockers and backgrounders. Light store steers improved in line with quality, and well grown heifers sold to stronger rates. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Burketown, Croydon, Mt Garnet, Pentland, Collinsville, local and coastal areas.

Light steer calves sold easier, while increased numbers of vealer steer lines generally improved in price. Vealer heifers improved throughout, particularly heavier types to restockers. Yearling steers to live export improved on last sale, and steers to feed also improved. Yearling heifers sold up to 4c/kg higher and a few grown heifers sold firm. Grown steers to feed improved by 4c and heavy bullocks to export slaughter improved by 4c/kg. Heavy 3 score cows improved by 15c and medium weight 2 score cows increased by 9c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export sold firm on previous weeks.

Steer calves sold to 286c to average 262c, while light vealer steers sold to 272c to average 260c/kg. Light vealer heifers to restockers sold to 199c, averaging 197c and lines above 280kg sold to 196c to average 175c/kg. Light yearling steers to restockers made to 258c to average 255c and steers to live export topped at 268c multiple times to average 261c/kg. Yearling heifers returning to the paddock sold to 182c, averaging 179c and PTIC heifers made to 194c/kg. Heavy grown steers to feed destined for live export made to 256c and heavy bullocks to live export made to 271c to average 264c/kg. Suitable bullocks for live export backgrounded to feed averaged 271c/kg. 

Heavy 3 score cows to slaughter sold to 185c to average 184c and heavy D muscled cows made to 186c to average 162c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows to slaughter sold to 128c to average 117c and better quality lighter cows to restockers sold to 127c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export made to 286c to average 280c and similar types to feed destined for live export sold to 277c to average 268c/kg. Bulls from 280kg to 400kg to live export sold to 288c to average 280c/kg.  Young males to restockers made to 280c with better quality types averaging 266c/kg.  

A small number of cows and calves sold to $880/unit.

Numbers increased by 115 head to 2,557, consisting of very several mixed quality lines. Quality was variable and well below recent weeks however prices for most categories were firm on last sale. The regular buying panel was missing one southern processor, however three live exporters and regular feeder buyers were supported by opportunity restockers. Increased numbers of prime cows sold firm, yearling heifers to feed improved 5c and heavy bulls to live export increased 10c/kg on last sale. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Mt Garnet, Pentland, Ingham, Ravenswood, Belyando, local and coastal areas.

Heifer calves again sold to strong processor demand reaching 374.2c to average from 347c to 364c, with light heifer calves to restockers averaging 337c/kg. Fewer numbers of vealer steers returning to grass sold to 398.2 to average from 359c to 377c, with vealer heifers returning to the paddock averaging from 316c to 344c/kg. Many small pens of yearling steers sold according to quality, with the majority to feed averaging 350c/kg. Yearling heifers continued recent strong demand with pens from 200 to 330kg to feed topping at 342.2c to average from 307c to 309c, while heifers above 330kg averaged 321c/kg.

A small offering of grown steers to live export sold from 320c to 330c, while better quality grown heifers to feed sold to 334.2c to average 305c/kg. Grown heifers to the trade topped at 300.2c with heavy 3 score heifers averaging from 286c to 297c/kg. Reduced numbers of heavy bullocks to export slaughter topped at 339.2c to average 336c/kg. 

Fewer numbers of medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 252.2c to average 240c and 3 scores sold to 268.2c to average 251c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export sold from 318c to 338c to average near 330c, with medium weight bulls to background feed for live export averaging 320c/kg.

Numbers increased by 1,111 head to 2121 cattle.  Quality was quite good throughout with some good heavy steers and lines of cows, supported by several lines of store steers and heifers presenting in fresh condition. The buyer panel increased with most regular processors and feeders returning along with two live exporters, and several opportunity local, central and western restockers operating in stronger market.  Cattle were drawn from Julia Ck, Richmond, Georgetown, Einasleigh, Bowen, local and coastal areas.

Yearling steers lifted up to 13c, yearling heifers improved by 10c, cows to processors increased 9c to 11c and bulls averaged 9c better.

Suitably weaned steers above 200kg returning to grass topped at 472.2c to average  426c. Yearling steers above 280kg to backgrounders made to 402c averaging 346c/kg. A small number of grown steers processors topped at 296c to average 293c/kg. A limited number of grown heifers to live export averaged 280c/kg. Fewer numbers of heavy bullocks to export slaughter sold to 316c, most selling from 272c to 292c/kg.

Medium weight 2 score cows  to processors averaged 227c selling to 258c and three scores reached 269.2c to average 259c/kg.  A good sample of prime heavyweight cows topped at 267c to average 266c/kg.  Suitable cows to live export sold to 280c to average 260c/kg. Bulls to processors topped at 300c to average 292c/kg.

Mixed age small lines of cows and calves sold from $1,100 to $1,550 per unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Numbers increased and the top end of the market improved in quality. Most of the regular buyers were in attendance and competition was fair. The yarding was made up of heavy cattle and this made accurate trends difficult to quote in places. On the whole the market was firm to dearer. The medium weight steers held firm while the heifers gained 4c/kg. The cow market mostly improved 5c to 9c/kg. 

The light steers peaked at 132.2c and averaged around 125c while the medium weights topped at 150.2c, which saw the better grades average 141.2c/kg. There was some good heavy steers penned and these reached 149.2c to average 146c/kg. 

Heifers made to 139.2c and most averaged 105.2c/kg. The light cows reached 127.2c and a large number averaged 104c/kg. Medium weights sold to 134.2c and the D3s averaged 124c/kg. 

Light bulls sold around 118c while the heavy weights peaked at 137.2c/kg.

Numbers increase by more than 600 head to 2,508 head for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, with greater numbers of store cows on offer. Prices eased for prime cows and store heifers, while remaining firm for bullocks and steers. All regular processors except one were in attendance and operating along with regular feeder buyers and restockers, accompanied by some central and western restockers. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Richmond, Prairie, Croydon, Einasleigh, Mt Garnet, Ravenswood, Belyando, local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers sold to higher rates than previous sale topping at 400c for lighter types, with best slaughter types selling to 301c/kg. Increased numbers of yearling steers were on offer, with those to feed selling similar to last sale with 330-380kg steers to feed selling to 280c, while those returning to grass sold to 290c to average 277c/kg. Lighter yearling steers less than 280kg returning to grass sold to 340c/kg. Some very good vealer heifers to slaughter sold to 282c/kg, averaging 276c, while lighter types returning to grass also sold to 282c with a 276c/kg average. Yearling heifers were of mixed quality and weight with lighter types selling to 294c, while heifers above 280kg returning to grass sold to 264c, to average 253c/kg. Heifers to feed sold to 273c, to average 264c/kg.

Bullocks were well supplied with quality also improving, with values firm on last sale, topping at 278c/kg to slaughter.  Heavy grown steers returning to grass sold to 285c, with medium weight grown steers selling to 252c/kg. A large mixed quality offering of cows saw values ease 10c to 12c/kg on last sale with heavier cows most affected. A reduced number of C muscled, heavy 3 score cows to slaughter sold to 230c, while D muscled 3 score cows sold to 215c, to average 204c/kg. Heavy 2 score cows topped at 213c, with a large run of D muscled 2 score cows averaging 196c/kg. Lighter 1 score cows returning to the paddock sold to 221c to average 205c/kg. A good selection of heavy bulls sold lower with the absence of live export, with best heavy bulls to slaughter topping at 254c, while bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 245c/kg. Young males to restockers sold to 348c/kg. A good offering of cows and calves sold to $1,450/unit.

Numbers for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents fell by 842 head to 967 this week, featuring an outstanding consignment of prime cows and vealer steers, supported by several small lines of mixed quality cattle. Prices for heavy cows improved by up to 20c/kg, with only one major processor absent this week, improving competition throughout the offering. Two live exporters were also present, along with one regular feeder buyer and several restockers. Cattle were drawn from Richmond, Einasleigh, Forsayth, Greenvale, Homestead, Ayr, Mt Coolon, local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers mostly consisted of smaller mixed quality lines, topping at 254c and averaging 248c/kg. One line of outstanding heavy vealer steers returning to grass sold for 248c/kg. There were too few yearling steers to quote. Vealer heifers were of plainer quality and weight to last sale and generally sold easier, topping at 200c for an isolated heifer, with most sales between 160c and 175c/kg. The quality of yearling heifers was very mixed, with better quality types returning to paddock selling to 190c, and most sales between 166c and 174c/kg. Heifers up to 400kg to slaughter sold to 217c, to average 183c/kg.

A small number of heavy bullocks generally sold to live export, topping at 232c, while grown steers sold to 239c/kg. A few heavy grown steers to slaughter sold to 241c, while plainer steers and bullocks to feed sold to 220c/kg. An outstanding offering of heavy cows sold to dearer trends, by up to 6c higher on last sale, with extra heavy 4 score cows topping at 191c and 3 score cows to 190c, improving 19c to average 183c/kg. Heavy 2 score cows sold to 168c to average 157c, while medium weight 3 score cows sold to 161c/kg. Medium and light weight cows to restockers eased by more than 20c, topping at 108c/kg, with quality a significant factor. Heavy bulls to live export, continued recent strong trends, topping at 270c, with most sales above 262c, and similar bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 268c, to average 261c/kg. Lighter males to restockers sold to 220c to average 190c, with the odd line to feed selling to 226c/kg. A larger offering of cows and calves sold to $1,090/unit.

Numbers fell to 1449 cattle 618 fewer than last sale.  Only 558 prime cattle were penned with quality and condition not up to the standard of the last few months, and there were no large lines of note.  Only three processors operated along with opportunity feeders, backgrounders and restockers. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Burketown, Prairie, Townsville, local and coastal areas.

Buyers were selective for the better quality pens with the lesser quality cattle and light heifers meting subdued demand. Yearling steers and heifers were mostly firm for better quality pens, grown steers eased 2-4c, bullocks fell 30c, heavy cows lifted 13c and heavy bulls averaged 20c lower.

Light yearling steers to restockers averaged 224c selling to 256c and steers above 330kg to feed sold to 250c to average 244c/kg. A good sample of heavy steers above 400kg to feed reached 250c to average 235c/kg. Light yearling heifers returning to the paddock sold to 234c to average 183c/kg.

Grown steers above 400kg to feed destined for live export sold to 266c to average 236c, processor types reached 220c/kg. Fewer grown heifers to feed reached 262c to average 236c/kg. 

A very small sample of heavy bullocks to export slaughter sold to and averaged 238c/kg. Light cows to restockers reached 168c to average 157c/kg. A reduced supply 3 score cows to processors topped at 207 to average 190c. Heavy bulls to feed destined for live export reached 240c averaging 230c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

Numbers fell by more than 300 for a yarding of 1,697 cattle for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, with some very good quality prime cows and bullocks the feature of the yarding.  All major processors were in attendance and operating, accompanied by two live exporters and regular feeder buyers and restockers.  With a major rain event forecast, bullocks and cows increased 5c to 8c, with light steers increasing by up to 20c/kg. Cattle were drawn from Croyden, Mt Surprise, Georgetown, Richmond, Bowen, local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers were in strong demand selling higher on last sale, returning to grass for a top of 386c and averaging 364c for lighter types, with heavier better conditioned lines topping at 361c/kg. Very few yearling steers were supplied, with heavier types to feed selling to 298c/kg. Vealer heifers were again well supplied, with better conditioned types to slaughter selling to 288c to average 282c/kg. A small number of yearling heifers of variable quality sold similar to last sale. Some very good bullocks sold higher on last sale, with heavy 3 score bullocks to slaughter topping at 285c, while bullocks for live export also sold to 285c, with most sales 277c to 282c/kg.

Several good lines of heavy 3 and 4 score cows sold higher on last sale. Heavy C3 score cows to slaughter sold to 234c, to average 221c, while D muscled cows sold to 227c, averaging 209c/kg. Heavy 2 score cows to slaughter sold to 231c to average 210c, with the odd pen of lighter cows returning to paddock selling to 178c/kg. A number of lesser quality cows less than 400kg sold to 165c/kg. Heavy bulls were again well supplied, selling similar to last week with those to live export topping at 284c, averaging 278c, while the few bulls to slaughter sold to 260c/kg. Young males less than 200kg returning to grass sold to 384c/kg. Some small lines of cows and calves sold to $1,340/unit.

Numbers fell by 932 head to 1,796 cattle for Charters Towers Combined Agents this week, with greater numbers of plainer and lighter cattle being presented, predominantly from northern areas.  Heavy bullocks and cows were firm on last sale while store steers and heifers eased across most categories. One regular processor was again absent this week, while a buyer for live export, regular feeder buyers and western restockers were all selectively active throughout the sale.  Cattle were drawn from Normanton, Chillagoe, Richmond, Einasleigh, Ingham, Rollingstone, Ayr, Woodstock, Balfes Creek, local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers again sold strongly this week, although quality was more variable the better quality lines sod to restockers to a top of 432.2c/kg.  One large line of yearling steers sold strongly to central restockers for a 368.2c/kg top. Steers to feed sold to 338.2c for a reduced average of 327.3c/kg. Vealer heifers were of more variable quality and sold to 365.2c/kg for light weigt heifers. Yearling heifers were fewer in number than recent weeks, with heifers selling to feed topping at 327.2c/kg.  Lighter heifers to restockers sold to 301.2c/kg.

A fewer number of well finished bullocks were on offer, with very well finished heavy 3 score bullocks to slaughter topping at 307.2c/kg. Heavy grown steers to feed sold to 341.2c/kg. Medium weight 2 score bullocks to restockers sold to 280.2c/kg.

Heavy 3 score cows again sold strongly to a top of 257.2c/kg, to average 251.7c/kg, with quality more variable and of generally lesser weight.  Heavy 2 score cows sold to 252.2c/kg for an average of 239.6c/kg, while medium and light 2 score cows were again in demand by restockers, selling to 240.2c/kg to average 234.2c/kg. Bulls again sold strongly due to the presence of a live export buyer, topping at 278.2c/kg. Heavy bulls to slaughter sold to 254.2c/kg, while medium weight bulls to feed, destined for live export sold to 243.2c/kg.  Young, light males to restockers sold to 364.2c/kg.

Cows and calves were of ore variable quality and size, selling to a top of $1200/unit, with most sales from $1000-$1160/unit.

Numbers fell by 880 for a yarding of 1148 cattle,  Quality was very mixed with fewer numbers of heavy prime bullocks and cows. Store cattle were generally plainer in condition, which also consisted of a large consignment of northern males.  Buyer attendance was limited to a couple of processors, two live exporters and opportunity feeders and restockers.  Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa to Hughenden, south to the Belyando, local and coastal areas.

Selective demand throughout the sale saw values ease in line with other selling centres, ranging from 20c to 40c in most categories, with secondary lines attracting limited competition.

Light vealer steers returning to grass sold to 196c, most sales from 160 to 188c/kg.  A limited supply of good quality heifers sold to 220c to average from 174c to 187c/kg.  An insufficient supply of yearling steers  and heifers were offered to reliably quote, but sold according to quality.  

A good sample of grown steers above 400kg to feed reached 202c to average 176c/kg, good quality heavy trade steers made to 240c to average 230c/kg. Good quality grown heifers to processors topped at 184c to average from 178c, heifers to feed reached 198c averaging from 172c to 190c/kg.

A mixed quality offering of full mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 240c to average 209c to 237c/kg. Medium weight 3 score cows to processors reached 190c to average 157 and prime heavyweight cows sold from 156c to 183c/kg.  Heavy bulls to live export reached 276c to average 262c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Numbers fell by 869 head to 1,883 cattle for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, which featured some very good quality lines of prime bullocks and cows, supported by some very good quality store steers and heifers. All processors were in attendance and operating, with prices at seasonal highs, in conjunction with two feeder buyers and several restockers. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Julia Creek, Prairie, Pentland, Greenvale, Ingham, Bowen, local and coastal areas.

A smaller offering of vealer steers were in strong demand, with lighter types selling to 368c, while steers 200-280kg sold to 366c, averaging up 11c to 344c/kg. Yearling steers generally sold to lower prices than previous week, with a greater proportion of light northern steers, prices eased by up to 40c/kg. Light yearling steers sold to 294c for those returning to grass, while steers to feed, destined for live export sold to 270c/kg. Heavy feeder yearlings to feeders sold to 286c for good quality crossbred types and 284c for steers returning to grass, averaging 271c/kg. Vealer heifer numbers increased and strong restocker bidding lifted prices to a top of 308c for light heifers, with 200-280kg heifers to feed selling to 304c, and one very good line of heavy vealers to feed selling to 290c/kg. Yearling heifers were of very good quality and displayed very good weight, with most to feeders selling to a top of 274c for 330-400kg heifers, averaging 269c, while lighter yearling heifers sold to 278c/kg. A small number of light yearling heifers returning to grass sold to 288c/kg. Bullock numbers lifted and sold strongly throughout, with numbers and quality much improved. Heavy 3 and 4 score bullocks to slaughter sold to 285c to average 281c, while medium weight bullocks to feed destined for live export sold to 265c, to average 256c/kg. Restockers were active on plainer types, securing lines to 259c, to average 248c/kg.

The cow offering was the best of the year for quality and weight, with prices firm on last sale, and heavy 3 score cows selling to 252c, to averaged 233c/kg. An unusually high number of 4 score cows sold to 242c, to average 239c/kg. Heavy 2 score cows sold to 210c and averaged 203c, while medium weight 2 score cows to slaughter sold to 210c, averaging 181c/kg. Plainer cows returning to grass sold to 222c, with most sales between 174c and 212c/kg. Some very good heavy bulls to slaughter sold to 271c, up 11c to average 253c, while bulls destined for live export sold to 273c, averaging 265c/kg. A single sale of one 870kg bull to be used for breeding sold for 301c/kg. Medium weight bulls to live export sold to 265c, while light males to restockers sold to 298c/kg. Some very good quality freshly weaned males sold to 340c/kg. Cows and calves sold to $1,390/unit.

Numbers fell by 788 for a yarding of 1050 cattle in a prime only sale.  Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa to Georgetown and south to the local area.  There were some good small lines of heavy cows and bullocks and bulls, however quality and weight was not as good as recent weeks.  All regular processors competed strongly for the better finished lines, while backgrounders and opportunity feeders were active on plainer lines.  Steers and bullocks sold firm to 6c higher, heavy cows lifted 12c to 15c and bulls averaged 11c better.

Heavy grown steers to processors topped at 408.2c, most sales from 396c to 400c and steers to feed sold to 414.2c to average 391c/kg.  A small sample of grown heifers to the trade reached 385c/kg.  Good quality heavy bullocks to export slaughter sold to 390.2c to average 366c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 370.2c to average 342c and 3 scores sold to 382.2c to average 353c/kg. A good sample of prime heavyweight cows topped at 372.2c to average 368c/kg. Cows to feed sold to 352.2c to average from 339c to 342c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors reached 356.2c to average 348c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Numbers fell by 774 head to 1,734 cattle for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, with numbers of prime cattle considerably lower than recent weeks, while a large run of northern store steers and heifers attracted strong buyer interest. One regular processor was again absent this week, while those attending operated with limited enthusiasm, mainly due to lower numbers of prime cattle. One feeder buyer and several restockers operated consistently throughout the store section on many good quality lines. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Richmond, Einasleigh, Ingham, Bowen, local and coastal areas.

The small number of vealer steers was keenly sought by restockers, selling to 360c/kg. A large line of yearling steers met strong competition from several restockers, with lighter pens selling to 346c, to average 326c/kg. Steers above 280kg sold to 286c, to average 274c/kg. Some good lines of vealer heifers were in demand, selling to 286c to average 282c/kg. A large line of yearling heifers met strong buyer interest, with increased rates influenced by quality, lighter types sold to 270c returning to grass, to average 264c/kg. Yearling heifers to feed sold to 263c/kg, averaging 260/kg. Bullocks were generally plainer in condition meeting limited processor demand, with one restocker very active throughout. Heavy 3 score bullocks to slaughter sold to 273c, while plainer types returning to grass sold to 265c, to average 260c/kg.

Limited numbers of prime cows sold up 6c on last sale, with heavy 3 score cows selling to 225c/kg to average 218c, while D3 cows topped at 218c, to average 212c/kg. Plainer 1 score cows to restockers sold to 194c, averaging 156c/kg. A large number of mixed quality bulls sold 12c lower on last sale with heavy bulls to slaughter topping at 245c/kg, while many lighter and plainer quality bulls to feed sold to 240c/kg. Young males to grass sold to 342c for an average of 335c/kg. Some good quality cows and calves sold to $1420/unit.

Numbers fell by 744 for a yarding of 3162 cattle. Quality was very good for the majority on offer comprising of large lines of well finished cows along with some high quality crossbred store lines. All processes were in attendance and operating, supported by regular feeders, one live exporter, central and western restockers. Cattle Were drawn from Mt Isa, Burketown, Normanton, Einasleigh, Hughenden, local and coastal areas.

Processor demand was firm throughout and good quality store lines were well supported, however lightweight and lesser quality lines attracted minimal support and were difficult to sell. Grown steers and bullocks lift7-20c, medium weight cows averaged firm to 5c higher and heavy bulls eased 18-25c/kg.

A large sample of young weaned crossbred steers above 200kg to backgrounders averaged 327c, selling to 356c, Brahman steers averaged 252c/kg. Good quality cross bred heifers returning to the paddock reached 220c/kg.. Light yearling steers to restockers sold to 260c to average 253c and steers above 330kg to grass averaged 258c/kg. Yearling steers from 280kg to 380kg to live export averaged 210c to 228c/kg. Yearling heifers above 200kg to restockers made to 198c to average 178c, heifers above 280 kg returning to the paddock averaged 213c and heifers to feed sold to 210c to average 201c/kg. Heifers above 330kg to the trade sold to 224c to average 193c to 215c/kg.

Fewer numbers of grown steers above 400kg to the trade reached 260c to average 236c/kg. Best quality grown heifers made to 220c to average 204c/kg. A small sample of young bullocks to processors sold to 242c, most selling from 210c to 230c/kg. Fewer numbers of grown cows met solid demand. Medium weight 3 score cows sold to 204c to average from 185c to 189c, prime heavyweight 4 score cows topped at 219c to average 215c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors sold to 222c to average 170c/kg.

A small number of cows and calves sold from $900 to $950/unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Numbers fell by 719 head to a yarding of 1,340 cattle for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, with a significant decrease in the number of cows on offer. The quality of the yarding was an improvement on the previous week's lighter cows and bulls, however prices for prime cattle eased in line with other selling centres. One of the major processors continued their absence and one southern processor has exited for the year, however all other processors were present and operating, supported by two feeder buyers and some central and northern restockers. Cattle were drawn from Cloncurry, Burketown, Croydon, Ingham, Woodstock, Pentland, local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers were in good supply in small consignments, with prices increasing on last sale, selling to a top of 412c, to average 390c/kg. Some very good lines of yearling steers sold strongly, with steers to feed selling for a top of 318c, to average 314c, while steers returning to the paddocks sold to 372c, for a 330c/kg average. Vealer heifers were predominantly one large line of northern cattle, which sold very strongly to central restockers to a top of 354c, to average 350c/kg. A very small offering of yearling heifers were presented, with the majority selling to feed for 290c/kg. Heifers to restockers sold to 336c/kg.

A reduction in the number of bullocks on offer also saw prices fall on previous sales, with 3 score bullocks to slaughter topping at 271c, to average 259c/kg. Restockers showed interest in lighter 2 score bullocks, returning to the paddock for a top of 242c/kg. Grown steers to feed sold to 322c, while steers to restockers sold to 257c/kg. Cow numbers more than halved for the smallest cow offering since the earliest sales of 2016, with the prices again lower than last sale. Heavy 3 score cows to slaughter sold to 234c for a lower average of 215c, while heavy 2 score cows sold to 238c, also averaging lower at 200c/kg. Light and medium 1 and 2 score cows to restockers, sold to a top of 219c/kg. Very few heavy bulls were on offer, with heavy 3 score bulls to slaughter topping at 220c/kg. Medium weight bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 314c/kg. A small number of cows and calves sold to $1,500/unit.

Numbers fell by 676 to pen 1584 head for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, comprised of some well finished cows, some poorer quality light cows and some good heavy bulls.  Heavy cows sold 4c to 8c lower on last sale and light cows to 30c lower, influenced by quality. Bulls sold similar to last sale. Two regular processors were absent this week, impacting on slaughter cattle prices, while regular restocker and feeder buyers were in attendance and operating.  Cattle were drawn from Cloncurry, Richmond, Pentland, Georgetown, Greenvale, Ingham, Guru, Ravenswood, Belyando as well as local and coastal areas.

Light vealer steers sold stronger on last sale owing to a western restocker, topping at 338c, with most sales from 314c to 325c/kg.  Yearling steers were of similar numbers to last sale; however quality was variable, averaging similar for better types at 274c, with lower quality types averaging 240c/kg. Vealer heifers were again represented by some well finished slaughter types selling to 290c, while lighter vealers returning to paddock sold to 324c, averaging 300c/kg.  Yearling heifers were of variable quality, with 280 to 360kg heifers to feed selling to 266c, averaging 264c/kg and heifers returning to paddock selling to 276c, to average 20c lower at 251c/kg.

Heavy well finished 3 score bullocks to slaughter sold 3c to 4c lower on last sale, topping at 270c, to average 259c/kg. This was in combination with a reduced number on offer, due to a recent live export order attracting many similar weight cattle.  2 score bullocks from 380 to 450kg sold to 249c and heavy grown steers returned to paddock sold to 300c/kg. A good offering of heavy 3 and 4 score cows sold 4c to 8c lower on last sale, topping at 235c, for an average of 219c, while 2 score cows above 400kg topped at 219c, to average 203c/kg. Heavy D muscled cows sold 12c to 15c lower on last sale, mainly influenced by quality.  Light cows returning to paddock, were average quality, selling to 163c, averaging 30c lower at 127c/kg Heavy bulls again sold strongly to 307c for select lines, with many selling to 279c for backgrounding to live export, averaging 263c/kg. A small number of cows and calves were of variable quality, selling to $1160/unit.

Numbers fell by 640 head for a yarding of 1477 cattle.  Quality was once again mixed, however there were some good lines of heavy cows and bulls and increased numbers of feeder steers, supported by a good line of northern yearling steers. The regular buyer panel was in attendance and operating, supported by two live exporters.  Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Croydon, Richmond, east to local and coastal areas. 

Increased competition saw grown steers firm to 8c higher, prime cows averaged 2c better and bulls improved by 7c/kg.

A good selection of suitably weaned steers returning to the paddock sold to 340c to average 337c/kg. Young heifers below 200kg reached 220c for those returning to the paddock and 204c for a small sample to the trade. Yearling steers above 200kg to restockers averaged 298c selling to 302c and steers above 330kg to live export topped at 260c to average 254c/kg. A small number of yearling heifers to the trade reached 199c to average 185c/kg.

An increased number of grown steers met good competition. Steers above 400kg suitable for live export reached 256c to average 243c and steers to feed sold to 244c to average 231c/kg. There were insufficient heavy bullocks to reliably quote.  Medium weight 2 score cows sold to 199 to average 191c and 3 score cows reached 201c to average 191c/kg. A small selection of prime heavyweight cows sold to 214c to average 196c/kg. Good quality heavy bulls to live export sold to 258c to average 245c feeder types sold to 260c to average 247c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Numbers fell by 576 to 2,170 head for Charter Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, with some good lines of prime cows and bulls continuing on trends of recent weeks. Some large lines of northern store cattle were also present, attracting restocker interest, however buyer competition was more selective. One regular processor was again absent this week, with all others operating along with feeder buyers and restockers. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Burketown, Chillagoe, Einasleigh, Tully, Ingham, Woodstock, Bowen, local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers increased in number and some good quality small lines sold strongly to restockers for a top of 401c/kg. Yearling steers were more limited in number and quality, with some northern lines actively sought by restockers, selling to a top of 374c, while feeder steers sold to 338c, to average 319c/kg. An increased number of grown steers were on offer, with steers to feed selling to 327c/kg. Vealer heifers were made up of predominantly good quality small lines selling strongly to 354c for slaughter, while heifers to restockers made to 348c/kg. Yearling heifers were dominated by one northern line meeting strong restocker demand, with heifers returning to the paddock topping at 342c/kg. A small number of yearling heifers to feed sold to 338c, while grown heifers to feed sold to 320c, for an average of 309c/kg.

Bullocks were fewer in number, with restockers particularly active on lighter weight types, with heavy bullocks to slaughter selling in line with southern markets. Heavy 3 score bullocks sold to 290c, while 2 score bullocks to restockers sold to 261c/kg. Some good lines of heavy cows sold strongly, although in line with the downward trend in southern sales. Heavy 3 score cows to slaughter sold to 262c to average 239c, while heavy 2 score cows to slaughter sold to 244c for an average of 223c/kg. Good numbers of 2 score medium weight cows to restockers sold to 238c/kg. A small number of cows and calves were on offer selling to $1,160/unit.

Numbers fell by 55 head to 1,815 cattle for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, with an improved supply of well finished heavy cows and bullocks and some large lines of northern store cows. One regular processor continued their absence, while all other processors were in attendance and active throughout along with regular feeder buyers, restockers and one live exporter. Cattle were drawn from Burketown, Cloncurry, Einasleigh, Forsayth, Ingham, Bowen, Woodstock, Belyando, local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers were again presented in small numbers, with solid demand from restockers topping at 374c/kg. Yearling steers of mixed supply and quality sold similar to last sale, topping at 334c for those returning to grass, while steers to feed sold to 278c, to average 268c/kg. One live exporter operated selectively on suitable weights to 299c/kg. There was a smaller number of vealer heifers of mixed quality and weight, which sold higher to 340c/kg, returning to grass. Yearling heifers sold stronger across all weight classes for the fewer on offer, topping at 270c to feed to average 265c, while heifers returning to grass sold to 274c, to average 260c/kg. Some well finished heavy 3 and 4 score bullocks sold to an easier trend, selling to 261c/kg to slaughter, while 2 score types to feed, destined for live export sold to 256c to average 252c/kg.

An increase in the number of grown steers to feed sold to 271c, to average 260c/kg. An increased supply and improvement in quality of heavy 3 and 4 score cows saw prices lift by 3c to 5c, while heavy C muscled cows to slaughter sold to 239c for an increased average of 220c/kg. Heavy D muscled cows sold to 218c, to average 210c/kg. Heavy 2 score cows to slaughter sold to 239c, for an improved average of 220c/kg. Several restockers were active on lighter types, lifting prices by up to 20c for better types, with medium weight 2 score cows returning to grass, selling to 230c to average 204c/kg. Lighter 2 score cows sold to 213c, averaging 185c/kg. 1 score cows in light condition sold to 195c to average 162c/kg. Heavy bulls lifted in value on last sale, with bulls to slaughter selling to 265c, while heavy bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 266c, to average 260c/kg. Young bulls 280-380kg, returning to paddocks sold to 346c/kg. Light males returning to grass sold to 348c/kg. Cows and calves sold from $1180 to $1300/unit.

Numbers fell by 545 head to 1,758 cattle for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, with most categories firm to dearer for the better quality lines. One regular processor continued their absence, however all others operated consistently throughout the offering, accompanied by three live exporters, two feeder buyers and several opportunity restockers. Increased numbers of northern cows and store steers reflected the developing dry season, however most lines displayed good condition and weight. Cattle were drawn from Burketown, Cohen, Mt Surprise, Tully, Richmond, Pentland, Ayr, Ravenswood, local and coastal areas.

An increased offering of steer calves sold strongly, particularly better quality, with lighter weight calves selling to 278c to average 262c/kg. Light male calves to restockers sold to 257c/kg. Better quality vealer steers above 200kg returning to grass sold to 266c, to average 260c/kg. Yearling steers met increased competition from live exporters, with suitable types to live export lifting 20c to average 270c, with a top of 274c/kg. Lighter yearling steers returning to grass sold to 270c to average 260c/kg. Stronger demand for heifer calves saw prices increase by more than 15c on recent weeks, selling to a top of 228c, with most sales from 204c to 220c/kg for better quality lines. Vealer heifers returning to grass improved significantly for light weights, topping at 222c to average 215c/kg. Heifers above 200kg to grass sold to 204c, easing 4c to average 200c/kg. Yearling heifers comprised of several small lines of very mixed quality types. Heifers suitable for live export from 280-330kg sold to 225c, while heifers above 330kg sold to 232c to average 221c/kg. Yearling heifers to feed sold to 220c to average 212c/kg.

A smaller, mixed quality offering of bullocks and grown steers met mixed demand, with a single heavy bullock selling for 261c/kg. Most bullocks to slaughter sold from 244c to 255c, while a small number to the live export market sold for 222c/kg. Heavy grown steers to slaughter sold to 256c, to average 255c/kg. A few to live export sold to 243c/kg. The supply of cows began to show the effects of the season, with most lines showing variation in condition and weight. Similar numbers of heavy 3 score cows to previous weeks' sold firm to 211c, to average 196c and some 4 score cows sold to 220c/kg. Heavy D3 cows also sold firm to average 185c, with a top of 191c, while medium weight D3 cows to slaughter sold to 179c/kg. Larger numbers of heavy 2 score cows sold to 186c, improving 7c to average 179c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows sold to 177c, improving 5c to average 160c/kg. Lighter cows to restockers improved 27c, topping at 164c to average 145c/kg. Increased numbers of heavy bulls met very strong live export demand, dominating the offering, with most selling from 261c to 268c, an increase of up to 14c/kg on last sale. Several small consignments of cows and calves met improved demand, selling from $760 to $940/unit.

Numbers fell by 507 for a yarding of 2065 cattle.  Quality was very mixed, with fewer numbers of prime cows and steers, while the store cattle comprised of many smaller lines of variable quality. All regular processors returned to the buyer panel, supported by regular feeders, one live exporter and opportunity restockers, all operating at easier rates. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Normanton, Einasleigh, Richmond, Hughenden, local and coastal areas.

Yearling steers averaged 25c lower, yearling heifers 6c easier,  grown steers were mostly firm, prime cows eased 5c and bulls were firm.

Good quality freshly weaned steers above 200kg returning to the paddock sold to 360c to average 316c, similar heifers to grass reached 232c to average 225c/kg. A good sample of yearling steers above 280kg to feed topped at 352c to average 317c and good quality yearling heifers to feed topped at 240c to average 224c/kg.

Grown steers to feed averaged 259c to 271c topping at 280c, the odd pen to processors reached 249c/kg. Grown heifers to the trade sold to 240c to average 232c and feeders made to 246c to average 231c/kg. 

A reduced supply of heavy bullocks to export slaughter topped at 274c to average 258c/kg. A good sample of medium weight 3 score cows sold to 195c to average 177c to 189c/kg. A small sample of prime heavyweight cows topped at 199c to average same. Heavy bulls to live export reached 270c to average 264c and bulls to processors sold to 254c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Numbers fell by 467 head to 1,346 cattle for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, led by a significant decrease in the number of cows. One processor was again absent, with all others operating on reduced rates in line with recent grid adjustments. One regular feeder and several restockers operated selectively, with strong competition for young males and better quality young heifers. Cattle were drawn from Burketown, Chillagoe, Julia Creek, Prairie, Pentland, Ingham, Ayr, Ravenswood, Belyando, local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers were of mixed quality, with some very good lines of heavier, well conditioned types selling to 311c, while lighter types sold to 354c/kg.  Yearling steers were of mixed quality and showing seasonal effects, with selective demand for the variable quality on offer. Feeder types lifted 3c on last sale to 276c, averaging 273c and similar weight returning to grass sold to 289c/kg. Lighter weight yearling steers returning to grass sold to 294c/kg. An increased offering of grown steers, sold to 264c for those returning to grass, while heavy steers to feed sold to 280c/kg. Vealer heifers were in strong demand with some very good quality small lines selling to 301c/kg, to restockers. Yearling heifers of variable quality and offered in many small lines sold to 254c for those returning to grass, while heifers to feed sold to 264c to average 259c/kg.

A large reduction in the number of cows on offer, saw values fall in line with recent grid adjustments, with good well finished heavy cows falling up to 15c to top at 216c to average 205c/kg. Heavy D muscled 3 score cows sold to 205c to average down 21c to 189c, while heavy 2 score D muscled cows averaged 19c lower at 186c/kg. Bulls were of mixed type and weight, with very good heavy bulls to slaughter selling to 223c, while medium and heavy bulls to feed sold to 230c/kg. A large line of young, light northern males met very strong restocker demand, selling to 342c to average 331c/kg. A small offering of cows and calves sold to $1,100/unit.

Numbers fell by 435 head, for a yarding of 1,453 cattle by Charters Towers Combined Agents, with a large number of well finished cows featuring in the prime section and one feature line of vealer store heifers.  All major processors were in attendance and operating, with a new southern processor active on lighter slaughter types. Cattle were drawn from Burketown, Georgetown, Richmond, Ingham, Woodstock, Bowen, Pentland, local and coastal areas. 

Vealer heifers sold very strongly, featured by a very good line of future breeders that sold for 295.2c/kg.  Other smaller lines sold to 265c/kg.  Vealer steers were also well supported and sold to 309.2c, with many small lines selling to 285.2c/kg. Yearling steers were in short supply, selling to 284.2c, while a smaller number of yearling heifers varied in quality and sold to 280.2c/kg.  Prime heifers to slaughter topped at 243.2c, with lighter heifers to restockers selling to 221.2c/kg.

Fewer bullocks were presented this week and the mixed quality offering sold comparable to last sale with the top line selling to 260.2c/kg. The large yarding of well finished cows was dominated by two large consignments, with values increasing slightly on last sale.  Heavy 3 score cows sold to 216.2c, averaging 204.6c, while lighter 2 score cows sold to 198.2c, with an increased average of 186.7c/kg.
Reduced numbers of plainer bulls sold to 224.2c for heavier slaughter types, feeder bulls destined for live export sold to 236.2c, while lighter young bulls topped at 300c/kg to a restocker for breeding purposes.

A small number of cows & calves sold to $1,000/unit.

Numbers fell by 225 for a yarding of 821 cattle. Quality was mostly good, with a much smaller offering of prime cattle, while store cattle featured a large line of northern feeder heifers. Buyer attendance was limited to a couple of regular processors and feeders, while there was additional restocker demand. Cattle were mostly drawn from north of Mt Isa and the local area.

Values continued the recent downward trend with limited demand due to a smaller yarding.

Light steers returning to the paddock sold to 252c to average from 195c to 213c/kg. A small number of yearling steers above 280kg to restockers averaged 209c/kg. A line of yearling heifers above 200kg to restockers reached 156c to average 132c/kg. Heifers above 280kg to feed made to 156c to average 153c/kg.

A limited number of grown steers to live export sold to 164c to average 153c/kg, an equally small number of processor types averaged 154c/kg. A small mixed quality sample of bullocks sold to 152c to average 130c to 150c/kg. A limited supply of medium weight 3 score cows to processors topped at 154c to average 151c/kg. A small number of heavy bulls to processors sold to 158c to average 126c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Numbers fell by 1276 for a yarding of 1971 cattle.  The supply of prime cattle fell by half in a very mixed quality yarding. All regular processors were in attendance and operating, however feeder and restockers attendance was subdued.  Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa to Ingham and south tho the Burdekin and local area.

Most categories struggled to maintain values of the previous week, particularly in the store section.  Good quality lines met firm competition, however secondary and plainer conditioned types attracted minimal buyer support with some individual animals failing to sell. Grown steers and heifers to processors eased 4c to 30c, bullocks fell 20c to 25c, medium cows averaged 7c to 10c lower and heavy bulls sold 40c to 55c lower.

Young, weaned cross bred steers to restockers topped at 334c, a good sample averaging 313c, with similar heifers returning to the paddock reaching 260c to average 231c/kg. Light yearling steers to restockers made to 266c to average 248c and steers above 280kg to the paddock sold to and averaged 230c/kg. Yearling steers above 330 kg to feed sold to 250c and steers above 400kg made 247c/kg. Light yearling heifers to restockers reached 200c to average 149c/kg. Very good quality heifers above 280kg for breeding topped at 242c to average 229c/kg.

Grown steers above 400kg to feed averaged 231c selling to 250c with similar trade types averaging 221c to 229c /kg. Heavy grown steers to processors reached 246c to average 241c/kg. Good quality grown heifers to the trade sold to 258c to average from 226c to 249c/kg.  PTiC heifers made 244c/kg.

Heavy bullocks to export slaughter topped at 258c to average 245c to 250c/kg. Medium weight three score cows sold to 240c to average from 219c to 236c and a good selection of prime heavyweight cows topped at 245c to average 240c to 243c/kg.  Heavy bulls to processors reached 230c to average 216c and bulls to feed destined for live export made to 240c, most averaging 195c to 218c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Numbers fell by 127 head to 1,360 cattle for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, featured by some good small lines of prime cows and store steers, in conjunction with some northern cattle. One major processor was again absent, while those present operated on lower rates with limited interest throughout, while on regular feeder buyer, two live exporters and restockers rounded out a larger buyer gallery. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Cloncurry, Ingham, Townsville, Woodstock, local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers met strong competition reaching 351c, averaging 10c lower at 343c/kg. Yearling steers were of mixed quality selling similar to last sale, with live exporters securing steers averaging 278c, with grown steers selling to 272c/kg. Light yearling steers returning to grass sold to 322c to average 304c/kg. Vealer heifers were well supplied with some small well finished heifers to slaughter selling to 270c, with those returning to grass selling to 278c, easing 5c to average 256c/kg. Yearling heifers were also of mixed quality selling lower across all categories. Heifers returning to grass sold to 258c, while heifers to feed sold to 255c, averaging 247c/kg. Grown heifers to slaughter sold to 230c/kg.

Small lines of bullocks to slaughter sold to 240c/kg, with variable quality on offer. Heavy steers and bullocks above 400kg to live export sold to 245c, averaging 243c/kg. Good quality heavy prime 3 and 4 score cows above 480kg to slaughter lifted 3c to 210c, averaging 205c, while 3 score cows above 400kg averaged 197c/kg. Heavy D muscled cows to slaughter sold to 197c to average 187c, while those returning to grass sold to 187c/kg with a lower average, mainly influenced by quality. Heavy bulls were of mixed quality, with competition from live exporters increasing values to 248c for heavy bulls, medium weights sold to 282c and the few to slaughter topped at 240c/kg. Bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 282c for medium weights and 249c/kg for heavy bulls. Young males sold to 324c/kg. A limited number of cows and calves sold to $1,240/unit.

Numbers fell by 1110 for a yarding of 1795 cattle. The number of prime cattle increased, with improved quality and many presenting with more weight than recent weeks.  An increased processor attendance lifted demand for all categories, with prices improving throughout.  Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa to Croydon, Georgetown, east to Ingham and south to the local area.

The improved demand resulted in grown steers and bullocks improving 35c, heavy cows lifted 40c and bulls averaged 12c better.

Light steers to restockers averaged 312c selling to 326c and similar heifers sold to and averaged 230c/kg. Yearling steers above 330kg to feed sold to 304c to average 266c those to the paddock averaged 284c/kg. Yearling heifers below 280kg returning to the paddock sold to 234c to average 225c/kg. A good sample.of yearling heifers above 280kg to feed made to 256c to average 249c/kg. Heavy grown steers to the trade topped at an isolated 268c to average 258c and steers to feed topped at 292c to average 268c/kg.  Good quality grown heifers to the trade sold to 246c to average 234c/kg.

Heavy full mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 284c to average from 255c to 278c/kg.
Medium weight 2 score cows sold to an improved 236c to average 218c to 234c, 3 and 4 scores reached 236c to average 226c/kg.
A good sample of prime heavyweight cows topped at 238c to average 231c/kg.

Heavy bulls to processors sold to 270c  average 251c and bulls to feed destined for live export made to 254c to average 244c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Numbers fell by 1024 head for a yarding of 1563 mixed quality cattle in Charters Towers.  Almost two thirds of the yarding consisted of prime cattle, with some very good lines of prime cows and bullocks penned, supported by some good lines of young store steers.  One major processor was absent,  but one new accompanied the regular panel of buyers.  Competition was strong throughout, with cattle drawn from Hughenden, Pentland, Home Hill, local and coastal areas.  Vealer steers and heifers sold firm, yearling heifers to feed eased 10c and prime averaged 7c/kg lower.

Light steer calves to restockers sold to a top of 460.2c to average 461c, while heifers calves to processors reached 428c/kg.  Light vealer steeers returning to the paddock topped at 496.2c to average 470c, with those above 280kg to feed averaging 442c/kg.  Vealer heifers to processors topped at 430.2c to average 422c and heifers to backgrounders averaged 386c/kg.  There were insufficient yearling steers to quote, while yearling heifers above 330kg to feed sold to 358.2c to0 average 342c/kg.  

Grown steers to feed reached 338.2c to average 324-332c and a small sample of grown heifers to feed averaged 309c/kg.  Heavy bullocks to export laughter topped at 326.2c with most selling around 310c/kg.  Medium weight 2 score cows to processors topped at 255.2c to average 244c and 3 score cows made to 272.2c multiple times to average near 258c/kg.  A good sample of cows to restockers sold to 257.2c to average from 249-257c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export sold to 346.2c/kg.

Numbers eased to 1,161 cattle in a prime only sale following widespread scattered rain across the northern region. Quality was mixed with some good single vendor lines of heavy cows a large consignment of light northern cows and increased number of heavy bulls.  All regular processors operated and stronger rates, supported by one southern processor, one live exporter, regular feeders and opportunity restockers. Cattle were drawn from Burketown, Normanton, Richmond, Greenvale, local and coastal areas. Most categories continued recent upwards price movements, particularly on better quality lines, however grown steers to feed met limited demand. Grown steers were firm to 39c easier, trade heifers improved 11c, heavy bullocks lifted 6c to 15c, heavy cows averaged 6c to 18c better and bulls to live export and processors improved 7-14c/kg.

A good quality sample of yearling heifers above 280kg to feed sold to 408.2c to average 406c with lesser quality types averaging 360c/kg. Grown steers above 400kg to feed averaged 368c to 378c selling to a top of 386.2c, while a small sample of heavy steers to the trade topped at 388.2c to average 368c to 385c/kg. A small sample of grown heifers to the trade sold to 364.2c to average 361c/kg. A mixed offering of heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter sold to 394.2c to average 367c to 390c/kg. 

Processor demand increased for the mixed offering of cows.  Medium weight two score cows to processors sold to 334.2c to average 330c, three score cows to processors sold to 354.2c to average from 330c to 335c, while prime heavy weight cows topped at 340.2c to average 332c/kg.  Increased demand for heavy bulls by one live exporter and processors once again improved averages for the quality penned.  A large sample of heavy bulls to live export sold to 374.2c to average 354c, while processors were active on suitable bulls from 320c to 362c/kg.

A store sale scheduled for Friday has 3,000 head booked.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Numbers eased slightly as the supply area remains dry and producers are left with little option but to continue destocking. Quality was not to the standard of recent weeks with a greater number of plainer cattle coming forward. Cattle were mainly drawn from the local area with a few large lines included in the offering.  As with some other markets, prices were not able to maintain recent high rates with falls of 10c to 15c/kg recorded in some instances. 

A large number of medium weight C3 steers averaged 173c after selling to 194.2c/kg. Heavy steers averaged 188.3c, as all the bullocks returned over $1,100/head after topping at 190.2c/kg. Good quality grown heifers were in limited numbers as light C3s averaged 156.2c/kg.

In the cow penning, the lightweights were the least effected by the falling market, easing 2c to 3c/kg. Light D2s averaged 124.6c, while D3s averaged 141.4c after selling to 151.2c/kg. Large numbers of medium weight D3s almost averaged 150c as good C3s reached 169.2c/kg. Heavy cows averaged mostly around 164.6c/kg. Bulls suffered a similar fate to the other grades to be cheaper, as heavy weights sold to 169.2c/kg.

Numbers eased slightly and values were considerably dearer. Quality was slightly better than previous weeks however the majority of the yarding was made of cows. The steers improved 5c to 7c while the heifers were only slightly cheaper. The cows mostly gained from 9c to 14c/kg.

Light steers sold to 123.2c and averaged just under 118c/kg. The medium weight steers sold to 140c and most averaged 134c/kg. A small of number heavy steers topped at 142.2c and averaged 138.7c/kg. 

Heifers sold to 139.2c and the better grades averaged 129.4c while the D2s averaged 106.5c/kg. Light cows sold to 118.2c and a large number averaged 103.9c/kg. There was 400 medium weight cows topped at 126.2c and over 300 D3s averaged 123.5c/kg.

Heavy bulls sold to 147.2c/kg and returned up to $1,049/head.

Numbers eased in a prime only sale by 448 head to 1,572 cattle this week. Quality was very mixed with many poor quality lines on offer. Some very good quality lines of heavy prime cows were penned including one line of grainfed cows along with increased numbers of heavy bulls. All regular processors, feeders and two live exporters were present and operating at values relative to quality. Heavy cows increased 2c while bulls to live export lifted 10c/kg. Cattle were drawn Doomadgee, The Cape, Richmond, Einasleigh, Townsville, Bowen, local and coastal areas. 

Yearling steers above 330kg to backgrounders sold to 426c to average 417c/kg. Yearling heifers above 330kg to feed sold to 388c to average 346c/kg. Grown steers to live export topped at 392c to average from 373c to 386c, while heavy trade types reached 398c/kg to average the same. A good sample of suitable heavy steers to feed sold to a top of 408c to average 394c/kg. Good quality grown heifers to the trade topped at 360c to average 318c and heifers to feed made to 360c multiple times, to average 316c/kg.   

Heavy bullocks suitable for live export sold to 392c to average 386c and full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter reached 380c, averaging near 364c/kg. Very strong demand for cows continued with all processors very active throughout the offering. Medium weight 2 score cows sold to a top of 314c to average 295c, while score 3 cows reached 320c to average 310c/kg. Prime heavy weight cows topped at 324c to average 319c/kg. A line of grainfed cows to processors topped at 328c, to average 314c/kg. Light cows to feed sold to 294, while medium weight cows averaged from 291c to 294c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export sold to a top of 384c while similar bulls to feed destined for live export averaged 306c to 332c/kg. 
A scheduled store sale for Friday has 4,000 cattle booked. 

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

Numbers eased by nearly 300 head in very hot conditions for a yarding of 2704 cattle.  Quality was mixed, comprising of fewer prime cows, however some good well finished bullocks were penned, supported by some very good quality store steers and heifers. All regular processors were in attendance and operating, supported by two live exporters, regular feeders and some western restockers. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Croydon, Torrens Ck, Hervey’s Range, local and coastal areas.

Buyer demand was good for the majority penned, with improved overall quality a factor. Price for light steers and heifers improved 18c to 25c, medium feeder steers and heifers slipped 16c/kg. Strong demand for heavy well finished cattle saw values improve by 6c to 25c/kg, secondary lines were firm to 8c easier.

Young steers above 200kg returning to grass averaged 254c to 277c, selling to 286c, similar heifers to grass reached 290c to average 236c/kg. Yearling steers above 200kg to backgrounders sold to 290c, averaging 271c to 286c/kg. Yearling steers to live export above 280kg sold to 310c to average near 277c, while steers above 400kg also made to 310c to average 298c/kg. A small sample of yearling heifers returning to the paddock averaged 247c and heifers above 280kg averaged 263c/kg. Yearling heifers above 280kg to the trade sold to 258c, heifers above 330kg to feed averaged 261c to 266c/kg. Grown steers above 400kg to the trade sold to 318c averaging 294c to 305c, those suitable to live export averaged 271c/kg. Heavy grown steers above 500kg sold to 334c to average 324c/kg.  Grown heifers to the trade made to 264c a good sample averaging 262c, feeder heifers averaged 258c to 274c/kg.

Heavy full mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 334c to average 314c to 328c/kg. A reduced supply of cows sold to firm demand.  Lightweight cows to processors made to 238c to average 216c, medium weight 3 scores topped at 282c to average 261c/kg. Medium and heavy weight bulls to live export sold to 306c to average 278c to 299c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors reached 306c, averaging 285c to 300c/kg.

A good supply of cows and calves sold to strong demand topping at $1,275 per unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Numbers eased by more than 500 cattle, for a yarding of 727 in Charters Towers this week, with cows making up greater than 60% of the total.  Most lines generally lacked weight and condition of previous week's, however values improved across most categories in line with southern markets. All regular processors operated at increased rates, supported by one live exporter and opportunity restockers and backgrounders. Cattle were drawn from as far north as Burketown and Croydon and south to the local area.

Reduced numbers of store steers and heifers sold in line with quality, while yearling steers and heifers to the trade increased by more than 20c/kg. Heavy bullocks and cows to export slaughter improved by 12c to 14c, medium weight cows eased 10c/kg and heavy bulls sold firm on last sale.

Limited numbers of vealer steers to restockers sold to 303c to average 290c and very good quality vealer heifers returning to grass made to 220c to average 203c/kg. Light and medium weight steers to live export sold from 259c to 277c to average 274c/kg. Medium weight yearling steers to restockers sold to 270c to average 253c and heavier finished lines to the trade sold to 331c to average 328c/kg. Heavy yearling heifers to the trade topped at 297c and heavy grown heifers sold to 300c to average 276c/kg.

Good quality heavy bullocks to export slaughter were in limited numbers, topping at 336c to average 327c and plainer, lower yielding types sold to 312c to average 302c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows to slaughter sold to 199c to average 154c/kg. Heavy 3 score cows sold to 250c to average 246c and extra heavy weights made 250c/kg. Light cows to restockers lifted 10c, topping at 150c to average 133c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors sold to 319c, multiple times, with most sales above 290, with medium weight lines to live export selling to 276c to average 275c/kg. Young males to backgrounders sold to 282c to average 269c/kg.

Numbers eased by 742 head to 2,670 mixed quality cattle in Charters Towers in a yarding of predominantly prime cattle. More than 3,700 are booked for a Store Sale this Friday. An increased supply of quality heavy export bullocks and well finished heifers were supported by many mixed lines of cows, generally lacking quality of recent weeks. All regular processors operated with the continued presence of southern orders, along with two live exporters and regular feeder orders. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Julia Ck, Richmond, Einasleigh, Greenvale, Ingham, Ayr, local and coastal areas. Demand was strong throughout, particularly on better quality steers and heifers to feed and light conditioned cows, while bullocks to processors eased 5 to 7c and heavy cows eased 6c to 9c/kg.

A small offering of yearling steers and heifers sold in line with quality, although generally 10c to 15c/kg easier than last store sale. Yearling steers above 330kg to feed sold to 319c averaging 318c/kg. Yearling heifers above 330kg to feed sold to 320.2c to average 299c to 304c and heavy heifers above 400kg to feed sold to 320c to average 319c with trade types selling to 326c to average 318c/kg. Grown steers eased 9c to 11c with steers to live export making to 358.2c to average 318c to 324c, while well bred heavy steers to feed sold to 346.2c to average 328c/kg. Heavy grown heifers to feed ease 17c to average 261c and suitable pens to the trade improved 8c making to 324.2c, to average near 279c/kg.

Heavy bullocks to export processor topped at 340c, with a large sample averaging 333c, while medium weights averaged 301c to 321c/kg. Medium and light conditioned cows increased 4c to 7c, with medium weight 2 score cows to processors selling to 272.2c, to average 253c, while a large sample of lightweight 2 score cows averaged 235c/kg. Heavy 3 score cows sold to 298c to average from 263c to 271c, with some very good pens of prime heavy weight cows averaging 285c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export made to 320.2c to average from 303c to 317c, while heavy bulls to processors sold to 320.2c to average 274c to 303c/kg. Several small pens of cows and calves sold from $780 to 1,720/unit.

Numbers eased by 609 head to 2,568 cattle in Charters Towers comprising of very mixed quality cattle.
