Reduced numbers of heavy prime cows and bullocks sold to stronger rates, particularly for better quality lines. The regular buyer panel operated in conjunction with recent southern processor and feeder orders along with a few opportunity local and western restockers. Cattle were drawn from north of Mt Isa, Normanton, Georgetown, Mt Surprise, East Palmerston, Ingham, Ravenswood, local and coastal areas.

Light male calves sold to enthusiastic competition, reaching 412.2c for multiple pens, with heifers calves to processors reaching 338.2c/kg. Light vealer steers returning to grass sold to 362.2c, averaging from 344c to 351c/kg. A good quality line of vealer heifers to feed sold to 310.2c to average 299c and heifers to processors reached 338.2c to average 327c/kg. Reduced numbers of medium weight yearling steer to feed sold to 348.2c, averaging 337c and heavy yearling steer above 400kg to feed sold to 365.2c/kg to average the same. Well bred yearling heifers above 280kg to feed sold to 324.2c to average 310c, while a good sample of heifers above 330kg to feed sold to 318.2c to average from 299c to 308c/kg.

Increased numbers of grown steers to feed sold to 340.2c to average from 290c to 338c/kg. Heavy grown steers to processors sold to 343.2c to average 340c/kg. Grown heifers to feed sold to 305.2c, with most sales from 262c to 300c, with heifers to the trade making to 326c, averaging 252c to 322c/kg. Some good lines of heavy bullocks to export process sold to 343.2c to average 323c to 341c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows eased 1c to average 237c, topping at 254c, while heavy 3 score cows lifted 6c to 11c, topping at 280.2c to average above 271c/kg. Prime heavy weight 4 score cows topped at 294.2c to average 286c/kg. 

Heavy bulls to live export sold to 318c, averaging above 301c and heavy bulls to processors sold to 332.2c to average 270c to 307c/kg. A pen of Limousin cows and calves sold for $1,720, while other pens of Brahman cows and calves sold from $1,000 to 1,320/unit.

Numbers eased by 586 head to 1,982 mixed quality cattle in Charters Towers this week. Overall quality was not as good as recent weeks particularly in the offering of heavy prime cows and bullocks. The regular buyer panel again consisted of southern processor and feeder orders operating consistently throughout the sale. Demand for mixed sex calves and feeder cattle was very strong, particularly the better quality lines. Cattle were drawn from Croydon, Georgetown, Einasleigh, Innisfail, Ingham, Greenvale, local and coastal areas.

Some very good quality mixed sex calves sold for improved rates of up to 8c, reaching a top of 406c, with steers returning to the paddocks to average 390c/kg. Suitable mixed sex calves to processors sold to 396.2c to average 366c/kg. Limited numbers of vealer steers sold according to quality. Vealer heifers suitable for processors sold to 372.2c and averaged 327c, while a large sample to feed eased 10c to average 288c/kg. Yearling steers above 280kg to feed sold to 356.2c and averaged 352c and steers above 330kg to feed averaged 320c/kg. Yearling heifers to feed met strong demand increasing by 2c to 9c, selling to 310c to average from 286c to 301c/kg.

Heavy grown steers above 400kg topped at 356.2c, averaging from 331c to 348c, with a small number to processors selling to 315.2c/kg. Grown heifers were of very mixed quality and weight, with heifers to feed selling to 312c and processor pens made to 300c to average from 256c to 298c/kg. Heavy export bullocks were in limited supply, easing 4c to 11c, topping at 336.2c, to average from 323c to 326c/kg.

Light and medium weight 2 score cows met strong demand for the quality penned, averaging from 219c to 238c, selling to 253.2c/kg. Heavy 3 score cows sold to 288c to average 263c to 275c and prime heavy weight cows sold to 285c to average 280c/kg. Reduced live export buyer activity resulted in heavy bulls easing 6c to 10c/kg. Suitable live export bulls averaged 273c to 312c and heavy bulls to processors sold to 308c and averaged from 271c to 299c/kg.

Numbers eased by 570 head for a yarding of 3189 cattle.  Quality improved on last sale, with one large line of very good quality bullocks, along with several smaller lines of prime cows.  A good supply of grown steers and heifers to suit feeders were supported by some good quality yearling steers and heifers.  All regular processors operated at reduced rates along with regular feeders and opportunity restockers.
Grown steers and heifers to feed improved 20c, heavy cows eased 18c to 20c and heavy bulls averaged 40c lower.

Light steers returning to grass sold to 652.2c to average 552c and heifers to the trade sold to 452.2c to average 443c/kg. Yearling steers less than 280kg to restockers averaged 538c and steers above 280kg to grass reached  532.2c to average 511c/kg. Yearling heifers returning to grass for breeding reached 454.2c to average 419c/kg.  A good sample above 280kg to feed topped at 392.2c averaging 389c/kg. Grown steers above 400kg to feed sold to 428.2c to average 404c and suitable trade types topped at 386.2c to average 379c/kg. Grown heifers to feed reached 392.2c to average 376c/kg.

A large single vendor line of bullocks to processors topped at 386.2c multiple times to average 381c/kg.  Medium weight 2 score cows to processors averaged 314c, selling to 334.2c, and 3 scores topped at. 359.2c to average 336c/kg. Prime heavyweight cows topped at 362.2c to average 343c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors sold to 330c to average 320c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Numbers eased by 491 head to 1,507 cattle in Charters Towers this week. Greater than one third of the yarding was made up of very good quality prime cows, supported by a good line of prime bullocks and one good line of young northern steers. One regular processor and feeder buyer was absent, however one live exporter and feeder buyer operated in conjunction with several opportunity restockers. Cattle were drawn from Croydon, Georgetown, Mount Surprise, Forsayth, Hughenden, Pentland, Mount Coolon, Collinsville, Proserpine, Clermont, local and coastal areas.

Young steers calves were of mixed quality and eased in line with quality, while vealer steers were too insufficient to quote. Yearling steers of feeder weight to live export improved by up to 12c/kg, while fewer heavier types eased slightly. Yearling heifers to live export improved for better quality suitable types. Heavy bullocks to live export sold firm, while heavy bullocks to export process improved by more than 20c/kg. Extra heavy 3 score cows sold firm and 4 scores eased by 1c, while heavy 3 score cows eased 7c/kg and medium weight 2 score cows improved in line with quality. Heavy bulls to live export eased slightly on previous week’s prices.

A small number of vealer steers to restockers sold to 257c to average 254c, while yearling steers to live export reached 268c for heavier types and feeder weights made to 256c to average 252c/kg. Yearling heifers to process sold to 227c for one heavy pen and suitable types to live export sold to 190c/kg multiple times. One good pen to restockers made 230c, with several small lines above 200c/kg. Heavy prime bullocks to export process reached 271c, to average 268c and 4 scores averaged 262c/kg. Heavy grown steers to live export sold to 266c/kg. Heavy 3 score cows sold to 175c to average 166c, while extra heavy 3 score cows topped at 185c, averaging 177c and 4 scores averaged 182c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 127c to average 107c and better quality lighter types to restockers sold to 125c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export made to 287c to average 282c and young males returning to grass sold to 244c/kg. Several pens of cow and calves sold from $680 to 880/unit.

Numbers eased by 48 head to 1,274 cattle in Charters Towers, with increased numbers of plainer conditioned lines, reflecting the lengthening dry season. All regular processors were in attendance and operating strongly throughout, particularly for lower yielding lines suitable for slaughter, supported by one feeder buyer, one live exporter and opportunity restockers and backgrounders. Cattle were drawn from Hughenden, Greenvale, Burdekin, local and coastal areas. 

Limited numbers of calves sold in line with quality, while young steers improved by 2c/kg. Mixed quality lines of young heifers eased by 17c/kg. Yearling steers to live export lifted 2c and a limited supply of yearling heifers to the trade sold firm. Several lines of plain cows to slaughter eased by 5c, while heavy cows continued recent stronger trends with a 12c to 14c/kg improvement in averages. Heavy bulls to processors eased by up to 15c/kg.

Vealer steers to restockers topped at 300c to average 293c, while yearling steers returning to the paddock made to 284c to average 265c/kg. Light young heifers eased 23c to average 218c, selling to a top of 236c, while the quality of yearling heifers was very mixed, selling to 213c to average 211c/kg. Increased numbers of grown steers to feed sold to 293c to average 289c, however limited numbers of grown heifers to processors sold to 261c, with most sales above 219c/kg. Heavy 3 score bullocks to export slaughter topped at 344c to average 342c, with lighter 2 scores sold to 281c to average 272c/kg.  

Medium weight 2 score cows to processors topped at 188c to average 169c and lighter cows returning to the paddock selling to 167c to average 164c/kg.  Heavy 3 score cows continued stronger trend, selling to 274c to average 262c and extra heavy 3 score cows topping at 272c to average 245c/kg. Heavy D muscled cows were in greater supply to average 245c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors made to 310c averaging 296c, while several heavy bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 308c to average 295c/kg. Young males returning to the paddocks sold to 277c to average 255c/kg.

Numbers eased by 456 head to 1,195 cattle in Charters Towers this week, with the quality of prime cattle improving on recent sales. The regular processors operated aong with two live exporters in a limited buyer gallery of restockers and backgrounders, with values improving across most categories. Cattle were drawn from Chillago, Croydon, Greenvale, Ingham, Townsville, Bowen, local and coastal areas.

Steer calves improved by up to 10c and some very good lines of vealer steers increased by more than 14c/kg, while lesser quality light types eased accordingly. Vealer heifers were of limited supply and variable quality. Yearling steers to live export increased by 6c/kg and a small supply of yearling heifers to feed sold firm. Grown steers to live export increased by more than 30c and heavy grown heifers to slaughter increased by 24c/kg. Heavy bullocks suitable to live export lifted by 20c/kg and heavy bullocks to export slaughter lifted by similar values. Medium weight 2 score cows lifted by more than 35c and heavy cows to processors lifted by 13c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export increased by 10c/kg.

A good line of steer calves sold to 288c to average more than 284c, while similar vealer steers topped at 300c to average 291c/kg. Heavy vealer steers to restockers sold to 260c/kg. Limited numbers of light vealer heifers to restockers made to 220c and a selection of heavy vealer heifers to domestic processors made to 256c/kg. Yearling steers to live export reached 278c to average 275c and steers to feed averaged 251c/kg. Feeder weight grown steers sold to 267c and heavy grown steers to live export topped at 304c/kg. A small supply of grown heifers to domestic slaughter made to 246c to average 233c/kg.  

Heavy bullocks to live export made 299c in pen lots with single sales to 307c, while heavy export bullocks to slaughter made to 303c to average 294c/kg.  Medium weight 2 score cows sold to 173c to average 165c, heavy 3 score cows reached 214c averaging 209c, with extra heavy 3 and 4 score cows topping at 218c to average 214c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export sold to 295c multiple times to average 290c and a large sample of good quality light young males returning to grass, sold to 277c to average 257c/kg.

Numbers eased by 45 head to 865 cattle for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents with all categories in high demand. Limited numbers of heavy prime cattle increased on last sale, while store cattle returned to season highs, with live exporters active throughout. All regular processors, two live exporters and opportunity restockers lifted prices on all classes and were highly active throughout the sale. Cattle were drawn from Cloncurry, Einasleigh, Ingham, Belyando, local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers mainly comprised one very good quality suitably weaned line reaching 296c/kg. Yearling steers were in very high demand for all types and weight classes. Light yearling steers returning to grass sold to 282c, with medium weight steers making to 274c to average close to 266c/kg. Light yearling steers to live export sold to 280c to average 272c, with feeder steers above 330kg topping at 298c to average 282c/kg. Some very good quality yearling steers to process sold for 290c/kg. A very good line of suitably weaned vealer heifers returning to grass attracted strong demand and sold accordingly, reaching 272c to average 257c/kg. Restockers were active on all weight categories, with vealer heifers above 280kg topping at 234c, while yearling heifers of similar weight made to 222c to average 189c/kg. Heavier heifers returning to grass sold to 230c/kg.

A mixed quality offering of grown bullocks lacked the finish of recent months, with considerable variation in quality and weight. A single heavy bullock sold to 306c, while younger medium weight types sold to 303c/kg. Good quality medium weight 2 score bullocks sold to 295c, lifting 17c to average 274c/kg. Medium weight bullocks to live export sold to 283c/kg. Heavy grown steers to export slaughter made to 298c, with live exporters very active on heavy feeder weights to 286c to average 277c/kg. Steers to background feed destined for live export made to 290c/kg. A reduced number of cows on offer met strong demand throughout, particularly on lighter cows, by opportunity restockers. The better draft of heavy cows lacked the weight of recent weeks, with heavy 3 score cows to process easing 4c to average 232c, with a top of to 246c, while heavy 4 score cows lifted 15c, to top at 254c/kg. Heavy 2 score cows eased 9c to average near 205c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 195c to average 176c and light 1 score cows made to 190c to average 185c/kg. Light cows to restockers sold to 168c to average 161c/kg. Heavy grown heifers lifted 18c to average 278c, reaching a top of 288c, while plainer grown heifers to feed made to 226c/kg. A very strong demand for bulls saw prices lift across all categories. Heavy bulls to process lifted to 292c to average 286c, while heavy bulls suitable for live export made to 268c/kg. Similar bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 287c and medium weight bulls made to 298c/kg. Young males above 300kg to feed destined for live export reached 292c to average 258c, while lighter types returning to grass sold to 270c/kg. Light conditioned cows and calves sold for $780/unit.

Numbers eased by 42 head for a yarding of 2,195 cattle in Charters Towers this week, featuring some very good lines of prime cows and bullocks and larger lines of store steers.  The regular buying panel operated at marginally easier prices throughout, with most prime cattle easier than last sale, while light store cattle improved. Cattle were drawn from the Northern Gulf, Burketown, Mt Surprise, Chillagoe, Georgetown, Hughenden, Torrens Creek, Ingham, Woodstock, local and coastal areas.

Light steer calves were offered in small numbers increasing by more than 15c, with young vealer steers improving by 11c/kg. Vealer heifers were of very mixed quality, with better types improving 3c/kg. Yearling steers to restockers eased 6c/kg, while yearling heifers returning to paddock sold firm. Grown steers to feed eased 4c, and better quality grown heifers to domestic processors sold firm, with lower yielding types 11c/kg cheaper. Heavy bullocks to export processors eased by more than 15c, while suitable types to live export eased 4c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows eased by 9c and heavy 3 score cows were from 7c to 13c/kg cheaper. Heavy bulls to live export eased by 4c, however a large sample of good quality young males returning to grass improved by 17c/kg. 

Steer calves to restockers sold to 282c, with a good sample averaging 262c, while heifer calves sold to 200c/kg. Vealer steers to restockers sold to 268c to average 261c, with heavier types selling to 266c/kg. Vealer heifers suitable for processing made to 186c, with lighter types returning to grass selling to 172c to average 159c/kg. Yearling steers over 280kg to live export made to 280c to average 268c, with steers over 330kg selling to 272c, averaging 270c/kg. Yearling heifers to processors made to 226c to average 188c, and heavy heifers to domestic processors sold to 243c to average 233c/kg.  A small number of heifers returning to the paddock averaged 199c/kg. Grown steers to processors sold to 265c, averaging 261c and heavy grown heifers sold to 230c to average 209c, with lower yielding types averaging 181c/kg.

Heavy bullocks to export processors sold to 281c to average 275c, with a large sample of D muscled full mouth bullocks also making to 281c to average 264c/kg. Medium weight cows to processors sold to 178c to average 136c, while a large sample of heavy D muscled cows averaged 188c/kg. Heavy 3 score cows sold to 214c to average 204c, while several pens of very good extra heavy cows sold to 215c to average over 214c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export topped at 285c, averaging 283c and similar types to feed destined for live export sold to 289c, with most sales from 263c to 280c/kg. Several lines of good quality young males returning to the paddock made to 266c, to average 257c/kg. A small number of cows and calves sold to $630/unit.

Numbers eased by 383 head to 2,287 mixed quality cattle in Charters Towers in another predominantly prime only yarding. There is 2,700 cattle booked for Friday's Store Sale. The regular buyer panel once again consisted of southern processor and feeder orders with all operating at slightly easier rates than previous weeks. Some very good lines of heavy bullocks and cows were penned, supported by increased numbers of heavy grown heifers. Bullocks eased 8c to 10c and heavy cows eased 6c to 9c/kg. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Georgetown, Einsaleigh, Mt Garnet, Greenvale, Ingham local and coastal areas.

Yearling steers above 330kg to feed sold to 342c to average 338c and heavy steers above 400kg to feed averaged 347c/kg. A good supply of yearling heifers above 330kg to feed sold to 308c to average 299c and heavy heifers to feed averaged 298c/kg. Grown steers generally eased by up to 25c, with those to feed topping at 345.2c to average 316c, with heavy weight steers to processors selling to 322c to average 309c/kg. Increased numbers of grown heifers to the trade sold to 304.2c to average 282c/kg.

A good supply of heavy bullocks to export processors topped at 338.2c for individual animals and 334.2c for pen lots to average 318c/kg. Fewer numbers of medium weight 2 score cows increased 3c, selling to 248.2c to average 238c and heavy 3 score cows reached 269.2c to average 257c/kg. Prime heavy weight cows topped at 280.2c to average 277c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export sold to 320.2c to average 304c and heavy bulls to processors averaged 311c/kg.

Numbers eased by 360 head to 1265 cattle in Charters Towers, with increased numbers of heavy prime heifers, cows and bulls. Most classes of prime cattle sold to a dearer trend with all processors active throughout, supported by one live exporter and opportunity restockers and backgrounders. Cattle were drawn from Normanton, Mt Surprise, Corfield, Pentland, Ayr, local and coastal areas.

Young steer calves improved 24c/kg for a small offering and young heifers to the trade also improved in price. Vealer steers returning to the paddock increased by 30c for better quality lines and heifers increased by up to 24c/kg. Yearling steers to feed improved by 8c and heavy yearling steers above 380kg to feed increased by 6c/kg. Light yearling heifers to the trade improved 4c and heavy heifers increased by 26c/kg. Grown steers to live export lifted by 25c and heavy bullocks increased by 30c, and those to export slaughter lifted by more than 10c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows lifted 6c, heavy 3 score cows rose 4c and heavy bulls to processors improved by more than 30c/kg.

Young steer calves sold to 286c to average 280c and vealer steers averaged 288c/kg for better quality types. Young vealer heifers to processors sold to 202c and light heifers returning to the paddock averaged 186c/kg. Yearling steers to feed sold to 270c, averaging 266c and a large sample of heavy steers to feed averaged 276c/kg. Light yearling heifers returning to grass sold to 196c, while heavy yearling heifers to the trade sold to 282c to average 274c and medium weights to feed made to 260c/kg. Grown steers to live export sold to 315c to average more than 300c and heavy bullocks to live export sold to 320c multiple times to average above 307c/kg.  Heavy bullocks to export slaughter also sold to 320c to average 315c/kg.

Medium weight 2 score cows made to 173c to  average 168c and heavy 3 score cows increased further on last sale, selling to 248c to average 234c/kg.  A large sample of very good extra heavy cows sold to 250c, averaging above 238c and 4 score cows averaged 228c/kg. Good numbers of heavy bulls to processors sold to all time highs of 318c averaging more than 302c and young males returning to the paddock sold to 280c to average 255c/kg.

Numbers eased by 350 head for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week for a yarding of 1,376 cattle. There were lower numbers of prime cows, but increased numbers of very good vealer steers. One major processor was absent, however a processor absent for a couple of years operated intermittently, supported by a live exporter, two feeder buyers and several opportunistic restockers at more buoyant prices than recent weeks.

The increased offering of vealer steers was generally very good quality and prices lifted by up to 20c/kg on last sale. Young steer calves sold to 304c with spirited restocker demand lifting prices for vealer steers to 297c to average 281c for a very large sample, with most sales above 266c/kg. Yearling steers were presented with considerable variation in quality and prices eased accordingly. Yearling steers 280-330kg returning to grass sold to 246c, while steers above 330kg to grass sold to 234c and a selection of similar weight steers to live export sold to 231c/kg. Some very well grown yearling steers to slaughter sold to 248c/kg. Vealer heifers sold to a much stronger trend than recent weeks, with light heifers and heifer calves selling to 218c and a small number of heifers above 280kg to restockers selling to 174c/kg. A very mixed offering of small lines of yearling heifers met subdued demand, however heifers above 330kg to feed sold to 210c/kg.

A small offering of mixed quality heavy bullocks to slaughter eased 8c on previous week, with quality related price movements most sales were between 229c and 243c with a top of 247c/kg. A selection of grown steers to slaughter improved to 233c and heavy steers suitable for live export sold to 226c/kg. A large percentage of grown steers lacked weight and finish, attracting limited interest from buyers. Reduced numbers of heavy prime cows met stronger demand from processors, with heavy C muscled 3 score cows selling to 193c to average 184c and D3 cows averaging 172c/kg. Heavy 2 score cows to processors averaged 154c and medium weight D2 cows averaged 135c/kg. Light cows to restockers improved 19c, with the better quality sample averaging 126c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export eased by more than 20c, topping at 256c to average 252c, while a few select bulls to restockers sold to 270c/kg. Light males attracted strong interest selling to 290c for the small offering. A small number of light conditioned cows and calves sold from $650 to a top of $900/unit.

Numbers eased by 226 head for a yarding of 1,588 cattle in Charters Towers, featuring increased numbers of heavy prime bullocks and bulls and mixed lines of store cattle. Prices eased across most categories, most notably heavy cows, however better quality pens of young cattle generally sold firm. All regular processors operated selectively, with one central feeder buyer and one live exporter, however restocker attendance was limited. Cattle were drawn from Burketown, Croydon, Einasleigh, Mount Surrise, Tully, Richmond, Torrens Creek, Belyando, local and coastal areas. 

Steer calves sold firm in pen lots, however reduced numbers of vealer steers mainly eased on last sale. Young heifer calves increased by more than 15c for better quality lines and vealer heifer demand improved prices by up to 25c/kg. Yearling steers to live export sold similar to recent weeks and steers to feed sold firm. Light yearling heifers to restockers improved, with better lines on offer, and heavier heifers to feed and live export both improved in price. Heavy export bullocks eased 3c and heavy cows decreased by 15c to 20c/kg, however medium weight cows to process sold firm. Medium and heavy bulls to live export improved by up to 15c/kg. Steer calves sold to 262c multiple times, averaging near 250c, while vealer steers to restockers reached 280c to average 260c/kg. Light heifer calves to restockers made to 200c to average 184c/kg. Vealer heifers less than 280kg to feed averaged 187c and those above 280kg averaged 185c/kg. Reduced numbers of yearling steers were presented, with steers to live export making to 265c to average more than 254c, while single sales to restockers made to 246c/kg. Heavy steers above 400kg to feed made 256c/kg. Yearling heifers were of mixed quality, heavy types to process made to 226c, while lighter lines returning to grass made to 182c to average 164c/kg. Heifers to feed above 330kg made to 184c to average 178c/kg.

Increased numbers of heavy export bullocks sold to 260c, averaging 3c lower at 247c, while extra heavy bullocks made to 275c, averaging 272c and one pen of 4 score bullocks made 277c/kg. Heavy bullocks to feed destined for live export made to 278c and plainer types sold to 249c/kg. Heavy 3 score cows sold to 175c to average 171c and cows above 520kg made to 179c to average 176c/kg. Lower yielding heavy D muscled cows made to 172c, averaging 161c and increased numbers of medium weight 2 score cows made to 157c to average 121c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export met increased demand, reaching 304c to live export multiple times, with most sales above 290c/kg and medium weights to feed destined for live export selling to similar prices throughout. Young males to restockers made to 292c/kg.

Numbers eased by 163 head to 3,327 cattle in Charters Towers this week, with very strong demand and price increases in most categories. A continuation of some very good lines of heavy prime cows and grown heifers, supported by similar quality young store steers and heifers. The regular buyer panel was in attendance and operating at increased rates, supported by the return of one live exporter and southern reseller orders. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Normanton, Georgetown, Mt Garnet, Greenvale, Pentland, Dalbeg, local and coastal areas.

Light vealer steers sold to improved rates, increasing by more than 25c, with similar heifers increasing by nearly 60c/kg. Light yearling steers to backgrounders lifted 35c and steers above 280kg to feed increased by 30c/kg.  Medium weight yearling heifers to feed improved by 15c and heavy heifers to the trade lifted by more than 20c/kg. Increased numbers of grown heifers to the trade lifted by 39c/kg mainly due to the quality in offer. Heavy bullocks to export processors improved 19c and heavy weight cows to processors improved by 9c to 13c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors lifted by more than 30c/kg.

Light vealer steers less than 200kg to backgrounders sold to 376.2 to average 354c, while steers above 200kg averaged 343c/kg. One outstanding line of vealer heifers to restockers reached 338.2c to average 334c, with a large sample of heifers averaging 310c/kg. Processor ready heifers topped at 300.2c to average 275c/kg. Light yearling steers to backgrounders sold to 332.2c to average 319c, while steers above 280kg to feed sold to 338c to average near 306c/kg. Medium weight yearling steers to feed topped at 328.2c to average 306c/kg. A large sample of yearling heifers above 330kg to feed sold to 284.2c to average an improved 271c/kg. A limited number of heavy grown steers to the trade sold to 326c to avergae above 314c/kg. An increased supply of good quality grown heifers to the trade sold to 296c to average above 249c/kg.

Heavy bullocks to export processors topped at 314c to average 309c, with medium weights selling to 326c to average 295c/kg.  Medium weight cows to processors reached 214c to average 200c, while increased numbers of heavy cows to processors topped at 251.2c to average above 227c/kg. Prime heavy weight cows sold to 257c to average 252c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors sold to 321.2c to average 314c, while suitable types for live export to background feed made to 322.2c to average from 256c to 283c/kg. Good quality Cows and calves sold from $860 to 1,230/unit.

Numbers eased by 150 head to 1,178 head for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, with increased numbers of prime cows and bullocks on offer. One major processor was again absent, along with one feeder buyer, however one live exporter operated on suitable lines, supported by several opportunity restockers. Cattle were drawn from Burketown, Richmond, Mount Garnet, Tully, Ingham, Rollingstone, Belyando, local and coastal areas.

Young male calves met increased restocker competition making to seasonal highs, while limited numbers of vealer steers improved by up to 25c/kg. Light yearling steers to restockers sold firm to 2c/kg dearer. Light heifers eased 15c for most lines on offer, while yearling heifers above 400kg to process improved by 17c/kg. Grown heifers met quality related price changes. Grown steers to process sold firm and heavy bullocks to processors improved by up to 20c/kg. Extra heavy 4 score cows eased by 4c and heavy 3 score cows averaged 7c/kg lower on last sale. Heavy bulls to live export increased by up to 40c/kg. Young male calves sold to 306c to average 266c, while light vealer steers were in limited supply, making to 268c/kg to restockers. Yearling steers less than 280kg to restockers topped at 258c and those above 330kg returning to paddock made to 245c to average 238c, while suitable steers to live export sold to 258c/kg. Yearling heifers to restockers sold to 219c for a large sample, with heavy yearling heifers to processors making to 231c to average 217c/kg.

Grown steers to live export sold to 251c, averaging 244c, while heavier types to process sold to 271c/kg. Heavy 4 score bullocks to export process topped at 283c and 3 score bullocks sold to 281c/kg. Suitable heavy bullocks to live export averaged 279c/kg. A good pen of extra heavy 4 score cows sold for 201c, with 3 score cows averaging 181c/kg. Heavy 3 score cows made to 198c to average 185c and medium weight 2 score cows averaged 127c/kg. Light cows returning to grass sold to 188c, with most sales from 140c to 155c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export increased by up to 40c, reaching 298c, with similar types to feed destined for live export topping at 297c to average 288c/kg. Medium weight feeder bulls to live export sold to 272c to average 269c/kg. Good quality cows and calves sold for $820/unit.

Numbers eased back and values were dearer across the board. A full field of processors, butchers and wholesalers were active on a fair quality selection of mainly steers and cows. These steers were mainly 4c to 11c dearer while the heifers improved 5c and 6c/kg. The light poor quality cows gained up to 27c and the balance were between 3c and 13c/kg dearer. Bulls were firm to 3c/kg above last weeks rates. 

The light steers sold to 131.2c and most averaged around 120c/kg. The medium weight steers of better quality received the greatest gains and topped at 152.2c to average 146.8c although those to lighter finish generally averaged 130c/kg. Heavy steers sold to 153.2c and averaged 147.9c/kg. 

The small number of heifers reached 133.2c and the better grades averaged 128.5c/kg. Light cows sold to 122.2c and the D2s averaged 112c while the D1s saw most sales around 92c/kg. The better medium weight cows topped at 138.8c and averaged 132.3c/kg. Light bulls sold to 138.2c and the heavy weights reached 148.2c/kg to return close to $1,200/head.

Numbers eased although prices were mostly dearer. Quality was fair to good with some even runs available and competition continued to be stronger from a full field of buyers. The steers were mostly 4c but up to 11c/kg dearer. The heifers gained from 2c to 4c while the light cows were 3c to 7c/kg above last weeks rates. The medium weight cows were slightly cheaper to 5c/kg dearer.

Light steers sold to 129.2c while the medium weights reached 140.2c and they averaged between 137c and 138c/kg. There was over 180 heavy steers that sold to 146.2c and averaged 142.9c/kg. 

Export heifers topped at 134.2c and most averaged from 123.3c to 131.5c/kg. The light cow topped at 121.2c and close to 100 D2s averaged 106.1c/kg. The medium weight cows sold to 125.2c and the D2s gained ground to average 115c while the D3s eased slightly to and most sales were around 123c/kg. Heavy cows topped at 128.2c/kg. Heavy bulls sold to 138.2c/kg.

Numbers eased again this week for Charter Towers Combined Selling Agents, with only 540 head on offer, 427 fewer than last sale. Heavy prime cows increased by 6c/kg with all regular processors in attendance and competing strongly, while two live exporters held heavy bulls firm on last week. Several lines of small steers and heifers attracted limited restocker interest, with no feeder buyers present. Cattle were drawn from Burketown, Hughenden, Ingham, Ayr, Ravenswood and local and coastal areas.

A few small lines of newly weaned, heavy vealer steers increased by 14c, selling to 262c/kg, with no yearling steers to quote. Lighter newly weaned males to restockers sold to 240c to average 227c/kg. Vealer heifers also consisted of small lines of newly weaned heavier types selling to 199c with most around 170c/kg. Yearling heifers attracted subdued buyer interest, with the absence of feeder operators. Better quality yearling heifers returning to grass sold to 183c, with most sales between 168c and 176c/kg.

A small offering of very good heavy bullocks lifted by 9c selling to 252c, to average 243c, while extra heavy bullocks rarely seen in the Charters Towers market made 253c/kg. Lesser quality types sold to 240c/kg. A yarding of 236 prime cows of mostly good quality, saw most categories improve with increased processor attendance. Extra heavy 3 score cows sold to 205c, with 4 score types to 195c to average 194c/kg. Heavy 4 score cows sold to 205c, to average 193c and 3 score cows sold to 199c several times to average 190c/kg. Heavy 3 score D muscled cows made to 198c to average 179c, with medium weights to 135c, easing more than 20c/kg on last sale. Only a small number of cows to restockers sold to 100c/kg. Heavy bulls continued recent strong price trends selling firm on last sale, topping at 275c to live export, with most above 253c, while lighter bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 242c/kg. A small number of cows and calves sold from $860 to $1,380/unit.

Numbers eased  by 725 head to 1,289 cattle in Charters Towers under grey skies and cooler conditions than recent weeks. Overall quality was mixed with fewer numbers of well finished prime cattle, however many store lines presented in good condition. Most of the regular processors were in attendance and operating along with two live exporters, two central feeder buyers and opportunity western restockers. Cattle were drawn from Mt Garnet, Greenvale, Pentland, Mingela, local and coastal areas.

Young vealer steers to restockers eased by up to 20c and heifers were up to 8c/kg easier. Yearling steers to feed sold firm, while yearling heifers improved by 7c to 10c/kg. Grown heifers to trade increased by up to 20c/kg for heavier lines. Limited good quality heavy export bullocks lifted by 11c, medium weight cows to feed lifted 6c to 10c, with prime heavy weight cows increasing by 13c/kg.

Vealer steers returning to grass sold to 374c to average 368c and vealer heifers to the paddock sold to 302c to average 285c/kg. Yearling steers above 330kg to feed sold to 370c to average 356c and suitable steers to live export reached 372c, averaging 367c/kg. Yearling heifers to feed sold to 317c to average 306c and heavier heifers to the trade sold to 364c/kg.

Grown steers to feed sold to 360c, with most sales above 325c and better quality grown heifers to the trade made to 350c to average 327c/kg. Limited numbers of heavy export bullocks to processors topped at 377c to average more than 375c/kg. Heavy D muscled cows averaged 269c, while heavy C muscled 3 score cows sold to 280c to average 276c, with 4 scores selling to 294c to average 291c/kg. Light weight cows to feed sold to 221c to average 183c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors sold to 364c/kg. Several small lines of cows and calves sold to $960/unit.

Numbers dropped again with the good falls of rain in the supply area a major factor. Quality was again mixed, but with the small yarding it is hard to accurately quote the market. All the regular buyers were present. 

Light steers sold to 120c in small pen lots as medium weights reached 130c/kg. A single heavy D3 topped at 135.2c/kg. 

Cows were in the majority with lightweights averaging mostly from 85c to 97c/kg. Medium weight D3s reached 107.2c and averaged just under 103c/kg.

Numbers decreased significantly today, making it very difficult to accurately identify a market trend. Lighter weight heifers and cows of all weight comprised the majority of the yarding with just a limited number of calves and bulls penned.

Those calves present in the yarding ranged from 120c to 144.2c/kg and were all over 80kg in weight.

Fifty D2 heifers under 540kg sold from 105c to 130.2c to average 120.2c/kg. This was a fall of 4c/kg on the previous sale. 

Most cows fell in the export weight range, however varied in both muscle and fat content, making it far too difficult to reliably quote a trend. Only two bulls were penned.

Numbers decreased once more as damaged roads following the large amount of rain received in February are still preventing transportation of stock. The regular field of buyers were in attendance and competition was strong. Quality was reported to be good although some of the heifers and cows were on the plainer side. There have been a few showers around the district although they have been scattered. 

There was only a handful of light steers penned that averaged 153.7c/kg. Medium weights were firm and topped at 175.2c, which saw averages between 152c and 167c/kg. Heavy weights sold slightly dearer and reached 180.2c and most sales were in around 176c/kg. The best heavy bullocks returned $1,214/head.

Export heifers were reported to be of fair quality and with signs of freshness in the coat following the recent rain. Prices were dearer and the best D3s topped at 166.2c/kg. There was a large percentage of light cows that sold 4c to 7c dearer and a large sample averaged 130c/kg. Medium weights improved and averaged 13c dearer at 158.6c after they sold to a top of 169.2c/kg. 

Bulls received mixed results and generally sold around the 150c/kg mark.

Numbers decreased in a fair quality yarding. Most of the regular buyers including several processors and all the local butchers were in attendance. Competition was reasonable with most cattle selling firm although some of the poorer grades experienced reduced buyer competition. On the whole the market was firm to a little cheaper in places. 

The light steers peaked a little higher compared to last week at 132.2c and averaged around 112.3c/kg. The medium weights topped at 148.2c, which saw the better lines average slightly lower at 140.9c/kg. There were some good heavy steers penned but they were not able to achieve the rates of last week and averaged 146.2c/kg. 

Heifers made to 137.2c and most averaged 85.6c, which was back around 20c/kg on last week. The light cows reached 120c, however the bulk of the light cows were cheaper by 7c to 11c/kg. Medium weights were also cheaper and sold to 125.2c and the D3s averaged 114c back almost 10c/kg. 

Medium weight bulls sold around 119.5c while the heavy weights peaked at 129.2c/kg.

Numbers decreased dramatically and quality varied across all grades.  There was a reasonable selection of grown steers and bullocks along with a few pens of grown heifers.  However a large percentage of the penning consisted of one line of 185 cows offered in the live weight section while another line of 190 pregnancy tested cows were sold in the open auction section.  The regular field of export buyers were present along with several local domestic processors.  

The prime grown steers and bullocks were fully firm to slightly dearer, however the plainer quality pens were slightly cheaper.  The well finished C3 heavy weight pens made from 148.2¢ to 153.2¢/kg.  Grown heifers were firm to slightly easier and the D muscled pens sold up to 130¢/kg.

Medium weight cows were firm to slightly dearer while some of the lightweight lines eased slightly.  The D2 lightweights averaged 117.8¢/kg while the large line of 190 pregnancy tested cows averaged $423/head in the open auction section.

Numbers decreased by nearly 600 to 906 head at Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents as the weather warms up across the north and west. Prime cows and bullock values lifted by up to 12c and store cattle suitable for live export attracted very strong buyer support throughout the sale. All regular processors were very active throughout the prime offering, supported by three live exporters, background feeder buyers and some opportunity restockers. Cattle were drawn from Cloncurry, Richmond, Hughenden, Torrens Creek, Tully, Ingham, Mount Coolon, as well as local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers were in short supply, with better bred types lifting 7c to average 261c and reaching 267c/kg. Several small consignments of yearling steers were highly sought by live exporters, with medium weight feeder steers topping at 277c, with most lines making from 272c to 276c/kg. Heavier yearling steers to live export sold for 279c/kg. Vealer heifers were highly variable in quality, with mixed demand. Better quality medium weights to restockers sold to 200c and similar quality lighter heifers to feed made to 186c/kg. Yearling heifers were generally very good quality, with many to live export making from 215c to 230c, averaging 226c/kg.

Some good pens of heavy 3 score bullocks attracted strong processor interest, reaching 277c to average 270c, up 2c on last sale, while extra heavy 4 score bullocks sold to a season high of 288c, to average 284c/kg. A higher percentage of plain heavy bullocks improved by up to 12c, reaching 257c to average 231c, with lighter bullocks averaging 267c/kg. Heavy grown steers to processors made to 288c to average 284c, while grown steers to live export sold from 220c to 270c/kg. The cow offering saw greater numbers of 2 score cows, with processors being very active on all weight categories. Heavy 3 score cows improved 11c to average 222c, topping at 231c/kg. Extra heavy 3 sore cows also reached 231c, while 4 scores made to 235c to average 231c/kg. A pen of extra heavy 5 score cows sold for 209c/kg. Heavy 3 score D muscled cows sold to 213c to average 179c and 2 scores made to 215c to average 190c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows to restockers eased 20c to average 117c/kg. Some very good quality 3 score grown heifers to processors improved 8c to average 233c and heavy 4 score heifers sold to 264c/kg. Heavy 3 score bulls to processors improved 8c to, reaching 275c to average 255c, with medium weight bulls making to 234c/kg. Live exporters were active on heavy bulls to 268c, while similar bulls to feed destined for live export made to 259c/kg. Feeder weight bulls to live export made to 278c to average 277c/kg. Young males returning to grass sold to 258c to average 243c/kg.

Numbers decreased by 643 for a yarding of 2327 cattle.  Quality was very mixed comprising of fewer numbers of heavy bullocks and cows, supported by several small lines of store steers and heifers with many lines reflecting the dry season.  All regular processors were in attendance and operating, supported by one live exporter, feeders and opportunity restockers. Demand for heavier well finished lines was firm, however lesser quality and lighter weight lines continued to struggle to attract buyer support. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa to Richmond, north to Georgetown and south to the local area.

Values for all categories were reflective of quality, with better quality lines improving by up to 30c and lesser types being further discounted. Yearling heifers above 280kg to feed improved 16c to 38c, prime grown steers and bullocks improved 4c to 15c, prime heifers lifted 3c to 9c and prime cows averaged 5c to 6c lower.

Light restocker steers returning to the paddock averaged 268c to 307c, reaching a top of 317c, similar heifers to processors sold to 222c to average 192c/kg. Yearling steers above 200kg to backgrounders reached 300c, a good sample averaging 298c and secondary types averaged 267c/kg. Yearling steers above 280kg to live export sold to 284c to average 274c/kg. Yearling heifers to feed above 200kg averaged 195c to 208c, with heifers above 280kg making to 250c to average 227c to 241c/kg.

Grown steers above 400kg to processors averaged 272c to 299c reaching 306c, feeders averaged 258c/kg. A reduced number of grown heifers reached 286c to average 245c to 266c/kg.  A smaller supply of heavy full mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 320c multiple times to average 286c to 304c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows made to 218c to average 196c, 3 scores reached 264c to average 239c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export sold to 272c to average 268c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Numbers decreased by 443 for a yarding of 2261 cattle. It was a mixed quality yarding consisting of some isolated good pens of heavy cows and bullocks, some very good individual animals, along with plainer conditioned lines. All regulars processors were in attendance and operating, supported by one feeder, one live exporter and opportunity backgrounders. Cattle were drawn from Richmond, Croydon, Mt Surprise, Torrens Creek, Pentland, local and coastal areas.

Buyer demand was strong for the majority penned, particularly good quality store steers and heifers, however heavy bulls met notably less demand. Grown steers and heifers lifted up to 15c, heavy bullocks increased 9c, heavy cows improved by. 5c and bulls averaged 30c to 60c lower.

Suitably weaned steers returning to the paddock sold to 282c to average 259c, similarly heifers averaged 246c/kg. A large sample of steers above 200kg to backgrounders made to 360c to average 314c/kg. Good quality flatback heifers made to 278c to average 253c to 263c/kg. Yearling steers above above 330kg to restockers sold to 326c to average 304c to 308c and those suitable for live export sold to 294c/kg. Yearling heifers above 200kg to the trade sold to 248c, averaging 242c and heifers above 330kg to feed averaged 275c/kg. Good quality yearling heifers above 400kg to the trade sold to 290c/kg.  A small number of Grown steers to the trade sold to 318c to average 309c, grown heifers to the trade reached 264c to average 245c/kg. 

Heavy young bullocks to export slaughter topped at 345c to average 326c/kg. Medium weight 3 score cows to processors sold to 280c to average 251c, prime heavyweight cows 4 score cows topped at 288c to average 283c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export sold to 284c, processor bulls reached 276c to average 240c/kg.

A small number of cows and calves sold to $935 per unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Numbers declined by more than half to yard 1,233 cattle for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week. The offering across all categories was lower in number as the selling year draws to a close. Not all buyers were operating, with those present operating at significantly lower prices. Prime cows eased by up to 20c/kg. One regular feeder and isolated restockers showed strong enthusiasm in the store section. Isolated rains across the state impacted the yarding, reducing numbers of cattle from the north, with most cattle drawn from local areas including Hughenden, Greenvale, Tully, Ravenswood and Belyando.

The small number of vealer steers sold stronger despite the limited buying panel, topping at 354c, with most sales from 344c to 348c/kg. There were insufficient yearling steers to quote. Vealer heifers were predominantly lighter, recently weaned types that eased by 15c to 25/kg despite strong restocker demand. Light heifers topped at 322c, averaging 293c, while well covered heavier vealer heifers sold to 282c, to average 279c/kg. Yearling heifers were of very mixed quality, featuring many small lines, with heifers to feed selling to 272c and averaging 265c, while heifers returning to grass sold to 268c/kg.

Some isolated pens of good bullocks sold 10c to 15c lower than last sale to top at 263c/kg to slaughter. Restockers were active on lighter, poorer conditioned types, topping at 256c, to average 225c/kg. A number of grown steers to restockers sold to 272c, with heavy feeder steers to feed selling to 285c/kg. All categories of cows eased by up to 20c on last sale, with heavy 4 score cows to slaughter topping at 224c, down 15c/kg. Heavy 3 score cows to slaughter, topped at 219c to average 214c, down 19c/kg on last sale. Heavy 2 score cows to processors topped at 214c to average 207c, while restockers were active on medium weight 2 score cows to 200c, averaging 188c/kg. Grown heifers to slaughter sold to 249c, while heavy heifers to feed sold to 260c/kg. A smaller offering of heavy bulls to processors sold to 247c, while medium and heavy weight bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 246c/kg. Young males to restockers sold generally higher, topping at 346c, to average 325c/kg. Good quality cows and calves sold to $1,140/unit.

Numbers declined by more than 1600 for a yarding of 1428 cattle.  Quality was very mixed, with only a small selection of heavy bullocks, less than 250 prime cows and many smaller mixed lines of steers and heifers. Only three regular processors were operating, with subdued demand throughout.  Regular feeders and opportunity coastal restockers operated selectively. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa to Georgetown and the local area.  

Prices continued an easing trend for most categories, better quality lines  of yearling steers and heifers eased 20c to 40c, prime bullocks and cows eased by 10c to 30c/kg, however medium and heavy bulls were firm to 10c dearer.

A reduced supply of young vealer steers returning to the paddock averaged 232 topping at 280c. Vealer heifers met limited demand, selling at reduced rates. Heifers under 200kg averaged 160c, better quality heifers above 200kg sold to 210c to average 187c/kg. Small lines of yearling steers above 280kg to backgrounders reached 238c, steers above 330kg averaged 223c/kg.  A limited supply of yearling heifers above. 330kg to feed made to 220c to average 214c/kg.

A mixed offering of grown steers to feed reached 240c to average 218c, best quality grown heifers to the trade sold to and averaged 220c/kg.

A limited supply of heavy bullocks to export slaughter met subdued demand, topping at 230. Reduced processor demand saw medium weight 3 score cows sold to 194c to average 181c and a small number of single sale prime heavyweight cows topped at 195c to average 194c/kg. Heavy bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 270c to average 251c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Numbers declined by 104 head to 1,020 for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week. The sale comprised several very good lines of prime cows and small lines of bullocks which both eased 8c to12c/kg, supported by several small lines of store steers and heifers that sold to limited competition. All processors were in attendance and operating, accompanied by one feeder buyer for live export and a limited gallery of restockers. Cattle were drawn from Croydon, Hugenden, Greenvale, Tully, Giru, local and coastal areas.

The few vealer steers sold to mixed demand, with the heavier better quality lines increasing 6c to 308c, averaging 293c, with plainer types topping at 322c/kg. Yearling steers were of very mixed quality and the small number sold to limited demand, topping at 278c/kg, with insufficient number to quote trends. Vealer heifers sold lower on last sale with many small lines and variation in quality and weight. Light vealer heifers to slaughter sold to 239c to average 236c, while larger framed heifers to restockers to 278c to average 271c/kg. The small number of yearling heifers to restockers reached 228c to average 220c/kg.

A small number of heavy 3 score bullocks sold 7c lower topping at 266c, with plainer types to feed destined for live export to 254c/kg. A number of well finished grown steers to slaughter sold to 256c, with similar types to feed also to live export to 258c/kg. A very good offering of cows dominated the sale and saw values generally ease on last sale and in line with southern markets, with best extra heavy 3 score cows to slaughter selling to 223c and 4 score cows to 224c/kg. Heavy C muscled 3 score cows sold to 220c to average 210c, with 3 score D muscled cows averaging 202c/kg. Heavy 2 score cows to processors sold to 221c to average 211c, with medium weight 2 score cows averaging 169c/kg. Grown heifers topped at 250c, easing 9c to average 234c, while a restocker was active on plainer types to 228c/kg. Heavy bulls increased in number and sold to much stronger prices due to a live export order, with most heavy 3 score bulls to slaughter making 269c, and similar bulls to live export making 268c to average 263c/kg. A small number of young males to restockers sold to 280c/kg. A small number of aged cows and calves sold to $820/unit.

Number reduced dramatically as quality too started to fall. All the regular buyers were operating on the yarding of predominately local cattle.  Values were varied with steers dearer, yet cows were mostly cheaper. 

Light steers in pen lots sold to 137.2c as plain lines averaged 105c/kg. A large number of good heavy steers sold to 159.2c to average 157c/kg. Light export heifers made to 129.2c, most closer to 117.6c/kg. 

Cows dominated the sale with most selling to a cheaper market. Light D2s averaged 112.2c as others made to 129.2c/kg. Plain E1s averaged 71.6c/kg. Medium weight D3s averaged 121.7c as the D4s topped at 137.2c/kg. 

A fair percentage of the bulls were plain lines, while a single C2 heavy weight reached 120.2c/kg.

Number increased considerably as did quality with a much better overall yarding than last weeks sale. The entire field of regular buyers attended the sale plus some additional southern support. Prices were generally dearer with keen demand for all heavier weight cattle. 

A number of large lines of steers were a standout in the grown cattle sale with some very good steers from the Homestead region selling in excess of 170c/kg. All weights and grades lifted in price with the medium weight lines selling from 151.2c to 171.2c a gain of 5c/kg. Heavy steers sold from 165.2c to 174.2c and a very good offering of bullocks lifted 9c/kg averaging $1,109/head.  

Cow prices continued their upward trend with all weights improving, lightweights jumped between 4c and 7c to average 139.3c/kg for the 3 scores. The greatest percentage of medium weights gained 9c selling from 137.2c to 155.2c and the heavyweight lines averaged 155.2c/kg.

Number increased by more than 350 head to 1,954 cattle for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, featuring several good quality lines of prime cow and one large line of northern bred steers. All major processors were in attendance, but not operating, while one feeder buyer had limited participation, supported by one live exporter and several restockers and onlookers. The larger offering of light and feeder weight steers sold slightly easier on last sale, while heavy 2 and 3 score cows lifted by 3c to 5c/kg and heavy bulls sold firm on last sale. Cattle were drawn from Normanton, Julia Creek, Richmond, Torrens Creek, Mt Garnet, Greenvale, Ravenswood, local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers were predominantly heavier suitable weaned types easing on last sale, topping at 288c, with most better quality lines selling from 268c to 274c/kg. A very large line of northern bred yearling steers met strong restocker interest with 280-330kg steers selling to 245c, to average 237c, while medium weight feeder steers also to restockers sold to 242c, also averaging 237c/kg. Heavy steers to restockers sold to 230c/kg. The supply of vealer heifers was insufficient to quote, however heifer calves sold to 221c/kg. There were insufficient yearling heifers to quote.

Fewer numbers of heavy bullocks were penned this week, with the reduced supply also off lesser quality and weight than recent weeks. Heavy 3 score bullocks to slaughter sold to 247c, with medium weight 3 score bullocks selling to 246c, to average 244c/kg. A small number of grown steers to feed made 218c/kg. Another very good offering of prime cows were on offer, with values generally increasing for a large selection of better quality types. Extra heavy cows improved by 1c to average 201c, topping at 207c/kg. A large sample of heavy 3 score cows sold to 206c, to average 193c, and 2 scores to processors sold to 197c, to average 188c/kg. A selection of heavy D muscled cows were of generally less weight than previous weeks, selling to 165c to average 23c lower, at 146c, while medium weight cows sold to 160c, to average 148c/kg. Cows to restockers were insufficient to quote. A larger offering of heavy bulls to live export continued recent prices, selling firm to a top of 274c, with similar types to feed destined for live export selling to 270c, with most between 250c and 260c/kg. Medium weight bulls to feed sold to 261c, with feeder weights to 235c/kg. A large offering of young males returning to grass sold to 294c, to average 253c/kg. Good quality cows and calves sold from $880 to $1,200/unit.

Number increased by 1,134 head to 2,752 cattle for Charters Towers Combined Selling agents this week, the bigger offering was comprised of some well finished lines of prime bullocks and cows, in conjunction with one large line of plainer northern store steers and heifers. All regular processors were in attendance and operating at increased prices, supported by two regular feeder buyers, one live exporter and several restockers. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Julia Creek, Croydon, Ingham, Ravenswood, Belyando, local and coastal areas.

Numbers lifted considerably due to a large line of light northern vealer steers which sold to 370c, averaging up 13c on last sale to 369c, with a large number of light steers(less than 200kg) averaging 323c/kg. Yearling steers were more variable and also lifted in price, with feeder weights to live export reaching 315c, and averaging 256c, while steers to restockers sold to 326c to average 323c/kg. Heavy feeder steers to feed sold 285c/kg. Vealer heifers most notably consisted of one northern line of light weight types selling to 298c for those returning to grass, averaging 283c, with multiple lines of better finished types to live export selling to 272c/kg. Yearling heifers of feeder specifications to live export sold to 285c, averaging 284c, while heifers returning to grass sold to 283c for lighter types and up to 300c/kg for heavier, better grown types. Grown heifers returned to grass sold to 305c with most sales between 242 and 266c/kg.

One very good line of heavy 3 score bullocks to slaughter sold to 275c, averaging 268c, with multiple lines selling for 272c/kg. Lighter conditioned bullocks returning to grass sold to 261c, to average 250c/kg. A larger offering of grown steers sold to similar prices to slaughter, reaching 275c to average 268c/kg. Heavy feeder steers to live export sold to 292c to average 287c, with plainer types returning to paddock making 289c/kg. Well finished heavy C muscled cows to slaughter sold to 260c, lifting 6c to average 234c, while heavy cows above 520kg sold to 247c to average 246c/kg. Heavy D muscled cows sold to 237c, to average 226c, up 3c, with 2 score cows averaging 209c/kg. A small number of lighter cows to restockers sold to 181c/kg. A small number of heavy bulls to slaughter sold to 254c, while suitable types to live export sold to 258c/kg. Feeder bulls to live export made to 300c, with most sales between 260 and 290c/kg. Light males to restockers sold to 318c/kg. Several small lines of cows and calves sold to $1,500/unit.

Not all the regular buyers were in attendance although there was added competition from wholesalers. The reduced yarding was mainly due to some stock not arriving at the market until after curfew and they were sold as store cattle at the completion of the sale. Trends followed those set across the state and the mainly poorer quality yarding generally lost ground. Cows were in dominant numbers although steers and heifers were well represented. 

The light steers were of poor quality, which was reflected, in low prices and the D2s averaged 113.7c/kg. Medium weights made up to the majority of the steer section and lost around 10c to 11c and the D3s averaged 135.5c/kg. The heavier steers faired a little better and were from 1c to 5c cheaper, which saw the better quality stock averaged 145.1c/kg. 

Grown heifers improved in value and the D3s averaged 120.4c/kg. The large number of cows offered were of plainer quality and the light weights lost up to 7c as the struggled to reach 100c and the D1s averaged 94c/kg. The medium weights saw a large number of D1s averaged 97.7c while the D2s averaged 103.4c/kg. 

A handful of bulls lost ground and the heavy weights averaged 104.9c/kg.

Not all buyers were present and of those that were, not all operated, on a mostly poor quality smaller yarding. With the majority of the yarding comprising store drafts only one processor purchased the majority of suitable export cattle, while the remainder was purchased by trader and butcher buyers. 

Grown steers were in limited number with light weights averaging between 103.4c and 128.5c/kg. Heifers comprised mostly medium weight D2s and they improved slightly to average 135.9c after topping at 139.2c/kg.

Cow were of mostly under 400kg descriptions and sold at an average of 119.2c after topping at 126.2c/kg. Bulls were of poor quality and topped at 110c/kg.

Most of the usual buyers were in attendance although the market sold to subdued competition. The smaller yarding was reported to be of poorer quality and it would appear producers held off yarding stock following the cheaper markets of the last month. Prices were much cheaper on the quotable grades and the cows, which made up over half the yarding lost up to 24c/kg. 

Close to half the steers were poor quality lightweights that sold to restockers at 105c/kg. An accurate trend is not possible on the remaining stock that sold to a top of 130.2c/kg. 

The grown heifers sold to 124.2c and the poorer quality stock averaged 86.9c/kg. The light cows reached 75c/kg. The medium weights topped at 95c and most were around 17c and 18c cheaper, which saw a large number of D2s averaged around 80c/kg.

Limited supply led to another reduced yarding of mixed quality. All but one of the regular processors were present and all local buyers attended. Steers were in better condition than the previous sale but cows were of poorer quality. 

Grown steers sold to strong processor competition, medium weights averaged 161.4c after selling to 170.2c/kg. Heavy weight C3 types remained fully firm and sold mostly around 172c/kg. The better quality D2s improved slightly to sell to 125.2c, averaging 120.7c/kg. 

A plainer quality cow yarding sold to a dearer trend, possibly as a result of the lower numbers. Light weight D2s averaged 126.6c after topping at 132.2c/kg. Heavy cows were mostly D3 descriptions and they sold to 146.2c to average 141.1c/kg. Most bulls were light weights and they topped at 118.2c/kg.

Large numbers continue with 2,020 cattle penned in a prime only sale today, with 4,200 cattle booked for a store sale on Friday. Quality was very mixed - ranging from some very good quality lines of heavy prime cows along to lines of northern pastoral cows and bulls. All the regular processors operated at stronger rates in line with recent grid adjustments, along with two live exporters, regular feeders and backgrounders. Grown steers increased 7c, heifers lifted 9c and cows to processors sold 9c to 17c/kg higher. Cattle were drawn from far northern and western areas, with many small lines from the local area. 

Yearling steers to feed sold to 426c to average from 397c to 410c/kg. Yearling heifers above 330kg to feed sold to a top of 402c to average 394c/kg. Grown steers above 400kg to feed reached 400c and averaged 371c, while heavy trade types reached 378c/kg to average the same. A good sample of suitable heavy steers to live export averaged 374c/kg. Grown heifers to the trade topped at 338c to average 327c and heifers to feed made to 368c to average 342c/kg.   

Small lines of heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter sold to 376c, averaging near 360c/kg. Very strong demand for cows continued with all processors very active throughout the offering. A small sample of medium weight score 2 cows sold to a top of 310c, while score 3 cows reached 324c to average 311c/kg. Prime heavy weight cows topped at 327c to average 318c/kg. Light cows to restockers averaged 283c and medium weight cows to restockers sold to 308c to average 302c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export sold to a top of 378c to average 321c and bulls to processors averaged 297c/kg. 

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

It was a very small yarding of mostly plain cattle. All the regular buyers attended but not all made purchases as one major processor is yet to open it s operating plant in that region of the state. As a result competition was weaker and the market sold to local butchers and one or two processor buyers only. 

Steers averaged 117.3c/kg while the limited number of heifers were bought by local butchers. 

A plain quality cow yarding eased on last weeks levels, lightweight D2s managed 103.6c while medium weights averaged 110.1c/kg.

It was a reduced yarding of 913 cattle for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents, 207 head fewer than last sale, with many lines showing the effects of the season. Some isolated storms over the past week contributed to the reduced yarding, with limited numbers of prime bullocks and cows selling to dearer prices. The regular buyer panel of processors, live exporters and one feeder buyer were in attendance and operating strongly throughout, although the limited numbers of store cattle penned saw minimal restocker activity. Cattle were drawn from Mount Isa, Normanton, Einasleigh, Greenvale, local and coastal areas.

There were insufficient numbers of vealer steers to quote, with one pen making 280c/kg. Yearling steers were also in limited supply, as steers above 330kg and going to live export sold for 276c, while those above 380kg made 282c/kg. A very small offering of vealer heifers returning to grass made to 180c and yearling heifers to feed sold to 236c to average 225c/kg.

Despite the limited numbers, some good pens of heavy export bullocks lifted 4c, reaching 294c and averaging 291c, while 4 score bullocks sold to 299c/kg. Younger and lighter medium weight bullocks sold to 298c, averaging 293c, up 12c/kg on last sale. A single heavy grown steer to processors sold for 310c, with similar steers making from 274c to 299c/kg. The quality and weight of heavy cows was generally below that of the previous few months, with several lines showing the effect of the season. However, competition was still strong throughout. Heavy 3 score cows improved by 5c, with 3 scores reaching 252c to average 236c, while 4 score cows sold to 242c/kg. Heavy 3 score D muscled cows sold to 228c, lifting 12c to average above 222c, while medium weight 2 score cows lifted 10c to average 185c/kg. Light 1 and 2 score cows to processors also improved by 6c to 10c/kg. Some very good lines of grown heifers to processors improved by 25c, reaching a top of 271c to average 260c/kg. Some large lines of northern bulls met strong demand, with most types lifting 5c to 20c/kg. Heavy 3 score bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 269c to average 260c and heavy 2 score bulls made to 270c to average 261c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors eased 14c making to 244c, while 2 score bulls sold to 231c, with most sales making from 216c 230c/kg. Feeder bulls weighing 280-360kg destined for live export, sold to 278c, with most sales making from 230c to 255c/kg. A small sample of young males weighing 280-330kg sold to live export for 272c/kg.

It was a reduced yarding compared to the previous week, with 2,083 head drawn by Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents. A full gallery of regular processors and western restockers competed on a mixed quality yarding ahead of a promising weather forecast. Cattle were drawn from Normanton, Croydon, Georgetown, Richmond, Ingham, Woodstock and local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers were of mixed quality, however restockers were very active throughout. Light weight vealer steers topped at 366.2c, with many lines selling above 360.2c and averaging 352.3c/kg. Yearling steers to feed topped at 296.8c, while those to restockers sold to 315.2c/kg. Vealer heifers were in good supply and in strong demand, selling to 318.2c and averaging 298.6c/kg. Yearling heifers were of very good quality, with very strong competition from feeder and restocker buyers. Feeder weight heifers sold to 311.2c and averaged 294.4c, while yearling heifers to restockers sold to 312.2c, to average 278.6c/kg.

Grown steers sold to 328.2c/kg. An increased number of bullocks sold strongly, with heavy 3 score bullocks selling to 299.2c/kg for slaughter types. Restockers were active on 2 score and lighter weight bullocks which topped at 276.2c/kg. Heavy 3 score cows were fewer in number than previous weeks, with values decreasing by up to 10c/kg. They sold to a top of 254.2c and averaged 235.1c/kg. Heavy 2 score cows sold to 241.2c and averaged 227.8c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows to slaughter returned an average of 214.8c and sold to 229.2c, while cows to restockers sold to 220.2c/kg. A limited number of heavy heifers to slaughter sold to 267.2c/kg. A large number of mixed quality bulls were offered, with heavy 3 score bulls to slaughter topping at 269.2c, while a live exporter paid to 278.2c/kg for medium and heavy 2 score bulls. Medium weight bulls to feed, destined for live export sold to 314.2c/kg, while younger males sold to 350.2c/kg.

A limited number of mixed quality cows and calves sold to $1,200/unit.

It was a mainly poor quality yarding which saw most stock in store condition although the heifers were of better quality and sold to increased butcher competition. Values for these improved while the cows and light quality steers were cheaper. Most of the regular buyers were in attendance however competition was subdued on the small poor quality yarding. 

The light steers topped at 112.2c to average 109c while the best medium weights reached 119.2c/kg. The better quality heifers improved by 8c and averaged 115.4c after they topped at 127.2c/kg. 

Light cows were firm to 6c cheaper and the better grades sold around 78c/kg. The medium weight cows lost from 4c to 11c and most averaged 96c after the D3s topped at 108.2c/kg. Heavy bulls sold to a top of 109.2c/kg.

Isolated storms across the supply area reduced numbers by 420 head to 2587 cattle this week in very humid conditions.  Several lines of good conditioned cows were presented with overall quality generally good for both prime and store cattle.  The regular buyer panel of processors, backgrounders and feeders was bolstered by two opportunity central restockers operating strongly throughout.  Cattle were drawn from Cloncurry, Richmond, Ingham, Belyando, local and coastal areas.  Most categories improved by 5-20c, with strong demand throughout the sale.

Increased numbers of steer calves returning to grass sold to 506.2c to average 475c, while heifer calves to processors reached 420.2c to average near 418c/kg.  A large sample of vealer steers above 200kg returning to grass reached 488c to average 469c/kg and steers above 280kg to feed topped at 446.2c  to average 420-426c/kg.  Vealer heifers above 200kg to processors made to 424.2c to average from 388-416c and heifers to feed destined for slaughter sold to 418.2c to average 396c/kg.  A reduced supply of yearling steers to feed sold to 446.2c to average 410-424c/kg.  Yearling heifers above 280kg to feed topped 368.2c averaging 335-361c/kg.

Grown steers above 400kfg to feed reached 357.2c, with trade types also reaching 357.2c.  Good quality lines of grown heifers to the trade sold to 336.2c to average 308c, with lesser quality lnes averaging 272c/kg.  Heavy full mouthed bullcoks to export slaughter sold to 357.2c/kg.  Several lines of medium weight 3 score cows sold to 307.2c to average 267c and prime heavyweight cows averaged 281c/kg.  heavy bulls to live export topped at 340.2c to average 323c/kg.  Small lines of cows and calves sold to $1720/unit.

Isolated storms across the region and a store sale on Friday with 3,600 head booked, resulted in numbers easing by 1,656 head to 1,943 cattle this week.  Records tumbled for heavy cows and bulls in spirited competition, with heifers and steers to the trade up by 20c for most categories, cows eased 5c and bulls were up by 3 to 5c/kg. Quality was generally good, led by one large single vendor line of grain-fed heifers and some very good pens of heavy prime cows. All regular processors were in attendance, supported by two live exporters, central and southern feeder buyers and restockers from the south and west. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Normanton, Pentland, Greenvale, Belyando as well as local and coastal areas.

Heifer calves returning to grass sold to a top of 452.2c with steer calves from the same draft also making to 452.2c/kg. A small number of vealer steers sold to a top of 400.2c to average 393c/kg. Yearling steers above 330kg to feed reached 382.2c with most sales making from 358c to 378c/kg. Yearling heifers to feed above 330kg sold to a top of 345.2c to average 330c, with heavy heifers to feed topping at 354.2c to average 351c/kg. A large line of grainfed yearling heifers to the trade sold to a top of 360.2c to average 353c/kg. Grown steers to live export topped at 366.2c to average 357c with steers to processors reaching 376.2c to average 352c/kg. Grown heifers to the trade topped at 366.2c to average 350c while heifers to feed averaged from 328c to 347c/kg. Due to there being limited numbers of heavy bullocks, this category was not quoted. 

Cow prices hit all time highs, heavy cows (speyed and PTE) to live export sold to 370.2c, with a large sample averaging 345c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 292.2c to average above 278c, while 3 score cows made to a top of 306.2c to average from 278c to 293c/kg. Prime heavy weight 4 score cows sold to a top of 300.2c to average 295c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export also sold to new highs, selling to a top of 370.2c to average from 362c to 369c/kg. Medium weight bulls to background feed for live export averaged from 296c to 303c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors sold to a top of 376.2c to average above 374c/kg.

Isolated showers and storms across much of the local area saw a reduced yarding of 1,380 cattle in a prime only sale. A store sale scheduled for Friday has 3,000 head currently booked. Quality was well below recent weeks, with several lines of northern pastoral cows and bulls, along with many local lines showing the effects of the lengthening dry season. All processors were active for the quality on offer along with regular feeders, backgrounders and opportunity restockers. Grown steers increased 6c, heifers to the trade were 4c easier, bullocks were firm, cows to processors averaged 7c to 13c/kg higher and heavy bulls were firm. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Burketown, Normanton, Pentland Ayr, local and coastal areas.  

A good supply grown steers met strong demand with those to feed reaching 396c to average 386c and heavy trade types sold to 390c to average between 363c and 385c/kg. Plainer conditioned steers to restockers averaged from 374c to 396c/kg. Reduced numbers of grown heifers to the trade sold to 348c and averaged between 323c and 346c, while a small sample of heifers to feed averaged 354c/kg.

A good supply of heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter reached 388c multiple times to average from 374c to 380c and 2 scores averaged 362c/kg. A rain affected reduction in the supply of cows resulted in very strong demand for the reduced quality on offer. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors made to 328c to average 319c and 3 scores topped at 346c to average 332c/kg. A small sample of prime heavy weight cows averaged 343c and a good line of grain fed cows averaged 332c/kg. Strong demand for plainer conditioned cows saw those returning to grass sell to 308c to average from 278c to 300c/kg. Heavy bulls suitable for live export topped at 368c to average between 350c and 367c and heavy bulls to processors averaged 323c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

Isolated showers across the region and a return to a combined prime and store sale, saw 2,882 cattle penned this week. Quality was mixed throughout, however some very good lines of prime cows, steers and heifers were on offer. One major export processor was again absent from the gallery, however one southern processor attended for the first time this year, supported by regular feeder and background operators, restockers and two live exporters who were all active throughout the sale. Strong demand from processors saw cows selling firm, steers to feed eased, while yearling heifers sold to stronger rates for the improved quality. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Burketown, Richmond, Mt Surprise, Mareeba, Tully, Townsville, Ayr, Collinsville, local and coastal areas. 

Steer calves returning to grass sold to a top of 492c with mixed sexes averaging 460c and heifers to the trade reaching 396c to average above 386c/kg. A good selection of vealer steers to feed reached 440c to average 437c/kg. Heifers to the trade averaged 383c while restocker lines sold higher to 434c to average 432c/kg. A very good line of heifers above 330kg to backgrounders reached 418c to average 389c/kg. A small sample of yearling steers above 330kg to feed sold to a top of 398c and backgrounder steers averaged 378c/kg.
