Yearling heifers above 280kg to feed sold from 330c to 358c and restocker lines averaged 368c/kg. Grown steers were once again well supplied with the best heavy steers above 500kg to the trade selling to a top of 368c to average 351c, while steers above 400kg to feed sold to 370c, averaging from 327c to 336c/kg. Grown steers to live export topped at 360c to average from 345c to 356c/kg. Grown heifers to the trade reached 328c to average 319c/kg. 

The supply and quality of heavy full-mouthed bullocks was mixed, with the best types to export slaughter reaching 368c and averaging from 311c to 326c/kg. Strong demand by processors for cows continued with medium weight score 2 cows to processors reaching 280c to average 269c, while score 3 cows topped at 290c multiple times to average from 279c to 288c/kg. A large sample of prime heavy weight cows sold to a top of 296c to average 290c/kg. PTIC cows sold from 276c to 298c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export topped at 365c to average near 350c and similar bulls to feed destined for live export averaged from 308c to 340c/kg. Good lines of young males returning to the paddock sold to a top of 438c to average 429c/kg. There was insufficient number of cows and calves to reliably quote. 

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

Isolated rain events across much of the north and a scheduled store sale on Friday, numbers fell to 582 cattle in a Prime only sale. The regular buyer panel operated at similar rates to last sale despite a smaller offering, with some very good quality lines of heavy grown steers, bullocks and cows penned. Grown steers to feed lifted 21c to 25c, bullocks improved 6c, heavy cows to processors were 6c to 15c dearer and bulls increased by 6c/kg. Cattle were drawn from Richmond, Hughenden, Pentland, Mt Garnet, Ingham, local and coastal areas. 

Limited number of yearling steers sold to feed, reaching 494.2c to average 484c/kg. Yearling heifers to feed sold for 398.2c/kg. Very good quality grown steers above 400kg to feed reached 488.2c to average 466c, while single trade types selling for 426.2c/kg. A small sample of grown heifers to the trade made 400.2c to average 397c/kg. 

A reduced supply of heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 450.2c to average 440-443c/kg, while 4 scores sold for 442c/kg. Cows continued recent strong demand for all categories. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 398.2c to average 377c and 3 scores reached 398.2c to average 384c/kg. A small sample of prime heavyweight 3 and 4 score cows topped at 396.2c multiple times to average 394c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors sold to 380.2c to average from 364c to 370c/kg, with similar bulls to feed selling to 368.2c to average near 330c/kg. 

A scheduled store sale on Friday has 2,500 head booked.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Included in the larger yarding were large lines of even cattle, which improved the overall quality. As the supply area stays dry and the prices stay high it is expected that producers will keep offloading cattle through the yards. All the regular buyers were active with values improving for all descriptions with the cows gaining the most. 

Most of the steers offered were medium weights selling to a top of 193.2c/kg. The heavy steers were in relatively small numbers for the size of the yarding, and reached 195.2c/kg to return over $1,100/head. All of the heavy bullocks returned over $1,100/head with over 140 averaging 193.3c/kg.

The light heifers received further gains with the D3s gaining 14c after selling to 178.2c/kg. The light cows were in large numbers but this had no negative effect on values, as the D2s averaged 145.5c/kg. The top of the cows was the medium weights selling to 179.2c/kg.  

All classes of bulls were offered in larger numbers with values improving further. The heavy bulls sold to 176.2c/kg to return over $1,200/head.

In very humid conditions, a yarding of 1,914 cattle was penned in a Combined Prime and Store sale, 270 more than the sale a fortnight ago.  Quality was mixed with limited numbers of well finished cattle offered.  A large offering of cows and calves were offered by several vendors.  All regular processors were in attendance and operating, supported by opportunity feeders, backgrounders and southern restockers. Cattle were drawn from Hughenden, Ingham, Belyando and the local area.

Light restocker steer calves sold to 826.2c top average 803c/kg. Good quality light vealer steers to restockers sold to 804.2c and steers above 200kg returning to grass reached 810.2c to average 756-759c/kg. A small sample of good quality vealer heifers to the trade sold to 640.2c to average 596-631c/kg.   Light yearling steers above 200kg to backgrounders sold to 706.2c to average 678c and steers above 280kg averaged 627c/kg. Light yearling heifers under 200kg to southern backgrounders reached 720.2c/kg to average same. A large sample above 200kg to feed reached 684.2c to average 495c/kg. And the 591c/kg. Good quality yearling heifers above 330kg to feed sold to 476.2c to average 432-443c/kg. 

A limited supply of grown steers above 400kg to feed sold to 428.2c to average near 400c/kg.  Grown heifers were also in limited supply to feed up to 410.2c to average 379c/kg.  Bullocks were too few to quote.

Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 358.2c to average 341c and a large sample of 3 scores reached 398.2c to average from 379-393c/kg. A good sample of lightweight cows returning to grass sold to 342.2c to average 301-332c/kg. Processor activity on bulls was limited to suitable heavyweight types reaching 384.2c to average 373c/kg.  Young males returning to the paddock sold to 728.2c to average 665c/kg.

A large offering of cows and calves met strong demand selling with good quality cows and calf units selling from sold from $2,200 to $2,800 per unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

In very humid conditions and with isolated storms across the northern region, a yarding of 1,718 mostly good quality cattle were penned in a prime only sale. A store sale on Friday has more than 4,000 head booked. More than half of the yarding comprised of grown steers and bullocks including one single vendor line, along with several smaller lines of good quality prime cows. The regular buyer panel was in attendance and operated at stronger rates throughout on last sale. Grown steers improved 6c to 10c, heifers lifted 8c, bullocks increased 22c, heavy cows lifted 4c to 8c and heavy bulls averaged 8c/kg higher. Cattle were drawn from Normanton, Croydon, Mt Surprise, Richmond, Hughenden, Belyando, Ayr, local and coastal areas.  

A good supply of heavy yearling steers above 400kg to feed sold to 464c to average 448c while grown steers above 400kg to feed averaged 446c/kg. A large single vendor line of heavy grown steers to the trade topped at 446c to average 440c, with similar plainer conditioned steers to feed averaging 445c/kg. Heavy grown heifers to the trade topped at 424c to average 401c and lighter conditioned heifers to feed averaged from 371c to 407c/kg.  

A good sample of heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 440c, to average from 434c to 439c/kg. Processor demand for cows remains very strong with medium weight 2 score cows to processors selling to 378c to average 367c and 3 scores reached 394c to average from 374c to 385c/kg.  Some good pens of prime heavy weight cows topped at 396c to average 389c/kg. A line of heavy grain-fed cows averaged 382c/kg. Fewer numbers of light conditioned cows to restockers sold to 358c to average 337c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors sold to 368c to average from 348c to 366c/kg. A small number of cows and calves sold to $2,340/unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

In very hot conditions, the opening sale of 2025 saw 1517 cattle penned in a very mixed quality yarding. Only three  regular processors were operating along with one live exporter and one feeder supported by opportunity restockers and backgrounders. Cattle were drawn from Georgetown to Richmond, then south and east to local and coastal areas. 

Less than one third of the yarding consisted of prime cattle, with only a few lines of good quality store lines penned. Competition was good for better quality, however secondary and lighter conditioned types met limited demand. Values were reflective of quality and mostly eased in line with other selling centres. 

Good quality light suitably weaned steers sold to 300c to average 285c, similar steers above 200kg returning to the paddock reached 320c to average 319c/kg. Light yearling steers to backgrounders averaged 266c, a good sample to feed made to 282c to average 245c/kg.  Yearling steers above 280kg to live export sold to 314c to average 313c, steers above 330kg averaged 290c/kg. Yearling heifers above 200kg to grass sold to 240c to average 211c, processor types sold to 280c to average 264c/kg. Heifers to feed above 330kg reached 278c to average 247c to 269c/kg. Grown steers above 400kg to the trade sold to 318c, heavy steers above 500kg topped at 341c/kg. Good quality heavy grown heifers to the trade made to 280c to average 269c/kg. 

A limited supply of heavy full mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 331c to average 329c/kg. Medium weight 3 score cows to processors sold to 270c to average 248c, a small sample of prime heavyweight  3 and 4 score cows averaged 266c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export made from 260c to 290c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

In very hot and humid conditions, numbers eased by 354 head to 3,492 cattle in a Combined Prime & Store Sale.  Overall quality was very good with increased numbers of well finished prime cows, and a larger offering of cows and calves which set a new saleyard record.  All regular processors were in attendance, but one did not operate, supported by two live exporters, regular feeders, backgrounders and opportunity restockers, who operated strongly throughout the sale. Prices for better quality lines improved in many categories, particularly for cows suitable to restockers, and younger feeder lines.  Cattle were drawn from Hughenden, Georgetown, Greenvale, Townsville, Collinsville, local and coastal areas.

Light vealer steers to southern restockers topped at 854.2c to average 835c, with a large sample above 200kg also making to 854.2c to average 768c/kg. Light vealer heifers reached 710.2c to average 700c, while a large sample of similar heifers above 200kg to southern restockers sold to 708.2c to average 661c/kg.  Suitable heifers to the trade sold to 636.2c to average 593c to 603c/kg. Good quality heifers above 280kg returning to grass for breeding made to 646.2c to average 633c/kg. Light weight yearling steers above 200kg to backgrounders sold to 738.2c to average 630c/kg. A good sample of steers above 330kg to backgrounders sold to 646.2c to average 628c/kg. Yearling heifers to feed above 330kg topped at 506.2c, averaging 486c to 496c/kg.

Fewer numbers of grown steers above 400kg to feed sold to 516.2c to average 491c to 512c/kg. An increased supply of grown heifers to feed topped at 496.2c averaging 428c to 458c/kg. The suitable trade types reached 434.2c to average 418 to 428c/kg. Some good pens of heavy full-mouthed bullocks topped at 456.2c to average 438c to 455c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors reached 396.2c to average 372c/kg. The and 3 scores sold to 402.2c to average 397c/kg, with prime heavy weights topping at 408.2c to average 400c/kg. Cows to live export sold to 402.2c to average 390c to 400c/kg. A good line of PTIC cows to restockers topped at 424.2c to average 422c/kg. Heavy weight bulls to live exports sold to 430c to average 390c to 424c/kg. Medium weight bulls to feed reached 582.2c to average 533c/kg. Light weight males returning to grass sold to 852.2c to average 779c/kg.

Increased numbers of good quality cows and calves sold to very strong gallery demand, selling from $2,700 to a saleyard record $3,750/unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

In the second sale for 2023, there were 1980 cattle penned.  Quality was mostly very good, with a good sample of prime cows and grown steers, supported by some large lines of steers and heifers. All regular processors operated at reduced rates in line with recent grid adjustments, supported by one regular feeder buyer and opportunity restockers. Cattle were drawn from Richmond and Hughenden, north to Lakeland and south to Belyando, local and coastal areas.

Young steers to grass topped at 472.2c to average 420c/kg. Yearling steers below 280kg returning to the paddock sold to 448.2c to average 409c, while steers above 330kg to backgrounders reached 342.2 to average 334c/kg. A good sample of prime yearling steers to processors sold to 310.2c to average 305c/kg. A large sample of yearling heifers above 280kg met strong restocker demand, topping at 338.2c to average 321c/kg, with heifers above 330kg to grass for breeding topping at 446.2c/kg.

Grown steers to feed sold to 330.2c to average 308c and trade types reached 328c to average 291c to 299c/kg. Grown heifers to the trade sold to 296.2c to average 290c/kg. Young bullocks to processors topped at 300.2c, most sales from 260c to 280c/kg. 

Medium weight 3 score cows to processors sold to 268.2c to average 245c and prime heavyweight cows topped at 296.2c to average 290c/kg.  Heavy bulls to processors sold to 308.2c to average 278c/kg. Very good quality cows and calves sold to $2,510 per unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

In line with the other selling centres this week, values at Charters Towers for the 756 head offered on  Thursday were easier.  The sale was held in cold and wet conditions.  

In the steers, the lighter types sold to 120.2c isolated with a good sample of D2 s in the medium range selling to 122.2c/kg.  The C3 heavier steers made to 129.6c/kg to average 126c while C3 bullocks topped at 128.2c/kg. The  D2 heifers sold up to 111.4c/kg. 

Heavy cows sold to 110.2c/kg in two different categories while bulls made to 112.2c/kg.

In a prime only sale, numbers fell to 753 cattle,  840 fewer prime cattle than last week.  Quality was very mixed, comprising of several small lines of prime cows and an increase number of plain conditioned cows and grown heifers.  The buyer panel consisted of most regular processors, opportunity feeders and local backgrounders and one restocker.  Cattle were drawn from Croydon, Greenvale, Belyando and the local area.

Values eased in line with other selling centres, grown heifers were down 25c, cows eased 19c to 22c, bullocks fell 13c and bulls averaged 14c lower.

A small number of grown steers to feed sold to 264c/kg. A good line of plain conditioned heifers returning to the paddock sold for 226c, while heifers to the trade sold to 246c to average 237c/kg.

A reduced number of heavy bullocks to export processors sold to 255.2c to average 246c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 188c to average 176c and 3 scores reached 196.2c to average 192c/kg. A good sample of prime heavyweight cows topped at 214c to average 211c/kg. Heavy bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 279c, most sales between 250 and 264c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

In a prime only sale, Charters Towers agents penned 1150 cattle.  Quality was mostly good throughout consisting of a  larger number of heavy bullocks and 820 cows presenting with good weight and condition.  The buyer panel was bolstered by one additional central processor and feeder, with demand strong across all categories.  Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Richmond, Einasleigh, Mt Garnet, local and coastal areas. 

Grown steers above 400kg to feed averaged 297c and sold to 302, while heavy steers to the trade reached 302c multiple times. An increased supply of young bullocks to export slaughter sold to 316.2c to average 307 to 311c/kg.  A good sample of grown heifers to the trade made to 294c with most selling from 272c to 280c/kg.

A significant increase in the number of cows offered attracted strong demand throughout. Medium weight 2 score cows to restockers averaged 236c. Three scores topped at 282.2c to average 252c to 257c/kg.  A large sample of prime heavyweight cows topped at 272c to average 262c/kg.  Increased processor demand for heavy bulls pushed values to a top of 310.2 to average 277c or 296c/kg.

A store sale scheduled for Friday has 4,500 head booked.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

In a prime only sale there was a yarding of 1727 cattle.  Quality was similar to last week with some good quality bullocks and prime cows on offer, supported by improved quality heavy bulls.  One regular processor was absent which impacted values throughout the sale, however one southern processor was active along with regular feeder buyers.  Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa  to Croydon, south to Greenvale, with many from the local area.

Grown steers to feed eased 10c to 16c, with processors types averaging 36c lower. Grown heifers averaged 27c less, bullocks fell 40c to 43c, heavy cows fell 13c to 17c and bulls to processors averaged 40c lower.

A good sample of grown steers above 400kg to feed sold to 402.2c to average 380c  and steers to processors topped at 364.2c to average from 341c to 350c/kg.  Grown heifers to the trade made to 346.2c to average 323c and heifers to feed reached 370.2c to average 348c/ kg.  A good supply of full mouth bullocks to export slaughter sold to 346.2c to average 332c/kg.

Reduced competition impacted cow values. A reduced supply of 2 score cows sold easier, averaging 290c with a top of 314c, while 3 scores sold to 332.2c to average from 308c to 332c/kg.   Prime heavyweight cows topped at 334.2c to average 330c/kg.  Heavy bulls to processors sold to 288.2 averaging from 266c to 276c/kg.

A store sale scheduled for Friday has 4,300 head booked.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

In a pre Easter sale the Charters Towers agents yarded a slightly increased offering of cattle on Thursday. The market was cheaper overall, however some export heifers and bulls managed to display a dearer market. Once again females dominated the offering with increased numbers of steers, especially on the medium weight ranges. 

The grown steers and bullocks saw a sample of D2 medium weight steers sell to 123.8c/kg with their average at 119.7c/kg. In the heavier categories the same grade topped at 123.6c to average at 121.6c/kg, with double the numbers of the previous week. A sample of 62 D2 grown heifers saw both ends of the prices range fall to average at 105.1c/kg, however the leaner drafts managed to pick up their averages. 

Cows displayed a cheaper trend for the majority of categories to see the medium weight D2 average at 100.2c and top at 103.2c/kg. A smaller offering of bulls saw the light weights gain on average to top at 94.2c and average 90c/kg

Half the number of cattle were penned and it was mostly a poor quality yarding.  Not all the regular buyers were in attendance and all but a handful of heifers sold to a cheaper market. 

Grown steers were 3c to 7c cheaper, the medium weights reached 135.2c and a fair sample averaged 128.9c/kg, Heavy steers topped at 145.2c and averaged 142.1c/kg.

The grown heifers received mixed trends with some better quality D3s averaging dearer at 29.3c/kg. Most of the light cows were of poor quality and a large number sold under 100c/kg. The medium weight cows reached 115.2c and the D3s averaged 113.7c while the D1s averaged 95.3c/kg.

Going against the trend of larger yardings, the agents offered a smaller number of cattle. Similar to other southern centre values suffered falls with not all buyers in operation. The quality was on par with recent weeks, but the plainer cattle are increasing, which is indicative of the current season. Cattle were drawn from the normal supply areas and west to Richmond.

Most of the steers and bullocks offered were medium weights. The light steers sold to 162.2c, as medium weights reached 191.2c/kg. A small number of better heavy weights managed to top at 200.2c with the heavy bullocks making to 198.2c/kg and averaging $1,200/head. 

The heifers in any number were dealt losses as the limited supply of C muscled types sold well to top at 167.2c/kg. The cows were dominated by light weights but the medium weights suffered the greatest losses. The best of the cows was the small number of heavy weights reaching 178.2c/kg. 

The large numbers of light bulls suffered only a small loss as the heavy weights made to 186.2c/kg.

Following useful rain across a good section of the north, numbers lifted by 1700 to 2394 cattle in a Combined Prime and Store Sale. Quality was mixed throughout, featuring 1,100 cows in the prime section with some good heavy lines presented along with fewer good quality lines of store steers and heifers.  One major export processor was in attendance but not operating in a generally weaker market. Cattle were drawn from many northern areas including Mt Isa, Burketown, Mt Garnet, Hughenden, Torrens Creek, local and coastal areas.

Young light cattle met reduced competition easing by more than 100c on many lines, yearling steers and heifers averaged 40-60c lower, while grown heifers and cows averaged 13c to 30c/kg less. Heavy bulls improved by 13c in line with quality.

Vealer steers above returning to the paddock sold to 488.2c to average 439c to 465c/kg. Light vealer heifers returning to grass sold to 400.2c to average 385c/kg. A good sample of better quality yearling steers above 280kg to feed sold to 430.2c to average 387c/kg while steers above 330kg reached 400.2c to average 376c/kg. Yearling heifers feed sold to 426.2c to average 399c/kg. Grown steers were too few to quote. Grown heifers to feed reached 350.2c to average 315c to 332c/kg while a small sample to the trade sold from 308c to 322.2c/kg.

A line of northern heavy, well finished full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 328.2c to average 306c to 311c/kg. An increased offering of cows met subdued demand in line with other selling centres. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 294.2c to average 255c while a large sample of 3 score cows to processors topped at 324.2c to average 295c to 308c/kg.  The supply of heavy bulls increased with those to feed selling to 350.2c to average to 328c to 340c/kg.

Good quality mixed age pens of cows and calves sold from $1,450 to $1,785/unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Following the week off for Anzac day, numbers decreased by more than 800 head on the sale a fortnight ago for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents which featured some very good lines of prime cows and grown heifers along with some good lines of northern steers and heifers. Two major processors continued their absence with values easing in line with recent downward grid adjustments. With the absence of any feeder buyers, restockers were selective on quality with yearling steers easing by up to 14c/kg for better quality feeder weights, while the lack of competition saw heifers suffer the largest declines across all weight ranges. Cattle were drawn from Normanton, Hughenden, Greenvale, Pentland, Woodstock, Ravenswood, Mt. Coolon, local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers were generally very good quality, but sold easier due to the lack of competition, topping at 260c, to average 247c/kg. Yearling steers largely sold 13c to 20c easier with 280-330kg steers returning to grass selling to 260c, to average 249c, while 330-400 kg steers averaged 238c/kg. Heavy feeder steers above 400kg sold to 222c/kg. Vealer heifers met limited demand across all classes, with values easing accordingly by more than 30c/kg. Vealer heifers returning to grass sold to 222c to average 180c while similar weight yearling heifers average 194c/kg. Yearling heifers above 280kg sold to 200c and were largely dominated by a large northern line.

Bullocks consisted of some good quality small lines selling firm on last sale to 244c for those to slaughter, while similar weights to live export sold to 252c, averaging 246c/kg. A similar number of grown steers above 400kg also sold firm, with a higher percentage going to feed destined for live export. These steers sold to 241c, with most sales from 200c to 227c/kg. A very good yarding of cows sold lower on last fortnight in line with recent grid adjustments and prices in southern selling centres. Extra heavy 3 score cows to processors sold to 179c and heavy cows sold to 181c to average 164c/kg. Heavy 2 score cows sold to 167c to average 154c, while light conditioned cows to restockers above 400kg sold to 162c/kg. Medium weight 3 score cows below 400kg to slaughter sold to 140c, to average 132c and light cows to restockers sold to 136c to average 111c/kg. A lift in numbers of very good grown heifers saw values ease by more than 20c, with 3 score heavy heifers to slaughter topping at 212c to average 193c, and 2 score heifers averaged 174c/kg. Heavy bulls continued recent strength topping at 271c to live export, most above 260c, with very few going to slaughter. Medium weight bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 275c, while young males returning to the paddock sold to 240c/kg.

Following the trend of other centres, numbers were less than last week as the falling market sees producers not offloading cattle. All the regular buyers were operating, but the quality of the yarding was not up to previous weeks standards. As has happened at the rest of the markets, values have suffered further falls with the steers the most affected. 

Most of the steers and bullocks offered were lighter weights but it was the heavier categories that received the greatest losses. Medium weight steers sold to 185c, with heavy weights reaching 181.2c/kg. The limited heavy bullocks all returned over $1,000/head after selling to a top of 180.2c/kg. 

The heifers held on surprisingly well to remain firm to slightly cheaper with the D3s making to 162.2c/kg. The large number of light cows reached 152.2c and went against the falling trend to gain 2c and average 131.6c/kg. The medium D3s held firm after selling to 175c/kg

The bulls were dominated by light weights as the heavy weights made to 171.2c/kg and returned over $1,100/head.

Following the trend of other centres, most descriptions sold to a dearer market as the regular panel of buyers plus an extra buyer competed strongly to secure numbers. The overall quality was reported as improved on previous weeks and this may have also played a part in the increased competition. The plainer types also sold to solid demand. 

The steers dominated the yarding with medium weights selling to 176.2c/kg. Almost two hundred and fifty heavy steers gained close to 20c after selling to 179.6c/kg. All of the heavy bullocks returned over $1,000/head with the better types selling to 178.2c/kg.

Heifers have been in demand at all centres and this continued to be the case here as the light D3s sold to 159.2c/kg. The light cows sold to 127.2c, as medium weight D3s averaged 138.5c after selling to 146.2c/kg. There was only two heavy cows offered and these sold for 157.2c/kg. 

The bulls also sold to a dearer trend. The medium weights sold to 140.2c, as the heavy weights averaged 136.9c/kg.

Following the larger yardings of recent weeks, supply was reduced considerably as an annual bull sale will be held later in the day. The change in numbers made accurate quotes difficult although the overall trend was cheaper despite some grades gaining ground slightly. All the regular buyers were in attendance and there was some good steers penned however a large number of poor cows were sold.  Steers were 5c cheaper while the heifers varied either side of last weeks rates by 3c to 6c/kg. The cows lost 12c to 18c/kg although a small number of heavy weights did improve slightly.

The medium good quality weight steers sold to 147.2c and averaged 141.5c while the poorer grades saw most sales around 112c/kg. A fair percentage of the yarding was heifers that averaged around 101c although isolated sales reached 140.2c/kg. 

The light cows lost up 12c and over 70 head averaged 91.4c after they reached 116.2c/kg. There were also a large number of poor quality light cows that averaged 36c/kg. A small number of medium weight cows sold to 128c and averaged 117.2c/kg.

The bulls were mostly light weights and they sold to 119.2c although most averaged 88.4c/kg. Heavy bulls topped at 131.2c/kg.

Following the large supply in recent weeks with seperate prime and store sales, the supply eased for a yarding of 2679 cattle in a return to a combined prime and store sale. Two southern processors were notably absent in a very small buyer panel, assisted by one regular feeder and opportunity backgrounders. Quality was mixed, comprising of small lines of heavy bullocks, several good quality large lines of prime cows, supported by small lines of store steers and heifers. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa to Georgetown, Richmond to Ingham and south to Belyando.

Values for all classes were lower than last sale.  Competition for well finished heavy lines was good, however lesser quality cattle in light condition were difficult to sell. Steers and heifers below 250kg met limited demand, with some failing to sell. Grown steers fell 30c to 40c, grown heifers eased 8c to 12c, bullocks softened by 2c to 23c, prime cows averaged 2c to 14c lower and bulls were down by 20c to 25c/kg.

Lightweight suitably weaned steers of good quality returning to the paddock averaged 266c, selling to 270c, with similar heifers to processors selling to 246c to average 225c/kg. Mixed quality yearling steers above 280kg to feed sold to 268c and steers above 330kg made to 258c to average 257/c/kg. Yearling heifers in light condition to feed made to 200c to average 158c, a good line of grain assisted heifers returning to feed made 254c, plainer types averaged 232c/kg.

Grown steers above 500kg to the trade sold to 330c, a good sample averaging 306c/kg. Small lines of grown heifers to the trade reached 268c to average 242c/kg. Heavy full mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 311c to average from 294c to 310c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows sold from 160c to 232c to average 210c, 3 scores sold from 202c to 268c to average 256c and a good supply of prime heavyweight 3 and 4 score cows topped at 270c multiple times to average 263c/kg.
Heavy bulls to processors made to 264c to average 224c to 250c/kg.

A small number of cows and calves sold to $950 per unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Following the exceptional unseasonal rain after last sale, numbers fell by 170 head for a yarding of 1,526 cattle this week for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents. Some good lines of cows and bullocks, heavy bulls and one large line of northern cattle were the feature of the sale. All regular processors were in attendance and operating, while one live exporter, feeder buyer and several restockers were active throughout the sale. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Richmond, Hughenden, Torrens Creek, Forsayth, Ingham, Woodstock, local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers met mixed competition with isolated sales selling higher to 389c with most 340c to 358c/kg. Yearling steers were well supplied, dominated by one large line, selling stronger for all types. Heavier types to feed sold to 325c, with steers to live export lifting to 300c/kg. Lighter and lesser conditioned types to grass sold higher to 340c average 335c/kg. Vealer heifers comprised of some good quality finished lines, with better conditioned types to slaughter selling to 260c, while lighter heifers returning to paddock sold to 292c/kg. A small number of yearling heifers of variable quality sold similar to last sale, with most destined for feed, averaging 256c/kg. Some very good small lines of bullocks sold higher on last sale, with heavy 3 score bullocks to slaughter topping at 280c, while bullocks destined for live export sold to 279c, with most sales 268c to 278c/kg. Heavy steers to live export sold to 300c, while heavy feeder steers sold to 312c, with lighter steers returning to grass sold to 338c/kg. 

Although cow numbers fell, some good lines of heavy 3 and 4 score cows sold higher on last sale, with heavy C3 score cows to slaughter selling higher at 244c to an increased average of 224c, while D muscled cows sold to 219c, averaging 211c/kg. Heavy 2 score cows to slaughter sold to 217c to average 205c, with the odd pen of lighter cows returning to paddock selling to 187c/kg. Heavy heifers to slaughter sold to 245c to average 228c/kg. Heavy bulls were again well supplied, selling similar to last week with those to live export topping at 280c, averaging 272c, while the few bulls to slaughter sold to 260c/kg. Young males less than 200kg returning to grass sold to 368c/kg. A small line of cows and calves sold to $1,400/unit.

Following some well received and widespread rainfall across much of the north and west over the last couple of weeks, Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents yarded 1,124 head, 1,200 fewer than the sale three weeks ago. All major processors were in attendance but not operating, accompanied by a select few restockers lifting demand throughout the sale. A good offering of heavy cows and grown steers saw prices lift for better quality heavy lines, while very light store cows eased by up to 20c/kg. A small number of store cattle were presented, with quality determining the increase in price. Cattle were drawn from Hughenden, Croydon, Woodstock, Belyando, local and coastal areas.

There were insufficient vealer steers and heifers to quote, however small lines of steers sold to 330c, while heifers made to 248c/kg. Yearling steers met stronger demand for the small number on offer, reaching 338c, with most selling from 300c to 328c/kg. The few yearling heifers presented made to 236c/kg.

Heavy bullocks to slaughter sold to 285c to average 273c, while lighter weights destined for live export sold to 265c/kg. A very good offering of heavy grown steers to slaughter sold to 284c multiple times, while medium weights also to slaughter made 266c/kg. Medium weight pens of the same line to restockers reached 271c to average 265c/kg. Some very good lines of heavy cows were in strong demand, increasing by up to 10c for better quality lines. Extra heavy 4 score cows sold to 223c, while heavy 3 score C muscled cows above 400kg sold to 221c, to average 216c, with isolated sales to 238c/kg. Similar weight D muscled cows sold to 219c, to average 209c with medium weight cows to processors topping at 185c to average 150c/kg. Restockers were selective on lighter conditioned cows, topping at 180c to average 174c for better quality types, with very light northern cows regularly selling from 110c to 120c/kg. Grown heifers to slaughter sold to 243c with most sales from 223c to 229c/kg. The few heavy bulls on offer lifted by more than 10c, topping at 264c for those destined for live export, while bulls to processors made to 265c/kg. A small selection of light males to restockers sold to 250c/kg.

Following significant rain in early February, the first sale for over a month attracted 3276 cattle in very warm conditions. Quality was mixed, comprising of some good quality heavy bullocks and 985 cows, supported by many mixed quality lines of store steers and heifers.  All regular processors were in attendance and operating in line with other selling centres. One regular feeder was notably absent, however the buyer gallery was filled with many interested onlookers, opportunity restockers and backgrounders. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa to Richmond, north to Georgetown and south to the local area.

Despite firm demand, values eased across all prime categories. Prices for vealer steers and heifers was solid for better quality types. Yearling steers to backgrounders and feed sold firm and heifers generally attracted good demand from processors and backgrounders.

Young steers returning to the paddock sold to 314c, averaging from 281c to 299c/ kg.  A large sample of young heifers to processors reached 268c to average 249c/kg. Yearling steers above to 280kg to backgrounders sold to 280c averaging 278c and those above 330kg averaged 277c/kg. Prime yearling steers to the trade sold to 294c/kg. Yearling heifers above 200kg to processors averaged 243c.  Heavy yearling heifers above 400kg to the trade reached 276c to average 271c/kg. 

Grown steers above 400kg to processors averaged 264c to 282c, selling to 286c, heavy grown steers sold to 283c/kg. A fair sample of grown heifers to feed made to 282c to average 263c, processor types reached 278c, to average 271c to 273c/kg.

Heavy full mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 300c to average from 272c to 298c/kg.  Medium weight 2 score cows reached 236c to average 221c, 3 scores made to 268c averaging 236c to 251c and a good sample of prime heavyweight cows topped at 270c to average 253c to 261c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors sold to 256c, averaging 238c, while medium and heavy bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 272c to average from 240c to 266c/kg.

A good sample of cows and calves sold from $750 to $1,250/unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Following recent rain across many parts of the north and west in recent weeks and the Easter Long weekend, numbers declined dramatically for a very small yarding of 214 head for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week. With less than 100 prime cattle, values for cows or bullocks sold to similar prices of the previous sale a fortnight ago. All major processors were in attendance and operating for the very small offering, along with one live exporter and a few interested restockers and on lookers to round out the gallery. The limited numbers of store cattle sold to variable prices, varying on quality and weight. Cattle were drawn from Forsayth, Ingham, local and coastal areas.

A good quality line of weaned steer calves sold to 342c/kg, with insufficient vealer or yearling steers to quote. Yearling heifers averaged 225c for heavier types to slaughter, while lighter heifers returning to the paddock sold to 234c/kg.

Some well finished grown steers to slaughter sold to 269c/kg, with no bullocks on offer. Heavy 3 score cows to slaughter sold to 226c, averaging 221c, with heavy 2 score cows topping at 210c to average 204c and medium weight 2 score cows sold to 175c/kg. A few light cows to restockers sold to 166c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export sold to 267c, with medium weight bulls also to live export making 244c/kg. Medium weight bulls to feed sold to 250c/kg. A small pen of cows and calves sold for $940/unit.

Following recent heatwave conditions across much of the state and insufficient numbers for a sale last week, Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents yarded 2,393 cattle, with increased numbers of store cattle presented. Prices for all descriptions generally improved on prices a fortnight ago, featuring several small lines of prime cows and grown steers, supported by a large consignment of northern steers and local vealer steers and heifers. All processors operated strongly for prime cattle, while regular feeder buyers, one live exporter and opportunity restockers were active on many store lines. Cattle were drawn from Normanton, Richmond, Greenvale, Ingham, Clare, Ravenswood, Pentland, local and coastal areas.

Good quality vealer steers improved by up to 10c, with restockers securing small lines to 292c/kg. Young steer calves made to 286c, to average 244c for heavier types and 257c/kg for light steer calves. A large consignment of yearling steers attracted strong demand, with light yearling steers returning to grass selling to 296c and averaging 290c/kg. Yearling steers above 280kg made to 288c, to average 279c/kg. Steers above 330kg to feed sold to 288c, to average 279c/kg. Vealer heifers attracted mixed demand, with better quality lines improving by up to 10c, making to 243c and averaging 228c, with most sales from 215c to 235c/kg. Yearling heifers consisted of many mixed quality lines, with limited demand for many lesser quality types. Well-bred heavy heifers to feed sold from 253c to 256c, while heifers to restockers above 280kg sold from 230c to 264c/kg.

Limited numbers of heavy bullocks improved 10c, selling from 287c to 300c, while some good quality pens of grown steers sold to 286c/kg. Plainer grown steers returning to grass sold to 288c, to average 285c/kg. There was a limited supply of well finished cows, with increased processor competition on heavy cows lifting prices by 12c to 15c/kg. Heavy 3 score cows sold to 243c, to average 233c, while heavy 3 score D muscled cows averaged 228c/kg. Increased numbers of medium weight D2 cows sold to 200c, to average 167c/kg. Some well finished grown heifers sold from 253c to 272c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export eased by up to 15c/kg, with the absence of two live exporters reducing overall demand. Suitable bulls sold from 234c to 290c, while similar bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 299c, with most sales from 240c to 287c/kg. Increased numbers of store conditioned cows and calves sold from $650 to $1,020/unit.

Following no sale last week, Charters Towers agents yarded 1422 cattle, 1150 less than a fortnight ago.  Quality was generally good, consisting of several small lines of prime cattle, supported by some good quality lines of store cattle. Half of the regular processors were in attendance and operating at stronger rates, supported by two live exporters, one regular feeder and opportunity restockers.  Cattle were drawn from Cloncurry to Georgetown, east to Ingham and south to the Belyando and local area.

Increased demand saw values for light cattle improve 17-60c, prime cattle improved 14c to 35c/kg.

Light steers under 200kg to restockers averaged 294c reaching a top of 322c and steers above 200kg averaged 266c to 280c/kg.  SimilaR heifers returning to the paddock sold to 200c to average 189c/kg.  A small sample of yearling steers to live export sold to 238c most averaging 226c/kg.  Yearling heifers above 330kg to feed sold to 178c to average 172/kg.

Grown steers consisted of many small lines, with values reflecting quality.  A good offering of grown heifers to processors topped at 206c to average 185c to 199c/kg. A small sample of heavy full mouthed bullocks to processors reached 208c, most selling from 176c to 196c/kg.  Medium weight 2 score cows reached 172c, 3 scores made to 186c to average 175c/kg. Prime heavyweight cows topped at 184c to average 178c/kg. Heavy bulls suitable for live export reached 212c, and bulls processors sold to 180c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Following no sale last week and some scattered useful storm rain across many northern areas, Charters Towers Combined Agents penned 2554 cattle. Quality was mixed throughout, comprising of 470 prime cattle and over 2,000 store steers and heifers.  Only three regular processors were operating, supported by one regular feeder, one live exporter and opportunity restockers.  Cattle were drawn from Normanton, Croydon, Richmond, Mt Garnet, east to the coast and the local area.

Light steers lifted 20c, yearling steers and heifers improved 30c to 60c, better quality prime cows and bullocks improved 30c to 50c and heavy bulls averaged 60c to 80c/kg higher.

Steer calves averaged 325c, selling to 345c, suitably weaned vealer steers returning to the paddock made to 314c to average 301c/kg.  Vealer heifers under 200kg to restockers reached 230c to average 210c, while heifers above 200kg to processors averaged 225c/kg. Good quality yearling steers above 280kg to restockers sold to 280c to average 268c and steers to feed averaged same. Good quality yearling heifers destined for breeding made to 248c to average 223c, with heifers above 330 kg to feed averaging 221c to 239c/kg.

Grown steers  above 400kg to restockers reached 266c to average 251c, steers to feed averaged 258c/kg, with steers suitable for live export averaged 262c/kg. A small number of grown heifers to the trade sold to 250c to average 244c/kg.

Heavy bullocks to export slaughter reached 255c, most sales from 228c to 240c .those to live export made 260c/kg.

Medium weight 2 score cows to restockers reached 236c, 3 scores to processors reached to 256c to average 238c to 244c/kg. A small number of prime heavyweights made 240c/kg.  Heavy bulls to feed destined for live export reached 260c to average 252.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Following last weeks much cheaper market numbers reduced dramatically. Producers may also have had an opportunity to way up their marketing options with 4,000 head currently loading on a boat in Townsville destined for Egypt. In spite of the small numbers there was a greater number of better quality cattle than previous weeks. Most of the regular buyers were in attendance and due to the small yarding an accurate quote on trends is not possible although there was stronger competition on the better quality grades. 

The medium weight steers sold to a top of 138.2c and a large number averaged 130.1c/kg. The heavy steers sold to a top of 140.2c and averaged between 133c and 137.8c/kg. The best heavy bullocks sold to 147.2c/kg and returned close to $1,000/head. 

The heifers topped at 130.2c although the D2s averaged 105c/kg. Medium weight cows sold to a top of 116.2c and the D3s averaged 110.8c while the D2s averaged 98.5c/kg. The heavy bulls topped at 111.2c/kg.

Following last weeks cancelled sale due to wet weather, Charters Towers Combined agents yarded 1544 cattle.  Quality was every mixed with only 490 prime cattle on offer.  Despite a large attendance in the gallery, there was a reduced buyer panel consisting of three regular processors, one live exporter and several opportunity local restockers.  Values for all classes eased in line with other selling centres, particularly poorer quality lines. Yearling heifers fell 40c, yearling steers averaged 15c lower and cows finished firm to 4c easier.

Light steers to restockers topped at 498.2c and steers above 200kg reached 458.2c while yearling steers above 280kg returning to the paddock sold to 420.2c to average 318c/kg. Yearling steers above 330kg to live export sold to 332.2c to average 323c and similar weight weight bulls reached 348c/kg. A good sample of light heifers to restockers sold to 330.2c to average 308c and heifers above 280kg for breeding sold to 346.2c to average 309c/kg.

Grown steers to the trade sold to 288.2c to average 280c and similar heifers to the trade sold to 286c/kg.
A small sample of bullocks topped at 304.2c  to average 282c/kg.
Medium weight 3 score cows averaged 231c reaching 248.2c and a good sample of prime heavyweight cows topped at 246.2c to average 244c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export sold to 340.2c to average 332c/kg.

An increased offering of good quality aged cows and calves sold from $1,450 to $1,800per unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Following a 2 week break due to insufficient numbers, a yarding of 642 head was drawn by Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents. Several small lines of well finished prime cows were on offer, supported by one large line of yearling heifers donated for the Western Flood Appeal. Two regular processors were present and operating, along with one live exporter, two feeder buyers, regular local backgrounders and restockers. Cattle were drawn from Greenvale, Mt Coolon and local areas. A small offering of vealer steers sold easier on last sale, while yearling steers generally comprised of small lines of irregular quality, easing by up to 13c/kg for those returning to the paddock. Yearling steers to feed improved by 10c/kg, with most destined for live export. Light yearling heifers to feed eased by 8c, however medium and heavy yearling heifers to feed improved by up to 27c/kg. An improved offering of heavy grown heifers to processing showed the largest gain, increasing more than 60c, while heavy 3 and 4 score cows improved from 15c to 20c/kg. Live export activity saw heavy bulls improve by up to 30c/kg.

Vealer steers to restockers sold to 266c, while yearling steers returning to the paddock made to 253c/kg. Good conditioned vealer heifers returning to the paddock made to 236c, while similar types to feed sold to 230c, averaging 223c/kg. Yearling heifers to feed made to 228c, to average 202c, while heifers over 330kg to feed averaged 219c, with a single heifer selling to 249c/kg. A line of heifers to the Western Flood Appeal averaged 235c/kg. 

Grown heifers to processors sold to 221c, to average 213c, while a small number of grown steers to feed sold to 246c, averaging 233c/kg. A limited number of heavy bullocks to processors made to 264c, to average 260c/kg. A good offering of extra heavy 4 score cows sold to 204c, to average more than 195c, while extra heavy 3 score cows sold to 207c, averaging 192c/kg. Heavy 3 score cows averaged 187c, while cows to restockers made to 183c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export sold to 272c, to average 269c, with similar types to feed destined for live export selling to 280c/kg. Good quality cows with weanable calves sold to $1,270/unit.

Even though numbers increased supply was still small. There were some good cows available and a fair number of medium weight steers. Quality was generally mixed apart from the very best steers. All the regular buyers were in attendance although a large percentage of the yarding sold to local butchers. 

Light steers generally sold around 100c/kg. The best medium weight sold to 131.2c although most were of poorer quality and averaged 115.9c/kg. The heavy steers were of better presentation and topped at 139.2c while heavy bullocks sold at 135.2c/kg. 

A small number of heifers sold to 129.2c/kg. The light cows sold on a dearer trend and averaged around 90c/kg. The medium weight cows were 3c to 9c dearer and the D3s averaged 108.7c while the best D4s topped at 122.2c/kg.

Even though a similar sized yarding was offered, it was down on what was drawn for. Competition was from the regular field of buyers with values following trends from other markets to be varied. There was only a handful of better quality pens with the remainder of the yarding plainer lines. 

Most of the light steers were plain lean lines averaging 89.6c as medium weights topped at 133.2c with a large number of D3s averaging 127.3c/kg. Good heavy steers made to 144.2c with heavy bullocks making to 146.2c/klg. Light export heifers did not miss out on the cheaper trend with most averaging close to 111c/kg. 

Better light cows sold to 102.2c as most averaged closer to 70.2c/kg. Lean medium weights in the in the greatest number averaged 101.4c/kg. The top of the cows was medium weights making to 115.2c/kg. A fair number of bulls were offered, however most were plainer lines.

Diminishing feed conditions and cooler temperatures resulted in a reduced yarding of plainer quality cattle. The number of well-finished descriptions is decreasing as the weeks roll on into winter. The absence of one export processor did not have much affect on competition as the remaining gallery secured the suitable lines of export grades. 

Medium weight grown steers were of fairly even quality with C3s topping at 158.2c/kg. The plainer lines averaged 135.9c for D2s and 144.4c/kg for the D3s. Similar fat and muscle score heifers topped at 135c to average 121.4c/kg. 

Large runs of D3 medium weight cows eased slightly to range from 119.2c to 136.2c to average 126.8c/kg. Lightweight cows were also offered in reasonable numbers and despite their lack of quality they held firm on last week levels to average 110.2c/kg. The best of the bulls made 120.2c/kg for a lightweight description.

Despite widespread scattered storms across the north, a combined prime and store sale attracted 2,595 cattle, an increase of 24 head on last sale. Quality was very mixed with a large offering of northern pastoral cows and bulls, and many lines showing effects of the lengthening dry season. However, some very good quality lines of grown steers and well finished cows were on offer. The regular buyer panel was in attendance and operated at stronger rates to last sale including new saleyard records. Grown steers lifted by 12c to 40c, bullocks sold firm, heavy cows to processors lifted 6c to 10c and bulls averaged 7c/kg higher. Cattle were drawn from Tennant Ck, Normanton, Hughenden, Pentland, Hervey’s Range, Ingham, local and coastal areas. 

Light steer calves to restockers sold to a saleyard record 764c with mixed sexes averaging 644c/kg. Vealer steers above 200kg returning to grass reached 668c to average 594c/kg. A good sample of vealer heifers above 200kg returning to grass topped at 540c to average 526c, with suitable heifers to the trade selling to 514c to average from 475c to 489c/kg. Yearling steers were insufficient to reliably quote, however steers to feed sold from 484c to 500c/kg. A good line of yearling heifers from Northern Territory below 280kg to feed topped at 444c to average 423c and similar heifers to feed above 280kg averaged 413c/kg. Heifers above 330kg to feed also sold to 444c to average from 428c to 440c/kg. Heavy heifers to feed above 400kg sold to 436c to average 430c/kg.

Grown steers were of very good quality with some large lines attracting strong demand, selling to a dearer trend. A large sample of steers above 400kg to feed sold to 450c to average 442c and similar types to restockers averaged from 441c to 468c/kg. Heavy steers to the trade topped at 444c to average 432c to 436c/kg. A reduced supply of good quality heavy grown heifers to the trade sold to 394c to average 366c to 392c/kg. A small sample of grown heifers to feed made to 434c to average 380c/kg. A good number of 3 score heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 428c to average 401c to 417c, while 4 scores sold from 428c to 448c/kg. 

Processor demand for cows continues to be very strong.  Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 368c to average 359c and 3 scores reached 390c to average from 372c/kg. A small sample of prime heavy weight cows topped at 390c/kg multiple times. Increased numbers of light conditioned cows to restockers and backgrounders regularly sold from 304c to 380c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors sold to 370c to average from 352c to 368c/kg. Young males returning to the paddock sold from 530c to 650c/kg. A small number of light conditioned cows and calves sold from $1,100 to $1,700/unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

Despite recent isolated storms across most eastern areas, numbers increased by 214 head to 1,120 cattle for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week. Prices for most categories improved owing to supply shortages in southern areas and subsequent need to fill orders. All processors were in attendance and operating at increased rates for better yielding prime cattle, while lighter types also lifted in price. Two feeder buyers, two live exporters and some opportunity local and central restockers were active throughout the store section. Cattle were drawn from Cloncurry, Richmond, Einasleigh, Belyando, local and coastal areas.

Some very good lines of vealer steers improved 2c to average 262c, topping at 288c/kg for lighter types. Several small lines of yearling steers were in strong demand, with light feeder steers to live export selling to 280c and heavier steers above 330kg sold to 273c to average near 253c/kg. Light steers to feed destined for live export sold to 250c/kg. Light yearling steers returning to grass sold to 266c, averaging 265c/kg. Small lines of vealer heifers to feed made to 200c to average 198c/kg. Light heifers calves sold for 180c to feed, with best quality heifers to 200c/kg. Yearling heifers returning to grass made to 214c to average 208c/kg, with similar types to feed selling to 204c with an average of 200c/kg. Heifers above 280kg to live export sold to 230c and those above 330kg made to 232c to average 230c/kg. Medium weight yearling heifers to feed sold to 217c/kg for better quality types.

A small offering of bullocks sold to improved rates across all types. Heavy 3 score bullocks to export slaughter sold to 293c to average 287c, with younger medium weight types selling to 281c/kg. Medium weight 2 score bullocks lifted more than 20c, selling to 271c to average 253c/kg. Heavy grown steers to slaughter rose more than 18c, selling to 293c and averaging 291c/kg. Medium weight grown steers to live export sold to 267c to average 266c/kg.

Cow numbers eased slightly on recent weeks with greater variation in yield and weight. A good supply of heavy 3 score cows improved 9c, topping at 237c, to average 231c/kg. Extra heavy cows also improved by up to 6c, selling to 239c with an average of 237c/kg. Heavy D muscled 2 score cows eased 1c, selling to 237c and averaging 188c, while medium weight 2 score cows lifted more than 20c, reaching 200c to average 175c/kg. Numbers of heavy bulls fell on recent good supply with demand remaining strong throughout. Heavy 3 score bulls to slaughter sold to 261c to average more than 255c, with one high yielding bull making 273c/kg. Heavy bulls to feed destined for live export made to 258c, with most around 240c, while medium weight bulls to feed made to 218c/kg. Feeder bulls to live export sold to 271c, while lighter males to backgrounders sold to 245c/kg. A small number of cows with young calves made $680/unit.

Despite isolated storms in the region over recent days, numbers increased by 547 to 2,430 head for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week. Featured were greater numbers of prime cows and bullocks and one large line of northern steers and heifers. All buyers were present and operating, along with additional support from feeders and exporters.

Vealer steers were predominantly light weight and the variable quality saw solid to mixed demand, topping at 359c for lighter types and 354c for better grown, heavier lines, which averaged 10c better at 343c/kg. Yearling steers eased slightly mainly due to quality, with a small number of steers to live export selling to 320c, while restockers secured steers of similar weight to 294c/kg. Heavier steers to restockers sold to 325c, averaging 6c lower, while steers to feed sold to 288c, down 25c/kg on last sale. Vealer heifers were predominantly one large northern line, selling to very strong restocker demand. Light heifers returning to grass sold to 328c with sales ranging from 298 to 312c, while lighter weaned heifers sold to 338c, averaging 334c/kg. Yearling heifer numbers were down on recent weeks, with heifers to restockers selling to 274c and heifers to feed topping at 278c, with most sales from 250c to 270c/kg. PTIC heifers sold to 268c/kg.

Some very good lines of heavy 3 and 4 score bullocks continued recent trends of solid processor demand, topping at 280c and averaging 272c/kg. Heavy 2 score bullocks to slaughter sold to 273c with D muscled types to 266c/kg. A large number of grown steers to slaughter sold to 261c, while lighter steers to feed sold to 260c/kg. The supply of good quality heavy cows continued, with heavy C muscled 3 score cows selling to 238c and averaging 233c/kg. 2 score cows averaged 227c/kg. Heavy 4 score cows eased 4c to 6c on last sale, selling for 231c/kg. Heavy 3 score D muscled cows sold to 232c, averaging 224c, with 2 score cows averaging 214c/kg. Lighter 2 score cows returning to grass sold to 198c, averaging 191c, with 1 score cows averaging 169c/kg. Grown heifers to slaughter sold to 270c, averaging 260c, while heifers returning to grass sold to 242c/kg. Heavy bulls to slaughter sold to 253c, while heavy bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 258c, with most sales ranging from 248c to 253c/kg. Feeder weight bulls to live export sold to 312c, while light bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 314c to average 265c/kg. An improved quality offering of young males met strong restocker demand, with those returning to grass selling to 338c, to average 315c/kg. Cows and calves sold to $1,750/unit.

Despite a two week break due to insufficient numbers and inclement weather conditions, a smaller yarding of 1,058 cattle were drawn by Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week. The yarding was of very mixed quality, with some small lines of well finished cows and very good quality yearling steers of most interest to a subdued buying gallery, with one notable processor absence, while regular feeder buyers and opportunity western restockers were present and operating. The yarding was drawn from Chillagoe, Hughenden, Greenvale, Ingham, Ravenswood, local and coastal areas. Vealer steers were of very mixed quality and sold higher to 376c for the better quality types, averaging 361c/kg. Yearling steers were well supplied and of generally very good quality, selling to 300c, averaging 339c for those returning to the paddock, while similar types to feed sold to 300c to average 269c/kg. Grown steers sold strongly to restockers, topping at 299c, averaging 298c/kg.

Vealer heifers presented in very good condition, with many selling to slaughter, to a top of 294c, averaging 284c/kg. Yearling heifers were of mixed quality, with better finished types to slaughter selling 286c averaging 251c, while heifers to feed sold to 280c/kg. Bullocks were of mixed quality and the better finished 3 score bullocks for slaughter sold to 270c, while 2 score bullocks to feed sold to 251c/kg. 

Some good lines of well finished heavy 3 score cows to slaughter topped at 240c to average 215c, while medium weight 3 score cows sold to 215c/kg.  Heavy 2 score cows also to slaughter sold to 211c, to average 202c/kg. Good quality heavy 3 score bulls to slaughter sold to 241c, with many 2 score bulls selling to 230c, while medium weight bulls to backgrounders, destined for live export sold to 246c/kg. Young males sold to 354c/kg. Some good quality young cows and calves sold to $1,440/unit.

Cooler temperatures and tightening feed supplies continue to affect quality with larger numbers of plainer cattle offered. The absence of one export buyer also contributed to a weaker overall market. Numbers were significantly reduced, as the number of cattle in the region appears to be declining. Market competition was mixed with demand strongest on the limited number of well-finished descriptions.  

Heavy weight grown steers were of plain quality with many store types offered.  C3 s topped at 165.2c after averaging 162.6c while the lighter lines topped at 160c/kg. Bullocks held firm to range from 160.2c to 167.2c to average 163.1c/kg. Lighter D3 heifers averaged 141.7c after reaching a top of 150.2c/kg. 

Large runs of D3 medium weight cows sold at mixed rates to range from 129.2c to 140.2c to average 136.7c/kg. Lightweight cows were also offered in reasonable numbers and despite their lack of quality they encountered strong demand from restockers but eased slightly on last week s levels to average 93.5c/kg. The best of the bulls made 146.2c/kg for a well-finished description.

Cooler temperatures and overcast skies could not prevent all the usual buyers turning out for a similar sized yarding. Overall quality was the best seen for some weeks with large runs of well-finished grown steers and cows offered. Market competition was strong and all grades achieved dearer levels. 

Heavy weight grown steers were of fairly even quality in a yarding of mostly older steers and bullocks. Quality C2 steers topped at 159.2c after averaging 157.6c while the better-finished lines topped at 168.2c/kg. Bullocks improved to range from 164c to 168.2c to average 165.7c/kg. Lighter D3 heifers averaged 135c after reaching a top of 139.2c/kg. 

Large runs of D3 medium weight cows improved slightly to range from 128.2c to 148.2c to average 137c/kg. Lightweight cows were also offered in reasonable numbers and despite their lack of quality, they gained slightly on last weeks levels to average 119.9c/kg. The best of the bulls made 138.2c/kg for a well-finished description.

Continuing hot and dry conditions across much of the north resulted in 1,723 cattle penned in a prime only sale, with 5,000 head booked for a store sale on Friday.  Quality was generally good with increased numbers of prime bullocks penned, along with good lines of heavy cows and fewer numbers of heifers and bulls. One regular central processor was absent, however all others operated selectively with feeders, backgrounders and opportunity restockers.  Grown steers eased by 6c to 15c, heifers averaged 20c lower, bullocks and prime cows averaged 14c/kg, lower and bulls sold firm. Cattle were drawn from Hughenden, Greenvale, Ayr, local and coastal areas.

A good sample of yearling steers above 330kg to feed topped at 526.2c to average 524c/kg, with backgrounders steers averaging a simlar amount.  A limited supply of yearling heifers to feed above 200kg sold to and averaged 496.2c, and heifers above 280kg to feed averaged 496c/kg.

Increased numbers of grown steers above 400kg to feed sold to 520.2c to average 462c to 498c, with backgrounders averaging 450c to 470c/kg. Fewer grown heifers to feed topped at 472.2c averaging 409c to 433c, while heifers returning to grass averaged 461c/kg. An increased supply of heavy full-mouth bullocks to export slaughter topped at 446.2c multiple times to average 441c/kg. A large sample of cows less than 400kg returning to grass sold to 380.2c multiple times to average 367c/kg.  Medium weight 3 score cows to processors reached 386.2c to average 376c to 378c/kg. Prime heavy weights topped at 390.2c to average 388c/kg. Heavy bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 384.2c to 366c/kg. The heavy weight bulls to processors topped at 378.2c to average 374c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

Charters Towers weighed 402 prime cattle on Thursday.  Female cattle dominated the yarding, and all descriptions sold in vendors favour.  

Light steers, D1 sold to 130c/kg, medium steers to an isolated 125.2c, while the best of the other steers and ox made to 133.2c/kg  and were considerably dearer than last week.  A large sample of heifers, D2, made to 118.2c/kg to average 111.2c and these improved 2c/kg.  

Good samples of D2 cows made to 113.8c/kg with a few other very heavy cows to the same money.  Bulls at Charters Towers peaked at 113.8c/kg.

Charters Towers was the only yard in Queensland to see a larger yarding of only export type cattle with most being D grades. Values for all grades were firm to dearer except for the light weight bulls. 

All weights of D3 steers saw rises of 4c to 7c. The medium steers averaged 127.5 after selling to a top of 131.2c as the heavy weights sold to a top of 138.2c and averaged 134.8c/kg.  

The heifers offered were all under 540kg with the D3s selling to 128.6c and the D4 selling to 122.2c/kg. The light weight D2 cows were one of the better performing types as they rose over 10c to average 101.1c/kg. Medium weight D3 cows also met good competition to rise 3c to average 115.4c and a top of 126.2c/kg.

Charters Towers saw a much smaller yarding of mostly D and E export type cattle with values remaining firm.  

The D3 medium weight steers were one of only two grades to lose value, to average 125.3c. The heavy weight C4 steers in large numbers sold to 148.2c, and averaged 147.2c/kg. 

All the heifers were under 540kg with the best of those offered being the D3 and D4s, which both saw increases of over 3c/kg, to average 121.2c and 133.7c/kg. The light weight D2 cows were only in small numbers and sold to 97.2c with the medium weight D3s selling to 125.2c/kg. 

The medium weight bulls were the other grade to lose value, selling to 113.2c as the light bulls met good competition to average 119.2c/kg.

Charters Towers held their fat sale a day early and sold 630 prime cattle over the lwt scales. All descriptions sold in vendors favour and most of the regular buyers were in attendance and operating in the market place.

In the steers, lighter butcher types sold to 104.2c/kg, medium and Korean weight steers, D2 sold up to 119.2c to average 108.6c/kg.  Heavier export steers to 600kg reached 125.2c and these averaged 117.5c/kg.  A few other heavier bullocks sold up to 126.2c/kg. The tops of the heifers made 114.2c for a good sample of D2s.  

The heavy D2 cows that were offered sold up to 106c/kg to average a shade under the 100c/kg. Bulls sold to an isolated 113.2c/kg.

Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents yarded only 512 cattle this week, 1,125 fewer than last sale owing to the Australia Day Public holiday and the local Ashes Cricket weekend. Some good lines of prime cows and grown steers were on offer, supported by several small lines of store bulls, steers and heifers. Two regular processors were absent, as were the regular feeder buyers, while those restockers present, attended generally for observation. Cattle were drawn from Greenvale, Pentland, Guru, Belyando, local and coastal areas.

A small number of vealer steers sold to a subdued market, topping at 348c for lighter types and 310c/kg for the few better conditioned, heavier types. There was insufficient yearling steers to quote, while grown steers to restockers sold to 248c, averaging 22c/kg lower. Vealer heifers were also made up of many small lines, topping at 244c/kg, with very few yearling heifers on offer. A small number of good quality 3 score bullocks to slaughter increased 7c topping at 257c, while 2 score bullocks lifted 18c and sold to 256c/kg. A few 2 score bullocks to grass sold to 245c, while grown steers also to grass sold to 248c/kg.

Some good lines of heavy C muscled 3 score cows to slaughter sold to 211c, averaging 8c lower, while similar D muscled cows sold to 203c to average 6c lower at 204c/kg. Heavy 2 score cows to slaughter sold to 197c, up 12c to average 185c/kg. Light cows to restockers were showing the effects of an extended dry season selling to 176c/kg. The few heavy bulls to slaughter sold to 237c, while a large number of store bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 246c, and young males to restockers sold to 278c/kg. A single cow and calf sold for $1,320/unit.

Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents yarded 2,464 cattle, 242 fewer than last sale. Increased numbers of prime heavy bullocks and cows generally saw prices ease, while store steers and heifers generally eased on previous week's prices. One regular processor and a more recent processor were absent, with others operating at revised prices. One local feeder buyer operated alone along with opportunity restockers. Cattle were drawn from Burketown, Normanton, Richmond, Hughenden, Ingham, Woodstock, Ravenswood, local and coastal areas.

Fewer numbers of vealer steers met limited demand, however better quality lines sold firm on last sale, topping at 285c for heavier types, to average 263c, while light vealer steers sold to 214c/kg. Yearling steers were of mixed quality and sold accordingly. Better quality steers to live export eased by 4c, to make 272c, while restockers and backgrounders were active on similar weights to 282c and light weight steers to 270c/kg. Vealer heifers met limited demand and suitably weaned types generally lacked weight. Better quality heifers above 200kg sold to 220c, to average 197c, while light heifers sold to 160c to average 156c/kg. The absence of a feeder buyer saw most yearling heifers return to grass, with those above 280kg selling to 184c to average 167c/kg. Yearling heifers to slaughter sold for 177c/kg.

Increased numbers of heavy bullocks were on offer, with most presenting in prime condition. Better quality heavy C3 bullocks to export slaughter sold to 250c, easing by 4c to 10c, to average 244c, while 2 score bullocks made to 245c/kg. Medium weight C3 bullocks to slaughter sold to 247c, to also average 245c, while D3 bullocks sold to 245c, to average 8c lower at 222c/kg. Heavy grown steers to slaughter sold to 235c and heavy steers to live export sold to 233c, to average 226c/kg. Plainer 2 score grown steers to feed sold to 226c/kg. Some good lines of heavy cows met subdued processor demand, with heavy cows easing by up to 20c/kg. Heavy 3 score cows sold to 198c, to average 190c, while extra heavy 4 score cows sold for 186c/kg. Heavy D3 cows eased 8c, to make 175c, topping at 189c, while medium weight D3 cows sold to 145c, to average 141c/kg. Cows above 400kg returning to grass lifted 11c, to average 145c, topping at 158c, while lighter 2 score cows to restockers sold to 139c, to average 115c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export sold to 270c, with most sales from 257c to 265c, while feeder weight bulls to live export sold up to 270c/kg. A large offering of light northern males, less than 220kg, to backgrounders sold to 272c, to average 259c and 220-280kg males sold to 266c, to average 210c/kg. A small number of average quality cows and calves sold to $540/unit.

Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents yarded 2,341 cattle this week, an increase of 44 head on last sale featuring continued lines of well finished good quality cows and bullocks, accompanied by some lines of western cattle showing the signs of the continuing dry season. With recent isolated storms across the northern region and the forecast of further isolated storms, there was cautious optimism among the buying gallery consisting of all regular processors for the first time this year, underpinning a firm to small increase in values for the heavier prime cattle, but more importantly creating competition throughout the offering. One regular feeder buyer and a small number of restockers were active on better quality lines, with lighter steers and heifers increasing by up to 20c for better types, while heavier types were generally 6c to 9c/kg lower. Cattle were drawn from Julia Creek, McKinlay, Richmond, Georgetown, Prairie, local and coastal areas.

Some very good quality large lines of vealer steers were on offer, lines attracting strong restocker interest, selling to 304c, with the improved quality averaging 297c, up 35c/kg on last sale. Lighter, newly weaned types sold to 306c/kg and some very light steer calves sold at $350/head. Yearling steers met mixed demand, influenced by quality with lighter steers returning to grass increasing by 21c, topping at 266c, with better grown 280-330kg steers selling to 286c to average 277c/kg and similar weight steers to feed of more variable quality sold to 210c to average 201c/kg. Vealer heifers were mostly newly weaned types and of good quality with one large line less than 200kg returning to grass for 237c/kg. Heifers 200-280kg sold to 278c for heavier types with most sales 238-242c/kg. Yearling heifers were very mixed in quality and weight, with the limited demand reflecting in significantly lower values for much of the offering. Heifers 220-280kg to feed sold to 220c to average 219c, while 280-330kg heifers also sold to 220c and heifers above 330kg to feed sold to 245c/kg.

A continued offering of well finished heavy bullocks sold up to 8c higher than last week, with best 3 and 4 score bullocks to slaughter reaching 255c to average 253c/kg.  Plainer 2 score bullocks to slaughter sold to 244c, with a small number to feed reaching 234c/kg. Heavy grown steers to slaughter reached 258c and lighter types to feed sold to 231c to average 215c/kg with quality influencing prices. A large offering of well finished heavy 3 score cows to slaughter sold to 219c for those over 520kg, and 218c for 400-520kg cows, up 1c, to average 208c/kg. Heavy C muscled 2 score sold to 206c to average 200c/kg. Heavy 3 score D muscled cows sold to 212c to average 207c, while 2 score heavy cows sold to 203c to average 186c/kg. A large number of lighter 1 score cows to a southern restocker sold to 165c to average 142c/kg. Heavy grown heifers to slaughter sold to 232c, while restockers secured smaller framed, lighter conditioned heifers to 191c, averaging 174c/kg. 

A small number of heavy bulls to slaughter sold to 226c, with sound types to feed or background destined for live export topping at 252c, while similar medium weight bulls sold to 259c/kg. Young males returning to paddocks sold to 270c to average 241c/kg. A large number of small framed, light western cows and calves sold for $530, while large frame cows and calves topped at $1,020/unit.

Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents yarded 2,297 cattle and increase of 1,760 on last sale. There was increased processor attendance and feeder buyers engaging in keen bidding on better quality lines. The offering comprised of some excellent lines of well finished cows and bullocks with values increasing 5c to 10c/kg in line with the improved quality. Vealer heifers had the strongest gains lifting by up to 30c for better quality types, while yearling steers eased by more than 10c/kg, with many lines showing the effects of a delayed wet season. Cattle were drawn from Julia Creek, Richmond, Georgetown, Einasleigh, Atherton, Townsville, Clermont, local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers were comprised of some very good quality newly weaned lines topping at 302c averaging 287c, with younger steer calves selling to 303c/kg. Well grown heavier vealer steers to restockers sold to 280c to average 262c/kg. Yearling steers were of variable quality and fewer in number, generally presenting in store condition, with limited buyer interest on some lines. Those returning to grass sold to 278c for lighter types, while steers to feed made to 258c for better quality and weight, and 248c/kg for lesser quality types. Vealer heifers were generally of very good quality featuring several newly weaned lines, attracting significant interest from restockers and feeders alike. Light heifers returning to grass topped at 256c to average 237c, while newly weaned heifers calves sold to 231c/kg. Heifers above 200kg to slaughter sold to 240c, with most sales above 230c/kg. Heavier vealer heifers to feed sold to 229c to average 226c and heifers above 330kg to feed sold to 243c to average 241c/kg.

An improved quality offering of well finished 3 and 4 score bullocks lifted by up to 10c on last sale with best heavy export bullocks to slaughter selling to 250c to average 245c/kg. A number of 2 score heavy bullocks also to slaughter sold to 246c/kg. Grown steers to feed sold to 248c and steers returning to grass sold to 245c/kg. An excellent line up of heavy cows lifted by 7c to 10c on last sale, primarily due to increased processor attendance, with heavy 3 and 4 score cows above 500kg to slaughter topping at 216c to average 214c/kg. A large offering of heavy C muscled 3 score cows 400-520kg lifted to 232c, averaging 207c, while similar weight D muscled cows sold to 210c to average 192c/kg. Heavy C muscled 2 score cows to slaughter sold to 206c to average 202c, and heavy D muscled 2 score cows to slaughter topped at 203c to average 186c/kg. Lighter 2 score cows returning to grass sold to 176c to average 170c/kg. A good quality offering of grown heifers to slaughter sold to 240c and heavy feeder weight types to feed sold to 230c/kg. Heifers returning to grass sold to 230c/kg for better quality types. Increased numbers of heavy bulls to slaughter sold to 243c, while similar heavy bulls to feed for live export sold to 256c/kg. Young males to restockers sold to 270c and similar types to feed sold to 260c to average 248c/kg. Cows and calves topped at $1,180, with several small lines selling from $920 to $1060/unit.

Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents yarded 1,990 cattle, a reduction of 474 on last sale, featuring a very good line of heavy bullocks and a very large consignment of northern heifers. Half of the regular processors were in operation, supported by one local feeder buyer and backgrounder, along with the regular and two new western and central restockers.
