Cattle were drawn from Burketown, Coen, Einasleigh, Richmond, Torrens Creek, Tully, Townsville, Homestead, Mount Coolon, local and coastal areas.

Fewer numbers of vealer steers presented in small lines as prices eased with limited buyer interest. Heavy vealer steers returning to grass sold to 250c/kg for better quality types. Yearling steers also showed considerable variability, with unpredictable buyer demand. Light yearling steers returning to grass sold to 214c, while 280-330kg steers sold to 228c/kg. Feeder steers to live export sold to 242c/kg multiple times. Vealer heifers were generally in light condition, with irregular demand for the variable quality. The lightest heifers of one large northern line sold to 190c, averaging 162c, while lesser quality types averaged 146c/kg. Yearling heifers comprised predominantly of one large northern line of generally good quality, attracting stronger demand from central and western restockers. The larger offering of heifers 220-280kg improved by up to 70c for those returning to grass, topping at 226c to average 190c/kg. Heifers in the 280-330kg range improved 30c to average 197c, reaching a top of 212c/kg.

Heavy export bullocks were again well supplied by one northern line, selling firm to 5c/kg dearer on last sale. Heavy 4 score export slaughter bullocks sold to 249c, to average 244c, while similar weight 3 score bullocks sold to 256c to average 249c/kg. Bullocks to live export sold to 260c, while medium weight bullocks made to 259c to average 249c/kg. Grown steers to live export sold to 259c to average 254c/kg. Heavy grown steers to slaughter sold to 245c to average 241c, while plainer steers returning to grass sold to 232c to average 215c/kg. Fewer numbers of prime cows were comprised of many smaller lines and variable weight. Extra heavy slaughter cows sold to 196c and heavy 3 score cows to slaughter eased by 4c, selling to 196c to average 185c/kg. Heavy D muscled 3 score cows sold to 182c, averaging 171c, while medium weight cows sold to 140c to average 136c/kg. Light cows returning to grass sold to 132c to average 121c/kg. Grown heifers were of mixed quality with better quality heavy heifers to slaughter reaching 234c to average 215c/kg. Heifers returning to grass sold to 192c to average 184c/kg. The demand for heavy bulls continued, with suitable heavy bulls to live export selling to 277c, averaging 267c/kg. Medium weight bulls less than 450kg sold to 264c to average 250c/kg. Bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 232c to average 231c/kg. Light males to restockers sold to 224c to average 214c/kg. Small lines of cows and calves sold to $860/unit.

Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents yarded 1,722 cattle, 232 fewer than last sale which comprised of several good quality lines of prime cows and northern steers. One major processor was absent with all others operating at lower prices than previous weeks, in line with southern market movements and drought induced supply. One live exporter and a feeder buyer continued recent demand for heavy bulls, while several restockers and backgrounders generated spirited demand for steers for the mixed quality on offer.

Several small lines of local suitably weaned vealer steers sold strongly, with lighter types topping at 280c to average 261c, while better quality heavier types eased by more than 15c, selling to 262c to average 251c/kg. The supply of yearling steers was considerably less than previous sale, with the lesser quality types easier, while better types were firm. A sample of good quality steers above 280kg returning to grass sold to 256c, to average 248c and those above 330kg to grass sold to 240c to average 235c/kg. A select few pens of heavy feeders above 400kg to feed sold to 246c, to average 235c/kg. The supply of vealer heifers were generally light suitable weaned types with lacklustre demand throughout. Light heifers returning to grass sold to 192c, with heavier vealers to restockers making 166c/kg. Yearling heifers were of mixed quality smaller lines with lighter heifers to restockers selling to 174c, however one larger line of feeder weights sold to feed to 183c, to average 177c/kg. 

Some very good heavy export bullocks sold to 240c, while heavy bullocks similar to previous weeks eased 5c to average 241c/kg. Bullocks suitable for live export sold to 243c, while lighter types to feed destined for live export sold to 230c/kg. A larger offering of grown steers to feed destined for live export sold to 246c, while 2 score steers returning to grass also topped at 246c to average 236c/kg. Similar numbers of heavy cows were on offer, however the heavier types lacked the yield of previous weeks and sold lower accordingly. Heavy 3 score C muscled cows eased by up to 17c, topping at 188c, to average 176c, while similar weight D muscled cows sold to 186c, easing 8c to average 164c/kg. Heavy 2 score cows sold to 173c, easing by 6c, to average 140c and fewer numbers of medium weight D3 cows sold to 140c, to average 132c/kg. An increased supply of light cows to restockers lifted by 10c, selling to 130c/kg. A small number of medium weight grown heifers eased 11c, to average 179c/kg. Heavy bulls continued strong demand by live exporters, topping at 280c, with most sales between 244c and 275c, while similar descriptions to feed also destined for live export sold to 283c/kg. Young males returning to grass sold to 254c, to average 250c/kg. Cows and calves sold from $640 to $880, with a single sale to $1,220/unit.

Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents yarded 1,607 cattle, 303 fewer than last sale comprising of some well finished cows and very good quality lines of northern store cattle. One processor was again absent, however all others were operating throughout, along with one live exporter, two regular feeder buyers and several enthusiastic restockers to a generally stronger market. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Normanton, Tully, Pentland, Ayr, Woodstock, local and coastal areas.

Good quality light vealer steers sold 24c higher on last sale to 352c, averaging 344c, with heavier better conditioned types returning to grass lifting by 5c and topping at 330c/kg. One large line of northern yearling steers attracted strong feeder and live exporter competition, with steers to live export topping at 324c for several pens, with heavier steers also to live export selling to 300c, to average 278c/kg. Some good conditioned lines of vealer heifers returning to paddock increased by 11c to average 271c and sold to 283c, with similar types to slaughter selling to 264c to average 251c/kg. Heavier weaned vealer heifers returning to grass, met enthusiastic restocker demand reaching 301c to average 290c/kg. A mixed quality offering of yearling heifers met selective demand, with live exporters securing heifers to 250c, while heifers returning to grass made to 269c, to average 263c/kg. A small number of heavier types to feed sold to 249c/kg. A large line of feeder weight northern heifers were dominated by live exporters paying to 268c, to average 264c, with heavier types selling to 262c to average 251c/kg.

A mixed quality offering of bullocks and grown steers sold 1c to 5c easier, while heavy bullocks to slaughter increased by up to 10c/kg. Heavy 3 score bullocks to slaughter made to 263c, averaging 259c, with medium weight lines averaging 248c/kg. Lighter conditioned northern types of lesser quality to feed sold to 243c, averaging 217c/kg. Good quality grown steers to live export sold to 281c, while steers to restockers averaged 251c, with most sales from 240c to 262c and up to 281c/kg. An increased number of well finished cows to slaughter lifted 14c to 19c, averaging 205c, with heavy C muscled cows reaching 209c and some D muscled heavy weight cows making 215c/kg. Heavy 2 score cows to slaughter made to 185c to average 166c/kg. Restockers secured cows of mixed quality and weight to 173c, averaging 148c/kg. Fewer heavy bulls were on offer, with most suitable for live export and selling to 245c, with most sales 230c to 240c/kg. Feeder weight bulls also to live export sold to 306c to average 287c/kg. Young light males met strong restocker demand selling to 322c, with males 280-330kg also returning to grass selling to 295c, to average 273c/kg. A small number of cows and calves sold for $1,060/unit.

Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents yarded 1,099 cattle, 1,073 fewer than last sale. Two lines of northern cattle again featured in a yarding of some very good heavy bullocks and cows and fewer numbers of mixed quality store cattle. Three regular processors were active throughout the sale, along with two live exporters and two regular feeder buyers, supported by a small number of restockers and backgrounders. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Burketown, Georgetown, Woodstock, Clare, local and coastal areas.

A smaller number of vealer steers were generally plainer than recent weeks, however, restocker activity lifted values by 10c to reach 244c/kg. Very light steer calves less than 100kg sold to 202c/kg. Several small lines of yearling steers mostly sold to live export making to 258c/kg for light feeder types. Vealer heifers were in short supply and the variable quality met limited demand from the gallery. Suitably weaned light heifer calves returning to grass made to 192c and light vealer heifers made to 188c/kg. Yearling heifers consisted of smaller mixed lines with variable weight and condition.  Better quality yearling heifers returning to grass made 179c, while 330-400kg heifers to feed sold to 205c to average 204c/kg. Heavy yearling heifers to feed sold to 215c/kg.

Despite fewer numbers of heavy bullocks, a few lines of extra heavy export bullocks improved 3c/kg on last sale. Heavy export 3 score bullocks sold to 274c to average 272c and 4 scores sold to 259c/kg. Medium weight 3 score bullocks made to 272c easing 7c to average 259c, while lesser yielding 3 score bullocks improved by 20c, selling to 268c to average 250c/kg. Heavy grown steers to slaughter reached 239c and heavy feeder steers to live export made to 245c/kg.

Heavy 3 score cows were again well supplied, however eased 9c/kg on last sale. Better yielding heavy 3 score cows sold to 222c to average 206c and extra heavy cows reached 215c to average 210c/kg. Heavy D muscled 3 score cows lifted 2c, selling to 200c to average 195c, while lesser quality medium weight 2 score cows eased 21c, making to 143c to average 133c/kg. Grown heifers were also in good supply but lighter than recent weeks and easing 28c, with 3 scores to slaughter topping at 232c to average 216c and 2 score heifers sold to 206c/kg. An increase in the number of heavy bulls attracted strong processor interest, making to 245c to average 232c/kg. Similar bulls suitable for live export sold to background feeders also for 245c, while feeder weight types made to 255c, with most sales above 225c/kg. Light feeder males to live export sold to 264c to average 260c and lighter types returning to grass sold to 250c to average 244c/kg. A single line of cows and calves sold to $810/unit.

Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents presented another small yarding of 549 cattle this week, comprising of a mixed quality yarding across all classes of cattle. Three regular processors were absent, which had a major impact on heavy prime cattle due to the lack of competition.  Store cattle were comprised of many small irregular lines and a couple of good lines of vealer and yearling heifers which meeting limited demand from restockers. Most regular feeder buyers were also absent. Cattle were drawn from Richmond, Homestead, Ravenswood, local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers of mixed quality and type sold to irregular demand, topping at 300c for some good conditioned, freshly weaned types. A small offering of yearling steers were also of variable quality, with one live exporter securing suitable feeder weights for 295c, while the few remaining better quality steers returning to grass sold from 240c to 270c/kg. Vealer heifers consisted of a couple of good lines that were freshly weaned, with one line to slaughter for 248c/kg. Heifers returning to the paddock sold to 204c/kg. One good line of yearling heifers to feed sold to 242c, while other small lines sold from 230c to 234c/kg.  

There was only a few bullocks suitable for slaughter yarded, which sold to 245c, while a similar number of grown steers sold to 249c/kg. An increase in the number of prime cows on offer was met with a number of absent processors, affecting demand throughout the sale. Heavy 3 and 4 score cows fell by up to 24c, with cows above 500kg topping at 205c and averaging 200c/kg. C3 score cows above 400kg sold to 195c and averaged 17c lower on 188c/kg. Similar weight D muscled 3 score cows sold to 196c, down 9c to average 184c, while 2 score types also sold 9c lower averaging 176c/kg. Lighter 2 score cows to processors bucked the trend, reaching 175c and averaging 164c, up 26c/kg. Better quality light cows to restockers sold to 138c to average 132c/kg. A number of lesser quality cows were on offer with limited demand. A few grown heifers to slaughter also sold to limited demand, topping at 219c to average 207c/kg. A number of small lines of heavy bulls to slaughter sold to 230c, while feeder weight types to live export sold to 272c/kg. An increased offering of cows and calves sold to $1,080, with most sales from $880 to $970/unit.

Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents opened the year with a yarding of 1,637 cattle under overcast skies and a full gallery of buyers and interested onlookers. Prime cattle consisted of some very good quality bullocks along with some mixed lines of cows and average quality northern bulls, while store cattle were predominantly very good quality in strong forward store condition. Most processors were in attendance along with one regular and one new feeder buyer, one live exporter and several restockers competing on selected lines with values easing on all classes in line with recent sales in other venues.  Cattle were drawn from Georgetown, Mt Surprise, Mt Garnet, Richmond, Brandon, Woodstock, Belyando and local areas.

Young steer calves met strong demand and sold to 346c, while similar bred heavier vealer steers also made to 346c to average 336c/kg. Plainer vealer steers above 200kg sold to 315c, to average 288c/kg. Yearling steers were of variable quality and weight, meeting mixed competition, with better quality steers returning to grass selling from 280c to 284c and feeder steers to live export sold to 286c/kg. Heavy yearling steers to feed sold to 266c/kg. Vealer heifers were generally very good quality and weight for age with restockers active throughout, securing lines above 200kg to 257c to average 255c, while heavier types to feed sold to 250c, with most lines selling to 246c/kg. Several small lines of yearling heifers were mostly snapped up by feeder buyers topping at 254c with most sales 235c to 250c, with lighter yearling heifers to grass making to 249c/kg.

The offering of bullocks was variable in quality and weight with values easing 5c to 13c/kg on last sale. Processors secured heavy bullocks above 500kg to 255c, while most bullocks less than 500kg sold from 237c to 247c/kg. One very good line of grown steers above 500kg to slaughter topped at 260c to average 257c, with lesser quality and weight types to feed selling from 215c to 250c/kg.

The cow market eased up to 25c/kg on the last sale of last year, with the offering of cows of variable quality and condition. Heavy 3 score C muscled cows to slaughter sold to 217c, with D muscled types selling to 210c to average 200c and 2 score cows sold to 208c to average 173c/kg. Lighter conditioned 1 and 2 score cows to restockers sold to 180c/kg, with lesser quality types meeting subdued demand. A small number of heavy bulls were on offer, with those to slaughter topping at 231c to average 227c/kg. A large consignment of northern bulls and males in the offering sold to feed, with heavy feeder types destined for live export selling up to 228c to average 224c, with lighter feeder types selling to 266c to average 188c/kg. Young males to restockers sold to 336c/kg. Cows and calves topped at $1,160 for a small line and one large single consignment of cows and calves sold to $910/unit.

Charters Towers combined selling agents had an increased yarding of 2,014 head this week, an increase of more than 600 on last sale, with some very good lines of well finished cows and bullocks the feature of the yarding. One major processor was again absent, with the remainder all in attendance and operating throughout the prime section, with one regular feeder buyer, several restockers and one live exporter also active throughout the sale. Cattle were drawn from Chillagoe, Einasleigh, Hughenden, Greenvale, Basalt, Tully, Woodstock, local and coastal areas.

Good quality vealer steers sold higher on last sale, increasing 4c to 10c to top at 388c/kg to restockers.  Yearling steers were of similar good quality to recent sales, topping at 346c for those retuning to grass, with feeder steers topping at 345c/kg. Fewer vealer heifers were on offer this week, with restockers lifting values to 296c, averaging 272c for heavier types, with lighter heifers selling to 300c/kg. Yearling heifers were of mixed quality with better quality types to feed selling to 263cc to average 255c/kg. Yearling heifers returning to paddock sold to 264c, to average 251c/kg.

One large line of very good quality well finished bullocks were a feature of the sale, with a live exporter dominating the offering, lifting values to 275c, to average 270c, with bullocks to slaughter topping at 269c to average 245c/kg. The few lighter weight types to restockers sold to 249c/kg. Several very good lines of well finished heavy 3 and 4 score cows attracted spirited bidding, selling similar to last sale, with C muscled cows above 500kg topping at 220c to average 218c, with 420kg-500kg cows topping at 219c, to average 211c/kg. Heavy D muscled cows sold to 215c to average 203c, while D2 cows sold to 220c to average 197c, while lighter conditioned cows to restockers lifted up to 20c selling to 185c, to average 157c/kg.

Heavy bulls were again sought after by one live exporter, securing most of the offering to 278c, with most sales from 268c to 274c, while the few heavy bulls to slaughter sold to 246c/kg. Some good lines of cows and calves sold strongly from $1,120, to a top of $1,340/unit.

Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents drew a reduced yarding this week following last week’s large store cattle consignment, with numbers falling by 1,296 head to 2,058 cattle this week. A continued large selection of well finished cows and grown heifers were 8c to 11c/kg dearer on last sale for heavier types, while light cows were fully firm on last sale. Some good lines of yearling steers and heifers in the store section attracted strong competition, particularly feeder types. All regular processors were in attendance and operating, accompanied by two live export operators and regular feeder buyers strong throughout the sale. Many recent restockers were absent, though this had little impact on sale results. Cattle were drawn from Chillagoe, Georgetown, Einasleigh, Belyando, Ingham, Woodstock local and coastal areas.

Vealer heifer numbers fell on last sale and the variable quality sold lower to a top of 346.2c/kg. A good selection of yearling and grown heifers attracted strong feeder competition, selling to 322.2c to average 295.8c/kg.  Lighter yearling heifers to restockers sold to 318.2c, to average 293.7c/kg. Vealer steers were in short supply and the small number sold strongly to top at 405.2c/kg, with western restockers most active, particularly on lighter types. Some good lines of yearling steers were in strong demand by feeders, selling to 354.2c, to average 344.1c/kg. Steers to live export sold to 344.3c, to average 332.9c, while restockers were active on lighter types, topping at 336.2c/kg. An increased number of grown steers to feed sold to 348.2c, to average 323.6c/kg.

A small number of bullocks eased on last sale, with 3 score bullocks to slaughter selling to 295.2c, while live exporters paid to 295.2c/kg. Another good quality yarding of well finished 2 and 3 score cows sold to increase rates with heavy cows lifting 10c to 14c, and lighter 2 score cows lifting 3c to 9c/kg. Heavy 3 score cows to slaughter sold to 256.2c, averaging 238.2c, while heavy 2 score cows sold to 238.2c, averaging 233.4c/kg. Lighter 2 score cows to restockers sold to 238.2c/kg. Heavy 3 score bulls were few in number and sold to 272.2c to live export, while heavy bulls to slaughter sold to 266.2c/kg. Cows and calves of varied quality made to $1,300, with many lines selling from $1,080 to $1,240/unit.

Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents attracted the biggest yarding of the year to date with 2,628 cattle, almost 900 higher than last sale, which featured several very good lines of prime cows and yearling steers.  One major processor continued their absence, while all others operated at significantly lower rates for all slaughter cattle, accompanied by several live exporters and a few opportunity restockers. Store steers and heifers met subdued interest as live export feeder orders remain absent and pastures across the region dry off with the wet season drawing to a close. Yearling steers continued their recent slide and yearling heifers were a difficult sell throughout, with some odd better bred lines meeting restocker interest.  Cattle were drawn from Normanton, Chillagoe, Georgetown, Mt Surprise, Einasleigh, Forsayth, Hughenden, Greenvale, Bowen, Woodstock, local and coastal areas.

Good quality recently weaned vealer steers sold to 310c, averaging 289c, while similar steer calves sold to 300c/kg. Several good quality lines of yearling steers met mixed demand with 280-330kg steers returning to grass made to 281c for better conditioned lines, increasing 4c to average 262c, while light steers sold to 280c to average 269c/kg. Heavier steers above 330kg returning to grass sold to 258c to average 252c/kg. Vealer heifer values fell across the board, with better quality light heifers returning to grass selling to 228c to average 5c lower for an average of 212c, while heifers above 280kg sold to 204c to average 188c/kg. Yearling heifers to restockers from 280-330kg fell by 20c to average 199c, topping at 211c, while heifers above 330kg topped at 190c/kg to limited demand.  Similar weight heifers to feed sold to 210c to average 28c lower at 180c/kg.  

An increased supply of heavy bullocks sold up to 23c lower than last sale, with heavy 3 score bullocks to slaughter topping at 248c to average 238c, with similar weight bullocks selling to live export for 247c to average 245c/kg. Lighter conditioned bullocks to feed destined for live export sold to 235c, lifting 4c to average 224c/kg. Several very good lines of prime cows met selective demand from processors as values eased in line with recent grid adjustments. Extra heavy cows sold 19c lower to 195c and heavy 3 score cows to slaughter sold 16c lower to average 191c, reaching a top of 202c/kg. Heavy D muscled 3 score cows sold to 191c to average 169c, easing 29c, with 2 score cows selling to 161c to average 154c/kg. Medium weight cows to slaughter sold to 180c to average 156c while better quality lighter 2 score cows to restockers sold to 159c, moving against the trend by lifting 31c to average 151c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export sold to 267c, with similar bulls to feed destined for live export selling to 266c/kg. Medium weight bulls also to feed made to 267c, with most sales 245c to 265c/kg. Lighter males to restockers sold to 276c/kg. Several small lines of cows and calves sold from $620 to $900, topping at $1,320/unit.

Charters Towers Combined Agents yarded 2,421 cattle this week following last week's cancelled sale due to widespread wet weather. With more than 3,500 head booked for Friday's store sale, most of the offering were prime cattle. All regular processors operated at increased prices, with the addition of two southern processors and one live exporter operating on much of the yarding. Cattle comprised of increased numbers of grown heifers and steers, with strong demand from several processors throughout, including light weight lines from northern areas. Cattle were drawn from as far north as Burketown, Croydon and Chillagoe and south to the Belyando and local areas. Grown steers and heifers met very strong demand with increases of 10c to 40c/kg.  Medium weight cows were highly sought after, improving by up to 13c, with heavy cows 7c to11c better. Heavy bullocks increased by 30c and heavy bulls suitable for live export gained 25c to 40c/kg.
 
Limited numbers of vealer steers sold to 372.2c to average 360c, while a very good line of vealer heifers to the trade sold to 314.2c/kg. Insufficient numbers of yearling steers were penned to reliably quote. Yearling heifers to feed sold to 325c to average 304c, with lesser quality types averaging 278c/kg. 

Grown steers above 400kg to live export sold from 336c to 351.2c, while those less than 400kg averaged 324c/kg. Increased numbers of grown heifers to the trade sold from 268c to 291c to average 279c/kg. A large sample of heifers to feed averaged 252c to 285c/kg. Heavy bullocks to export processor topped at 363c to average 360c, with 2 score bullocks averaging above 269c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows sold to 247.2c to average 226c, while heavy 3 score cows reached 270.2c to average 254c to 267c/kg. One generous vendor donated the proceeds of 6 prime cows to the Royal Flying Doctor Service for 260.2c/kg. Prime heavy weight 4 score cows averaged 272c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export sold to 367c to average above 360c, while similar types to feed destined for live export averaged near 349c/kg.  Small lines of cows and calves sold to $1,030/unit.

Charters Towers Combined Agents yarded 1,367 cattle in a prime only sale. Quality was mostly good, however many lines did not have the weight or conditions of previous weeks. Only three regular processors were in attendance and operating along with one live exporter and regular feeder operators. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa to Croydon, Richmond and the local area.

Demand was firm on better quality lines, however light conditioned pens met limited demand. Yearlings and bullocks  averaged firm to 8c better, while prime cows fell 5c and heavy bulls averaged 12c lower.

Yearling steers above 400kg to feed averaged 244c selling to 246c, yearling heifers above 330kg averaged 214c/kg. A good sample of grown steers to the trade sold to 246c to average 244c/kg.  An increased number of grown heifers to processors reached 226c, most selling from 185c to 210c/kg, while PTE heifers to live export made 170c/kg.

A mixed quality offering of heavy bullocks to export slaughter sold to 240c to average near 220c/kg. Lightweight 2 score cows to processors averaged 137c selling to 155c, medium weight 2 score cows sold to 150c/kg.  A large sample of medium weight cows to processors sold to 186c to average 167c, a small number of prime heavyweight cows topped at an isolated 214c to average 184c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export sold to 260c, with bulls to feed destined for live export averaging 216c to 220c/kg.

A small line of cows and calves sold for $775 per unit.

A store sale scheduled for Friday has 2,600 cattle listed.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Charters Towers Combined Agents penned 1768 cattle in a prime only sale, the largest prime offering in more than 18 months.  Quality was mostly good throughout, with several good quality heavy cattle on offer, with more than 300 bullocks and 1,100 cows penned. Processor attendance was good with all regular export processors in attendance, supported by one southern operator for the first time this year, along with one live exporter and one local feeder operator and opportunity restockers.
 
Values for most categories were firm on last week, despite the increased supply, however plainer conditioned lines of cows eased 14c to 20c while prime heavyweight cows lifted by 4c/kg.

Yearling steers above 400kg to feed destined for live export sold to 256c to average 237c, steers to the trade sold to and averaged 240c/kg. Yearling heifers above 400kg to the trade made to 230c to average 227c/kg. A small sample of heavy grown steers to the trade averaged 262c/kg. Grown heifers to processors reached 234c to average from 200c to 228c/kg.

An increased number of heavy full mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 264c to average from 242c to 263c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors reached 160c to average 15 5c and 3 scores sold to 225c to average from 192c to 199c/kg.  A large sample of prime heavyweight 3 and 4 score cows topped at 224c to average 214c to 221c/kg.

Heavy bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 242c to average 232c, bulls to processors averaged 214c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Charters Towers Combined Agents penned 1089 cattle in a prime only sale. Quality was very mixed with increased numbers of heavy well finished cows and a large single vendor line of northern pastoral cows and bulls. One major export processor returned to the buyer gallery supported by regular processors, feeders and one live exporter. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Normanton, local and coastal areas.

All categories improved in price in line with other selling centres and increased buyer demand for the quality penned. Grown steers and heifers to the trade lifted 20c, bullocks increased up to 27c, heavy cows to processors improved 13c to 24c and heavy bulls finished firm to 6c/kg higher. Good quality grown steers above 400kg to feed sold to 356.2c to average 345c, while heavy steers to the trade topped at 358.2c to average 344c to 358c/kg. Good quality heavy grown heifers to the trade made to 348.2c with most sales above 320c/kg.

A good supply of heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 354.2c to average from 342c to 347c/kg. The improved quality of well finished cows met strong demand. Medium weight 3 score cows to processors sold to 314.2c to average from 291c to 311c while prime heavy weight 3 and 4 score cows topped at 320.2c multiple times, to average 314c to 318c/kg. Increased demand for heavy bulls by one live exporter and processors improved averages for the quality penned. Heavy bulls to live export sold to 348.2c to average 328c, while processors were active on suitable bulls from 278c to 310c/kg.

A store sale is scheduled for Friday has 3,000 head booked.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

Charters Towers Combined Agents opened the selling year with a small yarding of 556 head of mixed quality cattle, comprising of many small lines to a limited gallery of buyers. The yarding was drawn from Belyando, Einasleigh, Croydon, Ingham, local and coastal areas. All meatworks operators were present with only one active on the day.  Limited numbers of prime cattle sold with limited competition to lower rates than the last sale 2015.  

Store cattle were in high demand for selected lines, with restockers, feeders and live exporters all active throughout the offering. The limited number of vealer steers sold to a new saleyard record of 381.2c, whilst yearling steers also sold to saleyard record of 352.2c/kg. Vealer heifers were again well contested, with vealer heifers selling to 308.2c and yearling heifers topping at 310.2c/kg.

A small number of 3 score bullocks sold to 276.2c/kg, with subdued competition by meatworks operators. The 2 score cows sold to 220c with many pens selling from 180c to 210c/kg. Heavy bulls sold to 199.2c, whilst lighter bulls to live exporters sold to 240c/kg. Younger males topped at 352.2c/kg to restockers.

A single pen of cows and calves sold to $922/unit.

Charters Towers combined agents had an increased yarding of 1,488 mixed quality cattle with some good lines of cows selling to strong competition, with the absence of one major buyer. Cattle were drawn from Burketown, Richmond, Belyando, Giru, Greenvale, local and coastal areas. 

Yearling steers, 200kg to 280kg, sold to 264c/kg, with spirited competition from a restocker on selected lines. The 220kg to 280kg yearling heifers sold to 211c/kg, to a limited buyer presence. 

Limited numbers of 3 score bullocks topped at 289c, to average 279.7c/kg. Heavy 4 score cows sold to 271c, to average 268.7c, whilst heavy 3 score cows topped at 259c, to average 235.7c/kg. Heavy bulls sold to stronger prices topping at 270c/kg, with strong competition for lines for live export. A limited number of cows and calves were penned and sold to $890/unit.

Charters Towers auction centre sold 482 cattle on Thursday.  Overall values varied little on the previous week.  

In the steers, medium weight D2s sold to 118.2c for a fair sample to be 2c dearer than last Thursday, while a few D3s topped the steer market at 123.6c, to average 121c/kg.  Lighter heifers made to 111.6c, to improve up to 5c/kg.  

Cows were well represented, best heavy cows to 108.6c to average 104c, to be unchanged, while best of the bulls topped at 113.6c to average 112.7c/kg.

Charters Towers agents yarded an increased offering today of 796 head, a rise of 551. The market has mainly held at the rates of the last sale for steers and bullocks with cows firm to cheaper.

Light weight steers made to 120 for a small sample of D3s, medium weight D2s ranged from 105.2c to 127.2c to average at 120.2c, with the D3s at 127.4c/kg. Heavier weight D3 steers sold from 117.2c to 135.2c, and they averaged just under 132c/kg. Only 5 head over 600kg with prices in the mid 130s.

A decent offering of export lightweight heifers saw the average at 110c, and most price in that 110 range. A decent sample of D2 medium weight cows saw the range from 90c to 107.6c to average at 100c/kg, with 32 D3s topping at 102c/kg. Heavy bulls ranged from 95c to 116.2c/kg to average in the early 110s.

Charters Towers agents weighed a shade under 500 prime cattle on Wednesday.  The yarding was made up of all export cattle.  

A couple of light steers sold to 116.2c, D2 steers in the medium weight range sold to 125.2c to average 122c/kg.  A good sample of D2 bullocks to 600kg made 127.2c to average 125.4c, while bullocks in the heavier weights peaked at 128.2c/kg.  A good number of heifers also sold, best sales to 116.2c/kg.  

Cows in the heavier weights, D2, made to 111.6c and these averaged 106.2c/kg.  A handful of bulls sold to 115c to average 111.2c/kg.  Overall, the market this week was a little easier in places.

Charters Towers agents and vendors penned 1,705 head, 352 head fewer than last sale. Cattle were drawn from a wide area of the north and northwest including Winton, Cloncurry the Atherton Tableland and most local and close coastal areas including Mount Coolon. The yard was very mixed as usual. The usual buying panel competed with a little more vigour on the best quality lines, however there were quality related drops in some classes. 

The few calves penned improved in value with the best steer calves selling to 252c/kg. Yearling steers sold to 246c to return averages from 225c to 240c/kg. Yearling heifers made to 228c on occasions with averages in the mid 180c/kg range for the better bred pens.
 
Grown steers to feed sold to 230c with processors averaging 254c for their best 4 score steers and paying to a top of 263c/kg. A few grown heifers to the trade made 220c to 223c/kg for the best. The 4 score cows reached a top of 214c for a few grain assisted cows with an average of 196c/kg. Plainer 3 score cows improved to average 177c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export topped at 262c, averaging 257c/kg. The better bred pens of cows and calves made from $910 to $1,100/unit.

Cattle numbers increased by over 200 head at Charters Towers in a market that was firm to dearer for all but two grades. Export steers dominated the yarding with bulls in the minority. 

Following on from the sales in the south of the state the steers have continued to sell well. Medium C3s sold to a top of 151.4c to average 150c/kg, while heavy C3 steers sold to a top of 164.2c or an estimated 299c/kg cwt. 

The light heifers saw some of the biggest gains, as the D2s increased over 10c to average 121.4c while the D3s rose 2c to average 134.3c/kg. In only very small numbers light D2s reached 120.2c, while medium weight D3s lost 4c to average 129.5c/kg and the D4s lost over 10c to average 132.9c/kg.

The largest number of bulls was the medium weight D3s reaching 129.2c, while the top price was for a heavy D2 of 137.2c/kg.

At Charters Towers on Thursday, values varied by a few cents either way of last weeks rates.  Medium steers D2 sold to 127.2c, to be up to 5c/kg dearer than last week.  A fair sample of D3s in the bullocks topped at 127.4c/kg.  

Best of the heifers sold up to 118.8c/kg for a fair sample of D2s.  In the cows, heavy D2s sold up to 115c to average 107.8c and were 2c/kg dearer than last Thursday.  

A few bulls sold to 116.2c/kg.

As with southern markets, a larger yarding was offered as the current prices attract producers to offload cattle. Strong competition was evident from all the regular buyers on the mainly local cattle offering. Quality was on par with previous weeks.

Light steers were mainly plainer lines, however values improved as most averaged close to 128c/kg. A large number of lean medium weights averaged 153.8c as those suited to the Korean market sold to 166.2c/kg. Good heavy steers improved 5c to average 164.3c/kg. The top of the heavy bullocks reached 175.2c/kg.  Lean export heifers sold to 115c as better conditioned lines averaged 132.2c/kg. 

 Cows met solid demand with all grades realising dearer rates. Light D3s sold to 137.2c and averaged 134.6c as plainer types averaged 76.2c/kg. Good medium weights made to 156.2c as C3s held firm. Medium weight D3s averaged 137.1c/kg. The top of the heavy cows reached 153.2c/kg. Most light bulls sold close to 104c as heavy weights made to 134.2c/kg.

As there was no sale last week this sale compares to a fortnight ago. Numbers decreased and all of the regular buyers were in attendance. Values were much dearer and quality was reported to be good for most descriptions. 

Grown steers were of much better quality and the light grades sold to 143.2c and the better D3s averaged 163.2c/kg. Medium weights were in the majority and topped at 173.2 to average 3c dearer at 167.2c/kg. A fair number of heavy steers reached 178.2c to average 175.2c/kg.

Heifers sold on mixed trends and those of lighter condition sold cheaper to average 130.6c, while the better D3s averaged close to 159c/kg. Cows were generally of good quality although there was a greater number of D2s available. Nevertheless values were dearer and light cows improved 8c to average 123.5c/kg Medium weight D3s increased by over 20c and reached 154.2 to average 145.9c/kg. 

Bulls followed the dearer trend and light weights averaged 120.8c/kg. the heavy weights topped at 165.2c to average 155.7c/kg.

As the selling season draws to a close, numbers fell by 1,227 head for a yarding of 1,017 cattle for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, featuring a much smaller yarding of prime cattle and some mixed quality store cattle. Only two of the five regular processors were in attendance and operating at slightly lower rates than last sale, while store cattle met very strong demand from several restockers, with plenty of onlookers analysing the market. Cattle were drawn from Chillagoe, Richmond, Hughenden, Ingham, Woodstock, local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers met solid demand selling firm on last sale, with restockers very active on the mixed quality types, selling to 356c to average 339c/kg. Yearling steers were of very mixed quality and weight with better quality steers less than 280kg selling to 330c to restockers, while 280-330kg steers sold to 304c, averaging 297c/kg. A small number of heavy feeder yearling steers sold to 266c. Vealer heifers lifted 7c to 9c on last sale, topping at 304c to average 282c for 200-280kg heifers, with some well grown 280-330kg heifers selling to 286c/kg. Yearling heifers were in shorter supply and the mixed quality met limited demand for lesser quality lines. Light yearling heifers returning to grass sold to 262c, while heavier joiner heifers sold to 269c/kg.

Fewer numbers of bullocks met good competition despite the lack of processor attendance, with bullocks to slaughter topping at 262c easing 5c to average 252c/kg. A central grass fattener was active for lighter types, lifting values by 15c, topping at 252 to average 240c/kg.

Cow numbers were lower again this week with heavy 3 score cows topping at 241c, averaging 216c, while 2 score cows sold to 217c to average 201c/kg. Heavy D muscled 2 score cows sold to 212c to average 197c, while lighter 2 score cows to restockers made to 191c, averaging 175c/kg. A small number of grown heifers to slaughter sold to 241c/kg. A mixed quality offering of bulls met stronger demand for better quality types, with heavy bulls to slaughter topping at 241c, while feeder weight bulls to feed, destined for live export sold to 300c/kg. Light young males met spirited bidding from the gallery, topping at 388c, with most sales 310c to 322c/kg. A small number of fair quality cows and calves sold to $860/unit.

As the end of the year draws closer, numbers fell away considerably. The overall quality of the yarding was rather plain. Most of the cattle offered were light weights and with only the one processors active values for some categories suffered falls.  

The light steers managed to sell to 140.2c while the single heavy bullock returned over $1,000 after reaching 178.2c/kg. The limited competition saw the heifers slip 10c/kg. 

Dominating the sale was the light cows and bulls. The light D2 cows averaged 128.8c with the heavier categories selling to 153.2c/kg. The top of the bulls was the light weights making to 140.2c, while the medium weights averaged 134.4c/kg. 

Depending on cattle availability this may well be the last sale for the year with the next one scheduled for the second week in January.

As prices continue to fall, numbers reduced considerably. Quality was mainly plain as the poor season continues. Females dominated the sale with limited numbers of young cattle penned. 

Medium weight steers made to 125.2c to average 115.7c as the limited number of heavy weights reached 133.2c/kg. The better light heifers sold to 116.2c as plainer E2s averaged 94.2c/kg. 

Light cows made to 91.2c as plainer lines averaged 65.4c/kg. Medium weight D2s reached 100c as a small pen of D3s sold for 105c/kg.

As numbers returned to pre-Easter levels, cows dominated the export yarding. The quality of the offering was reported as not to the standard of previous weeks. The lack of quality can be attributed to the drying season, causing feed quality to slip. All the usual local and export buyers were in attendance.

The light D2 steers sold to 141.2c, as the medium weights topped at 163.2c/kg. Processors were keen to obtain the better end of the heavy steers and bullocks, as large numbers of heavy steers also sold to 163.2c/kg. Heavy bullocks were in small numbers, but still sold to 166.2c to return over $1,000/head. 

The light weight heifers were dealt losses of up to 9c, as the D3s reached 146.2c to average 136c/kg. The large numbers of cows received similar losses to the heifers. The light D2s topped at 125.2c, as the medium weight D3s reached 139.2c to average 129.6c/kg.

All bulls fell into the D1 category, with both the light and medium weights selling to 127.2c/kg. Heavy bulls were in the largest number and sold to 135.2c/kg.

As is expected for this time of year, the yarding is becoming smaller and plainer in quality, there was however, some good cows scattered throughout. The reduced quality yarding was one of the major factors in the some types suffering losses. All the regular buyers were in attendance, but not all were active. 

The lighter steers gained 4c after selling to 128.2c, while the medium weights reached 160.2c/kg. The heavy steers and bullocks were in limited numbers, with the single heavy bullock returning over $1,000/head. 

The heifer quality was not up to previous weeks standards. Those in the largest number and suffering one of the largest falls for the sale was the D3s, despite selling to 136.2c/kg. The light cows sold to 122.2c, as large numbers of medium weight D3s averaged 126c/kg. 

Both the medium and heavy bulls suffered falls of 11c, with the heavy weights selling to 136.2c/kg.

As has been the case across most markets, a dearer trend resulted from the reduced cattle offered direct and at physical markets. Export categories have again received the greatest gains with good quality cattle assisting the improvements. 

Good medium weight steers averaged 156.7c after selling to 160.2c/kg. The heavy steers topped at 169.2c to average 167c/kg. Grown heifers were in too few numbers to accurately quote. 

Light lean cows lifted 10c to average 102.4c/kg. A large number of medium weight D3s averaged 134.6c after selling to a top of 142.2c/kg. Heavy cows reached 139.4c/kg.

Another reduced offering of 245 head at Charters Towers today in their post Easter sale. All grades managed to correct the losses that were encountered in last weeks market.

A limited number of grown steers and bullocks were penned with the top rates at 129.2c and the average at 128.1c/kg. There was very few grown heifers yarded and they made to 125.2c and averaged at 116.5c/kg.

A larger offering of lighter weight cows saw a sample of 106 D1s range from 85.2c to 105.2c/kg, with their average at 98.1c/kg. The smaller representation of medium weights ranged from 110c to 115c, to average at 112.7c/kg. Very few bulls were penned to form an accurate comparison however most quotes were in the early 100 mark.

Another larger yarding was offered to all the regular buyers. Competition was not as strong as previous sales with most categories selling to a cheaper market. Cattle were mostly drawn from the local areas, which are showing the signs of lack of recent rain. 

Light steers were in limited numbers as most medium weights averaged 140.7c/kg. Good heavy steers averaged 152c after selling to 155.2c/kg.  Export heifers were dominated by leaner descriptions averaging 122.2c/kg. 

A fair number of cows were yarded with the majority in the light and medium weight ranges. Light cows sold to 127.2c with most selling in the 93c to 116c/kg range. Plain lightweights averaged under 79c/kg. Medium weight D3s averaged 129.4c after selling to 138.2c/kg. A small pen of heavy weights sold for 143.2c/kg.

Another large yarding of 1,254 prime cattle were reported from Charters Towers this week where all descriptions met a strong market throughout.  In the export steers, medium types sold to 124.2c for a good sample of D3 s, heavy steers, C4, reached 133.6c, while other heavier ox topped at 133.8c/kg, this market mainly unchanged on last week.  

A large sample of D3 heifers sold up to 119.2c, and these averaged 107.7c/kg.  Cows dominated the yarding, with big samples of D2 heavy cows to 109.2c and a few very heavy types to 110.2c to average around 97c/kg.  Bulls sold at particularly strong rates to sell to 155.2c.

An increased yarding to 1,357 head this week after the previous week's very small numbers, saw values lift 2c to 4c/kg for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents. The increase was due to some increased restocker, backgrounding for live export and improved quality of the yarding. All but one of the major processors were in attendance and operating, with restockers showing an increased presence and bidding activity throughout the offering. Cattle were drawn from Dimbulah, Georgetown, Einasleigh, Greenvale, Hughenden, Pentland and local areas.

Vealer steers were few in number, with the better quality and heavy types selling to increased values, topping at 361c/kg. Good quality yearling steers sold to very strong restocker competition, topping at 358c, averaging 346c/kg. Vealer heifers were in strong demand and the short supply saw values lift to 324c/kg. Yearling heifers were well supplied and some good lines sold very strongly to return to the paddock for a top of 303c to average 296c/kg. PTIC heifers sold to 278c/kg.

Some good quality bullocks saw values increase 2c to 4c, with 3 score bullocks to slaughter topping at 266c, averaging 265c, while 2 score bullocks to restockers sold to 246c/kg. Some small lines of well grown steers to restockers sold to 258c/kg. Well finished, heavy 3 score cows also saw values increase 2c to 4c, selling to a top of 222c to average 209c, while heavy 2 score cows sold to 212c, averaging 203c/kg. Heavy grown heifers to slaughter sold to 248c/kg. Competition for good heavy bulls was very strong with most bulls destined for live export selling to 230c, averaging 226c, while medium weight bulls sold to 235c/kg.

An increased yarding of 806 head on previous sale owing to the Easter break, saw 1,864 head drawn by Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, with some very good lines of prime bullocks and cows selling 8c to 12c higher and heavy bulls lifting 60c/kg. One of the major processors was again absent, with four other major processors, two live exporters, regular feeder buyers and restockers operating in a large buyer gallery.  Cattle were drawn from Burketown, Chillagoe, Richmond, Hughenden, Greenvale, Ingham, Woodstock, local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers were in good supply, selling to 354c to restockers, averaging 326c/kg. Yearling steers sold lower on last sale, with heavy steers to feed - destined for live export selling to 289c, while those returning to paddock sold to 321, averaging 314c/kg. Grown steers sold strongly to restockers topping at 274c, while those to feed destined for live export sold to 256c/kg. Vealer heifers were generally well finished with heifers to slaughter selling to 286c and heifers to restockers sold to 302c, averaging 286c/kg. Yearling heifers were in good supply, topping at 302c to restockers, while heifers to feed sold 265c to average 257c/kg.

An increased supply of good quality heavy 3 score bullocks to slaughter sold to 287c, averaging 276c, while lighter 2 score bullocks returning to the paddock sold to 246c, to average 239c/kg. Good quality heavy 3 score cows were well supplied, selling 4c to 9c higher on last sale, topping at 242c, averaging 221c, while heavy 2 score cows sold to 225c, also averaging 221c/kg. Medium weight 3 score cows to slaughter topped at 240c, to average 209c, while lighter 2 score cows to restockers sold to 186c, averaging 179c/kg. Some very good heavy bulls were the highlight of the sale, with two live exporters pushing values to 291c, averaging 271c, with many selling above 274c/kg. Medium weight bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 287c/kg. Several smaller lines of cows and calves sold strongly from $1,180 to $1,410, topping at $1,640/unit.

An increased yarding of 1,864 mixed quality cattle were drawn by Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, following no sale last week. A spirited buyer gallery was present and supported by three regular processors, with only selective interest throughout the prime section. Store cattle dominated the yarding, with restocker interest very strong for many lines, whilst feeder operators were also active throughout the sale.  Cattle were drawn from Croydon, Richmond, Greenvale, Belyando, Tully, Ingham, Woodstock and local and coastal areas. 

Vealer heifers were mixed in quality and condition, selling to 298.2c, with many lines selling to 265c/kg. Vealer steers sold to consistently dearer rates, selling to a record 319.2c, with many lines surpassing 300c/kg. Restocker buyers actively competed for a couple of larger lines of very good quality steers and heifers, resulting in the highest prices for cattle sold in Charters Towers. 

3 score bullocks were very short in supply and sold to 275.2c/kg. Some large lines of cows lifted the quality of the cow offering, with 3 score cows selling to 229.2c and 2 score cows selling to 219c/kg.  Bulls sold strongly to feeder operators and one processor, with the top price of 240.2c/kg for 4 score heavy weight bulls. Lighter bulls sold to feed, destined for live export, to a top of 224c/kg. Several pens of cows and calves were offered with mixed quality and condition present. Lines sold from $380 to $820/unit.

An increased yarding of 1,806 mixed quality cattle were yarded by Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, with new record prices across most categories. Yearling steers and heifers were in strong demand, while cows and bullocks values increased on last sale with all major processors and feeder buyers active throughout the sale. Cattle were drawn from Croydon, Georgetown, Hughenden, Tully, Ingham, Guru, Woodstock, local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers were in short supply, however bidding from the gallery was very strong, resulting in a new record of 400.2c/kg. Yearling steers lifted in numbers, with feeder buyers underpinning the market, topping at 323.2c/kg, while steers to restockers sold to 326.2c/kg. A small number of very good vealer heifers were drawn which also sold to a new record of 340.2c/kg. Yearling heifers were well supplied, attracting strong competition from feeder buyers, selling to 302.2c/kg, while heifers to restockers sold to 277.2c/kg.

A mixed yarding of bullocks were firm on last week, with 3 score bullocks to slaughter selling to 298.2c/kg, while 2 score bullocks to restockers sold to 277.2c/kg. Several well grown steers sold to 294.2c/kg. There were some very good 3 and 4 score cows on offer, with yet another saleyard record of 274.2c/kg, averaging 258.7c/kg. Heavy 3 and 4 score supplementary fed cows sold to 265.2c/kg. Heavy 2 score cows made to 257.2c/kg, while medium weight 2 score cows to slaughter topped at 236.2c/kg, consistently selling above 220c/kg. Heavy heifers to slaughter sold to 298.2c/kg, while heifers to feed sold to 310.2c/kg. Some very good heavy bulls to slaughter sold to 265.2c/kg, while medium weight bulls to feed, destined for live export sold to 300.2c/kg. Recent strong sales for cows and calves saw an increased offering selling to a top of $1,480, with most pens making from $1,200 to $1,375/unit.

An increased yarding of 1,726 plainer cattle was drawn by Charters Towers Combined Agents, with finished cattle in short supply, whilst a large consignment of bulls from northern areas was on offer. Live export competition was strong for suitable lines, whilst one major processor did not participate on any slaughter cattle. 

Vealer steers were keenly sought after for live export, topping at 275.2c/kg. Very limited numbers of yearling steers sold to 260.2c/kg. Limited numbers of yearling heifers for slaughter sold to 282c/kg. Heavy 4 score cows sold to 260.2c, while 3 score cows sold to 235c/kg. 

A small number of 4 score bullocks topped at 289.2c/kg. Bulls sold to 260c, with many lines selling around 220c/kg, with strong bidding throughout the offering. A good line of cows & calves sold to $1,030/unit.

An increased supply of well finished bullocks and cows lifted numbers by 408 head to 2,744 head for Charters Towers Combined Agents this week, with a new record for cows and calves. The yarding also had an increase of grown heifers and steers which saw strong feeder competition, limiting restockers to younger lighter weight cattle. Despite the absence of one regular processor again this week, heavy bullocks and cows lifted 4c to 8c, while yearling cattle were 3c to 5c/kg easier on recent sales, while vealer cattle eased albeit reduced numbers with more variable quality. Cattle were drawn from Burketown, Normanton, Croydon, Einasleigh, Tully, Ingham, Woodstock, Guru, Balfes Creek, Belyando, local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers were in shorter supply this week, whilst there was an increase in the young male offering which sold to 386.2c/kg to restockers. Vealer steers once again sold above 400c to restockers, topping at 402.2c/kg. A lift in yearling steer numbers saw values again strong, with steers to feed selling to 356.2c, for an average of 338.1c, while live exporters filling their consignment paid to 332.2c/kg. Several pens of grown steers sold to feeder buyers to 336.2c for an average of 316.4c/kg. Vealer heifers were fewer in number and the more variable quality saw values ease 14c to 16c, with restockers topping at 339.2c/kg. Large numbers of yearling heifers again sold strongly to feeder buyers, topping at 334.2c, averaging 321.8c, while restockers paid to 298.2c/kg for lighter types.

A very good consignment of northern bullocks attracted strong processor interest selling to 299.2c, while heavy steers to slaughter sold to 336.2c/kg. Lighter 2 score bullocks to restockers sold to 294.2c and bullocks to feeder buyers destined for live export sold to 286.2c/kg. Another very good yarding of well finished cows saw values increase for best 3 and 4 score cows, selling to 265.2c to average 247.4, while heavy 2 score cows for slaughter sold to 243.2c to average 230c/kg. Lighter cows to restockers sold to 234.2c, averaging 197c/kg. Best grown heifers to slaughter sold to 316c/kg. A very good selection of heavy bulls to slaughter sold to 255.2c, while live exporters paid to 244c/kg for suitable types. Medium weight bulls to feed, destined for live export sold to 274.2c/kg. A significant record was set for cows and calves topping at $1,900/unit for a good line of cows and calves, with many lines selling for $1,330 to $1,780/unit.

An increased supply of some well finished bullocks and grown heifers, and some large store lines lifted numbers by 390 head to 2,892 cattle in Charters Towers this week, with bullocks firm on last sale and cows easing 2c to 6c/kg. Store cattle were in good supply particularly yearling heifers, which again attracted strong competition from feeder buyers. All regular processors and feeder buyers were present and operating, along with one live exporter, however restockers were fewer in number. Cattle were drawn from Burketown, Chillagoe, Georgetown, Einasleigh, Richmond, Belyando, Ingham, Woodstock, local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers sold to a new record of 419.2c, with many lines of good conditioned vealer steers selling above 400c/kg. Lighter, less conditioned types sold to 410c, to average 397c/kg. Yearling steers were in good supply with some larger northern lines selling strongly to feeder buyers topping at 342.2c, while steers to restockers sold to 363.2c/kg. An increased number of grown steers were penned selling to 328.2c/kg to feeder buyers. Live exporters were very active for suitable steers, topping at 349.2c, regularly bidding above 340c/kg to secure volume for next shipment. Vealer heifers again were in good supply with better conditioned heifers selling to 328.2c to restockers, while lighter types to feed sold to 322.2c/kg. Yearling heifers continued recent trends with strong demand from feeder buyers for suitable types. Heifers 300-380kg sold to 326.2c, while heifers less than 300kg to restockers sold to 310.2c/kg.

Increased numbers of well finished 3 score bullocks to slaughter sold to 292.2c, with some excellent 3 score grown steers to slaughter selling to 303.2c/kg. Restockers were very competitive on 2 score steers and bullocks, topping at 278.2c/kg. A mixed yarding of cows sold to easier rates on last sale, with heavy 3 score cows selling to 256.2c, to average 243.8c, while 2 score cows to slaughter topped at 239.2c, to average 229.6c/kg. Cows to feed sold to 231c, with cows to restockers selling selectively to 265.2c, with most around 240c/kg. Bulls were very mixed quality and topped at 247.2c for a small number of heavy 3 score types, with many 2 score medium weight bulls regularly making 228c/kg. Young males set a new saleyard record of 423.2c/kg to restockers. An increased number of cows and calves sold to $1,520, with most sales above $1,350/unit.

An increased supply of prime cows saw numbers lift by more than 650 head to 1,604 cattle in Charters Towers this week, with several very good lines of high yielding heavy cows and bullocks on offer. Two additional processors were in attendance coinciding with most categories improving in price, supported by one live exporter and several opportunity restockers and backgrounders. Cattle were drawn from Burketown, Cloncurry, Prairie, Croydon, Greenvale, Ingham, Belyando, local and coastal areas.

There were insufficient young steers to reliably quote, however a good supply of young heifers met strong demand on selected lighter types and those suitable for slaughter. Yearling heifers to feed increased by 5c to 12c and grown heifers to the trade improved by 5c to 7c/kg. Light heifer calves to restockers sold to 204c and heifers above 200kg sold to 202c, to average 169c, with heavier types to feed reaching 230c/kg. A small line of yearling steers to the trade sold to 294c/kg. Yearling heifers to feed sold to 227c, averaging 220c and well grown types to slaughter made to 275c, to average 245c/kg. A large sample of yearling heifers to restockers sold to 214c to average 197c/kg.

Grown steers to processors increased by 8c and heavy export bullocks to slaughter improved by 12c/kg. Increased numbers of medium weight cows to processors increased by 20c and heavy cows improved by 5c, with better quality light cows returning to grass improving by up to 30c/kg. Grown heifers to the trade sold to 270c to average 256c/kg for better quality heavy lines. Grown steers to processors sold to 305c and heavy export bullocks topped at 307c, with most on offer selling above 300c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows sold to 187c to average 162c and lighter cows to restockers averaged 134c/kg. A large sample of very good quality heavy 3 score cows topped at 242c to average near 230c and high yielding extra heavy cows sold to a season high 246c, to average 244c, with 4 score cows averaging 240c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export sold to 297c to average more than 280c and heavy bulls to slaughter sold to 300c/kg.

An increased supply of cattle for a Combined Prime & Store sale resulted in 4,139 penned, an increase of 1,353 than a fortnight ago. Some very good lines of grown steers and heifers, along with 880 cows lifted the supply of prime cattle. Quality was mixed with some lesser quality northern cattle offered throughout. One major export processor was in attendance but not operating, while all other processors and feeders operated at softer rates on last sale. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Croydon, Georgetown, Richmond, Pentland, Hervey’s Range, local and coastal areas. Values eased for most classes with prime steers, heifers and cows easing 6c to 13c/kg while vealer and yearlings averaged 15c to 40c/kg lower.

Light vealer steers returning to the paddock sold to 590.2c to average 570c and suitably weaned steers above 200kg also returning to grass sold to 590.2c to average 517c. Similar heifers to the trade made to 428.2c to average 405c to 423c/kg. Good quality yearling steers met limited demand, with all categories easier on last sale. Steers above 280kg to feed sold to 540.2c to average 494c and similar weight steers to backgrounders sold to 546.2c to average 468c/kg. A good sample of steers above 330kg to feed topped at 510.2c to average 468c/kg. Yearling heifers were of mixed quality sold in line with quality. Good quality heifers above 280kg returning to grass for breeding sold to 432.2c while heifers to feed sold from 380c to 410c/kg. Heifers above 330kg to feed topped at 432.2c to average from 379c to 410c/kg. 

Two large lines of grown steers attracted strong demand. Steers above 400kg to feed sold to 444.2c to average 376c to 441c, with trade types averaging 403c/kg. A good sample of heavy steers above 500kg to processors sold to 426.2c to average 409c to 414c/kg. A large sample of grown heifers to the trade reached 382.2c to average 372c/kg. Mixed quality heifers to feed sold to 404.2c to average 343c to 389c/kg. A large single vendor line of heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 416.2c to average 394c to 406c/kg. 

Mixed demand for cows resulted in a general easing in price. Medium weight 3 score cows to processors sold to 350.2 to average 322c to 341c and prime heavyweight cows topped at 362.2c to average 338c to 344c/kg. Heavy bulls to feed destined for live export made to 370.2c to average 361c/kg. A small line of PTIC cows sold from sold for 420c/kg.

A small number of mixed quality cows and calves sold from $1475 to $1,950/unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

An increased number of prime cattle this week saw a larger yarding of 1,539 head drawn by Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents, with most rates easing in line with southern markets.  All major processors were in attendance and operating throughout the prime section alongside a major feeder operator and local backgrounders for live export.  Increased numbers of prime bullocks and steers generally sold lower, while prime heifers and medium weight cows also fell on last week.  Cattle were drawn from Richmond, Georgetown, Greenvale, Belyando, Ingham, Woodstock, local and coastal areas. Store cattle were fewer in number despite an increased presence of restocker buyers with most values easing as the northern dry season emerges, and reduced live export quotes in recent weeks.

Vealer steers were few in number, with very good condition pens selling to 290.2c/kg.  Yearling steers were in good supply, with some good lines attracting very strong interest selling from 260-280c topping at 282.2c/kg. Vealer heifers were generally plainer in condition and sold to 256.2c, while yearling heifers sold to 239.2c/kg to limited buyer competition. 

The increase in bullock numbers saw softer demand for lighter types, with feeders and backgrounders buying the majority of lines on offer.  3 score bullocks sold to 233.2c for slaughter, while 2 score grown steers sold to 234.2c/kg. Limited numbers of heavy 3 score cows sold to 204.2c/kg, whilst an increased number of plainer medium weight cows saw values ease across the offering, with processors, backgrounders and feeders all operating on selected lines. 2 score medium weight cows sold to 185.2c, with many lines selling for 140-160c/kg. Slaughter weight bulls sold to 195.2c, while medium weight bulls to feed for live export sold to 224.2c/kg.  Young feeder lines sold strongly to restockers and feeder buyers, selling to 252.2c/kg. A good line of medium age cows and calves sold to $1,160, with older cow and calf units selling for $820/unit.

An increase of nearly 1,000 head, for a yarding of 2,518 cattle this week for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents, dominated by some good lines of bullocks and cows and northern store steers. All regular processors were in attendance and operating, accompanied by one live exporter, feeder buyers and several restockers. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Cloncurry, Richmond, Normanton, Georgetown, Ingham, Ayr, Woodstock, Ravenswood, Belyando, local and coastal areas. A reduced number of vealer steer this week with variable quality saw values ease with lighter lines selling to 358c/kg. Yearling steers comprised mostly of two northern lines, with strong competition from the buying panel throughout, and backgrounders from Central Queensland keeping values firm, securing lines up to 329c, to average 325c/kg.

Vealer heifers comprised of some well finished smaller lines topping at 288c to slaughter to average 266c, and 267c/kg for lighter types returning to grass. Yearling heifer numbers increased, with some very good quality with most selling to feed, topping at 288c increasing 3c to 4c for an average of 266c/kg.

Some good lines of well finished bullocks and one very large line of high quality medium weight bullocks attracted strong processor and backgrounder competition, with heavy 3 score bullocks to slaughter selling to 278c and averaging 275c, while backgrounders sold to 274c to average 270c/kg. Heavy grown steers returning to grass sold to 294c to average 291c/kg. A good supply of heavy cows increased 8c to 11c on last sale, with heavy C muscled 3 score cows to slaughter selling to 242c averaging 232c, while D muscled 3 score cows sold to 234c to average 219c/kg. Heavy 2 score cows sold to 217c and averaging 205c, with lighter cows of variable quality to restockers sold to 183c/kg. The supply of good heavy bulls eased with more variation in weight and condition, however one live exporter continued recent demand, with bulls selling to 280c, with most sales from 271c to 276c while the occasional bull to slaughter sold to 246c/kg. A small number of average quality cows and calves sold to $875/unit.

An increase of 950 head to 2,746 head were drawn by Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week with some very good lines of prime cows and good lines of northern steers and heifers. All regular processors were in attendance, (except one notable absentee for several weeks now), with all operating along with regular feeder buyers and some southern and western restockers, although very selective on quality. Prime bullocks and cows eased 5c to 8c, bulls were 10c to 25c easier, while limited numbers of feeder cattle lifted 3c to 7c/kg. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Richmond, Prairie, Croydon, Einasleigh, Mt Garnet, Ingham, Woodstock, Belyando, local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers were in good supply, aided by a large run of northern steers which sold to 407.2c, with many lines selling around 386c/kg. Yearling steers were fewer in number again this week, with restockers active on lighter lines, which sold to 376.2c/kg. Yearling steers to feed sold to 346.2c, to average 333.6c, with grown steers to feed selling to 342.2c/kg. Yearling heifer numbers lifted this week, with a good line northern heifers to restockers making 335.2c/kg. Some very good lines of vealer heifers to slaughter sold to 343.2c/kg. Yearling heifers were of mixed quality this week, with restockers and feeder buyers very selective for quality on many lines. Yearling heifers to restockers sold to 336.2c, while heifers to feed sold to 340.2c, to average 334.5c/kg. Some very good grown heifers to feed sold to 344.2c/kg.

There were reduced numbers of 3 score bullocks on offer, which sold to slaughter for 288.2c/kg. There were greater numbers of 2 score bullocks being secured by restockers and feeder buyers, selling to 275.2c/kg. Heavy grown steers to feed sold to 338.2c/kg, as did heavy steers to central grass fatteners. Heavy 3 score cows were in good supply and sold strongly throughout, selling to 255.2c, to average 245.3c/kg. Heavy 2 score cows sold to 243.2c, for a reduced average of 236.8c, while the highlight of the sale was a pen of heavy 2 score cows to central restockers, making 282.2c, for an average of 256c/kg. Greater numbers of heavy bulls sold to easier rates, with heavy 3 score bulls to slaughter topping at 250.2c, while medium weight bulls to feed, destined for live export sold to 271.2c/kg. A very good pen of cows and calves set a new saleyard record of $1,900, with most other lines selling from $730 to $1,240/unit.

An increase of 748 cattle to 1,979 head were yarded by Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, with a significant lift in values for all classes, led by restockers throughout the offering.  All regular processors were in attendance and operating as in recent weeks, but the presence of central, southern and western restockers spurred on by recent rains and record values in southern markets, saw values for light cows, store steers and heifers surge by up to 50c/kg on some lines. Cattle were drawn from Richmond, Einasleigh, Ingham, Ayr, Woodstock, Ravenswood, local and coastal areas, with some very good quality lines of prime and young cattle on offer.

Vealer steers were in good supply and quality was generally very good for some lighter weight descriptions, with restockers from areas receiving good recent rains lifting values to a top of 378.2c, with many lines selling for 335c to 365c/kg.  Yearling steers were also in good supply with quality much better than recent sales selling to 346.2c, while feeder steers sold to 338.2c to average 323.4c/kg. Vealer heifers were also in high demand, with several restockers jostling to secure numbers - while setting new records - selling to a top of 345.2c/kg.  Yearling heifers were in good supply with one outstanding line of heifers selling to 312.2c to restockers to average 281.4c, while feeder heifers sold to 299.2c to average 292.9c/kg. 

A continuation of a very good selection of 3 and 4 score cows sold to a dearer market, with processors very competitive for heaviest cows selling to 269.2c, to average 254.7c/kg. Heavy 2 score cows sold to 246.2c/kg.  Medium weight 2 score cows to slaughter sold to 247.2c, to average 233.7c, while lighter 2 score cows to restockers sold to 226.2c to average 213.8c/kg.  The few good trade heifers sold to 252.2c/kg. Bulls varied in quality and condition with heavy bulls to slaughter selling to a top of 258.2c, while medium weight bulls sold to 256.2c/kg.  Bulls to feed for live export sold to 256.2c/kg.  Young light weight bulls sold to 378.2c to restockers, with most 160-220kg selling from 340c to 360.2c, while yearling bulls to feed sold to 279.2c/kg. Only a few cows and calves were on offer, selling from $700 to $1,050/unit, for a milking cow with calf at foot.

An increase of 73 head on last sale saw 3,175 cattle penned in Charters Towers, comprising of mixed lines of prime cows, heifers and bullocks and large lines of store steers and heifers. Only two regular processors actively operated throughout the sale along with one live exporter and a regular feeder buyers, with minimal restocker activity. Cattle were drawn from north of Julia Ck to Mt Surprise supported by many small local and coastal lines. The deteriorating season and influences outside the industry saw the majority of young steers and heifers selling to reduced rates, easing by 20c to 40c/kg for a large sample, with very subdued restocker demand. Yearling steers and heifers to feed eased 15c to 20c throughout, with trade types up to 30c/kg lower. Increased numbers of grown heifers to processors sold to rates up to 35c lower with selective demand from processors, while grown steers attracted some live export demand, generally easing by 15c to 20c/kg throughout. Medium weight cows to processors sold 8c lower and heavy weights were 11c to 13c lower, while heavy bulls to processors went against the trend improving by 20c/kg.

Light vealer steers to feed sold to 349c to average 324c, with processor types averaging 328c/kg. Vealer heifers to trade sold to 268c with most sales from 240c to 260c and yearling heifers to trade sold to 276c to average 225c to 240c, with a large sample to feed averaging 219c/kg. Yearling steers suitable for live export sold to 311c, with good quality steers to feed making to 342c to average from 323c to 328c/kg. Grown heifers to the trade sold to 259c to average 231c/kg.

Mixed quality lines of bullocks to export process sold to 304c with most sales from 272c to 296c to average 283c/kg. Medium weight cows to processors sold to 199c to average 187c and heavy 3 score cows sold to 236c to average 230c, with a large sample of lesser yielding cows averaging 217c and 4 score cows averaged 230c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors sold to 311c to average 304c/kg. Several small lines of cows and calves sold from $640 to 990/unit.

An increase of 573 head to 1,913 cattle were drawn by Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, with prices easing for slaughter cattle, but setting new records for lighter store categories. One regular processor was again absent this week resulting in less competition for prime cattle, however restockers and feeder buyers jostled throughout the sale for better quality types. A large yarding of lighter conditioned, medium weight bulls was on offer which consistently met subdued demand. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Cloncurry, Normanton, Richmond, Ingham, Ayr, Woodstock, local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers were generally of light condition, however restocker demand was exceptionally strong throughout, more particularly on larger lines. A new saleyard record was set for steers returning to the paddock for 450c, with many smaller lines selling from 350c to 380c/kg. Yearling steers again were in shorter supply, with feeder buyers securing most suitable weight lines to a top of 334c, to average 306c, while steers to restockers sold to 366c, for an average of 354c/kg. Vealer heifers were again dominated by one large northern line that sold strongly to restockers for a near record of 384c/kg. Yearling heifers were generally lighter than recent sales, with heifers to feed topping at 398c/kg.  Yearling heifers to restockers sold to 294c/kg.

Very few slaughter bullocks were on offer, with the best 3 score bullocks to slaughter selling to 271c, to average of 258c/kg. Grown steers returning to the paddock sold to 248c, while steers to feed sold to 322c/kg. Cow numbers again were well below many sales throughout the year, however quality was generally good, with restockers active throughout sale.  Heavy 3 score cows to slaughter sold to 224c, while 2 score cows sold to 218c/kg. Cows returning to the paddock sold to 218c/kg, with northern and western restockers continually active. A large number of lighter conditioned, medium weight northern bulls were present, which met subdued demand from processors and feeder buyers alike. Heavy 3 score bulls to slaughter sold lower to a top of 221c, while 1 and 2 score bulls to grass sold to 172c/kg. Young, light weight bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 326c/kg. Young males to restockers sold to 348c/kg. A good selection of cows and calves sold from $1,220 to $1,580 with most selling for $1,520/unit.

An increase of 261 head to 1,496 cattle were drawn by Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents, featuring some very good lines of bullocks and cows along with a large line of northern steers. Recent upward adjustments in grid prices was reflective across all heavy prime cattle, improving by 11c to 23c/kg. One regular processor continued their absence for the year, however all others operated on increased rates, accompanied by two live exporters, two feeder buyers and several restockers. Cattle were drawn from Normanton, Palmerston, Balfes Creek Ayr, Belyando, local and coastal areas.

A small offering of vealer steers met very strong demand, returning to grass for a top of 352c, averaging 335c/kg. A very good large consignment of yearling steers attracted spirited competition from feeder buyers, restockers and live exporters, with many sales above 310c/kg. Steers to restockers topped at 335c to achieve a strong average of 324c/kg. Heavy feeder steers (330-400kg) to live export sold to 314c to average 299c, while steers 280-330kg sold to 329c, to average 324c/kg. A number of small lines of vealer heifers of variable quality sold to mixed demand, with better quality and finished heifers topping at 282c to average 278c, with plainer types averaging 267c/kg. Yearling heifer numbers were considerably lower than recent weeks, with great variation in quality and type. Heifers to feed sold to 260c, while heifers returning to grass sold to 280c/kg. Heifers to slaughter averaged 199c/kg.
