A very good offering of some large lines of bullocks sold stronger on last sale, with best heavy 3 score bullocks to slaughter selling to 258c, increasing 12c to average 253c/kg. The small number fitting live export specifications sold to 254c, with lesser quality types to feed selling to 232c/kg. Grown steers also met strong demand from restockers topping at 278c, an increase of 5c to average 259c/kg. Some good pens of cows met stronger demand than previous weeks, with heavy C muscle 4 score cows topping at 207c multiple times, while heavy D muscled cows sold to 203c, increasing 11c to average 193c/kg. Better quality heavy D muscled 2 score cows sold to 205c, lifting 21c on last sale to average 183c/kg. A small number of cows returning to grass sold to 198c/kg. Heavy bulls of mixed quality met strong demand from live exporters and processors, with bulls to live export selling to 252c, while those to slaughter sold to 230c/kg. Some good lines of young light males sold very strongly, topping at 343c to average 326c/kg. A couple of small lines of cows and calves sold to $750/unit.

An increase of 2,105 cattle to 3,491 head, the largest in 4 years, was drawn by Charters Towers Combined Selling Agent this week.  All of the regular processors and one southern processor, feeder buyers and western restockers were active throughout the offering which saw prime values ease in line with southern markets, while store heifers increased to new record values.

Cattle were drawn from Normanton, Croydon, Einasleigh, Richmond, Hughenden, Greenvale, Tully, Ingham, Woodstock, local and coastal areas.

Vealer heifers were of good quality selling to a dearer market, topping at 322.2c, to average 309.3c/kg. Several large lines of yearling heifers were attracted strong feeder interest, with several western restockers also active on lighter types. Heifers to feed sold to 316.2c, averaging 304.7c, while heifers to restockers sold to 312.2c for a strong average of 292.8c/kg

Vealer steers sold very strongly to an active restocker panel of buyers selling to 384.2c, to average 356.7c/kg. Yearling steers were also in strong demand by feeder buyers, underpinned by restockers for lighter weights. Yearling steers to feed sold to 336.2c, while those to restockers sold to 309c/kg. 

Grown steers sold to 314c, for feeder weight lines while restockers pushed values to 325c to average 272.6c/kg. A continued large yarding of prime cows saw values ease by 10c to 20c, with heavy 3 score cows selling to 268.2c, to average 241.7c, while 2 score cows for slaughter sold to 247.2c, for an average of 221.9c/kg. Lighter 2 score cows sold to 230c, averaging 187c/kg. Heavy heifers sold considerably stronger, selling to 304.2c/kg. 

A very good selection of heavy bulls attracted interest from a live export buyer selling to 264.2c/kg. Processors pushed values to 272.2c/kg for heavy slaughter bulls. Lighter bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 260.2c/kg.

Only two small pens of cows and calves sold to $910/unit.

An increase of 148 head to 1,608 cattle were yarded by Charters Towers Combined Agents this week, with continued good lines of finished cows and bullocks presented along with some very good quality store cattle.  All regular processors were in attendance with the continued activity of two southern processors on suitable lines. Cattle were drawn from Normanton, Richmond, Einasleigh, Tully, Woodstock, local and coastal areas. The recent weather induced increase in values in southern markets and renewed northern live export demand, lifted prices throughout the offering, with heavy slaughter cows and bullocks up 10c to 14c/kg. Store values also increased on the better quality types by up to 25c/kg.

Vealer steers were present in small lines and sold to strong restocker competition reaching a top of 316.2c/kg. Yearling steers were varied in quality and number, with the best lines selling to a top of 314.2c/kg, again with restockers very active on the offering. A good offering of vealer heifers were present, with many restockers bidding for the better lines selling to a top of 285.2c/kg. Yearling heifers were few in number and sold to a top of 256.2c/kg.

Fewer bullocks were on offer this week, however the ensuing live export orders saw processors unable to match the values for suitable types.  Bullocks topped at 284.2c, to average 264.8c/kg. Feeder steers of suitable feeder and slaughter weights were also sold to live export, reaching 278.2c/kg. Another good quality offering of well finished cows were on offer with processors active throughout, supported by restockers on lighter types. Heavy 3 score cows to slaughter sold to 238.2c to average 221.3c, while heavy 2 score cows to slaughter sold to 239.2c, to average 211.6c/kg. Light cows to restockers sold to 192.2c for an average of 158.2c/kg. Heavy heifers to slaughter sold to 240.2c, while heifers to feed sold to 254.2c, to average 247c/kg. An increase number of bulls were on offer, with strong competition between live export and processors. Heavy 3 score bulls to slaughter sold to 230.2c, while heavy bulls to live export sold to 259.2c/kg. Feeder weight bulls to live export sold to 265.2c/kg. Light young males sold to 304.2c/kg.

A small number of cows and calves were on offer, selling to $1,190/unit.

An increase of 1,260 head saw 1,934 cattle drawn in Charters Towers this week, with increased numbers of prime cows and heavy bulls. Some large consignments of northern gulf cattle were also on offer for the regular buyer panel, supported by one live exporter, one feeder buyer and some opportunity western restockers. Cattle were drawn from far northern gulf areas, Corfield, Mt Surprise, Mingela, Belyando, local and coastal areas.

Light steer calves eased for many variable lines, however good quality vealer steers increased by 4c/kg. The demand for vealer heifers was very subdued, with a large sample easing by 29c/kg, however better grown types to live export sold strongly. Many mixed lines of yearling steers sold in line with quality, and yearling heifers to live export and processors increased by more than 20c/kg.  Grown heifers also improved on last sale by up to 20c/kg for heavier types. Heavy bullocks to export processors improved by 1c and medium weight bullocks to processors increased by 7c/kg. A greater supply of medium weight cows saw increased prices throughout, with cows to restockers increasing by 20c/kg along with better covered types to processors. Heavy 3 score cows to processors eased by 1c and extra heavy cows declined by 3c, however a large sample of lower yielding heavy D muscled cows increased by up to 11c/kg. Suitable heavy bulls to live export sold 9c dearer and heavy weight bulls to processors increased by up to 17c/kg.

Steer calves sold to 254c, to average 242c and young heifer calves averaged 160c/kg. Small lines of vealer steers made to 310c, to average 270c/kg. A small sample of good quality vealer heifers to restockers sold to 226c, with the majority of lighter heifers selling 29c cheaper to average 142c/kg.  Yearling steers were very mixed with lighter types to restockers selling to 268c, with a small number of heavier types to processors selling to 294c/kg. Medium weight heifers to live export sold to 224c/kg. Very good quality medium weight yearling heifers to restockers sold to 234c and heavy heifers made to 236c, averaging 227c/kg. Heavy grown heifers to domestic processors sold to 286c, to average 273c/kg.  

Heavy bullocks to export processors sold to 301c, to average 290c, with medium weights selling to 290c, up 7c to average 285c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 160c to average 151c, an increase of 20c/kg, while lighter types to restockers averaged 150c/kg. Heavy 3 score cows to processors sold to 225c to average 218c, while extra heavy cows made to 236c, averaging 226c and 4 score cows averaged 220c/kg. Lower yielding heavy D muscled 3 score cows increased 11c to average 208c, to make a top of 228c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors made to 298c to average 268c and suitable types to live export sold to 290c to average 280c/kg. Young males to restockers and backgrounders sold to 278c, to average 261c/kg.

An increase in supply of 798 head saw 2,014 cattle in Charters Towers this week, following minimal rain in patchy storms last week. Overall quality was mixed with most prime cattle plainer than last sale supported by some very good lines of young steers and heifers. Some of the regular processors operated at comparable rates to last sale, in conjunction with active central feeder and backgrounder buyers and western restockers. Cattle were drawn from Forsayth and Tully in the north to Belyando in the south, supported by many local lines.

Young steers sold to improved rates lifting by 20c to 40c for better quality lines, while young heifers improved by 8c, however mixed lines of yearling heifers to feed and restockers eased by 17c/kg. Increased numbers of grown steers to feed sold to similar rates for better quality types and grown heifers to the trade improved by 4c/kg. A small number of bullocks to export processor sold firm to 5c/kg stronger and plainer lines eased slightly. Increased numbers of medium weight cows to processor eased by up to 50c, while heavy 2 score cows eased by 15c and 3 scores were firm to 5c/kg easier for the small number on offer. Heavy bulls to feed destined for live export increased by 15c/kg.

Steer calves returning to grass sold to 388c, averaging above 372c and heifer calves averaged 282c/kg. Light vealer steers below 200kg to restockers made to 338c to average 328c, with better quality lines above 200kg topping at 388c to average 377c, with lesser quality types averaging 347c/kg. Good quality light vealer heifers returning to grass sold to 290c and heifers above 200kg reached 299c, to average 292c/kg. A large sample of heifers to feed above 200kg sold to 302c to average 295c, with those suitable for process averaging 289c/kg.  

A small number of yearling steers to feed sold to 380c to average 356c/kg. Yearling heifers were of mixed quality with those to feed selling to 310c to average 293c and lighter types to restockers sold to 289c, to average 285c/kg. Fewer numbers of yearling heifers above 400kg to the trade made to 314c/kg.  Increased numbers of grown steers to feed sold to 354c and heifers to feed made to 300c to average 281c, with those to the trade making to 296c to average 281c/kg.

A few small lines of heavy bullocks to export processor sold to 371c, with most selling from 349c to 364c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows to processor sold to 220c, to average 212c, with plainer types returning to grass selling to 200c to average 180c/kg. Heavy 3 score cows sold to 278c to average 263c, with a small number of extra heavy cows making 282c/kg. Heavy bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 349c to average above 345c and prime heavy bulls to processor made to 354c/kg. Young males to backgrounders sold to 390c, while young bulls to feed sold to 372c to average 359c/kg. 

Some good quality lines of cows and calves sold from $1,050 to $1,350/unit.

An increase in numbers to 1,610 cattle was yarded by Charters Towers Combined Agents this week, with quality improving across all lines.  Regular processors were present and active throughout prime sections, accompanied by a live exporter competing for bullocks in particular.  The yarding was drawn from Richmond, Greenvale, Belyando, Ingham, and Woodstock, along with local and coastal areas.

Vealer & yearling steers were in greater numbers and supported by some larger lines that attracted strong competition from restockers. Vealer steers sold from to 280 to 296c, topping at 313c/kg.  Yearling steers were keenly contested, selling in line with the reduction in live export values, and to a top of 286c/kg. Vealer heifers attracted good interest from all restockers and feeders, with many lines selling for 230 to 265c, and reaching a top of 283c/kg. Yearling heifers were less sought after and sold to 212c/kg. A much improved yarding of 2 and 3 score bullocks attracted the interest of a live exporter, with many lines selling for 240 to 245c, and reaching a top of 260c/kg as a result.  Processors were active on 3 score cows that sold to a top of 211c, whilst lighter 2 score cows were sourced primarily by restockers, selling to 195c/kg.

A small number of bulls sold to 190c, with lighter types suitable for live export made to 268c/kg. A number of smaller mixed cows and calves sold to $970/head.

An increase in numbers occurred with many producers offloading cattle in the hope of receiving some of the high rates available. Cattle are being moved not only through the saleyards but also between regions as transport operators are being kept very busy as dry conditions persist. The quality of the yarding was mixed with a very good run of grown steers offered, however the cows were not to the standard of last week.

Grown steer quality was as good has been offered at the centre this year despite the seasonal conditions. A full panel of export buyers operated but one did purchase the greatest percentage of the steers. The medium weights ranged from 151.2c to 164.2c and a larger number of heavy steers sold from 157.2c to 165.2c/kg. 

A plainer cow yarding compared to last week was offered with many back in quality and condition. Lightweight cows were in large numbers and the 2 scores gained 3c to average 125.5c/kg. Prices for medium weights fell for the lighter conditioned lines with the 2 and 3 scores loosing between 5c and 7c, however the 4 score lines were able to maintain a fully firm trend averaging 146.4c/kg.

An improved quality yarding of 967 cattle were drawn by Charters Towers Combined Agents this week, with general improvement in animal condition seen across all classes on offer. Cattle were drawn from Greenvale, Belyando, Ravenswood, Guru, and Ingham, along with local and coastal areas. Bullocks and cows improved on recent sales, with major processors operating on many lines throughout the prime section.  Restocker activity was strong on selected lines of steers and heifers, most notably on well grown vealers.

Vealer steers were strongly contested and sold to a top of 354c/kg, with many lines selling to 340c/kg. Yearling steers were limited in selection, selling to 282c, and averaging 258c/kg. Vealer heifer were limited in supply and sold strongly to a number of restockers, topping at 261c/kg.  A limited number of Yearling heifers sold to a top of 268c/kg.

An increased number of good condition 3 score bullocks sold to 263c, with many selling above 250c, while 2 score bullocks sold to 243c/kg.  An improved quality yarding of cows eased 3 to 8c, with 3 score cows selling to a top of 214c/kg.  2 score cows were in good supply week-on-week, selling to 187c, with most lines ranging from 167 to 174c/kg. Cows and calves were in good supply and sold to a top of $1400, with the plainer lines selling from $700 to 970/head. Bulls were dominated by mixed quality types and sold to a top of 202c/kg.

An even smaller yarding was at Charters Towers to see 215 head yarded. Steers were in the largest numbers, while there was only a few bull yarded and the values varied for all descriptions. 

The D4 bullocks weighing 500 to 600kg sold to an average of 128.1c, up 4c on last week with a top of 129.2c/kg. The heavy weight bullocks sold to the best price for the day of 130.6c to return the vendor $840/head in small numbers. 

The best of the cows were medium weight D4s that sold to 117c which was 4c/kg up on last week.

Although the supply area is too far north for the fair rainfall recorded in other centres, numbers still fell compared to the previous market. Quality was a little better with the trade buyers present competing strongly to secure adequate numbers while restockers competed successfully for the store cattle offered. Steers and heifers were limited in number while cows were well represented percentage wise.

The few medium pens of C muscled steers traded from 148c to 160c while the lower muscled drafts sold from 133c to 142c/kg. 

Cows were 5c dearer with light pens trading from 88c for the D1 pens to a top of 145c/kg for good quality C muscled lines. Medium and heavy drafts sold from 121c to 144c/kg. The top price recorded for bulls was 142c/kg.

All the usual processors, local butchers and other buyers were present and bidding on a slightly smaller yarding. Plain quality cattle are appearing in increasing numbers as the effect of the current dry season begins to show. Some good quality pens of grown steers and cows were offered but they were countered with some poorer quality pennings.

Grown steers sold to strong competition, the medium weight D2s averaging 152.9¢ after reaching 157.9¢/kg. Heavy weights comprised mostly D3s which sold at 163.4¢ after topping at 167.2¢/kg. Heifers were in limited number and sold to a mixed trend.

Cows dominated the yarding with large lines of plain types offered, E1s averaging 77.8¢, E2s averaging 115¢/kg. Heavier D3 types reached 153.2¢ with most sales around 144.5¢/kg. Light E1 bulls were the most prominent in their category and averaged 74¢/kg.

All the regular export buyers were present plus the usual local and coastal butcher competition. Following the trend of the rest of the state s yardings export grades eased as processors operated at reduced rates. Quality overall was mixed with some well-finished pens of bullocks offset by some lighter descriptions. The cow yarding was also varied with a wide range of conditions offered.

The large lines of C muscled bullocks sold to mixed demand to top at 140.2c to average 138.2c/kg. Heavier C4 types topped at 158.2c with most sales at 155.7c/kg. Grown heifers sold to an easing trend with C muscled lines in the majority, they ranges from 121.2c to 138.2c to average 127.6c/kg. 

Large lines of medium weight D3 cows could not avert the falling prices and sold at reduced levels of between 116.2c and 136.2c/kg. Lighter weight cows of similar frame averaged 115c/kg. The best of the bulls sold for 120.2c/kg.

All the regular buyers were in attendance and despite numbers more than doubling prices held firm to slightly dearer form most grades. Some lighter steers of poorer quality lost 4c while all other steers were firm. The heifers sold slightly dearer in places while the poorer quality light cows lost 7c/kg. There was some better quality cows penned that were in fair supply and these generally gained 1c to 2c/kg. 

The light steers sold to an isolated 126.2c while the poorer grades averaged 110.8c/kg. The medium weight steers varied in quality and the better grades averaged 129.3c after they reached 132.2c while the poorer grades averaged 116.7c/kg. The good quality heavy steers sold to 137.2c and they averaged 133.3c/kg. 

The best heifers sold to 122c and they averaged 112.9c while the very light grades sold around 87c/kg. Light cows sold to 112.2c and the D3s averaged 107.3c while the D2s averaged 89.1c/kg. The large number of medium weight D3s topped at 120.2c and averaged 114.3c/kg. 

Light bulls sold around 75c while the heavy weights topped at 123.2c/kg.

All the regular buyers turned out for one of the dearest sales seen at these yards for some time. Strong competition forced a dearer trend for all grades including plain quality descriptions with large improvements recorded on last week s levels. Steer quality was similar to last week, heifers were slightly better conditioned while there was some good cows offered from the local area.

Medium weight C2 and C3 steers averaged between 165.4c and 175.1c/kg. Heavy steers jumped 8c to average 181.9c after topping at 187.2c/kg. Bullock prices also improved to sell at mostly 185.2c/kg. Grown heifers sold at levels between 135.7c and 150.7c/kg. 

Cow quality was good and prices reflected this by showing large improvements. Light D3s averaged 146.3c after topping at 154.2c/kg. Medium weights ranged from 142.2c to 163.2c to average 152.9c/kg. A good selection of bulls including several pens of cleanskin descriptions sold mostly around 167c/kg.

All the regular buyers attended but not all operated as a select few processors competed to secure the limited available lines. Quality varied from very poor steers and cows to well finished descriptions, which were in small numbers. Demand was strong enough to push a dearer trend for all grades.

Light grown steers ranged from 140c to 177.2c while medium lines improved to average 188.2c/kg. The majority of heavy steers averaged over 200c/kg. Grown heifers were of plain quality but sold to dearer levels.

Plain, light cows comprised the majority of the cow yarding with the plainer lines holding firm at 119.9c/kg. Light D3s ranged from 139.2c to 167.2c while a select few very poor cows made 75c/kg. Medium weight cows ranged from 135.2c to 179.2c/kg. Bulls sold to processors at dearer rates.

After the large sale last week, numbers dropped by around half. Most of the cattle offered were plainer lines. Very little rain resulted from the wet season and this is forcing producers to offload. All the regular local and export buyers were present and active on a yarding that was dominated by light cows. 

Light steers sold to 121.2c with most selling closer to 104.4c/kg. The good medium and heavy steers met solid demand from processors to reach 165.2c/kg. A large number of light plain export heifers were penned and averaged just over 102c/kg. 

The cows sold to strong demand and this helped to lift values. A large number of light D2s averaged 105.8c as the better medium weight D3s made to 128.2c/kg.

After the increased yarding last week, numbers dropped dramatically. The quality of the yarding was mainly plain, although there were a few better types scattered throughout. The regular buyers were in operation with the better descriptions selling to good demand. Dominating the yarding were the females and in particular the cows. 

The light steers sold to 150.2c, as the medium weights reached 173.2c/kg. The top of the steers were the heavy types selling to 180.2c, while the small number of heavy bullocks sold for 175.2c/kg to return over $1,000/head.

The light heifers could not maintain the rates of the last sale with the D3s slipping 12c to average 137.5c/kg. The light cows also suffered losses, despite the D2s selling to 125.2c/kg. Receiving further gains was the large number of medium weights D3s after selling to 152.2c/kg.

The bulls sold to good competition and the heavy weights received the largest gains of the sale. The light bulls sold to 129.6c, as the heavy weights reached 170c/kg to return over $1,500/head.

After last weeks very small yarding a larger number was offered. There was some better quality steers penned considering the season along with a fair number of heifers and light cows.  All buyers were in attendance and processor competition was quite strong however the steers eased 1c to 2c/kg. The heifers were 4c cheaper while the light cows gained 4c to 9c and the medium weights lost 14c/kg. 

Light steers made to 130.2c and averaged 128.4c/kg. The medium weight steers sold to 148c and the C3s averaged 141.3c while those showing less finish averaged 132.2c/kg. Close to 140 heavy steers peaked at 148.2c and averaged 144.8c/kg.  

Heifers reached 120c and the D2s averaged 106.3c/kg. The light cows sold to 110.2c, which saw the better grades average from 99c to 107c/kg. The medium weight cows sold to 125.2c and the D3s averaged 115.7c/kg. A small number of bulls were penned and the heavy weights sold to 131.2c/kg.

After last weeks exceptionally large yarding, numbers returned to normal figures. All the usual meatworks buyers were present along with local butchers and wholesalers. Quality was similar to the previous sale with a wide range of descriptions offered. Competition at the beginning of each run began well but tended to taper off towards the end. 

Grown steers sold to a cheaper market with medium weight C and D muscles both easing up to 3c to average 146.8c for C2s and 124.5c/kg for D2s. Japan ox consisted of some well finished lines which averaged 144.7c while the plainer types were not too far behind selling at mostly 142.2c/kg. D muscled heifers ranged from 112c to 125c to average 115.5c/kg.

Medium weight cows comprised the majority of the cow yarding with large runs of D3s selling to a slightly cheaper market. They ranged from 114.2c to 131.2c to average 120.5c/kg. The best of the bulls sold for 113.2c/kg.

A yarding of just over 1,000 head were penned, which included up to 600 store cattle. The quality of slaughter cattle was quite plain and a number of processors and local butchers provided competition. The majority of cattle were offloaded by producers who are currently overstocked and are in areas where they have missed out of much of the rain. The immediate surrounding region is beginning to respond to with feedstocks improving.

Of the grown steers offered prices ranged from 161c to 170c/kg for the heavy weight lines.

Light D2 cows dominated the yarding and sold from 105c to 135c/kg. Of the reasonable number of heavyweights sold prices averaged 130.2c/kg.

A yarding of 3,409 cattle was penned in a combined prime and store sale this week, down 168 head on last sale. Quality was very mixed, featuring some very good lines of heavy cows, increased numbers of heavy bullocks and large lines of yearling steers along with lesser quality northern pastoral cows. The regular buyer panel were present and operating at similar rates along with a new live exporter and opportunity restockers. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Burketown, Croydon, Georgetown, Julia Ck, Hughenden, Belyando, local and coastal areas. Grown steers and heifers were mostly firm, heavy bullocks were firm to 15c higher, heavy cows were firm to 4c easier and heavy bulls averaged 5c/kg lower.

Light steer calves returning to the paddock sold to a top of 560c, with mixed sexes averaging 472c/kg. Light vealer steers to restockers reached 564c to average 560c and a good sample of steers above 280kg reached 462c to average 456c/kg. Mixed quality vealer heifers to the trade sold to 466c to average 447c, while heifers above 200kg returning to the paddock also reached 462c to average 458c/kg. Increased numbers of yearling steers sold to improved rates, with steers above 330kg to feed selling to 448c and averaging 441c, while those returning to grass reached 462c to average 420c/kg. Heavy steers above 400kg to backgrounders topped at 454c to average 453c/kg. Heavy yearling steers to feed sold to 442c to average between 433c and 440c/kg. Light yearling heifers above 280kg to feed sold to 402c, while heifers above 330kg to feed reached 394c to average 381c/kg. PTIC heifers sold in open auction for $1,800/head.

Grown steers met strong demand with those to feed reaching 446c to average from 392c to 401c/kg. Heavy steers to the trade reached 370c to average 368c/kg. Grown heifers to the trade sold to 362c to average 323c, while those to feed topped at 390c to average above 364c/kg. A large consignment of northern heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter reached 370c to average from 353c to 369c/kg. The reduced number of cows continued to meet strong processor demand. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors made to 316c to average between 301c and 314c and 3 score cows sold to a top of 322c multiple times to average from 306c to 315c/kg. Increased numbers of prime heavy weight cows topped at 326c to average 324c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export topped at 374c, while light males returning to the paddock sold to 565c to average 488c/kg. Some good lines of young cows with calves at foot made from $1,720 to $2,040/unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

A yarding of 3,148 cattle were penned in Charters Towers, 27 fewer than last sale. Increased numbers of heavy prime cows and bullocks were on offer, supported by large lines of store steers and heifers, with most cattle from local areas and north to Georgetown with some western lines. One southern processor joined the regular buying panel, operating at increased rates for heavy, good yielding lines, supported by regular feeder buyers and selective restocker and backgrounder activity, mostly due to the deteriorating season in many parts.  

Young steers saw quality related adjustments with better types improving slightly on last sale, while young heifers eased 4c to 8c/kg. Yearling steers also saw quality related adjustments, with feeder types easing 8c to 12c/kg, and restocker types firm on last sale. Light and medium weight yearling heifers eased 4c to 8c throughout, while heavier types to the trade improved 14c/kg. Improved lines of grown steers sold up to 15c higher on last week, however a large sample of grown heifers averaged 4c to 8c/kg lower. Selected lines of heavy bullocks increased by 8c to 10c, with plainer types 10c/kg easier on last week. Light weight steers to restockers sold to 318c, with a large sample averaging 288c to 295c, with young heifers returning to the paddock averaging 217c/kg. Yearling steers to feed reached 328c, with better types averaging 304c/kg. Yearling heifers to feed averaged 237c, with heavy heifers to the trade reaching 265c to average 230c to 255c/kg. Good quality heavy grown steers to processors sold from 307c to 318c/kg. A very good pen of heavy heifers sold for 290c to the trade, with most grown heifers selling from 232c to 254c/kg. 

Medium weight 2 score cows to processors eased more than 10c, while heavy weights increased by 5c with light cows to feed increasing from 10c to 20c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors improved 14c, while medium weights and bulls to feed destined for live export averaged 10c to 35c/kg lower. Increased numbers of heavy export bullocks sold to 319c to average 299c to 307c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows sold to 196c to average near 171c, with light weight types to feed averaging 152c to 167c/kg. A large sample of D muscled lower yielding heavy cows averaged 222c, with better quality heavy 3 score cows attracting increased demand selling to 249c to average 242c/kg. Prime heavy weight cows topped at 250c to average near 246c/kg. Select heavy bulls to processors sold to 320c, with most sales from 250c to 260c, while suitable types for live export to background feed averaged 240c to 305c/kg depending on weight. Some good lines of cows and calves sold to $800/unit.

A yarding of 2,844 cattle were presented in Charters Towers, a reduction of 304 head on last sale. The prime cattle offering comprised of mixed quality lines, however some very good heavy lines of bullocks and cows, attracted strong demand for heavy yielding types from processors. Store cattle displayed improved weight on recent weeks, with quality contributing to the improvement. All regular processors and feeder/backgrounder buyers were in attendance and operating relative to quality for the cattle drawn from Mt Isa, Normanton, Richmond, Greenvale, Mt Coolon, local and coastal areas. Light weight vealer steers to restockers lifted 20c, while heifers to processors eased by more than 20c/kg. Medium weight yearling steers to feed averaged 17c lower, while those below 280kg to feed improved in price by up to 30c/kg. Grown heifers to the trade sold firm to 12c/kg dearer depending on quality. Strong demand for good lines of heavy bullocks saw prices increase 3c to 5c/kg, while medium and heavy weight cows sold firm on last sale. Heavy bulls to processors eased 5c to 8c/kg.

Light weight vealer steers returning to the paddocks sold to 322c, averaging 318c for better quality lines, with suitable types to feed averaging 300c/kg.  Vealer heifers to processors reached 214c/kg. Medium weight yearling steers to feed made to 326c, with a good sample averaging 288c, while yearling steers above 280kg to feed reached 290c to average 263c/kg. Yearling heifers to the trade sold to 275.2c to average 266c, while suitable types to feed also averaged 266c, topping at 278c/kg. Grown heifers to the trade reached an occasional 278.2c, with a large sample averaging 215c/kg. 

Increased numbers of heavy bullocks sold to strong demand for heavy weights, reaching 322.2c, with most sales from 302c to 318c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows sold to 189.2c to average 169c to processors, while light conditioned cows to feed sold to 175.2c to average 158c/kg. Prime heavy weight cows to processors sold to an isolated 250.2c, with the 3 scores averaging 240c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors sold to 301c, while suitable types to live export to background feed averaged 286c/kg. Feeder weight males to background feed for live export topped at 255c to average 224c/kg. Mixed quality cows and calves sold to $800/unit.

A yarding of 2,736 cattle were penned in Charters Towers for the second consecutive prime only sale due to capping numbers following recent wet weather. With more than 3,000 store cattle booked for Friday's Store sale, large numbers of cattle from all regions continue to move, particularly with recent price increases. The yarding consisted of some large lines of northern cows, along with some excellent lines of prime yearling and grown heifers and  heavy weight cows, all selling to increased prices. The regular buying panel continued with several southern operators also in attendance, supported by two south Qld feeder orders. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Burketown, Croydon, Georgetown, Greenvale, Ayr, local and coastal areas.

A small number of yearling steers sold to the trade made to 322c, with a single steer to feed making to 338c/kg. Some well bred yearling heifers to feed sold to 329.2c, with a large sample selling from 324c to 327c/kg. Heavy weight yearling heifers above 400kg to the trade sold to 306.2c to average 293c/kg.

A small sample of grown steers to feed sold to 340.2c to average 332c/kg. Increased numbers of very good quality grown heifers lifted in price, with heavy weight heifers to the trade reaching 294.2c to average 284c, and similar lines to feed made to 329.2c, with a large sample making from 318c to 327c/kg. A small number of heavy weight export bullocks to processors sold to 342c, with many small lines making from 268c to 325c/kg. Increased numbers of medium weight 2 score cows improved in price by 3c, with strong demand throughout topping at 248.2c, to average 230c/kg. Heavy 3 score cows sold 5c to 6c higher, reaching 286.2c to average 271c, while lesser yielding 3 score cows averaged almost 260c/kg. Increased numbers of very good prime heavy weight cows topped at 285.2c to average 278c/kg. Heavy bulls to background feed destined for live export mostly sold from 310c to 340c, with heavy bulls to processors making to 350c, with most above 340c/kg.

A yarding of 2,585 cattle were penned in a combined Prime and Store sale. Quality was once again very good with some large lines of grown steers, along with some good small lines of yearling steers and heifers in fresh condition. The regular buyer panel was in attendance and operated at stronger rates to last sale including new saleyard records. Grown steers were 10c to 25c dearer, bullocks improved 5c, heavy cows to processors were 3c to 7c/kg dearer and bulls averaged firm on last sale. Cattle were drawn from Richmond, Hughenden, Pentland, Mt Garnet, Ingham, local and coastal areas. 

A large line of light vealer steers to restockers sold for 852c with other lines averaging 774c/kg. Light vealer heifers returning to grass reached 740c to average 661c/kg. Light yearling steers above 200kg to restockers sold to 702c steers to average 569c and steers above 200kg returning to grass reached 614c with most averaging 583c/kg. Steers above 330kg to backgrounders sold to 642c to average 570c and heavy steers above 400kg to feed averaged 545c/kg. Yearling heifers above 280kg to feed reached 606c, while similar heifers to backgrounders averaged 560c/kg. Good quality heifers above 330kg to feed topped at 570c to average from 492c to 552c/kg.

Grown steers were of very good quality with some large lines attracting strong demand, selling to a dearer trend. A large sample of steers above 400kg to feed sold to 552c to average from 513c to 541c and similar types to the trade selling to a top of 454c to average 453c/kg. A reduced supply of good quality heavy grown heifers to the trade sold to 400c, while a small sample of grown heifers to feed averaged 416c/kg. A limited supply of 3 score heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 450c average 439c/kg. Processor demand for cows continues to be very strong. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 380c to average 371c and 3 scores reached 404c to average from 386c to 400c/kg. A small sample of prime heavy weight cows topped at a record 416c multiple times to average 402c/kg. There was no processor activity on bulls with increased numbers to feed selling to 360c to average between 338c and 357c/kg. Young males returning to the paddock sold to 830c to average from 640c to 696c/kg. Good quality cows and calves sold from $1,750 to $2,950/unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

A yarding of 2,442 cattle were presented in Charters Towers, in a predominantly prime only sale. Nearly 4,000 store cattle are booked for Friday, following recent restrictions in numbers due to two live exporter bookings. Cattle were of very mixed quality with fewer numbers of heavy prime cows and bullocks, with a large increase in plainer conditioned cows and bulls. The regular buyer panel continued with southern processor and feeder orders in conjunction with four live exporters and opportunity western restockers. Demand for plainer conditioned cattle was very strong from feeder and restocker buyers and bulls destined for live export attracted significant buyer interest. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Normanton, Mareeba, Ingham, Home Hill, Belayando, local and coastal areas.

There were insufficient young cattle to quote due to a store sale on Friday, with the small sample selling in line with recent weeks according to quality. Yearling steers to feed sold to 356.2c, to average from 284c to 226c, while yearling heifers above 330kg to feed topped at 334.2c, to average 325c/kg. Yearling heifers to the trade generally sold from 284c to 340.2c/kg, to average 297c/kg. Increased numbers of grown steers to feed reached 348.2c, to average from 315c to 344c, while suitable types to live export sold to 330.2c, to average 325c/kg. Grown heifers to the trade sold to 300.2c, to average from 268c to 294c, with heifers destined to feed reaching 326.2c, to average 284c/kg.

Increased numbers of plain conditioned cows sold to strong demand, with plain conditioned cows improving by more than 20c and heavy cows easing by 5c to 10c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows to restockers averaged 233c, while cows to processors sold to 243.2c, to average 234c/kg. Three score cows reached 269.2c, averaging from 251c to 263c, while prime heavy weight cows sold to 270.2c with a large sample selling for 268.2c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export sold to 334.2c averaging from 301c to 332c, with bulls to processors selling to 270.2c, to average from 244c to 268c/kg.

A yarding of 2,381 predominantly prime cattle were penned in Charters Towers, with a further 3,500 store cattle booked for a store sale on Friday. More than half the yarding comprised of cows, mostly of good quality, while increased numbers of good heavy bullocks and bulls were also supplied. Grown steers to feed improved 20c, heavy bullocks eased 10c, medium and heavy weight cows improved 11 to 20c and heavy bulls to live export increased by 16c and heavy bulls to processors were firm to 10c higher. All regular processors operated at stronger rates than previous week, supported by two central feeder buyers and opportunity restockers and backgrounders. Cattle were drawn from north of Mt Isa, Normanton, Doomadgee, Richmond, Ingham, Greenvale, Ayr, local and coastal areas.  

A small number of vealer heifers to processors made to 398.2c to average 382c and steers to backgrounders sold to 426.2c/kg, averaging near 407c/kg. A small number of light yearling steers returning to grass sold for 384.2c and steers above 330kg to feed mostly sold from 366c to 372c/kg. Limited numbers of yearling heifers were insufficient to reliably quote and sold according to quality. Grown steers above 400kg to feed sold to 372.2c to average 358c to 365c and suitable steers to live export sold from 310c to 330c/kg. Heavy grown heifers to the trade sold to 338.2c to average from 312c to 334c, with plainer lines to backgrounders averaging near 289c/kg.

Some very good pens of heavy export bullocks topped at 375.2c to average from 358c to 368c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows sold to much improved demand and values lifted accordingly, topping at 290.2c, with a large sample averaging 261c and 3 scores sold to a record 329.2c to average from 292c to 319c/kg. Prime heavy weight cows reached 326.2c to average near 320c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export sold to 350.2c to average above 332.2c, while heavy bulls to processors sold to 346.2c to average above 320c/kg.

A yarding of 2,172 cattle were drawn by Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents. Featuring several northern lines of bullocks, cows and grown steers. Most categories improved on last sale, with export bullocks lifting 8c and heavy cows improving by more than 10c/kg, particularly better yielding pens. Two processors did not operate, however the remaining regular processors, two live exporters and regular feeder buyers operated, with selective support from cautious restockers and backgrounders. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Burketown, Cloncurry, Richmond, Georgetown, Greenvale, Ravenswood, local and coastal area.

Several small lines of vealer steers were on offer, with most meeting selective buyer interest. Better quality lines sold to 268c to average 259c, while lighter steers averaged 264c/kg. Yearling steers were very mixed quality with better bred types improving by up to 10c/kg. Live exporters were active on suitable feeder types up to 263c, while steers returning to grass sold to 268c for lighter types and from 234c to 239c/kg for plainer steers above 330kg. Steers to feed sold up to 260c/kg for some very good quality heavy feeders. Generally young heifers were in short supply, with vealer heifers comprising of many small lines with minimal buyer demand. The best quality heifers returning to grass sold to 198c to average 176c/kg. Light yearling heifers to feed reaching 208c and heavier feeder heifers made to 210c to average 209c/kg. 

Heavy export bullock supply decreased, however there were some very good quality local lines attracting strong demand, improving by up to 8c/kg on the previous week. Processors secured heavy 4 score export bullocks to 270c to average 267c, while 3 scores sold to 274c to average 269c/kg. Plainer D muscled heavy bullocks sold to 263c to average 231c, while plainer types to feed destined for live export sold to 220c to average 205c/kg. Suitable heavy grown steers to live export sold to 264c multiple times and plainer types to feed destined for live export sold to 245c to average 228c/kg. Heavy grown steers to feed sold to 237c and medium weight feeders to 245c/kg. Plainer grown steers returning to grass sold to 236c to average 228c/kg. A continuation of prime heavy cows improved by up to 8c for better yielding lines, with extra heavy cows improving by 16c/kg on last sale. Extra heavy 4 score cows sold to 218c and 3 score cows to 225c to average 221c/kg. Heavy 3 score cows to processors sold to 246c for a single animal, with a large sample averaging 215c/kg.  Plainer, heavy 2 score cows sold to 218c to average 203c/kg. Heavy D muscled cows sold to 215c to average 193c and plainer 2 score medium weight cows averaged 154c/kg. An increase in the number of grown heifers met an easier trend, with quality and yield determining market trends. Heavy 4 score heifers to slaughter topped at 258c and 3 score heifers sold to 245c, easing 12c to average 244c/kg. Better quality heavy heifers to feed sold to 212c and lighter feeder heifers sold to 207c to average 195c/kg. Plainer, lesser quality heifers returning to grass sold to 188c to average 184c/kg.

Fewer numbers of heavy bulls were on offer and generally plainer in condition. Bulls to slaughter sold to 239c to average 233c, with a single sale to 249c/kg. Similar bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 257c with most sales from 220c to 232c/kg. Medium weight bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 222c to average 202c, while suitable feeder bulls to live export made 240c/kg. Good quality light males to restockers topped at 250c to average 211c, with plainer types to 248c to average 205c/kg.  

A small number of cows and calves sold to $820/unit.

A yarding of 1221 cattle were penned in a prime only sale. More than 60% of the yarding comprised of cows with quality very mixed. There was an increased supply of single vendor lines of heavy prime cows along with a large consignment of northern pastoral cows and bulls. One additional export processor was operating with regular processors and feeders operating at stronger rates. Increased processor demand lifted averages for medium and heavyweight cows by 13c to 19c, grown steers increased by 7c and bulls to processors improved by up to 23c/kg. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Normanton, Collinsville, local and coastal areas. 

Yearling steers above 400kg to feed sold to 418.2c to average the same. Yearling heifers above 330kg to feed reached 404.2c to average 397c/kg. Good quality grown steers above 400kg to feed topped at 426.2c to average 406c to 418c and heavy steers to the trade reached 400.2c to average 383c/kg. A small supply of grown heifers to the trade sold to 386.2 to average 349c to 370c/kg.  

A small number of heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter sold from 380c to 392c/kg. Cows continued to meet strong processor demand for all categories. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 358.2c to average 331c to 344c and 3 score cows to processors sold to 366.2c to average 351c/kg. A larger sample of prime heavy weight 3 score cows made to 378.2c to average 358c/kg, while 4 scores topped at 382.2c to average 368c/kg.  Increased demand by processors for heavy bulls continued reaching 396.2c to average 373c/kg.

A store sale scheduled for Friday has 2,800 cattle booked.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

A yarding of 1,910 cattle, 137 head fewer than the previous sale for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents, which featured greater numbers of cattle showing the effects of the dry season across much of the state. One regular processor and feeder buyer were absent this week, with all others operating selectively and often at reduced rates in line with quality on offer, supported by one live exporter and several restockers. A very plain offering of bullocks were firm, while prime cows were 6c to 9c lower and store cattle up more than 20c/kg on last sale. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Burketown, Richmond, Torrens Creek, Bowen, Ayr, Woodstock, Belyando, local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers again sold strongly to a buoyant buyer gallery topping at 370c for an isolated pen, with most selling from 318c to 324c/kg. Yearling steers were in short supply and with the variable quality on offer sold firm on last sale. Increased numbers of vealer heifers lifted more than 20c on last sale, with those to slaughter selling to 246c, while heifers returning to grass sold to 274c, averaging 258c an increase of 44c on last sale, while plainer types to feed sold to 254c/kg. Yearling heifers consisted of a few small lines, with the variable quality firm on last week.  Grown heifers of variable quality and weight to feed sold to 230c, averaging 224c, while similar types to grass sold to 234c, averaging 215c/kg.

Bullocks were generally plain in condition with only average quality, limiting processor interest and buyer demand. The few heavy prime bullocks to slaughter made to 253c, while one live exporter secured most of the offering for 241c to 248c and up to 253c/kg. Some very good grown steers to slaughter sold to 256c, with suitable types to live export selling to 250c, while lighter types to feed selling to 247c/kg.

The offering of cows was very mixed with some isolated pens of good heavy cows, with several lines of plainer conditioned cows meeting subdued demand.  Heavy C muscled 3 score cows to slaughter sold to 207c, with an isolated 4 score cow selling for 213c, while D muscled cows sold to 201c, averaging 11c lower at 185c/kg. Heavy 2 score cows to slaughter averaged 9c lower at 177c, while large framed 2 score cows returning to grass increased 6c topping at 175c to average 167c, with lighter types averaging 163c/kg. An improved selection of heavy bulls sold strongly, with one live exporter securing most on offer from 240c to 256c/kg. Medium weight bulls to live export sold to 282c, generally selling from 256c to 266c, while bulls to feed, destined for live export made to 266c, averaging 225c/kg. Young males to feed sold to 320c/kg. A small number of cows and calves sold to $950/unit.

A yarding of 1,487 cattle, 9 head lower than last sale for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, with a much smaller offering of prime cattle, but some good lines of northern store steers and young males. One processor continued their absence for the year, however all others were operating selectively throughout the sale, accompanied by two live exporters, one regular feeder buyer and local restockers. Cattle were drawn from Julia Creek, Normanton, Einasleigh, Georgetown, Greenvale, Ingham, Ayr, Belyando, local and coastal areas. 

A small number of vealer steers sold similar to last sale, selling to 354c to average 343c/kg. Yearling steers eased on last sale, mainly due to offering of smaller lines and variable quality. Steers to live export sold to 290c, while steers returning to grass sold to 358c for lighter weights, while steers above 280kg, sold to 320c to average 315c/kg. Heavier yearling steers above 400kg sold to 318c, with most sales between 268c and 275c, while similar steers to feed sold to 275c/kg for same average. Some very good lines of light vealer heifers eased more than 10c on last sale, topping at 262c multiple times to average 261c/kg for light and medium weight types. Yearling heifers of mixed quality and weight sold similar to last sale, with most returning to grass averaging 260c/kg. A small number of heavy grown heifers returning to grass sold to 245c/kg.

Bullock numbers were much lower than last sale, however demand was strong with one live exporter securing heavy bullocks to 255c multiple times, while bullocks to slaughter also sold to 255c, with lighter lines averaging 250c/kg. Grown steers to restockers sold to 266c to average 262c/kg.  Steers to feed sold to 264c/kg multiple times. A reduced number of cows met firm demand, with heavy C muscle 3 score cows lifting 6c, topping at 213c to average 205c, while D muscle cows sold to 197c to average 189c/kg. Some good pens of 2 score cows sold to 200c to average 199c, while lighter 2 score cows sold to 182c to average 167c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export sold to 239c with most above 235c, while heavy bulls to slaughter sold to 230c/kg. Some good lines of light northern males sold to 326c to average 318c, while males of feeder weight to live export sold to 322c to average 307c/kg. A small number of cows and calves sold to $900/unit.

A yarding of 1,325 cattle were drawn by Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, a fall of 125 head on last sale with some very good lines of yearling steers and heifers on offer. One regular processor continued their absence, while all those in attendance operated selectively and at much lower values than recent weeks - particularly prime cows - selling 11c to 18c/kg lower. Live exporters were prominent on suitable type and weight steers, bullocks and bulls. Regular feeder buyers were also absent, however restockers displayed strong competition on all classes of steers and better quality yearling heifers. Cattle were drawn from Georgetown, Einasleigh, Innisfail, Ingham, Aramac, Pentland, Woodstock, Mt Coolon, local and coastal areas.

A similar number of very good quality vealer steers sold generally stronger on last sale returning to paddocks to 352c, averaging 335c for better C muscled types, while D muscled steers averaged 327c/kg for similar weights. Yearling steers were represented by many small mixed lines that sold to 305c to restockers, with live exporters securing a small number to 290c/kg. Heavy yearling steers returning to grass sold to 292c to a lower average of 276c/kg. Vealer heifers were of mixed quality and in small lines which generally sold higher for better type. Young heifers returning to grass averaged 260c, topping at 270c, while a small number to feed sold to 264c/kg. Yearling heifers sold to 266c, averaging 261c/kg, with the higher average heavily influenced by quality. 

A larger offering of grown heifers to slaughter sold to 238c, averaging 209c, with many lighter and mixed quality lines selling from 190c to 210c/kg. Bullocks and heavy steers were of mixed quality and weight with virtually nil to slaughter. Live exporters secured heavy bullocks to 247c several times, with restockers accumulating steers and lighter bullocks to 250c/kg. Some good lines of prime cows met subdued processor interest, with heavy C muscled 3 score cows to slaughter selling to 195c, averaging 18c lower to 186c/kg. Heavy D muscled sold to 188c, averaging 11c lower to make 181c, while 2 score cows averaged 9c lower at 163c/kg. Restockers secured lighter cows for a 145c average, with some heavier cows above 400kg returning to grass selling to 182c/kg. Good quality heavy bulls generally sold to live export, selling to 248c, to average 246c/kg. A small number of bulls to slaughter sold to 228c/kg. Medium weight bulls to feed sold to 249c/kg, also destined for live export. Young males met very strong restocker demand selling to 316c, with most sales from 270c to 310c/kg. A small number of cows and calves sold to $1,200/unit.

A yarding of 1,043 cattle were drawn by Charters Towers Combined Agents, with many plainer cattle dominating the yarding and showing the effects of the prolonged dry season.  Cattle were sourced from Doomadgee, Einasleigh, Woodstock, Ingham, Ayr, local and coastal areas. The regular processors operated throughout the prime section, supported by a limited number of feeder buyers, destined for live export.  Store buyers were in limited numbers, however competition was very strong, and selling to dearer prices, with one very good quality line of heifers attracting solid bidding, which was maintained throughout the offering.
 
Vealer heifers topped at 270.2c with many pens selling from 254c to 260c/kg. Limited numbers of vealer steers also attracted strong buyer support and again topped at 270.2c/kg. Yearling heifers sold strongly throughout, topping at 270.2c/kg. Yearling steers attracted strong competition from feeder buyers destined for live export and sold to 262.2c/kg. 

Bullocks were penned in limited numbers and sold to 281.2c, mostly selling from 225c to 250c/kg. Very few 3 score cows were offered, selling to 241.2c, whilst 2 score cows sold to 224.2c/kg. A large run of mixed quality bulls sold to strong processor competition, selling to 235.2c/kg.  

Cows and calves were in limited numbers and mixed quality selling to a top of $900/unit.

A very plain quality yarding was offered. All the regular buyers were present however they all were not active. Prices followed the cheaper trend  of other centres last week with reduced competition a factor behind this.

The top of the heavy steers sold to 120c as the medium weights averaged just under 110c/kg. In limited numbers the better light export heifers sold to 108c as plainer lines averaged 67.1c/kg.            

The cows were in the largest number with the light weights in very plain condition. Both the medium and heavy D3 cows met fair demand to sell to 105c  and 110c/kg respectively.

A very good quality yarding of 1,552 cattle were yarded by Charters Towers Combined Agents this week, with some very good lines of prime bullocks and cows along with some store steers. Cattle were drawn from Croydon, Richmond, Belyando, Ingham, Woodstock local and coastal areas. The regular processors were all present and active throughout the sale, accompanied by a central feeder buyer and some western restockers. Live export was dominant on suitable slaughter weight bullocks and bulls, while processors competed for suitable heifers and cows.

Vealer steers were reduced in numbers and values eased markedly on last week, selling to 286.2c/kg. Yearling steers were well supplied and met strong competition from restockers and a central feeder buyer, selling to 288.2c, to average 275.2c/kg.  Vealer heifers were limited in supply and sold strongly to 250c/kg. Yearling heifers met limited competition and sold to 256.2c, with a line of PTIC heifers selling to 249.2c/kg to restockers.

A much improved quality and supply of bullocks met strong buyer competition from processors and a live exporter, selling to 264.2c, while heavy steers sold to 266.2c/kg. A very good supply of prime 2 and 3 score cows were penned attracting solid buyer interest throughout the offering. 3 score cows sold to 225.2c for a pen of heavy cows, with many lines selling from 195c to 208.2c/kg. Heavy heifers sold to limited demand for 213.2c, while a pen of spayed heifers sold to 235.2c/kg.  Bulls suitable for live export sold to 224.2c, with heavy bulls to slaughter selling from 180c to 216.2c/kg. A limited number of average quality cows and calves sold to $760/unit.

A total yarding of 1,443 cattle at Charters Towers this week selling to a strong market, with values varying a few cents up and down on last sale.  

Steers and bullocks were in large numbers, best of the medium steers to 129.2c for a good sample of D3 s and these averaged 123c/kg.  Heavier export steers reached 133.2c to remain firm while best of the other bullocks reached 134.2c/kg.  A big number of export type heifers sold up to 112.2c while cows, topped at 106.4c/kg for a large sample of D3 s and averaged 103.4c/kg.  Bulls made to a top of 119.2c/kg for a small number.

A total of 797 cattle were offered at Charters Towers Prime sale on Thursday, a rise of 261 head on last weeks yarding.  The offering comprised principally export cattle, and overall, values were dearer for the bulk of the cattle.

A few D3 steers in the lighter weight range sold from 90c to 128.2c to average 110.6c/kg.  In the 400kg to 500kg range, a good sample of D3 steers sold from 100c to 130.6c to average 119.2c/kg, and were 4c cheaper than last week.  Heavier steers weighing 500kg to 600kg were unchanged on last week, and sold from 119.2c to 130c to average 124.8c/kg.  Other D4 bullocks reached 131.4c/kg for a single pen.

The best of the D3 heifers sold up to 119.2c/kg.  Heavy D3 cows made to 115.2c and averaged 113.3c/kg for a large sample.  Heavy bulls sold to 122.2c/kg,

The Queensland Cattle Market Index stands at 138.4 points.

A total of 668 prime cattle were traded at auction in Charters Towers on Thursday.  The better export cattle sold in vendors favour and in places sold at rates dearer than last week.  

Light steers, D2 made to 114.2c to average 106c/kg.  A good sample in the medium weight steers topped at 114.6c and they averaged 110.6c/kg.  Best of the bullocks, D2, made to 125.2c/kg.  

A large sample in the heifers sold up to 106.6c/kg.  Female cattle dominated the yarding, the best of the heavier cows making to 115.2c to average 110c and these were up to 9c/kg dearer in places.  

Bulls sold at rates which were consistent with other Southern Queensland centres, the best recorded to 114.2c/kg.

A total of 439 prime cattle were sold at Charters Towers saleyards on Thursday, which was down by 358 head on the sale held last week.  The yarding included a good mix of cattle suited to exporters, and overall, values were cheaper.

The D3 Light steers sold to 127.2c to average 126.7c/kg, and went against the trend to be dearer.  A fair sample of D3 steers weighing 400 to 500kg sold up to 125.2c to average 119.5c/kg, and were unchanged on last Thursday.  The best of the other heavy bullocks reached 127.2c/kg.

A large number of D3 heifers sold to 116.2c/kg and heavy cows, D3 sold up to 106.2c for an average of 100.5c/kg.  A few heavy bulls D1 sold to 106.2c/kg.

A total of 308 prime cattle was traded at Charters Towers on Thursday where values varied just a few cents either way of last week for most descriptions.  

Light steers D1, sold to 107.6c to average 93c/kg.  Medium steers, D2 improved by 4c to sell to 116.6c, while the best D3s in the bullocks peaked at 121.6c and averaged 119.9c/kg.  Light weight heifers, D2 made 113.2c/kg.  Manufacturing steers to 114.6c to average 111.4c/kg.  

Cows, in bigger numbers sold to a top of 113.6c for a large sample of D2 heavy cows and these averaged 109c, this market remaining fairly firm on last Thursday.  Heavy bulls sold up to 116.6c/kg for a small sample.

A total of 305 prime cattle were yarded at Charters Towers on Thursday, which was down by 134 head on last week.  Overall, values were dearer, the exception were a few of the plainer cows that showed an easing trend.

The light steers that were offered sold to an isolated 120.2c/kg, while D3 steers in the 400 to 500kg weight range made to 128.2c to average 121.3c/kg.  The best of the bullocks peaked at 130.2c to average 127.3c/kg, and were 7c/kg dearer than last Thursday.

The light D3 heifers sold up to 126.2c to average 114c/kg while best of the heavy cows sold to 114.2c/kg for a small number.  The few bulls yarded made to 109.2c and averaged 104.5c/kg.

A total of 268 cattle was sold at Charters Towers this week, where values varied by a few cents either way of last week.  Light steers sold to 129.2c, medium steers to 132.6c/kg. A good sample of D2 bullocks to 138.2c to average 136.7c/kg.  Light heifers to 120.2c and heavy cows made to 121.6c/kg. The bulls available sold to an isolated 106.2c/kg.

A substantially smaller yarding of export cattle was at the Charters Towers sale on Thursday. Values remained firm for the majority, although some of the female grades recorded losses. 

A pen of C3 medium weight steers sold to 158.2c/kg.  A single heavy B3 sold to 160.2c/kg as a steer weighing over 600kg sold to 163.2c to return $1,045/head. Only light heifers were offered and the top of these was the D3s reaching 146.2c to average 141.5c, up 7c/kg on last week. 

The light D2 cows topped at 138.2c, as did the medium weight D2s in the largest numbers. But once again it was the heavier grades that topped the cow section, as a D3 reached 144.2c/kg.

Heavy bulls were in the largest numbers to top at 135.2c/kg.

A substantially larger yarding was offered to a full field of buyers. Values, while improved on the last sale, were not up to state averages. Cattle were drawn mainly from the local areas, although drafts were penned from coastal regions and Hughenden. Even though rain has been received in many surrounding areas, pasture growth has been rather limited and this was a factor in such a large number of store cattle being offered.

Most of the steers yarded were D2 lightweights averaging just under 127c/kg. Medium weights suited to the Korean market sold to good demand to sell to 176.2c as the heavy steers receiving solid strong competition topped at 178.2c/kg. 

Only a handful of light export heifers were offered selling to a slightly dearer market with the D3s making to 145.2c/kg. A large number of cows were included in the line up with the majority lightweights averaging 122c/kg. The better medium weight D3s, had benefited from being from areas that had received early rains and subsequent pasture growth, selling to 142.2c to average 135.5c/kg.

A substantially larger yarding at Churchill was met with a relatively firm market with only the medium weight cows suffering a loss. In a yarding dominated by export types, steers were in the largest numbers. With numbers for some types low, it is difficult to get an accurate quote on sections of the yarding. 

Large numbers of medium weight D3 steers sold to 149.2c to average 142.8c as bullocks weighing between 500 and 600kg reached 145.2c to also average 142.8c/kg. 

Light D3 heifers sold to 140.2c with the only other heifers in any numbers being the light D4s, which reached 134.2c/kg. The light D2 cows remained unchanged to average 98.8c, but the medium weight D3s suffered a 2c loss to average 107.8c/kg.

The largest number of bulls was the medium weight D1s that sold to 115.4c/kg.

A smaller yarding was offered with quality quite mixed across all categories. all the major export buyers attended the sale but not all operated to full capacity, with the shorter kill week next week attributing to the weaker demand. Prices generally eased in the face of the broken demand with grown cattle categories falling between 4c and 10c/kg. The season has tapered off sharply in the surrounding region and many don t expect further rain till late winter. 

Grown steers lost considerable value with limited demand evident for all weight ranges. Quality was similar to the previous sale and prices for medium weights averaged 151.5c, while heavier steers ranged from 147.2c to 155.2c, with both categories loosing between 5c and 8c/kg. A small number of bullocks averaged 160.2c and the C muscled grown heifers sold to varied competition averaging 130c/kg.

The quality of the cow yarding was well below last weeks market and prices eased accordingly. Light conditioned cows that were receiving between 100c and 110c last week, all sold for under a 100c, with little interest shown. Medium weights ranged from 123.2c to 136.2c falling 4c while lighter conditioned 2 scores lost 6c to average 117.5c/kg

A smaller yarding was offered with quality generally quite plain. Most cattle showed the effect of the season and prices reflected this. A full panel of buyers were in attendance but one major processor appeared to be stronger than the other works. 

Grown steers and bullocks were of slightly mixed quality with overall large consignments of bullocks the most keenly sought. Medium weight steers ranged from 164.2c to 167.2c/kg and most of the heavy steers sold in the 170s. The large consignment of bullocks sold from 176.2c to 181.2c/kg averaging $1,157/head.

Cows were dominated by medium weights with most in pretty plain quality. Medium weights eased slightly selling from 130.2c to 149.2c and a small number of good heavyweights held around 152c/kg.

A smaller yarding today at Charters Towers and as usual was made up predominantly of export types. The overall market slipped slightly for most grades, however some descriptions lost value significantly, despite the lesser numbers.

The reduced quality had an effect on the steers with most types losing up to 10c/kg.  The only grade to witness a rise was the small number of light D3s, which averaged 133.9c/kg. In the largest number, D3 bullocks slipped 9c to average 142.1c and topping the sale was the heavy bullocks reaching 148.6c/kg. 

Going against the sale trend, were the light D3 heifers in large numbers, which improved 10c after selling to a top of 145.2c/kg.  A small number of light cows topped at 100.2c, to average 91.8c/kg. Medium weight cows were in the largest numbers but also sold on a cheaper trend, with a large number of D3 types losing 3c to average 115.9c after reaching a top of 125.2c/kg. 

The top of the bulls was a D mucle heavy weight selling to 138.2c/kg.

A smaller yarding of 805 cattle were penned following the Easter weekend and a scheduled store sale for Friday with 2400 head booked. Quality was quite good with some well finished local lines of prime cows with reduced numbers of grown steers, bullocks and bulls. A smaller gallery consisted of the regular processors operating selectively supported by one southern feeder operator. Steers to feed improved 15c/kg, bullocks lifted 4/kg heavy cows averaged 6c to 15c/kg higher and bulls sold firm. Cattle were drawn from Richmond, Pentland, Greenvale, local and coastal areas.

A small sample of grown steers above 400kg to feed sold to 392.2c to average 356c to 376c/kg and suitable steers to the trade reached 390.2c to average above 390c/kg. Fewer numbers of grown heifers to feed sold to 358.2c to average 332c to 349c/kg. Several small lines of heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 394.2c to average 384c to 393c/kg. 

Solid buyer support for cows saw increased competition for the quality penned. Medium weight 2 score cows made to 282.2c to average same, 3 score cows to processors reached 314.2c to average 299c to 310c and prime heavyweights topped at 318.2c to average 310c/kg. Cows to feed reached 290.2c to average 270c to 286c/kg. A small sample of heavy bulls to feed destined for live export topped at 340.2c to average 317c to 336c/kg. 

Market Reporter; Mick Kingham.

A smaller yarding of 2,009 cattle were penned in Charters Towers, 966 fewer than last week. The prime cattle were of mixed quality throughout, with several lines lacking weight and quality of last sale. The regular buying panel operated at lower rates than last sale, with all heavy prime cattle selling to lower rates in line with recent grid adjustments, however medium weight cows averages increased.  Fewer store cattle met strong restocker demand for good quality lines, with most prices easing on previous week. Cattle were drawn from Chillagoe, Richmond, Pentland, Greenvale, local and coastal areas along with one mixed consignment from Katherine in Northern Territory.

Light vealer steers met strong demand from restockers easing by 6c on last week's rates and vealer heifers to restockers averaged 9c lower, with suitable types to processors lifting by 9c/kg. Limited numbers of yearling steers to feed eased by 15c to 20c and yearling heifers eased by more than 30c/kg in line with quality. Fewer numbers of grown heifers to the trade eased by 8c/kg. Heavy bullocks to export processor averaged 22c/kg lower. Medium weight cows went against the trend increasing by 8c, however heavy prime cows sold 14c to 18c lower and heavy bulls averaged more than 30c/kg lower throughout.

Vealer steers returning to grass sold to 325c to average more than 312c and vealer heifers to restockers averaged from 205c to 214c/kg. Yearling steers to feed sold to 289c to average more than 240c, while steers above 330kg to feed averaged 273c/kg. Limited numbers of mixed quality light yearling heifers to feed averaged 199c/kg. A small supply of grown heifers to the trade sold to 253c to average 223c/kg.

Increased numbers of heavy bullocks presented in many small consignments with those to export processor selling to 288c, with medium weights selling to 293c to average 263c/kg. Medium weight cows to processors reached 198.2c to average near 180c, while heavy prime cows topped at 238.2c to average 211c/kg. Heavy bulls to feed back grounded for live export sold to 295.2 to average 242c, while heavy bulls to processor reached 270c to average 233c to 250c/kg. Mixed quality cows and calves sold to $720/unit.

A smaller yarding of 1339 cattle were penned, 966 fewer than last sale. Quality was very mixed, with a reduced number of well finished cows and bullocks and several smaller mixed lines of store steers and heifers.  Some regular processors were absent from the buyer panel, with those in attendance operating at reduced rates with the support of most regular feeders and opportunity restockers. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Burketown and east to local and coastal areas. 

Values for most categories came under further pressure with bullock easing 13c, cows slipped 20c and bulls with no live export presence fell by up to 50c/kg.

Light steers to restockers sold to 226c, similar heifers returning to the paddock reached 160c/kg. A reduced supply of yearling steers below 280 kg to restockers made to 204c, averaging 199c/kg. Yearling heifers above 280kg to feed reached 155c to average 134c/kg.

A reduced number of grown steers to feed reached 175c to average 170c, a few heavy grown steers to processors made 158c/kg. A limited number of grown heifers to processors sold to 144c to average 133c/kg.

A good sample of heavy full mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 162c averaging from 152c to 156c/kg.
Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 143c to average 124c, 3 scores sold to 152c to average 138c/kg.  A small sample of prime heavyweight cows reached 154c/kg.

Heavy bulls to processors topped at 160c to average 146c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

A smaller yarding of 1,127 mixed quality cattle were yarded by Charters Towers Combined Agents. There was limited buyer competition for the prime cattle, with one meatworks operator present, but not active on the day, whilst store buyers keenly bid on selected lines. Cattle were drawn from the Northern Gulf, Richmond, Greenvale, Belyando, Woodstock, Ingham, local and coastal areas. 

Yearling steers were in limited supply and better quality types sold to keen competition, topping at 263.2c/kg, with one western restocker active across the store section of the sale. Yearling heifers were sold to a spirited buying panel to top at 252.2c/kg. 

A plainer yarding of cows sold to reduced rates topping at 199.2c/kg, with many returning to restockers and feeders. A limited number of finished bullocks sold to lower rates in line with other selling centres this week, topping at 249.2c, with plainer types selling around 210c/kg to buyers feeding for live export. A large number of plain PTIC heifers greater than six months sold to $680, with many selling from $490 to $580/head.  Similar aged females with calves at foot sold to $605, whilst older cows and calves sold to $760/unit.

A smaller yarding at Charters towers today made up mostly of steers and cows. Lightweight steers experienced some good price rises with a large number of D3 steers lifting 25c, to average 143.2c/kg. Steers suited to the Korean market were firm to dearer, topping at 150.2c/kg. Jap ox sold at dearer rates than last sale, topping at 151.2c/kg. A small yarding of heavy steers rose 13c, to reach 153.2c/kg.

Heifers sold from firm to slightly easier, with D3 heifers losing 8c on last sale. Light cows followed an irregular trend, while the medium and heavy weights were slightly dearer. A large number of D3 cows rose 5c, to average 113.6c/kg.

Bulls sold from firm to slightly easier rates.

A small yarding was offered with cattle being drawn mainly from the local area. All the regular processors, wholesalers and local butchers were present and active. Quality was similar to last week with the majority of the yarding D2 and D3s. The pastures in the local area are starting to feel the effects of the cooling weather.

Light steers made to 126.2c as medium weights held firm to average 134.2c/kg. The good heavy steers reached 158.2c as a small number of heavy bullocks averaged 146.2c/kg. 

A large number of light export heifers and cows were offered. Leaner heifers averaged just under 108c with others making to 123.2c/kg. Light cows made to 110c with most of the medium weights selling from 93.5c to 107.7c/kg. The top of the cows sold to 113.2c/kg.

A small yarding of 536 prime cattle were offered at the Charters Towers saleyards this week, which was down by 69 head on last weeks offering.

In the steers, medium weight D3s sold up to 126.2c/kg for a fair number and these averaged 123c/kg.  The D3 steers weighing to 600kg made 128.2c/kg and averaged 125c, while a few other heavier bullocks topped at 126.2c/kg.  A big line of lighter weight heifers sold to 117.2c to average 112.4c/kg.  

The cows dominated the yarding, the better heavy cows peaking at 116.2c/kg to average 114.9c with a big number selling to 115.c/kg.  Bulls sold to 108.2c/kg.

A small yarding of 437 prime cattle were offered at Charters Towers on Thursday.  The bulk of the offering were export cattle which sold at rates which were cheaper when compared with last week.  

The best of the D4 medium weight steers sold to 122.6c to average 119.3c/kg, while a good sample of D4 bullocks weighing 500 to 600kg made to 126.2c for an average of 125c/kg.  Bullocks in the heavier weight range sold to an isolated 131.2c/kg.

A small sample of D3 heifers sold up to 120.2c/kg while the better heavy cows reached 115.2c and averaged 113.4c/kg.  Bulls sold to 127.2c/kg.

A small increase in numbers to 1,656 cattle for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, with some good lines of feeder steers and northern prime cows in an improved yarding on last sale. One regular processor was again absent this week, with all other processors in attendance and operating along with regular feeder buyers and restockers. Cattle were drawn from Burketown, Chillagoe, Georgetown, Ingham, Richmond, Ayr, Woodstock, Belyando, local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers attracted strong restocker interest, with prices increasing 3c to 5c to a top of 404c for a small line with most selling above 350c to average 360c/kg. Yearling steers were in short supply with some good quality local lines returning to grass selling to 308c/kg. Steers to feed sold to 294c/kg. Vealer heifers were again small in number selling to increased values on last sale topping at 334c to average 314c/kg. Yearling heifers of variable quality sold to similar rates to last sale topping at 270c for those returning to grass, averaging 262c, while heifers to feed also sold to 270c to average 266c/kg.

Some good quality bullocks sold similar to last sale, with heavy 3 score bullocks topping at 280c to slaughter, while lighter types returning to grass sold to 271c/kg. Heavy feeder steers to backgrounders sold to 312c, while grown steers to feed, destined for live export sold to 298c/kg. Grown steers returning to paddock sold to 291c, averaging 288c/kg. Some good lines of prime cows, including some northern lines sold averaged 3c to 5c up on last sale, with heavy C muscled 3 score cows topping at 237c to average 223c/kg. Heavy 3 score D muscled cows sold to 231c, to average 214c, with heavy 2 score cows averaging 201c/kg. Lighter, younger cows to restockers sold stronger to 204c to average 183c/kg, with improved quality on offer. A small number of heavy bulls sold lower due to the absence of live export activity, with those to slaughter topping at 251c, while medium and heavier weight bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 268c/kg. A good line of cows and calves sold to $1,450/unit.

A small increase in numbers resulted in 1,477 cattle in a Combined Prime and Store Sale. Quality was very mixed with some good quality northern single vendor lines of cows and bullocks along with some poor quality cows and bulls. Two good quality lines of store steers were on offer supported by smaller lines of steers and heifers. One major export processor was again in attendance but not operating, with other regular processors operating with renewed enthusiasm on better quality lines. Additional feeder orders were operating supported by enthusiastic southern and western restocker participation. Cattle were drawn from mostly northern areas including Burketown, Normanton and Mareeba, then to Richmond, Hughenden, Mt Coolon local and coastal areas.
