Most categories improved in price, with grown steers and heifers increasing 20c to 60c, bullocks lifted 23c to 47c, cows to processors increased 10c to 20c and bulls averaged 11c to 37c/kg better. Increased buyer demand pushed values for steer calves to 622.2c, while vealer steers returning to the paddock sold to 556.2c to average 510c/kg. Similar vealer heifers returning to grass made to 428.2c and trade types sold to 380c/kg.

A small sample of yearling steers above 280kg returning to grass reached 380.2c to average 346c to 380c/kg. Limited numbers of yearling heifers to the trade sold to 370.2c to average 368c/kg. Good quality grown steers above 400kg to feed sold to 350.2c to average 311c to 336c/kg. A good sample of heavy grown heifers to feed made to 348.2c to average 331c/kg. Suitable heifers to the trade averaged 300c to 310c selling to 332c/kg for the best types.

An increased supply of heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter made to 336.2c to average from 315c to 334c/kg. A large decrease in the supply of cows met renewed processor demand. Medium weight three score cows to processors topped at 290.2c to average 275c to 288c/kg. Prime heavy weight 3 and 4 score cows reached 310.2c to average 282c to 301c/kg. A good line of cows to southern restockers sold to 342.2c to average 331c/kg. Increased demand for heavy bulls to feed improved averages from 295c to 322c/kg reaching a top of 338.2c, while young males returning to grass sold to 562.2c to average 408 to 412c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

A small decrease in supply by 155 head resulted in 2105 cattle penned this week. Quality was very mixed, representing the lengthening dry season and smaller mixed lines being presented for sale. All regular processors operated on the fewer numbers of prime cattle offered along with one live exporter, regular feeders and opportunity restockers. Cattle were drawn from across the north down to the local area.

Processor demand was good for the reduced supply of well finished types, most  categories were firm to 5c dearer, particularly for the better quality types and those displaying weight, however plainer steers and cows eased 12c to 15c/kg. Restocker demand continued to improve for good quality, well bred younger cattle.

A good sample of young lightweight suitably weaned steers returning to the paddock averaged 271c to 306c, reaching a top of 358c/kg. Similar heifers also returning to grass made to 254c to average 240c, well covered heifers to processors averaged 241c/kg.  Very good quality young steers above 200kg to backgrounders reached 358c to average 317c, lesser types averaged 269c/kg. Light yearling steers above 200kg returning to the paddock made to 328c for a small sample of well bred types, the majority selling from 218c to 298c to average 236c/kg. Steers above 330kg to feed averaged 229c to 305, selling to 328c, steers to live export made 290c/kg. Yearling heifers above 280kg to feed sold to 262c to average 257c/kg.

Grown steers above 400kg suitable for live export sold to 284c, steers to the trade reached 302c to average 296c/kg. Heavy grown steers to processors sold to an isolated 326c most from 310c to 318c/kg.  Heavy well finished grown heifers to processors sold to 312c, a good sample averaging 269c/kg. A small number of heavy full mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 310c multiple times to average 308c/kg. Medium weight 3 score cows to processors sold to 272c to average 256c, a limited number of prime heavyweight 3 and 4 score cows made from 268c to 290c/kg. Heavy bulls suitable for live export made from 250 to 294c, most around 280c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

A slightly smaller yarding of similar quality saw values ease although not to the extent of some centres. Not all the regular buyers were in attendance and those that were only operated on specific categories. 

Light steers lost 18c and averaged 109.7c/kg Medium weights were in the largest numbers and sold 16c to 20c/kg cheaper. The large number of D3s offered averaged 141c after they sold to a top of 152.2c/kg. Heavy steers reached 154.2c to average 18c lower at 150.2c/kg. 

Grown heifers felt the brunt of the cheaper rates and a large number averaged 114.7c/kg. Light cows were 6c to 11c cheaper and large number of D2s averaged 98.3c and the better quality descriptions averaged 119.6c/kg. There was over 200 medium weight D3s that averaged 8c cheaper at 120.7c/kg. 

The bull market lost 7c to 19c and average prices ranged from 102.2c to 113.6c/kg.

A slightly smaller yarding of improved quality cattle was offered to a larger panel of buyers. Normally there are only two processors in operation, but this week there was four, the extra competition pushed steers up by at least 5c and the cows gained over 10c/kg in places.  

Medium weight steers sold to 187.2c, as the heavy steers averaged 184.1c after selling to 193.6c/kg. The top of the heavy bullocks reached 194.6c/kg and returned over $1,200/head. 

Females represented over half the yarding with demand reported as strong. The heifers were not able to sustain last weeks high values, however the light D3s reached 172.2c/kg. Most of the cows offered were light weights and the increased number had a negative effect on values, albeit only slightly. The D2s averaged 130.4c, while the D3s topped at 138.2c/kg. The medium weights received further gains with the better types selling to 175.2c/kg. 

Both the light and medium weight bulls received further gains, while the medium weights suffered a 7c/kg fall.

A slightly smaller yarding of 1,297 cattle were drawn by Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week. The yarding attracted several small lines of prime cows and northern mixed lines, supported by some very good lines of vealer steers and heifers. One processor continued their absence, with all others operating, supported by two live exporters, regular feeder buyers and some opportunity restockers. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Croydon, Belyando, Ingham, local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers sold to mixed demand from a subdued buying panel. Light steer calves sold to 282c and light vealers topped at 272c, to average 258c, while heavier types returned to grass sold to 246c/kg. Small lines of yearling steers were very mixed, with those above 280kg selling to 228c, an increase of 12c, and medium weight feeder steers above 330kg lifted 15c, to average 230c/kg. Similar weight steers meeting live export specifications sold to 246c/kg. A mixed quality offering of vealer heifers sold stronger for the better grown heavier types, lifting 15c to top at 210c, with light vealer heifers 14c easier, to average 200c/kg. A very good line of yearling heifers above 330kg to feed sold to 229c, averaging 214c, with similar types to restockers making to 224c/kg.

Bullocks were variable in quality and weight, with the best heavy 3 score bullocks to processors selling to 240c, with lighter conditioned bullocks to feed selling to 225c/kg. A larger offering of grown steers generally sold stronger, with heavy 3 score steers to slaughter selling to 248c, while lighter grown steers to live export sold to 240c, with most sales between 230c and 238c/kg. Increased numbers of heavy 3 score cows sold firm on last sale, with extra heavy cows topping at 196c, to average 190c and heavy 3 score cows selling to 193c, to average 185c/kg. Heavy D3 score cows sold to 185c, to average 171c, while a larger number of medium weight D2 cows eased 2c, to average 133c/kg. Light cows to restockers sold to 136c/kg. Grown heifer prices improved, with C3 heifers selling to 221c and heavier D3 heifers to 206c, lifting 10c, to average 186c/kg. Grown heifers returning to paddock sold to 199c, to average 168c/kg. The continued live export demand for heavy bulls lifted prices by more than 10c, topping at 277c, with most sales between 255c and 272c, and a small number of slaughter bulls sold to 240c/kg. Light males attracted limited demand selling to 240c/kg. Mixed quality cows and calves sold to $960/unit.

A slightly reduced yarding was offered to all the regular trade and export buyers. Most of the cattle were drawn from the local area, and as it quickly dries out, the quality of the cattle is falling on a weekly basis. Once the top few pens were sold, and onto the plainer lines, competition quickly fell away.  

The plainer muscled medium weight grown steers suffered falls to average from 138c to 146c/kg. A small pen of better quality medium weights averaged 152.2c/kg. Good heavy steers met solid demand and reached 163.2c/kg. Grown heifers sold to a generally firm market for the small numbers that were offered. 

A fair percentage of the yarding comprised of cows as values held surprisingly well to be firm to 3c/kg cheaper. Lightweights sold to 138c as the better lines averaged from 114c to 124c/kg. Medium weight D3s were in large numbers to average almost 130c, while heavy weights reached 140.2c/kg.

A slightly reduced offering saw a total offering of 553 head at the weekly prime market. Rises were consistent with other physical markets throughout the state, with increases of up to 17c/kg. 

Grown steers saw only a few lightweights offered to average 128.8c/kg. Medium weights reached a top of 147.6c/kg, while heavy steers averaged at 145.6.

A fair sample of heifers, with females dominating the yardings, ranged form 114.2c to 131.2c to average 129c/kg. Lightweight D3 cows averaged 124.2, while the same grade in medium weights averaged 124.1c/kg. 

A smaller number of bulls saw a top rate of 142.2c, and averaged at 137.8c/kg.

A slightly larger yarding was offered to a full panel of buyers. As has been the case at southern markets, competition was strong with most grades selling on a dearer trend. The quality of the yarding was the best seen for a few months with very few tail end drafts being penned. 

Only a small number of light steers were penned with the better descriptions selling to 200.2c/kg. The heavier steers realised gains of over 20c in places as medium weights reached 222.2c as heavy steers sold to 234.2c/kg. The highlight of the sale was the heavy bullocks topping at 235.2c/kg and returning over $1,500/head. 

Heifers have been met with solid support all week and this was no different here as the single C3 reached 200.2c/kg. The only grade going against the rising market were the light D2 cows, which suffered a 5c, fall to average 149.3c/kg. The better light cows reached 189.2c as medium D3s averaged 189.5c/kg. The top of the cow section was some very good medium weights reaching 201c/kg. A single heavy weight returned over $1,300/head after selling to 200.6c/kg. 

The bull market was also strong as light weights made to 166.2c and the better heavy weights averaged 200.1c/kg.

A slightly larger yarding was offered to a full contingent of buyers. Quality was similar to some other markets and was varied. Steers dominated the sale with fair number of cows also penned. 

Light steers averaged 139.8c as medium weight C3s sold to 170.2c to average 158.9c/kg. Other medium weights averaged 151.8c/kg. Heavy steers sold to 176.2c as a single heavy bullock reached 185c/kg. Light export heifers sold to 149.2c as the D2s averaged 118.3c/kg. 

Light D2 cows averaged 117.8c as D3s sold to 132.2c/kg. Medium weight D3s in the largest number topped at 149.2c and averaged 136.1c/kg. Plain light bulls averaged 89.9c as medium weights reached 127.2c/kg.

A slightly larger yarding of prime cattle plus another 500 store conditioned cattle was offered to local wholesalers, processors and restockers.  The local area is starting to look really dry with feed and water becoming an issue and no real wet season rain has been received. Quality was generally plain except for the steers, which included a good line up. An accurate trend is difficult for nearly all grades due to the limited numbers.

There was a run of steers included in the yarding with a couple of processors active in purchasing them paying to 149.2c/kg. These were the majority of the yarding. 

The light export heifers sold to 113.2c as the light and medium weight cows reached 116.2c/kg. A pen of medium weight bulls sold for 126.2c/kg.

A slightly larger yarding of fair quality sold to a near full field of buyers although competition was not as strong as earlier in the year. The top of the market was good quality but the bottom end tapered off especially in the cow categories. Values trended either side of firm although the majority was slightly dearer.

Most of the medium weight steers sold dearer and averaged 127.1c while some better quality descriptions averaged 136.8c after they reached 146.2c/kg. A handful of heavy steers averaged close to 135c/kg. 

Grown heifers were marginally cheaper and reached 137.2c to average126.3c/kg. Light cows sold on a cheaper trend the poorer quality stock averaged 106.8c while the better types saw most sales around 117c/kg. There were over 100 D3 medium weights that sold slightly dearer and averaged 123.8c after they reached 130.2c/kg.

Bulls sold to a top of 122.6c and most sales were around 120c/kg.

A slight reduction of 1,966 cattle were drawn by Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, featuring some good lines of prime cows and one large line of northern steers. One major processor continued their absence, while all other processors were in attendance and operating, with one live exporter, regular feeder buyers and local and western restockers. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Burketown, Croydon, Mt Surprise, Richmond, Hughenden, Prairie, Ingham, Greenvale, Belyando and local areas.

A mixed supply of vealer steers sold lower this week, influenced by quality, reaching 363c/kg to western restockers. Yearling steer numbers increased, with one good quality large line selling to 370c for lighter types to average 345c, while the heavier draft sold to 332c to average 305c/kg. A small number of steers to feed sold to 290c/kg. Vealer heifers were well supplied, with slaughter types selling to 270c to average 255c, while heifers returning to grass sold to 286c to average 267c/kg. Several small lines of yearling heifers of mixed quality sold to 260c to feed, with heifers returning to paddock topping at 256c/kg.

Bullocks were of mixed quality and the small number, sold lower on last sale, owing to the mixed quality, topping at 268c to slaughter, while lighter conditioned types returned to grass to 250c/kg. A small number of grown steers to restockers sold to 270c/kg. A continued large yarding of cows sold 2c to 5c/kg lower on last sale, despite some well finished good lines of cows on offer. Heavy 3 score cows sold to 232c, to average 220c, while D muscled cows sold to 220c to average 209c/kg. Lighter cows to restockers sold to 222c to average 212c/kg. Well finished grown heifers to slaughter sold to 255c/kg. A smaller number of bulls of mixed quality and weight sold to 262c to slaughter, while bulls to live export sold to 260c/kg. Some good quality lines of young bulls less than 200kg to restockers sold to 376c, to average 365c/kg. Light cows and calves sold to $1,480/unit.

A slight reduction in numbers by 90 head to 2,654 cattle were yarded by Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, with some good lines of well finished bullocks and cows along with a large line of northern yearling steers and heifers a feature of the yarding. One regular processor was again absent this week, however prime cattle increased by 2c to 3c/kg on last sale, light cows lifted up to 30c/kg, while feeder buyers and restockers continued recent strong sale values throughout the store section. Cattle were drawn from Normanton, Einasleigh, Richmond, Tully, Ingham, Ayr, Woodstock, Belyando, local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers were again in demand for the small number on offer, with restockers active for lighter weight lines, which sold to 414.2c/kg. The larger lines of yearling steers attracted strong restocker interest, with steers returning to paddocks topping at 383.2c, for an average of 382.4, while feeder buyers sourcing suitable weight steers topped at 358.2c, to average 338.4c/kg. Some grown steers to feed sold to 348.2c/kg. Vealer heifers sold strongly for the smaller number on offer, selling to 360.2c, with very good well conditioned vealers selling to 340.2c/kg.  Yearling heifers dominated the female store offering, selling to 334.2c to feeder buyers while restockers paid to 321.2c/kg for lighter types. Grown heifers to feed sold to 330.2c, to average 319.1c/kg.

Some excellent lines of well finished 3 score bullocks sold to 299.2c to slaughter, to average 291.3c/kg. A number of 2 score bullocks to feed destined for live export, sold to 275.2c/kg. Grown steers to feed sold to 348.2c/kg. Another very good yarding of prime cows this week saw values lift 2c to 3c for the best heavy 3 score cows, topping at 267.2c, to average 250.4c, while heavy 2 score cows to slaughter sold to 263.2c, to average 234.4c/kg. Light cows returning to the paddock lifted significantly, selling to 248c to average 234.2c/kg to western restockers. A good selection of heavy 3 score bulls to slaughter sold to 257.2c, while medium and heavy bulls to live export sold to 280.2c/kg. Younger feeder weight bulls sold to 328.2c, while young light weight males to restockers sold to 342.2c/kg. Cows and calves consisted of several smaller lines, with the sale top of $1,840, with most sales $1,120 to $1,450/unit.

A similar yarding to the last sale was drawn by Charters Towers Combined Agents this week, with some larger lines of cows and heavy bulls in good condition attracting solid buyer competition.  All of the major processors were in attendance and operating, supported by a feeder buyer for live export.  Cattle were drawn from Georgetown, Forsayth, Hughenden, Ingham, and Bowen, along with local and coastal areas.  

A small number of vealer steers attracted strong demand from restockers, resulting in dearer trend, reaching 306c/kg, and at 278c/kg.  Yearling steers were of mixed quality and sold to 276c, with several restockers and one feeder buyer for live export competing strongly throughout. Vealer heifers were few in number and sold to higher rates, topping at 260c/kg.  Yearling heifers sold to 256c/kg for the small number on offer.

Heavy bullocks were in short supply and very mixed in quality, selling to 258c/kg.  3 score cows were in good supply and assisted by strong competition, values increased to top at 212c, and average 199c/kg.  Medium weight 2 score cows sold to 197c, averaging 169c/kg.  Medium weight heifers were in good supply and sold strongly to a top of 225c/kg. A larger offering of heavy bulls sold to increased rates, topping at 213c for heavy slaughter lines and 265c/kg for lighter live export types. Some good large lines of cows and calves sold strongly, selling from $900, to a sale top of $1090/unit.

A similar yarding to last sale of 1,440 cattle were yarded by Charters Towers Combined Agents, with a very good yarding of prime cows and bullocks, predominantly from northern areas, supported by some very good quality lines of store heifers and steers. All major processors were in attendance and active throughout the sale, along with a southern processor and feeder, while restockers continued recent buying activity on all categories throughout the sale.

Increased numbers of vealer heifers sold strongly for better, well grown types, topping at 282.2c/kg. Yearling heifers were mixed in quality and buyers were selective on the offering, with the heavier more covered types selling to a top of 232.2c/kg. Vealer steers were similar in number to last sale, with better grown, good conditioned lines attracting very strong restocker activity, selling to 328.2c/kg. Yearling steers to restockers sold to 282.2c, averaging 274.2c/kg.

An increased number of very good prime bullocks, dominated by a very good northern draft topped at 268.2c to average 252.2c/kg. 2 score bullocks sold to 242.2c/kg, with several restockers competing for the better grown types. Another very good yarding of prime cows saw values increase by up to 10c, with heavy 3 score cows topping at 225.2c to average 218.3c, while 2 score cows sold to 214c to average 196.4c/kg. Restockers were very active on lighter 2 score store cows and one line of PTIC cows, which sold for 210.2c/kg. Well finished 3 score trade heifers sold to 245.2c, while heifers to restockers for breeding sold to 249.2c/kg. Heavy slaughter bulls again sold to increased rates, topping at 229.2c for the heavier types, while lighter young bulls destined for live export sold to 250.2c/kg. Light bull calves sold to 326.2c/kg. A limited number of cows and calves were on offer, selling from $800 to $970, with one outstanding line of big framed cow/calf units selling for $1,475/unit.

A similar sized yarding was offered with quality to the same level as last week. A wide field of buyers operated with consistent export competition, coupled with local butchers, restockers and independent buyers aiding prices. Consistent cold weather and significant frost have really knocked feedstocks in the local region and many suspect producers to off load cattle in the coming weeks. 

Grown steer quality was similar to the previous sale and prices for medium weights averaged 151.1c, while heavier steers ranged from 151.2c to 164.2c, with both categories improving slightly.
 
The quality of the cow yarding was similar to the previous market, but the tail end of poorer quality cows did appear to be larger than last week. Restockers were very strong purchasing around 100 head of the poorer cows at an average of 99c/kg. Lightweight D3 cows ranged from 125.2c to 135.2 and the large number of heavyweights improved slightly to average 135.1c/kg.

A similar sized yarding was offered to a regular field of local and export buyers. Despite the supply area slowly drying off there is still a good body of feed available. The overall quality of the yarding was improved on previous weeks, but it did include some plainer types, as is expected at this time of year. The better types continue to sell to very solid demand. 

The light steer numbers improved along with values after selling to a top of 146.2c/kg. The medium weight steers reached 162.2c as heavy weights topped at 170.2c/kg. The limited number of heavy bullocks sold to 171.2c/kg in pen lots. 

The light D3 heifers were in large numbers, selling to 143.2c/kg. The light cow numbers increased dramatically and this had a negative effect on values. The medium weight sold to 136.2c, as the heavy weights averaged 132.1c/kg.  

Most of the bulls offered were heavy weights, which sold to 133.2c/kg.

A similar sized yarding of mainly local cattle was penned. A full panel of buyers was in operation, however values eased for most categories. Quality in most instances was fair to good as the local area remains particularly dry. 

Light steers averaged 136.2c/kg as most were showing signs of the season. Good medium weights sold to 171.2c to average 167.3c/kg. A large number of heavy steers averaged 168.9c/kg. A small number of light export heifers held firm as the majority eased 8c/kg. 

Cows dominated the yarding with most in the lightweight range as values overall slipped up to 6c/kg. Light D2s averaged 118.7c as others sold to 134.2c/kg. Better medium weights reached 155.2c as D3s averaged 138.4c/kg. Both medium and heavy D4s topped at 148.2c/kg. Most of the bulls offered were in the lightweight range as heavy weights sold to 132.2c/kg.

A similar sized yarding of export cattle was offered at Charters Towers Wednesday. Values remained firm with gains of up to and over 10c/kg being recorded. 

A large proportion of the steers weighed between 400 and 500kg as the D3s sold to a top of 136.2c/kg. But heavy D3 bullocks selling up to 140.8c/kg outsold these. 

The cows received the biggest gains for the day as light types improved over 20c as a line of twenty-four D2s sold for 95.6c/kg. Medium weight D3 cows also witnessed a healthy rise to average 110.5c with the top of heavy D4s selling to 119.2c/kg. 

Bulls did not miss out on the improved rates with rises of up to 14c being recorded. Large numbers of heavy D1s reached 122.2c/kg.

A similar sized yarding at Charters Towers saw values ease for most, except for the larger yarding of bulls. Also able to realise a rise were the D4 steers weighing between 500 and 600kg.

The light steers and heavy bullocks were in small numbers making an accurate quote difficult. The medium weight C4s suffered an 11c loss to average 133.2c with the top price for the sale being a medium weight D4 reaching 145.2c/kg. As mentioned before, D4 steers weighing between 500 and 600kg-increased 1c to average 134.4c/kg, even though increased numbers were offered this week. 

Heifers were not as fortunate as last sale, with losses occurring for both the D2s and D3s. Cows also suffered losses with medium weight D3s slipping 7c to average 94.2c after reaching 107.2c/kg and topping the cow section.

All bulls offered were D1s, as light weights increased 8c to average 94c and the heavy weights increased over 20c to average 102.8c/kg.

A similar number of cattle were offered with a large supply of good quality cows accounting for over a third of the yarding.  Steers were also in fair numbers. All buyers were in attendance, although competition was not as keen in some instances. The bulk of the steers held firm while the heifers improved 4c to 7c/kg. Cows eased by 2c to 6c/kg. 

Light steers sold to 128.2c while the D3 medium weights topped at 149.2c to average 139.7c/kg. Heavy steers peaked at 149.2c also and they averaged 144.6c/kg. One heavy bullock made to 153.2c/kg. Heifers sold to an isolated 125c though most averaged 117.6c/kg. 

Light cows were in good numbers and they sold to 109.2c while a large number of D1s averaged 94.5c/kg. There was close to 400 medium weights penned and they reached 127.2c with close to 300 D3s averaging 119c/kg. Heavy bulls peaked at 107.2c/kg.

A significantly reduced offering was drawn from the usual supply area and included some plainer quality cattle. With rain threatening in the district it appears producers were keen to retain stock or simply that the region is beginning to run out marketable cattle. The limited supply forced a dearer trend from all the usual buyers plus an extra export operator. 

Lightweight grown steers held firm to range from 103.2c to 145.2c with plainer types averaging 100c/kg. The limited amount of well finished medium weights reached 185c with most sales at 174.7c/kg. Heifers improved to range from 150c to 177.2c/kg. 

Cow demand eased for light cows to average 150.3c with plainer pens averaging 132c/kg. Medium weight D3s ranged from 157.2c to 163.2c with occasional sales reaching 163.2c/kg. Bull competition was mixed for the limited number on offer with some lightweight sales reaching 190.2c/kg.

A significant reduction in the amount of prime cattle penned saw reduced yarding of 2,610 cattle in Charters Towers this week, 1,040 fewer than last sale.  Quality was very mixed, consisting of many small lines, however some very good pens of cows and steers were presented. All regular processors were in attendance an operating at reduced rates, supported by two live exporters, central and southern feeders, backgrounders and western restockers. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Hughenden, Georgetown, Mt Surprise, Greenvale, Ingham, Prosperpine, local and coastal areas.

The heifer calves to processors sold to 406c to average 383c/kg. Vealer steers to southern restockers topped at 446c/kg. Vealer heifers reached 376c to average from 342c to 355c whilst processor lines averaged from 356c to 385c/kg. Several small lines of light yearling steers to feed sold to 386c as heavy steers reached a top of 388c/kg. Mixed lines of yearling heifers sold according to quality with best quality types to feed selling to 358c/kg. 

Grown steers to live export sold to 366c, most selling from 346c to 354c, with small numbers of steers to the trade reaching 354c/kg. Limited numbers of heifers to the trade sold to 344c/kg. A small number of full mouth bullocks sold to slaughter for a top of 350c/kg. 

Reduced numbers of cows to processors sold to lower rates, with medium weight 2 score cows selling to 280c, while 3 scores topped at 286c multiple times to average from 275c to 281c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export topped at 344c to average 329c/kg. A large sample of young males returning to grass sold to 422c/kg. Some very good cows and calves sold from $1,825 to $1,900/unit.

A significant increase in the supply of cattle by 1,813 head, saw 3,102 head presented in Charters Towers this week, comprising of several heavier lines of prime cows and a large line of store steers and heifers. Most regular processors operated at subdued rates compared to recent weeks, supported by one live exporter, central feeders and restockers along with regular local backgrounders. Cattle were drawn from Croydon, Richmond, Greenvale, Bowen, Belyando, local and coastal areas. 

Good quality young vealer steers to restockers eased slightly, with plainer types more than 15c/kg easier and plain vealer heifers easing by similar values despite an increase in the number of buyers. Mixed quality yearling steers and heifers sold according to quality, with large samples more than 30c/kg easier. Increased numbers of yearling heifers to the trade sold firm to 5c/kg dearer. A small offering of grown steers sold according to quality, while a large increase in the supply of grown heifers to processors sold to stronger rates throughout. Bullocks eased with quality a factor while heavy cows eased more than 30c/kg on most categories from recent subdued processor values. Increased numbers of medium weight cows sold firm to slightly dearer. Heavy bulls to live export and processor eased by up to 25c/kg.

Good quality vealer steers to restockers topped at 378c, with most sales from 325c to 350c/kg. Very good quality vealer heifers returning to grass sold from 298c to 306c, with a large sample of plainer types to feed averaging 261c/kg. Small lines of yearling steers sold to 346c to average near 328c/kg.  Light yearling heifers to feed sold to 265c and heifers above 330kg reached 300c, with a large sample averaging 285c/kg. Heavy grown heifers to processors made to 294c, averaging from 241c to 286c/kg. 

Small numbers of heavy bullocks to export processor sold to 311c to average near 289c/kg. Medium weight cows sold to 212c to average 189c, with heavy 3 score cows reaching 244c to average 242c, with lesser yielding heavy cows averaging 228c and extra heavy cows reaching 252c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export made to 330c, with a select group returning to the paddock as sires made 348c/kg. A small number of cows and calves made $700 with individual sales to $1050/unit.

A significant increase in supply of cattle this week with 4,285 head yarded, 2,303 more than last sale. Overall quality improved on recent weeks with some very good lines of heavy prime cows and bullocks, along with increased numbers of plainer conditioned cows. Demand was strong throughout for most lines with a new saleyard record for steer and heifer calves. One regular processor was absent, however they were replaced by another major processor for their first attendance of the year. Regular southern processor and feeder orders continued, along with one live exporter and several opportunity driven southern and central restockers. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Burketown, Richmond, Einasleigh, Mt Garnet, Greenvale, Ingham, Pentland, Woodstock, local and coastal areas.

Increased numbers of calves met a very strong demand for most lines, with a line of steer calves setting a saleyard record of 470.2c, to southern restocker and the heifer portion of the draft made 378.2c/kg. The better bred mixed sex calves averaged from 350c to 392c/kg. Vealer steers to restockers sold to 418.2c multiple times to average from 382c to 400c/kg. Vealer heifers to processors were highly sought after, making to 366.2c to average from 337 to 354c/kg. Restockers paid to 338.2c for light weight pens, and light heifers to feed topped at 324.2c to average 306c/kg.  

Yearling steers to feed sold to 350.2c to average 334c and suitable backgrounder lines sold to 358.2c to average 352c/kg. A small number to live export averaged 330c/kg. Variable quality and weight of the yearling heifers met mixed demand, most selling to feeder orders, reaching 330.2c to average from 256c to 313c/kg. A good draft of grown steers to live export sold to 338.2c to average 331c and heavy feeder steers sold for 334c to average from 320 to 326c/kg.  Reduced numbers of grown heifers were of variable quality with those to the trade selling to 300.2c to average from 262c to 277c/kg.  Heifers to feed averaged 267c/kg.

Heavy bullocks to export slaughter sold to 340.2c to average 325c, while one live exporter secured suitable bullocks at 338.2c to average 331c/kg. Increased numbers of lightweight cows to processors averaged from 192c to 223c, while medium weight 2 score cows sold for 262.2c to average 236c/kg.  Heavy 3 score cows sold at 276.2c to average from 258c to 267c/kg and suitable cows to live export averaged from 226c to 269c/kg. A consignment of prime heavy weight cows sold to 282.2c/kg. Heavy bulls suitable for live export sold to 325.2c to average from 291c to 312c, while processor bulls mostly averaged from between 236c to 240c/kg. Young light males returning to grass sold to 390.2c to average from 341c to 348c/kg. One good pen of Cows with young calves sold to $1270/unit.

A significant decrease in supply resulted in 678 cattle drawn in Charters Towers this week, 1,801 fewer than previous sale. Most notably, prime cattle were in short supply, however most lines were well finished and values improved on recent weeks. The regular buying panel was in attendance, competing strongly for the smaller yarding, supported by one feeder buyer and a select few restockers and backgrounders. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Pentland, Ingham, Mt Coolon, local and coastal areas. Despite the smaller offering, good quality vealer steers increased by 35c/kg and vealer heifers lifted by similar rates on last sale. Yearling steers were mostly heavier selling firm, while a good selection of yearling heifers to domestic processors improved by up to 30c/kg. Grown steers and heifers were insufficient to quote and bullocks were also of limited supply. Medium weight cows were insufficient to reliably quote, however a very good offering of heavy cows increased by 10 to 15c/kg. Heavy bulls eased by up to 9c for the better quality heavy pens.

Vealer steers returning to grass sold to 299c, to average 266c, with most better quality lines selling above 273c/kg. Vealer heifers to slaughter sold to 267c, to average 237c, while lighter types returning to grass made up to 203c/kg.  Yearling steers were generally heavier types, mostly above 330kg, returning to the paddock averaging 272c, reaching a high of 277c/kg. A good supply of heavy yearling heifers suitable for slaughter sold to 268c, averaging 264c, with medium weight lines to slaughter averaging 193c/kg. 

The few heavy bullocks to export slaughter sold to 300c, averaging 289c/kg. The supply of medium weight cows was minimal and sold in line with quality, while good heavy 3 score cows sold to 230c, averaging 218c and extra heavy cows topped at 234c, to average 229c/kg. The small offering of heavy bulls mostly sold to feed and destined for live export selling from 240 to 274c/kg.

A return to combined Prime and Store sale attracted 2,564 cattle, 246 fewer than comparable sale a fortnight ago. Quality was very mixed with a large offering of northern pastoral cattle and many lines showing effects of the lengthening dry season; however, some good quality local lines of well finished cattle were on offer. The regular buyer panel was in attendance and operated at stronger rates to last sale, supported by one live exporter. Grown steers and heifers lifted by 10c to 15c, bullocks increased 4c, while heavy cows and bulls to processors averaged 10c to 12c/kg higher. Cattle were drawn from Doomadgee, Normanton, Greenvale, Ingham, local and coastal areas.  

Light steer calves to local restockers sold to 552c to average 484c and best quality light weight vealer steers returning to grass reached 642c to average between 452c and 508c/kg. A good sample of light vealer heifers returning to grass topped at 498c to average 461c/kg. Yearling steers consisted of many small and variable lines with those above 280kg to backgrounders reaching 488c to average 442c/kg. Yearling steers above 330kg to feed averaged 427c/kg. A limited supply of yearling heifers below 280kg to feed topped at 382c to average 304c/kg.

Grown steers were of very good quality and met strong demand with heavy steers to the trade topping at 426c and averaging from 417c to 421c while medium weights averaged 408c/kg. Plainer conditioned medium weight steers to feed averaged 425c and backgrounder lines averaged 431c to 443c/kg. A small sample of good quality heavy grown heifers to the trade sold to 398c to average from 359c to 393c/kg. A small sample of grown heifers to feed made to 358c to average 340c/kg. A good number of heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 416c, to average 404c to 408c/kg. Processor demand for cows continues to be very strong. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 356c to average 343c and 3 scores reached 372c to average from 350c to 371c/kg. A good sample of prime heavy weight 4 score cows topped at 378c to average 374c/kg. Increased numbers of light conditioned cows to restockers sold to 334c to average 303c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors sold to 356c to average from 320c to 354c/kg. A small sample of suitable bulls to live export sold from 310c to 358c/kg.

Good quality cows and calves sold from $1,680 to $2,200/unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

A return to a prime only sale resulted in 2,315 cattle penned, an increase of more than 1,100 on the equivalent prime cattle last week. Quality was very mixed, however some very good lines of heavy bullocks, grown steers and prime cows were on offer. One major processor continued their absence, however other regular processors, feeders and two live exporters operated at stronger rates throughout. Cattle were drawn from as far west as Mt Isa to Normanton, Croydon, Mt Surprise, Einasleigh, Richmond, Torrens Ck, Greenvale, local and coastal areas. Grown steers lifted 4c to 13c and the heifer portion also improved, 17c to 25c/kg. Bullocks improved 30c and prime cows sold from 7c to 15c/kg higher.   

Yearling steers above 400kg to feed sold to 410c to average 407c, and yearling heifers above 330kg to feed, made to 376c to average 367c/kg. Grown steers to feed topped at 416c multiple times to average 400c and steers to live export sold to 378c with a large sample averaging 376c/kg. Suitable trade steers averaged 377c/kg. Grown heifers to the trade topped at 340c, averaging 330c, and heifers to feed sold to 338c to average 326c/kg.   

A large sample of heavy full mouthed bullocks topped at 381c to average 374c/kg. Increased numbers of cows met very strong demand on all types throughout the offering. Medium weight score 2 cows to processors sold to 296c to average 283c and score 3 cows sold to a top of 308c/kg. Prime heavy weight cows topped at 312c to average 307c/kg. Medium cows to restockers made to 294c to average 274c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export reached 374c multiple times to average 371c/kg.   

The store sale scheduled for this Friday has 3,200 cattle booked. 

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

A return to a combined prime and store sale, resulted in 1847 cattle penned.  Quality was mostly good throughout with almost 600 heavy prime cows and and an outstanding line of northern weaner steers and heifers.  Two major processors were absent from the buyer panel, supported by regular feeders, local and western restockers.  Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa to Mt Garnet, Greenvale, local and coastal areas.

Most categories eased on last week, with young cattle 8c to 15c easier, bullocks  down 4c, cows to processors averaged 9c to 12c lower and bulls eased 5c to 8c less than last sale.

A large line of suitably weaned vealer steers returning to the paddock sold to 432c to average 413c/kg. Yearling steers above 330kg returning to grass sold to 336c and heavy yearling steers also to the paddock sold to 298c to average 294c/kg.  A very good line of vealer heifers destined for breeding reached 360c averaging 337c/kg. A limited supply yearling heifers to feed averaged 268c topping at 278c.

A limited number of bullocks to export slaughter averaged 292c, selling to 298c with isolated single sales to 302c/kg.  Another good offering of prime cows sold to an easier trend.  Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 224c to average 210c and 3 scores topped at 254.2 to average 242c/kg.   A large sample of prime heavyweight 4 score cows sold to and averaged 254c/kg.  An increase offering of heavy bulls to processors reached 299c to average 282c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

A return to a combined prime and store sale resulted in numbers increasing by 792 to 2,735 head in Charters Towers this week. Demand was once again very strong across all categories, with quality very mixed and many lines showing increasing effects of the dry season. All regular processors operated to increased rates often in competition with three live exporters, one feeder buyer and opportunity restockers. Very strong demand for cows lifted averages from 20c to 30c, yearling heifers to feed increased by more than 20c, grown steers improved more than 6c/kg, while bulls were mostly firm. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Normanton, Croydon, Julia Creek, Ravenshoe, Greenvale, Belyando as well as local and coastal areas.

Light steer calves attracted strong restocker demand, reaching 504.2c to average from 429c to 445c, while heifer calves to processors made 378.2c/kg. Vealer steers to restockers sold to a top of 500.2c to average from 446c to 468c and steers above 280kg returning to grass averaged 403c/kg. Vealer heifers to feed sold to a top of 396.2c to average from 345c to 368c whilst processor lines averaged 388c/kg. Yearling steers to live export sold to 382.2c, while steers to feed weighing above 280kg sold to 402.2c with steers above 330kg averaging 394c/kg. Several very good lines of yearling heifers met strong competition, selling to 384.2c, averaging from 347c to 367c/kg. 

Grown steers to live export sold to 366.2c and heavy steers to the trade made to a top of 380.2c with better bred pen lots averaging from 377c to 378c/kg. Grown heifers to the trade sold to 366.2c or to average from 329c to 353c, while heifers to live export sold to 330.2c. A limited number of heavy bullocks to export slaughter sold to 371.2c with single sales averaging 330c/kg.  

Strong demand saw medium weight cows to processors sell to 312.2c to average 302c and 3 scores made to 354.2c or to average from 310c to 324c/kg. Prime heavy weight cows sold to 328.2c to average from 312c to 322c/kg. Cows to live export sold to 310.2c to average 302c and cows less than 400kg to live export averaged from 257c to 282c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export reached 378.2c, with most sales from 360c to 376c, while heavy bulls to processors topped at 376.2c to average 370c/kg. Feeder weight bulls to live export sold to 378.2c with better quality pens averaging from 300c to 362c/kg. Limited numbers of good quality cows and calves sold to $1,525/unit.

A return to a combined prime and store sale resulted in 3,690 cattle penned. Quality was very mixed with some good lines of yearling and grown steers along with heavy prime cows, however, there was a large consignment of poor quality northern cattle. All regular processors, feeders, backgrounders and two live exporters operated at mostly higher rates than previous weeks - particularly on cows. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Julia Ck, Normanton, Doomadgee, Georgetown, Mt Garnet, Hughenden, Belyando, local and coastal areas. 

Good quality steer calves to southern restockers sold to 584c with mixed sexes averaging 542c and heifers to the trade making to 440c/kg. Vealer steers to backgrounders reached 532c to average 474c, with steers above 280kg to feed selling to 504c/kg. Vealer heifers to the trade sold to 435c with a good sample averaging 428c, while heifers to southern restockers reached 478c to average 445c/kg. Yearling steers above 330kg to feed reached a top of 440c to average 422c and a large sample above 400kg to feed reached 430c to average 419c/kg. The best quality yearling heifers above 330kg to feed topped at 394c with a large sample averaging from 379c to 383c/kg. Heifers above 400kg to feed averaged 387c/kg. Suitable grown steers to live export sold to 374c and heavy steers to the trade topped at 376c/kg. Steers above 400kg to feed reached 418c to average 383c/kg. Grown heifers to the trade sold to 346c, while heifers to feed reached a top of 360c to average 351c/kg. A good supply of bullocks continued with general quality and weight not up to standard of last week. Heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export processors sold to a top of 374c/kg.  

Strong demand from all sectors of the buyer panel continued for most lines of cows. Medium weight 2 score cows returning to the paddock reached a top of 308c and processor lines sold to 304c to average 291c/kg. Medium weight score 2 cows to processors sold to 296c and score 3 cows reached 312c/kg. Prime heavy weight cows topped at 306c to average 300c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export reached 360c to average near 355c and similar bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 366c to average 346c/kg. Young males returning to grass topped at 554c, while males weighing 300 to 400kg to feed reached 466c/kg. Small lines of good quality cows and calves sold to $2,050/unit. 

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

A return to a combined prime and store sale resulted in 3,599 mixed quality cattle penned in Charters Towers under very hot conditions.  Small lines of well finished cows and bullocks and some large single vendor lines of certified grain-fed and grass-fed grown heifers in the prime section were supported by some very good lines of light weight store steers and heifers.  Most of the regular processors were in attendance and operating strongly throughout, along with regular central feeder buyers, one live exporter and local opportunity backgrounds and restockers. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Normanton, Croydon, Richmond, Hughenden, Pentland, Ingham, local and coastal areas.

Strong demand for steer calves continued, topping at 512.2c and heifer calves returning to grass sold to 420.2c, with mixed sex calves averaging 501c/kg.  A large sample of light vealer steers returning to the paddock sold to 504.2c to average from 422 to 455c and heifers to backgrounders selling to 433.2c to average 411c/kg. Fewer numbers of mixed quality yearling steers returning to the paddock sold to 395.2c, most selling from 320 to 378c/kg. A good supply of yearling heifers met strong demand with those to feed selling to 368.2c averaging from 327 to 351c and heifers to the trade sold to 376c/kg. Grown steers to the trade sold to 370.2c and suitable types to live export sold to 354.2c averaging from 344 to 351c/kg. A rare offering of heavy grain-fed heifers to the trade sold to 342.2c, averaging above 330c, while grass-fed heifers sold to 358.2c to average 347c and a large sample of heifers to feed sold to 362.2c to average near 360c/kg.   

Heavy bullocks to export slaughter topped at 376.2c, mostly averaging from 347 to 370c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows sold to 284.2c with most averaging 258c, while 3 score cows topped at 318.2c to average from 280 to 302c/kg. An increased supply of heavy bulls to processors topped at 370.2c, with most averaging from 332 to 365c, while suitable types to live export averaged from 310 to 366c/kg.

A return to a Combined Prime and Store sale resulted in 2629 cattle penned.  In a mixed quality yarding, there was a reduced supply of heavy prime bullocks and cows and increased numbers of plainer conditioned types.  Yearling steers and heifers consisted of several smaller mixed quality lines. All regular processors operated at reduced rates supported by regular feeders and backgrounders who were selective on the quality penned.  Cattle were drawn from Georgetown to Richmond and Hughenden, south to Belyando, local  coastal areas.

Light steers to local restockers sold to an isolated 600c with most selling from 470c to 530c, while similar heifers returning to grass reached 454c to average 389c/kg.  Yearling steers above 200kg to backgrounders reached 394c to average 370c/kg.  A good sample of yearling heifers above 280kg to grass made to 430c to average 414c/kg.   

Mixed quality grown steers above 400kg to feed sold to 342c to average 322c/kg.  Heavy grown steers to the trade reached 432c to average 416c/kg.  Grown heifers to feed made to 342c to average 335c and trade types sold to 316c averaging 308c/kg.

Reduced numbers of full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter sold to 348c  to average 316c/kg.  Medium weight 2 score cows sold to 296c averaging 267c and 3 score cows reached 316c to average 295c/kg.  Prime heavyweight 4 score cows topped at 324c to average 311c to 316c/kg. Heavy processor bulls topped at 296c to average 270c to 277c/kg.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

A return to a combined prime and store sale resulted in 2,729 cattle penned of which 1,190 were prime and quality was mostly good throughout. There were some very good lines of yearling crossbred steers and heifers along with very good heavy cows that all met strong demand. One major processor was absent, however all other regular processors were supported by one live exporter, several southern and central backgrounders and feeders, along with western and local restockers. Fewer numbers of cows and heifers saw values increase with improved quality of bullocks and steers also resulting in price increases in most categories. Cattle were drawn from the far north west of Mt Isa, to the gulf near Georgetown and south to the Belyando and Collinsville including local and coastal areas. 

Light weight steer calves to southern restockers sold to 546c and good quality vealer steers under 280kg made to a top of 478c multiple times to average from 450c to 478c/kg. Steers above 200kg returning to western paddocks made to 500c/kg. Vealer heifers under 200kg sold to 480c to southern backgrounders while suitable processor lines above 200kg sold to 430c to average near 407c/kg. Yearling steers under 330kg to feed reached 430c to average 416c, with some very good quality yearling steers above 330kg going onto feed topping at 438c and a good sample averaging 399c/kg. Heavy steers above 400kg made to 426c to average 407c/kg. Yearling heifers under 280kg to feed reached 380c with restockers paying to 400c/kg. Heifers above 330kg to feed averaged 374c and heifers returning to grass topped at 412c to average 385c/kg. 

Grown steers to live export sold to 372c multiple times and good quality steers to feed reached 392c/kg. Lighter types to restockers averaged from 334c to 339c, while a small number to the trade reached 392c and heavy weights made from 374c to 380c/kg. Reduced numbers of grown heifers to the trade sold to a top of 338c with better quality types averaging from 305c to 331c/kg. Heavy full mouthed bullocks to export slaughter reached 350c/kg. Reduced numbers of cows continued to attract strong demand, with medium weight score 2 cows reaching a top of 262c and score 3 cows selling to 296c/kg. Prime heavy weight cows topped at 298c, averaging from 289c to 294c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export sold to a top of 368c to average from 330c to 360c and similar types to feed destined for live export made to 360c/kg. Young males to western restockers topped at 558c to average from 414c to 514c/kg. Good quality cows and calves made to $1,775/unit. 

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

A return to a combined prime and store sale resulted in 2,223 cattle penned. Quality once again was very mixed with many smaller single vendor lines and fewer well finished heavy cows and bullocks. One regular export processor was in attendance but did not operate, while two additional operators were active alongside regular processors, feeders, restockers and one live exporter. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa to Georgetown, Ingham and south to Belyando. Most categories continued to improve in price particularly better-quality lines. Grown steers to feed improved 30c, heifers to feed increased 20c, heavy bullocks lifted 19c and heavy cows averaged 20c/kg higher.

Vealer steers returning to grass reached 558.2c to average from 477c to 538c and similar heifers to the trade made to 404.2 to average 403c/kg. Yearling steers above 280kg to feed reached 428.2 to average 419c and steers above 330kg to feed reached 440.2c to average 412c/kg. Yearling heifers above 280kg to feed sold to 410.2 to average the same and heifers above 330kg to feed reached 392.2c to average 373c to 391c/kg. A good sample of heifers returning to the paddock for breeding made 420.2c to average 400c to 419c/kg. Good quality grown steers above 400kg to feed sold to 410.2c to average 382c, while heavy steers to the trade topped at 388.2c to average 381c/kg. A small sample of heavy grown heifers to feed made to 366.2c and suitable trade types sold to 360.2c to average 335c to 357c/kg.

A reduced supply of heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 372.2c to average from 364c/kg. Additional processor demand pushed demand for cows. Medium weight 3 score cows to processors sold to 332.2c to average from 320c to 329c while prime heavy weight 4 score cows topped at 340.2c to average 337c/kg. Increased demand for heavy bulls by one live exporter and processors once again improved averages for the quality penned. Heavy bulls to live export sold to 352.2c to average above 332c, while processors were active on suitable bulls from 324c to 350c/kg.

Good quality cows and calves sold from $2,000 to $2,500/unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

A return to a Combined Prime and Store sale resulted in 2,166 cattle penned this week. Quality was once again very mixed, however there were several single vendor lines of very good quality heavy prime cows and grown steers. All regular processors were in attendance and operating at stronger rates, supported by one southern processor, several feeders, backgrounders and opportunity restockers. Increased processor demand lifted averages for medium and heavyweight cows by 8c to 23c, grown steers increased by 7c and bulls to processors improved by up to 8c/kg. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Burketown, Croydon, Hughenden, Greenvale, local and coastal areas. 

Yearling steers above 200kg to restockers sold to 518.2c and steers to backgrounders reached 480.2c to average 441c to 458c/kg. A large single vendor line of steers above 400kg to feed sold to 406.2c to average 401c/kg. Yearling heifers above 200kg returning to the paddock averaged 414c reaching a top of 418.2c while heifers above 330kg to feed sold to 400.2c to average 352c to 366c/kg. Grown steers above 400kg to feed reached 394.2c to average 390c and heavy steers to the trade sold to 392.2c to average 390c/kg. An increased supply of grown heifers to the trade sold to 378.2 to average 357c to 364c/kg.  Heifers to feed sold to 408.2c averaged 358c to 383c/kg.

A good supply of heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter sold to 390.2c to average 361c to 388c/kg. Cows continued to meet strong processor demand for all categories. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 338.2c to average 329c and 3 score cows to processors sold to 358.2c to average from 338c to 353c/kg. A larger sample of prime heavy weight 3 and 4 score cows also topped at 358.2c to average 345c to 356c/kg. Increased demand by processors for heavy bulls continued reaching 360.2c to average 352c/kg.

Several small lines of cows and calves sold from $1,125 to $1,950/unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

A return to a Combined Prime and Store Sale in very humid conditions resulted in 3097 cattle penned.  Overall quality was good, with some very good quality heavy bullocks and cows along with some larger single vendor lines of store steers and heifers.  All regular processors buyer operated at firm rates with one southern processor, one live exporter, regular feeders and opportunity backgrounders and restockers.  Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa to Georgetown, south to Belyando and local areas.

Light steers sold to 606.2c to restockers and vealer heifers returning to grass sold to 458.2c to average 432c/kg. Yearling steers above 280kg to feed sold to 496.2c to average 464c and suitable steers for live export sold to 458c. A good supply of yearling heifers above 280kg to restockers sold to 460.2c to average 417c/kg.  

Grown steers above 400kg to feed eased by up to 20c, selling to 402.2c to average 392c, while trade types sold to 400.2c multiple times to average 395c/kg.  Grown heifers to the trade reached 388.2c to average 365c/kg.  Increased numbers of prime heavy bullocks to export slaughter improved up to 20c, reaching 396.2c to average 392c/kg.  Cows eased 8c to 10c, with medium weight processor cows selling to 358.2c/kg to average 335c and 3 score cows reached 370.2c to average 354c/kg. A good supply of prime heavyweight 4 score cows topped at 376.2c to average 371c/kg.  Heavy bulls to processors made to 344.2c to average 326c to 334c/kg. 

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

A return to a combined prime and store sale attracted 2,847 cattle this week. Quality was very mixed and featured an increased numbers of heavy bullocks, one line of good quality grain fed cows and some good lines of store steers and heifers. However, most cows are showing the effects of the dry season. The regular buyer panel was bolstered by one major export processor operating at higher rates compared to recent weeks. Grown steers increased up to 7c, heifers were 10c easier, heavy bullocks lifted 13c, heavy cows averaged 7c/kg higher and heavy bulls held firm. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Burketown, Cloncurry, Georgetown, Hughenden, Ingham, Ayr, Belyando, local and coastal areas.  

Steer calves to central restockers sold to 526c to average 498c while processor lines averaged between 426c and 450c/kg. Good quality light vealer steers returning to the paddock sold to 554c, while those above 200kg averaged 483c/kg. A good sample of vealer heifers to processors sold to 450c to average between 391c and 403c, and a small sample to feed averaged between 388c and 391c/kg. Good quality yearling steers above 280kg to backgrounders reached 476c to average 456c, and a large sample of steers above 330kg to backgrounders, topped at 446c to average 432c/kg. Yearling heifers to feed above 330kg sold to 390c to average 388c and restocker lines topped at 420c to average 407c/kg.

A good supply of grown steers met strong demand with those to feed reaching 402c to average between 368c and 385c/kg. Heavy steers to the trade topped at 382c and a good sample to restockers averaged 375c/kg. Grown heifers to the trade sold to 356c to average 352c and heifers to feed averaged 339c/kg. An increased supply of heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter reached 386c and averaged between 371c and 377c/kg. A plainer offering of cows continued to meet strong processor demand. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors made to 310c to average 302c and 3 scores sold to 344c to average between 319c and 339c/kg. Some good pens of prime heavy weight cows topped at 343c, averaging from 330c to 341c/kg. A good line of heavy weight grain fed cows averaged 331c/kg. Strong demand for light cows saw those returning to grass sell to 322c and average between 290c and 310c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export topped at 370c to average 369c/kg. Medium weight bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 374c and averaged at 369c/kg. Young males returning to the paddock sold to a top of 522c/kg. A small quantity of young cows with calves at foot made $2,150/unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

A return to a combined Prime and Store sale attracted 2,722 cattle, 346 fewer than the comparable sale of a fortnight ago. Quality was mixed with many lines showing effects of the lengthening dry season, however some good quality local lines of well finished cattle were on offer. One southern export processor was again absent, while all others were in attendance and operating at similar rates to last sale, with only quality related price movement. Grown steers and heifers eased by 10c to 15c/kg, bullocks eased slightly, while cows and bulls to processors were mostly firm. Cattle were drawn from Normanton, Richmond, Georgetown, Greenvale, Ingham, Collinsville, local and coastal areas.  

Best quality light weight vealer steers returning to grass reached 598c multiple times to average 544c to 594c, while a large sample of plainer types to feed averaged 510c/kg. A small sample of vealer heifers to the trade topped at 446c to average near 453c/kg. A good sample of heifers returning to grass reached 476c, to average 384c/kg. Increased numbers to feed reached 442c to average 411c/kg. A large sample of yearling steers above 280kg to feed sold to 474c to average from 409c to 441c/kg. Yearling steers above 330kg to feed averaged 416c/kg. A good supply of yearling heifers above 330kg to feed topped at 398c multiple times to average 397c/kg. Heifers to backgrounders and restockers averaged 422c/kg. 

A good supply of heavy grown steers met strong demand with heavy steers to the trade topping at 410c to average 394c to 406c while medium weights averaged 379c/kg. Medium weight steers to feed reached 390c multiple times to average 364c to 376c/kg. Good quality heavy grown heifers to the trade sold to 370c to average 363c/kg. A small sample of grown heifers to feed made to 384c to average from305c to 348c/kg. A reduced offering of heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 407c, to average 393c to 401c/kg. Processor demand for cows continues to be very strong. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 344c to average 317c and 3 scores reached 353c to average from 338c to 348c/kg. A good sample of prime heavy weight cows topped at 356c to average 344c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors sold to 335c to average from 313c to 325c/kg.

Good quality cows and calves sold from $1,650 to $2,240/unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

A return to a combined prime and store sale attracted 2,571 cattle, very similar to the comparable sale a fortnight ago. Quality was very mixed with a large offering of northern pastoral cows and bulls and many lines showing effects of the lengthening dry season; however, some very good quality lines of bullocks and cows were on offer. The regular buyer panel was in attendance and operated at stronger rates to last sale. Grown steers and heifers lifted by 10c to 15c, bullocks increased 4c, while heavy cows and bulls to processors average 10c to 12c/kg higher. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Normanton, Hughenden, Hervey’s Range, Collinsville, Belyando, local and coastal areas.  

Light weight vealer steers returning to grass reached 618c to average 606c, while steers above 200kg to restockers made to 584c to average 527c/kg. A good sample of vealer heifers above 200kg returning to grass topped at 496c to average from 467c to 476c/kg. Yearling steers consisted of many small and variable lines with those above 280kg to backgrounders reaching 496c to average 487c and steers above 330kg averaging from 459c to 464c/kg. A small sample of yearling steers above 330kg to feed averaged 468c/kg. A limited supply of yearling heifers below 280kg to feed topped at 432c to average 418c and similar heifers to backgrounders averaged 414c/kg. Heifers above 330kg to feed averaged 433c/kg.

Grown steers were of very good quality with some large lines attracting strong demand, selling to a dearer trend. A large sample of steers above 400kg to feed sold to 468c to average 439c and similar types to restockers averaged 459c/kg. Heavy steers to the trade topped at 434c to average 423c/kg. An increased supply of good quality heavy grown heifers to the trade sold to 404c to average 388c/kg. A small sample of grown heifers to feed made to 432c to average from 407c to 432c/kg. A good number of heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 428c, to average from 403c to 418c/kg. Processor demand for cows continues to be very strong. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to a top of 357c to average 346c and 3 scores reached 384c to average from 367c to 371c/kg. A small sample of prime heavy weight cows topped at 382c multiple times. Increased numbers of light conditioned cows to restockers regularly sold from 338c to 358c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors sold to 368c to average from 329c to 362c/kg. A small sample of plainer bulls to feed export sold from 322c to 422c/kg. Very good quality cows and calves sold for $2,960/unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

A return to a Combined Prime & Store Sale attracted 3667 cattle in very hot conditions.  Despite continuing dry weather, quality and condition was good throughout with some large lines of very good quality steers and heifers penned.  All regular processors were in attendance and operating- including a central processor returning from flooding last week- supported by regular feeders, backgrounders and opportunity restockers.  Competition from the buyer panel was more selective than past weeks, with values across all categories easing - particularly classes of younger cattle and those to processors. Cattle were drawn from Richmond, Hughenden, Pentland, Georgetown, Einasleigh, Tully, Ingham, Belyando, local and coastal areas. 

Light vealer steers to restockers sold to 702.2c, while a large sample above 200kg returning to the paddock topped at 704.2c to average 617c to 645c/kg.  Vealer heifers to southern restockers sold to 750.2c to average 593c, with suitable heifers to the trade averaging 592c/kg. Yearling steers above 280kg to feed reached 600.2c to average 556c and a large sample of yearling steers above 330kg to feed topped at 590.2c to average 516c/kg. Increased numbers of good quality steers above 400kg to feed sold to 506.2c to average 500c/kg.  Light yearling heifers to southern restockers topped at 560.2c to average 526c to 534c/kg.  A good sample of heifers above 280kg to feed reached 490.2c to average 475c and heifers above 330kg to feed sold to 480.2c multiple times to average 436c to 441c/kg. 

Grown steers comprised several large lines in good condition with those above 400kg to feed selling to 500.2c to average 450c to 472c/kg. A large sample of steers above 500kg to the trade reached 434.2c to average 416c and heavy lines above 600kg to processors topped at 434.2c to average 427c/kg.  Greater numbers of grown heifers to feed topped at 420.2c to average 385c to 410c/kg, while heifers to the trade reached 400.2c to average near 380c/kg.  A good sample of heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 430.2c multiple times to average 421c/kg. 

Some good large lines of well finished cows met mixed demand with medium weight 3 score cows to processors reaching 384.2c to average 367c to 375 and prime heavyweights topping at 382.2c to average 379c/kg. Heavy bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 360.2c to average 340c to 352c/kg.  
Young males returning to grass topped  at 714.2c to average 591c/kg.

Good quality cows and calves sold from $2,200 to $2,875/unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

A reduced yarding was offered to all the usual export and local buyers. Quality was poor across most of the yarding with only the occasional offering showing some condition. Despite this, market trends were dearer form all categories as the major export buyers competed for the limited stock available. 

Medium grown steers averaged between 201.2c and 205.5c for the better conditioned types while plainer lines averaged 173.2c/kg. Grown heifers sold at dearer levels to average between 143c and 173.4c/kg. 

Cow quality was plainer than last sale but all suitable grades sold to dearer levels. Well conditioned light cows averaged 176.2c while the plainer lines sold to 169.2c to average 157.3c/kg. Medium weights were well represented and averaged between 174.2c and 181.8c/kg thanks to some solid processor competition. Bulls sold at dearer levels with heavy weights reaching 178.2c/kg.

A reduced yarding was offered to all the regular buyers. As with other markets, competition was strong particularly on the better grown steers and cows. 

Light steers were in limited numbers as medium weights suited to the Korean market topped at 155.2c and others averaged 144c/kg. A large number of heavy steers and bullocks were penned with rates lifting up to 10c/kg. Heavy steers averaged 157.5c after selling to 165.2c as the bullocks averaged 160.2c/kg. Export heifers sold to only fair demand making to 130c/kg. 

Most of the cows were light and medium weights with medium weights improving up 14c/kg. Light D2s averaged 117.5c as the D3s averaged 126.8c/kg. Medium weight D3s, in largest number, averaged 132.2c after selling to 139.2c/kg.   Good heavy cows in limited supply sold to 142.2c/kg.

A reduced yarding of 3313 cattle were penned, 826 fewer than last sale.  Quality was very mixed – particularly in the prime section – with fewer heavy bullocks and steers and a wide variation in the quality if the 1,300 cows penned.  Some very good quality lines of young steers and heifers were presented in the store section.  Demand was subdued with one regular export processor continuing their absence in the market, another did not operate, with the remainder participating at reduced rates in line with recent grid adjustments.  One live exporter was active on suitable lines along with a southern feeder and local opportunity restockers. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Normanton, Croydon, Georgetown, Einasleigh, Mt Garnet, Greenvale, local and coastal areas. Prime categories further eased while lightweight young cattle averaged firm to slightly dearer.

Light vealer steers returning to the paddock sold to 628.2c, with a good sample averaging 582c to 613c/kg and suitably weaned steers above 200kg also returning to grass sold to 628.2c to average 501c to 579c/kg. Similar heifers to backgrounders made to 440.2c to average 436c/kg.  A mixed quality offering of yearling steers met limited demand, with all categories easier on last sale.  Steers above 280kg to feed sold to 460.2c to average 450c with average quality types returning to grass selling from 326.2c to 432/kg. The quality of yearling heifers improved on last sale and sold to strong demand.  Lightweight yearling heifers returning to the paddock sold to 418.2c to average 396c, while heifers above 280kg returning to grass for breeding sold to 404.2c to average 399c/kg.  Heifers above 330kg to feed reached 380.2c to average 350c and heifers for breeding made 426.2c to average 408c/kg. 

A reduced supply and lesser quality offering of grown steers met reduced demand - Steers above 400kg to feed sold to 430.2c to average 357c to 399c.  Suitable steers to live export made from 390c to 396.2c and a small sample to the trade sold to 390.2c to average 377c to 382c/kg.  A lesser quality small supply of grown heifers to the trade reached 360.2c to average 331c/kg.  Mixed quality heifers to feed sold to 378.2c to average 334c/kg.  Fewer numbers of heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter sold to 396.2c to average 376c to 395c/kg. 

An increased supply of cows attracted subdued demand reflecting the lesser quality than recent weeks and an easing in values. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors made to 286.2c to average 281c, with three score cows to processors reaching 338.2c multiple times to average 316c to 324c and prime heavyweight cows topped at 348.2c to average 340c/kg. A small line of PTIC cows sold from sold to 360.2c to average 353c/kg.
Heavy bulls to live export sold to 380.2c and bulls to feed destined for live export made to 352.2c to average 361c/kg. 

A small number of mixed quality cows and calves sold to $2,020/unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

A reduced yarding of 2,653 cattle were penned this week, 593 fewer than last sale. Some good lines of heavy grown steers, bullocks and prime cows were on offer, supported by some very good quality lines of young store steers and heifers. All regular buyers were in attendance, with one additional central feeder order increasing demand for suitable lines. Grown steers to feed and the trade were mostly firm, heavy bullocks increased 7c, grown heifers to the trade eased 10c and prime cows increased by 2c to 5c/kg. Cattle were drawn from Richmond, Einasleigh, Greenvale, Pentland, local and coastal areas.  

Very good quality steer calves sold to 510.2c averaging 489c and a large sample of similar bred vealer steers returning to grass reached 528.2c to average 493c/kg. Similar vealer heifers returning to the paddock made to 476.2c to average 440c/kg and heifers to the trade topped at 422.2c to average 403c/kg. Yearling steers above 330kg to feed sold to 436.2c to average 399c and restocker lines topped at 428.2c to average 410/kg. Yearling heifers above 330kg to feed reached 378.2c to average 355c/kg.

Heavy grown steers to the trade topped at 360.2c, while steers above 400kg to feed reached 362.2c to average 366c/kg. Grown heifers to the trade eased with best quality heifers selling to 330.2c to average 309c/kg and plainer types to feed averaged 305 to 309c/kg. An increased supply of heavy full mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 356.2c to average above 345c/kg. Fewer numbers of cows were presented with processor demand strong throughout.  Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 274.2c to average 266c and 3 score cows reached 293.2c to average 275c/kg. Prime heavy weight cows topped at 292,2c to average 291c/kg. Heavy bulls were well supplied with increased buyer activity pushing values to 356.2c with those to feed destined for live export averaging 328c to 346c/kg and bulls to processors averaged 278c/kg. Young males returning to grass sold to 496.2 to average 422c/kg. Several small lines of good quality cows and calves sold to $1,785/unit.

Market Reporter: Mick Kingham

A reduced yarding of 2,420 cattle were presented in Charters Towers, 165 fewer than last sale due to two live export orders in progress. Quality was very mixed with several northern lines of young males and bulls, however some very good small lines of prime cows and bullocks were on offer. The regular buyer panel were in attendance and operating at increased rates, particularly better bred heavier lines. Cows improved by 5c to 7c and heavy bullocks averaged up to 15c/kg higher than last sale, while good quality bulls to live export sold firm. Cattle were drawn from Burketown, Doomadgee, Palmerston, Richmond, Hughenden, local and coastal areas. 

A small number of steer calves returning to the paddock sold to 400.2c as did vealer steers to average 385c/kg. Vealer heifers to processors made to 374.2c to average 367c, while restocker lines reached 340.2c to average from 324c to 336c/kg. Heifers to feed reached 340.2c with most selling from 320c to 334c/kg.  Yearling steers above 330kg to live export sold to 358.2c, while well bred steers to feed mostly sold from 345c to 364c/kg. Grown steers to live export topped at 344.2c to average 338c, while processors paid to 344.2c to average 341c/kg. Grown heifers were of very mixed quality and weight, with heavy heifers to the trade selling to an isolated 322.2c, with the majority averaging 265c/kg. Grown heifers to restockers sold to 300.2c to average near 276c/kg.

Heavy bullocks to export slaughter topped at 360.2c, with most sales above 348c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 270.2c to average 253c and 3 score cows topped at 300.2c to average from 270c to 280c/kg. Prime heavy weight cows reached 307.2c for a single cow, with most selling from 288c to 295c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export reached 344.2c with better types regularly selling above 330c, with many plainer lesser quality pens selling from 270c to 298c/kg. Bulls 270 to 380kg to feed destined for live export sold to 348.2c to average 280c/kg. Small lines of cows and calves sold from $1,040 to 1,260/unit.

A reduced yarding of 1437 cattle were presented in Charters Towers this week, 126 fewer than last sale.  Quality was very good throughout with increased numbers of heavy prime cows and some well presented lines of younger store cattle.  The regular buyer panel saw the return of one major processor along with two southern backgrounder and feeder buyers, resulting in solid demand throughout the sale.  Cattle were mostly drawn from the local area and south to Belyando.  Most categories showed price improvements, with light calves improving by 30c, yearling steers and heifers increased by up to 30c and heavy cows lifted by 10-16c/kg.

Heifer calves to processors topped at 466.2c to average 458c and steer calves to restockers reached 496.2c to average 480c/kg.  Light vealer steers to restockers sold to 452.2c multiple times. A small sample of vealer heifers to processors reached 386c/kg. Yearling steers to feed topped at 424.2c to average from 397-405c/kg.  Increased numbers of yearling heifers returning to grass reached 388.2c to average 380c/kg.  

Limited numbers of grown steers to the trade sold to 344.2c, steers to southern backgrounders sold to 386.2c to average 325-377c and suitable steers to feed averaged 356-372c/kg.  A small sample of grown heifers to the trade sold from 246-328c/kg.  A single pen of bullocks to processors sold to 336.2c/kg.  Increased numbers of medium weight cows met very strong demand, with 2 score cows selling to 274.2c to average 266c and 3 scores topped at 280.2c to average 266-276c/kg.  Cows to restockers sold to 269.2c to average 248c/kg.  Heavy bulls to feed destined for live export reached 334.2c, with most sales from 310-324c/kg.

A reduced yarding of 1211 cattle were offered by Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents, 429 fewer than last sale.  Less than 50 prime cattle were penned, with the buying panel thin on the ground.  Only one processor was in attendance, along with two regular feeder buyers and several local and western restockers.  One large line was drawn from Normanton, with several lines of store steers and heifers from Einasleigh, Ayr, local and coastal areas.  

Young steers to restockers improved by 15c, while yearling steers returning to grass averaged 11c lower.  Lesser quality steers to feed eased by more than 20c/kg.  An improved quality offering of young heifers to restockers improved by as much as 30c, while yearling heifers to feed also improved in price.  A small number of grown steers to processors sold firm while limited numbers of prime cows averaged 6c higher than last sale.

Good quality light vealer steers returning to the paddock made up to 282c to average 264c, while heavier young steers above 280kg to restockers averaged near 268c/kg.  Lightweight yearling steers to restockers sold to 264c, averaging 257c and steers above 280kg averaged 247c/kg.  Young suitably weaned heifers sold to 180c multiple times.
