Yearling heifers to feed sold to 210c to average 207c/kg, with heifers above 330kg averaging 206c/kg.  One bullock sold for 270c and a small number of grown steers to slaughter sold for 240c/kg.  A mixed selection of heavy D muscled 3 score cows made to 191c to average 178c/kg.  Bulls to feed backgrounded for live export sold to 270c, while young males to restockers sold up to 262c to average 240c/kg.

A reduced yarding of 1,655 cattle was drawn by Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents, following a week's break due to insufficient numbers. The yarding was of very good quality despite coming to the close of the selling season. The yarding included some well finished cows and grown steers, supported by some very good lines of store cattle, albeit in many small lines which lifted by 2c to 8c/kg. One regular processor continued their recent absence, while one another did not operate. Recent hot weather did not deter the remainder of the buying gallery, with a live exporter, feeder buyer and several western restockers displaying very strong and spirited bidding for suitable cattle throughout the sale. Cattle were drawn from Einasleigh, Richmond, Hughenden, Greenvale, Ingham, Woodstock, local and coastal areas.

Some very good quality vealer steers sold very strongly to 442c, with most selling between 385c and 395c/kg. Yearling steers also were of very good quality and sold accordingly to a top of 317c to feed, while those returning to the paddock made to 330c, and a live exporter was very dominant on the suitable weight cattle throughout this segment of the sale, securing lines to 318c/kg. Vealer heifers were readily sought after and many restockers and backgrounders jostled for the available lines selling to 390c, with most sales around 360c/kg. Yearling heifers were of variable quality and weight with heifers to feed selling to 290c, averaging 259c, while those returning to paddock were generally lighter and sold to 312c/kg. 

Bullocks and grown steers increased in number and despite less processor interest, a live exporter assisted in increasing price for suitable types, with bullocks to slaughter selling to 278c, while those to live export sold to 279c/kg. Grown steers to feed sold to 294c, while those to live export reached 319c/kg. Heavy cows were sporadic but the better finished types were of very good weight, averaging 221c and selling to 240c/kg for heavy 3 score cows. 2 score cows sold to 234c, averaging 217c/kg. Restockers were active for lighter one and two score cows, with many sales around 20c, selling to 232c/kg. Bulls were of mixed quality and weight, with a live exporter very dominant on all descriptions. Heavy bulls to slaughter sold to 206c, while similar lines to live export sold to 234c/kg. Medium weight bulls destined for live export sold to 340c/kg. Young males returning to paddock sold to 402c/kg. One good line of young cows and calves sold to $1,220/unit.

A reduced yarding of 1,424 mixed quality cattle was drawn by Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, a reduction of 566 on last sale. Fewer numbers of well finished prime cattle were on offer, with many lines displaying considerable variation in weight and condition. Store cattle comprised of many small lines, with a large variation in quality attracting subdued demand. Only three regular processors were in attendance and operating at similar rates to last sale, while one local feeder buyer and some regular backgrounders and restockers rounded out a small gallery of buyers. Cattle were drawn from Croydon, Georgetown, Cloncurry, Richmond, Torrens Creek, Ingham, Belyando, local and coastal areas.

The absence of vealer steers and the very mixed quality of yearling steers attracted minimal interest with values easing accordingly. Heavy yearling steers to background destined for live export sold to 236c, with many easing by up to 20c/kg with quality a factor. A mixed offering of vealer heifers returning to grass sold to 208c multiple times, with most lesser quality lines selling from 120c to 156c/kg. Yearling heifers comprised of many small lines and one very good quality line of feeder weight heifers. Better types to backgrounders sod to 196c, while heavy yearling heifers to slaughter sold to 225c/kg.

Bullocks were generally lighter and plainer in condition than recent weeks.  Heavy 3 score bullocks to export slaughter sold to 247c, and averaged 3c lower at 246c/kg. Medium weight 3 score bullocks to processors sold to 249c to average 228c, with plainer types to feed selling to 196c to average 166c/kg. Grown steers to feed sold to 206c, while some good quality heavy steers to backgrounders sold to 230c/kg. Some isolated pens of heavy 3 score cows to slaughter sold firm on last sale to 191c to average 184c, with 4 score heavy cows selling to 196c to average 192c/kg. Single sales of extra heavy 3 score cows sold to 213c, to average 197c/kg. Medium weight 2 core cows to slaughter sold to 152c to average 106c/kg. Increased numbers of light conditioned cows to restockers eased by up to 20c, selling to 140c to average 99c/kg. The absence of live export activity saw heavy bulls ease across the offering. A small number of heavy bulls to slaughter sold to 244c, while many heavy bulls suitable for live export sold to backgrounders to 236c, with most sales from 220c to 228c/kg. Feeder weight bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 236c to average 201c, while better quality light males to backgrounders sold to 236c/kg. Light conditioned cows with young calves at foot sold for $460/unit.

A reduced yarding of 1,356 cattle were yarded by Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, with a mixed quality yarding dominated by good lines of prime cows, selling to a new saleyard record. All regular processors were in attendance and operating, however restocker competition for store cows was noticeably absent. Cattle were drawn from Richmond, Einasleigh, Forsayth, Tully, Ingham, Woodstock, Pentland, local and coastal areas.

Following a large store yarding the previous week, with a limited buyer panel, values for vealer steers decreased significantly for the mixed quality on offer, selling to 321.2c/kg.  Yearling steers were also of mixed quality selling to 319.2c/kg. Vealer heifers were of mixed quality, however sold to increased rates with strong competition throughout the offering, selling to 306.2c/kg.  A large line of northern yearling heifers sold to 273.2c, with the best line selling to 304.2c/kg.

Bullocks were of mixed quality and age selling to 307.2c, while grown steers sold to 286.2c/kg to feeder buyers destined for live export. Another large yarding of prime cows sold to a new saleyard record of 280.2c for heavy 3 score cows, for an increased average of 263.7c/kg.  Heavy 2 score cows sold to 248.2c, to average 237.9c/kg. Lighter 2 score cows sold to limited competition to average 189.8c/kg.  Heavy heifers to slaughter sold to 255.2c, while feeder types sold to 287.2c/kg. Heavy bulls also firmed, with bulls to slaughter selling to a top of 271.2c/kg.  Heavy young bulls returning to paddock for breeding sold to 379.2c, while heavy bulls destined for live export sold to 261.2c/kg. A single line of cows and calves sold to $1,090/unit.

A reduced yarding of 1,231 mixed quality cattle were yarded by Charters Towers Combined Agents this week, with limited lines of good quality cows and store cattle. All regular processors were in attendance and active throughout the sale, along with some additional store buyers generating strong competition for store lines. Cattle were drawn from Burketown, Richmond, Einasleigh, Ingham, Ayr, Woodstock, local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers were of mixed quality, with restockers very competitive on better quality types, selling to 337.2c/kg. Yearling steers were in short supply, with quality varying considerably. A very good line of yearling steers sold to 308.2c/kg. Vealer heifers were in small numbers and quality was mixed, with strong competition for the better lines, which sold to 276.2c and averaged lower at 223.4c/kg. Yearling heifers also sold generally lower than previous sale due to the quality on offer, selling to 266.2c/kg for the limited numbers available. 

A very good line of grown heifers sold to 247.2c/kg to a central feeder buyer. Bullocks were very mixed in quality, with live export dominating the buyer gallery to secure for a pending shipment. The very few good 3 score bullocks on offer sold to 293.2c, while many smaller, lighter bullocks sold between 240c and 255c/kg. Cows were again in good supply, with quality more variable than recent weeks, with more northern drafts being offered. A very good draft of heavy 3 score cows sold to a stronger market, with all processors active. The best cows sold to 252.2c, averaging 234.8c/kg. A larger consignment of heavy 2 score cows also sold to a dearer market, topping at 238.2c, while lighter 2 score cows to restockers sold to 223.2c, to average 178.4c/kg. Bulls were in good supply and sold to a dearer market with the presence of a live export buyer. Heavy 3 score bulls to processors sold to 231.2c, while some very good quality aged bulls to restockers for breeding sold to 303.2c/kg.  Bulls to live export sold to 270.2c, to average 245.3c/kg. A small number of cows and calves were on offer, selling to $1,300, with lesser quality types selling to $1,080/unit.

A reduced yarding of 1,219 head of plainer cattle showing seasonal effects were drawn by Charters Towers Combined Agents this week, with limited lines of finished cattle presented. Cattle were drawn from Burketown, Einasleigh, Belyando, Woodstock, Ayr, local and coastal areas. Live export and restocker buyers were active across all lines of young cattle.

Restocker and live exporter competition saw yearling steers sell to 279.2c/kg. Yearling heifers sold to 245.2c/kg, with many being purchased to feed for live export.  

A limited number of 4 score cows were presented, selling at reduced rates to northern processors, to top of 255.2c/kg, with one southern processor exiting from the market. A considerable number of 1 and 2 score cows sold from 180c to 200c/kg. Minimal numbers of 3 and 4 score bullocks sold to 285.2c/kg, with feeder buyers operating on the lighter end for live export in the coming weeks. A good selection of bulls sold to spirited bidding to a top of 253.2c/kg. A limited number of fair quality cows and calves were yarded, selling to $690/unit.

A reduced yarding of 1,130 mostly prime cattle were penned in Charters Towers, 1,480 fewer than last sale, due to the store sale on Friday. The buyer panel was much reduced, with several restockers, feeders and processors absent, reducing overall demand. Quality was very mixed, with many small lines showing the effects of the lengthening dry season. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Richmond, Greenvale, Ayr, local and coastal areas.

Young mixed sex calves were in short supply and reflected quality related price changes, the processor calves averaged 374c/kg. Vealer steers to restockers sold to limited demand, topping at 394c to average 351c/kg. Vealer heifers to processors sold to 368c, most selling from 340c to 356c/kg. Mixed quality small lines of yearling steers above 280kg to feed sold to 374c to average from 355c to 370c/kg. Yearling heifers above 280kg to feed reached 344c to average from 317c to 332c/kg. Grown steers to feed made to 360c to average from 343c to 358c/kg. Single grown heifers to processors made to 292c with better quality types selling above 266c/kg.

The supply of cows was much reduced on recent months, with subdued demand reflective of animal weight. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 246c to average 236c, while 3 scores reached a top of 276c to average from 260c to 269c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export topped at 348c, averaging from 303c to 340c, while those to background feed destined for live export sold to 302c to average 270c/kg.

The final store sale of 2020 will be held on Friday 4th December with 2,900 head booked. The final prime and store sale is booked for Wednesday the 9th December 2020.

A reduced yarding of 1,040 cattle were drawn by Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents, with another good quality selection of prime cattle and some well grown store cattle.  The three major processors were all in attendance and operating with the market firm to slightly cheaper than the last sale.  Cattle were drawn from Einasleigh, Hughenden, Malanda, Belyando, local and coastal areas. The overnight reduction in live export values saw reduced rates for all suitable lines, despite active restocker competition.

Vealer steers were few in number and sold to lower rates topping at 292.2c/kg.  A good line of yearling steers attracted spirited bidding, selling to 266.2c/kg, with most lines 226-260c/kg. Reduced numbers of heifers sold to reduced rates with less buyer interest than previous weeks. Vealer heifers sold to 230.2 c/kg, whilst some very good lines of yearling heifers sold to 234.2c/kg.

Bullocks were fewer in number this week and sold to slightly reduced rates, with one feeder buyer in attendance for suitable live export types.  3 score bullocks sold to 253.2c/kg, while 2 score bullocks sold to 226.2c/kg. Prime heifers were in good supply this week, selling to 224.2c/kg.  Heavy 3 score cows sold to 211.2c/kg, while medium weight 2 score cows sold in line with last week’s rates, topping at 197.2c/kg. The few bulls penned sold to 220.2 for heavy slaughter types, while younger bulls suitable for live export sold to 224.2c/kg. A single cow and calf sold for $810/unit.

A reduced offering was drawn from the usual supply area including northern and coastal regions. Overall quality was plainer than last sale, as is the case across much of the state this week. Prices reflected the quality by easing for most grades. The exceptions were limited pens of well finished stock that sold to good returns under strong competition from all the usual buyers. 

Lightweight grown steers slipped to range from 147.2c to 163.2c with plainer types averaging 133.7c/kg. The limited amount of well finished medium weights reached 193.2c with most sales at 169.8c/kg. Heifers eased to range from 129.2c to 143.2c/kg. 

Cow demand eased for light cows to average 139.5c with plainer pens averaging 121.6c/kg. Medium weight D3s ranged from 127.2c to 164.2c with occasional heavy cow sales reaching 166.2c/kg. Bull competition was mixed for the limited number on offer.

A recent easing of numbers saw Charters Towers return to a combined Prime/Store sale with 2,979 cattle presented.  With a rain event imminent, cows once again made up more than 50% of numbers, with quality highly variable. Some excellent lines of well finished cows and bullocks were present combined with some poorly bred plainer types. All regular buyers including southern orders were present and operating with strong demand on suitable lines. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Normanton, Cape York, Greenvale, Ingham, Ayr, Ravenswood, local and coastal areas.

Young male calves sold to strong restocker and backgrounder demand, reaching 358.2c for pens less than 200kg, with a large northern line averaging above 332c/kg. Limited numbers of vealer steers sold to mixed demand, with most selling from 290c to 328c/kg to restockers and feed. Vealer heifers to restockers made to 314c to average 288c and those to feed averaged near 270c/kg.  

Yearling steers above 280kg to feed sold to 330.2c to average 299c, with steers above 330kg averaging 318c with a top of 338.2c/kg. Well grown yearling heifers to feed sold to 290.2c to average 284c, with a large sample of lesser quality pens averaging from 267c to 279c/kg. Increased numbers of grown steers to feed sold to 313c to average above 300c for better bred lines, with suitable trade types reaching 325c/kg. Grown heifers of mixed quality sold firm to 10c/kg easier. Well finished good quality heifers to the trade topped at 312.2c to average 304c and a large sample of lesser yielding types averaged 272c/kg.

Some good pens of heavy export bullocks sold to strong demand, reaching 330.2c to average 325c, with lesser yielding bullocks averaging near 287c/kg.  Medium weight 2 score cows sold to 250.2c to average 240c and heavy 3 score cows made to 260.2c to average 246c/kg. Heavy weight 4 score cows reached 264c to average 263c, while a pen of 5 score cows weighing 724kg made 272.2c/kg. Increased numbers of 2 score cows less than 400kg averaged 205c/kg.

Heavy bulls to live export sold to 296.2c to average 284c, with feeder weights reaching 299c to average 279c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors sold to 304c to average 290c/kg. Small lines of average quality cows and calves sold from $790 to 950/unit.

A prime only sale saw numbers ease by 998 for a yarding of 1788 cattle. Quality was particularly good, featuring some large lines of well finished local steers and cows. One major export processor was absent with a reduced buyer panel showing intermittent demand. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Einasleigh, Pentland, Hervey’s Range, local and coastal areas. Most categories averaged 5c to 45c lower apart from heavy bulls increasing 5c to 13c/kg.

Two large lines of grown steers met strong processor demand. Steers above 400kg to feed sold to 428.2c to average 416c with trade types averaging 420c/kg. A good sample of heavy steers above 500kg to processors sold to 422.2c to average 407c/kg. Grown heifers to the trade reached 388.2c to average 364c and heifers to feed averaged 362c/kg. A good sample of heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 424.2c to average 418c/kg. 

Mixed demand for cows resulted in a general easing in price. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 320.2to average 315c, 3 scores reached 358.2c multiple times to average 341c and prime heavyweight cows topped at 362.2c to average 354c/kg. Heavy bulls to feed destined for live export made to 370.2c to average 359c/kg. Light conditioned PTIC cows sold from sold from 280c to 340c/kg. Heavy bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 350.2c to average 341c to 344c/kg. 

A store sale scheduled for Friday has 4,000 cattle booked

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

A prime only sale resulted in 1,922 cattle penned this week, up 140 head on comparative sale a fortnight ago. Quality was very mixed, with a good line of grown steers, however there were fewer lines of heavy prime cows and bullocks. The supply of lesser quality lines of northern pastoral continued, comprising of increased numbers of bulls, making up nearly 20% of the yarding! One southern processor was absent, while the regular gallery operated at firmer rates on last sale, particularly for better quality lines. There was no live export participation. Grown steers improved by 12c to 25c, grown heifers were firm, bullocks improved more than 20c, medium weight cows lifted 8c to 20c and heavy bulls averaged up to 12c/kg higher. Cattle were drawn from Camooweal, Mt Isa, Normanton, Croydon, Georgetown, Pentland, local and coastal areas.  

A small sample of yearling steers above 330kg to feed reached 420c to average 416c/kg. Yearling heifers above 330kg to feed averaged 368c/kg. Good lines of grown steers were on offer selling to increased rates, with those above 400kg to feed selling to 428c to average 393c/kg. Medium weight steers to the trade sold to 410c, averaging 400c, while heavy steers topped at 422c to average 416c/kg. Single sales of grown heifers to the trade topped at 392c, with the majority averaging 323c and heifers to feed sold to 350c to average 313c/kg.

A small sample of heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 404c, to average 393c/kg. A reduced offering of cows once again met strong demand. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 332c to average 319c, while 3 scores reached 350c to average 334c/kg. A small sample of prime heavy weight cows topped at 354c to average 351c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors sold to 334c to average from 310c to 325c/kg. Males above 300kg to backgrounders sold to 456c to average 341c, while those to feed averaged 311c/kg.

A store sale to be held on Friday 1st October has 4,000 cattle booked.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

A prime only sale attracted 1328 cattle with 4,700 cattle booked for a store sale on Friday. More than half of the yarding comprised of cows, which were of lesser quality and condition than previous weeks. Quality of bullocks and heifers and bulls were mostly good. All regular processors were in attendance, but operating selectively, supported by one live exporter and regular, feeders, backgrounders and restockers. Buyer demand was lacklustre on some lines, with quality a factor. Values for bullocks and steers to processors lifted by up to 30c, heifers improved 8c to 15c, while cows to processors eased by 11c to 15c/kg. Cattle were drawn from Pentland, Georgetown, Ingham, Belyando, local and coastal areas. 

Small lines of vealers and yearlings were insufficient to reliably quote. Good quality grown steers above 400kg to feed sold to 460.2c to average 436c to 456c, with suitable steers to live export reaching 426.2c to average 421c/kg. A good sample of steers above 500kg to the trade reached 438.2c to average 434c to 436c and suitable steers to live export topped at 438.2c to average 430c to 438c/kg. A good selection of grown heifers to backgrounders sold to 400.2c to average 399c and heifers to the trade reached 396.2c/kg to average same. A small number of mixed quality heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 432.2c to average 423c to 428c/kg. 

Some small lines of well finished cows met mixed demand with medium weight 3 score cows to processors reaching 362.2c to average 356c and prime heavyweights topped at 370.2c to average 360c to 367c/kg. A large sample of cows to opportunity restockers sold to 396.2c to average 366c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export sold to 410.2c to average 386c to 398c/kg.  

A small number of good quality cows and calves sold for $2,020/unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

A prime only sale attracted 1,838 cattle, 602 fewer than last sale. Quality continues to be mixed with several good quality lines of heavy bullocks and cows penned, however there were increased numbers cows and bulls of lesser quality and weight. One southern processor was absent, with the regular buyer panel operating at reduced rates throughout.  Cattle were drawn from Normanton, Julia Ck, Mt Garnet, Belyando, local and coastal areas.

Grown steers to feed and the trade were mostly firm, heifers eased up to 30c, bullocks were firm to 6c easier, heavy cows fell 12c to 17c and bulls averaged 9c less.
Grown steers above 400kg to feed sold to 414.2c to average 398c to 408c and a small sample of steers suitable to the trade topped at 388.2c to average 376c/kg. Reduced numbers of grown heifers to feed sold to 358.2c multiple times to average 354c/kg.  

Several lines of well finished heavy bullocks to export slaughter averaged from 377c to 388c/kg, reaching a top of 398c. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 336.2c to average 308c and 3 scores made to 348.2c to average 327c/kg. A good sample of prime heavyweight 3 and 4 score cows topped at 354.2c to average 348c/kg.  Heavy bulls to processors sold to 348.2 c to average from 337c/kg.

A store sale scheduled for Friday has 3,500 head booked.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

A prime only sale attracted 1,593 cattle, 340 more than the comparable sale a fortnight ago. More than 60% of the yarding comprised of cows. Quality was very mixed with a large offering of northern pastoral cattle and many lines showing effects of the lengthening dry season. However, some good quality local lines of well finished cattle were on offer. The regular buyer panel was in attendance supported by one additional southern processor and operated at stronger rates to last sale. Grown steers and heifers sold firm with quality related prices movements, bullocks increased 4c, while heavy cows lifted 5c/kg and bulls sold firm. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Normanton, Julia Ck, Richmond, Bowen, local and coastal areas.  

There were insufficient yearling steers to reliably quote. A large single vendor line of yearling heifers above 330kg to feed topped at 428c to average 411c and heavy heifers above 400kg to feed reached 408c/kg. Grown steers consisted of many small lines quality and met strong demand. Good quality steers above 400kg to feed sold for 413c and similar steers to the trade topped at 415c to average 411c/kg. Heavy weights reached a top of 420c/kg to average the same. A small sample of good quality heavy grown heifers to the trade sold to 394c to average 368c/kg. 

A reduced supply of heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 426c, to average between 416c and 420c/kg. Processor demand for cows continues to be very strong. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 356c to average 345c and 3 scores reached 372c to average from 357c to 362c/kg. A small number of prime heavy weight cows topped at 374c to average 370c/kg. Increased numbers of light conditioned cows to restockers sold to 334c to average from 305c to 323c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors sold to 356c to average from 336c to 350c/kg. 

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

A prime only sale attracted 1,171 mixed quality cattle this week. A store sale scheduled for Friday has 3,400 cattle booked. A good supply of cows continued with some good lines of heavy western cows along with some average quality northern cows and increased numbers of heavy bulls. Two regular processors were in attendance and operating along with one southern processor with demand very subdued on most pens. One major feeder buyer was absent, replaced by two opportunity feeders, with minimal restocker activity. Cattle were drawn from Burketown to Mt Isa, east to Georgetown and south to Belyando and the local area.

There were insufficient yearling cattle to reliably quote. Grown steers to feed improved 3c to 19c, trade steers eased 17c, trade heifers eased 30c to 40c, heavy bullocks fell 22c/kg. Heavy cows averaged mostly firm to 2c dearer and bulls to feed closed firm to 30c/kg higher.

Yearling heifers above 330kg to feed sold to 318.2c to average 307c/kg. Good quality grown steers above 400kg to feed sold to 334.2c to average 314c/kg, with lesser types averaging 294c/kg. A good sample to the trade reached 306.2c to average 297c to 302c/kg. Very good heavy grown heifers to the trade averaged 302c/kg topping at 310.2c, while good quality heifers to feed sold to 306.2c multiple times to average 284c to 303c/kg.

A good sample of heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter made to 300.2c to average from 268c to 291c/kg. Another good supply of cows continued to meet selective processor demand particularly the heavier pens. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors averaged 223c/kg selling to 265.2c and a large sample of 3 score cows to processors topped at 286.2c to average 258c to 277c/kg. Prime heavy weight 3 and 4 score cows reached 298.2c to average 279c/kg. Heavy bulls received stronger demand throughout topping at 323.2c to average from 275c to 325c/kg. 

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

A postponed Combined Prime & Store Sale due to wet weather attracted 2198 cattle 320 more than last Wednesday’s regular sale. Significant rain across much of the north restricted numbers, however producers have found significant enthusiasm with the change of season. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Normanton, Georgetown, Mt Garnet, local and coastal areas. Quality was mixed with 680 prime cattle dominated by good conditioned cows, while store cattle were of very good quality consisting of two large northern lines.

Buyer attendance was not as good as previous weeks with one processor in attendance but not operating however, competition was strong for the better quality lines of young steers and heifers from southern and central restockers. Young steers lifted 50c, yearling heifers improved 25c and heavy cows to processors increased by 35c/kg.

A sample of very good quality weaned steers above 200kg to southern restockers toped at 700.2c to average 654c/kg while the female portion sold to 600.2c to average same. Yearling steers above 280kg to backgrounders reached 548.2c to average 513c/kg. Light yearling heifers to feed sold to 450.2c to average 408c and a good sample of yearling heifers above 280kg to feed sold to 430.2c to average 409c/kg. Limited numbers of grown steers under 400kg to feed sold to 450.2c to average 399c to 442c/kg. Grown heifers to feed reached 430.2c to average near 400c/kg. There were insufficient bullocks to reliably quote.

Medium weight 3 score cows to processors sold to 370.2c to average 360c and prime heavyweights topped at 379.2c to average 376c/kg. A limited number of heavy bulls to feed destined for live export topped at 370.2c to average above 369c/kg. A large sample of young males returning to grass sold to 660.2c to averaged 631c/kg.

Mixed ages store conditioned cows with 2-7mth calves at foot sold for $1,900/unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

A much smaller yarding sold to most of the usual buyers. Quality was fair and values were mostly dearer than last weeks rates. The majority of the yarding was females and there was only a handful of steers and bulls penned. 

Most of the medium weight steers sold 5c dearer and averaged 145.1c after they reached 152.2c/kg.  Heavy steers were slightly dearer after they topped at 154.2c/kg.

There were a large number of heifers considering the size of the yarding and they reached 135.2c to average 13c dearer at 127.7c/kg. Light weight cows were dearer and averaged 110.3c while the most were medium weights that sold 2c dearer to average 123c/kg. Heavy cows reached 134.2c to average just below 130c/kg. 

A small number of bulls topped at 120c/kg.

A much smaller yarding sold to a regular field of buyers, although not all were active. Numbers eased following storms in the area, as it appears producers are holding onto some stock. Steers received mixed results, while values eased dramatically in the cow and bull market, although quality was a major factor.

Steers were of poorer quality and were mainly light and medium weights. Lightweight D2s were 2c dearer averaging 170.5c after topping at 185.2c/kg. Medium weight D2s were slight cheaper reaching 190.2c, while D3s sold to 206.2 with most around the 191c/kg mark. Heavy weight steers sold to 211.2c and averaged 207.8c/kg.

A limited number of heifers realised losses from 7c to 21c and D3s averaged 169c/kg. The cow market that was predominantly lightweights eased by 16c to 38c/kg. The D2 lightweights averaged 133.3c after reaching 149.2c/kg. The better quality cows sold on firm rates which saw medium weight D3s average 189.6c after selling to 202.4c/kg.

Bulls also lost value, light weights were 27c cheaper averaging 127c/kg. The medium weights were back by 26c averaging 143.1c with top sales reaching 174.2c/kg. Heavyweights were slightly dearer selling to 200.2c/kg.

A much smaller poorer quality yarding sold to reduced competition with only a limited number of processors operating and most purchases were made by a handful of works. Storm activity has not assisted stock as yet and the majority of the yarding were in 2 score condition. 

There were a small number of steers available and Korean weight D3s were the only grade with sufficient numbers to quote. Values were back for these and after topping at 175.2c averaged 170.4c/kg.

The female component of the sale saw some values increase. Light D2 heifers were 6c dearer averaging 140.2c/kg. Cows were in the greatest supply and the lighter and D2 descriptions sold on a dearer trend. Close to 100 Light D2s averaged 135.9c and reached 146.2c/kg. Medium weight D3s lost ground and averaged 148.4c after selling to a top of 150.2c/kg. 

A limited number of bulls saw lightweights cheaper and after reaching a top price of 121.2c averaged 113.9c/kg.

A much reduced yarding off 633 mixed quality cattle were drawn at Charters Towers this week, with strong competition from restockers throughout the sale as a result of recent isolated storms across the north. Processors were all in attendance, however were selective on cattle suitable for slaughter. Cattle were drawn from Hughenden, Einasleigh, Ingham, Ayr, Woodstock and local and coastal areas. 

Vealer heifers were keenly sought by restockers selling to 286.2c/kg, with a lift in values throughout the offering. A limited number of vealer steers sold to stronger rates on the previous sale, with restockers again active on all lines, topping at 300.2c/kg. Light calves sold to 298.2c/kg. 
 
The limited number of 3 score bullocks sold to 287.2c/kg. A small number of 3 score cows sold strongly to 267.2 c/kg and 2 score cows to 245.2c/kg. Bulls were variable in condition and sold to 268.2c/kg for lighter weights, with heavier bulls selling to 239.2c/kg. 

Very few cow and calves were presented and sold they to $1060/unit.

A much larger yarding was offered to the regular field of buyers. The large numbers saw cows in the majority and some reports suggested that the influx was driven by the cheaper markets earlier in the week. Quality was of the same standard as the previous sale and the lesser market rate was mainly associated with increased supply and overall state trend. Further rain would be welcomed to ensure sufficient amounts have been received for the upcoming dry season. 

Light steers lost substantial ground and averaged 127.5c after they reached 140c/kg. Close to 100 medium weights made to 170.2c and averaged 7c cheaper at 160.8c/kg. Heavy steers followed a similar trend and reached 172.2c to average 168.4c/kg. 

Grown heifers faired the best in the cheaper market realising a 6c loss to average 153.5c/kg. There was over 200 light C2 cows that lost 21c and averaged 109.5c/kg. The very poorer quality stock averaged 98.5c while the better types saw most sales around 125.2c/kg. Medium weights were in similar numbers and lost the most ground, which saw 155 D3s averaged 128.8c after they reached 138.2c/kg.

The bull market continued the cheaper trend and most averaged around 120c/kg.

A much larger yarding sold to strong and healthy competition. Rain fell throughout the sale and some areas in the district have received up to 350mm. All the regular meat works purchased stock and values increased from 9c to 14c/kg. The steer market saw a greater number of good quality descriptions available while it appeared that there was a more even line up of cows available. 

Medium weight steers sold 11c dearer and over 100 head averaged 154.3c after they reached 166.2c/kg. Heavy weights averaged 13c dearer at 159c and they also topped at 166.2c/kg. Bullocks sold to 174.2c/kg to return up to $1,184/head. 

Heifers sold on a mainly dearer trend and averages were around 142c to 143c/kg. The cow market realised gains of up to 9c/kg. Light cows faired the best and averaged 115.2c after reaching close to 140c/kg. Medium weights sold 3c dearer and averaged close to 124c after they topped at 134.2c/kg. 

Bulls realised mixed results and heavy weights average 135c/kg.

A much larger yarding of export cattle was offered at Charters Towers with values remaining firm to dearer for most descriptions. 

In the light weight steers, D3s sold from 140.2c to 141.2c/kg. The heavier steers above 500kg managed to average above 150c, the only grade that was not able to do this were the D3s, which still sold to 149.5c/kg. 

With only light heifers available, a rise of 11c was recorded for the D3s and D4s to average 132.9c and 144.5c/kg respectively. The light weight D3 cows saw a loss of 9c to average 116.4c/kg with all other grades remaining firm. One heavy D4 cow sold to 158.2c to return over $900/head.

The medium weight bulls saw substantial rises of more than 10c to average 136.3c after reaching a top of 155.2c/kg.

A much larger yarding of 1,597 cattle was drawn by Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, an increase of 1,057 head, featuring a very good line of full mouthed heavy bullocks, supported by several good lines of cows and heavy grown heifers, along with some high quality northern bred weaner steers. All regular processors were in attendance and operating at more enthusiastic rates than previous week's, supported by one local feeder buyer, one live exporter and some opportunity restockers throughout the sale. Cattle were drawn from Burketown, Richmond, Hughenden, Guru, local and coastal areas.

Increased numbers of vealer steers were generally suitably weaned types of very good quality, selling to increased rates, with a large sample of heavier vealers lifting by 10c, making to 280c to average 272c, with lighter types to 300c to average 279c/kg. Yearling steers were of mixed quality and the variation of the smaller lines was not a good indicator of the market. Medium weight steers to restockers sold to 258c averaging 250c, while medium weights to feed sold to 234c for better types and light yearling steers returning to grass sold to 269c to average 256/kg. Only a small number of vealer heifers were on offer, with no solid trends for the mixed quality lines. Suitably weaned heifers calves sold for 216c, with some very good quality crossbred vealer heifers returning to the paddock selling to 220c/kg. Yearling heifers consisted of many individual sales from 170c to 180c, topping at 188c/kg.

A large line of good quality full mouthed heavy bullocks, was the highlight of the sale, with those above 540kg easing 3c to average 247c, topping at 254c, while those above 470kg sold to 249c to average 244c/kg. Grown steers were very mixed with heavy steers to feed selling to 237c to average 231c, with 3 score types to feed selling to 240c/kg. A few grown steers to slaughter made to 243c/kg. Heavy cows values were more variable than recent weeks, with extra heavy 3 score cows easing 5c to average 200c, topping at 212c, with 4 scores increasing by more than 20c with a top of 219c/kg. Heavy 3 score cows improved by 2c, topping at 216c to average 191c, with D muscle types to 192c to average 184c/kg. Heavy D2 cows increased by more than 30c for a large sample to average 169c/kg. A small number of light cows to restockers sold to 127c/kg. Larger numbers of grown heifers were generally well finished and the improved weights saw improved demand topping at 230c to average 210c/kg. Heavy bulls continued recent strong demand led by live exporters, with heavy bulls making 272c, with similar bulls to feed destined for live export selling to 279c, to average 260c/kg. A larger offering of young males improved by more than 30c, with strong restocker interest pushing values to 266c to average 261c/kg. A good offering of cows and calves sold to $1,240/unit.

A mixed yarding of 1,385 cattle, 222 fewer than previous sale for Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, dominated by a large number of plainer cattle showing the effects of the season and some good lines of young cattle meeting very strong demand. One regular processor and feeder buyer were absent this week with all others operating on lower prices than previous weeks, while one live exporter and a local feeder buyer along with restockers provided very strong demand throughout the store section. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Normanton, Croydon, Richmond, Pentland, Tully, Ingham, Townsville, local and coastal areas.

A similar number of vealer steers sold firm on last sale with some very good quality small lines reaching 340c to average 324c/kg. One line of heavier vealer steer to restockers sold for 312c/kg. Yearling steers were more variable in quality and weight with prices increasing by 2c to 16c, driven by live export demand with light feeder steers making 286c and heavy feeder steers 299c/kg. Light yearling steers to restockers sold to 310c, to average 305, while heavier steers 330-400kg also reached 310c, averaging 287c and heavy backgrounder steers sold to 269c/kg. Increased numbers of vealer heifers in very good condition- mostly freshly weaned- sold mainly to restockers, reaching 283c to average 278c, while lighter muscled heifers reached 285c to average 275c/kg. A small number to feed sold to 240c/kg. A greater supply of yearling heifers was attractive to many buyers, with light feeder heifers to live export topping at 276c and averaging 258c/kg. Heavy feeder heifers made 282c, to average 274c. Heifers to feed sold to 252c to average 241c/kg, while a small number above 330kg returning to grass topped at 264c, to average 255c/kg. Some good lines of grown heifers to restockers sold to 247c, with plainer heifers to feed 232c/kg. A small number of heavy heifers to live export made 251c/kg. Bullocks were generally much plainer across the offering, with the odd pen of well finished 3 score bullocks selling to 256/kg. Restockers were very active securing plainer types to 250c, with most sales from 233c to 247c, with heavy plain types making 233c/kg. Heavy grown steers to slaughter made 262c, averaging 247c, while plainer types returning to grass sold to 261c/kg.

A mixed offering of cows saw heavy cows firm on last sale with heavy 3 score cows to slaughter topping at 209c, averaging up 1c to 206c, with D muscled heavy cows easing 8c, to average 196c/kg. D muscled 2 score cows sold to 195c, to average 190c/kg. Restockers secured young store cows to 192c, and forward store cows reached 189c to average 158c, with very light secondary store type cows selling to 145c/kg. A mixed selection of bulls eased on last sale with heavy bulls to slaughter topping at 237c, mostly were from 226c to 234c, while heavy bulls to feed, destined for live export, sold to 246c/kg. Live exporters secured feeder weight bulls to 289c, while medium weight bulls to feed destined for live export topped at 270c/kg. Several small lines of cows and calves sold to $1,120/unit.

A mixed quality yarding of 948 cattle were presented in Charters Towers, 990 head fewer than last week. Several good lines of heavy prime cows were penned along with some small lines of very good quality young steers. The regular processors and one live exporter operated at improved rates for better quality lines, along with opportunity local restockers and backgrounders, however no regular feeder buyers were in attendance. Cattle were drawn from Normanton, Julia Ck, Prairie, Bowen, Collinsville, local and coastal areas.  

Young steer calves increased by more than 20c and a large sample of vealer steers improved by 4c/kg. There were insufficient yearling steers and heifers to reliably quote, with most individual lines in line with recent sales. Young steer calves sold to 304c to average 265c, with heifer calves made a top of 224c/kg for a small sample. Vealer steers sold to 296c to average 274c, with vealer heifers selling to 211c/kg to average the same. A small number of yearling heifers above 330kg returning to grass made 234c/kg.

Grown steers sold firm to 4c/kg dearer and heavy bullocks sold to similar rates on last sale. Medium weight 2 score cows to slaughter eased by 13c, however heavy 3 score cows improved by 7c to 11c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export eased by 7c to 15c/kg. Grown steers to slaughter sold to 307c, with most sales making from 281c to 289c and heavy bullocks to export slaughter made to 295c, with most sales making from 281c to 288c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows sold to 170c, to average 135c, with light cows to restockers making to 110c, to average 105c/kg. Heavy 3 score cows sold to a season high of 239c, to average 225c and extra heavy cows averaged 237c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export sold to 270c, with similar types to feed destined for live export making to 273c/kg. Extra heavy bulls to slaughter sold for 274c/kg.

A mixed quality yarding of 450 cattle were drawn by Charters Towers Combined Agents this week, with strong competition throughout the sale. Consignments came from Mt Garnet, Greenvale, Tully, Home hill, along with local and coastal areas. All meatworks buyers were present and active for suitable lines, with restockers, backgrounders and a central feeder buyer active throughout the sale. A very good line of prime cows met strong demand from processors, and were supported by a number of small pens in good condition despite the light season being experienced in the region.  Limited store lines were on offer, with values easing compared to last sale.    

Yearling steers were of mixed quality, with a number of small lines penned, selling to 336c/kg.  Vealer steers topped at 352c/kg for a limited offering to restockers and feeder buyers.  Yearling heifers sold to strong competition to restockers for a top of 336c/kg.

The good offering of 3 score cows sold to higher rates, topping at 256c on several occasions, with lighter condition 2 score cows selling to 225c/kg.  The small number of bulls on offer sold to 240c/kg. Some well-presented pens of cows and calves sold from $830, to a top of $920/head.

A lift in the supply of cattle by 595 head saw 1,322 cattle in Charters Towers this week, featuring some very good lines of prime cows, with most categories increasing in price. Cattle were drawn from far northern and western areas, supported by several small local lines. All regular processors operated at increased rates, particularly for heavier lines, supported by one live exporter and several opportunity restockers and backgrounders. Young steer calves increased by 2c and vealer steers lifted by more than 10c/kg. Vealer heifers increased by more than 30c and yearling heifers to the trade eased by 5c/kg. Heavy bullocks to export slaughter increased by up to 5c and heavy cows to processors improved by 2c to 9c/kg. Heavy bulls to slaughter eased by 5c/kg in line with quality.

Steer calves returning to grass topped at 322c to average 291c, with good quality vealer steers to restockers selling to 309c to average more than 291c and heavier types averaged 286c/kg. Better quality vealer heifers returning to the paddock sold to 240c to average 235c, with more lesser quality lines averaging 228c/kg. Limited numbers of good quality yearling steers predominately sold to live export, selling for 272c and small lines of steers returning to grass sold to 278c, to average 262c/kg. Good quality heavy yearling heifers above 400kg to the trade topped at 289c to average 284c/kg. 

Grown steers to processors sold to 329c for the small number on offer. Heavy export 3 score bullocks sold to 331c to average 324c and 2 score bullocks sold to 319c to average 295c/kg. Very good quality heavy 3 score cows reached 258c to average 248c and heavy 3 score D muscled cows made to 243c to average 233c/kg. Extra heavy cows topped at 260c to average nearly 259c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors sold to 320c to average above 310c, with many lesser quality types selling from 270c to 294c/kg. Increased numbers of good quality cows and calves sold to $980/unit.

A lift in numbers by 74 head to 2,728 cattle were drawn by Charters Towers Combined Agents this week with the quality fair to good, including an increased number of cattle in store condition. One regular processor was absent again this week, however the processors in attendance were all operating including one live exporter and two regular feeder buyers. Cattle were drawn from Doomadgee, Burketown, Mt Isa, Richmond, Croydon, Einasleigh, Mt Garnet, Ingham, Woodstock, local and coastal areas.

An increase in the number of vealer heifers saw increased values for better quality and conditioned types, with one outstanding line of heifers selling to restockers a top of 382.2c/kg. Yearling heifers were variable in quality and sold strongly to both restockers and feeder buyers, with heifers to restockers selling to 282.2c, while heifers to feed sold to 334.2c/kg. Vealer steers were of very mixed quality, however restockers were particularly competitive on lighter types with a new saleyard record of 440.2c for light weight vealer steers, which averaged 415.8.2c/kg. Yearling steers were dominated by light weight northern consignments which sold to a top of 412.2c to restockers and averaged 360.4c, while yearling steers to feed topped at 341.2c/kg.

Some large lines of grown heifers attracted strong feeder interest and sold to 340.2 to average 311.7c/kg. Several pens of heavy unfinished bullocks were on offer, with the best heavy 3 score bullocks to slaughter selling to 301.2c, while heavy grown steers to feed sold to 345.2c to average 319.1c/kg. Medium weight steers and bullocks to feed sold 306c/kg. The offering of cows was more variable than previous weeks, resulting in fewer 3 and 4 score cows, with the best cows to slaughter topping at 259.2c, to average 251.4c, while heavy 2 score cows to slaughter sold to 254.2c/kg.  Western restockers were very active on medium and light weight cows, which sold to a record 286.2c, with many sales to 270.2c and averaging 237c/kg. Increased numbers of grown heifers to feed sold to 340.2c, averaging 331.7c while heavy heifers to slaughter sold to 291.2c/kg. An increased number of bulls were present, with plainer types dominating the offering. The few heavy 3 score bulls on offer to slaughter topped at 270.2c, while bulls to live export sold to 280.2c to average 266.6c/kg. The medium and lighter weight bulls mostly sold to feeder buyers, destined for live export, and sold for 303.2c/kg. Young males to restockers sold to 390.2c/kg. A continued good offering of cows and calves sold to a top of $1,800 for some very good quality pens, with most selling from $1,220 to $1,420/unit.

A larger yarding was penned at Charters Towers with values for almost all types improving under very good buyer support. The quality of the yarding was described as mixed as the quality of the bullocks below last weeks standard yet the penning of cows was of improved quality. 

The only description to suffer a loss was the small number of light steers. The 500 to 600kg bullocks improved over 10c to average 158.6c as the heavy bullocks reach a top of 163.2c/kg.

In large numbers, were the light D4 heifers, which sold to 144.5c and averaged 138.3c/kg. The improved line up of cows was met with very good demand with most improving over 7c/kg. As has been the case at other centres, the top of the cows was a heavy D4, which sold to 139.2c/kg. 

All weights of bulls were D1s with the top being heavy types reaching 140c/kg and returning $1,141/head.

A larger yarding was offered to a full panel of buyers. Quality was mixed, however most were plainer lines showing the signs of the current poor season.  Steers and cows dominated the yarding with no trade weights in the prime section of the sale. 

Light steers were in limited numbers as the better medium weights suited to the Korean market sold to 145c as a large line of plainer D2s averaged 130.1c/kg. Good heavy steers topped at 156.2c to average 146.3c/kg. Light export heifers were mainly plainer lines averaging around 113c/kg. 

The large numbers of cows sold to an improved market and this has been a similar trend at southern sales. Light D2s averaged 94.5c as medium weights sold to 115.2c/kg. The D3 medium weights average 112.9c/kg.

A larger yarding was offered to a full field of buyers. The trend of dearer prices has continued with only the plainest cows selling to a cheaper market. The yarding was dominated by steers and cows with only a small number of bulls yarded. 

Most of the light steers were showing the signs of the ongoing dry season to average around 114c/kg. There were some good medium weights included in the yarding and these averaged 145.6c as heavy weights sold to 155c/kg. A large number of medium weight D2s averaged 132.4c/kg. Most of the light export heifers averaged 91.2c with others selling to 117.2c/kg. 

Light D2 cows reached 109.2c as a pen of D3s sold for 119.2c/kg. The large supply of medium weight D3s improved 5c after selling to 122.2c to average 117.6c/kg. The top of the cows reached 126.2c/kg.

A larger yarding was offered and values followed a similar trend to previous weeks to be cheaper again for most grades. All the regular buyers were in attendance with the yarding predominately females. As has been the case, quality was once again mixed. 

Only a handful of light steers were penned as medium weights reached 150.2c/kg. A large number of heavy steers were offered averaging 140.1c after topping at 151.2c/kg. The leaner light export heifers sold to a cheaper market, while the D3s managed to improve 9c topping at 120c/kg. 

Almost all the cows were light and medium weights selling to a cheaper market as a small pen of heavy weights sold for 105c/kg. Light cows made to 85.2c as medium weights reached 99.2c/kg.

A larger yarding sold to the regular field of buyers who were all active. The mixed quality run saw better descriptions sell on a dearer trend while the plainer types continued to loose ground.  Competition was strong for most of the market however later sales were not as highly sought after. 

The large supply of light steers lost 14c and averaged 116.7c/kg although the cheaper trend can be attributed to the drop in quality. The better quality medium weights received gains and averaged 145.8c after they sold to a top of 151.2c/kg. Heavy weights experienced the greatest gains following the poor quality offerings of previous weeks and averaged 150.9c after the reached 154.2c/kg. 

Grown heifers mainly sold on a cheaper trend and a fair sample averaged 115c/kg.  The very light and poor quality cows received fair results and averaged 95.3c/kg. The medium weight cows that dominated the yarding sold firm to 3c cheaper and the D3s averaged 120.5c while the lighter quality descriptions averaged just under 110c/kg.  

The bull market continued to loose ground and the heavier bulls toped at 120c/kg.

A larger yarding of better quality sold to a larger field of buyers that saw processors purchasing stock along with local butchers. Good lines of steers and cows dominated the sale. There has been some storm activity in the area although sufficient rain for runoff is yet to be received 

The steer penning was dominated by D3 Korean weights that sold to 152.2c to average 143.8c/kg. Heavy weights averaged slightly dearer while the best bullocks sold to 160c/kg to return $1,080/head.

Mainly cows made up the balance of the penning and they sold at slightly cheaper rates. The lightweights topped at 106.3c to average just over 111c/kg. Medium weights topped at 128.2c to average close to 121c/kg. 

The medium and heavy weight bulls averaged from 134.9c to 137.8c/kg.

A larger yarding of 2,123 head were yarded by Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week, primarily due to improvement in weather conditions after the rain affected yarding the previous week. The yarding attracted some very good quality and well finished bullocks and cows, along with some very good small lines of vealer steers and heifers. Most of the regular processors were in attendance and operating with one notable absence, however restockers were active throughout the sale on suitable lines along with regular feeder buyers.

Vealer steers again attracted strong competition, with western restockers very dominant for the limited offering, topping at 383.2c, averaging 371.7c, with most sales above 360c/kg. Yearling steers were in good supply, with some very good quality steers to restockers topping at 350.2c, while light feeder steers made to 329.2c/kg. The small number of grown steers to restockers sold to 294.2c/kg. Vealer heifers were of mixed quality and the fewer number sold strongly to a top of 350.2c/kg. Yearling heifers sold to 320.2c to restockers, while those to feed sold to 310.2c/kg. A very good line of bullocks dominated the offering, with processors jostling pen for pen, with restockers active on lighter weights. Heavy 3 score bullocks topped at 290.2c, while restockers paid to 272.2c, while medium weight feeder types sold to 298.2c/kg.

Heavy 3 score cows were again in good supply with values improving 5c to  8c/kg on last sale, with medium weight 2 score cows holding firm on last week. Heavy 3 score cows topped at 258.2c, to average 242.6c, while heavy 2 score cows to slaughter sold to 247.2c, averaging 217.3c/kg. Medium weight 3 score cows sold to 222.2c, with lighter cows to restockers selling to 221.2c, to average 209.1c/kg. A good offering of heavy heifers to slaughter sold to 267.2c, with feeders were also active on suitable lines, topping at 300.2c/kg. A good selection of heavy 3 score bulls sold to 263.2c multiple times, while restockers paid to 264.2c/kg for breeding. Medium weight bulls to feed destined for live export, sold to 312.2c/kg. Light weight males to restockers sold to 389.2c for crossbred types, with many selling for 310c to 344.2c/kg. A good offering of cows and calves sold strongly, topping at $1,410, with most selling from $1,200 to $1,380/unit.

A larger yarding of 1,085 head was drawn by Charters Towers Combined Agents this week, with an improved quality yarding on the last sale. Cows dominated the prime section, with a large line from the Northern Gulf reflecting the improvement in season conditions in some areas across the yarding. Competition was strong from two of the three regular processors, supported by a southern processor and feeder buyer in conjunction with restockers operating throughout the sale. Cattle were drawn from Normanton, Greenvale, Hughenden, Prairie, Belyando, Guru and local areas.

Vealer steers were fewer in numbers, with restockers competing strongly on selected lines selling to top at 378.2c/kg. Yearling steers were mixed in quality and sold to 340.2c/kg for the few on offer. Vealer heifers were in high demand and sold to 310.2c/kg, with solid competition for many lines. Yearling heifers sold to a high of 310.2c/kg for some very good quality pens.  

The small number of bullocks sold to 252.2c/kg. The large number of cows sold to lower reduced rates in line with southern sales earlier in the week. Heavy 3 score cows fell by up to 30c, selling to a top of 218.2c, with many selling for 204c to 210c/kg. 2 score cows were well in demand and lifted in rates by up to 10c, selling to 209.2c, to average 197c/kg. An increased number of heavy bulls for slaughter sold to 232.2c, while bulls to live export sold to 236.2c for heavier bulls and 255.2c/kg for feeder types. A very good quality pen of cows and calves sold to $1,340, with other lines selling from $650 to $990/unit.

A larger yarding at Charters Towers was met with solid competition as values remained fully firm. With the single calf sale reaching 119.2c/kg, all the other cattle offered were export types. 

The low Australian dollar kept buyers active on all lines of steers with rises of 3c to 4c/kg being recorded. A pen of medium weight C3 steers sold for 161.2c as heavy C3 steers topped at 165.2c/kg. Heavy D1 bullocks weighing over 600kg topped the sale after reaching 174.6c/kg in pen lots. 

The light D1 cows sold to a top of 126.2c with the medium weight D1 cows were in the largest numbers and sold to 166.2c to average 147.5c/kg.  Heavy D3 bulls sold to 154.6c to return the vendor $1,228/head and average 147.6c/kg.

A larger number was offered to a full panel of buyers. Quality was of a lesser standard than previous weeks and there was only a handful of fair quality steers available. This contributed to values falling once again, however competition was not as strong as processors looked to lower rates. Steers were up to 18c cheaper though the better grades only eased 3c/kg. Heifers lost 25c and more in places while the cows ranged from 7c to 10c/kg lower. 

Light older steers peaked at 107.2c and the D2s averaged 93c/kg. Medium weight D3s sold to 135c and averaged 125.6c while a large number of D2s averaged 106.5c/kg. Heavy steers sold to 150.2c and over 120 D3s averaged 142.4c/kg. Poor conditioned heifers sold to a very weak market and averaged 58.6c while the best stock made to 120c and averaged 112.1c/kg. 

Light cows peaked at 93.2c and the D2s averaged 80.8c/kg. The medium weights were the largest numbers and made to 109.2c and 90 D3s averaged 101c/kg. Heavy cows reached 105c/kg. The bulls were mainly lightweight and of poorer quality. Only a handful sold over 100c/kg.

A large yarding of mainly local cattle was again offered as the season falls further. Quality is being impacted by the dry conditions with more plainer lines being yarded. Values were similar to other markets and have finished up mixed. 

Good medium weight steers reached an isolated 154.2c/kg. A large number of heavy weights averaged 145.9c as others sold to 150.2c/kg. Heavy bullocks made to 152.2c/kg. A fair supply of export heifers was penned with most selling around 106c, as the plainer lines averaged 90.9c/kg. 

Most of the cows yarded were light and medium weights. Light D2s sold to 116.2c as most lightweights ranged from 99c to 111.6c/kg. Medium weight D3s in large numbers averaged 118.5c as the D4s topped at 124.2c/kg. A single heavy cow sold for 128.2c/kg.

A large increase in supply saw 2,430 cattle yarded in Charters Towers this week, 1,156 more than last sale. Overall quality was generally good, however there were greater numbers of lesser quality prime cows and bulls on offer. All regular processors were in attendance and active on several lines of heavy prime cows and bullocks at easier rates to recent weeks, however light cows and heavy bulls sold to a dearer trend. Cattle were drawn from Normanton, Richmond, Ingham, Belyando, local and coastal areas.

Steer calves sold to similar rates as last sale, while vealer steers eased by 6c/kg for better quality types. Good quality vealer heifers to restockers increased by 18c/kg. Yearling steers saw quality related price changes, with steers above 330kg to feed improving 13c and suitable types to live export eased by 4c/kg. Increased numbers of grown steers to feed and background sold firm while heifers improved 4c/kg. Heavy bullocks to export processor eased by more than 20c, with plainer types selling firm on last week. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors eased 9c, however light cows to restockers lifted by more than 29c/kg. Heavy 3 score cows to processor averaged 23c lower and extra heavy cows eased by 20c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors lifted by 22c/kg.

Better quality steer calves sold to 308c and young vealer steers returning to the paddock sold to 308c to average 287c/kg. Light vealer heifers to restockers sold to 262c, with heifers above 200kg topping at 240c to average 236c/kg. Limited numbers of light yearling steers sold to 280c, averaging 261c, with steers above 330kg to restockers selling to 289c to average284c/kg. Heavy yearling steers above 400kg sold for 290c/kg. Yearling heifers returning to the paddock made to 250c to average 218c, while a large sample of 280kg to restockers average sold to and averaged 256c/kg. Heifers above 330kg to restockers sold to 256c for a similar average and heifers above 400kg to feed averaged 265c/kg.

Grown steers to feed sold to 288c to average more than 279c, with heavier types making to 297c to average 287c and suitable steers to live export sold for 290c/kg. Grown heifers to feed sold to 265c, averaging 253c, while a large sample to grass backgrounders sold to 250c, to average 223c/kg. Increased numbers of heavy bullocks to export processor sold generally lower, reaching 326c to average 315c, with plainer types selling firm to 282c to average 277c/kg. Lesser quality plain types averaged 250c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 172c to average 160c, with plainer light cows returning to grass selling higher, reaching 182c to average 139c/kg. Heavy 3 score cows to processor topped at 243c to average 239c, with lower yielding heavy cows averaging 226c/kg. Extra heavy cows sold to 259c to average 247c/kg.

Heavy bulls to processors topped at 320c to average 318c, with better quality plainer 2 score bulls averaged 290c/kg. Medium weight bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 282c to average 277c, while heavy bulls averaged 290c/kg.

A increase of 185 head this week saw numbers lift to 1,085 of cattle drawn by Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents, with a very mixed quality yarding penned. Demand was strong across most categories however, with prices lifting by 2 to 8c/kg for the better types.  All major processors were in attendance, although not all were active in the market, while two feeder buyers and several central and western restockers demonstrated their presence.  Cattle were drawn from Richmond, Ingham, Ayr, Woodstock, local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers were readily sought after and continued a stronger trend, averaging 372c, with active bidding for lighter types topping at 441c/kg. Yearling steers were few in number, with quality and age variable, while light yearling steers returning to the paddock averaged 366c and topped at 370c/kg. Those steers to feed reached 312c, to average 307c/kg. Many small lines of vealer heifers, also of variable quality, sold to 378c/kg, and most sold from 330c to 346c/kg.  Yearling heifers were short in supply, with those to feed averaging 270c and restocker sections to 340c/kg, averaging 307c/kg.

Bullocks were very limited in number and the highly variable quality attracted equivalent buyer interest, topping at 268c/kg.  Some heavy steers to feed sold to 308c/kg. Cows continued in line with recent sales, with heavy 3 score cows selling to 232c, averaging 225c, while heavy 2 score cows sold to 227c for an average of 216c/kg.  Restockers were particularly active on 1 and 2 score medium weight cows, selling to 227c and averaging 223c/kg.  A small number of heavy grown heifers to slaughter sold to 234c/kg. Bulls lifted up to 15c/kg on recent sales, primarily due to a live export order in the coming weeks.  Heavy 3 score bulls to slaughter sold to 226c, while medium weight bulls to feed averaged 243c and sold to 308c/kg.  Light males to restockers sold to 342c/kg. Some small lines of cows and calves sold to $1,360/unit.

A full panel of processors, local butchers and traders operated on a reduced quality yarding. As the persisting dry conditions continue, producers are wary of the weeks ahead and numbers were slightly up. Quality was average with increasing numbers of poor cattle offered.

Grown steers remained firm to average 128¢ for the light weights, medium C muscled types reached 155.2¢ with most sales at152.9¢/kg. The plainer lines of medium weights averaged 145.4¢, large numbers of heavy weight C2s sold mostly at 157.6¢ after topping at 163.2¢/kg. Heifers averaged 122.2¢ after reaching 130.2¢/kg.

Cow quality was down with the majority of the yarding consisting of light E muscled cattle. Plain, light cows averaged 78.6¢ while the heavier D muscled types made to 137.2¢ to average 132.7¢/kg. Bulls topped at 129.2¢/kg for the heavier lines.

A decreased yarding that saw a large amount of unfinished stocked penned sold to the regular field of buyers along with extra orders that allowed values to continue to increase. The current market environment saw more small lots being offered as producers took advantage of the increased values. Those cattle of better quality demanded the best prices.

Light steers realised a 5c/kg cheaper trend to average 155.6c/kg. Heavy bullocks and steers sold on a trend of 5c to 7c/kg dearer, with the best D3s reaching a top of 206.2c/kg. 

The heifer portion received mixed results with the D2s selling on a dearer trend of 16c while the D4s were slightly cheaper to average 169.7c/kg. The cow market was mainly firm to dearer with the best of the medium weights selling to 183.2c/kg to average $767/head. 

The bull market was also dearer with the heavy weights returning up to $1,760/head.

A decreased yarding on the back of some welcome rain across much of the region resulted in 945 cattle penned. Overall quality was good with one large line of PTIC cows dominating the prime section, supported a smaller offering of very good quality store cattle. One large processor was in attendance but did not operate while two other regular processors were absent. Backgrounder and feeder operators were mildly active along with spirited opportunity restockers.  

Averages improved in line with quality in most categories with young steers and heifers lifting 40-47c, cows to processors averaged 20c to 34c higher and bulls increased 11c/kg. Cattle were drawn from Croydon, Einasleigh, Hughenden, Greenvale, local and coastal areas.

A sample of very good quality weaned steers returning to grass sold to 644.2c to average 638c/kg while the female portion sold for 490.2c/kg. Yearling steers above 280kg to feed sold to 508.2c to average 495c/kg. A small sample of yearling heifers sold in line with quality. A reduced offering of grown steers above 400kg to feed sold to 418.2c to average near 380c and suitable steers to the trade sold to and averaged 420c/kg. There were insufficient grown heifers and bullocks to reliably quote. 

A large draft of mixed age PTIC cows returning to grass reached 338.2c to average 318-337c/kg. Medium weight 3 score cows to processors sold to 344.2c to average 320c and prime heavyweights also topped at 344.2c to average same. A small sample of heavy bulls to feed destined for live export topped at 346.2c to average 329c/kg. 

Mixed ages store conditioned cows with 1-10 month calves at foot sold for $2,360/unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

A decrease of 111 head to 2,059 cattle, were drawn by Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents this week with large lines of store cows dominating the offering. A subdued buying gallery was present with only three of the regular processors in attendance and operating, two recent feeder buyers absent and several restockers attending purely for observation. The large numbers of store cows saw values decrease by up to 15c/kg across all classes of cows, while bulls continued their recent cheaper trend. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Chillagoe, Richmond, Mt Garnet, Tully, Ingham, Bowen, Woodstock, local and coastal areas.

A reduced number of vealer steers met with subdued competition, with the best light weight steers, making 402c, with many small lines selling for 360c to 374c/kg. Yearling steers were of variable quality with many small and inconsistent pens selling to a cheaper trend. Steers, to feed sold to 338c, while light yearling steers to restockers sold to 374c/kg. Vealer heifers were also of variable quality and consistency, selling to 348c/kg to restockers. Yearling heifers consisted of some good light weight lines, supported by some good quality heavier types. Heifers to restockers sold to 342c, while a small number of heifers to feed sold to 318c/kg.

Some small lines of excellent quality, well finished bullocks to slaughter sold to 290c, while several smaller lines of 2 score bullocks to restockers sold to 271c/kg. Grown steers to feed were fewer in number and more variable in quality and sold to 288c/kg. A much larger yarding of cows were presented this week, with several lines of 1 and 2 score cows offered, along with some isolated lines of well finished 3 score cows. Processors showed selective interest in 4 score cows, selling to 253c, while 3 score cows to slaughter sold to 249c/kg. 2 score cows to slaughter sold to 244c, while 2 score cows to restockers sold to 245c/kg. One line of light PTIC cows to restockers sold to 201c, with most selling for 188c to 192c/kg. Some small lines of very good well finished bulls sold to 231c to slaughter, while medium weight bulls to feed sold to 217c/kg. Cows and calves were of mixed quality, many lines selling from $890 to $1,260, with the top price of $1,300/unit reached multiple times.

A considerably smaller yarding due to current isolated storms across most eastern parts of the state resulted in Charters Towers Combined Selling Agents presenting 716 cattle, 669 fewer than last sale. Prime cattle were of very mixed quality, with isolated pens of well finished types and several small lines showing the effects of the season. Two regular processors were absent, with the smaller prime offering shared between those in attendance, while one live exporter, opportunity feeder buyers and restockers competed for the store cattle. Cattle were drawn from Julia Creek, Pentland, Ingham, Ayr, Woodstock, local and coastal areas.

Vealer steers were in short supply and the plainer offering met mixed demand selling at similar prices to last sale, topping at 359c/kg. A smaller number of mixed quality yearling steers were generally 10c lower due to the offering, with feeder steers to live export selling to 287c and averaging 284c/kg. While steers returning to grass sold to 317c for lighter types with most selling from 274c to 295c/kg. A very good quality line of grown steers met select competition, heavy steers above 400kg sold to 266c to live export, with feeder weights to 274c, and similar steers returned to grass for 258c/kg. A small number of vealer heifers returning to grass averaged 10c lower, selling to 278c/kg, with one line failing to meet vendors reserve. Yearling heifers were also in short supply, with very mixed quality generally lower and those returning to grass selling to 240c/kg. A small number sold to live export, making to 274c/kg. Some good quality heavy grown heifers returning to grass sold to 264c, with feeder weights also destined for grass sold to 243c/kg. A line of PTIC heifers also failed to meet vendors reserve.

A mixed offering of bullocks were generally 1c to 3c lower, with one good line of heavy C3 bullocks to slaughter topping at 259c, and lesser quality types to feed selling to 255c, to average 225c/kg. Cows were of very mixed quality and weight, with only a small number of heavy slaughter cows. Heavy C muscled 3 score cows lifted by 6c to make 212c, while D muscled types sold to 200c, to average 197c/kg. Restockers were active on lighter cows lifting prices by 25c on last sale, to 190c, and light cows to slaughter sold to 155c/kg. A small offering of bulls was also of mixed quality with heavy bulls to slaughter selling to 242c, and similar types to feed selling to 240c/kg. Lighter bulls to restockers sold to 312c, to average 298c/kg. A small number of cows and calves sold to $1,110/unit.

A combined prime only sale resulted in 1,252 cattle penned 570 fewer than the comparable sale a fortnight ago. Quality was very mixed, with an increased supply of plain conditioned northern pastoral cows, however some very good quality local lines of well finished cows and grown steers were on offer. The regular buyer gallery operated at stronger rates throughout. Grown steers to the trade lifted 15c, bullocks improved 10c, heavy cows increased 12c and bulls to processors averaged 15c/kg higher. Cattle were drawn from Normanton, Georgetown, Hughenden, Torrens Ck, local and coastal areas.  

A small supply of yearling heifers less than 280kg to feed topped at 408c to average 387c, and heifers above 330kg to feed reached 416c to average 404c/kg. Heifers to backgrounders and restockers averaged 422c/kg. A good supply of heavy grown steers met strong demand with steers above 400kg to backgrounders reaching 396c/kg. Some excellent small lines of heavy 3 score trade steers averaged from 389c to 404c, while heavy 4 score trade steers topped at 414c/kg to average same. Good quality grown heifers to feed sold to 404c to average from 355c to 381c/kg. A small sample of heavy grown heifers to the trade made to 392c and averaged from 363c to 388c/kg.

A small number of heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 395c, to average the same. Processor demand for cows continues to be very strong. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 350c to average 338c and 3 scores reached 353c to average from 338c to 348c/kg. A good sample of prime heavy weight cows topped at 370c to average from 342c to 357c/kg. A large sample of prime heavy weight 4 score cows topped at a new saleyard record of 374c to average 362c/kg. A line of PTIC cows sold from 224c to 295c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors sold to 348c to average from 330c to 342c/kg.

A store sale scheduled for Friday has 3,700 cattle booked.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

A combined prime and store sale saw 2001 cattle penned.  Quality was mixed with a good supply of heavy prime cows and some very good quality young steers and heifers. A smaller buyer panel operated at reduced rates throughout including opportunity restockers who provided some valuable competition.  Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa to Georgetown and south to the local area.

Light steers to restockers sold to 366 with a good sample averaging 361c/kg. Similar heifers reached 258c to average 216c/kg. Yearling steers above 280kg to feed reached 300c to average 285c/kg. A good line of yearling heifers returning to the paddock sold to 306c to average 284c/kg. A greater supply of grown steers to feed made to 271c to average 268c/kg.  A small sample of grown heifers to the trade sold to 236c to average 223c/kg.

A mixed sample of heavy bullocks to export slaughter reached 264c to average 253c/kg.  Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 175c to average 170c and 3 scores topped at 206c to average 183c/kg.  A good sample of prime heavyweight cows topped at 195 to average 192c/kg.

Heavy bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 274c  to average 266c/kg.

Small pens of cows and calves sold from $1,000 to $1,125/unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

A combined prime and store sale attracted 3,046 mixed quality cattle. Some good lines of grown steers and prime cows were presented, along with good lines of store steers and heifers. The supply of lesser lines of northern pastoral continued. All regular processors were in attendance and operating at similar rates, with the regular gallery operating at softer rates than last week and notably there was no live export activity. Grown steers and heifers eased by 3c, bullocks fell 12c, medium weight cows eased 6c, while heavy cows to processors were firm to 4c higher and heavy bulls averaged up to 15c/kg lower. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa, Burketown, Normanton, Georgetown, Ingham, local and coastal areas.  

Light weight vealer steers returning to grass reached 602c to average 546c, with heavier types to feed averaging from 440c to 468c/kg. Vealer heifers to the trade topped at 480c to average near 453c/kg. A good sample of heifers returning to grass reached 572c, with most averaging between 456c and 492c/kg. Heavy yearling steers above 400kg returning to grass sold to 462c to average 452c/kg. A good supply of yearling heifers above 280kg to feed topped at 458c multiple times to average 392c/kg. Heifers to backgrounders and restockers sold to 414c to average 390c/kg.

A good supply of heavy grown steers met strong demand with heavy steers to the trade topping at 410c to average 386c and steers to feed reached 408c to average 360c/kg. Good quality grown heifers to the trade sold to 372c to average 332c and a small sample of grown heifers to feed made to 385c to average 342c/kg. A small number of heavy full-mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 388c, to average 370c/kg. Processor demand for cows continues to be very strong. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 306c to average 297c and 3 score cows reached 342c to average 336c/kg. A good sample of prime heavy weight cows topped at 346c to average 337c/kg. A sample of cows to feed reached 334c to average above 320c/kg. Heavy bulls to processors sold to 338c to average from 299c to 329c/kg.
