Market Reporter, Mick Kingham.

There was a slightly larger yarding today at Charters Towers, made up predominately of export types, with most grades losing value on the last sale.

Light steers sold on a firm trend while Jap Ox and those suited to the Korean market dropped in value from the previous sale. There were only a small number of heavy steers yarded that also followed a cheaper trend.

Heifers were in good numbers but sold at cheaper rates. Cows suffered the biggest falls with lighter weights losing as much as 29c/kg for the poorer muscled types. Medium weight cows topped at 126.2c/kg, after a drop of 15c that saw them average 118.8c/kg. Heavy cows were in very small numbers.

A small yarding of bulls topped at 131.2c, for heavy weights, losing 17c/kg on last sale.

A larger yarding saw all buyers present and active on a good quality cattle, however it was not quite up to the standard of previous markets. Cattle were drawn mainly from local areas, although some stock came from as far a field as Longreach and from north of Hughenden 

Steers and bullocks comprised the majority of the yarding. Light and heavy weights were cheaper while medium weights sold on a dearer trend. Lighter steers lost 7c averaging 168.4c/kg. Korean steers were in the largest numbers and sold 6c dearer after topping at 228.2c/kg. Heavy C3 steers were 5c cheaper averaging 227c/kg.

Good quality heifers sold 19c dearer while D muscled descriptions lost up to 10c/kg. The best C3 heifers sold to 200c/kg. Lightweight cows were in greater numbers and received mixed results although the large majority were firm on the rates of the previous sale. Medium weight D3s were slightly cheaper after selling to 191.2c while D2s were slightly dearer averaging 173.2c/kg. A small number of good heavy cows were offered topping at 207.2c/kg. 

Lighter bulls were in fair numbers and sold on a cheaper trend of 3c as a larger number of D1s averaged 154.5c/kg. A small number of heavy weights averaged close $1,400/head.

Numbers increased by 338 with 3247 cattle penned . Quality was good for the majority penned, consisting of more than 1100 cows, supported by some good heavy bullocks and prime yearlings and some larger lines of store steers and heifers. The buyer panel was similar to last sale with all operating including one live exporter, central backgrounders and opportunity restockers. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa to Georgetown, east to Tully and south to the local area.

Young steers and heifers to restockers lifted 15c to 35c, steers above 280kg lifted by up to 69c/kg. Grown steers and heifers improved by 8c to 40c, cows eased by 11c to 25c, bullocks were mostly firm and heavy bulls to live export lifted by up to 20c/kg.

Young weaned steers returning to the paddock averaged 280c reaching 306c for cross bred types, with similar heifers to processors selling to 244c to average 226c/kg. Light yearling steers to restockers made to 280c, to average 257c/kg. Yearling steers above 280kg to feed sold to 264c to average 257c and a good sample above 330kg to feed made to 270c to average 258c/kg. Good quality steers above 400kg to feed made to and averaged 304c/kg. A large sample of light yearling heifers to feed reached 228c to average 175c and feeder heifers above 280kg averaged 240c/kg. Good quality prime yearling heifers to processors topped at 270c to average 258c to 268c/kg.

Grown steers above 400kg to feed sold to 312c, most around 270c, steers suitable for live export made to 282c and heavy steers to the trade topped at 312c to average 298c/kg. An increased supply of heavy prime grown heifers reached 276c to average from 230c to 273c/kg. 

Heavy bullocks to export slaughter topped at 284c to average 251c to 259c and young bullocks to live export made to 308c to average 184c/kg.
A further lift in the supply of cows saw values ease on last week. Medium weight 2 score cows to processors sold to 220c to average 217c, 3 scores reached 248c to average from 227c to 236c and prime heavyweight cows topped at 252c to average from 232c to 244c/kg. Heavy bulls to live export made to 292c to average near 290c/kg and bulls to processors made from 224c to 292c/kg.

A small number of cows and calves sold from $700 to $1,020 per unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

Numbers increased by 147 head to 2,300 cattle in Charters Towers this week, with quality generally good. There were some very good small lines of store steer and heifers. Most prime cattle were in good condition, however many lines lacked weight compared to that of recent weeks. The regular buyer panel operated at similar rates to recent sales, supported by one live exporter and several opportunity restockers and backgrounders. Cattle were drawn from north of Mt Isa, Burketown, Cloncurry, Chillagoe, Georgetown, Ayr, Belyando, local and coastal areas.

Some very good lines of steer calves met enthusiastic buyer interest, improving by more than 20c/kg, while vealer steers to restockers sold similar to last sale. Heifer calves were in good supply, also selling to increased rates and a large sample of good quality vealer heifers improved by up to 13c/kg. Yearling steers were fewer in numbers and sold according to quality, with some good quality yearling heifers returning to grass selling higher. Grown steers to live export averaged 4c higher and grown heifers to the trade improved by 3c/kg. Heavy bullocks to export slaughter improved by 3c, while suitable types to live export improved by 4c/kg. Medium weight cows increased by up to 20c and heavy cows to processors lifted by up to 8c/kg.  Heavy bulls to live export sold to similar rates.

Good quality steer calves sold up to 301c to average 274c, while vealer steers sold up to 280c to average more than 270c/kg. A good line of heifer calves to restockers sold up to 200c, with a large sample averaging 197c and vealer heifers made up to 198c to average 179c/kg. Yearling steers to live export made up to 260c, with a large sample of lesser quality types to feed selling up to 222c to average 185c/kg. Grown steers to live export reached a top of 290c to average above 280c/kg. Yearling heifers returning to grass made 228c with suitable types to slaughter making 200c to average 191c/kg. Grown heifers to slaughter sold up to 248c to average above 235c/kg.  

Heavy bullocks to export slaughter sold up to 289c, averaging 280c and suitable types to live export made up to 288c to average 276c/kg. Medium weight 2 score cows reached a top of 183c to average 159c and good heavy 3 score cows sold up to 222c to average 212c/kg. A large sample of heavy 2 score cows sold up to 190c to average 172c/kg. A small number of heavy bulls to live export sold up to 291c, similar types to feed destined for live export mostly sold from 271c to 290c and medium weight bulls to live export made up to 286c/kg.  Young males returning to the paddock made up to 258c to average 254c/kg.

Numbers eased back from last weeks large yarding. Quality was not up to the standard of recent weeks and prices were much cheaper. All the regular buyers were in attendance. The steers were mostly 19c to 25c cheaper although the small number of better grades averaged 8c to 13c/kg lower. The heifers lost 20c to 24c while the light cows were 15c to 20c lower and the medium weights shed 24c to 29c/kg. Bulls lost up to 35c/kg. 

The small number of light steers mostly sold around 109c/kg. The medium weight steers of top quality were in very small numbers and reached 148.2c/kg. There was close to 270 D2s that averaged 116.9c while 230 D3s averaged 125.4c/kg. The heavy steers topped at 145c and the better grades averaged 143.3c while over 200 D3s averaged 129.2c/kg. Heavy bullocks sold to 142.2c/kg. 

The heifers reached 125.2c and the D3s averaged 115.3c/kg. There were 250 light cows of poor condition that averaged 82.2c/kg. It appears that many had just weaned calves and been sent directly to market. The medium weight cows felt the harshest blows of the week and close to 200 D3s averaged 112.8c after they reached 116.2c/kg. 

Light bulls averaged 85.7c while the heavy bulls reached 125.2c/kg.

Charters Towers Combined Agents yarded 2568 following no sale last week.  The yarding was dominated by a large single vendor line of lightweight northern weaners, supported by a limited number of prime bullocks and cows. Only  three regular processors were operating along with regular feeders, one live exporter and an increased number of opportunity restockers. Cattle weee drawn from Mt Isa, Croydon,, Georgetown and south to the local area.

Increased restocker competition saw light steers improve 25c to 50c, heavy steers and bullocks to processors improved 15c and prime cows were mostly firm.

Steers under 200 kg returning to the paddock averaged 262c, selling to a top of 276c, steers above 200kg made to 262c to average 245c/kg.  Similar heifers under 200kg returning to the paddock sold to 132c to average 127c/kg. Heifers above 200kg averaged 121c/kg, while those to the trade averaged 123c/kg.  Small mixed quality lines of yearling steers sold according to quality. Steers above 280kg to feed reached 218c to average 171c to 189c/kg. Yearling heifers to feed made to 136c to average 127c, heifers above 330kg sold to 158c to average 126c/kg.  A small sample of grown steers to live export averaged 170c/kg.  A large sample of grown heifers to processors sold to 155c for an improved average of 150c/kg.

Heavy full mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 190c, most sales 164c to 172c, a small sample to live export made 168c/kg. Medium weightlifting 3 score cows sold to 159c to average 140c, prime heavyweight cows topped at 190c to average 164c/kg.  Heavy bulls to live export made to 202c to average 178c/kg, processor bulls averaged from 130c to 180c/kg.

A small number of cows and calves made to $850 per unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham

A slightly reduced yarding of cattle was mostly drawn from the Ingham district with local lines in limited supply. All the local buyers and regular export buyers were operating. Quality was not as good as recent weeks with more tail end drafts coming forward. 

Good medium weight grown steers averaged 176.3c after topping at 188.2c/kg. Heavy steers reached 190.2c with the limited number averaging 187.4c/kg. Grown C3 heifers averaged 157.2c, as plainer D2s sold closer to 128c/kg. 

Cows dominated the yarding with most being lightweights. Light D2s averaged 135.8c as the D3s reached 165.2c/kg. Medium weight D3s averaged 158.8c as both medium and heavy cows reached 174.2c/kg. Most of the good bulls were C2 medium and heavy weights, which sold to 162.2c/kg to return over $1,300/head.

A slightly larger yarding attracted very strong competition from all the regular buyers. The quality was on a par with that of last week with values lifting further for a majority of the cattle. As has been the case at other centers, a fair percentage of the yarding was lighter weights. 

The really good quality steers and bullocks were made up of a large run from near Clermont. Medium weight steers were firm to slightly dearer as those suited to the Korean market averaged 214.5c/kg. All of the heavy steers and bullocks returned over $1,100/head with the better steers averaging close to 232c after selling to 237.2c/kg. 

The light heifers sold to a mixed market with the plainer categories loosing up to 6c/kg. A large number of light cows averaged 157.2c while the D3s reached 195.2c/kg.  Medium weight cows sold to 208.2c as the D3s averaged 187.7c/kg. 

The light bulls made to 168.2c as a heavy weight reached 199.2c/kg.
